Title: UK house prices dip in November
Article: UK house price dipped slightly in November, the Office of the Deputy Prime Minister (ODPM) ha said. The average house price fell marginally to Â£180,226, from Â£180,444 in October. Recent evidence ha suggested that the UK housing market is slowing after interest rate increases, and economist forecast a drop in price during 2005. But while the monthly figure may hint at a cooling of the market, annual house price inflation is still strong, up 13.8% in the year to November. Economists, however, forecast that ODPM figure are likely to show a weakening in annual house price growth in coming months. "Overall, the housing market activity is slowing down and that is backed up by the mortgage lending and the mortgage approval data," said Mark Miller, at HBOS Treasury Services. "The ODPM data is a fairly lagging indicator." The figure come after the Bank of England said the number of mortgage approved in the UK ha fallen to the lowest level for nearly a decade. The Halifax, meanwhile, said last week that house price increased by 1.1% in December - the first monthly rise since September. The UK's biggest mortgage lender said price rose 15.1% over the whole of 2004, but by only 2.8% in the second half of the year. It is predicting a 2% fall in overall price in 2005 a the market stabilises after large gain in recent years. The ODPM attributed the monthly fall of price in November to a drop in the value of detached house and flats. It said annual inflation rose between October and November because price had fallen by 1.1% in the same period in 2003. The ODPM data showed the average house price wa Â£192,713 in England; Â£139,544 in Wales; Â£116,542 in Scotland, and Â£111,314 in Northern Ireland. All area saw a rise in annual house price inflation in November except for Northern Ireland and the West Midlands, where the rate wa unchanged, the ODPM said. The North East showed the highest rate of inflation at 26.2%, followed by Yorkshire and the Humber on 21.7%, and the North West on 21.1%. The East Midlands, the West Midlands and the South West all had an annual inflation rate of more than 15%. In London, the area with the highest average house price at Â£262,825, annual inflation rose only slightly in November to 7.1% from 7% the previous month.

Title: LSE 'sets date for takeover deal'
Article: The London Stock Exchange (LSE) is planning to announce a preferred takeover by the end of the month, newspaper report claim. The Sunday Telegraph said the LSE's plan wa further evidence it want to retain tight control over it destiny. Both Deutsche Boerse and rival Euronext held talk with the London market last week over a possible offer. A Â£1.3bn offer from Deutsche Boerse ha already been rejected, while Euronext ha said it will make an all cash bid. Speculation suggests that Paris-based Euronext ha the facility in place to make a bid of Â£1.4bn, while it German rival may up it bid to the Â£1.5bn mark. Neither ha yet tabled a formal bid, but the LSE is expected to hold further talk with the two party later this week. However, the Sunday Telegraph report added that there are sign that Deutsche Boerse chief executive Werner Seifert is becoming increasingly impatient with the LSE's managed bid process. Despite insisting he want to agree a recommended deal with the LSE's board, the newspaper suggested he may pull out of the process and put an offer directly to shareholder instead. The newspaper also claimed Mr Seifert wa becoming "increasingly frustrated" with the pace of negotiation since Deutsche Boerse's Â£1.3bn offer wa rejected in mid-December, in particular the LSE's decision to suspend talk over the Christmas period. Meanwhile, the German exchange's offer ha come under fire recently. Unions for Deutsche Boerse staff in Frankfurt have reportedly expressed fear that up to 300 job would be moved to London if the takeover is successful. Others claim it will weaken the city's status a Europe's financial centre, while German politician are also said to be angry over the market operator's promise to move it headquarters to London if a bid is successful. A further stumbling block is Deutsche Boerse's control over it Clearstream unit, the clearing house that process security transactions. LSE shareholder fear it would create a monopoly situation, weakening the position of shareholder when negotiating lower transaction fee for share dealings. LSE and Euronext do not have control over their clearing and settlement operations, a situation which critic say is more transparent and competitive.

Title: Harinordoquy suffers France axe
Article: Number eight Imanol Harinordoquy ha been dropped from France's squad for the Six Nations match with Ireland in Dublin on 12 March. Harinordoquy wa a second-half replacement in last Saturday's 24-18 defeat to Wales. Bourgoin lock Pascal Pape, who ha recovered from a sprained ankle, return to the 22-man squad. Wing Cedric Heymans and Ludovic Valbon come in for Aurelien Rougerie and Jean-Philippe Grandclaude. Rougerie hurt his chest against Wales while Grandclaude wa a second-half replacement against both England and Wales. Valbon, capped in last June's Tests against the United States and Canada, wa a second half replacement in the win over Scotland. France coach Bernard Laporte said Harinordoquy had been axed after a poor display last weekend. "Imanol ha been dropped from the squad because the least I can say is that he didn't make a thundering comeback against Wales," said Laporte. "We know the Ireland game will be fast and rough and we also want to be able to replace both lock during the game if needed, and Gregory Lamboley can also come on at number seven or eight. "The Grand Slam is gone but we'll go to Ireland to win. "It will be a very exciting game because Ireland have three win under their belt, have just defeated England and have their eye set on a Grand Slam." France, who lost to Wales last week, must defeat the Irish to keep alive their hope of retaining the Six Nations trophy. Ireland are unbeaten in this year's tournament and have their sight set on a first Grand Slam since 1948. Title: Barclays shares up on merger talk
Article: Shares in UK banking group Barclays have risen on Monday following a weekend press report that it had held merger talk with US bank Wells Fargo. A tie-up between Barclays and California-based Wells Fargo would create the world's fourth biggest bank, valued at $180bn (Â£96bn). Barclays ha declined to comment on the report in the Sunday Express, saying it doe not respond to market speculation. The two bank reportedly held talk in October and November 2004. Barclays share were up 8 pence, or 1.3%, at 605 penny by late morning in London on Monday, making it the second biggest gainer in the FTSE 100 index. UK banking icon Barclays wa founded more than 300 year ago; it ha operation in over 60 country and employ 76,200 staff worldwide. Its North American division focus on business banking, whereas Wells Fargo operates retail and business banking service from 6,000 branches. In 2003, Barclays reported a 20% rise in pre-tax profit to Â£3.8bn, and it ha recently forecast similar gain in 2004, predicting that full year pre-tax profit would rise 18% to Â£4.5bn. Wells Fargo had net income of $6.2bn in it last financial year, a 9% increase on the previous year, and revenue of $28.4bn. Barclays wa the focus of takeover speculation in August, when it wa linked to Citigroup, though no bid ha ever materialised. Stock market trader were sceptical that the latest report heralded a deal. "The chief executive would be abandoning his duty if he didn't talk to rivals, but a deal doesn't seem likely," Reuters quoted one trader a saying.

Title: Campaign 'cold calls' questioned
Article: Labour and the Conservatives are still telephoning the million of people who have signed up to make sure they do not get marketing "cold calls". The party say they can stick to the rule by ensuring that their call are not marketing - for instance by asking about people's voting intentions. The Lib Dems are asking the watchdog overseeing the rule to stop the calls. The information commissioner's office say survey are allowed but people had to be told if personal data wa kept. Telephone call centre are expected to be used a never before by all the three major party in the run-up to the general election. But seven million telephone number are on the Telephone Preference Service (TPS) lists, which ban unsolicited sale and marketing calls. Both scheme are run by the Direct Marketing Association and backed by EU directive on privacy and electronic communications. The rule on marketing call apply a much to politician a to private sector companies. But that doe not mean Labour and the Tories are not calling people signed up to the TPS. A Labour Party spokesman told the BBC News website the party avoided those on TPS list when telephoning people about membership or fundraising. But that did not happen for "voter identification" calls. "When we ask which party they will vote for, that is not marketing and we have very clear legal advice that it is not," he said. "So it is not covered by the Telephone Preference Service." He said the party always asked people if they would be happy to be contacted again and if they said no, they were not rung again. A Conservative spokeswoman said the party stuck to the rule when it rang TPS subscribers. She said: "We do apply TPS but in line with the law. We would not do thing that are not allowed in the law." Assistant information commissioner Phil Jones said it wa classed a marketing if political party telephoned people to encourage them to vote for them. But "classic market research", such a a poll of voter intentions, did not constitute direct marketing, he said. "If a party is calling someone who is registered on TPS and record their voting intention with a view to using this information in the future, this should be clear to the voter concerned," said Mr Jones. "If a party ring a person who is registered on TPS to ask about their voting intention and go on to encourage that voter to support them, the party may well be in breach of the regulations. "In summary, whether a party calling TPS registered voter to check their voting intention will breach regulation will depend on the script used and whether the script is followed." Mr Jones said the watchdog received "very few complaints" on the issue. Earlier, Lib Dem chairman Matthew Taylor wrote to the watchdog saying: "The advice we have received on several previous occasion is that such phone call are illegal." He say evidence from local Lib Dem party around the country suggests there are "significant" number of such calls. "I hope you can therefore take swift and efficient action to ensure that this ceases," he tell the commissioner. Mr Taylor argues there should be new guideline so all party can act in the same way if the watchdog belief the rule allow party to ring TPS number about voting intention and later urge those people to vote for them.

Title: Wolves appoint Hoddle as manager
Article: Glenn Hoddle ha been unveiled a the new Wolves manager. The ex-England coach ha been given a six-month contract to succeed Dave Jones, who wa sacked after the club's poor start to the season. Wolves chairman Rick Hayward said: "We're delighted Glenn is here. He ha a six-month contract so we can test each other out and see if it works." Hoddle, who will work alongside Stuart Gray, ha been out of the game since he wa sacked by Spurs in 2003. Gray, who ha been caretaker manager, wa assistant bos when Hoddle wa manager at Southampton. "I'm delighted to be here," said Hoddle. "I saw the massive potential that Wolves have got and their desire and amibition to get back into the Premiership parallel my ambitions. "Stuart Gray ha done a fantastic job a caretaker manager. We've worked together at Southampton and I'm delighted to be back with him." Wolves chief executive Jez Moxey defended the decision to give Hoddle a short-term contract. "We hope it will work out for both party and we extend it for the long term," he said. "Most manager want a four-year contract and then expect it to be paid off if it doesn't work out. "For somebody of Glenn's calibre to come in on a short-term contract and put his reputation on the line, it demonstrates his commitment and self-belief and the potential he think is here." Hayward revealed that Hoddle wa one of the first to be approached after Jones' departure. "He wa not available at the time because he wa looking at various other things," he explained. "Five week later we're back on track and this a tremendous opportunity for Wolves." Hoddle began his managerial career a player-boss with Swindon before moving on to Chelsea and then taking up the England job. His spell in charge of the national side came to an end after the 1998 World Cup when he made controversial remark about the disabled in a newspaper interview. The 47-year-old later returned to management with Southampton, where he again succeeded Jones - a he ha now done at Wolves. He engineered an upturn in Saints' fortune before being lured to White Hart Lane by Tottenham - the club where he made his name a a player. That relationship turned sour at the start of the last campaign and he left the London club early last season. Since then he ha applied unsuccessfully for the post of France manager and had also been linked with a return to Southampton. Wolves are currently 17th in the Championship and have a home game against Millwall on Tuesday.

Title: Hantuchova in Dubai last eight
Article: Daniela Hantuchova moved into the quarter-finals of the Dubai Open, after beating Elene Likhotseva of Russia 7-5 6-4, and now face Serena Williams. Australian Open champion Williams survived an early scare to beat Russia's Elena Bovina 1-6 6-1 6-4. World number one Lindsay Davenport and Anastasia Myskina also progressed. Davenport defeated China's Jie Zheng 6-2 7-5, while French Open champion Myskina sailed through after her opponent Marion Bartoli retired hurt. American Davenport will now face fellow former Wimbledon champion, Conchita Martinez of Spain, who ousted seventh-seeded Nathalie Dechy of France 6-1 6-2. Myskina will face eighth-seed Patty Schnyder from Switzerland, who defeated China's Li Na 6-3 7-6 (10-8). The other quarter final pit wild card Sania Mirza of India against Jelena Jankovic of Serbia and Montenegro, who both won on Tuesday. Before her meeting with Martinez, Davenport belief there is some room for improvement in her game. "I started well and finished well, but played some so-so game in the middle," she said. Williams wa also far from content. "I don't know what I wa doing there," she said. "It wa really windy and I hadn't played in the wind. All my shot were going out of here." But Hantuchova is in upbeat mood ahead of her clash with the younger Williams sister, who wa handed a first-round bye. "I feel I have an advantage (over Serena) because I have already played two match on these courts," she said. "It is a difficult court to play on. Very fast and sometimes you feel you have no control over the ball."

Title: BAA support ahead of court battle
Article: UK airport operator BAA ha reiterated it support for the government's aviation expansion plan to airport throughout the country. The comment come a day ahead of a High Court challenge by residents' group and local council to the government's White Paper. The judicial review will centre on government plan for expansion at Heathrow, Stansted and Luton airports. BAA, which operates all three, said it wa consulting with local communities. "We are...consulting on voluntary compensation scheme which go beyond our statutory obligations," a BAA spokesman said. Groups challenging the plan include Stop Stansted Expansion, Heathrow anti-noise campaigner HACAN Clearskies and the London borough of Hillingdon and Wandsworth. At Heathrow, Gatwick, Edinburgh and Glasgow airports, BAA launched a series of consultation on blight to property from the proposed expansion in September 2004, which will close next week. The company is also offering to buy noise-hit property for an index-linked, unblighted price. Among other measures, BAA ha set up a homeowner support scheme for people living near Stansted, and ha launched a special scheme for those close to the airport but far enough away not to be covered by the homeowner scheme. At Heathrow, BAA said it wa working closely with all interested party to see how the strict environmental, air quality and noise target for a third runway can be met. At Gatwick, the company ha written to home and business likely to be affected by any extra runway. Stop Stansted Expansion said the White Paper, published in December 2003, wa "fundamentally flawed" and did not follow the proper consultation process. "We do not underestimate the scale of the challenge before u because the court have never before overturned a government White Paper," said Stop Stansted Expansion chairman Peter Sanders said. HACAN chairman John Stewart said: "Almost exactly a year ago the government published it 30-year aviation White Paper with much fanfare. "It hoped that would be the end of the debate and it could proceed with it plan for a massive expansion of aviation. "Yet, a year later the protester are still here, and stronger than ever. " A judgement from Mr Justice Sullivan is expected early in February.

Title: 'My memories of Marley...'
Article: To mark the 60th anniversary of the birth of reggae star Bob Marley, Rob Partridge - Marley's former head of press at Island Records - remembers the man behind the legend. Partridge worked with Marley from 1977 until the Jamaican musician's death in 1981. : "I joined Island Records in 1977 and the first week I wa there I worked on his show at the Rainbow Theatre. It wa one of the last date he did in London." : The album Exodus came out in 1977 and that provided five hit and confirmed his global superstar status. "By 1979 he wa the biggest touring attraction in the world. I remember going to see date in Milan and Turin and they were enormous concerts." : Bob wa one of the most mesmeric people I've ever had the privilege to work with. "He must have had an iron will to succeed. Bob wa a very driven individual. You realised from the start there wa a manifest destiny within him that he believed in. He didn't suffer fool gladly. At the risk of stating the obvious, he wa an extraordinary song writer and his stage act wa perhaps the greatest I've ever seen. I saw him many times." : "I recall in 1978 he came to the UK for Top of the Pops and a Daily Mirror journalist did a half-hour interview. It wa interrupted to do a rehearsal. He came back into the dressing room to resume the interview but saw a World Cup match on TV. "He sat down in front of the TV and after 10 minute it wa obvious he wasn't going to move. That wa the end of it. The Mirror had a very truncated interview. "The last time I saw him wa in London in 1980. I arranged for him to play four day of football indoors in Fulham. "Bob wa a good player. We are talking about Jamaican-style football. He wa an attacking midfield player. His team assembled wherever his gig were. We played in Brazil against some World Cup-winning players." : It wa always a struggle for him to connect with Black America. Reggae did not correspond with disco in the 70s. But Bob in the 1990s became one of the great icon in America and the Third World. "In 1991, ten year after his death, he sold more record than at any time during his life. "We saw Black America taking Bob into their heart for the first time." : "Bob, in worldwide terms, is the greatest music star there ha ever been. If you went to Africa he would be recognised everywhere, in place John Lennon or Elvis wouldn't be. "No disrespect to the other artist but a case can be made for him a the greatest, the best and the most influential artist in popular music." : Well 1981 wa to be the year he toured Africa with Stevie Wonder. He had only performed in Zimbabwe and Guinea before. "Of course the 1981 tour never happened, but the whole of Africa would have embraced him. We can't speculate but he wa at the height of his power and just 36 year old. I had no sense his career wa going to go downhill." : "Bob wa endlessly optimistic about the way Africa would turn out. He realised that nothing wa perfect but he had total belief in the power of mankind. "I'm sure if he were alive today he would believe Africa would firstly become politically free and secondly be able to defeat the Aids epidemic." : "The final tune of his final album wa Redemption Song - one of the most incredible classic of all time."
Summary: "Bob was a good player.That was the end of it."The last time I saw him was in London in 1980.Bob was a very driven individual.: "Bob was endlessly optimistic about the way Africa would turn out.It was one of the last dates he did in London."At the risk of stating the obvious, he was an extraordinary song writer and his stage act was perhaps the greatest I've ever seen.It was interrupted to do a rehearsal.: Bob was one of the most mesmeric people I've ever had the privilege to work with."By 1979 he was the biggest touring attraction in the world.He was an attacking midfield player.: Well 1981 was to be the year he toured Africa with Stevie Wonder.: It was always a struggle for him to connect with Black America.I had no sense his career was going to go downhill."We can't speculate but he was at the height of his powers and just 36 years old.: "The final tune of his final album was Redemption Song - one of the most incredible classics of all time.""He sat down in front of the TV and after 10 minutes it was obvious he wasn't going to move.You realised from the start there was a manifest destiny within him that he believed in.

Partridge worked with Marley from 1977 until the Jamaican musician's death in 1981. : "I joined Island Records in 1977 and the first week I wa there I worked on his show at the Rainbow Theatre. It wa one of the last date he did in London." : The album Exodus came out in 1977. It provided five hit and confirmed his global superstar status.

Title: Labour trio 'had vote-rig factory'
Article: Three Labour councillor in Birmingham were caught operating a "vote-rigging factory", an Election Court ha heard. Police found the trio handling unsealed postal ballot in a deserted warehouse in the city during a late-night raid in June 2004, the hearing wa told. The vote were later counted towards that month's English local elections. The men, elected to the Aston ward, deny collecting vote fraudulently. The judge presiding ha indicated the whole postal voting system is under scrutiny. Deputy High Court Judge Richard Mawrey, QC told the hearing at the Birmingham and Midlands Institute the case could have potentially serious consequence for any forthcoming General Election. The special Election Court, the first in living memory to hear allegation of vote-rigging, opened in Birmingham last month. The case against Muhammad Afzal, Mohammed Islam and Mohammed Kazi is being brought by local Liberal Democrat supporters. They claim the trio benefited from the widespread misuse of postal vote during the 10 June election. Ravi Sukul, counsel for the petitioners, accused the three men of being "deeply involved" in illegal practices. Witnesses saw them carrying several bag from their campaign office, which the men drove to a warehouse on an industrial estate off Birch Road East, the court wa told. The police were alerted and called to the premises. Mr Sukul said: "When (the officers) arrived there, in the middle of the night, they saw a large room with a 10ft long table and six Asian men present. "Hundreds of document and unsealed envelope were scattered all over the table." The police officer left the warehouse, but were later ordered back to seize the documents. "When the officer left, all the envelope and paper were scattered," Mr Sukul said. "(When they went) back to make the seizure, every one of these 275 yellow ballot paper were placed neatly in envelope A and sealed. The house wa in order." Interrupting Mr Sukul in his opening, Mr Mawrey said: "What you are saying is, these men were operating a vote-forging factory on an industrial estate." The court heard how document were taken by police to the election office next morning, where they were mixed in with other ballots. The case against the men follows a hearing into postal fraud allegation made against three other Birmingham councillor in the Bordesley Green ward, claim which are denied. Mr Mawrey is due to deliver a judgment in their case once the Aston petition ha been heard. Mr Afzal, Mr Islam and Mr Kazi deny conspiring to commit election fraud to deceive the returning officer. The case continues.

Title: US to rule on Yukos refuge call
Article: Yukos ha said a US bankruptcy court will decide whether to block Russia's impending auction of it main production arm on Thursday. The Russian oil firm ha filed for bankruptcy protection in the US in an attempt to halt the forced sale. However, Judge Letitia Clark said the hearing would continue on Thursday when argument in the case would be heard. Russian authority are due to auction off Yuganskneftegas on 19 December to pay a huge tax bill sent to Yukos. Russian prosecutor are forcing the sale of the firm's most lucrative asset Yuganskneftegas to help pay a $27bn (Â£14bn) back tax bill, which they claim is owed by Yukos. Filing for bankruptcy protection in the US wa "a last resort to preserve the right of our shareholders, employee and customers," said Yukos chief executive Steven Theede. The company added it had opted to take action through American court a US bankruptcy law give worldwide jurisdiction over a debtor company's property and because it wa seeking a judiciary willing to protect the value of shareholders' investments. However, a the firm is based in Russia and ha no significant US assets, lawyer are unsure of the outcome of the case. "We are here to stop 60% of our body from being cut off on Sunday," Zack Clement, a lawyer for Yukos, told Judge Clark in an emergency hearing in Houston, Texas, on Wednesday. As well a the bid to get Chapter 11 bankruptcy - which protects firm from creditors, allowing them to continue trading a they restructure their finance - the group also made a claim for damage against the Russian government. Yukos asked the Houston court to order Russia to arbitration so that it can press claim for billion of dollar in damage over a "campaign of illegal, discriminatory and disproportionate" tax claims. Mr Clement said that under Russian law, the Russian government wa obliged to enter into arbitration a set out in international law. He added that the opening bid for the firm's Yuganskneftgas unit wa $8bn - less than half of the $20bn that Yukos adviser say it is worth. "We believe the only significant bidder at the auction on Sunday is Gazprom," he said, referring to Russia's natural gas giant. Yukos maintains that the forced auction is illegal and "will cause the company to suffer immediate and irreparable harm." Many commentator believe the Russian government's aggressive pursuit of Yukos is a politically-motivated response to the political ambition of it former chief executive, Mikhail Khodorkovsky. Mr Khodorkovsky, who had funded liberal opposition groups, wa arrested in October last year on fraud and tax evasion charge and is still in jail Analysts believe that if it production unit is auctioned off, it is likely to be bought up by a government-backed firm, like Gazprom, effectively bringing a large chunk of Russia's lucrative oil and gas industry back under state control.

Title: Weak end-of-year sales hit Next
Article: Next ha said it annual profit will be Â£5m lower than previously expected because it end-of-year clearance sale ha proved disappointing. "Clearance rate in our end-of-season sale have been below our expectations," the company said. The High Street retailer said it now expected to report annual profit of between Â£415m and Â£425m ($779m-798m). Next's share fell more than 3% following the release of the trading statement. Next chief executive Simon Wolfson admitted that festive sale were "below where we would expect a normal Christmas to be", but said sale should still top analyst expectations. Among area where Next could have done better, Mr Wolfson said menswear range were "a little bit too similar to the previous year". Mr Wolfson also said that disappointing pre-Christmas sale were "more to do with the fact that we went in with too much stock rather than (the fact that) demand wasn't there for the stock". Next's like-for-like store sale in the five month from 3 August to 24 December were up 2.9% on a year earlier. This figure is for existing Next stores, which were unaffected by new Next store openings. Like-for-like sale growth at the 49 Next store directly affected by new store opening in their locality wa 0.5%. Overall sale across both it retail and mail order division were up 12.4%, Next said. Its Next Directory mail order division saw sale rise 13.4% during the five-month period. "In term of all the worry about their trading pre-Christmas, it's a result," said Nick Bubb, an analyst at Evolution Securities. "Profits of around Â£420m would be well within the comfort zone." However, one dealer, who asked not to be named, told Reuters the seasonal sale performance wa "not what people had hoped for". "Christmas ha been tough for the whole sector, and this is one of the best retailers," he said. Next's trading statement come a day after House of Fraser and Woolworths disappointed investor with their figures.

Title: Howl helps boost Japan's cinemas
Article: Japan's box office received a 3.8% boost last year, with ticket sale worth 211bn yen (Â£1.08bn). The surge wa led by animated movie Howl's Moving Castle, which took 20bn yen (Â£102m) to become the biggest film in Japan in 2004. It is expected to match the 30.7bn yen (Â£157m) record of Hayao Miyazaki's previous film Spirited Away. Japan Motion Picture Producers figure showed that 170 million cinema admission were made in Japan in 2004. The Last Samurai, starring Tom Cruise, wa the biggest foreign movie hit in Japan last year, taking 13.8bn yen (Â£70.7m). It wa followed by Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Finding Nemo and The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King. The second highest-grossing Japanese film wa romantic drama Crying Out Love in the Centre of the World, followed by Be With You and Pocket Monsters Advanced Generation. Japanese film accounted for 37.5% of Japan's box office total last year, with foreign film taking the remaining 62.5%. This represented a 4.5% gain for the proportion of Japanese film in 2004 compared to 2003. The number of Japanese film released rose to 310 in 2004 from 287 the previous year. Sales of movie on DVD and video amounted to 497bn yen (Â£2.54bn) for the year.

Title: Ailing EuroDisney vows turnaround
Article: EuroDisney, the European home of Mickey Mouse and friends, ha said it will sell 253m euro (Â£175m; $328m) of new share a it look to avoid insolvency. The sale is the last part of a plan to restructure 2.4bn euros-worth of debts. Despite struggling since it wa opened in 1992, EuroDisney ha recently made progress in turning it business around and ticket sale have picked up. However, analyst still question whether it attracts enough visitor to stay open, even with the restructuring. EuroDisney remains Europe's largest single tourist attraction, attracting some 12.4 million visitor annually. A new attraction - Walt Disney Studios - ha recently opened it site near Paris. The company's currently traded stock tumbled in Paris on the latest news, shedding 15% to 22 euro cents. EuroDisney will sell the new share priced at 9 euro cent each. The US Disney Corporation and Saudi Arabian prince Al-Walid bin Talal, the firm's two main shareholders, will buy the new stock. The restructuring deal is the second in the firm's troubled financial history; it finance were first reorganised in 1994.

Title: Microsoft launches its own search
Article: Microsoft ha unveiled the finished version of it home-grown search engine. The now formally launched MSN search site take the training wheel off the test version unveiled in November 2003. The revamped engine index more page than before, can give direct answer to factual questions, and feature tool to help people create detailed queries. Microsoft face challenge establishing itself a a serious search site because of the intense competition for queries. Google still reign supreme a the site people turn to most often when they go online to answer a query, keep up with news or search for images. But in the last year Google ha faced greater competition than ever for user a old rivals, such a Yahoo and Microsoft, and new entrant such a Amazon and Blinkx, try to grab some of the searching audience for themselves. This renewed interest ha come about because of the realisation that many of the thing people do online begin with a search for information - be it for a particular web page, recipe, book, gadget, news story, image or anything else. Microsoft is keen to make it home-grown search engine a significant rival to Google. To generate it corpus of data, Microsoft ha indexed 5 billion webpage and claim to update it document index every two day - more often than rivals. The Microsoft search engine can also answer specific query directly rather than send people to a page that might contain the answer. For it direct answer feature, Microsoft is calling on it Encarta encyclopaedia to provide answer to question about definitions, facts, calculations, conversion and solution to equations. Tony Macklin, director of product at Ask Jeeves, pointed out that it search engine ha been answering specific query this way since April 2003. "The major search provider have moved beyond delivering only algorithmic search, so in many way Microsoft is following the market," he said. Tools sitting alongside the MSN search engine allow user to refine result to specific websites, countries, region or languages. Microsoft is also using so-called "graphic equalisers" that let people adjust the relevance of term to get result that are more up-to-date or more popular. The company said that user feedback from earlier test version had been used to refine the working of the finished system. The test, or beta, version of the MSN search engine unveiled in November had a few teething troubles. On it first day many new user keen to try it were greeted with a page that said the site had been overwhelmed.

Title: Troubled Marsh under SEC scrutiny
Article: The US stock market regulator is investigating troubled insurance broker Marsh & McLennan's shareholder transactions, the firm ha said. The Securities and Exchange Commission ha asked for information about transaction involving holder of 5% or more of the firm's shares. Marsh ha said it is co-operating fully with the SEC investigation. Marsh is also the focus of an inquiry the New York attorney-general into whether insurer rigged the market. Since that inquiry wa launched in October, Marsh ha replaced it chief executive and held a boardroom shake-out to meet criticism by lessening the number of company executive on the board. Prosecutors allege that Marsh - the world's biggest insurance broker - and other US insurance firm may have fixed bid for corporate cover. This is the issue at the heart of the inquiry by New York's top law officer, Eliot Spitzer, and a separate prosecution of five insurer by the State of California. The SEC's investigation into so-called related party transaction includes dealing in the Trident Funds, managed by MMC Capital, the company's private equity firm. Marsh's new chief executive, Michael Cherkasky, is trying to negotiate a settlement with Mr Spitzer. Mr Spitzer ha built up a reputation a a fierce critic and campaigner against corporate America's misdeeds. The uncertainty unleashed by the scandal ha prompted three credit rating agency - Standard & Poor's, Moody's and Fitch - to downgrade Marsh in recent weeks. According to the Financial Times, insurance analyst are now questioning whether Marsh will be able to maintain it strong record of earning growth a they draw up forecast for the first quarter of next year. Doubts also exist over how much the company may have to pay regulator and lawyer to put the scandal behind.

Title: Campaigners attack MTV 'sleaze'
Article: MTV ha been criticised for "incessant sleaze" by television indecency campaigner in the US. The Parents Television Council (PTC), which monitor violence and sex on TV, said the cable music channel offered the "cheapest form" of programming. The group is at the forefront of a vociferous campaign to clean up American television. But a spokeswoman for MTV said it wa "unfair and inaccurate" to single out MTV for criticism. The PTC monitored MTV's output for 171 hour from 20 March to 27 March 2004, during the channel's Spring Break coverage. In it report - MTV Smut Peddlers: Targeting Kids with Sex, Drugs and Alcohol - the PTC said it witnessed 3,056 flash of nudity or sexual situation and 2,881 verbal reference to sex. Brent Bozell, PTC president and conservative activist said: "MTV is blatantly selling raunchy sex to kids. "Compared to broadcast television programme aimed at adults, MTV's programming contains substantially more sex, foul language and violence - and MTV's show are aimed at child a young a 12. "There's no question that TV influence the attitude and perception of young viewers, and MTV is deliberately marketing it raunch to million of innocent children." The watchdog decided to look at MTV's programme after Janet Jackson's infamous "wardrobe malfunction" at last year's Super Bowl. The breast-baring incident generated 500,000 complaint and CBS - which is owned by the same parent company a MTV - wa quick to apologise. MTV spokeswoman Jeannie Kedas said the network follows the same standard a broadcaster and reflects the culture and what it viewer are interested in. "It's unfair and inaccurate to paint MTV with that brush of irresponsibility," she said. "We think it's underestimating young people's intellect and level of sophistication." Ms Kedas also highlighted the fact MTV won an award in 2004 for the Fight for Your Rights series that focused on issue such a sexual health and tolerance.

Title: Australia rates at four year high
Article: Australia is raising it benchmark interest rate to it highest level in four year despite sign of a slowdown in the country's economy. The Reserve Bank of Australia lifted interest rate 0.25% to 5.5%, their first upwards move in more than a year. However, shortly after the Bank made it decision, new figure showed a fall in economic growth in the last quarter. The Bank said it had acted to curb inflation but the move wa criticised by some analysts. The rate hike wa the first since December 2003 and had been well-flagged in advance. However, opposition party and some analyst said the move wa ill-timed given data showing the Australian economy grew just 0.1% between October and December and 1.5% on an annual basis. The figures, representing a decline from the 0.2% growth in GDP seen between July and September, were below market expectations. Consumer spending remains strong, however, and the Bank is concerned about growing inflationary pressures. "Over recent month it ha become increasingly clear that remaining spare capacity in the labour and good market is becoming rather limited," said Ian Macfarlane, Governor of the Reserve Bank. At 2.6%, inflation remains within the Bank's 2-3% target range. However, export declined in the second half of 2004, fuelling a rise in the country's current account deficit - the difference in the value of import compared to export - to a record Australian dollar 29.4bn. The Australian government said the economy remained strong with unemployment at a near 30 year low. "The economy ha been strong and it is properly moderating but it doesn't look to me like it's slowing in any unreasonable way," said Treasurer Peter Costello. Stock market had factored in the likelihood of a rate rise but analyst still expressed concern about the strength of the economy. "That 1.5% annual growth rate is the lowest we have seen since the post-election slump we saw back in 2000-1," said Michael Blythe, chief economist at the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. "This suggests the economy really did slow very sharply in the second half of 2004."

Title: Almagro continues Spanish surge
Article: Unseeded Nicolas Almagro became the fifth Spaniard to reach the last eight at the Buenos Aires Open, ousting eighth seed Mariano Zabaleta. He showed admirable resolve to win a rain-affected match 6-7 6-4 6-4. Compatriot and seventh seed Rafael Nadal also reached the last eight, beating Italian Potito Starace 6-1 6-3. Nadal, playing in the outdoor clay event for the first time, hit some powerful forehand to oust Starace in a match delayed over an hour by rain. "It's always a problem to have to stop for rain but one get used to it," said Spanish teenager Nadal. "Luckily, I wa able to keep my pace going throughout the match." He will now play Gaston Gaudio, who beat unseeded Brazilian Flavio Saretta 6-3 6-2 in the day's late match.

Title: India power shares jump on debut
Article: Shares in India's largest power producer, National Thermal Power Corp (NTPC) have risen 13% on their stock market debut. The government's partial sell-off of NTPC is part of a controversial programme to privatise state-run firms. The 865 million share offer, a mix of new share and sale by the government, raised 54bn rupees($1.2bn). It wa India's second $1bn stock debut in three months, coming after the flotation by software firm Tata. The share offer wa eleven time oversubscribed. "It is a good investment bet," said Suhas Naik, an investment analyst from ING Mutual Fund. "Power need in India are set to rise and NTPC will benefit from that." Analysts say the success of the NTPC flotation would encourage the government to reduce stake in more power companies. NTPC ha said it will use the money from the share sale to feed the growing need of the country's energy-starved economy. The firm is the largest utility company in India, and the sixth largest power producer in the world.

Title: Stars pay tribute to actor Davis
Article: Hollywood star including Spike Lee, Burt Reynolds and Oscar nominee Alan Alda have paid tribute to actor Ossie Davis at a funeral in New York. Veteran star Ossie Davis, a well-known civil right activist, died in Miami at the age of 87 on 4 February 2005. Friends and family, including actress Ruby Dee his wife of 56 years, gathered at the Riverside Church on Saturday. Also present at the service wa former US president Bill Clinton and singer Harry Belafonte, who gave the eulogy. "He would have been a very good president of the United States," said Mr Clinton. "Like most of you here, he gave more to me than I gave to him." The 87-year-old wa found dead last weekend in his hotel room in Florida, where he wa making a film. Police said that he appeared to have died of natural causes. Davis made his acting debut in 1950 in No Way Out starring Sidney Poiter. He frequently collaborated with director Spike Lee, starring in seven Lee film including Jungle Fever, Do The Right Thing and Malcolm X. Attallah Shabazz, the daughter of activist Malcolm X, recalled the famous eulogy delivered by Davis at her father's funeral. "Harlem ha come to bid farewell to one of it finest hopes," she said, quoting the man she knew a Uncle Ossie. "Ditto." "Ossie wa my hero, and he still is," said Aviator star Alan Alda, a family friend for over forty years. "Ossie wa a thing of beauty." "I want so badly someday to have his dignity - a little of it anyway," added Burt Reynolds, Davis's co-star in the 90 TV comedy Evening Shade. Before the midday funeral, score of Harlem resident formed a queue outside the church to pay their respect to Davis. "It is hard to fathom that we will no longer be able to call on his wisdom, his humour, his loyalty and his moral strength to guide u in the choice that are yet to be made and the battle that are yet to be fought," said Belafonte, himself an ardent civil right activist who had been friend with Davis for over 60 years. "But how fortunate we were to have him a long a we did."

Title: Buyers snap up Jet Airways' shares
Article: Investors have snapped up share in Jet Airways, India's biggest airline, following the launch of it much anticipated initial public offer (IPO). The IPO for 17.3 million share wa fully sold within 10 minute of opening, on Friday. Analysts expect Jet to raise at least 16.4bn rupee ($375m; Â£198m) from the offering. Interest in Jet's IPO ha been fuelled by hope for robust growth in India's air travel market. The share offer, representing about 20% of Jet's equity, wa oversubscribed, news agency Reuters reported. Jet, which wa founded by London-based travel agent Naresh Goyal, plan to use the cash to buy new plane and cut it debt. The company ha grown rapidly since it launched operation in 1993, overtaking state-owned flag carrier Indian Airlines. However, it face stiff competition from rival and low-cost carriers. Jet's IPO is the first in a series of expected share offer from Indian company this year, a they move to raise fund to help them do business in a rapidly-growing economy.

Title: Dibaba breaks 5,000m world record
Article: Ethiopia's Tirunesh Dibaba set a new world record in winning the women's 5,000m at the Boston Indoor Games. Dibaba won in 14 minute 32.93 second to erase the previous world indoor mark of 14:39.29 set by another Ethiopian, Berhane Adera, in Stuttgart last year. But compatriot Kenenisa Bekele's record hope were dashed when he miscounted his lap in the men's 3,000m and staged his sprint finish a lap too soon. Ireland's Alistair Cragg won in 7:39.89 a Bekele battled to second in 7:41.42. "I didn't want to sit back and get out-kicked," said Cragg. "So I kept on the pace. The plan wa to go with 500m to go no matter what, but when Bekele made the mistake that wa it. The race wa mine." Sweden's Carolina Kluft, the Olympic heptathlon champion, and Slovenia's Jolanda Ceplak had winning performances, too. Kluft took the long jump at 6.63m, while Ceplak easily won the women's 800m in 2:01.52.

Title: Glasgow hosts tsunami benefit gig
Article: The top name in Scottish music are taking part in a benefit concert in aid of the victim of the Asian tsunami. All 10,000 ticket for Saturday's concert, featuring Franz Ferdinand, Belle and Sebastian and Travis, at Glasgow's SECC sold out in 36 hours. Mull Historical Society, Deacon Blue, Idlewild, Texas, Mogwai and Teenage Fanclub are among the other act performing at the concert. Organisers hope to raise at least Â£250,000 from the show. It follows a Cardiff gig starring Eric Clapton, Keane and Jools Holland, which raised more than Â£1.25m. And it is taking place on the same night a a tsunami benefit show in Bristol, which will see Massive Attack and Portishead share a stage for the first time. Colin MacIntyre, of Mull Historical Society, wa playing another gig on the same day but said he wa determined to make the Glasgow benefit. He said: "I think we were all affected by seeing the report coming from the Far East. "We all know somebody who wa there, but more than that it wa that we had never seen a wave of destruction, a natural disaster, like this in my generation. "I'm lucky a an artist to be able to perform at something like this."

Title: Crucial decision on super-casinos
Article: A decision on whether to allow Westminster to legislate on super-casinos is set to be made by the Scottish Parliament. The government ha plan for up to eight Las Vegas style resort in the UK, one of which is likely to be in Glasgow. Scottish minister insist they will still have the final say on whether a super-casino will be built in Scotland. But opposition party say that will not happen in practice. The vote is due to be taken on Wednesday and is expected to be close. The Scottish Executive belief that the legislation should be handled by Westminster. The new law will control internet gambling for the first time and is aimed at preventing child from becoming involved. A super-casino in Glasgow could be located at Ibrox or the Scottish Exhibition and Conference Centre. The new gambling bill going through Westminster will allow casino complex to open to the public, have live entertainment and large number of fruit machine with unlimited prizes. But the Scottish National Party and the Tories say the issue of super-casinos should be decided in Scotland and believe the executive is shirking it responsibility.

Title: Tigers wary of Farrell 'gamble'
Article: Leicester say they will not be rushed into making a bid for Andy Farrell should the Great Britain rugby league captain decide to switch codes. "We and anybody else involved in the process are still some way away from going to the next stage," Tigers bos John Wells told BBC Radio Leicester. "At the moment, there are still a lot of unknown about Andy Farrell, not least his medical situation. "Whoever doe take him on is going to take a big, big gamble." Farrell, who ha had persistent knee problems, had an operation on his knee five week ago and is expected to be out for another three months. Leicester and Saracens are believed to head the list of rugby union club interested in signing Farrell if he decides to move to the 15-man game. If he doe move across to union, Wells belief he would better off playing in the backs, at least initially. "I'm sure he could make the step between league and union by being involved in the centre," said Wells. "I think England would prefer him to progress to a position in the back row where they can make use of some of his rugby league skill within the forwards. "The jury is out on whether he can cross that divide. "At this club, the balance will have to be struck between the cost of that gamble and the option of bringing in a ready-made replacement."

Title: Redknapp poised for Saints
Article: Southampton are set to unveil Harry Redknapp a their new manager at a news conference at 1500 GMT on Wednesday. The former Portsmouth bos replaces Steve Wigley, who ha been relieved of first-team duty after just one win in 14 league game in charge. Redknapp, 57, quit his Fratton Park position on 24 November and vowed: "I will not go down the road - no chance." Pompey coach Kevin Bond is poised to join Redknapp, who will be Saints' third bos of the season. Redknapp's first game in charge will be at home to Middlesbrough on Saturday. Portsmouth chairman Milan Mandaric said he wa "disappointed" by the news and claimed Redknapp had been in talk with Southampton for "some time". "It would appear that negotiation over this have been going on for some time," Mandaric said on Portsmouth's official website. "I am surprised and a little shocked that the chairman of Southampton ha not picked up the phone and kept me informed." According to Mandaric, Redknapp vowed he would not join their South coast rival when he left Portsmouth. "I said to Harry 'I hope you don't go to Southampton', and he told me 'absolutely not'," he said. "I'm wouldn't say I'm bitter, disgusted or angry, just disappointed, but it's Harry's life and it's his decision." Redknapp became a cult hero after leading Portsmouth into the Premiership for the first time, and then masterminding their survival in their debut season. But he left the club claiming he needed a break from football, though many believed he wa upset with Mandaric's decision to bring in Velimir Zajec a executive director. Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe wa desperate to give former academy director Wigley, who replaced Paul Sturrock just two game into the season, every chance to succeed at St Mary's. But result under Wigley have been poor and Southampton are deep in trouble near the foot of the table. When Redknapp's appointment is confirmed, he will be Saints' ninth manager in eight years.

Title: Blair and Blunkett Sheffield trip
Article: Tony Blair is to join Home Secretary David Blunkett in a visit to Sheffield on Thursday. Mr Blunkett's conduct is being looked at to establish whether he abused his position in relation to his ex-lover. The Parliamentary standard watchdog is looking at his decision to give Kimberly Quinn free rail tickets. He is also being investigated over the visa application of Mrs Quinn's ex-nanny. The visit to Sheffield will be seen a a show of unity by Mr Blair. On Wednesday during Prime Minister's Questions, Tory leader Michael Howard went on the offensive over comment Mr Blunkett is alleged to have made in a new biography. He is understood to have made a series of criticism about his Cabinet colleague from the prime minister down. Mr Howard said Mr Blunkett had complained he had inherited a "giant mess" when he took over at the Home Office from Jack Straw, now foreign secretary. The Tory leader went on: "He doesn't stop there: he think the culture secretary's weak; he think the trade secretary doesn't think strategically and he think the education secretary hasn't developed a expected. "He say the prime minister doesn't like being told the truth and the chancellor - no doubt the prime minister will agree with this - is a bully." Mr Blair retorted voter remembered the record of a government and no comment by politicians. The home secretary ha already admitted he wa wrong to give the two first class tickets, given to him a an MP, to Mrs Quinn and ha since paid the Â£180 back. He ha apologised for "a genuine mistake" and say he will write to the watchdog to answer further questions. The rail ticket are meant to help MPs' spouse get between Westminster and their constituencies. After his inquiry, Parliamentary watchdog Sir Philip Mawer will report to the Commons Standards and Privileges Committee, the group of MPs who will recommend to the full House of Commons what action - if any - should be taken against Mr Blunkett. The separate inquiry by ex-senior civil servant Sir Alan Budd is investigating whether the home secretary helped fast-track a bid by Mrs Quinn's nanny, Leoncia Casalme, to stay in the UK. Last week, Mr Blunkett won the first round of a High Court battle with Mrs Quinn for access to her son. Mr Blunkett declined to comment about his own position, saying the inquiry wa under way and the High Court had stressed his right to privacy did not affect his job in improving security and stability. Downing Street ha stressed Mr Blair's support for the home secretary.

Title: More power to the people says HP
Article: The digital revolution is focused on letting people tell and share their own stories, according to Carly Fiorina, chief of technology giant Hewlett Packard. The job of firm such a HP now, she said in a speech at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES), wa to ensure digital and physical world fully converged. She said the goal for 2005 wa to make people the centre of technology. CES showcase 50,000 new gadget that will be hitting the shelf in 2005. The tech-fest, the largest of it kind in the world, run from 6 to 9 January. "The digital revolution is about the democratisation of technology and the experience it make possible," she told delegates. "Revolution ha always been about giving power to the people." She added: "The real story of the digital revolution is not just new products, but the million of experience made possible and story that million can tell." Part of giving people more control ha been about the freeing up of content, such a images, video and music. Crucial to this ha been the effort to make device that speak to each other better so that content can be more easily transferred from one device, such a a digital camera, to others, such a portable medium players. A lot of work still need to be done, however, to sort out compatibility issue and standard within the technology industry so that gadget just work seamlessly, she said. Ms Fiorina's talk also touted the way technology is being designed to focus on lifestyle, fashion and personalisation, something she see a key to what people want. Special guest, singer Gwen Stefani, joined her on-stage to promote her own range of HP digital camera which Ms Stefani ha helped design and which are heavily influenced by Japanese youth culture. The digital cameras, which are due to go on sale in the US by the summer, are based on the HP 607 model. The emphasis on personalisation and lifestyle is a big theme at this year's CES, with tiny, wearable MP3 player at every turn and rainbow hue giving colour to everything. Ms Fiorina also announced that HP wa working with Nokia to launch a visual radio service for mobiles, which would launch in Europe early this year. The service will let people listen to radio on their mobile and download relevant content, like a track's ringtone, simultaneously. The service is designed to make mobile radio more interactive. Among the other new product she showcased wa the Digital Media Hub, a big upgrade to HP's Digital Entertainment Centre. Coming out in the autumn in the US, the box is a networked, high-definition TV, cable set-top box, digital video recorder and DVD recorder. It ha a removable hard drive cartridge, memory card slots, and Light Scribe labelling software which let people design and print customised DVD label and covers. It is designed to contain all a household's digital media, such a pre-recorded TV shows, pictures, video and music so it can all be managed in one place. The hub reflects the increasing move to re-box the PC so that it can work a part of other key centre of entertainment. Research suggests that about 258 million image are saved and shared every day, equating to 94 billion a year. Eighty per cent of those remain on cameras. Media hub are designed to encourage people to organise them on one box. Ms Fiorina wa one of several keynote speakers, who also included Microsoft chief Bill Gates, to set out what major technology company think people will be doing with technology and gadget in the next 12 months. In a separate announcement during the keynote speech, Ms Fiorina said that HP would be partnering MTV to replace this year's MTV Asia music award. MTV's Asia Aid will be held in Bangkok on 3 February, and is aimed at helping to raise money for the Asian tsunami disaster.

Title: Hundreds vie for best film Oscar
Article: A total of 267 film are eligible for the best film Oscar but only five will be chosen to go forward a nominees. The Academy of Motion Picture, Arts and Sciences ha sent out the first ballot paper with the full list of film vying for recognition. Among those expected to receive nomination are The Aviator, Million Dollar Baby and Sideways. Academy member will now vote for their favourite before the final nominee are announced on 25 January. To be eligible for nomination a film must have been shown in a commercial theatre for seven consecutive day before the deadline of 31 December. Director Martin Scorsese's The Aviator, starring Leonardo DiCaprio went on general release on Christmas Day in the US, ensuring it just made the deadline. Studios have already begun lobbying voters, taking out full page advert in trade publication such a Variety urging them to remember particular film when it come to choosing what to back. Other movie tipped for possible success include Closer, starring Jude Law and Julia Roberts, Finding Neverland, with Johnny Depp a author JM Barry and Kinsey starring Liam Neeson a the famed sex scientist Alfred Kinsey. Meanwhile, design engineer Takuo Miyagishima will be awarded an Oscar at the Scientific and Technical Awards Dinner on 12 February 2005. Miyagishima is the 18th recipient of the Sawyer Award, which is "presented to an individual in the motion picture industry whose technological contribution have brought credit to the industry." The main Oscar ceremony will be held in Los Angeles on 27 February.

Title: 'Strong dollar' call halts slide
Article: The US dollar's slide against the euro and yen ha halted after US Treasury Secretary John Snow said a strong dollar wa "in America's interest". But analyst said any gain are likely to be short-lived a problem with the US economy were still significant. They also pointed out that positive comment apart, President George W Bush's administration had done little to stop the dollar's slide. A weak dollar help boost export and narrow the current account deficit. The dollar wa trading at $1.2944 against the euro at 2100GMT, still close to the $1.3006 record level set on 10 November. Against the Japanese yen, it wa trading at 105.28 yen, after hitting a seven-month low of 105.17 earlier in the day. Policy maker in Europe have called the dollar's slide "brutal" and have blamed the strength of the euro for dampening economic growth. However, it is unclear whether minister would issue a declaration aimed at curbing the euro's rise at a monthly meeting of Eurozone minister late on Monday. Higher growth in Europe is regarded by US official a a way the huge US current account deficit - that ha been weighing on the dollar - could be reduced. Mr Snow who is currently in Dublin at the start of a four-nation EU visit, ha applauded Ireland's introduction of lower tax and deregulation which have helped boost growth. "The eurozone is growing below it potential. When a major part of the global economy is below potential there are negative consequences... for the citizen of those economies... and for their trading partners," he said. Mr Snow's comment may have helped shore up the dollar on Monday, but he wa careful to qualify his statement. "Our basic policy, of course, is to let open, competitive market set the values," he explained. "Markets are driven by fundamental and towards fundamentals." US official have also said that other economy need to grow, so the US is not the main global growth engine. Economists say that the fundamentals, or key indicators, of the US economy are looking far from rosy. Domestic consumer demand is cooling, and heavy spending by President Bush ha pushed the budget deficit to a record $427bn (Â£230bn). The current account deficit, meanwhile, hit a record $166bn in the second quarter of 2004. For many analysts, a weaker dollar is here to stay. "No end is in sight," said Carsten Fritsch, a strategist at Commerzbank . "It is only a matter of time until the euro reach $1.30." Some analyst maintain the US is secretly happy with a lower dollar which help make it export cheaper in Europe, thus boosting it economy.

Title: EU-US seeking deal on air dispute
Article: The EU and US have agreed to begin talk on ending subsidy given to aircraft makers, EU Trade Commissioner Peter Mandelson ha announced. Both side hope to reach a negotiated deal over state aid received by European aircraft maker Airbus and it US rival Boeing, Mr Mandelson said. Airbus and Boeing accuse each other of benefiting from illegal subsidies. Mr Mandelson said the EU and US hoped to avoid having to resolve the dispute at the World Trade Organisation (WTO). "With this agreement the EU and US have confirmed their willingness to resolve the dispute which ha arisen between them," Mr Mandelson said. "I hope our negotiation in the next three month will lead to an agreement ending subsidy to development and production of large civil aircraft." Last year, the US terminated an agreement with the EU, reached in 1992, which limit the subsidy country can hand over to civil aircraft makers. The US filed a complaint against Brussels with the WTO over state aid to Airbus, prompting a retaliatory EU complaint over US support for Boeing. Title: WorldCom bosses' $54m payout
Article: Ten former director at WorldCom have agreed to pay $54m (Â£28.85m), including $18m from their own pockets, to settle a class action lawsuit, report say. James Wareham, a lawyer representing one of the directors, told Reuters the 10 had agreed to pay those who lost billion when the firm collapsed. The remaining $36m will be paid by the directors' insurers. But, a spokesman for the prosecutor, New York State Comptroller Alan Hevesi, said no formal agreement had been made. Corporate governance expert said that if the director do dip into their own pocket for the settlement, it will set a new standard for the accountability of bosses, when the firm they oversee face problems. "Directors very rarely pay," said Charles Elson, chairman of the Center for Corporate Governance at the University of Delaware. He added that the settlement "sends a pretty strong shockwave through the director world". A formal agreement on the payout is expected to be signed on Thursday in a US district court in Manhattan. Earlier, the New York Times had reported that the personal payment were required a part of any deal at the start of negotiations. The ten former outside director are James Allen, Judith Areen, Carl Aycock, Max Bobbitt, Clifford Alexander, Stiles Kellett, Gordon Macklin, John Porter, Lawrence Tucker and the estate of John Sidgmore, who died last year. It ha not yet been determined how much each director will have to pay. "None of the 10 former director wa a direct participant in the accounting machination of the WorldCom fraud," said the Wall Street Journal (WSJ). Two other outside former directors, Bert Roberts and Francesco Galesi, remain defendant in the lawsuit, said the newspaper. According to the WSJ, which cite people familiar to the case, the settling director are expected to deny wrongdoing and state they are settling the case to eliminate the uncertainty and expense of further litigations. The second-largest US long-distance telecom operator filed for bankruptcy in 2002 when an $11bn accounting scandal wa unearthed. The company emerged from Chapter 11 protection last year and changed it name to MCI Inc. Former WorldCom chief executive Bernard Ebbers is to face trial this month on criminal charge that he oversaw the fraud.

Title: Hewitt falls to Dent
Article: Lleyton Hewitt suffered a shock defeat to Taylor Dent in the quarter-finals of the Australian Hardcourt Championships in Adelaide on Friday. The top seed wa a strong favourite for the title but went down 7-6 (7-4) 6-3 to the American. Dent will face Juan Ignacio Chela next after the fourth seed wa too strong for Jurgen Melzer. Olivier Rochus beat third seed Nicolas Kiefer 6-7 (4-7) 7-6 (8-6) 7-5 and will take on second seed Joachim Johansson. The Swede reached the last four by beating compatriot Thomas Enqvist 6-3 4-6 6-1. "I felt like I wa striking the ball much better," said Johansson. "I felt like I had a lot of break chances, I didn't take care of them all, but I broke him four time and he only broke me once. "I felt that wa the key to get up in the set early."

Title: Apple laptop is 'greatest gadget'
Article: The Apple Powerbook 100 ha been chosen a the greatest gadget of all time, by US magazine Mobile PC. The 1991 laptop wa chosen because it wa one of the first "lightweight" portable computer and helped define the layout of all future notebook PCs. The magazine ha compiled an all-time top 100 list of gadgets, which includes the Sony Walkman at number three and the 1956 Zenith remote control at two. Gadgets needed moving part and/or electronics to warrant inclusion. The magazine staff compiled the list and specified that gadget also needed to be a "self-contained apparatus that can be used on it own, not a subset of another device". "In general we included only item that were potentially mobile," said the magazine. "In the end, we tried to get to the heart of what really make a gadget a gadget," it concluded. The oldest "gadget" in the top 100 is the abacus, which the magazine date at 190 A.D., and put in 60th place. Other pre-electronic gadget in the top 100 include the sextant from 1731 (59th position), the marine chronometer from 1761 (42nd position) and the Kodak Brownie camera from 1900 (28th position). The Tivo personal video recorder is the newest device to make the top 10, which also includes the first flash mp3 player (Diamond Multimedia), a well a the first "successful" digital camera (Casio QV-10) and mobile phone (Motorola Startac). The most popular gadget of the moment, the Apple iPod, is at number 12 in the list while the first Sony transistor radio is at number 13. Sony's third entry in the top 20 is the CDP-101 CD player from 1983. "Who can forget the crystalline, hiss-free blast of Madonna's Like A Virgin emanating from their first CD player?" asked the magazine. Karl Elsener's knife, the Swiss Army Knife from 1891, is at number 20 in the list. Gadgets which could be said to feature surprisingly low down in the list include the original telephone (23rd), the Nintendo GameBoy (25th), and the Pulsar quartz digital watch (36th). The list also contains plenty of oddities: the Pez sweet dispenser (98th), 1990s toy Tamagotchi (86th) and the bizarre Ronco inside the shell egg scrambler (84th). Almost everyone ha a mobile phone, how many people own a Powerbook? or an iPod? The finding of this magazine are not very convincing. What about the magnetic compass? We still use it 1,000 year after it wa invented. I am amazed by the obsession with individual gadget rather than genre. For example the Sony walkman wa the first truly portable way of listening to your own music on the move whereas Minidisc, Flash MP3, portable CD player etc. are really just improvement in technology. My favourite 'true' gadget are probably my portable MiniDisc player and the little battery powered whizzy thing I use to froth up my coffee! Calm down it's only in their opinion, and any list that includes the Taser in the top 100 gadget ha to be suspect.... Swiss army knife and no question about it. How many of the other item are still relatively unchanged from the original idea and still a useful/popular? You don't need a laptop or even a pocket calculator to work that one out! This list merely illustrates interesting cultural divide between the American author and the overwhelmingly British responses. Brits see no further than mobile phone and the over thirty Sinclair; whilst the Americans focus on Apple, TV remote and TiVO (which probably is rather obscure in Europe). What about the Soda Stream. This gadget changed my pre-teen life. Lap top may enable you to "think different, but you cant use them to "get busy with the fizzy" How about Astro Wars, one of the pioneer for computer games, i remember spending many an hour playing this and it still work today! However tried it the other day and it wa rubbish, still a great gadget of it time. Why worry about mobile phones. Soon they will be subsumed into the PDA's / laptop etc. What about the Marine Chronometer? Completely revolutionised navigation for boat and wa in use for centuries. For it's time, a technological marvel! Sony Net Minidisc! It paved the way for more mp3 player to explode onto the market. I always used my NetMD, and could not go anywhere without it. A laptop computer is not a gadget! It's a working tool! The Sinclair Executive wa the world's first pocket calculator. I think this should be there a well. How about the clockwork radio? Or GPS? Or a pocket calculator? All these thing are useful to real people, not just PC magazine editors. Are the people who created this list insane ? Surely the most important gadget of the modern age is the mobile phone? It ha revolutionised communication, which is more than can be said for a niche market laptop. From outside the modern age, the marine chronometer is the single most important gadget, without which modern transportation system would not have evolved so quickly. Has everyone forgot about the Breville pie maker?? An interesting list. Of the electronic gadgets, thousand of journalist in the early 1980s blessed the original noteboook pc - the Tandy 100. The size of A4 paper and light, three week on a set of batteries, an excellent keyboard, a modem. A pity Tandy did not make it DOS compatible. What's an Apple Powerbook 100 ? It's out of date - not much of a "gadget". Surely it ha to be something simple / timeless - the tin opener, Swiss Army Knife, safety razor blade, wristwatch or the thing for taking stone out of horse hoof ? It ha to be the mobile phone. No other single device ha had such an effect on our way of living in such a short space of time. The ball point pen ha got to be one of the most used and common gadget ever. Also many might be grateful for the pocket calculator which wa a great improvement over the slide rule. The Casio pocket calculator that played a simple game and made tinny noise wa also a hot gadget in 1980. A true gadget, it could be carried around and shown off. All top 10 are electronic toys, so the list is probably a better reflection of the current high-tech obsession than anything else. I say this a the Swiss Army Knife only made No 20. Sinclair QL a machine far ahead of it time. The first home machine with a true multi-takings OS. Shame the marketing wa so bad!!! Apple.. a triumph of fashion over... well everything else. Utter rubbish. Yes, the Apple laptop and Sony Walkman are classic gadgets. But to call the sextant and the marine chronometer 'gadgets' and rank them a less important than a TV remote control reveals a quite shocking lack of historical perspective. The former literally helped change the world by vastly improving navigation at see. The latter is the seed around which the couch potato culture ha developed. No competition. I'd also put Apple's Newton and the first Palm Pilot there a the front runner for portable computing, and possibly the Toshiba Libretto for the same reason. I only wish that Vulcan Inc's Flipstart wasn't just vapourware otherwise it would be at the top. How did a laptop ever manage to beat off the challenge of the wristwatch or the telephone (mobile or otherwise)? What about radio and TVs? The swiss army knife. By far the most useful gadget. I got mine 12 year ago. Still wearing and using it a lot! It stood the test of time. Psion Organiser series 3, should be up there. Had a usable qwerty keyboard, removable storage, good set of apps and programmable. Case design wa good (batteries in the hinge - a first, I think). Great product innovation. The first mobile PC wa voted best gadget by reader of...err... mobile PC?! Why do you keep putting these obviously biased list on your site? It's obviously the mobile phone or remote control, and reader of a less partisan publication would tell you that. The Motorola Startac should be Number One. Why? There will be mobile phone long after notebook computer and other gadget are either gone or integrated in communication devices. The Psion series 3c! The first most practical way to carry all your info around... I too would back the Sinclair Spectrum - without this little beauty I would never have moved into the world of IT and earn the living that I do now. I'd have put the mobile phone high up the list. Probably a Nokia model. Sinclair Spectrum - 16k. It plugged into the tv. Games were rubbish but it gave me a taste for programming and that's what I do for a living now. I wish more modern notebook -- even Apple's newest offering -- were more like the PB100. Particularly disheartening is the demise of the trackball, which ha given way to the largely useless "trackpad" which every notebook on the market today uses. They're invariably inaccurate, uncomfortable, and cumbersome to use. Congratulations to Apple, a deserved win!

Title: Strachan turns down Pompey
Article: Former Southampton manager Gordon Strachan ha rejected the chance to become Portsmouth's new boss. The Scot wa Pompey chairman Milan Mandaric's first choice to replace Harry Redknapp, who left Fratton Park for rival Saints earlier in December. "I think it's a fantastic job for anybody apart from somebody who ha just been the Southampton manager," Strachan told the BBC. Club director Terry Brady held initial talk with Strachan on Saturday. The former Scotland international added that joining Southampton's local rival would not be a wise move. "It's got everything going for it but I've got too many memory of the other side and I don't want to sour those memories," he said. "Everything's right - it's 10 minute away, there are good player there, a good set-up, a good atmosphere at the ground. "There's lot to do but it's not right for somebody who ha just been the Southampton manager." Since Redknapp's departure, executive director Velimir Zajec and coach Joe Jordan have overseen first-team affairs. The duo had gone five match unbeaten until Sunday's 1-0 defeat at home to champion Arsenal, but the club are still in a respectable 12th place in the Premiership table. Strachan left St Mary's in February, after earlier announcing his intention to take a break from the game at the end of the 2003-04 season. His previous managerial experience came at Coventry, whom he led for five year from 1996 to 2001.
