Title: Wi-fi web reaches farmers in Peru
Article: A network of community computer centres, linked by wireless technology, is providing a helping hand for poor farmer in Peru. The pilot scheme in the Huaral Valley, 80 kilometre north of the capital Lima, aim to offer the 6,000-strong community up-to-date information on agricultural market price and trends. The Agricultural Information Project for Farmers of the Chancay-Huaral Valley also provides vital link between local organisation in charge of water irrigation, enabling them to coordinate their actions. More than 13,000 rural inhabitants, a well a 18,000 student in the region, will also benefit from the telecom infrastructure. The 14 telecentres us only free open source software and affordable computer equipment. The network ha been three year in the making and wa officially inaugurated in September. The non-government organisation, Cepes (Peruvian Centre for Social Studies) led the $200,000 project, also backed by local institutions, the Education and Agriculture ministries, and European development organisations. "The plan includes training on computer and internet skill for both operator and user of the system," said Carlos Saldarriaga, technical coordinator at Cepes. Farmers are also taking extra lesson on how to apply the new information to make the most of their plot of land. The Board of Irrigation Users which run the computer centres, aim to make the network self-sustainable within three years, through the cash generated by using the telecentres a internet cafes. One of the key element of the project is the Agricultural Information System, with it flagship huaral.org website. There, farmer can find the price for local produce, a well a information on topic ranging from plague prevention to the latest farming techniques. The system also help the inhabitant of the Chancay-Huaral Valley to organise their vital irrigation systems. "Water is the main element that unites them all. It is a precious element in Peru's coastal areas, because it is so scarce, and therefore it is necessary to have proper irrigation system to make the most of it," Mr Saldarriaga told the BBC News website. The information network also allows farmer to look beyond their own region, and share experience with other colleague from the rest of Peru and even around the world. Cepes say the involvement of the farmer ha been key in the project's success. "Throughout the last three years, the people have provided a vital thrust to the project; they feel it belongs to them," said Mr Saldarriaga. The community training sessions, attended by an equal number of men and women, have been the perfect showcase for their enthusiasm. "We have had an excellent response, mainly from young people. But we have also had a great feedback when we trained 40 or 50-year old women, who were seeing a computer for the first time in their lives." So far, the Huaral programme promoter say the experience ha been very positive, and are already planning on spreading the model among other farmers' organisation in Peru. "This is a pilot project, and we have been very keen on it cloning potential in other places," underlined Mr Saldarriaga. The Cepes researcher recall what happened in Cuyo, a 50-family community with no electricity, during the construction of the local telecentre site. There it wa necessary to build a mini-hydraulic dam in order to generate 2kW worth of power for the computers, the communication equipment and the cabin lights. "It wa already dark when the technician realised they didn't have any light bulb to test the generator, so they turned up to the local store to buy light bulbs," recall Carlos Saldarriaga. "The logical answer wa 'we don't sell any', so they had to wait until the next morning to do the testing." Now, with the wireless network, Cuyo a well a the other community is no longer isolated.

Title: UK needs tax cuts, Tories insist
Article: A major change of direction is needed in Britain if it is to prosper, the shadow chancellor said a the Tory Party spring conference began. Oliver Letwin said the UK could not compete with other country without the Â£4bn tax cut he wa promising. Tory co-chairman Liam Fox had opened the forum in Brighton with an attack on Labour's record and party leader Michael Howard is due to speak later. Title: Mild winter drives US oil down 6%
Article: US oil price have fallen by 6%, driven down by forecast of a mild winter in the densely populated northeast. Light crude oil future fell $2.86 to $41.32 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange (Nymex), and have now lost $4 in five days. Nonetheless, US crude is still 30% more expensive than at the beginning of 2004, boosted by growing demand and bottleneck at refineries. Traders ignored the possible effect of Asia's tidal wave on global supplies. Instead, the focus is now on US consumption, which is heavily influenced in the short term by the weather. "With the revised milder temperatures... I'm more inclined to think we'll push lower and test the $40-40.25 range," said John Brady of ABN AMRO. "The market definitely feel to be on the defensive." Statistics released last week showed that stockpile of oil product in the US had risen, an indication that severe supply disruption may not arise this winter, barring any serious incident. Oil price have broken record in 2004, topping $50 a barrel at one point, driven up by a welter of worry about unrest in Iraq and Saudi Arabia, rising demand and supply bottlenecks. London's International Petroleum Exchange remained closed for the Christmas holiday.

Title: Edu describes tunnel fracas
Article: Arsenal's Edu ha lifted the lid on the scene that followed Manchester United's win over the Gunners. The Brazilian confirmed temper had flared but could shed no light on report that food wa thrown at United bos Sir Alex Ferguson. "I saw people being pulled apart, people pushing, pointing and shouting," he told Uefa's official website. "The United player were trying to wind u up about the result but I didn't see any soup being thrown at anyone." However, Edu tried to play down the incidents, adding: "There wa nothing that I haven't seen in Brazilian derbies. "Derby match in Brazil are worse. I like to play in game like this with this intense rivalry." But Edu wa highly critical of the ferocity of some of United's challenge during the game, particularly on Jose Antonio Reyes. "I think we were a lot fairer in the tackle than United," he said. "Reyes wa being kicked all over the park - they were beating up the boy and Gary Neville wa tackling in such a way that he should have been sent off." Following the game, the Football Association said it would look into event in the tunnel. It also charged Ruud van Nistelrooy with serious foul play while Arsenal bos Arsene Wenger ha been asked to explain comment he made about the referee.

Title: Robots learn 'robotiquette' rules
Article: Robots are learning lesson on "robotiquette" - how to behave socially - so they can mix better with humans. By playing games, like pass-the-parcel, a University of Hertfordshire team is finding out how future robot companion should react in social situations. The study's finding will eventually help human develop a code of social behaviour in human-robot interaction. The work is part of the European Cogniron robotics project, and wa on show at London's Science Museum. "We are assuming a situation in which a useful human companion robot already exists," said Professor Kerstin Dautenhahn, project leader at Hertfordshire. "Our mission is to look at how such a robot should be programmed to respect personal space of humans." The research also focus on human perception of robots, including how they should look, and how a robot can learn new skill by imitating a human demonstrator. "Without such studies, you will build robot which might not respect the fact that human are individuals, have preference and come from different cultural backgrounds," Professor Dautenhahn told BBC News Online. "And I want robot to treat human a human beings, and not like other robots," she added. In most situations, a companion robot will eventually have to deal not only with one person, but also with group of people. To find out how they would react, the Hertfordshire Cogniron team taught one robot to play pass-the-parcel with children. Showing off it skill at the Science Museum, the unnamed robot had to select, approach, and ask different child to pick up a parcel with a gift, moving it arm a a pointer and it camera a an eye. It even used speech to give instruction and play music. However, according to researchers, it will still take many year to build a robot which would make full use of the "robotiquette" for human interaction. "If you think of a robot a a companion for the human being, you can think of 20 year into the future," concluded Professor Dautenhahn. "It might take even longer because it is very, very hard to develop such a robot." You can hear more on this story on the BBC World Service's Go Digital programme.

Title: Podcasts mark rise of DIY radio
Article: An Apple iPod or other digital music player can hold anything up to 10,000 songs, which is a lot of space to fill. But more and more iPod owner are filling that space with audio content created by an unpredictable assortment of producers. It is called "podcasting" and it strongest proponent is former MTV host and VJ (video jockey) Adam Curry. Podcasting take it name from the Apple iPod, although you do not need an iPod to create one or to listen to a podcast. A podcast is basically an internet-based radio show which podcasters create, usually in the comfort of their own home. They need only a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. They then upload their show to the internet and others can download and listen to them, all for free. Using technology based on XML computer code and RSS - Really Simple Syndication - listener can subscribe to podcasts collected automatically in a bit of software, which Mr Curry ha pioneered. The latest MP3 file of show can then be picked up by a music playing device automatically. Mr Curry records, hosts, edits and produce a daily, 40 minute podcast called The Daily Source Code. He want to make podcasting "the Next Big Thing" and say it is an extension of his childhood love of radio gadgetry. "I wa always into technology and wires," he explains. "My parent gave me the Radio Shack 101 project kit, which allows you to build an AM transmitter and subsequently an FM transmitter. "I had my mom drive me around the block, see how far it would reach on the car radio." Mr Curry is American, but he grew up in the Netherlands where he hosted illegal, pirate radio show in the Dutch capital. He tried university in the US, and ended up back in Holland where he hosted a music video show. He spent the next seven year in New York where he worked at MTV hosting the Top 20 Video Countdown, but spent most of his hour tinkering with this new thing called the internet. "At a certain point in 1995, I wa driving in on a Friday afternoon, beautiful blue sky, one of those beautiful day thinking, this is so stupid. "You know, I'm going do the Top 20 Countdown, take the cheque, go home, and sit on the internet until three in the morning. "So, after I finished the show, I quit. I said, on air, it's been great, I've been here for seven year at that point, there's something on the internet, I've got to go find it, and I'll see you later." But Mr Curry's technology and broadcast interest started to gel a couple of year ago when computer storage wa growing exponentially and high-speed internet connection were becoming more widely available. The MP3 format also meant that people could create and upload audio more cheaply and efficiently than ever before. Most importantly, Mr Curry says, people across the globe were bored with the radio they were hearing. "Listen to 99% of the radio that you hear today, it's radio voices, and it's fake, it's just fake." He wanted to make it easier for people to find "real voices" on the internet. He wanted software that would automatically download new audio content directly onto player like, iPods. Mr Curry is not a computer programmer, so he asked others to create one for him. No one did, so he tried to write one himself. He finished it a few month ago and say it "totally sucked." He put it up on the net a open source software and now dozen of coder and audio junky are refining it; the result is a work in progress called "ipodder". Doug Kaye, a California-based podcaster, praise the former MTV VJ for what he ha done. "Adam created a simple script that solved what we call the last mile problem. Ipodder take audio from the web and brings it all the way down to the MP3 player," he explains. "People can wake up in the morning, pick up their iPods a they go to work or before they go exercise, and discover that there's all this new content automatically put onto their players." It is created an explosion in podcasting content and podcasters are springing up in Australia, Finland, Brazil, even Malaysia. One couple broadcast theirs, The Dawn and Drew Show, from Wisconsin in the US, sometimes even from the comfort of their own bed. Topics range from the comfort of their bed, to the latest film or music and have thousand of listeners. Already, website are springing up that point listener in the right direction of good podcasts. Chris McIntyre run Podcast Alley and say that there are good site out there but that not everyone ha the technological know-how to simply listen. "If I were to tell my mom, or my mother-in-law to copy an XML or RSS file to their podcast aggregator, they would think I wa speaking a foreign language," Mr McIntyre says. Along with technical challenges, there may be legal challenge to podcasters who air their favourite, albeit copyrighted, music. Some in podcasting also worry that too much attention may turn what they see a the "anti-radio" into something that is more like conventional broadcasting. Already there is interest in podcasting from the corporate world. Heineken is doing it own podcast now, and so is Playboy. For his part, Adam Curry's pressing ahead with his own vision of what podcasting should be. He love doing The Daily Source Code because it is about introducing good music and cool idea to new audiences. He ha even been called the Ed Sullivan or Johnny Carson of podcasting which, he says, "is a badge I'll wear with great honour. "To be the Johnny Carson, or Ed Sullivan of anything is wonderful. And you know what? You don't need a hell of a lot of talent. "You just have to be nice, have your ear open, and let people shine. And that's good for me." Clark Boyd is technology correspondent for The World, a BBC World Service and WGBH-Boston co-production.

Title: Apple sues to stop product leaks
Article: Computer firm Apple ha issued a lawsuit to prevent online leak of information about future products. The lawsuit, against an unidentified individual, come just week before the MacWorld conference in San Francisco, used to showcase new products. The complaint said an "unidentified individual... ha recently misappropriated and disseminated confidential information". The lawsuit wa filed with the Santa Clara California Superior Court. Apple is famously secretive about it future product launch while Apple user are equally famous for speculating about new technology from the company. Fans have speculated in recent week about the possibility of a new type of iPod being announced at the MacWorld conference. Apple said in the seven-page complaint, filed on 13 December, that it did not know the "true name or capacities, whether individual, associate, corporate or otherwise," of the defendants. The company said it would amend the complaint once they had discovered the name of those who had allegedly leaked information. It is not the first time Apple ha sued people who have posted information about future product on the internet. In December 2002, Apple sued a former contractor who allegedly posted online drawings, image and engineering detail of the company's PowerMac G4 computer. In a statement, Apple said of the current lawsuit: "Apple ha filed a civil complaint against unnamed individual who we believe stole our trade secret and posted detailed information about an unannounced Apple product on the internet."

Title: Chinese exports rise 25% in 2004
Article: Exports from China leapt during 2004 over the previous year a the country continued to show breakneck growth. The spurt put China's trade surplus - a sore point with some of it trading partner - at a six-year high. It may also increase pressure on China to relax the peg joining it currency, the yuan, with the weakening dollar. The figure released by the Ministry of Commerce come a China's tax chief confirmed that growth had topped 9% in 2004 for the second year in a row. State Administration of Taxation head Xie Xuren said a tightening of control on tax evasion had combined with the rapid expansion to produce a 25.7% rise in tax revenue to 2.572 trillion yuan ($311bn; Â£165bn). According to the Ministry of Commerce, China's export totalled $63.8bn in December, taking the annual total up 35.4% to $593.4bn. With import rising a similar amount, the deficit rose to $43.4bn. The increased tax take come despite healthy tax rebate for many exporter totalling 420bn yuan in 2004, according to Mr Xie. China's exporting success ha made the trade deficit of the United States soar even further and made trade with China a sensitive political issue in Washington. The peg keeping the yuan around 8.30 to the dollar is often blamed by US lawmaker for job loss at home. A US report issued on Tuesday on behalf of a Congressionally-mandated panel said almost 1.5 million post disappeared between 1989 and 2003. The pace accelerated in the final three year of the period, said the report for the US-China Economic and Security Review Commission, moving out of labour-intensive industry and into more hi-tech sectors. The US's overall trade deficit with China wa $124bn in 2003, and is expected to rise to about $150bn for 2004.

Title: French boss to leave EADS
Article: The French co-head of European defence and aerospace group EADS Philippe Camus is to leave his post. Mr Camus said in a statement that he ha accepted the invitation to return full-time to the Lagardere group, which owns 30% of EADS. "I will give up my role a soon a the board of director asks me to do so," he said. Airbus head Noel Forgeard is now set to replace Mr Camus, bringing the company's power struggle to an end. Fighting between Mr Camus and Mr Forgeard ha hit the headline in France and analyst feared that this fighting could destabilise the defence and aerospace group. French finance minister Herve Gaymard is on record a saying that he "deplored" the infighting at the company. The company should now be able put this dispute behind it, with the departure of Mr Camus and with the clear support given to Mr Forgeard by the Lagardere group, the main French shareholder of EADS. The other main shareholder of EADS are the French government (15%) , who also support Mr Forgeard, and Germany's DaimlerChrysler (30%). Rainer Hertrich, the German co-head of EADS will also step down when his contract expires next year. Mr Camus recently came under pressure a it became clear that the A380 superjumbo wa running over budget. EADS - Airbus' majority owner - admitted earlier this week that the project wa running 1.45bn euro (Â£1bn; $1.9bn) over budget. But Mr Forgeard ha denied this, telling French medium that there is no current overrun in the budget. "But for the sake of transparency, we told our shareholder last week that if we look at the forecast for total cost of the project up to 2010, there is a risk that we will go over by around 10%, which is about 1bn euro (Â£686m; $1.32bn)," he told France's LCI Television. Due to enter service in 2006, the A380 will replace the Boeing 747 jumbo a the world's biggest passenger aircraft.

Title: Text message record smashed
Article: UK mobile owner continue to break record with their text messaging, with latest figure showing that 26 billion text were sent in total in 2004. The figure collected by the Mobile Data Association (MDA) showed that 2.4 billion were fired off in December alone, the highest monthly total ever. That wa 26% more than in December 2003. The record even surpassed the MDA's own predictions, it said. Every day 78 million message are sent and there are no sign of a slow down. Before December's bumper text record, the previous highest monthly total wa in October 2004, when 2.3 billion were sent. Text messaging is set to smash more record in 2005 too, said the MDA, with forecast suggesting a total of 30 billion for the year. Even though mobile are becoming increasingly sophisticated with much more multimedia applications, texting is still one of the most useful function of mobiles. People are using SMS to do much more too. Booking cinema tickets, text voting, and news or sport text alert are growing popular. Mobile owner have also given the chance to donate to the Disasters Emergency Committee's (DEC) Asian Tsunami fund by texting "Donate" to a simple short code number. Looking further ahead in the year, the MDA's chairman Mike Short, ha predicted that more people will go online through their mobiles, estimating 15 billion WAP page impressions. Handsets with GPRS capability - an "always on" net connection - will rise to 75%, while 3G mobile ownership growing to five million by the end of 2005. These third generation mobile offer a high-speed connection which mean more data like video can be received on the phone. Globally, mobile phone sale passed 167 million in the third quarter of 2004, according to a recent report from analyst Gartner. That wa 26% more than the previous year. It is predicted that there would be two billion handset in use worldwide by the end of 2005.

Article: Movie monster Godzilla ha received a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame, honouring both his 50th birthday and the launch of his 28th film. An actor dressed a the giant creature breathed smoke over photographer on Monday a Godzilla received the 2,271st star on Hollywood Boulevard. "Godzilla should thank you for this historical and monumental star," said Final Wars producer Shogo Tomiyama. "But unfortunately, he cannot speak English," he added. Title: Christmas sales worst since 1981
Article: UK retail sale fell in December, failing to meet expectation and making it by some count the worst Christmas since 1981. Retail sale dropped by 1% on the month in December, after a 0.6% rise in November, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said. The ONS revised the annual 2004 rate of growth down from the 5.9% estimated in November to 3.2%. A number of retailer have already reported poor figure for December. Clothing retailer and non-specialist store were the worst hit with only internet retailer showing any significant growth, according to the ONS. The last time retailer endured a tougher Christmas wa 23 year previously, when sale plunged 1.7%. The ONS echoed an earlier caution from Bank of England governor Mervyn King not to read too much into the poor December figures. Some analyst put a positive gloss on the figures, pointing out that the non-seasonally-adjusted figure showed a performance comparable with 2003. The November-December jump last year wa roughly comparable with recent averages, although some way below the serious boom seen in the 1990s. And figure for retail volume outperformed measure of actual spending, an indication that consumer are looking for bargains, and retailer are cutting their prices. However, report from some High Street retailer highlight the weakness of the sector. Morrisons, Woolworths, House of Fraser, Marks & Spencer and Big Food all said that the festive period wa disappointing. And a British Retail Consortium survey found that Christmas 2004 wa the worst for 10 years. Yet, other retailer - including HMV, Monsoon, Jessops, Body Shop and Tesco - reported that festive sale were well up on last year. Investec chief economist Philip Shaw said he did not expect the poor retail figure to have any immediate effect on interest rates. "The retail sale figure are very weak, but a Bank of England governor Mervyn King indicated last night, you don't really get an accurate impression of Christmas trading until about Easter," said Mr Shaw. "Our view is the Bank of England will keep it powder dry and wait to see the big picture."

Title: 'No-one can define new hunt ban'
Article: The new law banning hunting with dog is "so poorly drafted" no-one can define the offence, pro-hunt MPs say. The accusation came after it emerged a Devon man had been told he could use his four dog to "chase away unwanted animals" from his farm. Because he did not intend to kill deer or fox it wa not hunting. Lib Dem MP Lembit Opik said minister had invented a new category of hunting - chasing away - and asked how police were supposed to interpret the rules. North Devon landowner Giles Bradshaw wa put in touch with the Middle Way Group, of which Mr Opik is a co-chairman, after he had been in contact with the rural affair ministry, Defra. He had asked whether his technique of using his four dog to frighten off deer and fox would be outlawed under the Hunting Act. Mr Bradshaw wa initially told it wa an offence - prompting him to complain. The Middle Way group also said Mr Bradshaw would be put in a position where he would have to buy a rifle to shoot animal that would have previously gone free. In a later conversation Mr Bradshaw wa told that according to Defra's lawyer chasing away unwanted animal wa "not in fact hunting a described in the Hunting Act 2004 therefore you would not be committing an offence". Mr Opik said: "Hunting with dog and flushing are not defined in the Hunting Act. "Now Defra have also invented a completely new category of hunting - 'chasing away' which isn't even covered by the Act. "However, all these activity involve the use of dog to chase wild mammals. "How is the village bobby who see a group of people with dog supposed to distinguish between illegal hunting, exempt hunting, drag hunting, unintentional hunting, a hunt exercising hound or simply chasing away?" Tory MP Peter Luff, another co-chairman of Middle Way, said that the legislation wa "so poorly drafted nobody appears able to properly define the offence". "It is no wonder the government desperately want to move on from this disastrous law. However, I seriously doubt the countryside will be that accommodating." Mike Hobday, of the League Against Cruel Sports, said: "There is no confusion, it is a matter of simple common sense. "If Mr Bradshaw is setting his dog to chase wild animal then he is hunting them and that will be a criminal offence. "If all the dog are doing is barking at the deer, then nobody can define that a hunting."

Title: Soaring oil 'hits world economy'
Article: The soaring cost of oil ha hit global economic growth, although world's major economy should weather the storm of price rises, according to the OECD. In it latest bi-annual report, the OECD cut it growth prediction for the world's main industrialised regions. US growth would reach 4.4% in 2004, but fall to 3.3% next year from a previous estimate of 3.7%, the OECD said. However, the Paris-based economics think tank said it believed the global economy could still regain momentum. Forecasts for Japanese growth were also scaled back to 4.0% from 4.4% this year and 2.1% from 2.8% in 2005. But the outlook wa worst for the 12-member eurozone bloc, with already sluggish growth forecast slipping to 1.8% from 2.0% this year and 1.9% from 2.4% in 2005, the OECD said. Overall, the report forecast total growth of 3.6% in 2004 for the 30 member country of the OECD, slipping to 2.9% next year before recovering to 3.1% in 2006. "There are nonetheless good reason to believe that despite recent oil price turbulence the world economy will regain momentum in a not-too-distant future," said Jean-Philippe Cotis, the OECD's chief economist. The price of crude is about 50% higher than it wa at the start of 2004, but down on the record high of $55.67 set in late October. A dip in oil price and improving job prospect would improve consumer confidence and spending, the OECD said. "The oil shock is not enormous by historical standard - we have seen worse in the seventies. If the oil price doe not rise any further, then we think the shock can be absorbed within the next few quarters," Vincent Koen, a senior economist with the OECD, told the BBC's World Business Report. "The recovery that wa underway, and ha been interrupted a bit by the oil shock this year, would then regain momentum in the course of 2005." China's booming economy and a "spectacular comeback" in Japan - albeit one that ha faltered in recent month - would help world economic recovery, the OECD said. "Supported by strong balance sheet and high profits, the recovery of business investment should continue in North America and start in earnest in Europe," it added. However, the report warned: "It remains to be seen whether continental Europe will play a strong supportive role through a marked upswing of final domestic demand." The OECD highlighted current depressed household expenditure in Germany and the eurozone's over-reliance on export-led growth.

Title: Hillbillies singer Scoggins dies
Article: Country and Western musician Jerry Scoggins ha died in Los Angeles at the age of 93, his family ha said. Scoggins wa best remembered for singing the theme tune to popular US TV show The Beverly Hillbillies. The Texan-born singer approached the producer of the programme with theme tune The Ballad of Jed Clampett for the pilot which wa screened in 1962. The show, which told the story of a poor man striking oil and moving to Beverly Hills, ran until 1971. Scoggins' daugher Jane Kelly Misel said that her father never tired of the song and would sing it at least once a day. "He'd sing it at birthday and anniversary and variety shows. He never stopped performing it," she said. When a film version of The Beverly Hillbillies wa made in 1993, Scoggins came out of retirement to perform the theme tune. Scoggins sang the lyric while bluegrass star Lester Flatt and Earl Scruggs played guitar and banjo.

Title: Candidate resigns over BNP link
Article: A prospective candidate for the UK Independence Party (UKIP) ha resigned after admitting a "brief attachment" to the British National Party(BNP). Nicholas Betts-Green, who had been selected to fight the Suffolk Coastal seat, quit after report in a newspaper that he attended a BNP meeting. The former teacher confirmed he had attended the meeting but said that wa the only contact he had with the group. Mr Betts-Green resigned after being questioned by the party's leadership. A UKIP spokesman said Mr Betts-Green's resignation followed disclosure in the East Anglian Daily Times last month about his attendance at a BNP meeting. "He did once attend a BNP meeting. He did not like what he saw and heard and will take no further part of it," the spokesman added. A meeting of Suffolk Coastal UKIP member is due to be held next week to discus a replacement. Mr Betts-Green, of Woodbridge, Suffolk, ha also resigned a UKIP's branch chairman.

Title: Asylum children to face returns
Article: The UK government is planning to return asylum seeker child without parent to Albania. The trial scheme, which could start in weeks, may be extended to apply to child from other countries. Children's charity have reacted with alarm, saying the policy amount to forcible removal and may not guarantee the safety of those affected. But the Home Office say it may be in the children's best interest if it reunites them with their communities. The pilot, included in the government's five-year immigration plan, aim to return unaccompanied asylum-seeking child from Albania who have failed in their asylum claims. Since 2002, at least 9,000 under-18s have arrived in the UK to seek asylum without other family members. These child automatically become the responsibility of social services. Up to now, minister have held back from final removal order against unaccompanied child until after they are legally adult at 18. At least a dozen Albanian-born teenager are thought to have been identified for return, according to sources, although there is no public confirmation of numbers. Those selected could either be returned to their families, should they be traced, or placed in the care of other Albanian authorities. Separate negotiation to establish a family tracing and return scheme are believed to be underway with another country. Under the 1989 Children Act, public body have a duty to act in the "best interest" of a child in their care. Laura Brownlees of Save the Children said there were grave concerns, not least because of the well-documented trafficking of child into crime and prostitution in Albania. "If child are going to be returned then there should be proper assessment and decision on a case by case basis," she said. "We do not think there are structure in place [to receive returning child in Albania]. 'If these decision are not in the best interest of the child, then that is a forced removal because the child will not have any choice in the final decision." In it five-year immigration plan, announced on Tuesday, the government said it wa addressing "the difficult issue" of returning unaccompanied asylum seeking children. A spokesman for the Home Office said it wa wholly wrong to suggest that the plan wa to return child "and leave them to rot". "We are developing a return programme for unaccompanied asylum-seeking child whose asylum and humanitarian protection claim have been refused," said the spokesman. "We have been exploring how we can establish reception and longer-term care arrangement in country of origin and believe that it's possible to return child in a way that is in their best interest and is safe and sustainable. "We do not believe that it is right, or in keeping with children's legislation, that child who can return should remain in the UK indefinitely separated from their family and communities." The spokesman stressed the UK would abide by it international human right obligations. Only those child who could be provided with a carefully planned reintegration package would be returned, he said. But Andrew Hogg, spokesman for the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture, said minister had so far failed to reassure agencies. "From what is so far known, we strongly oppose the scheme because the welfare and best interest of the child will not properly be taken into account," said Mr Hogg. "In Albania particularly there is no statutory child care or protection structure. "The Medical Foundation ha many serious concerns, including the assessment process for suitability for return, the degrading of best interest of the child principle and of child welfare, and the lack of safeguard in the chosen countries." A spokesman for the Albanian embassy in London said it wa the first it had heard of a scheme, but did not rule out that there had been an agreement between the two countries.

Title: France Telecom gets Orange boost
Article: Strong growth in subscription to mobile phone network Orange ha helped boost profit at owner France Telecom. Orange added more than five million new customer in 2004, leading to a 10% increase in it revenues. Increased take-up of broadband telecom service also boosted France Telecom's profits, which showed a 5.5% rise to 18.3bn euro ($23.4bn; Â£12.5bn). France Telecom is to spend 578m euro on buying out minority shareholder in data service provider Equant. France Telecom, one of the world's largest telecom and internet service providers, saw it full-year sale rise 2.2% to 47.2bn euro in 2004. Title: Survey confirms property slowdown
Article: Government figure have confirmed a widely reported slowdown of the UK's housing market in late 2004. House price were 11.8% higher on the year in the last quarter of 2004, down from 16.3% in the July-to-September quarter, the Land Registry said. The average house price in England and Wales wa Â£182,920, down from Â£187,971 in July-September. The volume of sale between October and December dropped by nearly a quarter from the same period in 2003. The government figure are the first official confirmation of fall in the market at the end of 2004. Land Registry figure are less up to date than those of bank and building societies, since they record completion not mortgage approvals. However, the figure are viewed a the most accurate measure of house price a they include all property transactions, including cash sales. The cost of buying a home fell in seven out of 10 region between the third and fourth quarter of 2004. The biggest annual gain were made in Wales, where house price were up by 23% in the fourth quarter. House price rose the slowest in Greater London, being up by 6%. In the capital, the volume of sale fell by 23% from 36,185 in 2003 to 28,041 for the same period in 2004. There wa also a decline in the number of million-pound property sold in the capital, with 436 property over Â£1m sold compared to 469 for the same period in 2003. Although the figure point to a slowdown in the market, the most recent survey from Nationwide and Halifax have indicated the market may be undergoing a revival. After registering fall at the back end of 2004, Halifax said house price rose by 0.8% in January and Nationwide reported a rise of 0.4% in the first month of the year. Members of the Bank of England's rate-setting committee will make their latest decision on interest rate on Thursday.

Article: Vodafone ha drafted in it UK chief executive William Morrow to take charge of it troubled Japanese operation. Mr Morrow will succeed Shiro Tsuda a president of Vodafone KK, Japan's number three mobile operator, in April. Mr Tsuda, who will become chairman, wa appointed president only two month ago but the business ha struggled since then, losing customer in January. Vodafone had pinned it hope on the launch of it 3G phone in November but demand for them ha been slow. While it ha more than 15 million customer in Japan, Vodafone ha found it difficult to satisfy Japan's technologically demanding mobile users. It suffered a net loss of more than 58,000 customer in January, it second monthly reverse in the last year. "Vodafone is going to need to put a lot of money into Japan if it want to rebuild the business," Tetsuro Tsusaka, a telecom analyst with Deutsche Bank, told Reuters. "I do not know if it will be worth it for them to spend that kind of money just for Japan."

Title: UK's National Gallery in the pink
Article: The National Gallery, home to some of the UK's greatest artworks, ha seen a big jump in visitor numbers. Five million visitor made the London gallery - which house treasure like Raphael's Madonna of the Pinks - the UK's most visited museum in 2004. It recorded a 13.8% rise in number and wa the country's second most visited tourist attraction, behind Blackpool Pleasure Beach. Charles Saumarez Smith, the gallery's director, said he wa "delighted". He said the number of visitor through the door had boosted figure to pre-11 September 2001 levels. Mr Saumarez Smith added that the pedestrianisation of Trafalgar Square, where the gallery is located, and strong temporary collection throughout 2004 had led to the strong performance. "Our 2004 exhibition programme of El Greco, Russian Landscape in the Age of Tolstoy and Raphael: From Urbino to Rome wa particularly strong and exceeded all targets," he said. "The exceptional quality of the painting in our permanent collection is also huge draw for the public. "The expectation of today's visitor are higher than ever and we have kept pace with their demands." Mr Saumarez Smith said he wa confident the gallery could maintain the attendance. "With important exhibition of the work of Caravaggio, Stubbs and Rubens in place for 2005, I am confident that the gallery is set for another highly successful year," he added. The figure were prepared by the Association of Leading Visitor Attractions (Alva). It found that the figure had been boosted by an increase in Europeans travelling to the UK on budget airlines. Popular cultural tourist spot such a the Tate Modern and the Natural History Museum all recorded increase of more than 10% in visitor number compared with 2003. But for legal or confidentiality reason some Alva member did not submit figure for 2004, including Buckingham Palace, Windsor Castle, Madame Tussauds and Alton Towers. Alva director Robin Broke said: "Visits from Western Europe were up by 10% and from North America by some 9% compared to 2003, while number from the rest of the world rose 20%. "European figure were helped by the rapid growth of low-cost flight to Britain from Europe, especially from new EU countries."

Title: Versace art portfolio up for sale
Article: The art collection of murdered fashion designer Gianni Versace could fetch up to Â£9m ($17m) when it is auctioned in New York and London later this year. Among the picture for sale are work by Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol and Henri Matisse. The collection wa housed at Versace's six-storey New York townhouse. The 51-year-old designer wa shot outside his Florida home in 1997 by suspected serial killer Andrew Cunanan, who later killed himself. The auction, at Sotheby's, will feature 45 contemporary, impressionist and 19th Century paintings. One of the highlight of the sale is Roy Lichtenstein's Blue Nude which ha been given an estimate of Â£1.8m ($3.4m). Tobias Meyer, Sotheby's worldwide head of contemporary art, said: "This collection reflects Mr Versace's wide-ranging taste and impeccable eye, and many of the work were commissioned directly from the artists. "Outstanding later example from champion of the Pop movement, such a Roy Lichtenstein, are juxtaposed with masterpiece from the most visible artist of the 1980's, including Jean-Michel Basquiat and the collaborative genius of Basquiat and Warhol, a well a Francesco Clemente." Much of the collection will be offered for sale at three auction in New York in June, with smaller contemporary painting going under the hammer in London on 22 and 23 June. A sale of Versace's furniture and artwork sold in 2001fetched Â£5.5m ($10.3m).

Title: G7 backs Africa debt relief plan
Article: G7 finance minister have backed plan to write off up to 100% of the debt of some of the world's poorest countries. UK chancellor Gordon Brown said the London meeting of the world's seven richest nation would be remembered a "the 100% debt relief summit". Some 37 country could benefit after a case-by-case review by body including the World Bank and the IMF, he said. But the US say it cannot support Mr Brown's International Finance Facility to boost aid to developing countries. BBC correspondent said the meeting had produced some movement towards the UK's ambitions, but much work wa needed. Mr Brown said it wa a major breakthrough for the international organisation to offer up to 100% multilateral debt relief - "the vast bulk" of money owed by the poorest countries. "We could be at the beginning of the final stage of the process where the debt that were owed by the poorest countries, built up over 20 or 30 years, debt that are simply unpayable in the real world, are finally taken care of," he said. He added: "It is the richest country hearing the voice of the poor." But he said they would insist on government reform and the need for transparency, tackling corruption and openness from both the poorest and richest nations. BBC correspondent Patrick Bartlett said while it wa an agreement in principle, the organisation involved now have to look at how it would work in practice. Oxfam senior policy adviser Max Lawson welcomed the statement and said G7 minister had "passed the first hurdle of 2005". But he added: "They need to move quickly to turn their proposal into real change for the world's poorest. "Two million child will die needlessly between now and the next meeting in April. If rich country are going to keep their promise to tackle obscene poverty they need deliver - and deliver quickly." Talks are continuing on how to finance increased overseas development assistance. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is to look at a proposal to use it gold supply to help the debt relief effort when it meet in April. Mr Brown said G7 minister had agreed to defer debt interest payment and repayment for some country affected by the tsunami until the end of 2005. But UK plan for an International Finance Facility (IFF) to help deal with debt in the developing world have not been agreed. Mr Brown wanted to provide $10bn (Â£5.38bn) a year over a decade, using G7 backing so the money could be borrowed up front on financial markets. It is a key element of his proposal for a modern version of the Marshall Plan, which brought US aid to rebuild Europe after World War II, for the developing world. Mr Brown said it wa "winning support every day" and said a programme had been agreed to draw up more detail in time for the G8 summit in July. But US Treasury Under-Secretary John Taylor said the US could not support the IFF because of it "legislative process". "The US is completely committed to poverty reduction and providing financing to do that," he said. "But this particular mechanism doe not work for the United States. It work for other countries, and that is fine." Earlier, he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme the US had increased support for Africa in the past four year from $1.1bn per year to $4.6bn per year. But South Africa Finance Minister Trevor Manuel told the BBC's Talking Point programme what wa needed wa one approach, with all wealthy nation on board. He said much of the money pledged by the US had not yet been dispensed. The UK ha made poverty in the poorest nation a key theme for it 2005 presidency of the Group of Eight (G8), which comprises the G7 and Russia. The G8 country will meet at Gleneagles in Scotland. At a dinner on Friday night, former South African president Nelson Mandela backed Mr Brown's plan when he urged the finance chief to write-off African debt and provide an extra $50bn (Â£26.69bn) a year in aid for the next decade. Talks also centred on the impact of the rising economy of China and India, the US budget and trade deficits, how the US, Europe and Japan can act to boost global economic growth, and HIV/Aids. G7 minister called for more flexibility in international exchange rate and said "excess volatility" would impede economic growth. Representatives from China, India, Russia, South Africa and Brazil were invited to attend some of the sessions. A G8 summit is set to take place in July.

Title: Lennon brands Rangers favourites
Article: Celtic's Neil Lennon admits Rangers could be considered "slight favourites" for the Old Firm CIS Cup clash, but insists his side can still win. Lennon concedes Rangers are in good form at the moment, but they have failed to beat Celtic in their last seven meetings. "Rangers are on the up and have been on a good run in recent weeks," he said. "But it's a game we believe we're capable of winning if we play our best," he told the Evening Times. "All the boy are looking forward to it because they are brilliant game to be involved in. "Without playing at the top of our game, we have still been winning matches. "At the minute, we are at the top of the league and still in with a chance of staying in Europe, so I don't think it is the crisis people have been trying to make out. "Of course, it is a concern when you are losing goals, because we have been notorious for being a team that is hard to beat and keeping clean sheets, but hopefully we are over that wee run. "Considering we lost Henrik Larsson at the end of last season, we have still been scoring a lot of goals, which is pleasing."

Title: Elvis fans hold birthday bash
Article: Elvis fan around the world have been marking the legendary singer's 70th birthday on Saturday. A three-day Elvis convention took place in Blackpool, England, over the weekend with the aim of finding the best European Elvis impersonator. His Graceland, Tennessee, home wa the focus for US celebration with four day of event including a concert by the Memphis Symphony Orchestra. Elvis' single Jailhouse Rock became the UK's number one on Sunday. Fans in France celebrated with a tribute concert by Elvis cover band and a special exhibition of memorabilia is on display in Bonn, Germany. Jailhouse Rock is now the 999th number one single in UK pop history. Record company SonyBMG are releasing Elvis' 18 number one single at the rate of one a week in Britain, complete with original artwork and a collector's box. Hit single One Night will follow next week - with the chance of becoming the 1,000th number one a interest surrounding Elvis' birthday grows. HMV spokesman Gennaro Castaldo said: "It would be a fantastic and truly fitting way to celebrate Elvis' landmark birthday."

Title: US consumer confidence up
Article: Consumers' confidence in the state of the US economy is at it highest for five month and they are optimistic about 2005, an influential survey says. The feel-good factor among US consumer rose in December for the first time since July according to new data. The Conference Board survey of 5,000 household pointed to renewed optimism about job creation and economic growth. US retailer have reported strong sale over the past 10 day after a slow start to the crucial festive season. According to figure also released on Tuesday, sale in shopping mall in the week to 25 December were 4.3% higher than in 2003 following a last minute rush. Wal-Mart, the largest US retailer, ha said it December sale are expected to be better than previously forecast because of strong post-Christmas sales. It is expecting annual sale growth of between 1% and 3% for the month. Consumer confidence figure are considered a key economic indicator because consumer spending account for about two third of all economic activity in the United States. "The continuing economic expansion, combined with job growth, ha consumer ending this year on a high note," said Lynn Franco, director of the Conference Board's consumer research centre. "And consumers' outlook suggests that the economy will continue to expand in the first half of next year." The overall US economy ha performed strongly in recent months, prompting the Federal Reserve to increase interest rate five time since June.

Title: Ukraine steel sell-off 'illegal'
Article: The controversial sell-off of a Ukrainian steel mill to a relative of the former president wa illegal, a court ha ruled. The mill, Krivorizhstal, wa sold in June 2004 for $800m (Â£424m) - well below other offers. President Viktor Yushchenko, elected in December, is planning to revisit many of Ukraine's recent privatisations. Krivorizhstal is one of dozen of firm which he say were sold cheaply to friend of the previous administration. On Wednesday, Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko said a many a 3,000 firm could be included on the list of firm whose sale wa being reviewed. Mr Yushchenko had previously said the list would be limited to 30-40 enterprises. More than 90,000 business in all, from massive corporation to tiny shopfronts, have been sold off since 1992, a the command economy built up when Ukraine wa part of the Soviet Union wa dismantled. Analysts have suggested that the government need to avoid the impression of an open-ended list, so a to preserve investor confidence. Thursday's ruling by a district court in Perchesk overturned a previous decision in a lower court permitting the sale. The consortium which won the auction for the mill wa created by Viktor Pinchuk, son-in-law of former-President Leonid Kuchma, and Rinat Akhmetov, the country's richest man. The next step is for the supreme court to annul the sale altogether, opening the way for Krivorizhstal to be resold. Mr Yushchenko ha suggested a fair valuation could be a much a $3bn. Article: Archbishop Desmond Tutu ha called for the release of the remaining inmate at Guantanamo Bay and terror suspect detained without trial in the UK. His comment follow news that all four Britons held by the US in the Cuban camp will be freed within weeks. The South African archbishop said detention without trial were "unacceptable" and "distressing". Twelve foreign national are being held indefinitely without trial in the UK under anti-terror laws. Referring to the detention in Cuba, Archbishop Tutu told BBC News: "It is utterly unacceptable. "The rule of law is in order to ensure that those who have power don't use their power arbitrarily and every person retains their human right until you have proven conclusively that so-and-so is in fact guilty." Moazzam Begg, from Birmingham, and Martin Mubanga, Richard Belmar and Feroz Abbasi, from London, have been held by the US at Guantanamo Bay for almost three years. On Tuesday Foreign Secretary Jack Straw told the Commons that the US had agreed to release the four after "intensive and complex discussions" over security. The Britons were detained a part of the US-led "war on terror". The archbishop added: "Whilst we are saying thank you that these have been released, what is happening to those left behind? "We in South Africa used to have a dispensation that detained people without trial and the world quite rightly condemned that a unacceptable. "Now if it wa unacceptable then how come it can be acceptable to Britain and the United States. It is so, so deeply distressing." Following Mr Straw's announcement, lawyer Louise Christian, who represents Mr Abbasi and Mr Mubanga, said the government should have acted sooner. Foreign national detained in the UK are being held at Belmarsh and Woodhill prisons. In December the House of Lords, the UK's highest court, ruled that the anti-terror measure broke human right laws. Shami Chakrabarti, director of civil right group Liberty, ha called on the government to "practise what it preaches" and either free or charge the detained men. A spokesman said: "These individual cannot currently be prosecuted because some evidence, such a that provided by third parties, cannot safely be disclosed in criminal proceeding without putting others at risk. "It is also currently the case that intelligence gained from covert intercept cannot be used in a court of law."

Title: Fit-again Betsen in France squad
Article: France have brought flanker Serge Betsen back into their squad to face England at Twickenham on Sunday. But the player, who missed the victory over Scotland through injury, must attend a disciplinary hearing on Wednesday after being cited by Wasps. "Serge ha a good case so we are confident he will play," said France coach Bernard Laporte. The inexperienced Nicolas Mas, Jimmy Marlu and Jean-Philippe Grandclaude are also included in a 22-man squad. The trio have been called up after Pieter de Villiers, Ludovic Valbon and Aurelien Rougerie all picked up injury in France's 16-9 win on Saturday. Laporte said he wa confident that Betsen would be cleared by the panel investigating his alleged trip that broke Wasps centre Stuart Abbott's leg. "If he wa to be suspended, we would call up Imanol Harinordoquy or Thomas Lievremont," said Laporte, who ha dropped Patrick Tabacco. "We missed Serge badly against Scotland. He ha now recovered from his thigh injury and played on Saturday with Biarritz." France's regular back-row combination of Betsen, Harinordoquy and Olivier Magne were all missing from France's side at the weekend because of injury. Laporte is expected to announce France's starting line-up on Wednesday. Title: Strike threat over pension plans
Article: Millions of public service worker could strike if minister scrap their final salary pension scheme and make them work longer, warn union leaders. The Cabinet Office ha confirmed it is reviewing the current pension system, prompting union representing 4.5m worker to threaten united action. They believe the plan include raising the mandatory retirement age for public service worker from 60 to 65. The government say union will be consulted before any change are made. It is thought the proposed overhaul, due on Thursday, could mean pension could be based on a "career average" salary. For each year served, staff currently get one eightieth of their highest salary in the final three years. Ministers will be anxious to avoid mass strike action in the lead-up to the next general election, which is widely expected next May. In a statement on Sunday, the Cabinet Office said it wa reviewing the Civil Service Pension Scheme, and hoped to announce proposal soon. "Unions will of course be consulted about any proposed changes. "Public sector pension scheme need to remain affordable and sustainable. People are living longer and pension are getting more expensive. "To maintain the long-term affordability of our pension scheme, the government announced in it Green Paper on pension that pension age would rise from 60 to 65." On Monday, Tony Blair's official spokesman declined to say whether the prime minister backed the plans. He said: "What's important is that there's a process going on, it's out for consultation at the moment, let's wait for that process to complete itself." There is already widespread anger over the chancellor's plan to get rid of more than 100,000 civil servants. Now public service union are united against the plan and the Trades Union Congress is discussing the issue next Monday. Dave Prentis, general secretary of Unison, said change to pension provision for worker in the public sector would mean they had to pay in more but would still face a raw deal. "Members working in the NHS or for local government have never had high pay or city bonuses, but they could look forward to a decent pension - now all that is being taken away," he said. "What really riles me is the breathtaking hypocrisy of MPs who recently voted themselves the best pension scheme in Europe, but say they can't afford it for anyone else. "This is a position that Unison cannot accept and will oppose. It will lead to conflict between Unison and the government, if not this year then next." Mr Prentis said worker did not want to go on strike and called for talk between union and the highest level of government. Mark Serwotka, from the Public and Commercial Services union said there should be a co-ordinated one day strike unless there wa a government rethink. The Fire Brigades Union said the government wa planning to cut ill health retirement benefit for firefighter and other measure to chip away at pensions. Pensions officer Paul Woolstenholmes said: "The pension of million of public sector worker are under threat - apart from MPs and judge who have the most generous pension arrangement in the country."

Title: Brown hits back in Blair rift row
Article: Gordon Brown ha criticised a union leader who said conflict between himself and Tony Blair wa harming the working of government. Jonathan Baume, of the top civil servants' union, spoke of "competing agendas" between Mr Brown and Mr Blair. But the chancellor said Mr Baume wa never at meeting between himself and the prime minister so could not judge. He said the union leader wa trying to block civil service reform which threatened his members' jobs. It suited the purpose of Mr Baume's union, the First Division Association, to suggest there were two agenda battling against each other because the union wa trying to resist the planned reforms, Mr Brown told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. Under the plans, unveiled in the Gershon report, some 84,000 civil servant job will be axed or changed and the saving ploughed back into frontline services. Mr Brown said: "To be honest I don't think you can rely on his [Mr Baume's] judgement on this matter when it come to the decision that the government are making. "Mr Blair and I are making exactly the same decision on civil service reforms. We are determined to go on with the Gershon reforms." He also said that a Mr Baume wa never present at meeting between himself and the prime minister, he wa not in a position to judge. On Wednesday, ahead of the Chancellor's pre-Budget report, Mr Baume told BBC News there were sometimes "conflicting and competing agenda for government" between Number 10 and the Treasury. What the chancellor wanted wa "not by any mean what Alan Milburn and the prime minister want to see", Mr Baume said. "Government department get their money from the Treasury on the basis of public service agreement they sign up to, but at the same time the prime minister also ha an agenda and that's not necessarily the same a the Treasury's and the prime minister is of course a very powerful figure in any government. "He also sends instruction and message and direction to department about how he would like each secretary of state and each department to implement a policy agenda. "The problem is that on many occasion these two don't add up and individual cabinet minister a well a department have to make sense of this battle." Number 10 said minister were interested in governing and not a "soap opera" about Mr Blair and Mr Brown. Tory shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin said: "The battle Royal that the top civil servant are now reporting on between the chancellor and Tony Blair is preventing them both from getting on with the business of getting taxpayer value for money."

Title: Solutions to net security fears
Article: Fake bank e-mails, or phishing, and story about ID theft are damaging the potential of using the net for online commerce, say e-business experts. Trust in online security is falling a a result. Almost 70% of those asked in a poll said that net firm are not doing enough to protect people. The survey of more than 1,000 people reported that 43% were not willing to hand over personal information online. It is worrying for shopaholic and firm who want to exploit the net. More people are becoming aware of online security issue but they have little confidence that company are doing enough to counter the threats, said security firm RSA, which carried out the poll. An estimated 12 million Britons now use the net a a way of managing their financial affairs. Security expert say that scare story and the vulnerability dogging e-commerce and e-banking are being taken seriously - by bank in particular. "I don't think the threat is overplayed," Barry Beal, global security manager for Capgemini, told the BBC News website. He added: "The challenge for bank is to provide the customer with something that improves security but balance that with usability." Ensuring extra security measure are in place protects them too, a well a the individual, and it is up to both party to make sure they do what is necessary to prevent fraud, he said. "Card issuer will keep u informed of type of attack and what procedure to take to protect ourselves. If we do that, they will indemnify us," he said. Many believe using login detail like usernames and password are simply not good enough anymore though. One of the biggest challenge to improving security online is how to authenticate an individual's identity. Several security company have developed method which complement or replace passwords, which are easily compromised and easy to forget. Last year, a street survey found that more than 70% of people would reveal their password for a bar of chocolate. On average, people have to remember four different passwords. Some resort to using the same one for all their online accounts. Those who use several password often write them down and hide them in a desk or in a document on their computer. In a separate survey by RSA, 80% said they were fed up with password and would like a better way to login to work computer systems. For many, the ideal is a single online identity that can be validated once with a series of password and questions, or some biometric measurement like a fingerprint or iris scan with a token like a smartcard. Activcard is just one of the many companies, like RSA Security, which ha been trying to come up with just that. RSA ha a deal with internet provider AOL that let people pay monthly for a one-time passcode generation service. Users get a physical token which automatically generates a code which stay active for 60 seconds. Many company use a token-based method already for employee to access network securely already. Activcard's method is more complex. It is currently trailing it one-time passcode generation technology with UK banks. Steve Ash, from Activcard, told the BBC News website there are two part to the process of identification. The most difficult is to ascertain whether an individual is who they say they are when they are online. "The end solution is to provide a method where you combine something the user know with something they have and present those both." The method it ha developed make use of the chip embedded in bank card and a special card reader which can generate unique code that are active for a specified amount of time. This can be adjusted at any time and can be active for a little a 30 second before it changes. It combine that with usual usernames and passwords, a well a other security questions. "You take the card, put it in the reader, enter your pin number, and a code is given. "If you wanted then to transfer funds, for instance, you would have to have the code to authorise the transaction." The clever bit happens back at the bank's secure servers. The code is validated by the bank's systems, matching the information they expect with the customer's unique key. "Each individual get a key which is unique to them. It is a 2048-bit long number that is virtually impossible to crack," said Mr Ash. It mean that in a typical security attack, explains Mr Ash, even if password information is captured by a scammer using keystroke software or just through spoof websites, they need the passcode. "By the time they go back [to use the information], the code ha expired, so they can't prove who they are," according to Mr Ash. In the next few years, Mr Ash predicts that this kind of method will be commonplace before we see biometric authentication that is acceptable for widespread use. "PCs will have reader built into them, the cost of reader will be very cheap, and more people will have the cards." The gadget we carry around, like personal digital assistant (PDAs) and mobiles, could also have integrated card reader technology in them. "The PDA or phone method is a possible alternative a people are always carrying phone around," he said.

Title: Beckham relief as Real go through
Article: David Beckham expressed his relief at Real Madrid's passage to the Champions League knockout phase. After Real's 3-0 win at Roma, the England skipper admitted another season of under-achievement would not be tolerated at the Bernabeu stadium. Beckham said: "It's expected of Madrid to get through, but it's a relief for the club and player to have won. "We lost momentum last season but we cannot afford to to go another season without winning anything." Real's finish a runner-up in their Champions League group mean they cannot face his old club Manchester United in the next round. But Real could be drawn against other Premiership hopefuls, Arsenal or Chelsea, who won their respective groups. "It's going to be great whoever we play, even if we don't get either of the two English teams."

Title: Cash gives way to flexible friend
Article: Spending on credit and debit card ha overtaken cash spending in the UK for the first time. The moment that plastic finally toppled cash happened at 10.38am on Wednesday, according to the Association for Payment Clearing Services (Apacs) Apacs chose school teacher Helen Carroll, from Portsmouth, to make the historic transaction. The switch over took place a she paid for her grocery in the supermarket chain Tesco's Cromwell Road branch. Mrs Carroll wa born in the same year that plastic card first appeared in the UK. "I pay for most thing with my debit card, with occasional purchase on one of my credit cards," said Mrs Carroll, who teach at Peel Common Infants School in Gosport. Spending pattern for the year and estimate for December led Apacs to conclude that 10.38am wa the time that plastic would finally rule the roost. Shoppers in the UK are expected to put Â£269bn on plastic card during the whole of 2004, compared with Â£268bn paid with cash, Apacs said. When the first plastic card appeared in the UK in June 1966, issued by Barclaycard, but only a handful of retailer accepted them and very few customer held them. "But in less than 40 years, plastic ha become our most popular way to pay, due to the added security and flexibility it offers," said Apacs spokeswoman Jemma Smith. "The key driver ha been the introduction of debit cards, which now account for two-thirds of plastic card transaction and are used by million of u every day."

Article: Ireland captain Brian O'Driscoll ha been ruled out of Saturday's RBS Six Nations clash against Scotland. Title: Man Utd through after Exeter test
Article: Manchester United avoided an FA Cup upset by edging past Exeter City in their third round replay. Cristiano Ronaldo scored the opener, slipping the ball between Paul Jones' leg after just nine minutes. United wasted a host of chance to make it safe a Jones made some great saves, but Wayne Rooney put the tie beyond doubt late on with a cool finish. Exeter had chance of their own, Sean Devine twice volleying wide and Andrew Taylor forcing Tim Howard to save. United bos Sir Alex Ferguson wa taking few chance after their 0-0 draw in the first game and he handed start to Paul Scholes and Ryan a well a Ronaldo and Rooney. Exeter began brightly with Devine and Steve Flack seeing plenty of the ball, but it did not take United long to assert their authority and the host soon found themselves a goal down. Scholes played a lovely pas in to Ronaldo on the left-hand side of the six-yard box and the Portuguese winger slid the ball between the leg of Jones to open the scoring. United sensed a chance to finish the tie a a contest early on and Ronaldo blazed over before Jones saved well from Scholes and then Rooney. The visitors' pressure by now wa incessant and Rooney had another shot blocked while Ronaldo slammed well over the bar again from a good position. Just before the break Giggs had a golden chance to double the advantage, but the Welshman dragged a left-foot effort badly wide from 10 yards. In stoppage time Exeter created their best chance a Alex Jeannin swung in a cross from the left that Devine managed to flick goalwards, but the ball flew wide of Howard's goal. The Grecians came out after the break in determined fashion and Howard had to show safe hand to collect two searching cross into the United box. Rooney looked like he might have sealed the result with a turn and shot but the ball stuck in the St James Park mud and Jones raced back to gather on the goalline. Moments later Devine had the chance to make himself a hero, but he could only volley Jeannin's brilliant cross wide of Howard's goal after being left unmarked six yard out. After Rooney had completely messed up a free-kick 20 yard out Taylor showed him how it should be done, his stunning drive from distance forcing a flying stop from Howard. The home crowd were baying for a goal and they did get the ball into the net only for Devine's low effort to be ruled out for an obvious offside. The persistent Rooney eventually rounded Jones with three minute to go and slotted into an empty net to book a home tie with Middlesbrough in the fourth round. Title: Casino Royale is next Bond movie
Article: Casino Royale, author Ian Fleming's first James Bond book, is to be the next Bond film, with Goldeneye director Martin Campbell behind the camera. It will be the 21st James Bond film to hit the big screen, and speculation ha been rife over who will play the lead. Casino Royale wa turned into a spoof spy movie by John Huston in 1967, with David Niven in the lead role. Pierce Brosnan led the past four Bond film but said producer axed him after offering him the chance to return. Among the favourite to take over the coveted role are Scottish actor Dougray Scott, Oscar nominee Clive Owen and Australian star Hugh Jackman. Producers say no decision ha yet been made on who will become the seventh actor, including Niven, to play Bond on film. Kill Bill director Quentin Tarantino had talked of wanting to take on the Casino Royale project, and said he had spoken to Brosnan about it. Shooting on Casino Royale is expected to begin once Campbell ha finished work on The Legend of Zorro, a sequel to The Mask of Zorro, starring Catherine Zeta Jones and Antonio Banderas. Producers Barbara Broccoli and Michael G Wilson expect the film to be released in 2006. The script will once again be developed by Neal Purvis and Robert Wade who have both worked on two previous Bond movies. Fleming's book saw the introduction of Bond pitted against a Russian spy in a game of baccarat. Simultaneously, a woman arrives on the scene to take his eye off the game. The novel is one of Fleming's most violent and sadistic stories, with 007 suffering a savage beating from his nemesis Le Chiffre. In addition to the 1967 film, it wa also adapted for television in 1954 with actor Barry Nelson a an Americanised "Jimmy" Bond. MGM Vice Chairman Chris McGurk said: "Martin (Campbell) is an incredibly exciting film-maker. Goldeneye wa a wonderful movie and helped reinvigorate the Bond franchise. We're thrilled to have him back to direct the newest Bond." New Zealand-born Campbell moved to the UK in 1966 and directed TV series such a The Professionals, Minder and Bergerac. His film credit include Edge of Darkness, Vertical Limit and Beyond Borders, which starred Angelina Jolie and Clive Owen.

Title: Feta cheese battle reaches court
Article: A row over whether only Greece should be allowed to label it cheese feta ha reached the European Court of Justice. The Danish and German government are challenging a European Commission ruling which said Greece should have sole right to use the name. The Commission's decision gave the same legal protection to feta a to Italian Parma ham and French Champagne. But critic of the judgement say feta is a generic term, with the cheese produced widely outside Greece. The Commission's controversial 2002 ruling gave "protected designation of origin" status to feta cheese made in Greece, effectively restricting the use of the feta name to producer there. From 2007 onwards, Greek firm will have the exclusive use of the feta label and producer elsewhere in Europe must find another name to describe their products. The German and Danish government argue that feta doe not relate to a specific geographical area and that their firm have been producing and exporting the cheese for years. "In our opinion it is a generic designation and we do not have any other name or term for this type of cheese," Hans Arne Kristiansen, a spokesman for the Danish Dairy Board, told the BBC. Denmark is Europe's second largest producer of feta after Greece - producing about 30,000 tonne a year - and export it product to Greece. It is concerned that the ruling could threaten the production of other cheese in Denmark such a brie. "It would cost million if we wanted to introduce a new designation," Mr Kristiansen said. "That is just one of the costs." The case will also have a major impact on Britain's sole feta producer, Yorkshire company Shepherds Purse Cheeses. Judy Bell, the company's founder, said it would cost a huge amount to rebrand it product. "If we lose we will have to go through a massive re-merchandising process and reorganisation," she said. "We have never tried to pull the wool over anyone's eye - it's very clear from the label that it's Yorkshire feta." The original decision wa a victory for Greece, where feta cheese is believed to have been produced for about 6,000 years. Feta is a soft white cheese made from sheep or goat's milk, and is an essential ingredient in Greek cuisine. Greece make 115,000 tonnes, mainly for domestic consumption. The Court is expected to reach a verdict in the case in the autumn.

Title: Japanese growth grinds to a halt
Article: Growth in Japan evaporated in the three month to September, sparking renewed concern about an economy not long out of a decade-long trough. Output in the period grew just 0.1%, an annual rate of 0.3%. Exports - the usual engine of recovery - faltered, while domestic demand stayed subdued and corporate investment also fell short. The growth fall well short of expectations, but doe mark a sixth straight quarter of expansion. The economy had stagnated throughout the 1990s, experiencing only brief spurt of expansion amid long period in the doldrums. One result wa deflation - price falling rather than rising - which made Japanese shopper cautious and kept them from spending. The effect wa to leave the economy more dependent than ever on export for it recent recovery. But high oil price have knocked 0.2% off the growth rate, while the falling dollar mean product shipped to the US are becoming relatively more expensive. The performance for the third quarter mark a sharp downturn from earlier in the year. The first quarter showed annual growth of 6.3%, with the second showing 1.1%, and economist had been predicting a much a 2% this time around. "Exports slowed while capital spending became weaker," said Hiromichi Shirakawa, chief economist at UBS Securities in Tokyo. "Personal consumption look good, but it wa mainly due to temporary factor such a the Olympics. "The amber light is flashing." The government may now find it more difficult to raise taxes, a policy it will have to implement when the economy pick up to help deal with Japan's massive public debt.

Title: Henman hopes ended in Dubai
Article: Third seed Tim Henman slumped to a straight set defeat in his rain-interrupted Dubai Open quarter-final against Ivan Ljubicic. The Croatian eighth seed booked his place in the last four with a 7-5 6-4 victory over the British number one. Henman had looked on course to level the match after going 2-0 up in the second set, but his progress wa halted a the rain intervened again. Ljubicic hit back after the break to seal a fourth straight win over Henman. Earlier in the day, Spanish fifth seed Tommy Robredo secured his semi-final place when he beat Nicolas Kiefer of Germany 6-4 6-4. Afterwards, Henman wa left cursing the weather and the umpire after seven break for rain during the match. "It wa incredibly frustrating," Henman said. "It's raining and the umpire doesn't take control. "He kept telling u to play till the end of the game. But if it's raining, you come off - the score's irrelevant. "It couldn't be more frustrating a I wa very happy with my form until now. You don't expect this in the desert."
