Title: Ireland win eclipses refereeing 'errors'
Article: The International Rugby Board may have to step in to stop frustrated coach and player from publicly haranguing referee when thing go belly-up. It may have to go the whole way and have NFL-style video camera all over the field, or slap the vociferous perpetrator over the knuckles. What the IRB doe not want is a football scenario where the verbal slanging match often overshadow the game itself. Sunday's explosive Six Nations clash at Lansdowne Road wa a good example a Ireland took another step towards their first Grand Slam since 1948. The game wa a exciting a it comes, with a much-improved England side enraged at a few decision that did not go their way. One can understand that frustration. There wa no doubt that Ireland had the rub of the green in their 19-13 victory, but the reaction from the England camp may not have endeared them to the sport's "blazers". Referee Jonathan Kaplan wa not perfect by any mean and two decision in particular made him the villain of the piece. I doubt whether Kaplan would have been too pleased at the comment made. After all, he ha no public recourse to criticism. It wa the same for Simon McDowell, the touch judge who wa heavily criticised by Scotland coach Matt Williams after their defeat against France. As far a England were concerned, there were query over Mark Cueto's first half-effort when he went over in the corner from a Charlie Hodgson kick. England coach Andy Robinson referred to a similar case at Ravenhill in January when Ulster were playing Gloucester in the Heineken Cup. On that occasion, David Humphreys kicked to Tommy Bowe, who touched down in the corner only for the try to be wiped out. But you cannot have camera at every conceivable angle to pick up such anomalies. Perhaps Robinson wa right to say the referee should have gone upstairs when Josh Lewsey wa driven over the Irish line near the end. Lewsey claim he touched it down and wa in full control. However, one ha to credit Ireland flanker Johnny O'Connor for cleverly scooping the ball away and blocking any evidence of a touchdown. But in rugby, everything tends to even out over the 80 minutes. The referee also missed England's Danny Grewcock taking out Ronan O'Gara off the ball to allow Martin Corry a Sunday stroll to the line. Those were the stand-out moment in a classic game between the two old foes. But there were many more, and one should not take away from those. Brian O'Driscoll's winning try wa a well-conceived a they come, while Charlie Hodgson's brilliant kicking display wa another highlight. And Ronan O'Gara's tremendous ability to control the game wa also a crucial component. But the defining moment came with Ireland under the cosh in the final 15 minutes. Two outstanding piece of defensive play denied England and allowed Ireland to hold on. The first wa Denis Hickie's brilliant double tackle in the right-hand corner. He gobbled up Cueto from another Hodgson cross-field kick, then regained his foot to stop Lewsey from scoring a certain try. Ireland's second-row colossus Paul O'Connell wa equally superb. England had turned Ireland one way then the other, and the defence cordon wa slowly disintegrating. England prop Matt Stevens ran in at full steam to suck in a few more tacklers. Unfortunately he ran into O'Connell who hit him hard - very hard - and then wrestled the ball away for a crucial turnover. That spoke volume about Ireland's back-foot display, with defensive coach Mike Ford taking a bow at the end. To win a game like that showed that Ireland have moved forward. It may be try that win games, but it is defence that win championships.

Title: Lloyd's of London head chides FSA
Article: The head of Lloyd's of London, the insurance market, ha criticised Britain's financial watchdog, the Financial Services Authority (FSA). In a speech on Monday, Mr Prettejohn urged the FSA to force broker to disclose the size of their commissions. "The FSA should change, and change now" said Mr Prettejohn, who want it to move from "disclosure on request" to mandatory disclosure. The call came in a speech on improving the London insurance market. "The FSA should not bide their time and 'wait and see'. They should seize the moment," Mr Prettejohn, Lloyd's chief executive said. The FSA took over regulation of the general insurance sector in January, but it sidestepped call to require broker to disclose the commission they earn from insurer to their clients. Last week, the City watchdog gave broker and insurer guidance on managing conflict of interest. Brokers must give information on their commission if, and only if, their customer request it, the FSA said. In the US, lack of transparency about brokers' commission ha led to problems. The world's biggest insurance broker Marsh & McLennan said last week it would pay $850m to settle charges, raised by New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer in October, that it sought to rig bid in conjunction with insurers. The probe centred around so-called contingent commissions, whereby broker were rewarded according to how much business they brought to an insurer, an arrangement that did not always benefit brokers' customers. All of the insurance business written in the Lloyd's market is placed via brokers.

Title: US actor 'found with gun residue'
Article: Actor Robert Blake had gunshot residue on his hand and clothes the night his wife wa shot dead, a court ha heard. But it may not have come from the shot that killed Bonny Lee Bakley in 2001, Mr Blake's murder trial wa told by criminalist Steven Dowell. Mr Dowell told a Los Angeles court the residue may have come from Mr Blake's revolver, his gun collection, his presence at the crime scene or police. The 71-year-old former star of US TV drama Baretta ha denied murder. Mr Blake said he found Ms Bakley, 44, dead in a car after they left a restaurant. He said he briefly returned to the restaurant to collect a gun he had left behind and discovered her body when he returned. The gun he collected wa not the murder weapon. It could also have been picked up if he touched or leant on the car when he found the body, or from a police box in which his clothes were later stored. The box had come from an area where officer went after being on the firing range. But Mr Dowell also said the residue would have been present if Mr Blake fired a gun that night. Title: U2's desire to be number one
Article: U2, who have won three prestigious Grammy Awards for their hit Vertigo, are stubbornly clinging to their status a one of the biggest band in the world. The most popular group in the history of rock all have several thing in common. The music must be inspired and appeal across generation and be distinctive, if not always groundbreaking. But such success is down to more than music. They have to be compelling performers, charismatic and intelligent enough to make good decision and keep their foot on the ground. They also have to want it. They have to want to be the biggest band ever and not stop wanting it. The Beatles had it, the Rolling Stones still have it, REM hold onto it and Queen were it in a catsuit. And U2 have it in spades, and keep churning it out. Their new album, How To Dismantle An Atomic Bomb, come 28 year after the schoolfriend got together in Dublin and 17 year after The Joshua Tree cemented their place on the all-time rock A-list. They may have lost some of the edginess and raw, youthful force that propelled them to the top, but they have lost none of the desire or ability to craft song and albums. Vertigo, the first single from the new album, went straight into the UK single chart at number one, knocking Eminem off the top spot and giving them their 26th top 10 hit. "The challenge is to be bigger and bolder and better - to make record the whole world will listen to," Bono recently said. Drummer Larry Mullen Jr echoed those sentiments: "We're very competitive - we want to be on the radio, have big singles. We don't want to be thought of a a veteran band." The band have done "everything in their considerable powers" to ensure they remain the biggest band in the world, according to Q magazine editor Paul Rees. "This make them hugely determined and formidable." He added: "They are equally determined to push themselves to make music that continues to stand up. "As such, they've constantly re-invented and challenged themselves. They are, perhaps, alone a the only rock band that ha got better with age." The other key ingredient wa the fact they were highly organised, Mr Rees said. "They do everything in the right way." The group were born when Mullen put an appeal for bandmates on a high school notice board, attracting fellow pupil Paul Hewson (Bono, vocals), Adam Clayton (bass), David Evans (The Edge, guitar) and his brother Dick. Dick Evans soon dropped out and the four-piece were known a The Feedback and The Hype before settling on U2. By 1978, they had won a talent contest and got noticed by a manager, Paul McGuinness. "They were brilliant, but very coarse," McGuinness recently said. "In a way, they were doing exactly what they do now. Only badly." They struggled to attract record company attention, later being described a "pretty damn average" and "strange and eerie" by scout who saw them live. They released two Ireland-only singles, which topped the national chart in 1979 and 1980, leading to a deal with Island and their debut album Boy. The stadium-filling, anthemic sound wa U2's aim from the start, and their third album, War, saw them make the breakthrough on both side of the Atlantic, going to number one in the UK and 12 in the US. Songs like Sunday Bloody Sunday and New Year's Day brought success and an image a a political and spiritual band - which Bono rejected a a cliche. His stage performance - which included flag-waving, speaker-climbing and drum-throwing - earned him a reputation a an electric performer, and their appearance at 1985's Live Aid is widely seen a sealing their global stardom. In 1987, The Joshua Tree broke sale record and saw the band reach the height of their power with hit including Where the Streets Have No Name, I Still Haven't Found What I'm Looking For and With Or Without You. Those song took the band's epic, atmospheric sound to a simple, powerful and popular pinnacle. The end of the decade marked a crucial point for the band - they had reached the top but still yearned for new challenge and achievements. These came in the form of exploration of different branch of rock and foray into electronic dance music, plus wildly extravagant stage shows, while still trying to retain their mass appeal. The Achtung Baby album in 1991 wa followed by Zooropa, Pop and their corresponding stadium tours, which featured giant olives, flying cars, live phone call to the White House and Bono's transformation into alter-egos The Fly and MacPhisto. He wa also building a parallel reputation - not always to the pleasure of his bandmates - a a campaigner on issue from global debt to Aids. Before the release of How To Dismantle An Atomic Bomb, they had sold 125 million album around the world. But they still want more.

Title: Moya fights back for Indian title
Article: Carlos Moya became the first man to successfully defend the Chennai Open title by beating four-times finalist Paradorn Srichaphan 3-6 6-4 7-6 (7/5). The Spaniard then donated his Â£28,000 prize money to relief effort for the victim of the Asian tsunami. The final wa close throughout, with Thai second seed Srichaphan - the 2003 winner - closing out the first set. But Moya took the second set, before bouncing back from 5-2 down in the decider to force and win a tie-break. Moya confirmed afterwards: "I'm donating my prize money from this tournament for the tsunami victims, hoping it make some difference to their lives. His contribution follows pledge by four other player to donate their prize money from the tournament, which went ahead after the 26 December disaster which ha so far claimed at least 150,000 lives. Scrichapan said he would donate an unspecified amount for relief work in Thailand, where more than 5,000 people were killed. The ATP ha announced that it would contribute the US$25,000 tournament fee to Unicef's emergency relief fund in Tamil Nadu. The ATP Tour's sponsor, Mercedes, said it would also contribute, increasing the ATP donation to US$40,000.

Title: Federer joins all-time greats
Article: The last year ha seen one player dominate men's tennis, and one country dominate the women's game. Roger Federer became the first man since Mats Wilander in 1988 to win three Grand Slams in one season. And after Anastasia Myskina became the first Russian woman to win a Grand Slam at the French Open, two more followed at Wimbledon and the US Open. Meanwhile, Briton Tim Henman enjoyed his best year, while Greg Rusedski fought back superbly from adversity. Federer began the year a world number one and holder of the Wimbledon and Masters Cup titles, and set about conquering new ground. The Swiss sounded warning of the dominance to come at the Australian Open. He ripped through the draw before beating Marat Safin in the final. Andy Roddick wa the only player to put up any real resistance at Wimbledon, and Federer's performance against Lleyton Hewitt in the US Open final wa breathtaking. Federer again got the better of Hewitt in the season-ending Masters Cup. His victory in Houston proved to be his 13th successive win in a final, an Open era record. The only major let-down wa a third-round loss to Gustavo Kuerten at the French Open, and Roland Garros will be his main target in 2005. There wa also a surprise loss to the unheralded Tomas Berdych at the Olympic Games, which saw Chile dominate a Nicoals Massu took the single and then paired up with Fernando Gonzaelz to win double gold. Another major trophy that look beyond Federer is the Davis Cup, which wa won by Spain in a 3-2 home success over the USA in Seville. Roddick struggled on the clay, losing to Rafael Nadal on the opening day before going down to Carlos Moya in the all-important fourth rubber. Henman broke new ground by reaching the semi on clay at the French Open - a stunning effort - and also at the US Open. A quarter-final defeat to Mario Ancic at Wimbledon wa disappointing for the limp manner of the Briton's defeat, but he remains optimistic of going further next year. British number two Rusedski endured a rollercoaster year, returning to the circuit after being cleared of a doping offence in March. With his ranking down at 168, many feared the 31-year-old's career wa over, but he battled back in the second half of the season to re-enter the top 50. The Russian woman finally delivered on their long-recognised promise in 2004, with Myskina, Maria Sharapova and Svetlana Kuznetsova winning Grand Slams, before taking the season-ending Fed Cup. But while the young Russians were on the way up, it wa a different story for the Belgians and the Williams sisters. Only veteran Lindsay Davenport held the new wave at bay, a stunning run of form after Wimbledon taking her to number one ahead of Amelie Mauresmo, whose Grand Slam drought go on. The year started in regulation fashion a Justine Henin-Hardenne beat compatriot Kim Clijsters at the Australian Open. A virus ruined the rest of Henin-Hardenne's year, although she wa fit enough to win Olympic gold, but Clijsters had an even more miserable 2004. She suffered a serious wrist injury and then announced the end of her relationship with Lleyton Hewitt, and will be happy to see the year end. In their absence, Myskina thrashed Elena Dementieva in a historic, but woeful, all-Russian final at the French Open. Wimbledon wa a more refreshing affair a Sharapova captivated SW19, showing nerve of steel a she battled past Davenport and Serena Williams to take the title. Davenport wa a strong favourite for the US Open but, hampered by injury, lost to the powerful and unflappable Kuznetsova in the semis. Kuznetsova went on to give Dementieva another Grand Slam final thrashing, with the latter's wayward serve becoming one of the talking point of the year. With the Russians still improving, the like of Henin-Hardenne, Clijsters, Davenport, Mauresmo, Venus and Serena will need to be fully fit and motivated in 2005. And it may take their compatriot Safin to challenge Federer on the men's side.

Title: Hansen 'delays return until 2006'
Article: British triple jumper Ashia Hansen ha ruled out a comeback this year after a setback in her recovery from a bad knee injury, according to reports. Hansen, the Commonwealth and European champion, ha been sidelined since the European Cup in Poland in June 2004. It wa hoped she would be able to return this summer, but the wound from the injury ha been very slow to heal. Her coach Aston Moore told the Times: "We're not looking at any sooner than 2006, not a a triple jumper." Moore said Hansen may be able to return to sprinting and long jumping sooner, but there is no short-term prospect of her being involved again in her specialist event. "There wa a problem with the wound healing and it set back her rehabilitation by about two months, but that ha been solved and we can push ahead now," he said. "The aim is for her to get fit a an athlete - then we will start looking at sprinting and the long jump a an introduction back to the competitive arena." Moore said he is confident Hansen can make it back to top-level competition, though it is unclear if that will be in time for the Commonwealth Games in Melbourne next March, when she will be 34. "It's been a frustrating time for her, but it ha not fazed her determination," he added.

Title: Fockers fuel festive film chart
Article: Comedy Meet The Fockers topped the festive box office in North America, setting a new record for Christmas Day. The sequel took $44.7m (Â£23.2m) between 24 and 26 December, according to studio estimates. It took $19.1m (Â£9.9m) on Christmas Day alone, the highest taking on that day in box office history. Meet The Fockers is the sequel to Ben Stiller comedy Meet The Parents, also starring Robert De Niro, Blythe Danner, Dustin Hoffman and Barbra Streisand. Despite the success of Meet The Fockers, taking were down 26.5% on 2003's figure - which wa blamed on Christmas falling over a weekend this year. "When Christmas fall on a weekend, it's bad for business," said Paul Dergarabedian, president of Exhibitor Relations, which compiles box office statistics. The weekend's top 12 film took an estimated $121.9m (Â£63.3m), compared with $165.8m (Â£86.1m) last year, when the third Lord of the Rings film dominated the box office. Meet The Fockers knocked last week's top film, Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events, down to third place, with $12.5m (Â£6.5m). Comedy Fat Albert - co-written by Bill Cosby - entered the chart in second place after opening on Christmas Day, taking $12.7m (Â£6.6m). The Aviator, starring Leonardo DiCaprio a Howard Hughes, took $9.4m after expanding from 40 to 1,796 cinema on Christmas Day.

Title: Klinsmann issues Lehmann warning
Article: Germany coach Jurgen Klinsmann ha warned goalkeeper Jens Lehmann he may have to quit Arsenal to keep his World Cup dream alive. Lehmann is understudy to Oliver Kahn in the German squad, but ha lost his place to Manuel Alumnia at Highbury. Klinsmann said: "It will be difficult for any of our player if he is not a first-choice at his club. "If Jens is not Arsenal's number one keeper, that is a problem for me. He must be playing regularly." Lehmann is desperate to keep his place in the Germany squad when the country host the World Cup in 2006. Klinsmann added: "If he is not playing regularly he cannot be Germany's number one keeper, or even number two keeper. "The situation for Jens is that he is currently the number two keeper at Arsenal. This could be critical if it remains the same during next season."

Title: Collins calls for Chambers return
Article: World 100m champion Kim Collins say suspended sprinter Dwain Chambers should be allowed to compete in the Olympics again. Chambers wa banned for two year after testing positive for the anabolic steroid THG and his suspension run out in November this year. But Collins say the British Olympic Association should reverse the decision to ban him from the Olympics for life. "It wa too harsh," Collins told Radio Five Live. "They should reconsider." Chambers ha been in America learning American football but ha not ruled out a return to the track. Collins added: "He is a great guy and I have never had any problem with him. We are friends. "I would like to see Dwain come back and compete again. He is a good person. "Even though he made a mistake he understands what he did and should be given a chance once more."

Title: S Korean credit card firm rescued
Article: South Korea's largest credit card firm ha averted liquidation following a one trillion won ($960m; Â£499m) bail-out. LG Card had been threatened with collapse because of it huge debt but the firm's creditor and it former parent have stepped in to rescue it. A consortium of creditor and LG Group, a family owned conglomerate, have each put up $480m to stabilise the firm. LG Card ha seven million customer and it collapse would have sent shockwaves through the country's economy. The firm's creditor - which own 99% of LG Card - have been trying to agree a deal to secure it future for several weeks. They took control of the company in January when it avoided bankruptcy only through a $4.5bn bail-out. They had threatened to delist the company, a move which would have triggered massive debt redemption and forced the company into bankruptcy, unless agreement wa reached on it future funding. "LG Card will not need any more financial aid after this," Laah Chong-gyu, executive director of Korea Development Bank - one of the firm's creditor - said. The agreement will see some 12 trillion won of debt converted into equity. "The purpose of the capital injection is to avoid delisting and the goal will be met," David Kim, an analyst at Sejong Securities, told Reuters. South Korea's consumer credit market ha been slowly recovering from a crisis in 2002 when a credit bubble burst and million of consumer fell behind on their debt repayments. LG Card returned to profit in September but needed further capital to avoid being thrown off the market. South Korea's stock exchange can delist any firm if it debt exceeds it asset two year running.

Title: Tories attack burglar 'U-turns'
Article: Tory leader Michael Howard ha accused Tony Blair of performing U-turns over rule on using force against burglars. The government ha ruled out amending the present law, which allows "reasonable force" in self defence. Mr Howard branded the decision unacceptable, saying: "It is not householder who should be frightened, it's the burglars." Home Secretary Charles Clarke said minister had kept to their pledge to review the law. Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir John Stevens last month backed a Tory attempt to change the law so only householder using "grossly disproportionate" force could be prosecuted. The pressure prompted the prime minister to say the police and Crown Prosecution Service would be consulted a part of a review of the law. He told MPs: "If we get the right response from those people, we will, of course, support a change in the law." Instead, the government ha decided no change is needed but there will be a publicity campaign so people are clear they are entitled to defend themselves. On Thursday, Mr Howard told BBC Radio 4's Today programme Mr Blair had initially refused the law change, then had come round to the idea and wa now backtracking again. He said: "We've had three policy position in three month and two U-turns. "It's not surprising Gordon Brown told him: 'There's nothing you could say to me now that I could ever believe.'" Mr Howard said the "grossly disproportionate" test matched the hurdle minister had introduced for civil case where burglar where claimed compensation from householders. The issue entered the public spotlight when Norfolk farmer Tony Martin wa jailed for shooting dead a 16-year-old burglar in 1999 a he ran away from the farm. But the home secretary said Mr Howard wa wrong to say the law wa biased in favour of burglars. The barrister who had represented Mr Martin had said the rule were "weighted overwhelmingly" in favour of the householder, said Mr Clarke. He said: "The problem is there ha not been enough understanding of it - that wa the point Sir John Stevens wa making and the prime minister wa making." The new guidance would help ensure clarity on the issue, added Mr Clarke. The director of public prosecutions, Ken Macdonald, say only 11 householder or occupier of business premise have been prosecuted in the last 15 years. Those case included a warehouse manager who had waited for a burglar, tied him up, beat him and set him alight, he said. Tory MP Patrick Mercer's private member's bill to change the law received a first reading in Parliament on Wednesday and go to a full debate next month.

Title: Circuit City gets takeover offer
Article: Circuit City Stores, the second-largest electronics retailer in the US, ha received a $3.25bn (Â£1.7bn) takeover offer. The bid ha come from Boston-based private investment firm Highfields Capital Management, which already owns 6.7% of Circuit City's shares. Shares in the retailer were up 19.6% at $17.04 in Tuesday morning trading in New York following the announcement. Highfield said that it intends to take the Virginia-based firm private. "Such a transformation would eliminate the public-company transparency into the company's operating strategy that is uniquely damaging in a highly competitive industry where Circuit City is going head-to-head with a tough and entrenched rival," Highfield said. One analyst suggested that a bidding battle may now begin for the company. Bill Armstrong, a retail analyst at CL King & Associates, said he expected to see other private investment firm come forward for Circuit City. The retailer is debt free with a good cash flow, despite the fact that it is said to be struggling to keep up with market leader Best Buy and cut-price competition from the like of Wal-Mart, said Mr Armstrong.

Title: Souness eyes summer move for Owen
Article: Newcastle bos Graeme Souness is lining up a summer move for England and Real Madrid striker Michael Owen. He see Owen a the ideal replacement for Alan Shearer, who is due to retire in the summer, although he hope to persuade Shearer to carry on. "Michael is in the category of player who would excite the fan and we're monitoring him," he told BBC Newcastle. "He is a great centre-forward and only 25 but I don't think we're the only one monitoring the situation at Real." Souness ha also hinted he think Shearer may carry on despite his stated intent to retire at the end of the season. He belief the prospect of breaking Jackie Milburn's club scoring record may influence the striker's decision. Milburn scored 200 league and cup goal between 1946 and 1957, while Shearer currently ha 187 goal to his name. "Without giving too much away, I am confident he will be here next season," said Souness. "I can't imagine him leaving without breaking Jackie Milburn's scoring record." Souness also revealed he tried to bring back Nolberto Solano during the January transfer window. The Peruvian international wa sold to Aston Villa a year ago but in the phone-in for BBC Newcastle, Souness said tried to re-sign him, but Villa were not interested in selling. The former Rangers and Liverpool bos is also looking to bring in a number of new acquisition once the current campaign ha been completed. "I'm after three, four or five new player in the summer - we have got lot of targets," he said. "Don't think we will wait to the last day of the season to say: `Who are we going to target now?"'

Title: Fed warns of more US rate rises
Article: The US look set for a continued boost to interest rate in 2005, according to the Federal Reserve. Minutes of the December meeting which pushed rate up to 2.25% showed that policy-makers at the Fed are worried about accelerating inflation. The clear signal pushed the dollar up to $1.3270 to the euro by 0400 GMT on Wednesday, but depressed US shares. "The market are starting to fear a more aggressive Fed in 2005," said Richard Yamarone of Argus Research. The Dow Jones index dropped almost 100 point on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq also falling a key tech stock were hit by broker downgrades. The dollar also gained ground against sterling on Tuesday, reaching $1.8832 to the pound before slipping slightly on Wednesday morning. The release of the minute just three week after the 14 December meeting wa much faster than usual, indicating the Fed want to keep market more apprised of it thinking. This, too, is being taken in some quarter a a sign of aggressive move on interest rate to come. The key Fed fund rate ha risen 1.25 percentage point during 2004 from the 46-year low of 1% reached not long after the 9/11 attack in 2001. That long trough "might be contributing to sign of potentially excessive risk-taking in financial markets", said the Federal Open Markets Committee (FOMC), which set interest rates. The odds now favour a further boost to rate at the next meeting in early February, economist said. But the respite for the dollar, which spent late 2003 being pushed lower against other major currency by worry about massive US trade and budget deficits, may be short-lived. "You can't rule out a further correction... but we don't think it's a change in direction in the dollar," said Jason Daw at Merrill Lynch. "Nothing fundamental ha changed."

Title: German music in a 'zombie' state
Article: The German music business - the third largest in the world - is "in the state of a zombie" because it ha failed to respond to the challenge posed by downloading and piracy, a leading industry figure ha said. Tim Renner, the head of Universal Music Germany until last year, told BBC World Service's The Music Biz programme that the country's music industry wa now struggling to survive. Renner warned that unless the industry accepted "new realties" - such a downloading - it decline could become irreversible. "The problem the music industry ha got is that they aren't willing to accept that the classic way of doing business is over and out," he stated. "So the music industry in it current form over here is pretty much in the state of a zombie." The music market in Germany peaked in 1997, with sale of 2.6bn euro (Â£1.8bn). Since 2000, sale have plummeted to just 1.6bn euro (Â£1.1bn) in 2003. In the space of one year - between 2002 and 2003 - CD album sale fell by 13.8%. But a study by the Society for Consumer Research found that at the same time, more than twice a many recordable CDs had music recorded on them than CD album were sold. Mr Renner pointed out that, because profit come mainly from the longevity of a good-selling record, this wa particularly damaging. "You need time," he added. However, Peter Zombic, the managing director of the International Federation of Phonographic Industry in Germany, said he did not feel the situation wa a "dramatic" a Mr Renner believed. "It's quite true that we have severe problem in Germany - but that's true in other part of the world and in most developed market too," he argued. "We have a severe problem with piracy, especially internet piracy, and we also have a severe problem of private copying. "I don't agree that the music industry lost control over the music market - in fact, especially in regard to Germany talent, the market is quite successful." He did, however, admit that copyright owner have "partly lost control of their copyright", due to piracy and copying. But he refuted suggestion that the industry had been too slow to respond to digital downloading. "We were the first to implement a download service - back in 1997," he argued. "At that time it wa not successful, because of the advent of piracy - it wa the Napster time, when P2P service became popular. "It still is quite difficult for the music industry to compete with a price that is zero a far a the illegal product is concerned." Mr Zombic also called for a change to the perception in Germany that private copying of music is not a problem. German law doe allow people to make copy of CDs for their family and close friends, without fear of breaking copyright. Mr Zombic said that this legal framework wa a "huge problem". "There is a widespread attitude that private copying is a hobby, it's nice, it's fun," he added. "We try to make clear it's not nice and it's not fun - it's endangering the creativity in our country."

Title: Roundabout continues nostalgia trip
Article: The new big-screen version of The Magic Roundabout, released in the UK on Friday, is the latest attempt to turn children's television into box-office gold. Recent year have seen a less-than-successful adaptation of the 1960s puppet show Thunderbirds and a moderately successful version of E Nesbit's Five Children and It, previously filmed by the BBC in 1991. He-Man and Transformers, which were cartoon favourite in the 1980s, will soon receive their own costly makeovers. With screen version of The A-Team, The Dukes of Hazzard and even Blake's Seven on the cards, nostalgia is clearly big business. But some critic complain that these expensive take on iconic series of yesteryear do not match up to our fond memory of the originals. The new version of The Magic Roundabout, which will be released a Sprung! in the US, replaces the stop-motion model of the 1960s TV show with polished, computer-generated animation. In a similar fashion, the 2004 Thunderbirds used human actor and special effect in place of the original's puppet and models. The film are squarely pitched at younger audiences. Pop star Robbie Williams and Kylie Minogue provide voice in The Magic Roundabout, while the now-defunct boy band Busted performed the Thunderbirds theme song. But while some reviewer have been won over, there ha nonetheless been a significant backlash. "This CG-animated adventure airbrush the sly charm and trippy otherworldliness which made the 60 stop-motion Roundabout a cult hit," writes Stella Papamichael on the BBC Movies site. And the recent puppet comedy Team America: World Police wa in part provoked by it directors' outrage that Gerry Anderson's Thunderbirds wa remade without it signature mannequins. Dan Jolin, review editor of Empire magazine, say classic children's TV show have a built-in audience that make them ideal for reinvention. "I can understand why people are taking these intellectual property and repackaging them for the kid of today. "But I think it's backfiring. What's next - The Clangers on some distant planet, with some giant CGI Soup Dragons chasing after them?" Despite Thunderbirds' disappointing global box-office performance - the film cost $42m (Â£22m) but only recouped $21m (Â£11m) - the nostalgia craze show no sign of abating. It can therefore be only a matter of time before some other TV favourite receive the Hollywood treatment. After the success of Garfield: The Movie, Britain's shabby tabby surely deserves his own film vehicle. With only 13 episode made of the 1974 series, there is plenty of room to explore the life of the pink cat, Professor Yaffle and the Mice of the Marvellous Mechanical Mouse Organ. Furry recyclers have already had one big-screen outing - 1977's Wombling Free. But with environmental issue still occupying our thought it is high time they made a comeback. Advances in special effect technology could do wonder for the BBC's supernatural comedy . And the success of Pirates of the Caribbean must surely herald a comeback for TV's most popular cartoon buccaneer, . It might also remind viewer the lewd character name often associated with the show never actually existed. The Magic Roundabout is out in the UK on 11 February. How about bringing Catweazle to the big screen? He could give Gandalf a run for his money! Thundercats!! I loved it. Should be fun to see on the big screen, if some effort is put in! it will bring my youth back! Get your hand off the Clangers! Is nothing sacred? Make a movie version of the Banana splits! What about Keanu Reeves and Richard Gere in a remake of The Wooden Tops? Or perhaps Robbie Williams could get his much mooted acting career off the ground by taking on the role of Andy Pandy. You forgot to mention the grearest of them all, Danger Mouse! But then again, it couldn't be better than the original series, could it? It's always nice to see these old toon re-released, but after the abysmal Thunderbirds movie (and the song!) I think I've been completely put off. Just leave these classic alone a good memories. I think remake are a good idea. As the world move on people tend to look more and more into the past to thing that make them feel safe. I believe this is the whole reason "retro" ha become so popular. As long a a remake doe justice to the original then all it can do is create a wider audience and possibly entice a new generation of person to enjoy and revive and old series. Personally i'd like to see cartoon such a Transformers, Thundercats and M.A.S.K. get full Hollywood remakes. Leave them alone, why ruin something that we all have very fond memory of in the first place? The thunderbird film wa apalling, not a patch on the puppet series I grew up with and the Magic Roundabout will never be the same without the voice of Eric Thompson. Part of the reason for the success of such classic a the Magic Roundabout wa that the character were not the sweet and cuddly creature that you would expect. They were moody, sarcastic, and rather human. Just looking at the picture of the animation for the new film show that these characteristic have not been preserved. Dougal never smiled like that! Films of this sort have an unfortunate habit of Disneyfying everthing, and they just lose the real magic that made the show special in the first place. I have fond memory of Bod (not least of which because I look like him) and would like to see someone attempt to make it into a film. It maybe that to an audience who have never seen the original they can watch them without prejudice, but to people who have grown up with all these show such a Thunderbirds and Magic Roundabout which are part of our childhood, they are never going to live up to expectation. It doe pose the question though that with all the long line of remake being made, are film-makers running out of original ideas? All I can say is bring back Danger Mouse, probably the greatest kids' show ever. I recently re-watched some episode and realised that there wa a level of humour shown in Danger Mouse that wa completely lost on me when I wa a child. There WAS a new Captain Pugwash cartoon made a couple of year back. Again, like so many of these nostalgia programmes, the animation - this time computer created flat-cell like animation - failed to match the original's cut out paper technique for inventiveness, and wa woefully inadequate. We live in a sampling world - the music industry ha been pludering past decade for inspiration, clipping sound from 20 year ago is much cheaper and easier that doing something new. If they got a decent producer and writer the story line could be great. And who to play the lead role? Well if it wa a comedy then it would have to be someone like Steve Martin. If it going to be an adventure then Johnny Depp playing a role similar to the Pirates Of The Caribbean Character. Muffin the Mule perhaps ? After all, granny and grandpa go to the cinema a well you know! Why can't the British film industry try making Gerry Anderson's UFO or Captain Scarlet, or Saphire and Steel, or The Tomorrow People. In today's media, it seems the past is the future. TV show such a Battlestar Galactica have new remakes, DJ's are sampling or re-working 70's and 80's music. Even computer game from 10-15 year ago are getting modern re-workings. Personally, I think it show that no one ha any originality any more! Why not just leave our misty-eyed nostalgia alone. Mary, Mungo and Midge. But of course for most of the episode the lift would be out of order and they would have to use the stairs. Plus would Mary be more of a Vicky Pollard character a she life in a high rise council block? Yeah but no but I wasn't even there! I'd like to see Mr. Benn, with Brad Pitt in the title role. Sean Connery could play the mysterious costume shop owner. It demonstrates a profound lack of imagination in today's film-makers that they continually try to remake and remodel the past in an effort to cash in on nostalgia. Would have loved to see Dungeons & Dragons made, but unfortunately the film that it wa made into didn't come up to scratch. The only one that isn't to be remade a yet is Thundercats, which I'd like to see. I'm an expat living in Norway, and I recently went through a period of buying the DVDs of many of my favourite children's program for my 2 daughters. My dearest wish, however, is to see a feature length version of Noggin the Nog appear on The Big Screen!! Very Scandinavian... Rainbow! I believe that Childrens classic should be left well alone, and I will not be surprised if the Magic Roundabout doe not do well at the Box Office, especially since it will be going up against The Spongebob Squarepants movie, popular among child because it's original, witty, and modern. The Magic Roundabout will never appeal to the child of today a it did all those many year ago. How about classic like Chorlton and the Wheelies, Rentaghost, Terrahawks, Bod.....oh the list could go on and on!!! And who remembers Trap Door voiced by the late Willie Rushden, superb children's programme. Could Morph hold his own in a big screen movie??? Or even Jamie and the Magic Torch....hmmmmm, I could go on and on. Danger Mouse? At 34 I'm showing my age. :-) Noggin the Nog wa one of the best children's programs. The problem with bringing it to the big screen is that no-one could approach Oliver Postgate's wonderful voices. So in general leave well alone. The original are good because they are of their time and the method used are an integral part of the story. Of course, Gerry Anderson's Supermarionation is a rich seam of material worthy of big-screen, big-budget action. It wa only that Thunderbirds The Movie wa targetted a a children't movie that really let it down. After all, the child that remember those show with such affection are now the parent of child themselves. It's only because the people who were child when these programme were first shown have grown up and are plundering their childhoods, isn't it? I'd hate to see Bagpuss with perfect animation - I love that 'done in a shed' clunkiness and you couldn't recreate the magic. Perhaps if the remake were done in a 'Look Around You' mock-authentic style I might be interested ... Chorton And The Wheelies or Jamie And His Magic Torch; that would be mega! This re-gurgitation of old film and TV show make me angry - it is corporate laziness resting on the safety of other people's ideas, because it guarantee to bring in the $$$. The same can be said of modern day pop band who release other people material, Will Young etc. The sad fact is nostalgia sell big buck in the short-term. The fact that they will be forgotten in 6 month time is irrelevant (e.g. Starsky & Hutch) Hence, the market is saturated with this mindless drivel, but it can only be stopped if people stop buying it! I pray they never do a remake of Chorlton And The Wheelies. I'm only 27 and don't remember the series from when it wa on TV, but have the set on DVD and it's a classic. The fact it's so great come from the fact that there were very few special effect involved and compared to today's stuff it look amateurish. Thats the appeal though, it's so innocent (like Chorlton himself) and it would be a real shame if they did remake it.

Title: Borussia Dortmund near bust
Article: German football club and former European champion Borussia Dortmund ha warned it will go bankrupt if rescue talk with creditor fail. The company's share tumbled after it said it ha "entered a life-threatening profitability and financial situation". Borussia Dortmund ha posted record loss and missed rent payment on it Westfallen stadium. Chief executive Gerd Niebaum stepped down last week and creditor are now pushing for greater control. Shares in Borussia Dortmund, Germany's only stock-market listed football club, dropped by almost 23% to 2.05 euro during early afternoon trading. Fund manager Florian Hamm - Borussia Dortmund's largest investor - said he would only invest more money in the company if he got a greater say in how it is run. "I demand better transparency," he is quoted a saying by Germany's Manger Magazin. The club ha also faced call to appoint executive from outside the club. Borussia Dortmund posted a record loss of 68m euro ($89m; Â£47m) in the 12 month through June. It made a loss of 27.2m euro in the first half of the current fiscal year and said that total debt will increase to 134.7m euro by the middle of 2006 unless a restructuring plan is pushed through. "This is the bill for their mismanagement over the past years," said HVB analyst Peter-Thilo Halser. The club appointed an auditor, who ha recommended a number of steps, including deferring the rent due on the stadium and suspending debt repayment until at least the 2006-2007 fiscal year. Stephen Schechter, a UK investment banker who ha held talk with Borussia Dortmund over a possible bond sale, said the club need a capital injection of 35m euros. "They need strong people on the board who do not have a history with the club," he said.

Title: Beer giant swallows Russian firm
Article: Brewing giant Inbev ha agreed to buy Alfa-Eco's stake in Sun Interbrew, Russia's second-largest brewer, for up to 259.7m euro ($353.3m; Â£183.75m). Alfa-Eco, the venture capital arm of Russian conglomerate Alfa Group, ha a one-fifth stake in Sun Interbrew. The deal give Inbev, the world's biggest beermaker, near-total control over the Russian brewer. Inbev bought out another partner in August 2004. Inbev brand include Bass, Stella Artois, Hoegaarden and Staropramen. It employ 77,000 people, running operation in over 30 country across the Americas, Europe and Asia Pacific. The Leuven-based brewery said it would own 97.3% of the voting share and 98.8% of the non-voting share of Sun Interbrew. The deal is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2005. Inbev wa formed in August 2004 when Belgium's Interbrew bought Brazilian brewer Ambev. Sun Interbrew, which employ 8,000 staff, owns brewery in eight Russian city - Klin, Ivanovo, Saransk, Kursk, Volzhsky, Omsk, Perm and Novocheboksarsk. There are also three brewery in Ukraine, in the city of Chernigov, Nikolaev and Kharkov.

Title: 'Debate needed' on donations cap
Article: A cap on donation to political party should not be introduced yet, the election watchdog ha said. Fears that big donor can buy political favour have sparked call for a limit. In a new report, the Electoral Commission say it is worth debating a Â£10,000 cap for the future but now is not the right time to introduce it. It also say there should be more state funding for political party and candidate should be able to spend more on election campaigning. There were almost Â£68m in reported donation to political party in 2001, 2002 and 2003, with nearly Â£12m of them from individual gift worth more than Â£1m. The rule have already been changed so the public can see who give how much to the party but the report say there are still public suspicions. The commission say capping donation would mean taxpayer giving party more cash - something which would first have to be acceptable to the public and shown to work. "While we are not in principle opposed to the introduction of a donation cap, we do not believe that such a major departure from the existing system now would be sensible," say it report. If there wa to be a cap, it should be Â£10,000 - a small enough amount to make a difference but which would have banned Â£56m in donation between 2001 and 2003. Even without change the commission doe urge political party to seek out more small-scale donation and suggests there should be income tax relief for gift under Â£200. It also suggests increasing state funding for party to Â£3m so help can be extended to all party with at least two member in the House of Commons, European Parliament, Scottish Parliament, Welsh Assembly or Northern Ireland Assembly. And it suggests new way of boosting election campaigning, seen a a way of improving voter turnout. All local election candidate should be entitled to a free mailshot for campaign leaflets, say the watchdog. And there should be a shift in the amount of money allowed to be spent at election from a national level to a local level to help politician engage better with voters. The report suggests doubling the money which can be spent by candidates, while cutting national spending limit from Â£20m to Â£15m. The commission also say the spending limit for general election should cover the four month before the poll - a happens with other elections. Electoral Commission chairman Sam Younger said: "There is no doubt that political party have a vital role to play in maintaining the health of our democracy and for this they need to be adequately resourced. "Our research ha shown that people want to be more informed about party politics and that they want politician to be more visible and accessible. "The public are reluctant for the state to fund party but at the same time are unhappy with large private donations." He called for a wider public debate on party funding to find the consensus needed for radical change to the current system.

Title: US woman sues over cartridges
Article: A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), saying it printer ink cartridge are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date. The unnamed woman from Georgia say that a chip inside the cartridge tell the printer that it need re-filling even when it doe not. The lawsuit seek to represent anyone in the US who ha purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's biggest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridge use a chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change. But the suit claim the chip also shut down the cartridge at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are empty. "The smart chip is dually engineered to prematurely register ink depletion and to render a cartridge unusable through the use of a built-in expiration date that is not revealed to the consumer," the suit said. The lawsuit is asking for restitution, damage and other compensation. The cost of printer cartridge ha been a contentious issue in Europe for the last 18 months. The price of inkjet printer ha come down to a little a Â£34 but it could cost up to Â£1,700 in running cost over an 18-month period due to cartridge, a study by Computeractive Magazine revealed last year. The inkjet printer market ha been the subject of an investigation by the UK's Office of Fair Trading (OFT), which concluded in a 2002 report that retailer and manufacturer needed to make pricing more transparent for consumers.

Title: Turkey-Iran mobile deal 'at risk'
Article: Turkey's investment in Iran's mobile industry look set to be scrapped after it biggest mobile firm saw it investment there slashed by MPs. Iran's parliament voted by a large majority to cut Turkcell's stake in a new mobile network from 70% to 49%. The move, which wa justified on national security grounds, follows an earlier vote by MPs to give themselves a veto over foreign investments. Turkcell said the decision "increases the risks" attached to the project. Although the company's statement said it would continue to monitor developments, observer said they thought Turkcell wa set to pull out of the $3bn deal. "The possibility of carrying out this project is next to zero," said Atinc Ozkan, analyst at Finans Investment in Istanbul. If Turkcell doe back out, MTN - the South African firm which lost out in the original tender - may well be back in the running. The company ha said it is prepared to accept a minority stake if Iran will award it the mobile deal. Turkcell's mobile deal is the second Turkish investment in Iran to run into trouble. Turkish-Austrian consortium TAV wa chosen to build and run Tehran's new Imam Khomeini International Airport - but the army closed it just hour after it opened in May 2004. In both cases, the justification ha been national security, amid allegation that the Turkish firm are too close to Israel. The hardline posture taken by parliament, which is dominated by religious conservatives, could yet impact other inward investments.

Title: Holmes back on form in Birmingham
Article: Double Olympic champion Kelly Holmes wa back to her best a she comfortably won the 1,000m at the Norwich Union Birmingham Indoor Grand Prix. The 34-year-old, running only her second competitive race of the season, shook off the rust to win in two minutes, 35.39 seconds. But she is still undecided about competing in the European Championships in Madrid from 4-6 March. "I'll probably be entered and make my mind up at the last minute," she said. "My training hasn't gone a well a expected but I've got two week to decide. "I need to take my time and make sure I feel good about what I'm doing. "I felt very good here but with the crowd behind you, you feel like you can do anything." American wa the eventual winner of the men's 60m race which almost ended in farce. The 25-year-old Briton clocked 7.98 second while pre-European Championships favourite Russian Irina Shevchenko finished down in sixth. Ethiopia's failed in her bid to smash compatriot Berhane Adere's world 3,000m record but still won the event in emphatic style. The Olympic 5,000m champion wa inside record pace but dropped off over the final third, finishing in eight minutes, 33.05 second - the fourth fastest time ever recorded for the event. Kenyan also missed out on the indoor 1500m world record, which Hicham El Guerrouj ha held for the last eight years. Lagat settled for silver behind El Guerrouj in Athens and wa almost four second short of the Moroccan's world best, clocking 3:35.27 in Birmingham. And wa still struggling to find his form after the death of his fiancee this year. The Olympic 10,000m champion had comfortably led the men's two mile race after his younger brother Tariku had set the pace. But fellow Ethiopian appeared ominously on Bekele's shoulder with two lap to go before surging past him at the bell to win in 8:14.28. Jamaican made the most of a blistering start to take the men's 400m title in 45.91 seconds. World indoor champion, Alleyne Francique, faded badly and finished in fourth while American duo Jerry Harris and James Davis took second and third respectively. Swede showed her class in the long jump a she stole top spot from Jade Johnson with the very last jump of the competition. The Olympic heptathlon gold medallist reached 6.66m to better Johnson's mark of 6.52m - her second personal best inside a week. "I wa quite surprised because I didn't think I'd end up with second place," said Johnson, who wore London's 2012 Olympic bid slogan, "Back the Bid", on her shorts. "But I'm pleased and hopefully I'll get a bit better for the Europeans. I really want to win a medal." won the men's event with a season's best of 7.95m, taking the scalp of world indoor champion Savante Stringfellow of the USA.

Title: 'No UK apology' for colonial past
Article: The day of Britain having to apologise for it colonial past are over, Gordon Brown ha said. The chancellor, speaking during a week-long tour of Africa, said it wa time to talk about enduring British value of liberty and tolerance. Mr Brown ha signed a debt relief deal with Tanzania which could cost the UK Â£1 billion. South African president Thabo Mbeki ha attacked British imperialists, saying they treated Africans like savages. Mr Brown said that missionairies had come to Africa because of their sense of duty. He added that the history of internationalism and enterprise had given Britain a greater global reach than any other country. BBC political correspondent Mark Mardell said Britishness had long been a theme of the chancellor's but "never before ha he been so outspoken in defending Britain's past history". The UK ha pledged to pay 10% of the developing world's foreign debt bill in an attempt to fight poverty. On top of the relief deal with Tanzania Mr Brown said the UK would make similar offer to 70 poorer nation around the world. Under the plan - which could cost the UK Â£1bn - country must spend the cash saved on health, education and welfare. "We make this offer unilaterally but we are now asking other country to join us," the chancellor said. Mr Brown, on a week-long tour of Africa, spent two day in Tanzania before heading on Friday evening to Mozambique, a country where more than half of the 17-million population life below the poverty line. There he is expected to strike a similar debt relief pact. The chancellor said he hoped other G8 and European country would follow suit. The UK ha already cancelled it bilateral debt - money the UK alone is owed - with the world's poorest nation including Tanzania. Former international development secretary Clare Short questioned the effectiveness of debt relief a a mean of tackling poverty.

Burnley have major injury concern over Frank Sinclair and John McGreal. Michael Duff look set to continue at right-back with John Oster in midfield and Micah Hyde is expected to recover from a knee injury. - Blackburn bos Mark Hughes: "Burnley are resolute and have individual talent but I fully expect u to progress. "I thought we were comfortable in the first game and never thought we were under pressure. "It's a competition we want to progress in and we are doing okay. If we beat Burnley, we have a home tie against another lower league club (Leicester)." - Burnley bos Steve Cotterill: "They will be fresh and we'll be tired. That is an honest opinion but our lad just might be able to get themselves up for one more big game. "The atmosphere at the last game wa very hot - a good verbal contest. "Our fan will not need whipping up for this game. I just want them to help u a much a they can in a positive way." But they've not been beaten in the competition by a club outside the Premiership for nine years, since Ipswich - then in the second tier - defeated them 0-1 after extra time in a third round replay at Ewood Park on 16 January 1996. History is on Rovers side. When they last met their near neighbour in the FA Cup 45 year ago, it also required an Ewood Park replay, which the home side won 2-0, and when they last met in the League, Rovers did the double. Success here, and victory home to Leicester in the next round, could see Rovers in the semi-finals without having played Premiership opposition. - BURNLEY make the eight mile journey to their fierce rivals, determined to send Blackburn the same way a Liverpool in the third round. But having failed to pull off another shock at Turf Moor, it could be that the Championship outfit - 17 place inferior on the League ladder - have missed their best opportunity. Having said that, Burnley are yet to concede a goal in this Cup run. - Steve Cotterills' Clarets have been knocked out in the fifth round four time in the last seven years, and have made only one appearance in the sixth round in 21 years. That wa in the season before last, when they disposed of Premiership Fulham at this fifth round stage. - While Blackburn have not played since the fifth round tie, Burnley have had two League outing away from home, drawing 1-1 at Derby and losing 1-0 at Preston. That take their winless run to four games. The combatant from one-time prosperous mill towns, are both founder member of the Football League. Title: Apple laptop is 'greatest gadget'
Article: The Apple Powerbook 100 ha been chosen a the greatest gadget of all time, by US magazine Mobile PC. The 1991 laptop wa chosen because it wa one of the first "lightweight" portable computer and helped define the layout of all future notebook PCs. The magazine ha compiled an all-time top 100 list of gadgets, which includes the Sony Walkman at number three and the 1956 Zenith remote control at two. Gadgets needed moving part and/or electronics to warrant inclusion. The magazine specified that gadget also needed to be a "self-contained apparatus that can be used on it own, not a subset of another device". "In general we included only item that were potentially mobile," said the magazine. "In the end, we tried to get to the heart of what really make a gadget a gadget," it concluded. The oldest "gadget" in the top 100 is the abacus, which the magazine date at 190 A.D., and put in 60th place. Other pre-electronic gadget in the top 100 include the sextant from 1731 (59th position), the marine chronometer from 1761 (42nd position) and the Kodak Brownie camera from 1900 (28th position). The Tivo personal video recorder is the newest device to make the top 10, which also includes the first flash mp3 player (Diamound Multimedia), a well a the first "successful" digital camera (Casio QV-10) and mobile phone (Motorola Startac). The most popular gadget of the moment, the Apple iPod, is at number 12 in the list while the first Sony transistor radio is at number 13. Sony's third entry in the top 20 is the CDP-101 CD player from 1983. "Who can forget the crystalline, hiss-free blast of Madonna's Like A Virgin emenating from their first CD player?" asked the magazine. Karl Elsener's knife, the Swiss Army Knife from 1891, is at number 20 in the list. Gadgets which could be said to feature surprisngly low down in the list include the original telephone (23rd), the Nintendo GameBoy (25th), and the Pulsar quartz digital watch (36th). The list also contains plenty of oddities: the Pez sweet dispenser (98th), 1980s toy Tamagotchi (86th) and the bizarre Ronco inside the shell egg scrambler (84th). Why worry about mobile phones. Soon they will be subsumed into the PDA's / laptop etc. What about the Marine Chronometer? Completely revolutionised navigation for boat and wa in use for centuries. For it's time, a technological marvel! Sony Net Minidisc! It paved the way for more mp3 player to explode onto the market. I always used my NetMD, and could not go anywhere without it. A laptop computer is not a gadget! It's a working tool! The Sinclair Executive wa the world's first pocket calculator. I think this should be there a well. How about the clockwork radio? Or GPS? Or a pocket calculator? All these thing are useful to real people, not just PC magazine editors. Are the people who created this list insane ? Surely the most important gadget of the modern age is the mobile phone? It ha revolutionalised communication, which is more than can be said for a niche market laptop. From outside the modern age, the marine chronometer is the single most important gadget, without which modern transportation system would not have evolved so quickly. Has everyone forgot about the Breville pie maker?? An interesting list. Of the electronic gadgets, thousand of journalist in the early 1980s blessed the original noteboook pc - the Tandy 100. The size of A4 paper and light, three week on a set of batteries, an excellent keyboard, a modem. A pity Tandy did not make it DOS compatible. What's an Apple Powerbook 100 ? It's out of date - not much of a "gadget". Surely it ha to be something simple / timeless - the tin opener, Swiss Army Knife, safety razor blade, wristwatch or the thing for taking stone out of horse hoof ? It ha to be the mobile phone. No other single device ha had such an effect on our way of living in such a short space of time. The ball point pen ha got to be one of the most used and common gadget ever. Also many might be grateful for the pocket calculator which wa a great improvement over the slide rule. The Casio pocket calculator that played a simple game and made tinny noise wa also a hot gadget in 1980. A true gadget, it could be carried around and shown off. All top 10 are electronic toys, so the list is probably a better reflection of the current high-tech obsession than anyhting else. I say this a the Swiss Army Knife only made No 20. Sinclair QL a machine far ahead of it time. The first home machine with a true multi-takings OS. Shame the marketing wa so bad!!! Apple.. a triumph of fashion over... well everything else. Utter rubbish. Yes, the Apple laptop and Sony Walkman are classic gadgets. But to call the sextant and the marine chronometer 'gadgets' and rank them a less important than a TV remote control reveals a quite shocking lack of historical perspective. The former literally helped change the world by vastly improving navigation at see. The latter is the seed around which the couch potato culture ha developed. No competition. I'd also put Apple's Newton and the first Palm Pilot there a the front runner for portable computing, and possibly the Toshiba Libretto for the same reason. I only wish that Vulcan Inc's Flipstart wasn't just vapourware otherwise it would be at the top. How did a laptop ever manage to beat off the challenge of the wristwatch or the telephone (mobile or otherwise)? What about radio and TVs? The swiss army knife. By far the most useful gadget. I got mine 12 year ago. Still wearing and using it a lot! It stood the test of time. Psion Organiser series 3, should be up there. Had a usable qwerty keyboard, removable storage, good set of apps and programmable. Case design wa good (batteries in the hinge - a first, I think). Great product innovation. The first mobile PC wa voted best gadget by reader of...err... mobile PC?! Why do you keep putting these obviously biased list on your site? It's obviously the mobile phone or remote control, and reader of a less partisan publication would tell you that. The Motorola Startac should be Number One. Why? There will be mobile phone long after notebook computer and other gadget are either gone or integrated in communication devices. The Psion series 3c! The first most practical way to carry all your info around... I too would back the Sinclair Spectrum - without this little beauty I would never have moved into the world of IT and earn the living that I do now. I'd have put the mobile phone high up the list. Probably a Nokia model. Sinclair Spectrum - 16k. It plugged into the tv. Games were rubbish but it gave me a taste for programming and that's what I do for a living now. I wish more modern notebook -- even Apple's newest offering -- were more like the PB100. Particularly disheartening is the demise of the trackball, which ha given way to the largely useless "trackpad" which every notebook on the market today uses. They're invariably inaccurate, uncomfortable, and cumbersome to use. Congratulations to Apple, a deserved win!

Title: Slater to star in Broadway play
Article: Actor Christian Slater is stepping into the role of Tom in the Broadway revival of The Glass Menagerie. Slater, 35, is replacing actor Dallas Roberts in the Tennessee Williams drama, which open next month. No reason wa given for Roberts' departure. The role will be played by understudy Joey Collins until Slater join the show. Slater won rave review for his recent performance in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest in London's West End. He ha also starred in a number of films, including Heathers, Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves and more recently Churchill: The Hollywood Years. Preview performance of The Glass Menagerie will begin at New York's Ethel Barrymore Theatre on Thursday. Philip Rinaldi, a spokesman for the show, said the play's 15 March opening date remains unchanged. The revival, directed by David Leveaux, will also star Jessica Lange a the domineering mother, Amanda Wingfield.

Title: UK youth 'interested' in politics
Article: The majority of young people are interested in politics, holding "strong opinions" on policy and have a "keen appetite" for direct action. Research undertaken for voting watchdog the Electoral Commission suggests 81% of 16 to 20-year-olds feel strongly about issue like crime and education. The survey finding are being released to coincide with the launch of the Y Vote Mock Elections 2005 initiative. Mock election are planned to take place in school across the UK. Electoral Commission bos Sam Younger said: "We know that young people often feel disengaged from democratic life and we believe in working creatively to encourage their interest and participation. "Mock election can play an extremely valuable role in helping young people understand how the democratic process work and why it matters," he said. The survey of a sample of 500 British 16 to 20-year-olds and 500 21 to 25-year old "showed Britain's young people are far from apathetic about issue that matter to most of their lives". The Y Vote initiative is being run jointly by the Electoral Commission, the Hansard Society and the Department for Education and Skills in the run-up to local election and the general election, possibly on 5 May. Michael Rafferty, who is mock election project manager at the Hansard Society, said he looked forward to seeing school and college across the UK participating in the mock votes.
Summary: "Mock elections can play an extremely valuable role in helping young people understand how the democratic process works and why it matters," he said.Michael Rafferty, who is mock elections project manager at the Hansard Society, said he looked forward to seeing schools and colleges across the UK participating in the mock votes.The Y Vote initiative is being run jointly by the Electoral Commission, the Hansard Society and the Department for Education and Skills in the run-up to local elections and the general election, possibly on 5 May.Mock elections are planned to take place in schools across the UK.

Title: German economy rebounds
Article: Germany's economy, the biggest among the 12 country sharing the euro, grew at it fastest rate in four year during 2004, driven by strong exports. Gross domestic product (GDP) rose by 1.7% last year, the statistical office said. The economy contracted in 2003. Foreign sale increased by 8.2% last year, compared with a 0.3% slide in private consumption. Concerns remain, however, over the strength of the euro, weak domestic demand and a sluggish labour market. The European Central Bank (ECB) left it benchmark interest rate unchanged at 2% on Thursday. It is the nineteenth month in a row that the ECB ha not moved borrowing costs. Economists predict that an increase is unlikely to come until the second half of 2005, with growth set to sputter rather than ignite. "During 2004 we profited from the fact that the world economy wa strong," said Stefan Schilbe, analyst at HSBC Trinkaus & Burkhardt. "If export weaken and domestic growth remains poor, we cannot expect much from 2005." Many German consumer have been spooked and unsettled by government attempt to reform the welfare state and corporate environment. Major company including Volkswagen, DaimlerChrysler and Siemens have spent much of 2004 in tough talk with union about trimming job and costs. They have also warned there are more cost cutting measure on the horizon.

Title: Halo 2 heralds traffic explosion
Article: The growing popularity of online gaming could spell problem for net service firms, warns network monitoring company Sandvine. It issued the warning following analysis which show that traffic on the Xbox game network increased fourfold on the launch day of Halo 2. The 9 November traffic explosion ha continued into December, said Sandvine. Service provider now need to make sure that their network can cope with the increasing demand for bandwidth. As well a being a popular single-player title, Halo 2 can be connected to Microsoft's subscription-based broadband network, Xbox Live. Gamers who want to play online can create their own clan, or team, and take on others to see how well they compare. But the surge in number and huge demand for bandwidth should be a wake-up call to the industry which must ensure that their network can cope with the increase in traffic, said Sandvine's chief technology officer Marc Morin. In a bid to cope and ease congestion, provider are increasingly making their network intelligent, finding out who is using bandwidth and for what. It could become common to charge people for the amount of bandwidth they use. "The explosion in Xbox Live traffic attributed to Halo 2 should be seen a a clarion call," he said. "ISPs need to enhance the broadband experience for these high-end user by prioritising or reserving bandwidth for games," he added. One of the main factor that spoil online gaming is "lag" in which there is a noticeable delay between a gamer clicking on a mouse or keyboard and what happens in the online gaming world. Gamers tend to migrate toward network with the lowest "lag". Analysing traffic will become increasingly important for service provider if they are to hold on to bandwidth-hungry gamers said Lindsay Schroth, an analyst with research firm The Yankee Group. "In the competitive broadband environment, operator need to differentiate the way they offer access to service like live-play gaming," she said. In country such a Korea, which ha high level of fast net connection to homes, online gaming is hugely popular.

Title: Little Britain vies for TV trophy
Article: BBC hit Little Britain and Strictly Come Dancing are among numerous British show nominated for the prestigious Golden Rose television awards. Homegrown reality programme dominated that category, including Channel 4's Supernanny and ITV1's Hell's Kitchen. EastEnders and Coronation Street were overlooked in the soap category, but Doctors and Family Affairs gained nods. The festival, which honour the best TV from around the globe, will take place in Lucerne, Switzerland from 3-8 May. Little Britain, which is now in it second series, face competition from BBC Two's The Catherine Tate Show and Sacha Baron Cohen's creation Borat and Bruno. In the separate sitcom category, dark comedy Nighty Night - which began life on BBC Three - will do battle with mainstream BBC One show My Family. BBC One's Strictly Come Dancing, which saw celebrity compete against each other to become champion of the dancefloor, is among five British nomination in the varirty category. Lenny Henry, who won a Golden Rose for his In Pieces series in 2001, pick up another nomination for his recent BBC show. British television music show have picked up six nominations, with BBC Three's Flashmob - The Opera up against the UK Music Hall of Fame series, which wa screened on Channel 4. British television ha performed very well in the art and special category, gaining a total of 11 nominations. The BBC lead the way with it programme on The Sound of Music, Agatha Christie and Rolf On Art - The Big Event - which saw Harris lead an effort to produce a life-size painting in London's Trafalgar Square. British show - which picked up a total of 48 nomination - will have to overcome competition from a host of other countries, including the US, Canada, Japan and across Europe. UK nominee TV Diaries, which is shown around the world, is owned by a British company but ha yet to be screened in this country. Previous UK winner have included Ant & Dec's Saturday Night Takeaway, Pop Idol, Channel 4 show Faking It and comedy duo French and Saunders, who became the first winner to receive and honorary Golden Rose. Individual performer will also be rewarded, with prize for best comics, best sitcom actor and actress and best gameshow host. Last year actor Shane Richie won an award for his portrayal of Alfie Moon in EastEnders.

Title: Dollar drops on reserves concerns
Article: The US dollar ha dropped against major currency on concern that central bank may cut the amount of dollar they hold in their foreign reserves. Comments by South Korea's central bank at the end of last week have sparked the recent round of dollar declines. South Korea, which ha about $200bn in foreign reserves, said it plan instead to boost holding of currency such a the Australian and Canadian dollar. Analysts reckon that other nation may follow suit and now ditch the dollar. At 1300 GMT, the euro wa up 0.9% on the day at 1.3187 euro per US dollar. The British pound had added 0.5% to break through the $1.90 level, while the dollar had fallen by 1.3% against the Japanese yen to trade at 104.16 yen. At the start of the year, the US currency, which had lost 7% against the euro in the final three month of 2004 and had fallen to record lows, staged something of a recovery. Analysts, however, pointed to the dollar's inability recently to extend that rally despite positive economic and corporate data, and highlighted the fact that many of the US's economic problem had not disappeared. The focus once again ha been on the country's massive trade and budget deficits, with prediction of more dollar weakness to come. "The comment from Korea came at a time when sentiment towards the dollar wa already softening," said Ian Gunner, a trader at Mellon Financial. On Tuesday, trader in Asia said that both South Korea and Taiwan had withdrawn their bid to buy dollar at the start of the session. Mansoor Mohi-Uddin, chief currency strategist at UBS, said that there wa a sentiment in the market that "central bank from Asia and the Middle East are buying euros". A report last month already showed that the dollar wa losing it allure a a currency that offered rock-steady return and stability. Compiled by Central Banking Publications and sponsored by the UK's Royal Bank of Scotland, the survey found 39 nation out of 65 questioned were increasing their euro holdings, with 29 cutting back on the US dollar.
