Title: Terror powers expose 'tyranny'
Article: The Lord Chancellor ha defended government plan to introduce control order to keep foreign and British terrorist suspect under house arrest, where there isn't enough evidence to put them on trial. Lord Falconer insists that the proposal do not equate to a police state and strike a balance between protecting the public against the threat of terrorism and upholding civil liberties. But thriller writer Frederick Forsyth tell BBC News of his personal response to the move. There is a mortal danger aimed at the heart of Britain. Or so say Home Secretary Charles Clarke. My reaction? So what? It is not that I am cynical or just do not care. I care about this country very much. But in the 66 year that I have been alive, there ha not been one hour, of one day, of one month, of one year, when there ha not been a threat aimed at us. My point is, the British have always coped without becoming a dictatorship. We have coped with fear without becoming a state based on fear; we have coped with threat without turning our country into a land of state threat. But that is what the Blair government now seek to do - create a tyranny to defend u from the al-Qaeda tyranny. I wa born on 25 August, 1938. The mortal threat back then wa a scruffy little Austrian called Adolf Hitler. A week after my first birthday, the threat had become reality. We were at war. My father wore a uniform for five years. After 1945 we yearned for peace at last. But in 1946 Winston Churchill told u - from the Baltic to the Adriatic an Iron Curtain ha descended across Europe. Behind the Iron Curtain, another genocidal psychopath, another threat. Josef Stalin triggered the Cold War, with the Berlin blockade in 1948. My whole generation wa blighted by it. We were threatened by the nuclear holocaust, the nuclear wind, the nuclear winter. We built shelter that would have sheltered nothing. We spent our treasure on weapon instead of hospitals. We took silly precautions. Some fought it; some marched futilely against it. Some pretended it wa not there. The Cold War lasted 43 years, but we remained a parliamentary democracy. By the early seventy it wa terrorism a well. Al Fatah, Black September, Red Brigades, but most of all for u the IRA and the INLA. Thirty more years; 300 policeman and women, over 600 soldiers, more than 3,000 civilian dead, but we won because even IRA bomb could not force u to become a tyranny. That wa why the tyrant lost. Civil right were infringed a little a humanly possible. Evidence had to be taken in secret to protect covert sources; yes , and one judge, no-jury court had to be instituted when jury were terrorised. Informants had to be given immunity from their own crime to win the bigger battle. But habeas corpus did not die; right of appeal wa not abolished. Now the threat is Islamic fundamentalism. Its leader want to destroy our society; so did the IRA. It is based and funded abroad; so wa the IRA. It ha sleeper fanatic inside our society; so did the IRA. It is extremely hard to penetrate with our agents; so wa the IRA. The prime mover are not easy to bring to trial; neither were the IRA. But we did. And without becoming a tyranny. Now the Blair government proposes the law system of fascism and communism. The citizen can be arrested and held without charge or trial, not even on the careful consideration of an experienced judge, but the whim of a political activist called a government minister. To be protected from terror the government says, we must become a tyranny. But a tyranny is based on the citizen's terror. This is not victory; this is defeat before a shot is fired. An interesting article - it good to see widening participation in the debate - but I suggest we move one step further. Our own bomb and bullet will can only shatter peace, because invading foreign nations, imprisoning the innocent and 'hunting' in the 'shadows' cannot destroy an evil of the mind, and hatred within the heart. Rather than focusing upon effect, we should consider the cause, because terrorism doe not begin with bombs. Why not try a foreign policy of compassion, it can only enhance our democracy, and share our freedom. I agree with Frederick Forsyth. We really can't deal with terrorism by turning Britain into a fascist state. What we really need is more honesty from our security service and our politicians. If they do not have evidence to bring these people to trial, there probably isn't any. Our security services, behave like the detective who having decided that a certain person is guilty, rake over all kind of obscure and flimsy evidence to try and prove it, while the real villain get away. Remember there were no WMD in Iraq. Just because a person may have made some stupid and naive decision in life doe not make them a terrorist. In this overly 'politically correct' society, it is good to see someone like Mr. Forsyth speak out. Yes, there ha been oppression by the British government in the past, and overstepping the mark in place like Ireland, but yes, we are still a democracy where it is rare to be arrested without charge/trial etc. (apart from a number of prisoner in Belmarsh goal, for example).This country sign up to human rights, and then pretend that they only apply to the people with nothing to fear, the innocent people (defined by whom?). When ID card become mandatory, the data collected will not be protected by the Data Protection Act, and will be readily available to people like GCHQ, with no control by the person whose ID is being checked. The threat now is new. You cannot compare the threat of past year with now. Forsyth say 3000 died over 30 year or terrorism; 3000 people died in one morning in NY on September 11th 2001. The threat today is that terrorist will acquire nuclear or biological technology. A Kilo of Semtex will flatten a building, a Kilo of plutonium will flatten a city. You now have a combination of people who will perform terrorist act with technology that is rapidly becoming accessible. I agree, the government is probably encouraging a degree of mass-hysteria and talking up the threat; but talking-down the threat and doing nothing is unacceptable too. The problem with this issue is not that it isn't important, but the fact that in general we Brits can be so politically apathetic some times, that we will just let this go without telling the government no. However, a the nation that gave the world the common law and a true sense of the right of individual liberty I hope this will prove to be one step too far. As somebody of Chinese origin, I can say that this country used to be a good place to migrate and start a new life. Whilst life wasn't perfect, we could make better for ourselves. Now we are riddled with red tape and be told what we can or cannot do. We have to be politically-correct and we are not allowed to have belief or opinions. We have a Prime Minister who spends too much time meddling in US politics and affair which have little to do with the life of British Citizens at home or abroad. Mr Forsyth ha done a good job in voicing his opinions. Let's hope the BBC doesn't get gagged for letting people express their views. The people have the right to know and the BBC's role is to Inform, Educate and Entertain... I agree. Terrorists intend to spread fear but in reality it is the government which ha spread the fear, by it constant publicising of the this invisible enemy so dangerous that we must allow them to ride roughshod over our right and liberties. In the end, the very thing we seek to protect is what we are giving up in the name of safety from this invisible enemy. The terrorist have already won. I absolutely agree with Frederick Forsyth. Yes we have to defend ourselves against terrorism but existing law seem to be more than adequate. The idea that the "new terrorism" demand new power is erroneous. The evidence of any real terrorist capability in the UK is scant. Ricin, for example, is a dangerous poison but it is not a weapon of mass destruction. What is really worrying is the enthusiasm of Mr Blair and his government for authoritarian reaction and attempt to manipulate the electorate through fear. If the government ha it way with ID cards, tracking and so on then totalitarianism ha won and a such it then matter little whether we give in to the terrorist demand or not. We will have lost the precious freedom which Bush and Blair constantly tell u we have and that they seek to bring to others. I agree wholeheartedly with Mr Forsyth. I am shocked at the ease with which this government is prepared to wipe out a major portion of the liberty that British people have enjoyed for century - the right not to be deprived of our liberty without a trial in open court. That go right back to Magna Carta, and ordinary people have spilled their blood to enforce that right against government who thought they "knew best". When you look at today's Britain, you realise George Orwell wa only wrong about one thing: the date. Frederick Forsyth put it beautifully. The government is seeking to introduce a police state. The new power of home internment without trial follow a pattern which includes the introduction of surveillance via compulsory ID card and the linking of data bases, together with the un-British idea that we will have to swear allegiance to the state at the age of 18 years. We are sleep-walking into this. Wake up! An interesting view but missing two crucial fact of this new threat: 1) If these terrorist acquire weapon of mass destruction they WILL use them without fear of Mutually Assured Destruction that kept the cold war in a state of tense balance. These people will use devastating force against u without fear of ANY consequence. 2) The terrorist are prepared to use suicide bomber which mean they could kill innocent people on the London Underground and we could do very little to stop it. Because these terrorist are potentially SO deadly, we have to come up with new, tougher responses. It will be a little late in the day when people outside London wake up one morning to find out that London ha been nuked. We won't have much of a society left to debate ! He's correct in most of what he says. Mind you he doe seem to have forgotten that disgraceful internment policy in Northern Ireland which probably caused many idealistic if misguided young Catholics to join the IRA. Administrative detention of Muslims could have a similar effect now. Surely we the public would be better protected if the security services, rather than alerting a suspect terrorist by placing them under house arrest (and for how long?)They were to place suspect terrorist under surveillance and maybe acquire sufficient evidence to prosecute or even better prevent a terrorist attack. I don't usually have much time for Mr Forsyth's largely right wing view but this time he ha got it spot on. There is no doubt that there are terrorist organisation who would like to do harm to the U.K. but it is very doubtful whether al-Qaeda is a global organisation co-ordinating this. The rise of surveillance cameras, ID cards, the plan to charge for road use by tracking every vehicle at all times, this is the stuff of nightmares. Add to this this new legislation which effectively mean that the protection of the law will be removed from anyone at the whim of the Home Secretary, and I genuinely wonder what sort of world my two child will inherit. Where will this end. As it stand terrorist do not need to attack the U.K. it's government will soon have it's people terrorised more that they could very achieve with a few bombs. Mr Forsyth ha expressed exactly what my gut fear and reservation were about this proposed legislation, but could not verbalise. Thank you. Mr Forsyth seems to forget that killing in the Troubles occurred on both side of the religious divide and wa carried out by killer from both sides. He also forgets basic Human Rights were suspended then a now. Experienced Judges sat over some of the greatest miscarriage of justice during those times. For very little return and maximum alienation. These law and the emphasis on the Islamic threat will just do the same. Forsyth is wrong. The nature of the current threat is new. It is no longer to our armed forces, a the Soviet threat in the Eastern bloc was. It is to you and I. The terrorist aim to kill indiscriminately. The best comparison is therefore the blitz, 1941. At this time, let u not forget, suspect (foreign and British were routinely rounded up and interned for the duration of the war, without any complaint from the public. We must not forget we are at war. I'd say that that the likelihood of an attack by a sleeper cell of fundamentalist lunatic against a major UK target is a "When" not an "If" probability. I'll bet any money you like that the day after any such attack Freddie Forsyth will be saying that the government didn't do enough to protect the UK. People like Forsyth can only see one side of any argument and for him it is the side that is opposite New Labour and Tony Blair. I agree wholeheartedly with Mr Forsyth. The very reason this country ha been such a wonderful place to live, is under attack, not from terrorists, but from this government. The perpetuation of the perceived terrorist threat is not because of what the 'alleged' terrorist are doing, but from our own government. I believe what this government is doing, is, at the very least, highly questionable and at worst, sinister. At what point will they feel they have enough control over every single person in the British Isles; when we are all tagged and monitored constantly? Our freedom is being craftily and surreptitiously whittled away by this government and we are gaining nothing. It should be of great concern to everyone. I am slightly older than Mr Forsyth and therefore have lived through the same history a him. I am against a police state and would not like to think that I lived in one. I think that the attack on Iraq made the international situation worse and may have provoked further act of terrorism. How true. There are extremely worrying parallel between Britain now and Germany during the 30's. I never thought it would be so easy to take over a country from within. Mr Forsyth ha forgotten one key point; the terrorist who threaten Britain today are well aware that Hitler, Stalin, and the IRA all failed. As a result modern day terrorist are willing to do thing their predecessor did not. That doe not mean that the civil liberty of modern Britain must be eroded to counter the threat; that should always be the absolute last resort. But to meet the new threat, to defeat the sinister fanaticism of today's terrorists, we may need to do thing a little differently. Let u hope not. Frederic Forsythe's comment seem to me to be a well-thought-out analysis of why we (human society a a whole, and Britain in particular) should resist the temptation to over-protect through fear. It is this fear which enables terrorist to succeed in the end, and terrorist can come in all forms, a Mr. Forsythe's opening comment suggest. I am reminded of a quote attributed to Thomas Jefferson. "A nation that limit freedom in the name of security will have neither." The government are faced with an incredibly difficult task, and have made a policy to deal with it. It's all very well criticising that policy, but if Mr Forsythe can't draw on his year of experience to offer an alternative, I say 'So what?' to his opinions. Frederick Forsyth's rhetoric is absurd and his conclusion laughable. He distorts reality to serve his own prejudice against New Labour. This government seek to balance protection of our democracy with minimum loss of civil rights. It is Frederick Forsyth who is the extremist, because he doe not appreciate the need for balance. I rarely find myself agreeing with My Forsyth, but in this instance I think he is correct. The rule of law must prevail, civil liberty are worth defending. If the government can hold 'suspects' without charge or trial, what's next? I agree absolutely. By introducing fascist type law we loose the moral high ground in our fight against terror. Our democratic system is not perfect, but a Churchill point out it is "better than all the others that have been tried". Terrorist attack will take place but for many reason we should take that personal risk in return for personal freedom. I do not usually agree with Mr. Forsyth, but he is spot on here. The single biggest threat we face is that of a government dedicated to acting illegally and manipulating international and national law to suit it own purpose. Totalitarianism always requires an outside threat, justifying a range of extraordinary power leader want. The British government is a far greater threat that and terrorist organisation. Although, in principle I agree with him, Frederick Forsyth fails to address one key point- al-Qaeda attack (though obviously there have been none yet in the UK) seek to kill the maximum number of people. The IRA wanted to limit the death toll of their attack so a to maintain support among the republican movement. Yes, I agree with Mr. Forsyth's views. I do not believe the government's plan are justified. There is over reaction to and the negative influence of the US President's interpretation of democracy and freedom. He us the same argument that were current before the WWII, the Wars to "liberate" Iraq, Afghanistan with Syria and Iran to come. We are leaving a poor inheritance for the future generations. Mr Forsyth is a wonderful writer and should keep his fiction where it belongs. The British Government is not going down the road that Mr Forsyth suggests. Sadly comment such a his will make a lot of people believe that they are governed by people who are fast becoming tyrant instead of being genuinely committed to stopping tyranny, even if the method employed to do that is at the moment alien to the British people who have lived in a democracy protected by Tony Blair and others of like mind who, Mr. Forsyth seems to be putting along side the 'scruffy little Austrian.' Thomas Hobbes would be smiling in his grave at Labour's propositions. Like New Labour, he called himself a libertarian. Like New Labour, he believed he wa promoting the people's best interests. But a Forsythe criticises this government, Hobbes ha been criticised by most subsequent philosopher for arguing his way into the hand of the totalitarians. Simply put, he argued that in favour of the ultimate liberty - the liberty to live - man should be prepared to surrender all other liberty to a supreme sovereign, a protection against his fellow, barbaric, man. Hobbes ha been roundly condemned by posterity, and rightly so. I hope New Labour suffers the same treatment. I agree with Mr Forsyth's views. The government approach is totally against the spirit of British democracy. They must not be allowed to get away with it. Of course Frederick is wrong about Britain winning the war against the IRA and he's wrong too about the country not becoming a tyranny. Has he forgotten about shoot to kill, torture, internment without trial, collusion with loyalist death squad etc? My background is somewhat similar to Freddie's so I am persuaded to agree with many of his sentiments. We can have no moral justification for imposing our system of government on anyone while we are systematically depriving our own citizen of basic individual and collective freedoms. Whilst the principle of keeping potential terrorist under house arrest might seem superficially attractive, it is, unfortunately, also the first step towards totalitarianism. Who is to decide whom is a suspect? Why should we believe them? Who can have faith in the honesty, integrity, and competence of our intelligence service and politician in light of the event of recent years? What is to stop false denunciations? What of those falsely accused who will lose their careers? Who will support their families? Will their child still go to school? It smack to me of the method of Nazi Germany, Stalin's Russia, Ceausescu's Romania - the list go on. It look a if a new dark age is coming. I see that opinion on Mr Forsyth's remark are divided. The problem I see is that those who support imprisonment without trial believe it will never happen to them or their family, only to people they don't like or are scared of. But history ha shown that if you have law like that, they always get abused by those in power. After all, today you may be scared of the same people a those in power but someday those in power may be scared of you! And that day, you'll be the one imprisoned without the chance of justice. Our law are such that you cannot just be imprisoned at the whim of our police forces, you have to be shown to be deserving of it. If we imprison people without trial for an indeterminate period, we are no better that those we are fighting. I never thought it possible for me to agree with a single word uttered by Frederick Forsyth, but I'm in wholehearted agreement with him on this one. We, a a nation are in grave danger of being duped by pro US propaganda, which of course also mean we'll inherit most, if not all of their total paranoia, and allow our governments, of any political persuasion incidentally, to gradually, and insidiously, impose a police state by well tried & tested back door methods. I grieve for the future of my children, it's no wonder they're adamant they don't ever want any of their own. This government, with much fanfare, sign u up to the European Convention on Human Rights but now want to introduce indefinite house arrest without trial. This put it on a par with the government of Burma. Like many of your respondents, I wouldn't usually think of Mr Forsyth a someone whose view I share, but in the instance of opposing Charles Clark's proposal for house arrest, I agree wholeheartedly with Mr Forsyth/ I agree with Mr Forsyth. Just look at the fact - our government (along with the US) invaded another sovereign country (Iraq) by selecting intelligence that backed it's case based on fear. The fact turned out to be very different. If individual are treated in the same distorted way, then we've done ourselves more damage than any terrorist organisation could with bombs. We become animal too. I agree in many way with what Mr Forsyth ha said - if we are to be respected and have influence within the world we must be seen to be walking the walk a well a talking the talk - how can we accuse country such a Zimbabwe and Burma of human right abuse when we are locking up people who may be totally innocent, it is hypocrisy of the highest order. Mr Forsyth link "Islamic fundamentalism" to the new "threat". However it appears that he ha misunderstood the term "Islamic fundamentalism". It should be pointed out that a Muslim who adheres to the true fundamental of the Qur'aan and the teaching of the last Prophet Muhammad is an Islamic Fundamentalist. This person doe not commit suicide in any shape or form, nor doe she/he kill innocent women, men and children. This person is self-reflective and constantly try to better her/his action by being good to others. The people who Mr Forsyth label the new "threat" are those who do not follow the correct teaching of Islam. They have arrived at their own interpretation and assumption with regard their actions. On top of that, they claim to be following Islam in it true form! I accept that the intention of these policy are to make Britain a safer place but I cannot think of a single example from history where doing this sort of thing ha ever made any difference - in Northern Ireland internment certainly didn't achieve anything - the bombing didn't stop, and it could be argued that all it achieved wa to just supply the IRA with yet more angry and resentful republican willing to take up arm against the British. Title: Lewis-Francis eyeing world gold
Article: Mark Lewis-Francis say his Olympic success ha made him determined to bag World Championship 100m gold in 2005. The 22-year-old pipped Maurice Greene on the last leg of the 4x100m relay in Athens to take top honour for Team GB. But individually, the Birchfield Harrier ha yet to build on his World Junior Championship win four year ago. "The gold medal in Athens ha made me realise that I can get to the top level and I want to get there again. It can happen, I don't see why not," he said. Lewis-Francis ha still to decided what event will feature in his build-up to the world - with one exception. He ha confirmed his participation in the Norwich Union Grand Prix in Birmingham on 18 February, where he will take on another member of Britain's victorious men's relay team - Jason Gardener - over 60m. He added: "It's a bit too early to make any prediction for Helsinki, but I have my eye open and I know I can be the best in the world."

Title: Download chart debut is delayed
Article: The inclusion of downloaded music in the official single chart ha been delayed for a month. The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) had planned to include download format in the chart from 20 March. But the date ha been put back to 17 April to create a "level playing field" for independent labels. The BPI is concerned that independent repertoire is not adequately represented online and said they were looking at way of rectifying it. BPI chairman Peter Jamieson said: "The inclusion of download format in the Official UK Singles Chart is the most significant development in the chart for 20 years. "But for a multitude of reason the current chart representation of independent repertoire at the major download outlet is poor. "I am very pleased we have secured this delay on behalf of independents. We have to try and establish a realistic 'level playing field' of opportunity. The Official UK Charts are run by The Official UK Charts Company (OCC) - a joint venture between the BPI and the British Association of Record Dealers (BARD). At an OCC board meeting on Wednesday, the OCC board agreed with BPI member that the 20 March start date be postponed. Download format will now be included in the Official UK Singles Chart for the first time in the chart published on 17 April - the sale week beginning 10 April. The US ha already merged downloaded single into it Billboard Hot 100 chart.

Article: Actor Gerard Jugnot - star of the Oscar-nominated film The Chorus - ha beaten Gerard Depardieu to become France's best-paid actor of 2004. Jugnot made 5.45m Euros (Â£3.77m) last year, according to a table drawn up by France's Le Figaro newspaper. In The Chorus (Les Choristes), Jugnot play an inspiring music teacher at a school for troubled boy in 1949. Despite starring in five film in 2004, Depardieu made 3.35m Euros (Â£2.31m) putting him third place in the chart. "His name [Depardieu] is no longer sufficient to guarantee the success of a film," said Le Figaro newspaper. The Chorus, which Jugnot also co-produced, ha drawn an audience of nearly nine million people since it release last year. Godzilla star Jean Reno wa France's second best-paid actor in 2004, earning 3.55m Euros (Â£2.45m) . His role include a recent uncredited cameo in the Oscar-nominated Hotel Rwanda. The highest-ranking woman on Le Figaro's list wa Audrey Tautou in 10th place, earning 885,000 Euros (Â£611,000). She starred in Jean-Pierre Jeunet's A Very Long Engagement (Un Long Dimanche de Fiancailles) and is also lined up to co-star with Tom Hanks in Ron Howard's The Da Vinci Code. The Chorus is nominated for best foreign film at Sunday's Oscar ceremony. On Saturday, it will compete for the title of best film against fellow nominee A Very Long Engagement in France's Cesar film awards.

Title: Kenteris denies faking road crash
Article: Greek sprinter Kostas Kenteris ha denied claim that he faked a motorbike crash to avoid a doping test day before the start of the Olympics. Kenteris and fellow sprinter Katerina Thanou are set to learn if they will face criminal charge this week. Part of the investigation ha centred on whether they staged the crash. Kenteris insisted: "The accident happened. I went crazy when I found out I had supposedly missed a test and I wanted to rush to the Olympic village." Kenteris, speaking on Greece's Alter Television station, also claimed that he asked to be tested for banned substance in hospital after the crash. "I told the hospital, which wa an Olympics-accredited hospital, to call the IOC and have me tested on the spot but no-one came." After a drama which dominated newspaper headline in Greece a Athens prepared for the start of the Athens Games, Kenteris and Thanou eventually withdrew. But Kenteris ha continually protested his innocence - and on Sunday blamed Greek Olympic Committee official and his former coach Christos Tzekos for failing to inform him of the test. The 31-year-old insisted he will be happy if he is charged so he can clear his name. "If a decision is taken to have charge filed against me, I will accept it gladly. "A prosecution mean that the case will be cleared... I want to go to the end and then we'll see who's right and who isn't." Kenteris, a Greek hero after winning gold in the 200m at the 2000 Olympics in Sydney, also confirmed that he wa due to light the flame at the Athens opening ceremony. "I had even rehearsed lighting the cauldron," he said.

Title: Uganda bans Vagina Monologues
Article: Uganda's authority have banned the play The Vagina Monologues, due to open in the capital, Kampala this weekend. The Ugandan Media Council said the performance would not be put on a it promoted and glorified act such a lesbianism and homosexuality. It said the production could go ahead if the organiser "expunge all the offending parts". But the organiser of the play say it raise awareness of sexual abuse against women. "The play promotes illegal, unnatural sexual acts, homosexuality and prostitution, it should be and is hereby banned," the council's ruling said. The show, which ha been a controversial sell-out around the world, explores female sexuality and strength through individual woman telling their story through monologues. Some parliamentarian and church leader are also siding with the Media Council, Uganda's New Vision newspaper reports. "The play is obscene and pornographic although it wa under the guise of women's liberation," MP Kefa Ssempgani told parliament. But the work's author, US playwright Eve Ensler, say it is all about women's empowerment. "There is obviously some fear of the vagina and saying the word vagina," Ms Ensler told the BBC. "It's not a slang word or dirty word it's a biological, anatomical word." She said the play is being produced and performed by Ugandan woman and it is not being forced on them. The four Ugandan NGOs organising the play intended to raise money to campaign to stop violence against woman and to raise fund for the war-torn north of the country. "I'm extremely outraged at the hypocrisy," the play's organiser in Uganda, Sarah Mukasa, told the BBC's Focus on Africa programme. "I'm amazed that this country Uganda give the impression that it is progressive and support women's right and the notion of free speech; yet when woman want to share their story the government us the apparatus of state to shut u up."

Title: Ministers lose slopping out case
Article: The Scottish Executive ha lost an appeal against an inmate's compensation for being forced to slop out in prison. Armed robber Robert Napier, 25, won Â£2,450 after he claimed he suffered an outbreak of the skin complaint, eczema, when slopping out at Barlinnie Prison. Napier said that the practice, where prisoner use bucket in their cell a toilets, breached his human rights. On Thursday, the Court of Session threw out a move by the executive to apply a more rigorous standard of proof. The executive face more than 1,000 similar claim for damage from prisoner and former inmates. More than 310 action have already been raised in the Court of Session and sheriff court in Scotland. An executive spokesman said: "We will study this judgement in detail. Much ha changed to address the issue raised in the Napier case, for example, slopping out ha ended at Barlinnie and work in other prison is being accelerated. "Today's judgement doe not affect the outcome of other cases." Napier, a remand prisoner at the time, raised a legal challenge in 2001 under the European Convention on Human Rights, in which he sought Â£5,000. He wa awarded compensation last April after winning his case. Executive minister raised an appeal arguing that the standard of proof to be applied in case alleging a breach of the European Convention on Human Rights through degrading and inhumane treatment should "be beyond reasonable doubt". This is the standard normally applied in criminal trial in Scotland. However, civil litigation is settled on the test of "a balance of probabilities". Judge Lord Cullen, sitting with Lord Osborne and Lord Hamilton, ruled that alleged human right breach involving degrading treatment should be dealt with on the normal civil standard. Title: Japan turns to beer alternatives
Article: Japanese brewer are increasingly making money from beer-flavoured drink rather than beer itself Beer and spirit are heavily taxed in Japan, driving brewery to search for alternatives. Japan's long economic downturn helped drive the trend, a drinker looked for cheaper opportunity to drown their sorrows. Now, according to Asahi Breweries, the market for so-called "beer-like" drink is set to grow 84% this year. Asahi is predicting profit to rise 50% in 2005 a it launch a drink based on soybean peptide rather than malt. The chosen name, "Shinnama" or "new draft", disguise it non-beer nature. But despite a record profit in 2004 of 30.6bn yen ($291m; Â£154m), up 31.8% on the previous year, Asahi is coming late to the market. Key rival Sapporo is already well-established with the beer-flavoured "Draft One". Suntory, meanwhile, is doing well with "Super Blue", which combine happoshu - an existing low-cost beer alternative made with malt and seawater - and shochu, a distilled alcohol derived from sweet potato or barley. Happoshu ha been a mainstay of brewery profit for years, taking over from beer thanks to it low tax and therefore low cost. Kirin, the fourth big name, is launching it own "third-type" drink in April.

Title: 'Nuclear dumpsite' plan attacked
Article: Plans to allow foreign nuclear waste to be permanently stored in the UK have been branded "deeply irresponsible" by the Liberal Democrats. The government ha confirmed intermediate level waste (ILW) that wa to have been shipped back to it home country will now be stored in the UK. The cash raised will go towards the UK's nuclear clean-up programme. But Lib Dem Norman Baker accused minister of turning Britain into a "nuclear dumpsite". Under current contracts, British Nuclear Fuels should return all but low level waste, but none ha ever been sent back. In future, only highly-radioactive waste will be sent back to it country of origin, normally Germany or Japan, under armed guard. Intermediate waste from country such a Japan, Germany, Spain, Italy, Switzerland and Sweden will be stored permanently in the UK. At the moment, this waste is stored at Sellafield, in Cumbria, in the form of glass bricks, untreated liquid waste or solid material in drums. In a statement, the Department of Trade and Industry said the new policy meant there would be a "sixfold reduction in the number of waste shipment to overseas countries". And it said highly-radioactive waste would be returned to it home country sooner, ensuring there would be no overall increase in radioactivity. Trade Secretary Patricia Hewitt said the new arrangements, revealed in a Commons written statement, would raise up to Â£680m for Britain's nuclear clean-up programme, under the new Nuclear Decommissioning Agency. But the move ha been criticised by environmental group and the Liberal Democrats. Mr Baker, the Lib Dem environment spokesman, said: "I have been warning for month that this would happen and raised it with government several times. But now our worst fear have been confirmed. "Once again Britain's environmental and health need are being ignored in policy driven by the Treasury and DTI. "This is a terrible attempt to offload some of the Â£48bn cost of cleaning up nuclear sites. "The Energy Act wa supposed to help Britain clean up, but in order to pay for it we are becoming a nuclear dumpsite. "The nuclear industry is an economic, social and environmental millstone that hang around Britain's neck."

Title: Remote control rifle range debuts
Article: Soon you could go hunting via the net. A Texas company is considering letting web user use a remote-controlled rifle to shoot down deer, antelope and wild pigs. For a small fee user will take control of a camera and rifle that they can use to spot and shoot the game animal a they roam around a 133-hectare Texas ranch. The Live-Shot website behind the scheme already let people practise shooting at target via the internet. John Underwood, the man behind the Live-Shot website, said the idea for the remote-control hunting came to him a year ago when he wa watching deer via a webcam on another net site. "We were looking at a beautiful white-tail buck and my friend said 'If you just had a gun for that'. A little light bulb went off in my head," Mr Underwood told the Reuters news agency. A year's work and $10,000 ha resulted in a remote-controlled rig on which sits a camera and .22 calibre rifle. Mr Underwood is planning to put one of these rig in a concealed location in a small reserve on his Texas ranch and let people shoot at a variety of game animals. Also needed is a fast net connection so remote hunter can quickly track and aim at passing game animal with the camera and rifle rig. Each remote hunting session will cost $150 with additional fee for meat processing and taxidermy work. Species that can be shot will include barbary, Corsican and mouflon sheep, blackbuck antelope and wild pigs. Already the Live-Shot site let people shoot 10 round at paper and silhouette target for $5.95 for each 20-minute shooting session. For further fees, user can get the target they shot and a DVD recording of their session. Handlers oversee each shooting session and can stop the gun being fired if it is being aimed off-range or at something it should not be. Mr Underwood said that internet hunting could be popular with disabled hunter unable to get out in the wood or distant hunter who cannot afford a trip to Texas. In a statement the RSPCA said it had "grave concerns" about people being allowed to go online and remotely control a rifle. "We assume it would be extremely difficult to accurately control a gun in this way and therefore it would be difficult to ensure a 'clean kill', something the RSPCA accepts is the intention of those shooting for sport," it said. "Animals hit but not killed would without doubt be caused to suffer unnecessarily," said the statement. Mike Berger, wildlife director of the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, said current hunting statute did not cover net or remote hunting. He said state law on hunting only covered "regulated animals" such a native deer and bird species. As such there wa nothing to stop Mr Underwood letting people hunt "unregulated" imported animal and wild pigs. Mr Underwood also let people come in person to the ranch to hunt and shoot game animals.

Title: US woman sues over ink cartridges
Article: A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), saying it printer ink cartridge are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date. The unnamed woman from Georgia say that a chip inside the cartridge tell the printer that it need re-filling even when it doe not. The lawsuit seek to represent anyone in the US who ha purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's biggest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridge use a chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change. But the suit claim the chip also shut down the cartridge at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are empty. "The smart chip is dually engineered to prematurely register ink depletion and to render a cartridge unusable through the use of a built-in expiration date that is not revealed to the consumer," the suit said. The lawsuit is asking for restitution, damage and other compensation. The cost of printer cartridge ha been a contentious issue in Europe for the last 18 months. The price of inkjet printer ha come down to a little a Â£34 but it could cost up to Â£1,700 in running cost over an 18-month period due to cartridge, a study by Computeractive Magazine revealed last year. The inkjet printer market ha been the subject of an investigation by the UK's Office of Fair Trading (OFT), which concluded in a 2002 report that retailer and manufacturer needed to make pricing more transparent for consumers.

Title: Big war games battle it out
Article: The arrival of new title in the popular Medal Of Honor and Call of Duty franchise leaf fan of wartime battle title spoilt for choice. The acclaimed PC title Call of Duty ha been updated for console formats, building on many of the original's elements. For it part, the long-running Medal of Honor series ha added Pacific Assault to it PC catalogue, adapting the console game Rising Sun. Call of Duty: Finest Hour cast you a a succession of allied soldier fighting on World War 2 battlefront including Russia and North Africa. It is a traditional first-person-viewed game that let you control just one character, in the midst of a unit where cohort constantly bark order at you. On a near-identical note, Medal of Honor: Pacific Assault doe all it can to make you feel part of a tight-knit team and plum in the middle of all-out action. Its arena are the war's Pacific battles, including Guadalcanal and Pearl Harbour. You play one character throughout, a raw and rather talkative US soldier. Both game rely on a carefully stage-managed structure that keep thing ticking along. When this works, it is a brilliant device to make you feel part of a story. When it doe not, it is tedious. A winning moment is an early scene in Pacific Assault, where you come under attack at the famous US base in Hawaii. You are first ushered into a gunboat attacking the incoming wave of Japanese planes, then made to descend into a sinking battleship to rescue crewman, before seizing the anti-aircraft guns. It is one of the finest set-pieces ever seen in a video game. This notion of shuffling the player along a studiously pre-determined path, forcibly witnessing a series of pre-set moment of action, is a perilous business which can make the whole affair feel stilted rather than organic. The genius of something like Half Life 2 is that it skilfully disguise it linear plotting by various mean of misdirection. This pair of game do not really accomplish that, being more concerned with imparting a full-on atmospheric experience. Call of Duty come with a suitably bombastic score and overblown presentation. Finest Hour ha a similar determination, framing everything in moody wartime music, archive footage and lot of reflective voice-overs. Letting you play a number of different role is an interesting ploy that add new dimension to the Call of Duty endeavour, even if it sacrifice the narrative flow somewhat. The game's drawback could be said to be it format; taste differ, but these wartime shooter often do seem to work better on PC. The mouse control is a big reason why, along with the sharper graphic a top-end computer can muster and the apparent notion that PC game are allowed to get away with a bit more subtlety. Call of Duty on PC wa more detailed, plot-wise and graphically, and this new adaptation feel a little rough and ready. Targeting with the PS2 controller proved tricky, not helped by unconvincing collision-detection. You can shoot an enemy repeatedly with zero question a to your aim, yet the bullet will just refuse to hit him. Checkpoints are so few and far between that when you get shot, which happens regularly, you are set harshly far back, and will find yourself covering vast tract of scorched earth again and again. The game want to be a challenge, and is, and many player will like it for that. It is a dynamic a battlefield simulator a you will experience and even if it is not a refined a it PC parent, the sense of being part of the action is thoroughly impressive. Both of these game feature military colleague who are disturbingly bad shot and prone to odd behaviour. And in Pacific Assault in particular, their command and comment are irritatingly meaningless. But the teamwork element in title like this is superficial, designed to add atmosphere and camaraderie rather than affect the gameplay mechanic at all. Of the two games, Pacific Assault get more thing right, including little point like auto-saving intelligently and having tidier presentation. It engages you very well and also look wonderful, making the most of the lush tropical setting that are reminiscent of the glorious Far Cry, although we had to ramp up the setting on a high-spec machine to get the most out of them. Finest Hour is by no mean bad, and it is only because the PC original wa so dazzling that this version sometimes feel underwhelming. Those looking for a wartime game with plenty of atmosphere and a hearty abundance of enemy to shoot will be contented. But they will also have a niggling puzzlement a to why it doe not break a little more ground rather then just being competent.

Title: Spirit awards hail Sideways
Article: The comedy Sideways ha dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six of the award for which it wa nominated. It wa named best film while Alexander Payne won best director and best screenplay, along with writing partner Jim Taylor. It also won acting award for star Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church and Virginia Madsen. Sideways is tipped to do well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, are given to film made outside the traditional studio system, and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winner included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who took best actress for her role a a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama Maria Full of Grace. Moreno is also nominated for best actress at the Oscars. The best first screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for Maria Full of Grace. Scrubs star Zach Braff won the award for best first feature for Garden State, which he wrote, directed and starred in. Oscar-nominated euthanasia film The Sea Inside from Spain won best foreign film, while Metallica: Some Kind Of Monster wa awarded best documentary. Actor Rodrigo de la Serna took the best debut performance prize for The Motorcycle Diaries. The award are voted for by the 9,000 member of the Independent Feature Project/Los Angeles, which includes actors, directors, writer and other industry professionals. Last year's big winner, Lost In Translation, went on to win the Oscar for best original screenplay, for writer-director Sofia Coppola.

Title: Fannie Mae 'should restate books'
Article: US mortgage company Fannie Mae should restate it earnings, a move that is likely to put a billion-dollar dent in it accounts, watchdog have said. The Securities & Exchange Commission accused Fannie Mae of using technique that "did not comply in material respects" with accounting standards. Fannie Mae last month warned that some record were incorrect. The other main US mortgage firm Freddie Mac restated earnings by $5bn (Â£2.6bn) last year after a probe of it books. The SEC's comment are likely to increase pressure on Congress to strengthen supervision of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The two firm are key part of the US financial system and effectively underwrite the mortgage market, financing nearly half of all American house purchase and dealing actively in bond and other financial instruments. The investigation of Freddie Mac in June 2003 sparked concern about the wider health of the industry and raised questionsmarks over the role of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight (OFHEO), the industry's main regulator. Having been pricked into action, the OFHEO turned it attention to Fannie May and in September this year said that the firm had tweaked it book to spread earnings more smoothly across quarter and play down the amount of risk it had taken on. The SEC found similar problems. The watchdog's chief accountant Donald Nicolaisen said that "Fannie Mae's methodology of assessing, measuring and documenting hedge ineffectiveness wa inadequate and wa not supported" by generally accepted accounting principles.

Title: New York rockers top talent poll
Article: New York electro-rock group The Bravery have come top of the BBC News website's Sound of 2005 poll to find the music scene's most promising new act. The Bravery, who have been compared to The Cure and New Order, were the most heavily-tipped act in the survey of 110 impartial critic and broadcasters. Rock band Keane won Sound of 2004 while US rapper 50 Cent topped Sound of 2003. Other new artist in this year's list include London indie group Bloc Party at second and UK rapper Kano third. The Bravery played their first gig in 2003 and have since supported band including The Libertines, Interpol and Echo and the Bunnymen. They were the subject of a record company bidding war in 2004 and their debut single, Unconditional, caused a huge buzz when it wa released in the UK in November. Singer Sam Endicott said he felt "great" about coming top of the Sound of 2005 list. "Anyone that say they don't want a zillion screaming fan is a jackass, a liar," he said. One of the expert to tip The Bravery wa The Times' music critic Paul Connolly, who said they were "spiky but in love with pop". Chris Hawkins, host of BBC 6 Music's chart show, said the band had "great guitar and a mastery of the electro-clash sound". "The Bravery are proof alone that New York City is still home to hot new talent," he said. Nigel Harding, head of music at London rock radio station Xfm, said every track from their live set "sounded like a potential single". Unconditional reached the summit of the station's listeners' chart within a fortnight of it first play, which Mr Harding described a "an unheard of achievement for a debut single". Title: Parry puts Gerrard 'above money'
Article: Listen to the full interview on Sport on Five and the BBC Sport website from 1900 GMT. But Parry, speaking exclusively to BBC Sport, also admits Gerrard, who ha been constantly linked with Chelsea, will have the final say on his future. He told BBC Five Live: "Steven is above money. He is the future of Liverpool. "It doesn't matter if it's Â£30m, Â£40m or Â£50m, we will not accept offers. But we are also realistic enough to know we can't keep Steven against his will." On the subject of Liverpool's finances, Parry also revealed the club is ready to explore the possibility of a sponsorship deal for it proposed new stadium. And responding to criticism from BBC Sport pundit and former Liverpool stalwart Alan Hansen, he insisted talk on new investment are ongoing, but added the door ha not closed on shareholder and lifelong fan Steve Morgan. Parry joined Liverpool a chief executive in July 1998 from a similar role at the Premier League. There have been several high and low during his time in charge at Anfield - and he had a busy summer, overseeing the arrival of new manager Rafael Benitez and managing to hold on to Steven Gerrard. On the subject of Liverpool's captain and prize asset, Parry revealed Real Madrid did ask for an option on the England midfield man during negotiation for striker Fernando Morientes. He said: "They were looking for way of saying they got more out of the deal for Fernando Morientes, but the response to Real Madrid wa the same - Steven is not for sale." But when asked if Gerrard would be a Liverpool player on the first day of next season, Parry said: "I sincerely hope he will be. Steven know my views. He know Rafa's views. "We have re-affirmed recently to Steven that we are trying to build a team around him. We crave success a much a he does. We know he's ambitious and nobody can argue with that. "I think Steven would dearly love to win thing with Liverpool more than he'd like to do anything else. "We all want to see progress by next season. He's not alone in that. There are a lot of other player who feel the same, so we all have a common aim." It is expected Chelsea will test Liverpool with a Â£30m-plus bid in the summer - but Parry claim he will be in no mood to listen. "There have been a lot of open secret about Steven, most of which have been complete myths. It is suggested we had a deal tied up last summer. We didn't had an offer last summer," Parry explained. "We had told Chelsea that a far a we were concerned he wa not for sale and we didn't want to sell him. In reality it didn't go beyond that. "Maybe there will be an offer in the summer. Maybe there won't. "Our position is we want Steven to stay, but we are also realistic enough and have enough respect for Steven - and he ha enough respect for u - to know that it is his decision that will be crucial. "You are not going to keep a player like Steven against his will. That just doesn't work, but any idea we are going to accept offer for Steven and then tell him 'by the way we've decided to sell you' is not on the agenda. You can forget that." Parry is currently in the process of finalising funding for Liverpool's new stadium in Stanley Park, which is set to open in 2007. And he confessed Arsenal's Â£100m deal with Emirates to sponsor their new ground - complete with naming right - ha given the Anfield club serious food for thought. He said: "I have to say historically it is something I have been against, and I have been on record a saying that, but I think the size of the Arsenal deal is a real eye-opener. "I would say in the past deal have been done frankly far too cheaply and it just hasn't even been worth contemplating. "But the Arsenal deal is the sort of deal that cause you to draw breath and say 'wow - that's interesting.' "My personal point of view is that I would find it a hell of a lot more palatable than a shared stadium." Some Liverpool fan would find such a move highly controversial, but Parry countered: "I recognise it would be an emotive issue for many supporters, but you look at the amount of money available and it could go into the team. "If it wa the right partner how strong an issue is it? Time will tell. "I think the stadium will always be Anfield, not least because of where it is, but do we need to investigate the possibility of sponsorship? I think it would be remiss not to. "That's not to say we have made a decision that we will go down that road, but I think it is clearly something we have to explore." On the subject of possible new investment, Parry revealed Liverpool are still in negotiation with a mystery investor, with rumour of interest from the Middle East. That prompted the withdrawal of tycoon Steve Morgan, who got frustrated by failed bid and what he claimed wa indecision by the board. He also accused Liverpool of using him a "a stalking horse" to attract other bids, but Parry explained: "Steve ha never been used a a stalking horse. There's no need, and that is not the way we do business. "We had discussion with Steve over the course of 2004. I think we came close to concluding a deal in the summer but it didn't happen. "Quite genuinely, the new interest did appear relatively late in the day just prior to the AGM in December, and a I have said it wa of such potential magnitude, and that potential is so exciting, we felt we had to evaluate it. We are still evaluating it. "Steve's interest wa taken very much on it own merits. His enthusiasm for the club is there for all to see and who know what the next few month will hold? "The door isn't closed on anything. We had a perfectly sensible dialogue with Steve last year. "We have a common interest in making Liverpool successful. We cannot let that sum of money go, despite Gerrard's quality. Through a cleverly worded statement, the club ha effectively forced Gerrard to publicly make the decision for himself, which I think is the right thing to do. Critical time for Liverpool with regard to Gerrard. Ideally we would want to secure his future to the club for the long term. I am hoping he doesn't walk out of the club like Michael Owen did for very little cash. Â£50m realistically would allow Rafa to completely rebuild the squad, however, if we can afford to do this AND keep Gerrard we will be better for it. I would however be happy with Gerrard's transfer for any fee over Â£35m. Parry's statement are clever in that any future Gerrard transfer cannot be construed a a lack of ambition by the club to not try and keep their best players. Upping the ante is another smart move by Parry. I would keep Gerrard. No amount of money could replace his obvious love of the club and determination to succeed. The key is if Gerrard come out and say that he is happy. Clearly, if he isn't, then we would be foolish not to sell. The worrying thing is who would you buy (or who would come) pending possible non-Champions League football.

Title: Downloads enter US singles chart
Article: Digital music downloads are being included in the main US single chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sale of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green Day's Boulevard of Broken Dreams is currently number two in Billboard's pop chart, and top it digital chart. Download sale are due to be incorporated into the UK single chart later this year. Digital sale in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be tallied with sale of physical single and airplay information to make up it new Hot 100 chart. Its second new chart - the Pop 100 - also combine airplay, digital and physical sale but confines it airplay information to US radio station which play chart music. In addition to Green Day, other artist in the current US digital sale top 10 include Kelly Clarkson, The Game and the Killers. Sales of legally downloaded song shot up more than tenfold in 2004, with 200 million track purchased online in the US and Europe in 12 months, the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI) reported last month. In the UK sale of song downloads overtook those for physical single for the first time at the end of last year. The last week of December 2004 saw download sale of 312,000 compared with 282,000 physical singles, according to the British Phonographic Industry. The UK's first official music download chart wa launched last September, compiling the most popular track downloaded from legal UK site - including iTunes, OD2, mycokemusic.com and Napster. Westlife's Flying Without Wings - a 1999 track reissued for the occasion - wa the first number one of the UK download chart. A spokesman for the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) said the first combined UK download and sale chart wa due to be compiled "within the first half of this year". "Work is going on across the music business right now to make sure the new chart work to plan," he said. The BPI spokesman described the UK music download chart, compiled by the Official Charts Company, a having been "a great success" since it launch. "It ha provided a focus for the industry and ha really driven interest in downloads among music fans," he said.

Title: Films on war triumph at Sundance
Article: A study of the United States at war in the past 50 year ha picked up one of the main award at the 2005 Sundance Film Festival in Utah, in the US. Why We Fight scooped the grand jury prize for documentary at the world's leading independent film festival. British director Sean McAllister's The Liberace of Baghdad - about a pianist in war-torn Iraq - won a special prize in the world documentary category. Both Why We Fight and The Liberace of Baghdad were made for the BBC. Why We Fight is due to be screened on BBC Four in March. The Sundance festival wa founded by actor Robert Redford in 1981. This year's festival - which ended on Sunday after a 11-day run - ha been dominated by the theme of war and politics. In the new world cinema drama category, the Angolan film The Hero triumphed to win the grand jury prize. The film - an Angolan/French/Portuguese production - tell the story of a veteran of the country's civil war who return home to face a new battle of survival. Twelve film competing in the new world cinema documentary category focused on country and people under siege. Finnish film The Three Rooms of Melancholia look at the war in Chechnya and Shake Hands With The Devil: The Journey of Romeo Dallaire tell the story of a UN mission to Rwanda during the 1994 genocide. But it wa Dutch documentary Shape of the Moon - a study of an extended family in Indonesia - which took the top prize. Meanwhile, French-Israeli production Wall, which look at Israel's controversial security wall separating it from the Palestinian territories, picked up a world cinema special jury prize for documentaries. In the main drama category, Forty Shades of Blue wa named winner of the grand jury prize. The film tell the tale of a forbidden tug-of-love between a father, his Russian immigrant girlfriend and his son. During it 24-year history, the Sundance Film Festival ha showcased success such a Reservoir Dogs, The Blair Witch Project and The Full Monty. Last year's festival provided a platform for hit such a Open Water, Napoleon Dynamite, Garden State and Super-Size Me. The festival is held in the mountain resort of Park City, east of Salt Lake City, which see it population rise from 7,500 to 45,000 during the festival.

Title: Isinbayeva heads for Birmingham
Article: Olympic pole vault champion Yelena Isinbayeva ha confirmed she will take part in the 2005 Norwich Union Grand Prix in Birmingham on 18 February. "Everybody know how much I enjoy competing in Britain. I always seem to break record there," said Isinbayeva. "As Olympic champion there will be more attention on me this year, but hopefully I can respond with another record in Birmingham." Kelly Holmes and Carolina Kluft are among other Athens winner competing. The organiser are hoping that Isinbayeva's main rival, fellow Russian Svetlana Feofanova, will also take part in the event. The pair had a thrilling battle in Athens which ended with Isinbayeva finally jumping a world record of 4.91m to claim the gold medal. Isinbayeva, 22, ha set 10 world record in the pole vault, three of which have come on British soil.

Title: Bridge could miss rest of season
Article: Chelsea left-back Wayne Bridge could miss the rest of the season with a suspected broken ankle. The England international, 24, wa hurt in an innocuous challenge with Alan Shearer during the Londoners' FA Cup defeat at Newcastle on Sunday. "We think it's a big injury," said Jose Mourinho, whose Chelsea team this week meet Barcelona in the Champions League and Liverpool in the Carling Cup final. William Gallas and Damien Duff could also miss the Barcelona game. France defender Gallas and Ireland winger Duff both picked up their injury in the closing stage of Chelsea's 1-0 defeat at St James' Park. With Bridge having gone off after Mourinho used all three substitutes, those knock plus Carlo Cudicini's red card meant Chelsea finished the game with seven able-bodied players. Cudicini would not have played against Barcelona, but had been promised a game in the Carling Cup final, although he will now miss the Cardiff showpiece through suspension. The manager is not planning to add any new name to his squad ahead of the trip to Barcelona, even though he ha few option to replace Bridge at left-back. Celestine Babayaro left the club in January, ironically to join Newcastle, and although Gallas ha deputised at left-back before, he is struggling to be fit himself. It could be that Paulo Ferreira, usually a right-back, is switched to left-back with Glen Johnson, who ended the Newcastle game in goal, playing on the right. Youngsters Ben Hudell, Joe Keenan and Sam Tillen would be option should Mourinho decide to call up a replacement, but it is unlikely he would risk an untried prospect in a Champions League tie. Bridge's injury also mean Mourinho, who reportedly want to sign Ashley Cole from Arsenal, will not have a specialist, senior left-back for the run-in to the season. "He (Bridge) ha no chance of playing against Barcelona, probably will not play against Liverpool (in the Carling Cup final) and maybe not for the rest of the season," he said. "The medical department will try to do everything to recover Gallas and Duff. We will have to wait and see, but I won't cry about injury because we will have 11 player to play on Tuesday." Shearer said he wa unsure what caused Bridge's injury. "I don't know what happened." he said. "It wa just a shame. I don't think we even touched each other. "By all account it's pretty serious. I went into the dressing-room after the game and wished him all the best." Mourinho, whose team are chasing three trophies, ha already lost winger Arjen Robben to a serious injury.

Title: Blair dismisses quit claim report
Article: Tony Blair ha dismissed report he told Gordon Brown he would quit before the next general election. "You don't do deal over job like this," the prime minister told BBC One's Breakfast with Frost programme. According to a new book, Brown's Britain, Mr Blair went back on a pledge to make way for Mr Brown after Cabinet ally intervened in June 2004. Mr Blair said the claim were "reheated from six month ago" and that he wa concentrating on running the country. Mr Blair said: "I've dealt with this six month ago. I said then you don't do deal over job like this - you don't. "What both of u are actually concentrating on are the issue that concern the country." The book, by Sunday Telegraph journalist Robert Peston and serialised in the newspaper, said the pair had "mutual animosity and contempt" for each other. It claim Tony Blair felt by November 2003 he had lost voters' trust because of the Iraq war and that he wa no longer an asset to the Labour Party. And that at a dinner hosted by Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott he told Mr Brown of his intention to stand down. According to Mr Peston the prime minister said: "Help me to get through the year and I will then stand down." But he then changed his mind in June 2004, following intervention from ally in the Cabinet and the suspicion that the chancellor wa deliberately manoeuvring against him, according to the book. Mr Peston told BBC News: "My understanding is that they are not nearly a close or a friendly a they once were. "What the book say is there is now a pretty profound mutual mistrust, mutual animosity. "I think in public you see this double-act pretending everything is alright, but in private I don't think the relationship is good because Brown, understandably, feel deeply betrayed - particularly over this issue of the leadership." But, in a wide-ranging BBC interview covering issue such a the Asian tsunami disaster, the Middle East peace process and Northern Ireland, Mr Blair said: "When you get to the top in politics you get this huge swell around you. "All sort of people make all sort of claim and counter-claims." He admitted to a "sense of frustration" about the allegation which he said had been made "countless times". There ha been fresh speculation of a rift recently, following their separate response to the Asian tsunami. These rumour were fuelled by Mr Blair's decision to hold his monthly medium conference at the same time a a long-planned speech by Mr Brown on UK plan to tackle global poverty with a new "Marshall Plan" for Africa. There wa speculation the pair were trying to outdo each other's response to the disaster. But the prime minister said he had discussed these claim with the chancellor and dismissed them a a "load of nonsense". Former welfare minister Frank Field MP said the prime minister should sack Mr Brown, but did not believe Mr Blair wa strong enough to do so. Title: Indy buys into India paper
Article: Irish publishing group Independent News & Media is buying up a 26% stake in Indian newspaper company Jagran in a deal worth 25m euro ($34.1m). Jagran publishes India's top-selling daily newspaper, the Hindi-language Dainik Jagran, which ha been in circulation for 62 years. News of the deal came a the group announced that it result would meet market forecasts. The company reported strong revenue growth across all it major markets. Group advertising revenue were up over 10% year-on-year, the group said, with overall circulation revenue are expected to increase almost 10% year-on-year. This wa helped by the positive impact of "compact" newspaper edition in Ireland and the UK, it said. "2004 ha proven to be an important year for Independent News & Media," said chief executive Sir Anthony O'Reilly. "Our simple aim at Independent is to be the low cost producer in every region in which we operate. I am confident that we will show a meaningful increase in earnings for 2005." Meanwhile, the group made no comment about the future of the Independent newspaper despite recent speculation that Sir Anthony had held talk with potential buyer over a stake in the daily publication. He ha consistently denied suggestion that the Independent and the Independent on Sunday are up for sale. Buy it is understood that the recent success of the smaller edition of the Independent, which ha pushed circulation up by 20% to 260,000, ha prompted interest from industry rivals, with Daily Mail & General Trust tipped a the most likely suitor. The loss-making newspaper is not expected to reach break-even until 2006.

Title: India widens access to telecoms
Article: India ha raised the limit for foreign direct investment in telecom company from 49% to 74%. Communications Minister Dayanidhi Maran said that there is a need to fund the fast-growing mobile market. The government hope to increase the number of mobile user from 95 million to between 200 and 250 million by 2007. "We need at least $20bn (Â£10.6bn) in investment and part of this ha to come a foreign direct investment," said Mr Maran. The decision to raise the limit for foreign investor faced considerable opposition from the communist parties, which give crucial support to the coalition headed by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh. Potential foreign investor will however need government approval before they increase their stake beyond 49%, Mr Maran said. Key positions, such a those of chief executive, chief technology officer and chief financial officer are to be held by Indians, he added. Analysts and investor have welcomed the government decision. "It is a positive development for carrier and the investment community, looking to take a longer-term view of the huge growth in the Indian telecom market," said Gartner's principal analyst Kobita Desai. "The FDI relaxation coupled with rapid local market growth could really ignite interest in the Indian telecommunication industry," added Ernst and Young's Sanjay Mehta. Investment bank Morgan Stanley ha forecast that India's mobile market is likely to grow by about 40% a year until 2007. The Indian mobile market is currently dominated by four companies, Bharti Televentures which ha allied itself with Singapore Telecom, Essar which is linked with Hong Kong-based Hutchison Whampoa, the Sterling group and the Tata group.

Title: Film production 'falls' 40% in UK
Article: The number of British film produced in the UK fell 40% in 2004, with movie starring Johnny Depp and Jude Law among those affected, Screen Daily ha said. Twenty-seven British film were made in the UK last year following a drop in funding, compared with 45 in 2003, according to the trade weekly. It attributed the drop to tighter tax law and reduced funding from source such a the National Lottery. UK and US co-productions in Britain fell from 102 in 2003 to 81 last year. Last year the government closed tax loophole that many film investor had taken advantage of to fund film in the UK. Several project were shelved a they faced the implication of this clampdown, coupled with the reduction in movie funding from traditional source including the lottery and Miramax Films. Shooting on period drama Tulip Fever, which wa to star Jude Law and Keira Knightley, wa postponed indefinitely while shooting of The Libertine starring Johnny Depp wa moved to the Isle of Man. "There isn't anything coming in to replace (the funds)," said The Libertine's executive producer Marc Samuelson. "We are in a hiatus." Films with "medium" budget of up to Â£9m, a similar level to box office hit Vera Drake, Calendar Girls and Enduring Love, are expected to be worst hit by the tax clampdown. The strength of the pound against the dollar is expected to have resulted in a fall in the number of US film shot in the UK during 2004, Screen International added. Big budget co-productions, such a the Harry Potter series, continued to be shot in the UK, however. The UK Film Council said the drop wa partly due to 2003 being an especially good year for British film production, when Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason, Wimbledon and Thunderbirds were all filmed in the UK. "The drop wa expected a there wa no way 2003's record level of production could be bettered," the council's spokesperson said. "The reduction in indigenous film production in 2004 wa due to a variety of factors, including the continuing long-term trend towards co-production of film in more than one country and change to financing arrangements." It wa "too early" to predict whether the downward trend in UK production would continue throughout 2005, the UK Film Council said. In September the government introduced subsidy worth up to Â£4m per film for medium budget films, under new Treasury measures. It is also due to announce a replacement for UK film tax relief scheme Section 48 in July.

Title: Mobile TV tipped as one to watch
Article: Scandinavians and Koreans, two of the most adventurous group of mobile users, are betting on mobile TV. Anders Igels, chief executive of Nordic operator Teliasonera, tipped it a the next big thing in mobile in a speech at the 3GSM World Congress, a mobile trade fair, in Cannes this week. Nokia, the Finnish handset maker, is planning a party in Singapore this spring to launch it TV to mobile activity in the region. Consultancy Strategy Analytics of Boston estimate that mobile broadcast network will have acquired around 51 million user worldwide by 2009, producing around $6.6bn (Â£3.5bn) in revenue. SK Telecom of South Korea, which is launching a TV to mobile service (via satellite) in May plan to charge a flat fee of $12 a month for it 12 channel of video and 12 channel of audio. It will be able to offer an additional two pay TV channel using conditional access technology. Mr Shin-Bae Kim, chief executive of SK Telecom, also at 3GSM, said: "We have plan to integrate TV with mobile internet services. "This will enable viewer to access the mobile internet to get more information on advert they see on TV." There will be 12 handset available for the launch of the Korean service. LG Electronics of South Korea wa demonstrating one at 3GSM that could display video at 30 frame a second. Footage shown on the handset wa clear and watchable. A speech on mobile TV by Angel Gambino of the BBC also drew a large crowd, suggesting that even those mobile operator and equipment vendor which are not particularly active in mobile TV yet are starting to look into it. But all is not simple and straightforward in the mobile TV arena. There is a battle for supremacy between two competing standards: DVB-H for Digital Video Broadcasting for Handsets and DMB for Digital Multimedia Broadcasting. Dr Chan Yeob Yeun, vice president and research fellow in charge of mobile TV at LG Electronics, said: "DMB offer twice the number of frame a minute a DVB-H and doe not drain mobile battery a quickly." The Japanese, Koreans and Ericsson of Sweden are backing DMB. Samsung of South Korea ha a DMB phone too that will be one of those offered to user of the TU Media satellite mobile TV service to be launched in Korea in May. Nokia, by contrast, is backing DVB-H, and is involved in mobile TV trial that use it art-deco style medium phone, which ha a larger than usual screen for TV or visual radio (a way of accompanying a radio programme with related text and pictures). Mobile operator O2 and Vodafone are among the operator trialling mobile TV. But even if the standard battle is resolved, there is the thorny issue of broadcasting rights. Ms Gambino say the BBC now negotiates mobile right when it is negotiating content. For those not convinced mobile user will want to watch TV on their handsets, Digital Audio Broadcasting may provide a good compromise and better sound quality than conventional radio. Developments in this area are continuing. At a DAB conference in Cannes, several maker of DAB chip for mobile announced smaller, lower- cost chip which consume less power. Among the chip company present were Frontier Silicon and Radioscape. The jury is still out on whether TV and digital radio on mobile will make much money for anyone. But with many new service going live soon, it won't be long before the industry find out.

Title: Microsoft sets sights on spyware
Article: Windows user could soon be paying Microsoft to keep PCs free of spyware. Following the takeover of anti-spyware firm Giant, Microsoft said it would soon release a toolkit that strip machine of the irritating programs. Although initially free, Microsoft ha not ruled out charging people who want to keep this toolkit up to date. Surveys show that almost every Windows PC is infested with spyware program that do everything from bombard user with advert to steal login data. Microsoft said that a beta version of the toolkit to clean up Windows machine should be available within 30 days. Designed for PCs running Windows 2000 and XP, the utility will clean out spyware programs, constantly monitor what happens on a PC and will be regularly updated to catch the latest variants. Before now many of Microsoft's other security boosting programs, such a the firewall in Windows XP, have been given away free. But Mike Nash, vice president in Microsoft's security business unit, said it wa still working out pricing and licensing issues. Charging for future version ha not been discounted, he said. "We'll come up with a plan and roll that out," he said. The plan could turn out to be a lucrative one for Microsoft. A recent survey by Earthlink and Webroot found that 90% of PCs are infested with the surreptitious software and that, on average, each one is harbouring 28 separate spyware programs. Currently user wanting protection from spyware have turned to free program such a Spybot and Ad-Aware. Spyware come in many form and at it most benign exploit lazy browsing habit to install itself and subject user to unwanted adverts. Other form hijack net browser setting to force people to view page they would otherwise never visit. At it most malign, spyware watch everything that people do with their PC and steal login information and other personal data. Microsoft's announcement about spyware come after it bought small New York software firm Giant Company Software. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed.
