Title: Tobacco giants hail court ruling
Article: US tobacco company have welcomed an appeal court's decision to reject the government's $280bn (Â£155bn) claim for alleged deceit about smoking dangers. Tobacco stock rose sharply on Wall Street after the 2-1 decision. The court in Washington found the case - filed by the Clinton administration in 1999 - could not be brought under federal anti-racketeering laws. Anti-smoking group urge the government to fight on, but the Justice Department ha not said if it will appeal. Among the accused were Altria Group, RJ Reynolds Tobacco, Lorillard Tobacco, Liggett Group and Brown and Williamson. They were delighted by the decision, which sent Reynolds share up 4.5% and Altria share up 5.11%. Charles A Blixt, executive vice-president of RJ Reynolds Tobacco, said the ruling "dramatically transforms" the government's lawsuit. Altria Group said, in a statement, the government now "must not only prove that the company have engaged in fraudulent behaviour in the past, but that they are likely to do so in the future." The government had claimed tobacco firm - manipulated nicotine level to increase addiction - targeted teenager with multi-billion dollar advertising campaign - lied about the danger of smoking and ignored research to the contrary. Prosecutors wanted the cigarette firm to "disgorge" $280bn in profit accumulated over the past 50 year and impose tougher rule on marketing their products. They brought the case under racketeering laws, which were passed to deny mafia gang the profit of their crimes. But the tobacco company denied that they illegally conspired to promote smoking and defraud the public. They also said they had already met many of the government's demand in a landmark $206bn settlement reached with 46 state in 1998. The three-judge panel in the District of Columbia's Court of Appeals ruled on Friday that the US government could not sue the firm under the anti-racketeering laws. Judge David Sentelle, in his ruling, said such law were aimed at putting an end to illegal conduct going forward. "We hold that the language of (the law) and the comprehensive remedial scheme of (the law) preclude disgorgement a a possible remedy in this case," he wrote. The Justice Department refused to say if it would appeal. "All we're saying today is that we have received the ruling and are reviewing it," a spokeswoman said on Friday. But William Corr of the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids urged the government to continue pressing it case. "Today's ruling should not be an excuse for this administration to seek a weak settlement that let the tobacco industry off the hook," he said.

Title: Lib Dems highlight problem debt
Article: People vulnerable to problem debt should be afforded greater protection from bank aggressively promoting financial products, the Lib Dems say. Vincent Cable say one in eight household already struggle with debt and that will worsen if there is a hike in interest rate or unemployment. The Lib Dems' Treasury spokesman is unveiling a policy aimed at the issue. He want to see "proper health checks" when loan are marketed so people know to take out payment protection. "Were economic condition to deteriorate at all, large number of people could be affected because they have borrowed to the limit," Mr Cable told BBC News. "Banks are very aggressively promoting debt in many case there is a bigger problem ahead." Mr Cable said the government's Consumer Credit Bill would target some of the "extreme problems" such a loan sharking, but minister had been "a bit complacent" about the wider issue of debt levels. He said much of the payment protection currently available wa "extremely expensive" and there were "lots of exclusions". Mr Cable added that the Office of Fair Trading should investigate the market. Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy meanwhile is in the middle of a tour of the UK aimed at persuading voter his is the "real opposition". Mr Kennedy is visiting a mixture of rural seats, where his party is hoping to make gain from the Conservatives, and urban area traditionally associated with Labour. Labour say a Lib Dem vote could "let the Tories in", while the Tories say the Lib Dems would mean "higher taxes, soft crime laws, more power to Europe". Mr Kennedy's tour come a he, Labour leader Tony Blair and Conservative leader Michael Howard all step up campaigning ahead of the next General Election, widely expected to be held on 5 May. The Liberal Democrats say in the northern cities, the race is between them and Labour, while in southern seat - particularly the south west - it is between them and the Tories. Speaking to the BBC's Westminster Hour on Sunday, Mr Kennedy said the upcoming general election - widely tipped for 5 May - would be much more unpredictable than any others in "recent experience". And he brushed off Labour suggestion a vote for his party would mean letting the Tories in "by the back door". "If you look at the four previous parliamentary by-elections, the Liberal Democrats have demonstrated that, not only can we leapfrog the Conservatives where we start in a third place position, but we can go on to defeat the government. "That's going to be the story, I think, of this coming general election."

Title: India seeks to boost construction
Article: India ha cleared a proposal allowing up to 100% foreign direct investment in it construction sector. Kamal Nath, Commerce and Industry Minister, announced the decision in Delhi on Thursday following a cabinet meeting. Analysts say improving India's infrastructure will boost foreign investment in other sector too. The Indian government's decision ha spread good cheer in the construction sector, according to some Indian firms. A spokesman for DLF Builders, Dr Vancheshwar, told the BBC this will mean "better offerings" for consumer a well a builders. He said the firm will benefit from world class "strategic partnerships, design expertise and technology, while consumer will have better choice." "Foreign investor can enter any construction development area, be it to build resorts, township or commercial premise but they will have to construct at least 50,000 square meter (538,000 square feet) within a specific timeframe," said Mr Nath, without specifying the timeframe. Title: Rings of steel combat net attacks
Article: Gambling is hugely popular, especially with tech-savvy criminals. Many extortionist are targeting net-based betting firm and threatening to cripple their website with deluge of data unless a ransom is paid. But now deep defence are being put in place by some of the UK's biggest net firm to stop these attacks. Increasing number of attack and the huge amount of data being used to try to bump a site off the web are prompting firm to adopt the measures. "Net firm are realising that it's not just about anti-virus and firewalls," said Paul King, chief security architect at Cisco. "There are more thing that can be done in the network to protect data centres." Mr King said the only way to properly combat these so-called Distributed Denial-of-Service attack wa with intelligent net-based systems. Many of the gambling site suffering DDoS attack are in offshore data and hosting centres, so any large scale data flood could knock out access to many more site than just the one the criminal were targeting, said Mr King. This overspill effect wa only likely to grow a attack grow in size and scale. Malcolm Seagrave, security expert at Energis, said the most common type of attack hit site with 10 megabyte of data over short period of time. Bigger attack sending down 200 megabyte of traffic or more were rarely seen, he said. "It doe feel like they are turning the dial because you see this traffic gradually growing," he said. So far there have been no attack involving gigabyte of data, said Mr Seagrave. However, he added that it wa only a matter of time before such large attack were mounted. Maria Capella, spokeswoman for net provider Pipex, said that when DDoS attack were at their height, customer were getting hit every four to five days. The defence being put in place constantly monitor the stream of data flowing across network and pluck out the traffic destined for target sites. "It's about understanding what's genuine traffic and keeping attack traffic from going to the site," she said. "We study the profile of their traffic and a soon a we see an anomaly in the profile that's when we start to get the backbone engineering boy to see if we are going to sustain an attack," said Ms Capella. This traffic can be hard to spot because DDoS attack typically use thousand of computer in many different countries, each participating machine only sends a small part of the entire data flood. Typically these computer have been infected by a virus or worm which report it success and the net address of compromised machine back to the malicious hacker or hi-tech criminal that set off the virus. Hijacked computer are known a zombie or 'bots and collection of them are called 'bot nets. Many spammer rent out 'bot net to help them anonymously send junk mail. Most of the zombie are based outside the country that host the target site so getting the attacking PCs shut off can be difficult. Often Pipex and other net supplier do get advance notice that an attack is about to happen. "The serious player tend to precede an attack with some kind of ransom e-mail," said Ms Capella. "We ask, a part of the service we provide, that customer notify u of anything they have in advance that would give u forewarning." Once an attack is spotted dedicated net hardware take over to remove the attack traffic and ensure that site stay up. Energis took a similar approach, said Mr Seagrave. "We have technology out there that allows u to detect attack in minute rather than let network engineer spend hour pulling the information together," said Mr Seagrave. Also net firm were starting to work more closely together on the problem of DDoS attack and pool information about where they are coming from. Information gathered on attack and where they originated ha led to some arrests. He said Energis also did it own intelligence work to get in insight into which site criminal gang plan to target. "We have people in place where they shouldn't be, monitoring tech sites," he said. Sometimes though, he said, spotting the next victim wa easy. "You can see them going alphabetically through the list with the gambling sites, trying one after another," said Mr Seagrave.

Title: De Niro completes box office coup
Article: Robert De Niro ha completed a transatlantic box office double by topping the UK and US film chart with two different film at the same time. Comedy sequel Meet the Fockers, in which he star with Ben Stiller, Dustin Hoffman and Barbra Streisand, shot to the top of the UK chart at the weekend. It took Â£7.2m in three day - eight time more than the number two, Closer. Assault on Precinct 13 wa in third. At the same time, US audience were won over by his new thriller Hide and Seek. In Meet the Fockers, he pick up the role of an uptight father and ex-CIA agent from 2000 hit comedy, Meet the Parents. It is a big leap to his role in Hide and Seek, a supernatural horror in which he play a widower whose daughter's imaginary friend turn nasty. In the UK box office chart, Meet the Fockers pushed Closer off the top spot while police action movie Assault On Precinct 13, starring rapper Ja Rule, made Â£750,000 in it first weekend. London Underground thriller Creep wa another new entry at six while quirky comedy Sideways, which got five Oscar nomination last week, entered in eighth place. The Oscar nomination do not seem to have had an impact on fans' choice at cinemas. Leading contender The Aviator, Million Dollar Baby and Ray all suffered substantial drop in taking compared with the previous weekend.

Title: Mobile games come of age
Article: The BBC News website take a look at how game on mobile phone are maturing. A brief round-up follows but you can skip straight to the review by clicking on the link below. If you think of Snake when some mention "mobile games" then you could be in for a bit of a surprise. This is because mobile game have come a long way in a very short time. Even before Nokia's N-Gage game phone launched in late 2003, many mobile operator were realising that there wa an audience looking for something to play on their handset. And given that many more people own handset than own portable game playing gadget such a the GameBoy it could be a very lucrative market. That audience includes commuter wanting something to fill their time on the way home, game fan looking for a bit of variety and hard core gamers who like to play every moment they can. Life for all these type of player ha got immeasurably better in the last year a the number of title you can download to your phone ha snowballed. Now site such a Wireless Gaming Review list more than 200 different title for some UK network and the range suit every possible taste. There are port of PC and arcade classic such a Space Invaders, Lunar Lander and Bejewelled. There are also version of titles, such a Colin McRae Rally, that you typically find on PCs and consoles. There are shoot-em-ups, adventure games, strategy title and many novel game only found on handsets. Rarely now doe an action movie launch without a mobile game tie-in. Increasingly such launch are all part of the promotional campaign for a film, understandable when you realise that a good game can rack up million of downloads. The return can be pretty good when you consider that some game cost Â£5. What ha also helped game on mobile thrive is the fact that it is easier than ever to get hold of them thanks to technology known a Wap push. By sending a text message to a game maker you can have the title downloaded to your handset. Far better than having to navigate through the menu of most mobile operator portals. The number of handset that can play game ha grown hugely too. Almost half of all phone now have Java onboard meaning that they can play the increasingly sophisticated game that are available - even the one that use 3D graphics. The minimum technology specification that phone should adhere to are getting more sophisticated which mean that game are too. Now double key press are possible making familiar tactic such a moving and strafing a real option. The processing power on handset mean that physic on mobile game is getting more convincing and the graphic are improving too. Some game maker are also starting to take advantage of the extra capability in a mobile. Many titles, particularly racing games, let you upload your best time to see how you compare to others. Usually you can get hold of their best time and race against a "ghost" or "shadow" to see if you can beat them. A few game also let you take on people in real time via the network or, if you are sitting close to them, via Bluetooth short-range radio technology. With so much going on it is hard to do justice to the sheer diversity of what is happening. But these two feature should help point you in the direction of the game maker and give you an idea of where to look and how to get playing. TOO FAST TOO FURIOUS (DIGITAL BRIDGES) As soon a I start playing this I remember why I never play driving game - because I'm rubbish at them. No matter if I drive the car via joystick or keypad I just cannot get the hang of braking for corner or timing a rush to pas other drivers. The game reward replay because to advance you have to complete every section within a time limit. Winning give you cash for upgrades. Graphically the rolling road is a convincing enough evocation of speed a the palm tree and cactus whip by and the city scroll past in the background. The car handle pretty well despite my uselessness but it wa not clear if the different model of car were appreciably different on the track. The only niggle wa that the interface wa a bit confusing especially when using a joystick rather than the keypad to play. FATAL FORCE (MACROSPACE) A futuristic shooter that let you either play various deathmatch mode against your phone or run through a series of scenario that involves killing alien invading Earth. Graphics are a bit cartoon-like but only help to make clear what is going on and level are well laid out and encourage you to leap about exploring. Both background music and sound effect work well. The scenario are well scripted and you regularly get hint from the Fatal Force commanders. Weapons include flamethrowers, rocket launchers, grenade and at a couple of point you even get chance to use a mech for a short while. With the right power-up you can go into a Matrix-style bullet time to cope with the onslaught of aliens. The game let you play via Bluetooth if others are in range. Online the game ha quite a following with clans, player ranking and even new downloadable maps.

Title: Ford gains from finance not cars
Article: Ford, the US car company, reported higher fourth quarter and full-year profit on Thursday boosted by a buoyant period for it car loan unit. Net income for 2004 wa $3.5bn (Â£1.87bn) - up nearly $3bn from 2003 - while turnover rose $7.2bn to $170.8bn. In the fourth quarter alone Ford reported net income of $104m, compared with a loss of $793m a year ago. But it auto unit made a loss. Fourth quarter turnover wa $44.7bn, compared to $45.9bn a year ago. Though car and truck loan profit saved the day, Ford's auto unit made a pre-tax loss of $470m in the fourth quarter (compared to a profit of Â£13m in the year-ago period) and it US sale dipped 3.8%. Yesterday General Motor's result also showed it finance unit wa a strong contributor to profits. However, Ford is working hard to revitalise it product portfolio, unveiling the Fusion and Zephyr model at the International Motor Show in Detroit. It also brought out a number of new model in the second half of 2004. "In 2004, our company gained momentum, delivering...more new products, and more innovative breakthroughs, such a the Escape Hybrid, the industry's first full-hybrid sport utility vehicle," said chairman and chief executive officer Bill Ford." "We also confronted operating challenge with our Jaguar brand and high industry marketing costs," he added. But Ford declined to provide guidance for first quarter 2005. It will do so at a presentation in New York on 26 January. In addition, the company said 2004 net income wa affected by a fourth-quarter pre-tax charge taken to reduce the value of a receivable owed to Ford by Visteon, a former subsidiary. Recent new model introduced by Ford include the Ford Five Hundred and Mercury Montego sedans, the Ford Freestyle crossover, the Ford Mustang, the Land Rover LR3/Discovery, and Volvo S40 and V50 in North America and Europe. Total company vehicle unit sale in 2004 were 6,798,000, an increase of 62,000 unit from 2003. Fourth-quarter vehicle unit sale totalled 1,751,000, a decline of 133,000 units. For the full year, Ford's worldwide automotive division earned a pre-tax profit of $850m, a $697m improvement from $153m a year ago.

Title: Takeover offer for Sunderland FC
Article: Bob Murray, chairman of Sunderland FC, ha launched a Â£1.5m ($2.8m) bid for the club after buying broadcaster BSkyB's stake in the business. Mr Murray is already Sunderland's leading shareholder, holding a 37.6% stake, and now hope to take full control of the Championship side. Mr Murray said the club would find it easier to attract more investment by having a single majority owner. Sunderland delisted it share from the stock market in August. A lifetime Sunderland supporter and board director since 1984, Mr Murray agreed to buy BSkyB's 4.76% holding in the Wearside club on Tuesday - taking his stake to 42.3%. Under stock market rules, Mr Murray is required to make an offer for the remaining share that he doe not already own at the same price paid for the BSkyB holding of 31p a share. Should the offer be fully accepted, Mr Murray said he expected to pay a maximum of Â£1.53m for the remaining shares. He also stressed that fan who wanted to keep in touch with the club's financial affair could retain a small number of shares, enabling them to attend annual meetings. "The football sector is experiencing significant change and uncertainty," Mr Murray said in a statement. "The recent speculation surrounding Malcolm Glazer and Manchester United ha shown the unsettling effect possible where there are a number of disparate interests," he added. "I believe that this offer will strengthen the company and remove the potential for that type of uncertainty." Sunderland were relegated from the Premiership in 2003 but are currently pushing for promotion. The club managed to reduce it loss last year from Â£20.6m to Â£1.2m after selling a host of leading players. However, the club's turnover dropped sharply from Â£42.5m to Â£28.5m over the same period, because of a fall in broadcast revenues. BSkyB bought it stake in Sunderland in 1999 a part of a five year medium partnership deal. The deal expired last month.

Title: Protect whistleblowers, TUC says
Article: The government should change the law to give more protection to employee who raise health and safety concern about their workplaces, the TUC ha said. It said data from employment tribunal suggested 1,500 "safety whistleblowers" had lost their job since 1999. Some firm found it cheaper to sack a worker than to improve building or change working conditions, it said. The Health and Safety Executive said it wa trying to get worker more involved in helping to make workplace safer. The TUC figure were drawn from unfair dismissal case at tribunal were health and safety were the main issue. Safety representative were often ignored when raising concern because there wa no legal duty to respond, claimed the union organisation. General secretary Brendan Barber said: "It shouldn't be a firing offence to object to unsafe work. "Workers should not be placed in the situation where they are forced to choose between risking their job or risking their personal health and safety." Mr Barber, who said the "problem is far worse than official statistic show", called for a legal system that "protects safety whistleblowers". He added that worker who are not in a union, a well a casual and migrant workers, "stand little chance of redress." Rory O' Neill, editor of union-backed Hazards magazine, which conducted the research, said: "Giving union safety rep more right in more workplace is the ultimate win-win. "Death and injury at work increased last year, for the second time since the turn of the century. "It would be a fatal mistake not to take full advantage of the union safety effect." The TUC ha called on the government to appoint "roving" safety rep and to increase spending on health and safety work inspections. The Health and Safety Executive had said that it had launched an initiative to make factory and office safer, with more worker involvement.

Title: Gerrard plays down European hopes
Article: Steven Gerrard ha admitted that Liverpool have little chance of winning the Champions League this season. The 24-year-old Reds skipper spoke out ahead of Tuesday's first leg at home to Bayer Leverkusen in the last 16, which he will miss through suspension. "Let's be realistic, there are some fantastic team left in the Champions League," he told BBC Radio Five Live. "We are just going to try to stay in a long a possible but we realise that maybe it is not our year this year." Gerrard ha made no secret of his desire to be involved in Europe's premier club competition. Last season he described qualification for the Champions League a the "be all and end all" - and rumour persist that he will leave Anfield if the Reds fail to secure a place in the competition. He ha consistently been linked with a move away from Liverpool, with Chelsea the favourite to snap up the England midfielder. And Blues bos Jose Mourinho backed Gerrard's view that Rafael Benitez's team could struggle to progress this season. "Rafa ha still time in front of him to build an even better team, maybe he's a little bit behind (right now)," he told BBC Radio Five Live. Gerrard, who fired Liverpool into the last 16 of this season's competition with a brilliant goal in December's win over Olympiakos, insisted he wa still fully focused on helping Liverpool to glory this season. The Reds are currently fifth in the Premiership table, five point off the crucial fourth spot, which brings Champions League qualification - and they face Chelsea in Sunday's Carling Cup final. "It's big couple of month for Liverpool," he added. "We're fighting for the fourth spot for the Champions League for next season but we are still involved in two cup competitions, which are very important. "We are confident we can upset Chelsea in the Carling Cup final and get to the last eight of the Champions League because, financially, it is big for the club and, personally for myself, it is very good."

Title: Musical treatment for Capra film
Article: The classic film It's A Wonderful Life is to be turned into a musical by the producer of the controversial hit show Jerry Springer - The Opera. Frank Capra's 1946 movie starring James Stewart, is being turned into a Â£7m musical by producer Jon Thoday. He is working with Steve Brown, who wrote the award-winning musical Spend Spend Spend. A spokeswoman said the plan were in the "very early stages", with no cast, opening date or theatre announced. A series of workshop have been held in London, and on Wednesday a cast of singer unveiled the musical to a select group of potential investors. Mr Thoday said the idea of turning the film into a musical had been an ambition of his for almost 20 years. It's a Wonderful Life wa based on a short story, The Greatest Gift, by Philip van Doren Stern. Mr Thoday managed to buy the right to the story from Van Doren Stern's family in 1999, following Mr Brown's success with Spend Spend Spend. He later secured the film right from Paramount, enabling them to use the title It's A Wonderful Life.

Title: India's Deccan gets more planes
Article: Air Deccan ha signed a deal to acquire 36 plane from Avions de Transport Regional (ATR). The value of the deal ha not been revealed, because of a confidentiality clause in the agreement. But Air Deccan's managing director Gorur Gopinath ha said the price agreed wa less than the catalogue price of $17.6m (Â£9.49m) per plane. Recently, India's first low-cost airline ordered 30 Airbus A320 plane for $1.8bn. Under the agreement, Air Deccan will buy 15 new ATR 72-500 and lease another 15. ATR will also provide six second hand airplanes. In a statement, ATR ha said delivery of the aircraft will begin in 2005 and will continue over a five-year period. Mr Gopinath said the plane will connect regional Indian cities. "After an evaluation of both ATR and Bombardier aircraft, we have chosen the ATR aircraft a we find it most suitable for our operation and for the Indian market for short haul routes." Filippo Bagnato, ATR's chief executive, ha said that his firm will also work with Air Deccan to create a training centre in Bangalore. The potential of the Indian budget market ha attracted attention from business at home and abroad. Air Deccan ha said it will base it business model on European firm such a Ireland's Ryanair. Beer magnate Vijay Mallya recently set up Kingfisher Airlines, while UK entrepreneur Richard Branson ha said he is keen to start a local operation. India's government ha given it backing to cheaper and more accessible air travel.

Title: Bad e-mail habits sustains spam
Article: The 'bad behaviour' of e-mail user is helping to sustain the spam industry, a new study ha found. According to a survey conducted by security firm Mirapoint and market research company the Radicati Group, nearly a third of e-mail user have clicked on link in spam messages. One in ten user have bought product advertised in junk mail. Clicking on a link in a spam message can expose people to virus and alert spammer to live e-mail accounts. The fact that one in ten e-mail user are buying thing advertised in spam continues to make it an attractive business, especially given that sending out huge amount of spam cost very little, the report concludes. "This preliminary data is surprising and somewhat shocking to us," said Marcel Nienhuis, market analyst at the Radicati Group. "It explains why e-mail security threat including spam, virus and phishing scam continue to proliferate," he said, accusing user of "bad e-mail behaviour". Spammers are increasingly hooking into whatever happens to be flavour of the month, according to security firm Clearswift. It ha recently seen a rise in the number of spam message offering phoney Sony PSP giveaways. And, in perhaps a nod to the popularity of the American drama series Desperate Housewives, it ha also seen a dramatic rise in junk mail purporting to give detail of woman looking for casual sex. But rather than finding a companion, user who click on such mail will find themselves redirected to porn sites, where they run the risk of downloading spyware on to their PC. Clearswift ha seen a 180% rise in sex-related spam over the course of the last month. "Without casting aspersions, those likely to respond to these kind of advert will be invariably hoping that 'one thing lead to another' but aside from the fact that these mail are bogus, clicking on any link within a spam mail can lead to a whole host of unwanted problems," said Alyn Hockey, Clearswift's director of research. Sexually explicit term make up 14% of security firm Sophos' top 50 word that spammer most commonly try to disguise in order to beat anti-spam filters. Spammers will deliberately misspell a word or use digit instead of letter in an attempt to by-pass anti-spam software, said Graham Cluley, senior technology consultant for security firm Sophos. "The list of word most commonly hidden by the spammer from anti-spam software reveals that most spam is about the old favourites: money, drug and sex," said Mr Cluley. But anti-spam filter can only be part of the solution to the menace of junk e-mail. "People must resist their basic instinct to buy from spam mails. Spammers are criminals, plain and simple. If no-one responded to junk e-mail and didn't buy product sold in this way, then spam would be a extinct a the dinosaurs," he said.

Title: Microsoft plans 'safer ID' system
Article: Microsoft is planning to make Windows and Internet Explorer more secure by including software to give people more control over personal information. "Info cards" will help people manage personal detail on their PCs to make online service safer, said Microsoft. Microsoft's two previous programs, Passport and Hailstorm, aimed to protect user but were criticised. ID fraud is one of the UK's fastest-growing crimes, with criminal netting an estimated Â£1.3bn last year. A quarter of UK adult ha either had their ID stolen, via hi-tech or other means, or know someone who has, a recent report by Which? magazine found. Microsoft is developing a new version of Internet Explorer browser and it operating system, Windows, which ha been code-named Longhorn. Michael Stephenson, director in Microsoft's Windows Server division, would not confirm however whether the new info card ID system will be built into the current Windows XP version or Longhorn. "We're trying to make the end-user experience a simple a possible," Mr Stephenson said. The system would differ from it previous attempt to make online transaction more secure, said Microsoft. While Passport and Hailstorm stored user information centrally on the net, the latest system will store data on a user's PC. "It's going to put control of digital IDs into the hand of an end-user, the end-user will be in full control," said Mr Stephenson. Hailstorm wa criticised by privacy campaigner for putting too much sensitive information into the hand of a single company. Passport provides a single log-in for more than one website and store basic personal information. But it popularity suffered after security scares. Up to 200 million Passport account were left vulnerable to online theft and malicious hacker after a flaw in the system wa exploited in 2003. Online auction site, eBay, stopped supporting it in January 2005. Although the flaw wa fixed, Microsoft ha come under regular criticism for the number of security loophole in Internet Explorer. Last year, it released a major security update for Windows, Service Pack 2, to combat some of the security concerns. Longhorn is due to be released commercially in late 2006, but an updated version of Internet Explorer is due for release later this year.

Title: Dawson set for new Wasps contract
Article: European champion Wasps are set to offer Matt Dawson a new deal. The 31-year-old World Cup winning scrum-half ha impressed since joining the London side from Northampton this summer on a one-year contract. Wasps coach Warren Gatland told the Daily Mirror: "We have not yet offered Matt a new contract but we will be doing so. "I'm very happy with his contribution and I think he's good enough to play for another couple of years." Dawson played a vital part in England's World Cup win last year but ha fallen out of favour with new coach Andy Robinson after missing a training session in September. However he hope the new deal will help him regain his England place. "Rugby is still my priority and there's still a burning desire within me to play the best rugby I possibly can," he said. "I know within myself, if I wa given the chance I could play for England again. "I know I'm fit enough, I'm strong enough, I'm skilful enough."

Title: Pavey focuses on indoor success
Article: Jo Pavey will miss January's View From Great Edinburgh International Cross Country to focus on preparing for the European Indoor Championships in March. The 31-year-old wa third behind Hayley Yelling and Justyna Bak in last week's European Cross Country Championships but she prefers to race on the track. "It wa great winning bronze but I'm wary of injury and must concentrate on the indoor season," she said. "Because of previous injury I don't even run up hill in training." Pavey, who came fifth in the 5,000m at the Athens Olympics, helped the British cross country team win the team silver medal in Heringsdorf last week. She is likely to start her 3,000m season with a race in either Boston or Stuttgart at the end of January.

Title: Lopez misses UK charity premiere
Article: Jennifer Lopez cancelled an appearance at the UK charity premiere of her new movie saying she wa too ill to fly. The actress and singer dropped out at the last minute and ha now cancelled all European promotion of the film Shall We Dance? and her new album. She said: "I very much wanted to be in London but unfortunately I'm not well. At the advice of my doctor I'm unable to travel." Co-star Richard Gere attended the event held in aid of the tsunami appeal. Thousands braved the cold weather to see the star in London's Leicester Square. The red carpet boasted waltzing dancer in honour of the film's ballroom dancing theme. The film's director Peter Chelsom said he wa disappointed that Lopez did not attend. "It's a shame. I know it's true that she's not well because she ha also cancelled her promotional tour. I've heard she ha swollen glands." Gere, 55, greeted the crowd and signed autographs, accompanied by his wife Carey Lowell. Other star who turned out on the night included Honor Blackman, Strictly Come Dancing presenter Tess Daly and actress Anita Dobson. Lopez issue a statement apologising for her absence. "I'm so proud of Shall We Dance and wa looking forward to visiting London," she said. "This film wa a labour of love for me, and I want to thank everyone involved in bringing it to you, from the cast, to the film director, to the crew." Lopez appeared at the Grammy award on Sunday, singing a duet with her third husband Marc Anthony.

Title: Rescue hope for Borussia Dortmund
Article: Shares in struggling German football club Borussia Dortmund slipped on Monday despite the club agreeing a rescue plan with creditor on Friday. The club, which ha posted record loss and racked up debts, said last week that it wa in "a life-threatening profitability and financial situation". Creditors agreed on Friday to suspend interest payment until 2007. News of the deal had boosted share in the club on Friday, but the stock slipped back 7% during Monday morning. In addition to the interest-payment freeze, Borussia Dortmund also will get short-term loan to help pay salaries. It estimated that it need almost 30m euro ($39m; Â£21m) until the end of June if it is to pay it bills. The football club is hoping that all it creditor will agree to defer rent payment on it Westfalen stadium. Borussia official met with almost all the bank involved in it financing on Friday and over the weekend. Three creditor have yet to agree to the deal struck last week. On 14 March, one of these creditor - property investment fund Molsiris which owns the club's stadium - hold it AGM at which it will discus the rescue plan. Chief executive Gerd Niebaum stepped down last week and creditor have been pushing for a greater say in how the club is run. Borussia Dortmund also is facing call to appoint executive from outside the club. The club posted a record loss of 68m euro in the 12 month through June. Adding to it woes, Borussia Dortmund wa beaten 5-0 by Bayern Munich on Saturday.

Title: DVD review: I, Robot
Article: Only one man recognises that robot are a threat to humanity - but that's fine because it only take one man to save the day in the thriller I, Robot. Will Smith co-star alongside more CGI robot than you can count and a a thrill-a-minute kind of action film, it's perfectly adequate. You'll have forgotten it all tomorrow but you'll have a fun night with the film and all the extras. There is a one-disc version that ha commentary and a Making Of but the two-disc add more. Unusually for this kind of film, the extra don't solely concentrate on the special effects. They're covered but there's also a general Production Diary and a Post-Production feature. Remember the National Lottery's draw machine Arthur and Guinevere? They were more accurate than this glossy Hollywood version of the tale. But a long a you're not expecting a documentary, live with it: King Arthur is a fun, exciting, totally shallow experience and look excellent. Clive Owen is the brooding king, Keira Knightly rise above her costume and Ray Winstone give it all some grit. It's at it best in it battle scene which are well done and are also the best part of the Making Of extra. Less flashy than a David Attenborough show and less detailed than a Simon Schama one, the BBC series British Isles nevertheless turned out to be quite engrossing. Admit it, the fact that this is one of the show Alan Titchmarsh left Ground Force to present did mean that you expected something equally frothy. But Titchmarsh turn out to know his subject and the sight of our present-day landscape being peeled back to reveal the past wa fascinating. He's now written an accompanying book, too.

Title: Mobile networks seek turbo boost
Article: Third-generation mobile (3G) network need to get faster if they are to deliver fast internet surfing on the move and exciting new services. That wa one of the message from the mobile industry at the 3GSM World Congress in Cannes last week. Fast 3G network are here but the focus ha shifted to their evolution into a higher bandwidth service, say the Global Mobile Suppliers Association. At 3GSM, Siemens showed off a system that transmits faster mobile data. The German company said data could be transmitted at one gigabit a second - up to 20 time faster than current 3G networks. The system is not available commercially yet, but Motorola, the US mobile handset and infrastructure maker, held a clinic for mobile operator on HSDPA (High Speed Downlink Packet Access), a high-speed, high bandwidth technology available now. Early HSDPA system typically offer around two megabit per second (Mbps) compared with less than 384 kilobit per second (Kbps) on standard 3G networks. "High-Speed Downlink Packet Access (HSDPA) - sometimes called Super 3G - will be vital for profitable service like mobile internet browsing and mobile video clips," according to a report published by UK-based research consultancy Analysys. A number of company are developing the technology. Nokia and Canada-based wireless communication product company Sierra Wireless recently agreed to work together on High Speed Downlink Packet Access. The two company aim to jointly market the HSDPA solution to global network operator customers. "While HSDPA theoretically enables data rate up to a maximum of 14Mbps, practical throughput will be lower than this in wide-area networks," said Dr Alastair Brydon, author of the Analysys report: Pushing Beyond the Limits of 3G with HSDPA and Other Enhancements. "The typical average user rate in a real implementation is likely to be in the region of one megabit per second which, even at this lower rate, will more than double the capacity... when compared to basic WCDMA [3G]," he added. Motorola ha conducted five trial of it technology and say speed of 2.9Mbps have been recorded at the edge of an outdoor 3G cell using a single HSDPA device. But some mobile operator are opting for a technology called Evolution, Data Optimised (EV-DO). US operator Sprint ordered a broadband data upgrade to it 3G network at the end of last year. We are "expanding our network and deploying EV-DO technology to meet customer demand for faster wireless speeds," said Oliver Valente, Sprint's vice president for technology development, when the contract wa announced. As part of $3bn in multi-year contract announced late last year, Sprint will spend around $1bn on EV-DO technology from Lucent Technologies, Nortel Networks and Motorola that provides average data speed of 0.3-0.5 megabit a second, and peak download rate of 2.4Mbps. MMO2, the UK-based operator with service in the UK, Ireland and Germany, ha opted for technology based on the High Speed Downlink Packet Access (HSDPA) standard. Using technology from Lucent, it will offer data speed of 3.6Mbps from next summer on it Isle of Man 3G network, and will eventually support speed of up to 14.4Mbps. US operator Cingular Wireless is also adopting HSDPA, using technology from Lucent alongside equipment from Siemens and Ericsson. Siemens' plan for a one gigabit network may be more than a user need today, but Christoph Caselitz, president of the mobile network division at the firm say that: "By the time the next generation of mobile communication debut in 2015, the need for transmission capacity for voice, data, image and multimedia is conservatively anticipated to rise by a factor of 10." Siemens - in collaboration with the Fraunhofer German-Sino Lab for Mobile Communications and the Institute for Applied Radio System Technology - ha souped up mobile communication by using three transmitting and four receiving antennae, instead of the usual one. This enables a data transmission, such a sending a big file or video, to be broken up into different flow of data that can be sent simultaneously over one radio frequency band. The speed offered by3G mobile seemed fast at the time mobile operator were paying huge sum for 3G licences. But today, instead of connecting to the internet by slow, dial-up phone connection, many people are used to broadband network that offer speed of 0.5 megabit a second - must faster than 3G. This mean user are likely to find 3G disappointing unless the network are souped up. If they aren't, those lucrative "power users", such a computer geek and busy business people will avoid them for all but the most urgent tasks, reducing the potential revenue available to mobile operators. But one gigabit a second system will not be available immediately. Siemens say that though the system work in the laboratory, it still ha to assess the mobility of multiple-antennae device and conduct field trials. A commercial system could be a far away a 2012, though Siemens did not rule out an earlier date.

Title: Top gig award for Scissor Sisters
Article: New York band Scissor Sisters have won a gig of the year award for their performance at this year's V Festival. The award wa voted for by listener of Virgin Radio, which compiled a top 10 which wa mostly dominated by newcomer on the music scene this year. The quirky disco-rock band beat The Red Hot Chili Peppers who came second for their Hyde Park performance in June. Virgin Radio DJ Pete Mitchell said: "This year ha seen an amazing array of talent come into the mainstream." He added: "The Scissor Sisters are one of the most original, eccentric band to come through and it's no surprise the British public are lapping up their performances." Newcomers Keane came in third place for their August gig at the V Festival, followed by Maroon 5 and Snow Patrol. Music veteran The Who and David Bowie, both earned place on the list, at number eight and 10 respectively. At number seven wa Oxfam's Make Fair Trade gig at London's Hammersmith Apollo in October, which featured performance by REM, Razorlight and Coldplay's Chris Martin. Glasgow's Franz Ferdinand earned a place at number nine for their home-town performance in April. The annual survey wa voted for by nearly 4,000 listeners.

Title: Israel looks to US for bank chief
Article: Israel ha asked a US banker and former International Monetary Fund director to run it central bank. Stanley Fischer, vice chairman of banking giant Citigroup, ha agreed to take the Bank of Israel job subject to approval from parliament and cabinet. His nomination by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon came a a surprise, and led to gain on the Tel Aviv stock market. Mr Fischer, who speaks fluent Hebrew, will have to become an Israeli citizen to take the job. The US say he will not have to give up US citizenship to do so. Previous incumbent David Klein, who often argued with the Finance Ministry, step down on 16 January. Mr Fischer will face a delicate balancing act - both in political and economic term - between Mr Sharon and finance minister Binyamin Netanyahu, who also backed his nomination. But his appointment ha also raised hope that it could bring in fresh investment - and perhaps even an improvement in the country's credit rating Mr Fischer first went to Israel for six month in 1973, and almost emigrated there before deciding finally to return to the US. While teaching at the Massachussetts Institute of Technology he spent a month seconded to the Bank of Israel in 1979, beginning a long-time involvement in studying Israel's economy. In 1983 Mr Fischer became adviser on Israel's economy to then-US secretary of state George Shultz. At the World Bank in 1985, he participated in drawing up an economic stabilisation package for Israel.

Title: 'Few ready' for information act
Article: Thousands of public body are ill-prepared for the Freedom of Information Act, due to come into force next month, because of government failures, say MPs. From next month anyone will have the power to demand information from a range of public body - from Whitehall department to doctors' surgeries. But an all-party committee said it wa "not confident" many would be ready. It blamed the Department for Constitutional Affairs for a "lack of consistent leadership". The Act come into effect in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, on 1 January while similar measure are being brought in at the same time in Scotland. It provides the public with a right of access to information held by about 100,000 public bodies, subject to various exemptions. But the government department responsible for implementing the change suffered from an "unusually high turnover" of staff within the department, which had "seriously interfered" with it work, said the Constitutional Affairs Select Committee. It said, despite four year of preparations, some local authority and part of the health sector were still not ready. The DCA had "failed" to provide early guidance on technical matter and shown a "lack of consistent leadership", the MPs found. Committee chairman Alan Beith said: "The DCA ha had four year to prepare for freedom of information, but with less than a month to go it appears that some body may not be well enough prepared. "Our report show that in the past support and guidance from the DCA, which ha overall responsibility for guiding the public sector through the process of implementation for the freedom of information regime, ha been lacking." A spokesman for the DCA said: "The DCA ha provided - and will continue to provide - strong, clear leadership. "It ha delivered a simple, liberal fee regime, guidance on the Act which ha been widely praised, and expert network of staff working on freedom of information implementation."

Title: Argonaut founder rebuilds empire
Article: Jez San, the man behind the Argonaut game group which went into administration a week ago, ha bought back most of the company. The veteran game developer ha taken over the Cambridge-based Just Add Monsters studio and the London subsidiary Morpheme. The Argonaut group went into administration due to a severe cash crisis, firing about half of it staff. In August it had warned of annual loss of Â£6m for the year to 31 July. Jez San is one of the key figure in the UK's game industry. The developer, who received an OBE in 2002, wa estimated to have been worth more than Â£200m at the peak of the dotcom boom. He founded Argonaut in 1982 and ha been behind title such a 1993 Starfox game. More recently it wa behind the Harry Potter game for the PlayStation. But, like all software developers, Argonaut needed a constant flow of deal with publishers. In August it warned of annual loss of Â£6m, blaming delay in signing new contract and tough condition in the software industry. The group's three subsidiary were placed in administration a week ago, with Mr Sans resigning a the company's CEO and some 100 staff being fired. After the latest round of cuts, there were 80 worker at Argonaut headquarters in Edgware in north London, with 17 at it Morpheme office in Kentish Town, London, and 22 at the Just Add Monsters base in Cambridge. Mr San ha re-emerged, buying back Morpheme and Just Add Monsters. "We are pleased to announce the sale of these two business a going concerns," said David Rubin of administrator David Rubin & Partners. "This ha saved over 40 job a well a the substantial employment claim that would have arisen had the sale not been achieved." Mr Rubin said the administrator were in talk over the sale of the Argonaut software division in Edgware and were hopeful of finding a buyer. "This is a very difficult time for all the employee there, but I salute their commitment to the business while we work towards a solution," he said. Some former employee are angry at the way cash crisis wa handled. One told BBC News Online that the staff who had been fired had been "financially ruined in the space of a day".

Title: Police praise 'courageous' Ozzy
Article: Rock star Ozzy Osbourne ha been praised by police for "very courageously" tackling a burglar who stole jewellery from his house. The singer grabbed an intruder who then jumped 30ft (10m) from a first floor window a the star gave chase at his Buckinghamshire home on Monday. "I acted on impulse," Osbourne said. "In hindsight, it could have been a lot worse. It could've got really ugly." A Â£100,000 reward ha been offered for information leading to a conviction. His wife Sharon, who called the police, said her wedding ring were taken from her bedside table a she slept. The heavy metal star said he could have met the same fate a late Beatle George Harrison, who wa repeatedly stabbed in a break-in in 1999. "I could have been badly injured or shot or anything," Osbourne said. "I just thank God that no-one got injured." He added he wa glad the intruder were not hurt. "I wouldn't want anyone to get injured." The singer did not want to talk in detail about his action but when asked whether he would do the same again replied: "Is the Pope a Catholic?" The incident happened at 0400 GMT on Monday in Chalfont St Peter. Detective Inspector Paul Miller of Thames Valley Police said it appeared a man used a ladder to get into the house through a first floor bedroom window. "Whilst selecting item of jewellery, the burglar wa disturbed by Ozzy who very courageously tackled this burglar and pursued him from the house," he said. Ozzy said he wa "just coming to grips" with what had happened and his opinion of the UK had been lowered after 12 relatively trouble-free year in the US. "We lived in Los Angeles where people get shot every day and have been trailed by lot of different stalker - and yet we come back to England and I'm very disappointed." At a press conference on Tuesday, Sharon Osbourne gave detail of nine stolen items. They included a diamond wedding ring and two handmade wedding band Ozzy gave her when they renewed their vow two year ago. She said she wished she had worn them at night. "I always take them off and put them beside my bed and that's where they were, right beside me on my bedside table." Also taken were a pearl necklace and a sapphire bought a an investment for their daughter described by Sharon a "one of the only 24-carat sapphire that is absolutely pure". A daisy chain necklace that wa a 20th anniversary present and a Franck Muller watch Sharon said wa one of only 10 made were also stolen. She expressed her anger at the person who "hasn't worked and want to take what's yours". "But the thing is, we worked for everything. I came from Brixton. Ozzy came from not a very nice part of Birmingham and everything we've got we have worked our arses off for." "If I choose to make an investment for my kid in whatever way I choose to make it, that's my business and I worked for every God damn penny." Ozzy also lamented two year in which the family ha been plagued by problems, including his critical injury in a quad bike accident, his wife's colon cancer, their childrens' drug problem and now the burglary. On Sunday night, the Osbournes had been celebrating the birthday of singer Sir Elton John's partner David Furnish. Police described the intruder a well-built, about 5' 10" tall and said he wa wearing a ski-mask, a light-coloured jacket and trainers. They believe he may have injured himself when he jumped from the window. There is no description of his accomplice. Police think the pair were driving a large vehicle, possibly a van, and are keen to hear from anyone who may have seen one leaving Chalfont St Peter at speed. Police appealed for public help to find the perpetrator and stolen item on 0845 8 505 505 or 0800 555 111.

Title: Ukraine revisits state sell-offs
Article: Ukraine is preparing what could be a wholesale review of the privatisation of thousand of business by the previous administration. The new President, Viktor Yushchenko, ha said a "limited" list of company is being drawn up. But on Wednesday Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko said the government wa planning to renationalise 3,000 firms. The government say many privatised firm were sold to ally of the last administration at rock-bottom prices. More than 90,000 business in all, from massive corporation to tiny shopfronts, have been sold off since 1992, a the command economy built up when Ukraine wa part of the Soviet Union wa dismantled. Ms Tymoshenko said prosecutor had drawn up a list of more than 3,000 business which were to be reviewed. "We will return to the state that which wa illegally put into private hands." A day earlier, Mr Yushchenko - keen to reassure potential investor - had said only 30 to 40 top firm would be targeted. The list "will be limited and final, and will not be extended after it completion", he said. An open-ended list could further damage outside investors' fragile faith in Ukraine, said Stuart Hensel of the Economist Intelligence Unit. But the government seemed keen not to make the review look like the kind of wholesale renationalisation which many fear in Russia, Mr Hensel said. As a result, it wa planning to resell rather than keep firm in state hands. "They're aware of the need not to scare investors, and to be careful of internal divide within Ukraine," he said. "They don't want to be seen to be transferring asset from one set of oligarch to a new set." Foreign investment in Ukraine, at about $40 a head in 2004, is one of the lowest among ex-Soviet states. Mr Yushchenko became president after two election in December, the first of which wa annulled amid allegation of voting irregularity and massive street protests. His opponent, Viktor Yanukovich, still ha huge support in the country's eastern industrial heartland. Mr Yushchenko's administration ha accused it predecessor, led by ex-President Leonid Kuchma, of corruption. The privatisation review's number one target is a steel mill sold to a consortium which included Viktor Pinchuk, Mr Kuchma's son-in-law, for $800m (Â£424m) despite higher bid from several foreign groups. The mill, Krivorizhstal, is one of the world's most profitable. "We say Krivorizhstal wa stolen, and at any cost we will return it to the state," Mr Yushchenko told an investors' conference in Kiev. One of the jilted bidders, Netherlands-based group LNM, said it welcomed the possibility that the mill might be back on the market. "If the original privatisation is annulled and a new tender issued, then we would look at it with great interest," a spokesman told BBC News. A resale of Krivorizhstal could potentially triple the price, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit's Mr Hensel. But he warned that the government could decide to take the easy route of revaluing the company and charging the existing owner the revised price rather than undertaking a fresh sale. "That way, Mr Yushchenko can go to the public and say he ha forced the oligarch to play by the rules," he told BBC News.

Title: Warning over tsunami aid website
Article: Net user are being told to avoid a scam website that claim to collect cash on behalf of tsunami victims. The site look plausible because it us an old version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, DEC ha no connection with the fake site and say it ha contacted the police about it. The site is just the latest in a long list of scam that try to cash in on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam e-mail that is currently circulating. The message's subject line read "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal" and it text bear all the poor grammar and bad spelling that characterises many other phishing attempts. The web address of the fake site is decuk.org which could be close enough to the official address to confuse some people keen to donate. Patricia Sanders, spokeswoman for the Disaster Emergency Committee said it wa aware of the site and had contacted the Computer Crime Unit at Scotland Yard to help get it shut down. She said the spam e-mail directing people to the site started circulating two day ago shortly after the domain name of the site wa registered. It is thought that the fake site is being run from Romania. Ms Sanders said DEC had contacted US net registrar who handle domain ownership and the net hosting firm that is keeping the site on the web. DEC wa going to push for all cash donated via the site to be handed over to the official organisation. BT and DEC's hosting company were also making effort to get the site shut down, she said. Ms Sanders said sending out spam e-mail to solicit donation wa not DEC's style and that it would never canvas support in this way. She said that DEC hoped to get the fake site shut down a soon a possible. All attempt by the BBC News website to contact the people behind the site have failed. None of the e-mail address supplied on the site work and the real owner of the domain is obscured in publicly available net records. This is not the first attempt to cash in on the outpouring of goodwill that ha accompanied appeal for tsunami aid. One e-mail sent out in early January came from someone who claimed that he had lost his parent in the disaster and wa asking for help moving an inheritance from a bank account in the Netherlands. The con wa very similar to the familiar Nigerian forward fee fraud e-mail that milk money out of people by promising them a cut of a much larger cash pile. Other scam e-mail included a link to a website that supposedly let people donate money but instead loaded spyware on their computer that grabbed confidential information. In a monthly report anti-virus firm Sophos said that two e-mail message about the tsunami made it to the top 10 hoax list during January. Another tsunami-related e-mail is also circulating that carry the Zar worm which try to spread via the familiar route of Microsoft's Outlook e-mail program. Anyone opening the attachment of the mail will have their contact list plundered by the worm keen to find new address to send itself to.

Title: Public show for Reynolds portrait
Article: Sir Joshua Reynolds' Portrait of Omai will get a public airing following fear it would stay hidden because of an export wrangle. The Tate Gallery unsuccessfully tried to buy the picture from it anonymous owner after a ban wa issued preventing the painting from leaving the UK. The 18th Century painting ha remained in storage but the owner ha agreed to allow it to be part of an exhibition. The exhibition of Reynolds' work will be shown at Tate Britain from May. Joshua Reynolds: The Creation of Celebrity will feature prints, caricatures, and sculpture by the 18th Century artist, who painted some of the most famous personality of his day. Portrait of Omai fetched the second highest amount for a British painting when it wa sold at auction for Â£10.3m in 2001. It wa bought by a London dealer who sold it on to a collector. The unnamed collector wanted to take it out of the country, but wa barred from doing so by the government because of it historical significance. In March 2004, the Tate managed to raise Â£12.5m funding to buy the portrait but the owner refused to sell and it ha been held in storage since. The portrait is of a young man who wa dubbed "the noble savage" when he arrived in London from Polynesia. He became a darling of London society and wa invited to all the best party by people who were fascinated by such an exotic character. Sir Joshua painted him after his arrival in 1774, and it became the artist's most famous work after it wa first exhibited at the Royal Academy in 1776.

Title: Howard 'truanted to play snooker'
Article: Conservative leader Michael Howard ha admitted he used to play truant to spend time with his school friend at a snooker hall. Mr Howard said his time at Jack's Snooker Hall in Llanelli in the 1950s had not done him "any lasting damage". But he told the Times Educational Supplement that truancy wa "very bad" and said "firm action" wa needed. Mr Howard also called for a return to O-levels and more classroom discipline. Mr Howard eventually left Llanelli Grammar School - and the snooker hall - to go to Cambridge University. He said: "I don't think it's done me any lasting damage. Nor ha it made me a snooker world champion. "There might have been some occasion when we left early of an afternoon. "I'm just being honest. I think truancy is a very bad thing and that firm action should be taken to deal with it." Another player who ha failed to win snooker's world championship - Jimmy "the Whirlwind " White - ha previously admitted missing lessons, instead spending his day in smoky halls. "Tony Meo [another player] and me used to spend all of our spare time there," Mr White said, "We loved the game and the atmosphere. "School went out of the window. I went for a while and then started taking time off." Mr Howard's fellow Welshman Ray Reardon - known by his fellow professional a "Dracula" - won the snooker world championship six times, having left school at 14 to work a a miner. And Terry Griffiths, like Mr Howard from Llanelli, won the tournament in 1979. It is not known whether the two of them ever clashed cue at Jack's.

Title: Slovakia reach Hopman Cup final
Article: Slovakia will play Argentina in the final of the Hopman Cup after beating Group B rival the Netherlands 3-0. Daniela Hantuchova defeated Michaella Krajicek 6-4 6-2 to give the Slovaks the perfect start before Dutchman Peter Wessels retired against Dominik Hrbaty. Wessels wa unable to compete in the mixed double but Slovakia had already booked their place in the final for the second year running. Argentina claimed top spot in Group A with three win from three matches. In the other Group B match, the United States defeated Australia 2-1. Meghann Shaughnessy lost the opening match against Alicia Molik but James Blake levelled the tie with a 6-3 6-4 win over Paul Baccanello, who came in a a replacement for the injured Mark Philippoussis. Blake and Shaughnessy then beat Molik and Baccanello in a tense mixed double contest to take the win. Hantuchova, who did not win a Hopman Cup single match in 2004, ha been in good form during this year's event and ha won two of her three matches. "I feel like it's really deserved this time a I've helped Dominik to get through," she said. "I think if I keep going the way I have been in the past few match then I will be okay. "I wa really pleased with my last two singles, even the first one, which wa a really high standard. "You can't ask for a better preparation than to play a few match here for the Australian Open."

Title: Blogger grounded by her airline
Article: A US airline attendant is fighting for her job after she wa suspended over posting on her blog, or online diary. Queen of the Sky, otherwise known a Ellen Simonetti, evolved into an anonymous semi-fictional account of life in the sky. But after she posted picture of herself in uniform, Delta Airlines suspended her indefinitely without pay. Ms Simonetti wa told her suspension wa a result of "inappropriate" images. Delta Airlines declined to comment. "I wa really shocked, I had no warning," Ms Simonetti told BBC News Online. "I never thought I would get in trouble because of the blog. I thought if they had a problem, someone would have said something before taking action." The issue ha highlighted concern amongst the growing blogging community about conflict of interest, employment law and free speech on personal websites. Ms Simonetti wa suspended on 25 September pending an investigation and ha since lodged a complaint with the US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC). A spokesperson for Delta Airlines told BBC News Online: "All I can tell you is we do not discus internal employee issue with the media." She added she could not say whether a similar situation over personal website had occurred in the past. Ms Simonetti started her personal blog in January to help her get over her mother's death. She had ensured she made no mention of which airline she worked for, and created fictional name for city and companies. The airline's name wa changed to Anonymous Airline and the city in which she wa based wa called Quirksville. A large part of the blog contained fictional story because Queen of the Sky developed over the month a a character in her own right, according to Ms Simonetti. The image were taken from a digital camera she had inherited from her mother. "We often take picture on flight or on layovers. I just though why not include them on my blog for fun. "I never meant it a something to harm my company and don't understand how they think it did harm them," Ms Simonetti said. She ha also claimed that picture of male Delta Airline employee in uniform are freely available on the web. Of the 10 or so image on the site, only one showed Ms Simonetti's flight "wings". "They did not tell me which picture they had a problem with. I am just assuming it wa the one of me posing on seat where my skirt rode up," she said. The image were removed a soon a she learned she had been suspended. As far a Ms Simonetti knows, there is no company anti-blogging policy. There is guidance which suggests the company uniform cannot be used without approval from management, but use in personal picture on website is unclear. Jeffrey Matsuura, director of the law and technology programme at the University of Dayton, said personal website can be hazardous for both employer and their employees. "There are many example of employee who have presented some kind of material online that have gotten them in trouble with employers," he said. It wa crucial that any policy about what wa and what wa not acceptable wa expressed clearly, wa reasonable, and enforced fairly in company policy. "You have to remember that a an employee, you don't have total free speech anymore," he said. Mr Matsuura added that some company actively encouraged employee to blog. "One of the area where it doe become a problem is that they encourage this when it suit them, but they may not be particularly clear when they [employees] do cross the line." He speculated that Delta might be concerned that the fictional content on the blog may be linked back to the airline after the image of Ms Simonetti in uniform were posted. "Whether or not that is successful will depend on what exactly is prohibited, and whether you can reasonably say this content now cross that line," he said. Ms Simonetti said her suspension ha caused two of her friend to discontinue their blogs. One of them wa asked to stop blogging by his company before any action wa taken. "If they had asked me just take down the blog, I would have done it, but that wa not been given to me a an option," she said. "This blogging thing is obviously a new problem for employer and they need to get a policy about it. If I had known it would cost me my job, I would not have done that."

Title: Aviator 'creator' in Oscars snub
Article: The man who said he got Oscar-nominated movie The Aviator off the ground and signed up Leonardo DiCaprio ha been shut out of the Academy Awards race. Charles Evans Jr battled over his role with the people who eventually made the film, and won a producer's credit. But he is not on the list of producer who can win a best film Oscar due to a limit on the number of nominees. The Oscars organiser have picked two of The Aviator's four producer to be nominated for best film. Up to three producer can be named per film but the studio behind The Aviator and Million Dollar Baby failed to trim their credit - so the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences (Ampas) ha done it for them. The Aviator's nominated producer are Michael Mann and Graham King - with Mr Evans and Sandy Climan, Mr Mann's former deputy, left off. Mr Evans sued Mr Mann in 2001, claiming he came up with the idea, spent year developing it and persuaded DiCaprio to play Hughes - but said he wa later excluded from the project. The two side settled out of court in a deal that ha remained secret apart from the fact Mr Evans' name ha appeared a a producer when the film's credit roll. At the Golden Globes, Mr Evans - who wa named among the winner when the film won best drama film - evaded a security guard to have his photo taken with DiCaprio, director Martin Scorsese, Mr Mann and Mr King. Ampas decided to limit the number of producer who could be nominated after Shakespeare in Love's victory in 1999 saw five producer collect awards. The eligible name for The Aviator and Million Dollar Baby were decided by Ampas' producer branch executive committee on Wednesday. The decision also saw Clint Eastwood get his third personal nomination for Million Dollar Baby. He is now named in the best film category a well a being nominated for best director and best lead actor. The Academy Awards ceremony will be held in Hollywood on 27 February. Chinese actress Ziyi Zhang, star of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, Hero and House of Flying Daggers, is the latest name to be added to the list of presenter on the night.

Title: Wales make two changes for France
Article: Wales coach Mike Ruddock ha made two change from the team that beat Italy 38-8 for Saturday's trip to France. Kevin Morgan take over from his injured Newport-Gwent Dragons colleague Hal Luscombe on the right wing. And in the pack Neath-Swansea Ospreys forward Ryan Jones is preferred at blindside flanker to Jonathan Thomas. Thomas, a try-scorer in Rome, drop down to the bench instead of Ian Gough, while Cardiff back Rhys Williams step up in place of Morgan. Luscombe is sidelined by a hamstring problem sustained during the Six Nations game against Italy last weekend. However, the experienced and in-form Morgan wa already pushing hard for a start at Stade de France. "Due to his impressive performance from the bench, Kevin wa very much in the selection mix anyway, and the unfortunate injury to Hal give him the chance to start," said Ruddock. "Now that Ryan Jones ha recovered from injury, we have increased the option in the back row. "Jonathan Thomas is unlucky to lose his spot after performing well against Italy and scoring a try, but such is the competition for place that every position is debated in detail. "For this particular game, we felt we might not always be afforded the open space out wide we were able to exploit against Italy, so an extra big ball-carrier in the back-row is thought to be necessary on this occasion. "Obviously, it's a 22-man game these days, and there is every chance that Jonathan will be making an impact from the bench." Wales have beaten France on two of their last three visit to Paris, and another victory this time around would keep them firmly on course for a first Five or Six Nations title triumph since 1994. "Graham Henry (former Wales coach) said a couple of year ago that we should 'be bold' when going to France, and he wa proved right," said Ruddock. "That is a great way to approach the game, and something we will further endorse with the player this week." Title: Security warning over 'FBI virus'
Article: The US Federal Bureau of Investigation is warning that a computer virus is being spread via e-mail that purport to be from the FBI. The e-mail show that they have come from an fbi.gov address and tell recipient that they have accessed illegal websites. The message warn that their internet use ha been monitored by the FBI's Internet Fraud Complaint Center. An attachment in the e-mail contains the virus, the FBI said. The message asks recipient to click on the attachment and answer some question about their internet use. But rather than being a questionnaire, the attachment contains a virus that infects the recipient's computer, according to the agency. It is not clear what the virus doe once it ha infected a computer. Users are warned never to open attachment from unsolicited e-mail or from people they do not know. "Recipients of this or similar solicitation should know that the FBI doe not engage in the practice of sending unsolicited e-mail to the public in this manner," the FBI said in a statement. The bureau is investigating the phoney e-mails. The agency earlier this month shut down fbi.gov accounts, used to communicate with the public, because of a security breach. A spokeswoman said the two incident appear to be unrelated.

Title: Student 'fee factor' played down
Article: A rise ha been recorded in the number of student from south of the border applying to university in Scotland. However, Lifelong Learning Minister Jim Wallace said that this would not result in Scottish student missing out. Applications from England and Wales rose by 17% between January 2005 and the previous year, up 23,600 to 27,700. Fears had been expressed that a flood of "fee refugees" would try to avoid top-up fee of up to Â£3,000 a year being introduced in England. In June last year, Mr Wallace announced proposal to increase tuition fee for English student studying in Scotland by Â£2,000 in an attempt to prevent a cross-border flood, although no figure ha yet been agreed. Legislation to introduce the top-up fee in England is not due to take effect until autumn 2006 and student who start before then will not have to pay additional fee at all. The figure were made public on Thursday by admission service Ucas. Universities Scotland, which represents university principals, claimed that an increase in application did not amount to Scottish student being squeezed out. Director, David Caldwell, said some student could be applying in an attempt to avoid the possible increase in annual fee at English universities, but this wa not a major factor. He told BBC Radio Scotland's Good Morning Scotland programme: "The reason people are opting for Scottish university is that they are perceived a being of very high quality, they offer very attractive course and Scotland is seen a a very attractive place to study. "They know that when they take up their study in 2006 they will be hit by top-up fee if they are going to a university in England and that may be part of the reason why the number coming to Scotland are so inflated. "However, it doe not mean that we will see thousand of additional student from England studying here." Mr Wallace agreed and said the figure had to be looked at in context. He explained that when application were translated into acceptances, the number wa not huge - an additional figure of about 200. Also, the picture wa further blurred by the fact that application from Wales, where there are no plan for top-up fees, have also risen, by 19%. Mr Wallace said: "Accepting student from all part of the world doe show the high regard in which Scottish higher education is held, not just in Britain. "We want to make sure that when student are making their choice, they do so on the nature of the course and not because they are under some sort of financial pressure to go to Scotland. "We do not want to have a situation where it becomes impossible for Scottish student to get place at Scottish university because we are seen a the cheap option. "Very often the quality of the university experience is enhanced by the fact there are student coming from a wide range of background so it would be wrong to go the other way and start excluding students."
