Title: Blair sees greater Bush consensus
Article: George W Bush will display a more consensual approach to world politics a he begin his second term a US President, Tony Blair ha said. The prime minister said Mr Bush had learned military force wa not the only way to fight terrorism. He understood that "the best prospect of peaceful co-existence lie in the spread of democracy and human rights", Mr Blair told the Guardian newspaper. Mr Bush wa sworn in at a ceremony in Washington DC on Thursday. Echoing the new US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, the prime minister said there ha been a clear evolution of US policy since the war in Afghanistan in 2001. Mr Blair had personally seen the change over time in conversation with Mr Bush. The president understood that while military and security measure were important, there also needed to be a multilateral approach to solving the world's problems. Turning to critics' fear that the US wa poised for further military action, Mr Blair refused to give succour to suggestion it wa preparing for strike against Iran. The prime minister conceded that the US had "what appears to be a harder position" towards the state than Europe. But the prime minister pointed out that until now the US had allowed Britain, France and Germany to take the lead in trying to halt the Iranian nuclear programme. Following claim that US force had worked inside Iran to identify potential targets, Mr Blair wa asked if the SAS had also been in the country. "We never answer question about special forces, but do not take that a indicating an affirmative," said Mr Blair. Mr Blair said he believed the president wa keen to work with other country while trying to spread democracy and human rights. "It is significant, in my view, that he is coming to Europe a his first foreign visit," said Mr Blair. Following his inauguration, Mr Bush is due in Europe at the end of January.

Title: DaimlerChrysler's 2004 sales rise
Article: US-German carmaker DaimlerChrysler ha sold 2.1% more car in 2004 than in the previous year, a solid Chrysler sale offset a weak showing for Mercedes. Sales totalled 3.9 million unit worldwide during 2004, the company said at the Detroit Motor Show. A switch to new model hit luxury marque Mercedes-Benz, with sale down 3.1% at 1.06 million. Chrysler avoided the fate of US rival Ford and General Motors, both of whom lost ground to Japanese firms. Its sale rose 3.5% to 2.7 million units. Similarly on the up wa the Smart brand of compact cars, with the division's sale jumping by 21.1% during 2004 to 136,000. The future of the brand - which is controlled by the Mercedes group within DaimlerChrysler - remains in question, however. Smart ha consistently lost money since it started trading in 1998, and new model launch are now "on hold", said Mercedes chief executive Eckhard Cordes. In Europe, the Smart will now go on sale through regular Mercedes dealership a well a it own dealer network, Mr Cordes said.

Title: Costin aims for comeback in 2006
Article: Jamie Costin should be paralysed. He say so himself in a matter-of-fact way a he recall the car accident which occurred nine day before he wa scheduled to step out into the Olympic Stadium in Athens for the 50K Walk. There is an ironic chuckle a he talk of his immediate thought after a lorry, driving on the wrong side of the road, had ploughed into his rental car. "I wa in a lot of pain and I guessed that one of my toe wa broken," say the Waterford man. "But I wa thinking maybe with a cortisone injection you never know. "In my back, it felt a though all the muscle had been ripped off my pelvis but I wa thinking maybe we could do something with laser therapy and ultra sound and hopefully I'd be able to race." It took over 10 hour before Jamie knew with certainty that he would not be competing in his second Olympics. "My back had been broken in two place and with one of my vertebrae, the bottom part had exploded so I'm fierce lucky not be paralysed. "I'd fractured my big toe a well which wa on the brake." Jamie didn't finally arrive at hospital in Athens until some nine and a half hour after the accident. "For the first nine hours, I had no pain killer which wa ridiculous in 35 degree heat. "But once I got the scan and saw them it wa a case of moving on and thinking:'OK, I've got a different set of circumstance now'." Within three day he wa arriving back in Ireland by air ambulance. Doctors in Athens had wanted to operate on Jamie's back immediately but he insisted on delaying any surgery until he arrived back home - something he is now very relieved about. "The Greek doctor were going to put three or four inch titanium rod either side of my spinal cord up through my vertebrae. "That would have fused all my lower back and I would never have been able to race again. They were really putting a lot of pressure on me to agree to the surgery. "But when I got to the Mater in Dublin they said it wa possible for it to heal totally naturally which is giving me the chance to get back into competition which is very important to me. The people at the Mater have been absolutely fantastic." Jamie had to wear a body cast for three and a half month after the accident and spent most of that time flat on his back. He then progressed to crutch for six week until he wa finally able to walk unaided on 10 January. "Walking without the crutch seemed like something finally really measurable in term of my recovery." Physio session with Johnston McEvoy in Limerick have been a vital part of his recovery. "Johnston us an advanced type of acupuncture and it's very effective. "Needles get put right close up to my spine. A two and a half inch needle went in yesterday and I'm fairly incapacitated today a a result." Jamie ha also travelled to receive treatment at the Polish training centre in Spala where he ha trained with triple Olympic champion Robert Korzeniowski over the past five years. "I wa there for over a fortnight earlier this month and underwent a fair extreme treatment called cryotherapy. "Basically, there's a small room which is cooled by liquid nitrogen to minus 160 degree centigrade and it promotes deep healing." Jamie head to Poland again on Sunday where he will be having daily cryotherapy in addition to twice-daily physio session and pool-work. All these session are small step on the way to what Jamie hope will be a return to racing in 2006. "It's all about trying to get mobility in my back. Lying down for three and a half month didn't really help with the strength. "There's a lot of work involved in my recovery. I'm doing about six hour a day between physio and pool work. "I'm also going to the gym to lift very light weight to try and build up my muscles. I'm fairly full on with everything I do. "I'd hope to be training regularly by March. But training is just part of the process of getting back. "At the moment, every time I go and do a big bit of movement, my whole pelvic area all down my lower back just tightens up. "It's a case of waiting and seeing how it reacts. Hopefully, after four or five month my back won't tighten up a much."

Title: UKIP candidate suspended in probe
Article: Eurosceptic party UKIP have suspended a candidate for allegedly suggesting the criminally insane should be killed. John Houston, 54, wa due to stand in the East Kilbride seat in Lanarkshire at the next election. But he wa suspended after his reported views, including the return of the British Empire, were sent to two Scottish newspapers. UKIP spokesman Mark Croucher said those who selected Mr Houston knew nothing of his views. The episode come at a difficult time for UKIP, soon after the high-profile departure of MEP Robert Kilroy-Silk. Mr Houston is alleged to have said that the organ of the criminally insane should be "made available to law-abiding member of the community" and proposed the legalisation of drug and the sex trade. The document reportedly said: "We're looking for the resurrection of the British Empire. "The problem for the human race - environmental and others - can only be dealt with on a global scale, and that call for a radical alliance of the English-speaking nations, which they are uniquely able to do." Mr Croucher said the main issue would be that Mr Houston's reported view had been presented a UKIP policy, which they were not. He said they might have been submission to a committee working on the party's manifesto, but would not have been matched to Mr Houston when he wa standing to become a candidate. He told BBC News: "He appears to have said these things. We have suspended him a a member and a a candidate. "By all account none of this wa mentioned at his selection meeting. "It is simply a distraction from the task in hand, the EU constitution, not individual idiocies." Mr Houston wa quoted in the Herald newspaper saying: "I feel UKIP have over-reacted and overshot the runway." Peter Nielson, who is UKIP Scotland chairman, said he had suspended Mr Houston on Friday night. "He will remain suspended while the matter is being investigated and then we will decide if and what further action will be taken." He said that any evidence would be looked into and Mr Houston may be interviewed by the party. He added: "I can't comment too much at the moment, I have one version from him but I haven't seen the paper yet."

Title: Santini resigns as Spurs manager
Article: Tottenham manager Jacques Santini ha resigned for "personal reasons". The former France manager moved to White Hart Lane this summer but now want to return to France. Santini said: "My time at Tottenham ha been memorable and it is with deep regret that I take my leave. I wish the club and the supporter all the best. "Private issue in my personal life have arisen which caused my decision. I very much hope that the wonderful fan will respect my decision." He added: "I should like to thank (sporting director) Frank Arnesen and (chairman) Daniel Levy for their understanding." Assistant coach Martin Jol ha been put in temporary charge and will take care of team affair for Saturday's Premiership match against Charlton. Arnesen said the club were sad to see Santini go: "We are obviously disappointed that Jacques is leaving us. We fully respect his decision. "I can assure you that the club will act swiftly to minimise the impact of Jacques' departure. "Our priority is to ensure that this season's performance remains unaffected by this move. "I shall make a further statement on Monday, clarifying our position. We wish Jacques well."

Title: Iraq to invite phone licence bids
Article: Iraq is to invite bid for two telephone licences, saying it want to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, Arab and foreign companies, Iraq's Ministry of Communications said. The winner will work in partnership with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC). The firm will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax and internet services. The ministry said that it wanted to increase Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years." It also hope to develop a "highly visible and changeable telecommunication sector". Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February. It also is planning a road-show for investor in Amman, Jordan. The ministry said it would base it selection on criterion including the speed of implementation, tariff rates, coverage, and the firm's experience and financial strength.

Title: Child access laws shake-up
Article: Parents who refuse to allow former partner contact with their child could be electronically tagged under plan being considered by ministers. Curfews and community service order were other option which could be used if court order to allow parental access were defied, Lord Falconer said. The constitutional affair secretary outlined some of the plan on Tuesday. He denied fathers' activist had forced the changes, telling the BBC "there is a recognition that something is wrong". Between 15,000 and 20,000 couple go to court to resolve access dispute each year, although in nine out of 10 separation there is no court intervention. Lord Falconer told BBC Radio 4's Today programme he hoped voluntary mediation could help solve dispute before they reached court. But he opposed compulsory mediation, saying that it would lead to many people taking part with the wrong attitude. Other plan include: - Parenting plan to give advice on access arrangements, based on real-life example that have worked in the past - Extending in-court conciliation - more informal hearing before contested court case - Better access to legal, emotional and practical advice by telephone and internet - Legal aid change to give incentive for early resolution of disputes. Title: Who do you think you are?
Article: The real danger is not what happens to your data a it cross the net, argues analyst Bill Thompson. It is what happens when it arrives at the other end. The Financial Services Authority ha warned bank and other financial institution that member of criminal gang may be applying for job which give them access to confidential customer data. The fear is not that they will steal money from our bank account but that they will instead steal something far more valuable in our digital society - our identities. Armed with the personal detail that a bank holds, plus a fake letter or two, it is apparently easy to get a loan, open a bank account with an overdraft or get a credit card in someone else's name. And it is then a simple matter to move the money into another account and leave the unwitting victim to sort out the mess when statement and demand for payment start arriving. Identity theft is an increasingly significant economic crime, and we are all becoming more aware of the danger of leaving bills, receipt and bank statement unshredded in our rubbish. But, however careful you may be, if the organisation you trust with your personal data, bank account and credit card are not able to look after their database properly then you are in trouble. It is surprising that it ha taken the gang so long to realise that a well-placed insider is by far the simplest way to break the security of a computer system. In fact, I suspect that the FSA is probably very late to this particular party and that this sort of thing ha been going on for rather a long time. Has anyone checked Bob Cratchit's family link to the criminal underworld, I wonder? And it is hardly likely to be only bank that are being targeted. Health authorities, government agency and of course the big e-commerce site like Amazon must also offer rich picking for the fraudsters. The good news is that better auditing is likely to catch out those who access account detail that they are not supposed to. And a we all become aware of the danger of identity theft and look more carefully for unexpected transaction on our statements, bank should have good enough record and log to trace the people who might have accessed the account details. Fortunately there are now way to keep bank system more secure from the sort of data theft that involves taking a portable hard drive or flash memory card into the office, plugging it into a USB slot and sucking down customer files. Companies like SecureWave, for example, can restrict the use of USB port just to authorised device or even to an individual's personal memory card. These solution are not perfect, but it doe not feel like a wave of fraud is about to wash away the entire financial system. However the warning doe highlight one of the major issue with e-commerce and online trading - the security or otherwise of the server and other system that make up the 'back office'. It ha been clear for year that the real danger in paying for good online with a credit card is not that the number will be intercepted in transit but that the shop you are dealing with will be hacked. In fact I do not know of a single case where an e-mail containing payment detail ha led to card fraud. There are simply too many e-mail passing over the net for interception to be a sensible tool for anyone out to commit fraud. CD Universe, Powergen and many other company have left their database open and suffered the consequences. And just last week the online bank Cahoot admitted that it customer account detail could be read by anyone who could guess a login name. Whether it is external hacker breaking in because of poor system security or internal staff abusing the access they get a part of their job, the issue is the same: how do we make sure that our personal data is not abused? Any organisation that process personal data is, of course, bound by the Data Protection Act and must take proper care of it. Unauthorised disclosure is not allowed, but the penalty are small and the process of prosecuting under the Act so convoluted a to be worthless in practice. This is not something we can just leave it to the market. The consequence of having one's identity stolen are too serious, and market respond too slowly. After all, I bank with Cahoot but it would be so much hassle to move my account that I did not even consider it when I heard about their security problems. I doubt many others have closed their accounts, especially when there is little guarantee that other bank are not going to make the same sort of mistake in future. The two option would seem to be more stringent data protection law, so that company really feel the pressure to improve their internal processes, or a wave of civil lawsuit against financial institution with sloppy practice whose customer suffer from identity theft. I have never felt comfortable with the US practice of suing everything that moves, partly because it seems to make lawyer richer than their clients, so I know which I'd prefer. Bill Thompson is a regular commentator on the BBC World Service programme Go Digital.

Title: Rovers reject third Ferguson bid
Article: Blackburn have rejected a third bid from Rangers for Scotland captain Barry Ferguson, BBC Sport ha learnt. It is thought Blackburn want Â£6m for the midfielder but chief executive John Williams ha confirmed the club are still "in dialogue" with Rangers. The 26-year-old ha already handed in a transfer request at Ewood Park a he seek a return to Ibrox. But the club have been unable to reach agreement over a fee for Ferguson, who moved to Lancashire in 2003 for Â£6.5m. On Thursday Rangers said they would not be increasing their offer of Â£4m. Blackburn have said all along that they want Â£6m for the midfielder and Williams ha rejected proposal from Rangers over a player-swap deal. Williams said: "We are in dialogue with Glasgow Rangers but we have no agreement." The negotiation will have to be concluded by midnight on Monday, when the winter transfer window shuts. Williams conceded any deal for Ferguson wa looking "unlikely" before the close of the transfer window but Rangers still had a chance to seal the deal. "We have no comment to make other than we have not got an agreement with Glasgow Rangers," he added. "The way thing are looking, I think it is unlikely we are going to. "The ball is in their court but we have not got an offer that is acceptable at this moment." It is understood that Blackburn accepted a Â£5m offer for Ferguson from Everton at the weekend. But the player is determined to return to Scotland and rejected a move to Goodison Park. Ferguson did not play in the FA Cup win over Colchester on Saturday despite recovering from a groin injury with Rovers bos Mark Hughes claiming it had been an "emotional and difficult time" for the player.

Title: Band Aid retains number one spot
Article: The charity single by Band Aid 20 ha held on the chart top spot for a second week, strengthening it chance of becoming the Christmas number one. Do They Know It's Christmas, featuring artist including Chris Martin and Jamelia, held off Kylie Minogue to remain the week's biggest single. Next week's chart will reveal who will have the festive chart-topper Minogue's latest release I Believe in You went in at number two, pushing down Ice Cube's You Can Do It to three. Destiny's Child also slipped one place to four with Lose My Breath, followed by Girls Aloud at five with the Children in Need record I'll Stand By You. The only other new entry in the top 10 came from Robbie Williams track Misunderstood, a new track written for his Greatest Hits album. There were no new release in the entire top 40 album chart a record company put out all the big release early hoping to cash in on the lucrative Christmas market. U2's How to Dismantle a Bomb remains at number one for a third week in a row, followed by Williams' Greatest Hits. Opera band Il Divo have moved up one place with their eponymous album to number three. Maroon 5's album Songs About Jane ha moved up to number seven despite being released 47 week ago. And the Abba Gold greatest hit album ha crept back into the top 40 more than nine year after it wa first released.

Title: Dundee Utd 4-1 Aberdeen
Article: Dundee United eased into the semi-final of the Scottish Cup with an emphatic win over Aberdeen. Alan Archibald prodded United ahead in 19 minute and James Grady made it two from close range 10 minute later. Richie Byrne's header gave Aberdeen a way back into the game, but Stevie Crawford restored United's lead from 18 yard before half time. The scoring wa completed by Grady just after the break - a superb shot on the turn making it 4-1. Tony Bullock in the United goal wa called into action for the first time with just over a quarter-of-an-hour on the clock. Noel Whelan laid the ball off to Jamie Winter on the edge of the box, but his first-time effort wa gathered by the United keeper. Moments later though, the home side took the lead. Barry Robson whipped in a free kick from the right, which Stevie Crawford caught on the volley. Russell Anderson failed to deal with it and Whelan's clearance off the line landed kindly at the foot of Archibald, who poked the ball into the net. United doubled their lead after 29 minute when Grady tapped the ball into an empty net after Robson had headed Mark Wilson's cross off the angle of post and bar. But only three minute later Aberdeen clawed their way back into the match. A free kick from the left by Winter wa met powerfully by the head of Byrne at the back post, leaving Bullock helpless. United restored their two-goal lead four minute before the end of a highly entertaining first half. Jason Scotland played a perfectly-weighted pas into the path of the onrushing Crawford and he coolly beat Ryan Esson from 18 yards. United ended the game a a contest just two minute after the interval. Grady received a pas from Crawford with his back to goal on the edge of the box and after taking one touch, he spun to volley the ball past the despairing dive of Esson. The home side were in complete control and it required a good stop from Esson to keep out Robson's drive after 62 minutes. The keeper denied the same player again 10 minute later, beating away his fierce shot from the left of the penalty area. Robson saw another long-range effort tipped round the post before a cute lob wa headed off the line. Title: Ask Jeeves joins web log market
Article: Ask Jeeves ha bought the Bloglines website to improve the way it handle content from web journal or blogs. The Bloglines site ha become hugely popular a it give user one place in which to read, search and share all the blog they are interested in. Ask Jeeves said it wa not planning to change Bloglines but would use the 300 million article it ha archived to round out it index of the web. How much Ask Jeeves paid for Bloglines wa not revealed. Bloglines ha become popular because it let user build a list of the blog they want to follow without having to visit each journal site individually. To do this it make use of a technology known a Really Simple Syndication (RSS) that many blog have adopted to let other site know when new entry are made on their journals. The acquisition follows similar move by other search sites. Google acquired Pyra Labs, maker of the Blogger software, in 2003. In 2004 MSN introduced it own blog system and Yahoo ha tweaked it technology to do a better job of handling blog entries. Jim Lanzone, vice president of search property at Ask Jeeves in the US, said it did not acquire Bloglines just to get a foothold in the blog publishing world. He said Ask Jeeves wa much more interested in helping people find information they were looking for rather than helping them write it. "The universe of reader is vastly larger than the universe of writers," he said. Mr Lanzone said the acquisition would sit well with Ask's My Jeeves service which let people customise their own web experience and build up a personal collection of useful links. "Search engine are about discovering information for the first time and RSS is the ideal way to keep track of and monitor those sites," he said. It would also help drive information and entry from blog to the portal that Ask Jeeves operates. There would be no instant sweeping change to Bloglines, said Mr Lanzone. "Our intent is to take our time to figure out the right business model not to try to monetise it right away," he said. Though Mr Lanzone added that Ask Jeeves would be helping organise the database of 300m blog entry Bloglines hold with it own net indexing technology. "Being able to search the blogosphere a one corpus of information will be very useful in it own right," said Mr Lanzone. Rumours about the acquisition were broken by the Napsterization weblog which said it got the hint from Ask Jeeves insiders.

Title: Italy to get economic action plan
Article: Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi will unveil plan aimed at kickstarting the country's sputtering economy on Thursday night in Rome. He will present an "Action Plan for the Development of Italy" in a meeting with industrialist and trade union leaders. Mr Berlusconi is expected to table reform aimed at boosting research and development (R&D) spending, and the competitiveness of small firms. Also in focus will be bankruptcy law and the slow pace of the legal system. The prime minister is scheduled to start the meeting at 1830 GMT. The government ha been accused of underfunding R&D, making it harder for Italy to compete with other European nation and leading to a "brain-drain" of the country's brightest talents. Analysts say that hiring and firing staff is still too difficult and expensive, hampering the development of small- and medium-sized businesses. As a result, they say, Italy's corporate landscape is filled with numerous smaller company that are often reluctant to become bigger because of all the extra hassle that would accompany the running of a larger firm. At the same time, bankruptcy law make it difficult for failed company director to set up new business and emerge from their debts, a situation that is hampering Italy's entrepreneurial spirit. The government say that it ha set about tackling the problems, adding that getting growth going wa the responsibility of all of Italy's 60 million population. According to Il Sole 24 Ore, Italy's business newspaper, the government will focus on "opening up markets, infrastructure, research, making more incentive available, bankruptcy law, the slow pace of the justice system". Mr Berlusconi ha previously promised to cut tax by 6.5bn euro ($8.6bn; Â£4.5bn) this year in an effort to get people and company to spend. He ha also promised to cap spending on transport, education and health so a to trim the ballooning budget deficit. Italy plan to raise a much a 25bn euro from privatisation in 2005, including a partial flotation of the post office and utility Enel. Critics argue that these move do not go far enough and could make Italy's problem worse. Limiting government spending will lead to job losses, they counter, while the income tax cut will have a negligible effect on sentiment and ultimately favour the wealthy. The country ha been one of the eurozone's worst economic performer in recent years. Growth wa 1.1% in 2004, up from just 0.3% in 2003 and 0.4% in 2002 - an improvement but still a long way from ideal. At the same time, business and consumer confidence ha dipped and analyst have raised concern that what little spending there is stem from Italians dipping into their saving account or using credit cards. Without a pick up in national growth, they say, the money could eventually run out, bringing Italy's economy to a juddering halt. Consumer spending account for about two-thirds of Italy's economy.

Title: US crude prices surge above $53
Article: US crude price have soared to fresh four-month high above $53 in the US a refinery problem propelled petrol price to an all-time high. US light sweet crude future jumped to $53.09 a barrel in New York before closing at $53.03. The gain tracked a surge in US gasoline future to a record high of $1.4850 a gallon. The jump followed a fire at Western Refining Company's refinery in Texas, which shut down petrol production. A spokesman for the group wa unable to say when the production unit would be back up and running. "This market simply want to go up," Citigroup Global Markets analyst Kyle Cooper told Reuters news agency. Ed Silliere, analyst at Energy Merchant, added: "Gasoline is up because of the refinery issue in Texas, which mean there will be a scramble for product in the (US) Gulf Coast." Elsewhere, a refinery in Houston wa closed due to mechanical problems, while on Tuesday production at BP's Texas City refinery wa taken down for a short time. In the approach to Spring, the market becomes much more sensitive to problem with petrol production a dealer anticipate rising demand for fuel ahead of the holiday season. The rise in price came despite a US government report that showed domestic supply of fuel oil and fuel were rising. Meanwhile, oil production cartel Opec's recent announcement that it wa now unlikely to cut production level ha also failed to calm fear on the market. Oil price are roughly 45% higher than a year ago and have risen sharply in recent week due to a combination of colder weather, the declining value of the dollar and fear that Opec could rein in production to head off a seasonal drop in demand. Instability in Iraq and underlying fear about terrorism have also played a part in the rally.

Title: Thanou bullish over drugs hearing
Article: Katerina Thanou is confident she and fellow sprinter Kostas Kenteris will not be punished for missing drug test before the Athens Olympics. The Greek pair appeared at a hearing on Saturday which will determine whether their provisional ban from athletics' ruling body the IAAF should stand. "After five month we finally had the chance to give explanations. I am confident and optimistic," said Thanou. "We presented new evidence to the committee that they were not aware of." The athletes' lawyer Grigoris Ioanidis said he believed the independent disciplinary committee set up by the Greek Athletics Federation (SEGAS) would find them innocent. "We are almost certain that the charge will be dropped," said Ioanidis. "We believe that we have presented [a case] that the charge are unreasonable." Thanou, the 2000 Olympic women's 100m silver medallist, and Sydney 200m champion Kenteris were suspended by the IAAF for missing three drug tests. The third wa supposed to take place on the eve of the Athens Games last August, but the pair could not be found in the athletes' village. They were later taken to hospital after claiming to have been involved in a motorcycle accident. Thanou's coach Christos Tzekos wa also suspended by the IAAF. "We were asked [by the disciplinary committee] all kind of question about the night of 12 August," said Tzekos. "We did not leave any gaps. As far a I am concerned there is no such issue [of refusing to be tested], and I am very optimistic." Tzekos, Thanou and Kenteris, who have all denied the charges, can expect a decision within a month. "Deliberations will start after some additional document are brought in by Thursday," said committee chairman Kostas Panagopoulos. "I estimate that the final ruling will be issued by the end of February."

Title: French honour for director Parker
Article: British film director Sir Alan Parker ha been made an officer in the Order of Arts and Letters, one of France's highest cultural honours. Sir Alan received his decoration in Paris on Wednesday from French Culture Minister Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres. "You have explored the possibility of film with an immense talent," Mr de Vabres said a he presented the award. Parker praised French films, saying: "Hollywood, which created modern cinema, us it only a a commodity." He told the minister: "I am honoured to be thus distinguished by France, the flag carrier of cinema throughout the world." Sir Alan's film include Oscar-winning Fame plus Midnight Express and The Commitments. A founding member of the Director's Guild of Great Britain, he is a former chairman of the UK Film Council and on the board of the British Film Institute. "Through your work and your campaigns, you have shown u how the artist occupies an essential place in our contemporary society," Mr de Vabres said. "Through your dream which you show us, through the link that you weave, you question the world through the mirror of your work." He also cited the director's 2003 film The Life of David Gale, in which Kevin Spacey played a man on Death Row, a proof of his "veritable artistic commitment against the death sentence".

Title: BT program to beat dialler scams
Article: BT is introducing two initiative to help beat rogue dialler scams, which can cost dial-up net user thousands. From May, dial-up net user will be able to download free software to stop computer using number not on a user's "pre-approved list". Inadvertently downloaded by surfers, rogue diallers are program which hijack modem and dial up a premium rate number when user log on. Thousands of UK dial-up user are believed to have been hit by the scam. Some people have faced phone bill of up to Â£2,000. BT's Modem Protection program will check number that are dialled by a computer and will block them if they have not been pre-approved, such a national and net service provider numbers. Icstis, the UK's premium rate service watchdog, said it had been looking for company to take the lead in initiatives. "The initiative are very welcome," a spokesperson from Icstis told the BBC News website. "We are very pleased to see they are putting into place new measure to protect consumers." The second initiative BT announced is an early warning system which will alert BT customer if there is unusual activity on their phone bills. If a bill rise substantially above it usual daily average, or if a call is made to a suspect number, a text or voice alert will be sent to the user's landline phone. As part of the clamp-down on rogue diallers, company must now satisfy stringent conditions, including clear term and conditions, information about how to delete diallers and responsibility for customer refunds. Any firm running a dialler without permission can now be closed down by Icstis. The watchdog brought in the action last October following a decision to license all company which wanted to operate legitimate premium rate dialler services. There are legitimate company who offer service such a adult content, sport result and music downloads by charging a premium rate rather than by credit card BT said it had ploughed an enormous amount of effort into protecting people from the problem. It ha already barred more than 1,000 premium rate number and ha tried to raise public awareness about the scams. "We now want to ensure there are even stronger safeguard for our customers, who we would urge to make use of these new option to protect themselves," said Gavin Patterson, group managing director for consumer the arm of BT. Both scheme have been undergoing trial in Ireland, and will be made available to 20 million BT customer from May.

Title: Slow start to speedy net services
Article: Faster broadband in the UK is becoming a reality a more internet provider offer super-fast services. Some lucky Britons can already take advantage of UK Online's 8 megabit per second service, which wa launched in November 2004. BT Retail ha announced that it will trial the same speed service, with a national rollout by year end. Other service provider are expected to follow suit and a glut of new voice and video service will follow. "If the bandwidth is there then ISPs will buy it," said Jill Finger, a research director at analyst firm IDC. Others will be watching BT Retail's trials, which is initially for employee and later in the summer for customers, with interest. For BT Retail, she said, the super-fast service could be a way of differentiating it from other players. "It ha been losing market share and this could be one way of gaining some of that back," said Ms Finger. Wanadoo is set to trial an 8Mbps service in the summer and also plan to roll out unbundled service - which mean it take over the network from BT - which will provide speed of up to 15Mbps. There is no timetable for this at the moment. Cable firm ntl and Telewest are also bound to increase bandwidth at some time in the future and, according to an ntl spokesman, are in a better position than BT in the long term. "BT's network is limited compared to that of cable. With all the other service coming on stream such a video on demand, the question is will 8Mbps be enough?" he asked.

Title: Media seek Jackson 'juror' notes
Article: Reporters covering singer Michael Jackson's trial in California have asked to see questionnaire completed by potential jurors. Lawyers for news organisation said it wa "really vital" for the response of 250 potential juror to be made public "to serve a a check on the process". Santa Barbara County Superior Court is due to consider the request on Monday. Mr Jackson denies child molestation. It is estimated his trial will cost Santa Barbara county up to $4m (Â£2.13m). Meanwhile Michael Jackson's mother ha said she is "100% certain" her son did not commit the child abuse charge he faces. The court is currently selecting 12 juror and eight stand-by juror for the trial, a process delayed until at least Thursday after a member of the star's legal team wa hit by family illness. Defence lawyer argued against the bid by Associated Press and other news organisation to have potential jurors' response made public. "The release of the completed jury questionnaire doe not serve any purpose other than to add to the sensationalist coverage of this case," a motion by Mr Jackson's lawyer stated. The estimated total cost of the trial, expected to last five months, range from $2.5m (Â£1.33m) to $4m (Â£2.13m) of local taxpayers' money. Those estimate do not include cost to the city of Santa Maria, the Superior Court or for the investigation and prosecution of the case. The cost of security and other need around the courthouse ha been estimated at $40,000 (Â£21,000) per day, said Jason Stilwell, a special project manager at the county administrator's office. Mr Jackson, 46, denies plying a boy with alcohol and molesting him. His mother Katherine Jackson told US TV network Fox News on Sunday that her pop star son told her he wa innocent. "I believe that for one reason - I know his character," she said. "He love children. You don't molest anything that you love." Describing Mr Jackson a "a good person", the mother-of-nine said she feared he would not be given a fair trial. "I can't sleep thinking about what these wicked people might try to do to him," she said.

Title: Blair blasts Tory spending plans
Article: Tony Blair ha launched an attack on Conservative spending plans, saying they are a "ludicrous improbability". The prime minister ha told a Labour Party gathering that the Tory policy would cause economic failure. Tory leader Michael Howard ha said his party would cut Â£35bn in "wasteful" spending to allow Â£4bn in tax cuts. On Saturday, Tory shadow home secretary David Davis said the Tories would fund the cut by removing "inefficiencies" which had "burgeoned" under Labour. In his speech, Mr Blair contrasted a reformed Labour party, which had learned to occupy the political centre ground, with a hidebound Tory party, which he said would turn the clock back with spending cuts. Mr Blair said: "The Conservative tax and spending proposal would put at risk, both Britain's hard-won economic stability - the lowest mortgages, inflation, unemployment, for decade - and the key investment in public services. "I believe that the Tory plan are a plain a call to return to the past a it's possible to imagine," he said. "It's a recipe for exactly the same boom and bust economics and cut in public service that were their hallmark in 18 year of Conservative government." Mr Blair added: "They, the Conservatives have learned nothing." By contrast, he said, New Labour had listened to it electorate and changed. Mr Blair went on to list his government's achievement and to issue a rallying call to the party. "So now we have a choice, we can defend this record and we can build on it and go on and fulfil the promise or give up and go back. And I say we have to fight." In response, David Davis said the Tories would make cuts, such a removing regional assemblies, but would bring in more police officer and match Labour's spending on health and education. "Everybody knows, having lived through this government the last seven years, that they faced lot of stealth tactics, lot of increase in taxes, but no improvement in public services," he said. Mr Davis said Labour had been responsible for "huge waste, huge overspending, not on the frontline at all but on bureaucracy". "The public face a choice between more waste and more tax with this government, less waste and lower tax with a Tory government," he concluded. Gordon Brown ha addressed the conference behind closed doors. The Chancellor said the Conservatives' plan would see some Â£50bn in spending cut by 2011, which the Tories deny. Mr Brown also issued call for party unity and warn of the danger of allowing themselves to be "distracted or diverted". According to an advance text released by officials, he told delegates: "We must all show the strength and unity of purpose to take the long-term decision necessary to meet them." Mr Brown warned that the Tories were planning "the biggest cut ever in the history of any election manifesto". Meanwhile, Tory shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin accused Mr Blair of "misrepresenting" the party's proposal and questioned how Labour would fund it own plans. "He still cannot accept the simple truth, which is that we will spend more on what matter to people - schools, hospital and police - and that we will offer value for money and lower taxes," Mr Letwin said. "Once again Mr Blair and his Chancellor have failed to answer the question that lie at the heart of this election - which tax will they put up to fill the Â£8bn shortfall in their plans?"

Title: MPs to debate 'euthanasia laws'
Article: MPs are preparing to debate a bill which critic claim would legalise euthanasia "by the back door". The bill would give legal force to "living wills", where people say they want medical treatment withheld if they become severely incapacitated. The Mental Capacity Bill ha broad support from charity who say it would give better safeguard over treatment. But Christian group say it could mean doctor withholding food and fluid even if they think it inappropriate. Ministers insist the Mental Capacity Bill - for England and Wales - would not change law on assisted suicide and contains a presumption in favour of preserving life. The bill would establish a legal presumption that everybody can make decision about their own treatment unless proved otherwise. It would allow people to give somebody the power of attorney to make decision on their behalf, which could be challenged by doctors. Critics fear it could allow "killing by omission" through withdrawing treatment. An amendment to the bill - specifically preventing decision that would bring about death - ha been tabled by former Conservative leader Iain Duncan Smith. Ninety one MPs have signed a petition backing the amendment. MPs could vote on it later on Tuesday, during the bill's report stage debate. The Bill will then go to a third reading and be debated in the Lords, before becoming law. The Christian Medical Fellowship (CMF) and Lawyers' Christian Fellowship (LCF) said the Mental Capacity Bill would allow euthanasia by the "back door". Peter Saunders of the CMF said it believed advance refusal should be only advisory, not legally binding. "CMF is concerned that patient will make unwise and hasty advance decision to refuse food and fluid without being properly informed about the diagnosis and the expected course their illness will take," he said. The LCF's Andrea Williams said there were "too many loophole that could be abused by unscrupulous doctors". Ex-Labour minister Frank Field told BBC Two's Newsnight programme there wa a danger people would feel under pressure to "do away" with themselves so relative could inherit their assets. Constitutional Affairs Minister David Lammy said law affecting 750,000 people with dementia needed updating. Mr Lammy told BBC News Labour MPs would not get a free vote a the law wa being strengthened, not changed. "We are against euthanasia, we are against assisted suicide but we are in a situation now where people can make living will and that ha the force of the common law," he said. "Doctors are saying they want more clarity. Patients are saying they want more clarity." The Making Decisions Alliance, which includes the Alzheimer's Society, Age Concern, Mencap and the National Autistic Society, said misunderstanding over the bill had to be cleared up. "It will not change the current law on euthanasia and will actually provide a series of better safeguard when decision are made for people who lack capacity," the alliance said in a statement. The British Medical Association also back the bill, saying it just give incapacitated people the same right a others. Debate on legalising euthanasia ha intensified in the UK because of case like that of motor neurone patient Diane Pretty. She died two year ago after losing a legal battle to allow her husband to help her commit suicide.

Article: England's defensive worry have deepened following the withdrawal of Tottenham's Ledley King from the squad to face Holland. Chelsea's John Terry and Wayne Bridge are also out, leaving coach Sven-Goran Eriksson with a real problem for Wednesday's match at Villa Park. Injured Rio Ferdinand and Sol Campbell were both left out of the squad, and Matthew Upson ha already pulled out. Wes Brown and Jamie Carragher are likely to be the makeshift partnership. Terry, the captain of Chelsea a they push for the Premiership title, would have been a certain starter in the absence of Campbell and Ferdinand. But now he ha pulled out with a bruised knee and is likely to be replaced by Carragher, alongside Brown. Manchester United's Brown last played for England in the defeat by Australia at Upton Park in February 2003. The 25-year-old wa only called into the squad on Sunday night a cover following the enforced withdrawal of Upson, who ha a hamstring injury. And Brown now look certain to add to his tally of seven senior appearance for England. King wa forced to pull out after his groin injury wa assessed by England's medical staff. Eriksson ha still not decided whether to call up any further back-up, having already summoned Phil Neville after Bridge pulled out with a foot injury.

Title: China 'to overtake US net use'
Article: The Chinese net-using population look set to exceed that of the US in less than three years, say a report. China's net user number 100m but this represents less than 8% of the country's 1.3 billion people. Market analyst Panlogic predicts that net user in China will exceed the 137 million US user of the net by 2008. The report say that the country's culture will mean that Chinese people will use the net for very different end than in many other nations. Already net use in China ha a very different character than in many Western nations, said William Makower, chief executive of Panlogic. In many Western nation desktop computer that can access the net are hard to escape at work. By contrast in China workplace machine are relatively rare. This, combined with the relatively high cost of PCs in China and the time it take to get phone line installed, help to explains the huge number of net cafe in China. Only 36% of Chinese home have telephone according to reports. "Net usage tends to happen in the evening," said Mr Makower, "they get access only when they go home and go off to the internet café." "Its fundamentally different usage to what we have here," he said. Net use in China wa still very much an urban phenomenon with most user living on the country's eastern seaboard or in it three biggest cities. The net is key to helping Chinese people keep in touch with friends, said Mr Makower. Many people use it in preference to the phone or arrange to meet up with friend at net cafes. What people can do on the net is also limited by aspect of Chinese life. For instance, said Mr Makower, credit card are rare in China partly because of fear people have about getting in to debt. "The most popular way to pay is Cash-On-Delivery," he said, "and that's quite a brake to the development of e-commerce." The arrival of foreign bank in China, due in 2006, could mean greater use of credit card but for the moment they are rare, said Mr Makower. But if Chinese people are not spending cash online they are interested in the news they can get via the net and the view it give them on Western way of living. "A large part of the attraction of the internet is that it go below the radar," he said. "Generally it's more difficult for the government to be able to control it." "Its real value is a an open window onto what's happening elsewhere in the world," he said. Government restriction on how much advertising can appear on television mean that the net is a source of many commercial message Chinese people would not see anywhere else. Familiarity with the net also ha a certain social cachet. "It's a sign of them having made it that they can use the internet and navigate around it," said Mr Makower.

Article: Olympic heptathlon champion Carolina Kluft wa full of admiration for Britain's Kelly Sotherton a the pair prepared to clash in Birmingham. Both will be in action on Friday in the 60m hurdle and long jump ahead of the European Indoor Championships later this month in Madrid. Sotherton finished third behind the Swede in Athens, and Kluft said: "I knew about her, she's a great girl. "She looked very good early in the season and wa competing really well." Kluft showed impressive early-season form on Tuesday in Stockholm's GE Galan meeting, winning the sprint hurdles, the long jump and the 400m. Sotherton ha also displayed promise, with a new high jump personal best in Sheffield at the combined Norwich Union European trial and AAA Championships, and a second place in the long jump behind Jade Johnson.

Title: Poppins musical gets flying start
Article: The stage adaptation of children's film Mary Poppins ha had it opening night in London's West End. Sir Cameron Mackintosh's lavish production, which ha cost Â£9m to bring to the stage, wa given a 10-minute standing ovation. Lead actress Laura Michelle Kelly soared over the head of the audience holding the nanny's trademark umbrella. Technical hitch had prevented Mary Poppins' flight into the auditorium during preview performances. A number of celebrity turned out for the musical's premiere, including actress Barbara Windsor, comic Graham Norton and Sir Richard Attenborough. The show's director Richard Eyre issued a warning earlier in the week that the show wa unsuitable for child under seven, while under-threes are barred. Mary Poppins wa originally created by author Pamela Travers, who is said to have cried when she saw Disney's 1964 film starring Julie Andrews. Travers had intended the story to be a lot darker than the perennial family favourite. Theatre impresario Sir Cameron Mackintosh ha said he hope the musical is a blend of the sweet-natured film and the original book.

Title: US bank 'loses' customer details
Article: The Bank of America ha revealed it ha lost computer tape containing account detail of more than one million customer who are US federal employees. Several member of the US Senate are among those affected, who could now be vulnerable to identity theft. Senate source say the missing tape may have been stolen from a plane by baggage handlers. The bank gave no detail of how the record disappeared, but said they had probably not been misused. Customers' account were being monitoring and account holder would be notified if any "unusual activity" wa detected, bank official said. Bank of America said the tape went missing in December while being shipped to a back-up data centre. "We, with federal law authorities, have done a very robust, thorough investigation on this and neither we nor they would make the statement lightly that we believe those tape to be lost," Alexandra Tower, a spokeswoman for the North Carolina-based bank, told Time magazine. But although there wa no evidence of criminal activity, the bank said, the Secret Service - a federal agency whose brief includes investigation of serious financial crime - is said to be looking into the loss. New York Senator Charles Schumer said he wa told by the Senate Rules Committee that the tape were probably stolen from a commercial plane. "Whether it is identity theft, terrorism, or other theft, in this new complicated world baggage handler should have background check and more care should be taken for who is hired for these increasingly sensitive positions," the Democrat senator said. Details of his Vermont colleague Pat Leahy's credit card account are among those missing, Senator Leahy's spokeswoman Tracy Schmaler said. About 900,000 military and civilian staff at the defence department are among the 1.2 million affected, according to a Pentagon spokesman.

Title: The Force is strong in Battlefront
Article: The warm reception that ha greeted Star Wars: Battlefront is a reflection not of any ingenious innovation in it gameplay, but of it back-to-basics approach and immense nostalgia quotient. Geared towards online gamers, it is based around little more than a series of all-out gunfights, set in an array of location all featured in, or hinted at during, the two blockbusting film trilogies. Previous Star Wars title like the acclaimed Knights Of The Old Republic and Jedi Knight have regularly impressed with their imaginative foray into the far corner of the franchise's extensive universe, and their use of weird and wonderful new characters. Battlefront on the other hand wholeheartedly revisits the most recognisable element of the hit movie themselves. The sights, sound and protagonist on show here will all be instantly familiar to fans, who may well feel that the opportunity to relive Star Wars' most memorable screen skirmish make this the game they have always waited for. The mayhem can be viewed from either a third or first-person perspective, and you can either fight for the force of freedom or join Darth Vader on the Dark Side, depending on the episode and type of campaign a well a the player's personal propensity for good or evil. There is ample chance to be a Wookie, shoot Ewoks and rush into battle alongside a fired-up Luke Skywalker. In each section, the task is simply to wipe out enemy troops, seize strategic waypoints and move on to the next planet. It really is no more complicated than that. Locations include the frozen waste of Hoth, the ice planet from The Empire Strikes Back, complete with massive mechanical AT-ATs on the march. There are also the dusty, sinister desert of Tatooine and Geonosis, a well a the forest moon of Endor, where Return Of The Jedi's much-maligned Ewoks lived. The feel of those place is well and truly captured, with both backdrop and character looking good and very authentic. It is worth noting though that on the PlayStation 2, the game's graphic are a curiously long way behind those of the Xbox version. The pivotal element behind Battlefront's success is that it successfully give you the feel of being of being plunged into the midst of large-scale war. The number of combatants, noise and abundance of laser fire see to that, and the sense of chaos really come over. Speaking of noise, Battlefront is a real testament to the strength of the Star Wars galaxy's audio motifs. The multitude of distinctive weapon and vehicle noise are immensely familiar, a are the stirring John Williams symphony that never let up. There is also a particularly snazzy remix of one of his theme in the menu section. It ha to be said if the game did not have the boon of being Star Wars, it would not stand up for long. The gameplay is reliable, bog-standard stuff, short on originality. There are also odd annoyances, like the game's insistence on re-spawning you mile away from the action, an irritating price to pay for not getting blown up the second you appear. And some of the weapon and vehicle are not a responsive and fluid to operate a they might be. That said, it is still great fun to pilot a Scout Walker or Speeder Bike, however non user-friendly they prove. Whilst it is firmly designed with multiplayer action in mind, Battlefront is actually perfectly good fun a an offline game. The above-average AI of the enemy see to that, although given the frenetic environment they operate in, their strategic behaviour doe not need to be all that sophisticated. Battlefront's novelty value will doubtless wear off relatively fast, leaving behind a slightly empty one-trick-pony of a game. But for a while, it is an absolute blast, and one of the most immediately satisfying video game offering yet from George Lucas' stable.

Title: Bombardier chief to leave company
Article: Shares in train and plane-making giant Bombardier have fallen to a 10-year low following the departure of it chief executive and two member of the board. Paul Tellier, who wa also Bombardier's president, left the company amid an ongoing restructuring. Laurent Beaudoin, part of the family that control the Montreal-based firm, will take on the role of CEO under a newly created management structure. Analysts said the resignation seem to have stemmed from a boardroom dispute. Under Mr Tellier's tenure at the company, which began in January 2003, plan to cut the worldwide workforce of 75,000 by almost a third by 2006 were announced. The firm's snowmobile division and defence service unit were also sold and Bombardier started the development of a new aircraft seating 110 to 135 passengers. Mr Tellier had indicated he wanted to stay at the world's top train maker and third largest manufacturer of civil aircraft until the restructuring wa complete. But Bombardier ha been faced with a declining share price and profits. Earlier this month the firm said it earned $10m (Â£19.2m) in the third quarter, down from a profit of $133m a year ago. "I understand the board's concern that I would not be there for the long-term and the need to develop and execute strategies, and the need to reshape the management structure at this time," Mr Tellier said in a statement on Monday. Bombardier said restructuring plan drawn up by Mr Tellier's would continue to be implemented. Shares in Bombardier lost 65 Canadian cent or 25% on the news to 1.90 Canadian dollar before rallying to 2.20 Canadian dollars.

Title: Brown targets OAPs and homebuyers
Article: Gordon Brown ha doubled the level at which house buyer pay stamp duty to Â£120,000 a he put the economy at the heart of Labour's election campaign. The chancellor also unveiled a one-off Â£200 council tax refund for pensioner and a rise in child tax credit. Mr Brown put 1p a pint on beer, 4p on a bottle of wine and 7p on 20 cigarette but froze petrol duty until September. The Tories called it a "vote now, pay later" Budget. The Lib Dems branded it a "sticking plaster" for the election. Tory leader Michael Howard predicted the Budget would do nothing to help Labour's "faltering" election campaign. "This government and this chancellor have run out of solution to the problem Britain faces," Mr Howard told MPs. "Their only answer is to tax, to spend and to waste - to get people to vote now and pay later." He ended his response with an election challenge to Labour, saying "bring it on". Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy attacked Mr Brown for failing to mention the environment and for his record on social justice. "How can it be right in Britain today that the poorest 20% pay more in tax, a a proportion of their income, than the richest 20%?" he asked. Mr Kennedy criticised Mr Brown for failing to mention the "ticking bomb" of council tax revaluation, saying it wa "high time" the system wa replaced by a "local tax based on the ability to pay". During his 49 minute speech Mr Brown told MPs he had defied the pundit by hitting his growth target of 3.1% for 2004. He said his Budget struck a balance "between tax cut that are affordable, investment that are essential and stability that is paramount". He rejected across-the-board tax cut in favour of targeted help for families. The child tax credit will rise in line with earnings, giving family an extra Â£5 a week. In contrast, the personal income tax allowance will rise only in line with inflation from Â£4,745 to Â£4,895 next month. Mr Brown told MPs child benefit would rise to a maximum of Â£63 a week for the first child and Â£111 for two children. Despite his giveaways, Budget document show Mr Brown clawed back Â£265m through a clampdown on tax avoidance and increased revenue from a windfall tax on oil companies. He also scrapped stamp duty relief for commercial property in disadvantaged area - a measure brought in just over three year ago. BBC political editor Andrew Marr suggested the sweetener were not big enough to have a transforming effect on voters. But trust in Mr Brown's economic stewardship would be a central election issue, he said. Mr Brown also unveiled plan for a memorial to the Queen Mother, funded through a special coin to celebrate the Queen's 80th birthday. Other measure include equal tax status for same-sex couple and a deal with the Council of Mortgage Lenders to boost low cost home ownership. The level where people start paying inheritance tax will also rise from Â£263,000 to Â£275,000 from April. Mr Brown said he had met his financial "golden rule" with a Â£6bn surplus and he said public borrowing would continue to fall over the next five years. The economy had grown for 50 consecutive quarters, he said, and wa forecast to continue doing so over the next year, with a forecast of 3% to 3.5% in 2005 and 2.5% to 3% in 2006. The first Â£2bn of value-for-money saving identified in the Gershon Review have been achieved, the chancellor said. Some 12,500 civil servant post have been axed, and 7,800 relocated out of the south east of England, he added. SNP leader Alex Salmond said Mr Brown had failed the "tartan test" a there were no measure to boost the Scottish economy. Simon Thomas, of Plaid Cymru, called it a budget for Middle England. UK Independence Party leader Roger Knapman attacked the plan for pensioner saying they needed "more money and the dignity of being allowed to spend it how they want," not "free bus rides". The Green Party said the Budget wa a "wasted opportunity" for environmental protection, adding: "Brown obviously ha an eye on the coming election, and ha taken his eye off the need of the planet."

Title: Johnson accuses British sprinters
Article: Former Olympic champion Michael Johnson ha accused Britain's top sprinter of lacking pride and ambition. "At the moment, the biggest factor on the mind of British sprinter is to be number one in Britain," the world 200m and 400m record holder told Five Live. "Athletics at the moment is all about international competition and they need to show a little more pride." However, Linford Christie countered: "It's easy to criticise when you haven't gone through the system here." Johnson wa involved in a verbal spat with Britain's Darren Campbell earlier this year. The American had cast doubt on Campbell's claim he had torn a hamstring in the wake of his failure to reach the Olympic 100m and 200m finals. And the American remains highly critical of aspect of British sprinting. "The only time you see British sprinter getting upset or riled is when there is a debate a to which one is better than the other," he claimed. "Athletes here have to compete more outside the UK. Their focus ha to be on being the best in the world and not just on being the top British sprinter." Title: Tory backing for ID cards
Article: The Tories are to back controversial government plan to introduce ID cards. The shadow cabinet revealed it support ahead of next week's Commons vote on a bill to introduce compulsory ID. The decision follows a "tough meeting" where some senior Tories argued vociferously against the move, party source told the BBC. The bill, which minister claim will tackle crime, terrorism and illegal immigration, is expected to be opposed by the Liberal Democrats. They have said the scheme is "deeply flawed" and a waste of money. Sources within the Conservative Party told the BBC Michael Howard ha always been in favour of ID cards, and tried to introduce them when he wa Home Secretary. The party ha been "agnostic" on the issue until now but had now decided to come off the fence, the Tory source said. Despite giving their backing to ID cards, the Conservatives insisted they would hold minister to account over the precise purpose of the scheme. They said they would also press Labour over whether objective could be met and whether the Home Office would deliver them. And they pledged to assess the cost effectiveness of ID card and whether people's privacy would be properly protected. "It is important to remember that this bill will take a decade to come into full effect," a spokesman said. "It will do nothing to solve the immediate problem of rising crime and uncontrolled immigration." Lib Dem home affair spokesman Mark Oaten said: "This ha all the sign of Michael Howard overruling colleagues' concern over ID cards. "The Tories should have the courage to try and change public opinion not follow it." The new chairman of the Bar Council, Guy Mansfield QC warned there wa a real risk that people on the "margins of society" would be driven into the hand of extremists. "What is going to happen to young Asian men when there ha been a bomb gone off somewhere? They are going to be stopped. If they haven't [ID cards] they are going to be detained."

Title: Holmes urged to compete at Worlds
Article: Jolanda Ceplak ha urged Britain's Kelly Holmes to continue competing at the major championships. Double Olympic gold medallist Holmes ha strongly hinted she will not run in this year's Worlds and is undecided about next month's European Indoors. But World Indoor 800m record holder Ceplak said: "There is never an easy race when she is in the field. There is only excitement at what might happen. "It is good for the sport. She always fetch the best out of everyone." Ceplak ha been a great rival of Holmes' during the Briton's career and the pair fell out when Holmes questioned the manner of the Slovenian's runaway 800m victory at the 2002 European Championships. But the controversy ha since been forgotten, with Ceplak acting a pacemaker for Holmes' failed attempt on the British Indoor 1500m record at the Norwich Union Grand Prix in Birmingham in 2003. Ceplak added: "I like running against her - you know the race is always going to be fast. "That is the sort of competition that I like. She is special to me. She wa like my idol from the beginning of my career." Meanwhile, Ceplak will be looking to follow up last Saturday's win in Boston with a fast time and victory in Friday's Night of Athletics in Erfurt, Germany. Britain's Jason Gardener had been expected to defend his 60m title in Erfurt but instead he will save himself for a competition in Leipzig on Sunday. Gardener's decision mean Scotland's 400m man Ian Mackie will carry British hope in what look sure to be a tough preparation for next weekend's Norwich Union European trial in Sheffield.

Title: Federer claims Dubai crown
Article: World number one Roger Federer added the Dubai Championship trophy to his long list of success - but not before he wa given a test by Ivan Ljubicic. Top seed Federer looked to be on course for a easy victory when he thumped the eighth seed 6-1 in the first set. But Ljubicic, who beat Tim Henman in the last eight, dug deep to secure the second set after a tense tiebreak. Swiss star Federer wa not about to lose his cool, though, turning on the style to win the deciding set 6-3. The match wa a re-run of last week's final at the World Indoor Tournament in Rotterdam, where Federer triumphed, but not until Ljubicic had stretched him for five sets. "I really wanted to get off to a good start this time, and I did, and I could really play with confidence while he still looking for his rhythm," Federer said. "That took me all the way through to 6-1 3-1 0-30 on his serve and I almost ran away with it. But he came back, and that wa a good effort on his side." Ljubicic wa at a loss to explain his poor showing in the first set. "I didn't start badly, but then suddenly I felt like my racket wa loose and the ball were flying a little bit too much. And with Roger, if you relax for a second it just go very quick," he said. "After those first three game it wa no match at all. I don't know, it wa really weird. I wa playing really well the whole year, and then suddenly I found myself in trouble just to put the ball in the court." But despite his defeat, the world number 14 wa pleased with his overall performance. "I had a chance in the third, and for me it's really positive to twice in two week have a chance against Roger to win the match. "It's an absolutely great boost to my confidence that I'm up there and belong with top-class players."

Title: FA decides not to punish Mourinho
Article: The Football Association will take no action against Chelsea bos Jose Mourinho following his sending-off in Sunday's Carling Cup final. Mourinho, who wa sent from the touchline for appearing to taunt Liverpool fans, ha been "reminded of his responsibility to the game". But the FA confirmed: "There will be no further action taken in this matter." Mourinho claimed his 'silence' gesture wa aimed at the media, although they were on the other side of the ground. The former Porto coach wa forced to watch the climax of his side's 3-2 victory over Liverpool on television after being ushered away from the touchline by fourth official Phil Crossley. His gesture came after Chelsea's equaliser on 79 minute courtesy of a Steven Gerrard own goal. Mourinho still face an FA investigation into his allegation that Manchester United's player 'cheated' during January's Carling Cup semi-final at Stamford Bridge. And Uefa could also launch disciplinary action following Mourinho's failure to attend a compulsory post-match press conference after Chelsea's Champions League defeat at Barcelona last week. In addition, some time this month, Chelsea must also answer a charge of failing to control their player during the Premiership win at Blackburn in February. And a charge of failing to control their supporter following a Carling Cup meeting with West Ham earlier this season is still to be heard. The Premier League is also continuing investigation into allegation Chelsea official tapped up Arsenal defender Ashley Cole in January.

Title: UK firms 'embracing e-commerce'
Article: UK firm are embracing internet trading opportunity a never before, e-commerce minister Mike O'Brien says. A government-commissioned study ranked the UK third in it world index of use of information and communication technology (ICT). The report suggests 69% of UK firm are now using broadband and that 30% of micro business are trading online. Mr O'Brien said UK business were sprinting forward in ICT use, but that there were more challenge ahead. The report, carried out independently by consultant Booz Allen Hamilton and HI Europe, placed the UK third behind Sweden and Ireland for business use of ICT. It showed British business brought greater maturity to their ICT use, by using broadband in increased numbers, bringing ICT into their business plan and using new technology such a voice activated programme and desktop video conferences. Mr O'Brien said: "The increase in the proportion of business connected by broadband show that UK company are embracing the opportunity that ICT can bring. "It is particularly encouraging to see that small business are beginning to narrow the digital divide that appeared to have opened up in recent years." The government would play it part in "cultivating an environment where information and communication technology can flourish", Mr O'Brien said. The "clear message" the report sends is that effective use of ICT can bring real improvement in business performance for all business. "However, we are not at the finishing line yet and many challenge remain if the UK is to reach it aim of becoming a world-leading e-economy," he added. The International Benchmarking Study wa based on 8,000 telephone interview with businesses, of which more than 2,700 were UK businesses. It is the eighth in a series of examining the adoption and deployment of ICT in the world's most industrialised nations.

Title: Gamers could drive high-definition
Article: TV, films, and game have been gearing up for some time now for the next revolution to transform the quality of what is on our screens. It is called high-definition - HD for short - and it is already hugely popular in Japan and the US. It is set, according to analysts, to do for image what CDs did for sound. Different equipment able to receive HD signal is needed though and is expensive. But Europe's gamers may be the early adopter to drive demand. Europeans will have to wait until at least 2006 until they see mainstream HDTV. To view it, it need to be transmitted in HD format, and people need special receiver and display that can handle the high-quality resolution. The next generation of consoles, however, are expected to start appearing at the end of 2005, start of 2006. And most new computer display and plasma set are already capable of handling such high-resolution pictures. "In the next generation [of consoles] HD support is mandatory," Dr Mark Tuffy game system director at digital content firm THX told the BBC News website. "Every game is going to be playable in HD. "So consumer who have gone out and spent all this money on HDTVs, and who have no content to watch, are going to be blown away by these really high-detail pictures. "It's going to change really the way they look at gaming." At the end of last year, Chris Deering, Sony's European president, made a prediction that 20 million European household would have HDTV set by 2008. A previous prediction from analyst Datamonitor put the figure at 4.6 million by 2008, an increase from an estimated 50,000 set at the end of 2003. But those in Europe may see little point in buying what is quite an expensive bit of technology - about Â£2,000 - if there are few programme or film to watch on them. Satellite broadcaster BSkyB is planning HDTV service in 2006 and the BBC intends to produce all of it content in HD by 2010. Until broadcast rights, format standard - and the practicality of updating equipment - are agreed, TV content will be limited. All TV image are made up of pixel which go across the screen, and scan line which go down the screen. Most standard UK TV picture are made up of 625 line and about 700 pixels. HD offer up to 1,080 active lines, with each line made up of 1,920 pixels. This mean the picture is up to six time a sharp a standard TV. "Probably, in the UK [gaming] is going to be the only thing you are going to really be able to show off, a in 'look what this TV can do', until HD is really adopted by broadcasters," explains Dr Tuffy. But gamers are also the ideal target audience for HD because they always crave better quality graphics, and more immersive gaming experiences. They are used to spending money on hardware to match a game's requirements. Demographics have changed too and the "sweet spot" for the game industry is the gamer in his or her late 20s. This mean they are likely to have higher disposable income and can afford the price of big-screen, high-definition display technology and HD projectors, earlier than others. Higher capacity storage discs, such a HD-DVD and blue-ray , are set to be standard in the next round of game console - allowing developer more room for detailed graphics. For console developer though, HD offer some production changes. It could make game production slightly more expensive, think Dr Tuffy. "But we may see the cross-platform development of game becoming more common because they will more easily be able to take a PC game and apply it to a console," he says. "You are literally going to get to the point, with a Lord of the Rings game for example, is going to be closer and closer to the actual film, especially the CGI stuff from the DVD. "And the transition when they move from a cut scene to the game, just now they have almost got it seamless." With HD, he says, the transition will be completely seamless and the same quality a the big-screen cinema release. This could herald an increasing convergence between the film and gaming industry. But it may not be until the generation after the next game console where the two industry really collide. At that point, say Dr Tuffy, game could become more or less interactive movies.

Title: Pixies take on Reading and Leeds
Article: Pixies, Foo Fighters and Iron Maiden will headline this summer's Leeds and Reading festivals. The trio of rock heavyweight will top the bill for the three-day event at Bramham Park, near Wetherby, and at Richfield Avenue, Reading. They are the Pixies' and Iron Maiden's only UK festival gigs, while Foo Fighters are also at T In The Park. The Killers, Razorlight and Queens of the Stone Age are also playing the twin festivals, to be held on 26-28 August. Other act in this year's line-up include The Charlatans, Marilyn Manson and Kings of Leon. Pete Doherty's band Babyshamblers will appear on the NME/Radio One stage along with Kasabian, Black Rebel Motorcycle Club and Bloc Party. Organiser Mean Fiddler said more act were still to be confirmed for the summer event. "We are all very excited to be going back to Reading and intend to have a fantastic time," said Iron Maiden's Bruce Dickinson. "We're sure fan will too." It will the first time the veteran British metal band have played Reading in 23 years. At Leeds, Iron Maiden will headline the first day of the festival on the Friday, Pixies will follow on Saturday and the Foo Fighters will close the event on Sunday. The Pixies will headline the first day of Reading, while Foo Fighters will play on Sunday and Iron Maiden will close the event. Weekend ticket are now on sale priced at Â£125 each.
