Article: The Football Association ha said it will not be bringing charge over the tunnel incident prior to the Arsenal and Manchester United game. Arsenal's Patrick Vieira had earlier denied accusation that he threatened Gary Neville before the 4-2 defeat. Vieira also clashed with opposing skipper Roy Keane and referee Graham Poll had to separate them. They are big enough player to handle themselves," said Vieira. "I had a talk with Roy Keane and that's it. Gary Neville is a big lad, he can handle himself. "I thought it wa a horrible game in the first half, and it wa not much better in the second," he said. "There is no way that should have happened in a football match." Title: Blair pledges unity to Labour MPs
Article: Tony Blair ha sought to reassure Labour backbencher that nothing will stand in the way of the party's bid for a third term in power. Mr Blair wa speaking to MPs amid fresh rumour of a rift with Gordon Brown. A new book say the prime minister went back on a pledge to Mr Brown to stand down before the next general election. The chancellor ha said he is focused on winning the poll and is due to join election supremo Alan Milburn for a Labour poster launch this week. Mr Blair told the Parliamentary Labour Party (PLP) on Monday: "I know from everyone here, in Cabinet and government, nothing is going to get in the way of a unified Labour Party with a unified position and winning the third term people desperately need." The prime minister and his chancellor arrived within second of each other and seemingly in good spirit at the start of the meeting which lasted around an hour. A new book, Brown's Britain by Sunday Telegraph journalist Robert Peston, say Mr Blair went back on a pledge to make way for Mr Brown after Cabinet ally intervened in June 2004. It ha caused a new wave of concern among Labour MPs gearing up to defend their seat in an election, widely expected to be held in May, and several member are understood to have lined up to express their discontent at the PLP meeting. Health Secretary John Reid earlier warned that Labour member would not easily forgive anybody fuelling damaging speculation. He told BBC News: "Those who co-operate or inspire these books, in my view, have to know that, whatever the short-term political or personal advantage that they think they might secure, they always do it by damaging the record, the unity and the re-election chance of the Labour Party and the government." Mr Blair on Sunday dismissed claim of broken promises, saying: "I've dealt with this six month ago. I said then you don't do deal over job like this - you don't." In a separate BBC interview, Mr Brown said he and the prime minister would not be distracted by "gossip". "It's very important that we all do what we can in a unified way to ensure the election of a Labour government," he said. On Monday, Mr Blair's spokesman said: "The prime minister is determined that he will get on with the business of government because he belief that what people want." Mr Brown say he discussed the election campaign with Mr Blair on Saturday and promised to play his part. Mr Peston said the pair had "mutual animosity and contempt". Mr Blair had decided in November 2003 he would quit because he felt he had lost voters' trust because of the Iraq war. He had then changed his mind in June 2004, following intervention from Cabinet ally and suspicion that the chancellor wa manoeuvring against him. Mr Brown allegedly said he could no longer believe anything Mr Blair told him. Conservative co-chairman Liam Fox likened the two men to "self-obsessed schoolboys". Liberal Democrat parliamentary chairman Matthew Taylor said their personal ambition wa "getting in the way of good government". Ex-Labour leader Neil Kinnock said Mr Blair and Mr Brown could only deal with the medium frenzy by continuing to say they would not allow a row to damage Labour or British interests. He told BBC Radio Five Live that Mr Brown would never encourage any kind of insurrection or coup.

Title: Cyber criminals step up the pace
Article: So-called phishing attack that try to trick people into handing over confidential detail have boomed in 2004, say security experts. The number of phishing e-mail message stopped by security firm MessageLabs ha risen more than tenfold in less than 12 months. In 2004 it detected more than 18 million phishing e-mail messages. Other statistic show that in 2004 73% of all e-mail wa spam and one in 16 message were infected with a virus. In it end-of-year report, MessageLabs said that phishing had become the top security threat and most popular form of attack among cyber criminals. In September 2003, MessageLabs caught only 273 phishing e-mail that tried to make people visit fake version of the website run by real bank and financial organisations. But by September 2004 it wa stopping more than two million phishing related e-mail message per month. Worryingly, said the firm, phishing gang were using increasingly sophisticated technique to harvest useful information such a login detail or personal data. Older attack relied on user not spotting the fact that the site they were visiting wa fake, but more recent phishing e-mail simply try to steal detail a soon a a message is opened. Other phishing scam try to recruit innocent people into acting a middleman for laundering money or good bought with stolen credit cards. "E-mail security attack remain unabated in their persistence and ferocity," said Mark Sunner, chief technology officer at MessageLabs. "In just 12 month phishing ha firmly established itself a a threat to any organisation or individual conducting business online," he said. Mr Sunner said MessageLabs wa starting to see some phishing attack become very focused on one company or organisation. "Already particular business are threatened and blackmailed, indicating a shift from the random, scattergun approach, to customised attack designed to take advantage of the perceived weakness of some businesses," he said. Although phishing attack grew substantially throughout 2004, virus and spam remain popular with cyber-criminals and vandals. One of the biggest outbreak took place in January when the MyDoom virus started circulating. To date the company ha caught more than 60 million copy of the virus. Also up this year wa the amount of spam in circulation. In 2003 only 40% of message were spam. But by the end of 2004, almost three-quarters of message were junk.

Title: Savvy searchers fail to spot ads
Article: Internet search engine user are an odd mix of naive and sophisticated, suggests a report into search habits. The report by the US Pew Research Center reveals that 87% of searcher usually find what they were looking for when using a search engine. It also show that few can spot the difference between paid-for result and organic ones. The report reveals that 84% of net user say they regularly use Google, Ask Jeeves, MSN and Yahoo when online. Almost 50% of those questioned said they would trust search engine much less, if they knew information about who paid for result wa being hidden. According to figure gathered by the Pew researcher the average user spends about 43 minute per month carrying out 34 separate search and look at 1.9 webpage for each hunt. A significant chunk of net users, 36%, carry out a search at least weekly and 29% of those asked only look every few weeks. For 44% of those questioned, the information they are looking for is critical to what they are doing and is information they simply have to find. Search engine user also tend to be very loyal and once they have found a site they feel they can trust tend to stick with it. According to Pew Research 44% of searcher use just a single search engine, 48% use two or three and a small number, 7%, consult more than three sites. Tony Macklin, spokesman for Ask Jeeves, said the result reflected it own research which showed that people use different search engine because the way the site gather information mean they can provide different result for the same query. Despite this liking for search site half of those questioned said they could get the same information via other routes. A small number, 17%, said they wouldn't really miss search engine if they did not exist. The remaining 33% said they could not live without search sites. More than two-thirds of those questioned, 68%, said they thought that the result they were presented with were a fair and unbiased selection of the information on a topic that can be found on the net. Alongside the growing sophistication of net user is a lack of awareness about paid-for result that many search engine provide alongside list of website found by indexing the web. Of those asked, 62% were unaware that someone ha paid for some of the result they see when they carry out a search. Only 18% of all searcher say they can tell which result are paid for and which are not. Said the Pew report: "This finding is ironic, since nearly half of all user say they would stop using search engine if they thought engine were not being clear about how they presented paid results." Commenting Mr Macklin said sponsored result must be clearly marked and though they might help with some query user testing showed that people need to be able to spot the difference.

Title: Asia shares defy post-quake gloom
Article: Thailand ha become the first of the 10 southern Asian nation battered by giant wave at the weekend to cut it economic forecast. Thailand's economy is now expected to grow by 5.7% in 2005, rather than 6% a forecast before tsunami hit six tourist provinces. The full economic cost of the disaster remain unclear. In part, this is because of it scale, and because delivering aid and recovering the dead remain priorities. But Indonesian, Indian and Hong Kong stock market reached record high on Wednesday, suggesting that investor do not fear a major economic impact. The high showed the gap in outlook between investor in large firm and individual who have lost their livelihoods. Investors seemed to feel that some of the worst-affected area - such a Aceh in Indonesia - were so under-developed that the tragedy would little impact on Asia's listed companies, according to analysts. "Obviously with a lot of loss of life, a lot of time is needed to clean up the mess, bury the people and find the missing. But it's not necessarily a really big thing in the economic sense," said ABN Amro chief Asian strategist Eddie Wong. India's Bombay Stock Exchange inched slightly above it previous record close on Wednesday. Expectations of strong corporate earnings in 2005 drove the Indonesian stock exchange in Jakarta to a record high on Wednesday. In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index may be benefiting in part from the potential for it listed property company to gain from rebuilding contract in the tsunami-affected region of South East Asia. In Sri Lanka, some economist have said that a much a 1% of annual growth may be lost. Sri Lanka's stock market ha fallen about 5% since the weekend, but it is still 40% higher than at the start of 2004. Thailand may lose 30bn baht (Â£398m; $768m) in earnings from tourism over the next three months, according to tourism minister Sontaya Kunplome. In the affected provinces, he expects the loss of tourism revenue to be offset by government reconstruction spending. Thailand intends to spend a similar sum - around 30bn baht - on the rebuilding work. "It will take until the fourth quarter of next year before tourist visitor in Phuket and five other province return to their normal level," said Naris Chaiyasoot, director general at the ministry's fiscal policy office. In the Maldives the cost of reconstruction could wipe out economic growth, according to a government spokesman. "Our nation is in peril here," said Ahmed Shaheed, the chief government spokesman. He estimated the economic cost of the disaster at hundred of million of dollars. The Maldives ha gross domestic product of $660m. "It won't be surprising if the cost exceeds our GDP," he said. "In the last few years, we made great progress in our standard of living - the United Nations recognised this. Now we see this can disappear in a few days, a few minutes." Shaheed noted that investment in a single tourist resort - the economic mainstay - could run to $40m. Between 10 and 12 of the 80-odd resort have been severely damaged, and a similar number have suffered significant damage. However, many experts, including the World Bank, have pointed out that it is still difficult to assess the magnitude of the disaster and it likely economic impact.

Title: How to make a gigapixel picture
Article: The largest digital panoramic photo in the world ha been created by researcher in the Netherlands. The finished image is 2.5 billion pixel in size - making it about 500 time the resolution of image produced by good consumer digital cameras. The huge image of Delft wa created by stitching together 600 single snap of the Dutch city taken at a fixed spot. If printed out in standard 300 dot per inch resolution, the picture would be 2.5m high and 6m long. The researcher have put the image on a website which let viewer explore the wealth of detail that it captures. Tools on the page let viewer zoom in on the city and it surroundings in great detail. The website is already proving popular and currently ha more than 200,000 visitor every day. The image wa created by imaging expert from the Dutch research and technology laboratory TNO which created the 2.5 gigapixel photo a a summer time challenge. The goal of the project wa to be one of the first group to make gigapixel images. The first image of such a size wa manually constructed by US photographer Max Lyons in November 2003. That image portrayed Bryce Canyon National Park, in Utah, and wa made up of 196 separate photographs. The panorama of Delft is a little staid in contrast to the dramatic rockscape captured in Mr Lyons' image. "He did it all by hand, which wa an enormous effort, and we got the idea that if you use automatic techniques, it would be feasible to build a larger image," said Jurgen den Hartog, one of the TNO researcher behind the project. "We were not competing with Mr Lyons, but it started a a lunchtime bet." The Dutch team used already available technologies, although it had to upgrade them to be able to handle the high-resolution image. "We had to rewrite almost all the tools," Me den Hartog told the BBC News website. "All standard Windows viewer available would not be able to load such a large image, so we had to develop one ourselves." The 600 component picture were taken on July 2004 by a computer-controlled camera with a 400 mm lens. Each image wa made to slightly overlap so they could be accurately arranged into a composite. The stitching process wa also done automatically using five powerful PCs over three days. Following the success of this project, and with promise of help from others, the TNO team is considering creating a full 360-degree panoramic view of another Dutch city, with even higher resolution.

Title: Safety alert as GM recalls cars
Article: The world's biggest carmaker General Motors (GM) is recalling nearly 200,000 vehicle in the US on safety grounds, according to federal regulators. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) said the largest recall involves 155,465 pickups, van and sport utility vehicle (SUVs). This is because of possible malfunction with the braking systems. The affected vehicle in the product recall are from the 2004 and 2005 model years, GM said. Those vehicle with potential fault are the Chevrolet Avalanche, Express, Kodiak, Silverade and Suburban; the GMC Savana, Sierra and Yukon. The NHTSA said a pressure accumulator in the braking system could crack during normal driving and fragment could injure people if the hood wa open. This could allow hydraulic fluid to leak, which could make it harder to brake or steer and could cause a crash, it warned. GM is also recalling 19,924 Cadillac XLR coupes, SRX SUVs and Pontiac Grand Prix sedan from the 2004 model year. This is because the accelerator pedal may not work properly in extremely cold temperatures, requiring more braking. In addition, the car giant is calling back 17,815 Buick Raniers, Chevrolet Trailblazers, GMC Envoys and Isuzu Ascenders from the 2005 model year because the windshield is not properly fitted and could fall out in a crash. However, GM stressed that it did not know of any injury related to the problems. News of the recall follows an announcement last month that GM expects earnings this year be lower than in 2004. The world's biggest car maker is grappling with loss in it European business, weak US sale and now a product recall. In January, GM said higher healthcare cost in North America, and lower profit at it financial service subsidiary would hurt it performance in 2005.

Title: Call to overhaul UK state pension
Article: The UK pension system ha been branded inadequate and too complex by a leading retirement think-tank. The Pensions Policy Institute (PPI) said replacing the state pension with a "citizen's pension" would help tackle inequality and complexity. The change would see pension being calculated on length of residency in the UK rather than National Insurance (NI) contributions. Reform could reduce poverty by aiding people with broken employment records. The PPI added that once the state system wa reformed the government should look at option to overhaul private and workplace pensions. The think tank's proposal were made in response to the recent publication of the Pensions Commission's initial report into UK retirement savings. According to the Pensions Commission's report 12 million working people are not saving enough for their retirement. As a result, living standard could fall for the next generation of UK pensioners. The report added that a combination of higher taxes, higher saving and/or a higher average retirement age wa needed to solve the UK pension crisis.

Title: Tokyo says deflation 'controlled'
Article: The Japanese government ha forecast that the country's economic growth will slow to 1.6% in the next fiscal year starting in April 2005. While it predicts this fall from the current 2.1% level, it said it wa making progress on ending deflation. The figure were given by economics minister Heizo Takenaka who said the economy would grow by 2% in 2006/07. He said the consumer price index (CPI) would rise 0.1% in the next fiscal year, the first gain since 2000/01. "We are attempting to make real economic condition better and to overcome deflation. I think we are on track," said Mr Takenaka. Deflation - or falling consumer price - ha plagued Japan for more than five years. To ease the problem the Bank of Japan ha regularly flooded the money market with excess cash to keep short term interest rate at 0% in an attempt to spur economic activity.

Title: Tautou 'to star in Da Vinci film'
Article: French actress Audrey Tautou, star of hit film Amelie, will play the female lead in the film adaptation of The Da Vinci Code, it ha been reported. The movie version of Dan Brown's best-selling novel is being directed by Ron Howard and also star Tom Hanks. Tautou will play Hanks' code-cracking partner, according to various newspapers. She is currently starring in A Very Long Engagement, directed by Jean-Pierre Jeunet. Jeunet wa also responsible for directing Tautou in Amelie in 2001, which launched the actress into the mainstream. She also starred a the lead role in critically-acclaimed film Dirty Pretty Things in 2002. Oscar-winning director Ron Howard chose Tautou for the part, preferring a French actress to a big name Hollywood star. Article: New Home Secretary Charles Clarke ha vowed to plough on with plan for ID card despite a call for him to "pause for thought" from Charles Kennedy. Title: Royal couple watch nation's mood
Article: Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles are awaiting the nation's reaction after announcing they are to be married on 8 April. Mrs Parker Bowles will take the title HRH Duchess of Cornwall after a civil ceremony to be held at Windsor Castle. A Daily Telegraph poll of 1,313 people suggests two-thirds of Britons support the couple's decision to marry. But only 40% think Mrs Parker Bowles should become Princess Consort a planned after Charles becomes king. Some 47% believe she should have no title, while 7% think she should become queen. The poll also found that the majority of Britons would prefer the monarchy to miss a generation, with the Queen handing the throne to her grandson Prince William, 22, on her death or abdication. On Thursday night, Prince Charles, 56, and Mrs Parker Bowles, 57, hosted a dinner at Windsor Castle, their first public appearance since announcing their engagement. Mrs Parker Bowles said the prince went down on one knee to propose and added: "I'm just coming down to earth." She displayed her diamond engagement ring - a Royal Family heirloom - to reporters. Charles said he and his wife-to-be were "absolutely delighted". Their marriage will end year of speculation on a relationship which date back to 1970. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh said the news had made them "very happy". Princes William and Harry said they are "very happy" and wish the couple "all the luck in the future". The wedding will be a civil ceremony followed by a service of prayer and dedication in St George's Chapel at which the Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr Rowan Williams, will preside. The marriage is likely to be a sensitive issue because Mrs Parker Bowles is divorced and her former husband is still alive. If he became king, Charles would be the supreme governor of the Church of England and some Anglicans remain opposed to the remarriage of divorcees. "His divorce from Diana and the disappointment the country felt over how Diana had been treated... opened up a sense of disillusionment with [Prince Charles]," said Ros Coward, who wrote the authorised biography of Diana, princess of Wales. The Archbishop of Canterbury said: "I am pleased that Prince Charles and Mrs Camilla Parker Bowles have decided to take this important step." Tony Blair said he wa "delighted" for the couple and offered his congratulations, a did Conservative leader Michael Howard and Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy. Australia's Prime Minister John Howard also offered his congratulations, adding that their decision to marry wa a "sensible and a good thing". Mrs Parker Bowles ha joined the prince at numerous engagement in recent year - mostly at evening event for The Prince's Trust. Clarence House staff were at pain to point out that she attended these event in a private capacity.

Title: Blair returns from peace mission
Article: Prime Minister Tony Blair ha arrived back from his diplomatic mission to the Middle East to try to resurrect the peace process. Mr Blair held talk with his Israeli counterpart, Ariel Sharon, and the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas. He confirmed that a renewed drive to reform the Palestinian Authority and address security issue would come at a London conference in March. Mr Blair also made a surprise trip to Iraq this week. The Israelis described the meeting a important but said they would not need to attend. Mr Blair briefly visited the tomb of Yasser Arafat in Ramallah - the first world leader to do so. He nodded briefly towards the tomb, rather than lay a wreath, in what Palestinian official said wa a compromise gesture agreed at the last minute. The BBC's Paul Reynolds say the London conference will be a limited measure to shore up the leadership of Mahmoud Abbas, also known a Abu Mazen, who is expected to win the Palestinian presidential election on 9 January. At a news conference following talk with Mr Blair, Mr Abbas said the British prime minister wa "in a unique position to help u progress in our peaceful pursuit". He added: "Your endeavour to hold a conference in London is another example of your deep commitment to this purpose." In an interview with the BBC's political editor Andrew Marr, Mr Blair said getting progress between Israelis and Palestinians would be "tough, but at least we have got the first step". Mr Blair acknowledged some people believed he wa too close to the Israelis, but said the Israelis were entitled to expect Palestinians to give up terrorism. He argued that Mr Sharon wa committed to the internationally-agreed roadmap peace plan and said his bid to disengage from Gaza had to be part of the peace process, not the end of it. Earlier, Mr Sharon again said he had not seen "the slightest step" the Palestinians were working to end terror attack - though he acknowledged Palestinian leader were in the middle of an election campaign that could be hampering their efforts. Before visiting Israel, Mr Blair made a surprise visit to Iraq, where he met leader in Baghdad during his first trip to the city. He wa briefed on preparation for the national poll, which is scheduled for next month but is threatened by a deadly campaign of insurgent violence. He also flew to Basra in southern Iraq where British force are stationed.

Title: Howard attacks cost of asylum
Article: Michael Howard ha launched an attack on the cost of Britain's "chaotic" asylum system under Tony Blair. The Tory leader said English local authority have spent more than Â£3bn - or Â£140 per household - on asylum since Labour won power in 1997. Mr Howard is expected to tell activist in Kent that voters' tolerance and desire to help others are being abused. Other party and refugee agency have already attacked Tory plan for annual limit on numbers. Mr Howard said Britain should take it fair share of the world's "genuine refugees". "The anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz - where my grandmother wa murdered along with over a million others - ha reminded all of u that we have a moral responsibility to those fleeing persecution," he wa due to say. "But if we are to fulfil responsibility, we have to get a grip of the system. "Fair play matters. People want a government that upholds the rule - not one that turn a blind eye when they are bent and abused," he said. "And let's be clear. Our asylum system is being abused - and with it Britain's generosity." Earlier this week, Mr Howard said his party's plan to cut immigration were not racist, arguing they would make the asylum system fairer for genuine refugees. If elected, his party would institute an annual limit on asylum and all claim would be processed overseas. That prompted some charity to say the plan would put refugees' life at risk if they were turned away once quota were filled. "If we have a moral responsibility towards people fleeing persecution, then these policy will not provide a safe haven," said Hannah Ward of the Refugee Council. "If people turn up in the UK asking for help they will be turned away. Michael Howard's policy effectively mean there is no safe haven in the UK. "When it come to costs, then perhaps we should start with how decision are made on asylum seekers. So many of them are shown to be wrong - one in five decision that are appealed are successfully overturned, rising to half for some nationalities. "We need good quality decision-making on asylum application because it is delay in the system which cost so much." Tony Blair said Labour would set out workable plan for tackling immigration abuse in the next few week and attacked the Tory plans. "By cutting the number of front-line immigration staff at our borders, they will actually make the problem worse," said Mr Blair. Liberal Democrat chairman Matthew Taylor said there needed to be a quick, fair and firm asylum system. But he said it wa "absolutely disgusting" to propose a system which could turn away genuine refugees. The Conservatives say there is little risk of this happening a demand for asylum will be considered when quota are set. On Monday, Mr Howard said: "It's not racist, a some people to claim, to talk about controlling immigration far from it."

Title: Fiat chief takes steering wheel
Article: The chief executive of the Fiat conglomerate ha taken day-to-day control of it struggling car business in an effort to turn it around. Sergio Marchionne ha replaced Herbert Demel a chief executive of Fiat Auto, with Mr Demel leaving the company. Mr Marchionne becomes the fourth head of the business - which is expected to make a 800m euro ($1bn) loss in 2004 - in a many years. Fiat underperformed the market in Europe last year, seeing flat sales. The car business ha made an operating loss in five of the last six year and wa forced to push back it break-even target from 2005 to 2006. The management change are part of a wider shake-up of the business following Fiat's resolution of it dispute with General Motors. As part of a major restructuring, Fiat is to integrate the Maserati car company - currently owned by Ferrari - within it own operations. Ferrari, in which Fiat owns a majority stake, could be separately floated on the stock market in either 2006 or 2007. Mr Marchionne, who only joined the company last year, said Fiat Auto wa now the "principal focus" of his attention. "I have made the decision to take on the post of chief executive of the auto unit to speed up the company's recovery," he said. "A profound cultural transformation is underway following a management reorganisation that ha delivered a more agile and efficient structure," he added. Although Mr Marchionne doe not have a background in the car industry, he ha been playing an increasing role in the group's activities. Last year, he said that a series of new models, launched a part of the group's recovery plan, had not boosted revenue a much a hoped. The car business, best known for it Alfa Romeo marque, is expected to make a loss of about 800m euro in 2004. Sales are expected to fall in 2005, Fiat said this week, a it exit unprofitable area such a the rental car market. Mr Demel, a car industry veteran, took the helm in November 2003 after being recruited by former Fiat chief executive Giuseppe Morchio. Mr Morchio made a bid last year to become chairman after the death of president Umberto Agnelli. However, this wa rejected by the founding Agnelli family and Mr Morchio subsequently resigned. Earlier this week, Fiat reached an agreement with GM to dissolve an alliance which could have obliged GM to buy the Italian firm outright. GM will pay Fiat $2bn a part of the settlement.

Article: A British Muslim group ha criticised the new series of US drama 24, which is about to be aired on Sky One, claiming it portrays Islam unfairly. The Muslim Council of Britain ha complained to broadcasting watchdog Ofcom. It say the programme breach editorial guidelines. The group's member met with Sky executive on Tuesday after viewing preview of the first five episodes. The drama, now in it fourth series, begin on Sunday evening. The new series portrays a Muslim family a a sleeper terrorist cell. The Muslim Council of Britain said in a statement: "We are greatly concerned by the unremittingly hostile and unbalanced portrayal of Muslims in this series of 24 based upon a preview of the first five episode that we have seen." "There is not a single positive Muslim character in the storyline to date. At a time when negative stereotype of Muslims are on the increase we feel that Sky - a a major UK broadcaster - ha a responsibility to challenge these insidious views, not help to reinforce them." Title: Ruddock backs Yapp's credentials
Article: Wales coach Mike Ruddock say John Yapp ha what it take a an international. The 21-year-old Blues prop is the only uncapped player in Wales' Six Nations squad, gaining a chance in the absence of Ospreys loose-head Duncan Jones. "John is a young man with a big future. He ha been playing with the Blues for two year and ha racked up mileage on his playing clock," said Ruddock. "He ha international size, is a big, physical lad and a good ball-carrier with a high tackle-count." Ruddock's assessment wa backed up by Yapp's coach at the Blues, former Wales and Lions prop Dai Young. "John's been on an upward curve all season and is going from strength to strength," Young told BBC Sport Wales. "His ball carrying give u good go-forward, he impress in defence and his work-rate is excellent. "He's working hard on his scrummaging technique, which he is keen to improve to become a destroyer on the loose-head. "To be fair to him he's not quite there with the scrummaging yet, but nobody can fault his effort, commitment and attitude. "John's a very strong man and is eager for the challenge, if he's pitched in he won't let anyone down. "He's developing quickly, but I hope he isn't pushed too quickly in a way that would hurt his development." Ruddock hope that the selection of Yapp and Dragons lock Ian Gough - out of the international reckoning since falling out with former coach Steve Hansen - will send a message to other player in Wales. "John and Ian have been rewarded for impressing during the Heineken Cup competition," said Ruddock. "Both of them have played well, and we want to send a message out that consistently playing well get you in the squad. "We believe this is an exciting squad representing traditional value of Welsh rugby, and based on the performance in the November internationals. "We have strength and experience up front, and well-recognised talent, pace and skill behind. "The management team just want to get hold of the player and get out on the training pitch at the moment. "They are all due in on Sunday, and that's when the hard work starts."

Title: Mourinho to escape FA charge
Article: Chelsea bos Jose Mourinho will not face any Football Association action over the comment he made after their Carling Cup tie with Manchester United. Mourinho intimated that United bos Sir Alex Ferguson influenced referee Neale Barry after the duo walked down the tunnel together at half-time. But an FA spokesman told BBC Sport: "We are not taking action over Mourinho. "We have looked at the comment and we have decided that no further action is required. That is the end of it." Mourinho wa concerned that Ferguson's conversation with Barry wa followed by an inconsistent display by the official. "I see one referee in the first half and another in the second," said Mourinho. "If the FA ask me what happened, I will tell them. What I saw and felt made it easier to understand a few things. "Maybe when I turn 60 and have been managing in the same league for 20 year and have the respect of everybody I will have the power to speak to people and make them tremble a little bit. "The referee controlled the game in one way during the first half but in the second they had dozen of free-kicks. It wa fault after fault, dive after dive. Title: Prodigy join V Festival line-up
Article: Essex act Prodigy are to headline the second stage at this year's V Festival, joining main stage headliner Scissor Sisters and Franz Ferdinand. The event, which is in it 10th year, will be held at two venue - Hylands Park in Essex and Weston Park in Staffordshire on 20 and 21 August. Meanwhile, rock veteran New Order have joined the T in the Park line-up alongside Athlete and Green Day. The Manchester band will play on 9 July at Scotland's biggest festival. It will be their debut performance at the music event which is held over the weekend of 9 and 10 July in Balado near Kinross. Other band at the sold-out festival include Queens of the Stone Age, The Killers, Keane, The Streets and Foo Fighters. A month later at the V Festival, Prodigy will play at Weston Park on Saturday 20 August and Hylands Park on Sunday 21 August and the Chemical Brothers vice versa. It will be the Chemical Brothers' only UK festival performance of the year. V festival director Bob Angus said: "With the Prodigy and the Chemical Brothers now confirmed to headline the second stage, we are headed for a really stellar line-up. "We pride ourselves on putting on an unbeatable live music experience and V Festival 2005 will not disappoint." Tickets for the V festival go on sale on Friday 11 March.

Title: Petrol duties frozen, Brown says
Article: Chancellor Gordon Brown ha announced a freeze on fuel duty in his pre-budget speech to the Commons on Thursday. Mr Brown told the House that government policy is to raise fuel duty at least in line with inflation each year to fulfil environmental commitments. But this financial year, because of "volatility in the oil market", he said the duty would be frozen. During 2000 many motorist campaigned against the rise but environmentalist believe less duty mean more pollution. He said: "It is our policy that each year fuel duty should rise at least in line with inflation a we seek to meet our target for reducing polluting emmissions and fund our public services. "But this financial year because of the sustained volatility in the oil market I propose to match the freeze in car vehicle licence duty with a continuation on the freeze on the main road fuel duties." The RAC welcomed the news, calling it an "early Christmas present" for motorists. But the organisation urged driver to continue to shop around to get the best price for petrol. Environmental group Transport 2000 said the freeze sends the wrong message to motorists. "We are concerned that although Britain lead the world in rhetoric about climate change it often fails in practical action," said a spokesman. In 2000 the People's Fuel Lobby caused chaos by blocking road with slow-moving convoy after Mr Brown threatened to raise fuel taxes. The chancellor did not raise duty that year, but despite threat of more protest in 2003, he added 1.28p per litre.

Title: Net fingerprints combat attacks
Article: Eighty large net service firm have switched on software to spot and stop net attack automatically. The system creates digital fingerprint of ongoing incident that are sent to every network affected. Firms involved in the smart sensing system believe it will help trace attack back to their source. Data gathered will be passed to police to help build up intelligence about who is behind worm outbreak and denial of service attacks. Firms signing up for the sensing system include MCI, BT, Deutsche Telekom, Energis, NTT, Bell Canada and many others. The creation of the fingerprinting system ha been brokered by US firm Arbor Networks and signature of attack will be passed to anyone suffering under the weight of an attack. Increasingly computer criminal are using swarm of remotely controlled computer to carry out denial of service attack on websites, launch worm and relay spam around the net. "We have seen attack involving five and ten gigabyte of traffic," said Rob Pollard, sale director for Arbor Networks which is behind the fingerprinting system. "Attacks of that size cause collateral damage a they cross the internet before they get to their destination," he said. Once an attack is spotted and it signature defined the information will be passed back down the chain of network affected to help every unwitting player tackle the problem. Mr Pollard said Arbor wa not charging for the service and it would pas on fingerprint data to every network affected. "What we want to do is help net service firm communicate with each other and then push the attack further and further back around the world to their source," said Mr Pollard. Arbor Network's technology work by building up a detailed history of traffic on a network. It spot which computer or group of user regularly talk to each other and what type of traffic pass between machine or workgroups. Any anomaly to this usual pattern is spotted and flagged to network administrator who can take action if the traffic is due to a net-based attack of some kind. This type of close analysis ha become very useful a net attack are increasingly launched using several hundred or thousand different machines. Anyone looking at the traffic on a machine by machine basis would be unlikely to spot that they were all part of a concerted attack. "Attacks are getting more diffuse and more sophisticated," said Malcolm Seagrave, security expert at Energis. "In the last 12 month it started getting noticeable that criminal were taking to it and we've seen massive growth." He said that although informal system exist to pas on information about attacks, often commercial confidentiality got in the way of sharing enough information to properly combat attacks.

Title: Bryan twins keep US hopes alive
Article: The United States kept the Davis Cup final alive with victory in Saturday's double rubber, leaving Spain 2-1 ahead going into the final day. Masters Cup champion Mike and Bob Bryan thrashed Juan Carlos Ferrero and Tommy Robredo 6-0 6-3 6-2 in front of a partisan crowd in Seville. Victory would have given Spain the title but they were outclassed. In Sunday's reverse singles, Carlos Moya take on Andy Roddick before Rafael Nadal face Mardy Fish. "It feel good, but it's not going to be a good if we don't win two tomorrow," said Mike Bryan. "It feel good to give those guy another shot, and Spain ha to go to sleep on that." Bob Bryan added: "I'm really confident in Andy winning that first match, and then anything can happen." Spain coach Jordi Arrese chose to rest 18-year-old Nadal in the double after his epic single win over Roddick on Friday. He wa replaced by former world number one Ferrero, but the Spanish pair were out of their depth against one of the world's best double teams. The 26-year-old Bryan twin have won all four of their Davis Cup match this year. And they quickly silenced the huge crowd at the Olympic Stadium, racing through the opening set to love. The Spaniards then twice surrendered break of serve at the start of the second before the Bryans broke to go 5-3 ahead and served out. When Robredo dropped serve in the opening game of the third set the match wa all but over, and the unflappable Bryan brother powered on to an impressive win. Ferrero, who wa upset to be dropped for Friday's singles, hinted at further dissatisfaction after the defeat. "It wa a difficult game against the best double players," he said. "They have everything calculated and we had very little to do. "I wa a bit surprised that I wa named to play the double match because I hardly play doubles." Arrese said: "Juan Carlos hasn't played at all badly. He played the right way but the Bryans are great double players."

Title: Oscar host Rock to keep it clean
Article: Oscar host Chris Rock said he will steer clear of bad language when he front the award on 27 February. The comedian, who recently got into trouble for poking fun at the ceremony, is renowned for his heavy use of expletive during his stand-up routine. The live ceremony will be broadcast with a transmission delay on US network ABC to ensure swear word are removed. "I've been on TV and been funny not cursing," he said during an interview for CBS network's 60 Minutes show. "As far a content is concerned, I will talk about the movies. I'm not really worried about it. I'm sure ABC might be more worried about it than me," he added. The 40-year-old comedian caused a furore when he said in an interview with US magazine Entertainment Weekly recently that he hardly ever watched the Oscars and labelled award ceremony "idiotic". The show's producer defended Rock and confirmed that he would still be presenting the Oscar ceremony, saying his comment were "humorous digs". Meanwhile, the Academy ha announced that Oscar-nominated actress Natalie Portman will present an award at the ceremony. Portman, who ha been nominated for a best supporting actress gong for her role in Mike Nichols' Closer, join a growing list of star set to bestow an award at the ceremony including Dustin Hoffman, Drew Barrymore, Renee Zellweger and British-born actress Kate Winslet.

Title: BMW cash to fuel Mini production
Article: Less than four year after the new Mini wa launched, German car maker BMW ha announced Â£100m of new investment. Some 200 new job are to be created at the Oxford factory, including modernised machinery and a new body shell production building. The result of the investment could be to raise output to more than 200,000 car from 2007. The rise, from 189,000 last year, is a response to rapidly-rising demand and could help wipe out waiting lists. Before Wednesday's announcement, BMW had invested some Â£280m in Mini production. Since it launch during summer 2001, the new Mini ha gone from strength to strength. Last year, almost one in six car sold by the BMW group wa a Mini. The company admits that the success of the brand came despite scepticism from many in the industry. "Our decision to produce a new Mini wa not received well right away," said Norbert Reithofer, a member of the BMW management board. Initially, BMW said it would produce 100,000 Mini model a year at it vast Cowley factory on the outskirt of Oxford, but the target wa quickly reached, then raised, time and time again. Not everyone is convinced that the boom can continue. "The risk is that after they've invested massively in the brand, demand taper off like it did with the new VW Beetle," said Brad Wernle, from Automotive News Europe. The price of the car ha also gone up. When it wa launched, the cheapest Mini cost just more than Â£10,000. These days, buyer will have to fork out almost Â£11,500 to own a new Mini One, or even more for the Cooper S which cost up to Â£17,730. The Mini Convertible, which wa launched last spring, cost up to Â£15,690 for the top model, and there is even a waiting list. Second-hand Minis are not cheap either. A Mini One bought when the model wa launched should still fetch at least Â£8,000 for the cheapest model, while a used Cooper S is likely to be priced from Â£12,556, according to the-car buying website Parker's. The consumers' association Which operates with slightly different numbers, yet it confirms that the Mini Cooper 1.6 depreciates slower than any other car, other than the Mercedes Benz C180 SE and the BMW 1 Series 116i SE. The Cowley factory, which initially seemed far too large a production plant for just 100,000 Minis, is increasingly being put to good use. There are plan to tear down old building and build new one and there are rumour that a new paint shop could be included in the plans. BMW's Mini adventure ha made good much of what went wrong during it stewardship of the UK car maker Rover which it sold for Â£10 five year ago to the Phoenix consortium. In 1999, when BMW still owned Rover, the Oxford factory wa producing the award-winning Rover 75. During that year, 3,500 people produced 56,000 cars. Last year, in the same factory, almost four time a many vehicle were produced by just 4,500 Mini-workers. The Mini factory's current output is equally impressive when compared with the main Rover factory in Longbridge, which in 1999 produced 180,000 Rover cars. Last year, MG Rover, which employ more than 6,000 people, produced just 110,000 cars, though it hope to land a deal with Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation (SAIC) that could help double the number of car produced at Longbridge. Indeed, Mini is not only producing more car than MG Rover does; it remains ahead even when the current sale of Land Rovers and Range Rovers (which are made by the former Rover unit that BMW sold to Ford) are taken into account.

Title: Microsoft takes on desktop search
Article: Microsoft ha entered the desktop search fray, releasing a test version of it tool to find documents, e-mail and other file on a PC hard drive. The beta program only work on PCs running Windows XP or Windows 2000. The desktop search market is becoming increasingly crowded with firm touting program that help people find files. Search giant Google launched it desktop search tool in October, while Yahoo is planning to release similar software in January. "Our ambition for search is to provide the ultimate information tool that can find anything you're looking for," said Yusuf Mehdi, corporate vice president at Microsoft's MSN internet division. Microsoft's program can be used a a toolbar on the Windows desktop, the Internet Explorer browser and within the Outlook e-mail program. The software giant is coming late to the desktop search arena, competing with a large number of rivals. Google ha already released a desktop tool. Yahoo is planning to get into the game in January and AOL is expected to offer desktop searching early next year. Small firm such a Blinkx, Copernic, Enfish X1 Technologies and X-Friend offer tool that catalogue the huge amount of information that people increasingly store on their desktop or home computer. Apple will release a similar search system for it computer called Spotlight that is due to be released with the Tiger operating system.

Title: BT offers equal access to rivals
Article: BT ha moved to pre-empt a possible break-up of it business by offering to cut wholesale broadband price and open it network to rivals. The move come after telecom regulator Ofcom said in November that the firm must offer competitor "real equality of access to it phone lines". At the time, Ofcom offered BT the choice of change or splitting into two. Ofcom is carrying out a strategic review aimed at promoting greater competition in the UK telecom sector. BT's competitor have frequently accused it of misusing it status a the former telecom monopoly and controller of access to many customer to favour it own retail arm. This latest submission wa delivered to the watchdog ahead of a deadline for the second phase of it review. "Central to the proposal are plan by BT to offer operator lower wholesale prices, faster broadband service and transparent, highly-regulated access to BT's local network," the former monopoly said in a statement. "The United Kingdom ha the opportunity to create the most exciting and innovative telecom market in the world," BT chief executive Ben Verwaayen said. "BT ha a critical role to play, and today we are making a set of far-reaching proposal towards that framework," he said. BT want lighter regulation in exchange for the changes, a well a the removal of the break-up threat. The group is to set up a new Access Services division - with a separate board which would include independent member - to ensure equal access for rival to the "local loop", the copper wire that run between telephone exchange and households. The company also unveiled plan to cut the wholesale price of it most popular broadband product by about 8% from April in area of high customer demand. It added that it plan to invest Â£10bn in the next five year to create a "21st Century network". To meet the growing demand for greater bandwidth, BT said it would begin trial in April with a view to launching higher-speed service nationally from the autumn. Telecom analyst Ovum welcomed the move, saying BT had "given a lot of ground". "The big question now is whether the industry, and particularly Ofcom feel BT's proposal go far enough ...Now the real negotiation begins," director of telecom research Tony Lavender said. Internet service provider (ISP) Plus.net also backed the proposal saying "we will be entirely happy if Ofcom accepts them". "BT ha been challenged to play fair and it plan will introduce a level playing field. The scenario now is how well people execute their business plan a a service provider," chief executive Lee Strafford said. Chris Panayis, managing director of ISP Freedom2surf said that it would make the situation clearer for business. "I think it's the first productive thing we've had from BT," he said. AOL backed the price cut but said regulation wa still needed to ensure a level playing field. "This is a reminder to Ofcom that a long a BT can change the dynamic of the whole broadband market at will, the process of opening up the UK's local telephone network to infrastructure investment and competition remains fragile," a spokesman said. "Ofcom need to return to regulation of the wholesale broadband service [IPStream] and provide more robust rule for local loop unbundling if consumer are to see the benefit of increased competition and infrastructure investment." More than 100 telecom firms, consumer group and other interested party are expected to make submission to the regulator during this consultation phase. Ofcom is expected to spend the next few week examining the proposal before making an announcement within the next few months.

Title: Clijsters hope on Aussie Open
Article: Kim Clijsters ha denied report that she ha pulled out of January's Australian Open because of her persistent wrist injury. Open chief Paul McNamee had said: "Kim's wrist obviously isn't going to be rehabilitated." But her spokesman insisted she had simply delayed submitting her entry. "The doctor are assessing her injury on a weekly basis and if there is no risk she could play. But if there's the least risk she will stay away." Despite being absent from the WTA entry list for the tournament, which begin on 17 January, Clijsters would be certain to get a wild card if she requested one. Clijsters is still ranked 22nd in the world despite only playing a handful of match last season. The Belgian had an operation on her left wrist early in the season but injured it again on her return to the tour. Meanwhile, Jelena Dokic, who used to compete for Australia, ha opted out of the first Grand Slam of the season. Dokic ha not played in the Australian Open since 2001 when she lost in the first round. But the 21-year-old would have had to rely on a wild card next season because her ranking ha tumbled to 127th. Four-time champion Monica Seles, who ha not played since last year's French Open, is another absentee because of an injured left foot.

Title: HealthSouth ex-boss goes on trial
Article: The former head of US medical service firm HealthSouth overstated earnings and asset to boost the company's share price, it wa claimed in court. Richard Scrushy, 52, is accused of "directing" a $2.7bn (Â£1.4bn) accounting fraud at the company he co-founded in Alabama in 1984. Prosecutors said he wa motivated by wealth - spending about $200m between 1996 and 2002 while earning much less. Defence lawyer said Mr Scrushy had been deceived by other executives. Several former HealthSouth employee have already pleaded guilty to fraud and are expected to give evidence against Mr Scrushy. "We will present evidence that Richard Scrushy knew about the conspiracy, that he participated in the conspiracy and that he profited," prosecutor Alice Martin told the court. Mr Scrushy is the first chief executive to be tried for breaching the Sarbanes Oxley Act - a law introduced in the wake of the Enron and WorldCom fraud which obliges corporate boss to vouch for the accuracy of their companies' results. Among the charge he face are conspiracy to commit fraud, filing false statement and money laundering. After federal agent raided HealthSouth's office in March 2003, the company said none of it past financial statement could be relied on. The firm ha since reorganised it board and management team and currently operates about 1,400 health clinics.

Title: 'Fido' to be taken off vote lists
Article: The risk of pet and child being given vote could be cut by changing how people register to vote, the UK election watchdog ha said. Those are some of the mistake found under the current system, where one person in each household applies for voting form for the other occupants. The Electoral Commission say enabling people to register individually could cut some error and combat fraud. Voters need to register by 11 March if the next poll is on 5 May a expected. But any individual registration scheme would not be introduced in Britain before that general election. The proposed scheme would mean voter using individual "identifiers" when they vote - such a their own voting number, date of birth and signature. The Electoral Commission say having voter register individually rather than the head of household do it for them fit better with human right laws. Chairman Sam Younger told MPs on Tuesday care wa needed to ensure that people were not lost off the register in the process - which happened when Northern Ireland switched to a similar system. There have been rare case when household pet have been put on the electoral roll, the MPs heard. And some people have registered all their family, regardless of their age - birth date are not included on the form so election officer cannot easily check. Non-British citizen who are not entitled to vote have also been registered in some cases. Mr Younger said there wa anecdotal evidence of inaccuracy in the register, the vast majority of which were caused by genuine mistakes. He argued local council could look harder at promoting targeted campaign at "hard to reach" voters, for example. Some authority already run such programme but in others councillor worry about the party political impact of encouraging particular area to turn out. Mr Younger said using the Royal Mail's postal redirection service had already helped election officer retrace about 50,000 voters. He argued individual registration would also increase security for postal ballot and other new way of voting. There have been fear there are too few check to ensure current postal vote are cast by the person on the voting form. He said it might also help register student in hall of residences, where the hall warden often ha to do the job for everybody. The MPs on the Office of the Deputy Prime Minister and Constitutional Affairs select committee pressed Mr Younger on how to avoid losing voter in any changeover. He said the Northern Ireland example illustrated real difficulty to be confronted. Currently, British voter have to re-register to vote every year or face being removed from the electoral roll if they fail to do so two year running. Mr Younger suggested the re-registration could happen less frequently but argued effort were needed to check the electoral roll were up-to-date.

Title: US interest rates increased to 2%
Article: US interest rate are to rise for the fourth time in five months, in a widely anticipated move. The Federal Reserve ha raised it key federal fund rate by a quarter percentage point to 2% in light of mounting evidence that the US economy is regaining steam. US company created twice a many job a expected in October while export hit record level in September. Analysts said a clear-cut victory for President Bush in last week's election paved the way for a rise. Another rise could be in store for December, some economist warned. The Fed's Open Market Committee - which set interest rate policy in the US - voted unanimously in favour of a quarter point rise. The Fed ha been gradually easing rate up since the summer, with quarter percentage point rise in June, August and September. The Central Bank ha been acting to restrain inflationary pressure while being careful not to obstruct economic growth. The Fed did not rule out raising rate once again in December but noted that any future increase would take place at a "measured" pace. In a statement, the Fed said that long-term inflation pressure remained "well contained" while the US economy appeared to be "growing at a moderate pace despite the rise in energy prices". Financial analyst broadly welcomed the Fed's move and share traded largely flat. The Dow Jones Industrial average closed down 0.89 points, or 0.01%, at 10,385.48. Recent evidence ha pointed to an upturn in the US economy. US firm created 337,000 job last month, twice the amount expected, while export reached record level in September. The economy grew 3.7% in the third quarter, slower than forecast, but an improvement on the 3.3% growth seen in the second quarter. Analysts claimed the Fed's assessment of future economic growth wa a positive one but stressed that the jury wa still out on the prospect of a further rise in December. "Let's wait until we see how growth and employment bear up under the fourth quarter's energy price drag before concluding that the Fed ha more work to do in 2005," said Avery Shenfeld, senior economist at CIBC World Markets. "I think the Federal Reserve doe not want to rock the boat and is using a gradual approach in raising the interest rate," said Sung Won Sohn, chief US economist for Wells Fargo Bank. "The economy is doing a bit better right now but there are still some concern about geopolitics, employment and the price of oil," he added. The further rise in US rate is unlikely to have a direct bearing on UK monetary policy. The Bank of England (BoE) ha kept interest rate on hold at 4.75% for the past three months, leading some commentator to argue that rate may have peaked. In a report published on Wednesday, the Bank said that with rate at their current level, inflation would rise to it 2% target within two years. However, BoE governor Mervyn King warned only last month that the era of consistently low inflation and low unemployment may be coming to an end.

Title: Bank holds interest rate at 4.75%
Article: The Bank of England ha left interest rate on hold again at 4.75%, in a widely-predicted move. Rates went up five time from November 2003 - a the bank sought to cool the housing market and consumer debt - but have remained unchanged since August. Recent data ha indicated a slowdown in manufacturing and consumer spending, a well a in mortgage approvals. And retail sale disappointed over Christmas, with analyst putting the drop down to less consumer confidence. Rising interest rate and the accompanying slowdown in the housing market have knocked consumers' optimism, causing a sharp fall in demand for expensive goods, according to a report earlier this week from the British Retail Consortium. The BRC said Britain's retailer had endured their worst Christmas in a decade. "Today's no change decision is correct," said David Frost, Director General of the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC). "But, if there are clear sign that the economy slows, the MPC should be ready to take quick corrective action and cut rates. "Dismal report from the retail trade about Christmas sale are worrying, if they indicate a more general weakening in consumer spending." Mr Frost added: "The housing market outlook remains highly uncertain. "It is widely accepted that, if house price start falling more sharply, the risk facing the economy will worsen considerably." CBI chief economist Ian McCafferty said the economy had "slowed in recent month in response to rate rises" but that it wa difficult to gauge from the Christmas period the likely pace of activity through the summer. "The Bank is having to juggle the emergence of inflationary pressures, driven by a tight labour market and buoyant commodity prices, against the risk of an over-abrupt slowdown in consumer activity," he said. "Interest rate are likely to remain on hold for some time." On Thursday there wa more gloomy news on the manufacturing front, a the Office for National (ONS) statistic revealed British manufacturing output unexpectedly fell in November - for the fifth month in the past six. The ONS said manufacturing output dropped 0.1% in November, matching a similar unrevised fall in October and confounding economists' expectation of a 0.3% rise. Manufacturers' organisation, the EEF, said it expected the hold in interest rate to continue in the near future. It also said there wa evidence that manufacturers' confidence may be waning a the outlook for the world economy becomes more uncertain. "So far the evidence suggests that last year's rate increase have helped to rebalance the economy without damaging the recovery in manufacturing," said EEF chief economist, Steve Radley. "However, should the business outlook start to deteriorate, the Bank should stand ready to cut rates." Some economist have predicted rate will drop later in the year, although others feel the Bank may still think there is a need for a rise to 5% before that happens. The Bank remains concerned about the long-term risk posed by personal debt - which is rising at 15% a year - if economic condition worsen.

Title: MG Rover China tie-up 'delayed'
Article: MG Rover's proposed tie-up with China's top carmaker ha been delayed due to concern by Chinese regulators, according to the Financial Times. The paper said Chinese official had been irritated by Rover's disclosure of it talk with Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp in October. The proposed deal wa seen a crucial to safeguarding the future of Rover's Longbridge plant in the West Midlands. However, there are growing fear that the deal could result in job losses. The Observer reported on Sunday that nearly half the workforce at Longbridge could be under threat if the deal go ahead. Shanghai Automotive's proposed Â£1bn investment in Rover is awaiting approval by it owner, the Shanghai city government and by the National Development and Reform Commission, which oversees foreign investment by Chinese firms. According to the FT, the regulator ha been annoyed by Rover's decision to talk publicly about the deal and the intense speculation which ha ensued about what it will mean for Rover's future. As a result, hope that approval of the deal may be fast-tracked have disappeared, the paper said. There ha been continued speculation about the viability of Rover's Longbridge plant because of falling sale and unfashionable models. According to the Observer, 3,000 job - out of a total workforce of 6,500 - could be lost if the deal go ahead. The paper said that Chinese official believe cutback will be required to keep the MG Rover's cost in line with revenues. It also said that the production of new model through the joint venture would take at least eighteen months. Neither Rover nor Shanghai Automotive commented on the reports.

Title: Asia shares defy post-quake gloom
Article: Indonesian, Indian and Hong Kong stock market reached record highs. Investors seemed to feel that some of the worst-affected area were so under-developed that the tragedy would have little impact on Asia's listed firms. "Obviously with a lot of loss of life, a lot of time is needed to clean up the mess, bury the people and find the missing," said ABN Amro's Eddie Wong. "[But] it's not necessarily a really big thing in the economic sense." India's Bombay Stock Exchange inched slightly above it previous record close on Wednesday. Expectations of strong corporate earnings in 2005 drove the Indonesian stock exchange in Jakarta to a record high on Wednesday. In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index may be benefiting in part from the potential for it listed property company to gain from rebuilding contract in the tsunami-affected region of South East Asia. In Sri Lanka, some economist have said that a much a 1% of annual growth may be lost. Sri Lanka's stock market ha fallen about 5% since the weekend, but it is still 40% higher than at the start of 2004. Thailand may lose 30bn baht (Â£398m; $768m) in earnings from tourism over the next three months, according to tourism minister Sontaya Kunplome. In the affected provinces, he expects the loss of tourism revenue to be offset by government reconstruction spending. Thailand intends to spend a similar sum - around 30bn baht - on the rebuilding work. "It will take until the fourth quarter of next year before tourist visitor in Phuket and five other province return to their normal level," said Naris Chaiyasoot, director general at the ministry's fiscal policy office. In the Maldives the cost of reconstruction could wipe out economic growth, according to a government spokesman. "Our nation is in peril here," said Ahmed Shaheed, the chief government spokesman. He estimated the economic cost of the disaster at hundred of million of dollars. The Maldives ha gross domestic product of $660m. "It won't be surprising if the cost exceeds our GDP," he said. "In the last few years, we made great progress in our standard of living - the United Nations recognised this. Now we see this can disappear in a few days, a few minutes." Shaheed noted that investment in a single tourist resort - the economic mainstay - could run to $40m. Between 10 and 12 of the 80-odd resort have been severely damaged, and a similar number have suffered significant damage. However, many experts, including the World Bank, have pointed out that it is still difficult to assess the magnitude of the disaster and it likely economic impact. In part, this is because of it scale, and because delivering aid and recovering the dead remain priorities. "Calculators will have to wait," said an IMF official in a briefing on Wednesday. "The financial and world community will be turning toward reconstruction effort and at that point people will begin to have a sense of the financial impact."

Title: Kuznetsova 'failed a drugs test'
Article: US Open champion Svetlana Kuznetsova ha tested positive for a banned drug, according to Belgian authorities. Belgian sport minister Claude Eerdekens said that the Russian world number five tested positive for the stimulant ephedrine on 19 December. Kuznetsova wa playing in an exhibition event in Charleroi at the time. Eerdekens said: "There is a problem. Ephedrine wa discovered. She remains innocent until proved guilty. She can ask for it to be tested again." The situation remains unclear a the tournament wa not commissioned by the World Anti-Doping Agency (Wada), the International Tennis Federation (ITF) or the Women's Tennis Accosiation (WTA). The test wa carried out by regional Belgian authority and Kuznetsova ha not yet been able to have a B sample tested. Speaking at the Australian Open on Monday, before Eerdekens identified her, Kuznetsova said: "I'm not worried. I'm not using anything to push myself. "I have not been notified of any positive test, and I think it is unfair that it's come out the way it did." Eerdekens said that confirmation of the finding wa sent last Friday to the player's address in Spain, a well a to the Belgian prosecutors' office and the Belgian and Russian tennis federations. He conceded Kuznetsova might have taken a medicine which contained the banned substance. "We have simply stated a fact," he said. "It is for the federation concerned to impose the disciplinary measure after a procedure that respect the defence. "Either the ephedrine wa taken to improve her performance or it is because she took some medicine legitimately to cure an infection." However, Kuznetsova's naming wa condemned by Russian tennis chief Shamil Tarpishchev. "First of all, this Belgian sport minister ha broken every ethical rule in the book by naming a player without any proof of wrongdoing, without any basic evidence," Tarpishchev said. "We all know the basic principle in doping cases. If there is a positive sample, then they should notify the International Tennis Federation (ITF) a well a the national federation within three days," he said. "This is not the case here. As of today we have not received any statement from the doping officials, nor did the ITF. "Today I called the ITF headquarters and they told me they know nothing about it. "If WADA (the World Anti-Doping Agency) wa behind the testing, then we would also have known something by now. "Otherwise, all these look to me a pure fiction and fabrication of the facts."

Title: Economy 'stronger than forecast'
Article: The UK economy probably grew at a faster rate in the third quarter than the 0.4% reported, according to Bank of England deputy governor Rachel Lomax. Private sector business survey suggest a stronger economy than official estimates, Ms Lomax said. Other survey collectively show a rapid slowdown in UK house price growth, she pointed out. This mean that despite a strong economic growth, base rate will probably stay on hold at 4.75%. Official data come from the Office for National Statistics (ONS). Though reliable, ONS data take longer to publish, so now the BoE is calling for faster delivery of data so it can make more effective policy decisions. "Recent work by the Bank ha shown that private sector survey add value, even when preliminary ONS estimate are available," Ms Lomax said in a speech to the North Wales Business Club. The ONS is due to publish it second estimate of third quarter growth on Friday. "The MPC judge that overall growth wa a little higher in the third quarter than the official data currently indicate," Ms Lomax said. The Bank said successful monetary policy depends on having good information. Rachel Lomax cited the late 1980s a an example of a time when weak economic figure were published, but substantially revised upwards year later. "The statistical fog surrounding the true state of the economy ha proved a particularly potent breeding ground for policy error in the past," she said. Improving the quality of national statistic is the single the best way of making sure the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) make the right decisions, she said. The Bank of England is working in tandem with the ONS to improve the quality and speed of delivery of data. Her remark follow criticism from the House of Lords Economic Affairs Committee, which said the MPC had held interest rate too high given that inflation wa way below the 2% target. A slowdown in the housing market and this year's surge in oil price ha made economic forecasting all the more tricky, leading to a more uncertain outlook. "This year rising oil price and a significant slowdown in the housing market have awoken bad memory of the 1970s and 1980s," Ms Lomax said. "The MPC will be doing well if it can achieve the same stability over the next decade a we have enjoyed over the past 10 years." Decisions on interest rate are made after the MPC gather together the range of indicator available every month. The clearest signal come when all indicator are pointing the same direction, Ms Lomax intimated. "In economic assessment, there is safety in numbers."

Title: Parties warned over 'grey vote'
Article: Political party cannot afford to take older UK voter for granted in the coming election, say Age Concern. A survey for the charity suggests 69% of over-55s say they always vote in a general election compared with just 17% of 18 to 24 year olds. Charity bos Gordon Lishman said if a "decisive blow" wa struck at the election it would be by older voter who could be relied on to turn out. A total of 3,028 adult aged 18 or over were interviewed for the study. Mr Lishman urged the next government to boost state pension. He also called for measure to combat ageism and build effective public service to "support u all in an ageing society". "Older people want to see manifesto commitment that will make a difference to their lives," Mr Lishman said. "Political party must wake up to the fact that unless they address the demand and concern of older people they will not keep or attract their vote." In the survey carried out by ICM Research, 14% of people aged between 18 and 34 said they never voted in general elections. Among the over-65s, 70% said they would be certain to vote in an immediate election, compared with 39% of people under 55. Age Concern say the over-55s are "united around" key area of policy they want the government to focus on. For 57%, pension and the NHS were key issues, while the economy wa important for a third, and tax wa a crucial area for 25%. The report wa welcomed by Conservative shadow pension secretary David Willetts. "The pensioners' voice must certainly be heard in the next election a they have never fitted into Blair's cool Britannia," he said. "Labour's continued refusal to admit the true extent of the pension crisis will be one of the monumental failure of this government." He pointed to Tory plan to increase the basic state pension to reduce mean testing, strengthen company pension and encourage savings. A Liberal Democrat spokesman said the party took the issue raised in the report very seriously. He highlighted the party's promise to raise the basic state pension, provide free long-term care for the elderly and replace council tax, seen a a particular problem for pensioner on fixed incomes. Labour ha said it want to use saving reform to Incapacity Benefit to improve the basic state pension and ha set up a review of the council tax system.

Title: Anelka 'eyes Man City departure'
Article: Striker Nicolas Anelka reportedly want to leave Manchester City in search of Champions League football. Anelka, 25, is in talk over a contract extension beyond 2007 with City but is believed to fear his career will go stale if he stay at the club. The News of the World report that Anelka told a French magazine: "I either decide to win title or to have an easy life. "I think I will always choose football, if a great club make me an offer." He added: "To win title you need player who have the capability of doing so. If we stagnate between eighth and 15th place it's impossible to progress. "If I am going to score goal and not win, there is a risk it is going to create a feeling of being fed up." Anelka ha earned a reputation for being a difficult character to handle after spell at Arsenal, Real Madrid and Paris St Germain and he feel that is now coming back to haunt him. "I am in talk to sign an extension to my contract," he said. "I am well here but the sporting aspect also come into account. "Playing for eighth place is good but I miss the Champions League. "I won it with Real Madrid in 2000 and I need to be playing in it - and I should be playing in it. "I'm not in it because of thing that have happened in the past and had nothing to do with football. "But I don't blame anyone. It's a bit my fault."
