Title: Kenyan school turns to handhelds
Article: At the Mbita Point primary school in western Kenya student click away at a handheld computer with a stylus. They are doing exercise in their school textbook which have been digitised. It is a pilot project run by EduVision, which is looking at way to use low cost computer system to get up-to-date information to student who are currently stuck with ancient textbooks. Matthew Herren from EduVision told the BBC programme Go Digital how the non-governmental organisation us a combination of satellite radio and handheld computer called E-slates. "The E-slates connect via a wireless connection to a base station in the school. This in turn is connected to a satellite radio receiver. The data is transmitted alongside audio signals." The base station process the information from the satellite transmission and turn it into a form that can be read by the handheld E-slates. "It downloads from the satellite and every day process the stream, sort through content for the material destined for the user connected to it. It also store this on it hard disc." The system is cheaper than installing and maintaining an internet connection and conventional computer network. But Mr Herren say there are both pro and con to the project. "It's very simple to set up, just a satellite antenna on the roof of the school, but it's also a one-way connection, so getting feedback or specific request from end user is difficult." The project is still at the pilot stage and EduVision staff are on the ground to attend to teething problem with the Linux-based system. "The content is divided into visual information, textual information and questions. Users can scroll through these section independently of each other." EduVision is planning to include audio and video file a the system develops and add more content. Mr Herren say this would vastly increase the opportunity available to the students. He is currently in negotiation to take advantage of a project being organised by search site Google to digitise some of the world's largest university libraries. "All book in the public domain, something like 15 million, could be put on the base station a we manufacture them. Then every rural school in Africa would have access to the same library a the student in Oxford and Harvard" Currently the project is operating in an area where there is main electricity. But Mr Herren say EduVision already ha plan to extend it to more remote regions. "We plan to put a solar panel at the school with the base station, have the E-slates charge during the day when the child are in school, then they can take them home at night and continue working." Maciej Sundra, who designed the user interface for the E-slates, say the project's ultimate goal is levelling access to knowledge around the world. "Why in this age when most people do most research using the internet are student still using textbooks? The fact that we are doing this in a rural developing country is very exciting - a they need it most."

Title: Stock market eyes Japan recovery
Article: Japanese share have ended the year at their highest level since 13 July amidst hope of an economic recovery during 2005. The Nikkei index of leading share gained 7.6% during the year to close at 11,488.76 points. In 2005 it "will rise toward 13,000", predicted Morgan Stanley equity strategist Naoki Kamiyama. The optimism in the financial market contrast sharply with pessimism in the Japanese business community. Earlier this month, the quarterly Tankan survey of Japanese manufacturer found that business confidence had weakened for the first time since March 2003. Slower economic growth, rising oil prices, a stronger yen and weaker export were blamed for the fall in confidence. Despite this, trader expect strength in the global economy to benefit Japan, which ha been close to sliding into recession in recent months. Structural reform within Japan and an anticipated end to the banking sector's bad debt problem should also help, they say.

Title: Famed music director Viotti dies
Article: Conductor Marcello Viotti, director of Venice's famous La Fenice Theatre, ha died in Germany at 50. Viotti, director of La Fenice since 2002, conducted at renowned opera house worldwide including Milan's La Scala and the Vienna State Opera. His time at La Fenice coincided with it reopening in 2003 after it wa destroyed by fire in 1996. He fell into a coma after suffering a stroke during rehearsal for Jules Massenet's Manon last week. He conducted some of the best orchestra in the world including the Berlin Philharmonic and the English Chamber Orchestra. Viotti wa born in Switzerland and studied the piano, cello and singing at the Lausanne Conservatory. His career breakthrough came in 1982 when he won first prize at the Gino Marinuzzi conducting competition in Italy. Viotti established himself a chief conductor of the Turin Opera and went on to become chief conductor of Munich's Radio Orchestra. At La Fenice Viotti wa widely acclaimed for his production of the French composer Massenet's Thais and some of his other production included Giuseppe Verdi's La Traviata and Richard Strauss's Ariadne auf Naxos. The last opera he directed at La Fenice wa Massenet's Le Roi de Lahore. Viotti's debut at the New York's Metropolitan Opera came in 2000 with Giacomo Puccini's Madame Butterfly, followed by La Boheme, La Traviata and Fromental Halevy's La Juive. Giampaolo Vianello, superintendent of the Fenice Theatre Foundation, said: "I am filled with extreme sadness because, other than a great artist, he is missed a a friend - a main character in the latest joyous times, during the rebirth of our theatre." Viotti's last public performance wa on 5 February when he conducted Vincenzo Bellini's Norma at the Vienna State Opera.

Title: Vera Drake scoops film award
Article: Oscar hopeful Mike Leigh and Imelda Staunton were both winner at the 2004 Evening Standard British Film Awards. Vera Drake - Leigh's 1950s drama about a backstreet abortionist - wa named best film and Staunton, who played the title role, wa named best actress. Other winner included Paddy Considine, who wa crowned best actor for his role in Dead Man's Shoes. Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason wa named Evening Standard Readers' Film of 2004 at the central London ceremony. Leigh wa presented with his winner's statuette by Timothy Spall and Staunton's award wa announced by Patrick Stewart, during the glittering ceremony at The Savoy on Sunday night. Evening Standard film critic Derek Malcolm said: "He [Leigh] ha never made a film that is better controlled and technically more secure... If this isn't one of the film of the year, I don't know what is." The Alexander Walker Special Award - which honour those who have made a supreme contribution to British film - went to Tim Bevan and Eric Fellner, the co-chairmen of Working Title films. The production company is behind film such a My Beautiful Laundrette, Billy Elliot, About A Boy, Shaun of The Dead and Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason. Simon Pegg, who star in and co-wrote Shaun of the Dead, won the 2004 Peter Sellers Award For Comedy. Other winner included Emily Blunt and Nathalie Press who were jointly named ITV London Most Promising Newcomer Award for their performance in Pawel Pawlikowski's rites-of-passage story, My Summer of Love. Pawlikowski won the best screenplay statuette, while Roger Deakins won the Technical Achievement Award for his cinematography on The Village and The Ladykillers. Guests at the ceremony included Dame Judi Dench, Kim Cattrall, Charles Dance, Bill Nighy and Colin Firth. The awards, which were hosted by Jack Dee, are to be screened on ITV London on Tuesday at 2300 GMT.

Title: Chelsea sack Mutu
Article: Chelsea have sacked Adrian Mutu after he failed a drug test. The 25-year-old tested positive for a banned substance - which he later denied wa cocaine - in October. Chelsea have decided to write off a possible transfer fee for Mutu, a £15.8m signing from Parma last season, who may face a two-year suspension. A statement from Chelsea explaining the decision read:"We want to make clear that Chelsea ha a zero tolerance policy towards drugs." Mutu scored six goal in his first five game after arriving at Stamford Bridge but his form went into decline and he wa frozen out by coach Jose Mourinho. Chelsea's statement added: "This applies to both performance-enhancing drug or so-called 'recreational' drugs. They have no place at our club or in sport. "In coming to a decision on this case, Chelsea believed the club's social responsibility to it fans, players, employee and other stakeholder in football regarding drug wa more important than the major financial consideration to the company. "Any player who take drug breach his contract with the club a well a Football Association rules. "The club totally support the FA in strong action on all drug cases." Fifa's disciplinary code stipulates that a first doping offence should be followed by a six-month ban. And the sport's world governing body ha re-iterated their stance over Mutu's failed drug test, maintaining it is a matter for the domestic sporting authorities. "Fifa is not in a position to make any comment on the matter until the English FA have informed u of their disciplinary decision and the relevant information associated with it," said a Fifa spokesman. Chelsea's move won backing from drug-testing expert Michelle Verroken. Verroken, a former director of drug-free sport for UK Sport, insists the Blues were right to sack Mutu and have enhanced their reputation by doing so. "Chelsea are saying quite clearly to the rest of their player and their fan that this is a situation they are not prepared to tolerate. "It wa a very difficult decision for them and an expensive decision for them but the term of his contract were breached and it wa the only decision they could make. "It is a very clear stance by Chelsea and it ha given a strong boost to the reputation of the club." It emerged that Mutu had failed a drug test on October 18 and, although it wa initially reported that the banned substance in question wa cocaine. The Romanian international later suggested it wa a substance designed to enhance sexual performance. The Football Association ha yet to act on Mutu's failed drug test and refuse to discus his case.

Title: Laporte tinkers with team
Article: France coach Bernard Laporte ha made four change to the starting line-up that beat England for Saturday's Six Nations clash with Wales. He opted for Yannick Nyanga in the back row instead of Grand Slam winner Imanol Harinordoquy, who is back in the squad. Other change see Julien Laharrague win his first cap at full-back, Aurelien Rougerie return after injury on the wing and Yannick Jauzion in at centre. But Laporte ha resisted fan pressure to start Frederic Michalak at fly-half. The dependable Yann Delaigue keep the number 10 jersey, despite clamour for the flair of Michalak. The 26-year-old Laharrague get his chance despite playing on the wing for his club Brive. "We are launching him into the great international level," said team manager Jo Maso. "He is young and this is a great opportunity for u and above all for him. "There are 25 match left before the World Cup so we must see a many player a possible. The competition is very high and open." Jauzion, France's player of the year in 2004, would probably have played in the first two match instead of the South African-born Liebeneberg had he been fit. The Stade Toulousain star win his 23rd cap and is reunited with Damien Traille, with whom he forged an effective midfield in 2004. "The return of Jauzion is going to be a plus for us," said Laporte. "We are going to test him at an international level." Title: Hantuchova in Dubai last eight
Article: Daniela Hantuchova moved into the quarter-finals of the Dubai Open, after beating Elene Likhotseva of Russia 7-5 6-4, and now face Serena Williams. Australian Open champion Williams survived an early scare to beat Russia's Elena Bovina 1-6 6-1 6-4. World number one Lindsay Davenport and Anastasia Myskina also progressed. Davenport defeated China's Jie Zheng 6-2 7-5, while French Open champion Myskina sailed through after her opponent Marion Bartoli retired hurt. American Davenport will now face fellow former Wimbledon champion, Conchita Martinez of Spain, who ousted seventh-seeded Nathalie Dechy of France 6-1 6-2. Myskina will face eighth-seed Patty Schnyder from Switzerland, who defeated China's Li Na 6-3 7-6 (10-8). The other quarter final pit wild card Sania Mirza of India against Jelena Jankovic of Serbia and Montenegro, who both won on Tuesday. Before her meeting with Martinez, Davenport belief there is some room for improvement in her game. "I started well and finished well, but played some so-so game in the middle," she said. Williams wa also far from content. "I don't know what I wa doing there," she said. "It wa really windy and I hadn't played in the wind. All my shot were going out of here." But Hantuchova is in upbeat mood ahead of her clash with the younger Williams sister, who wa handed a first-round bye. "I feel I have an advantage (over Serena) because I have already played two match on these courts," she said. "It is a difficult court to play on. Very fast and sometimes you feel you have no control over the ball."

Title: Ban on hunting comes into force
Article: Fox hunting with dog is now illegal in England and Wales after a ban on the activity came into force overnight. The law face a stiff test this weekend, with the Countryside Alliance saying many hunt will be out in force. Chief police officer spokesman Nigel Yeo said he expected most people would obey the law - by drag hunting or chasing fox then shooting them. He said police would challenge the "one of two isolated hunts" which are threatening to break the law. But Simon Hart of the Countryside Alliance ha questioned how police will ensure there are no violations. "The definition of legal and illegal hunting are so blurred that the police are being asked to make impossible judgements. "You can hunt a rat, but not a mouse, a rabbit but not a hare, an artificial scent, but not a real one," he said. The Attorney General, Lord Goldsmith, ha so far issued no instruction to police on how they should deal with hunter who violate the law. He said he will consult the Director of Public Prosecutions and the police "in the near future" to decide what measure to take with regard to hunting prosecutions. He ha rejected a "blanket policy" of not enforcing the ban until the House of Lords ha considered it legality. John Cooper, a barrister and chairman of the League Against Cruel Sports, said the anti-hunting lobby expects the authority to prosecute wherever there is clear evidence of illegal hunting practices. He said police had "acknowledged their duty to investigate allegation of hunting offences". The Beaufort Hunt had one pack out on Thursday and ha promised a hunt this weekend. Under the new law hunter have a number of legal option available to them. As well a being able to mount a hunt for an artificial scent, it will still be legal for the hunt to "flush out" foxes, a long a they shoot their quarry rather than set the hound on them. "We are not going away. We will keep these hound going, we will keep this community going and in the end we will come back and hunt when hunting is legal again," hunt master, Captain Ian Farquhar, said. But Tony Banks, Labour MP for West Ham, said the issue would soon disappear, and that "people in a few year time will be wondering what it wa all about". He said had the government not prevaricated since 1997 in introducing the ban, hunting with dog would have passed into history like other former country pursuit such a otter hunting and badger baiting. "Let the election decide this because the Conservatives have made clear that if they get elected into government they will restore hunting," he said.

Title: Sony PSP tipped as a 'must-have'
Article: Sony's Playstation Portable is the top gadget for 2005, according to a round-up of ultimate gizmo compiled by Stuff Magazine. It beat the iPod into second place in the Top Ten Essentials list which predicts what gadget-lovers are likely to covet this year. Owning all 10 gadget will set the gadget lover back Â£7,455. That is Â£1,000 cheaper than last year's list due to falling manufacturing cost making gadget more affordable. Portable gadget dominate the list, including Sharp's 902 3G mobile phone, the Pentax Optio SV digital camera and Samsung's Yepp YH-999 video jukebox. "What this year's Essentials show is that gadget are now cheaper, sexier and more indispensable than ever. We've got to the point where we can't live our life without certain technology," said Adam Vaughan, editor of Stuff Essentials. The proliferation of gadget in our home is inexorably altering the role of the high street in our life think Mr Vaughan. "Take digital cameras, who would now pay to develop an entire film of photos? Or legitimate downloads, who would travel mile to a record shop when they could download the song in minute for 70p?" he asks. Next year will see a new set of technology capturing the imagination of gadget lovers, Stuff predicts. The Xbox 2, high-definition TV and MP3 mobile will be among the list of must-haves that will dominate 2006, it says. The spring launch of the PSP in the UK is eagerly awaited by gaming fans.

Title: Yukos sues four firms for $20bn
Article: Russian oil firm Yukos ha sued four company for their role in last year's forced state auction of it key oil production unit Yuganskneftegas. Yukos is claiming more than $20bn (Â£11bn) in damage after Yugansk wa sold in December to settle back taxes. The four company named in the law suit are gas giant Gazprom, it unit Gazpromneft, investment company Baikal, and state oil firm Rosneft. Yukos submitted the suit in Houston, where it filed for bankruptcy. As well a suing for damages, Yukos ha asked the US court to send it tax dispute with the Russian government to an international arbitrator. It also ha submitted a reorganisation plan a part of it Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing. The clash between Yukos and the Kremlin came to a head last year when Yukos wa hit with a bill of more than $27bn in back tax and unpaid fines. To settle the bill, Russia forced Yukos to sell off Yuganskneftegas. Yukos called the sale illegal and ha turned to court in the US in an effort to regain control of the oil production business. It also ha vowed to use all legal mean at it disposal to go after any firm that try to buy or take control of it assets. Earlier this month it sued the Russian government for $28.3bn. Analysts have questioned whether a US court ha any jurisdiction over Russian companies, while Moscow official have dismissed Yukos' legal wrangling a meaningless. In Houston, bankruptcy Judge Letitia Clark will start a two-day hearing on 16 February to hear argument on whether a US court is the proper forum for the case. The threat of legal action from Yukos and it bankruptcy filing in Houston did have an effect on last year's auction, however. Concerned that it would be caught up in a court battle, Gazprom and Gazpromneft withdrew from the auction, and Yuganskneftegas wa sold to little-known investment firm Baikal Finance Group. A few day later, Baikal gave control of the company to state-run oil group Rosneft for $9.3bn. Rosneft, meanwhile, ha agreed to merge with Gazprom, bringing a large chunk of Russia's very profitable oil business back under state control. Yukos claim that the right of it shareholder have been ignored and that is ha been punished for the political ambition of it founder Mikhail Khodorkovsky. Mr Khodorkovsky, once Russia's richest man, is in prison, having been charged with fraud and tax evasion and repeatedly denied bail.

Title: Elvis set to top UK singles chart
Article: Rock 'n' roll legend Elvis is set to top the UK single chart on Sunday, 27 year after his death. The re-release of hit song Jailhouse Rock wa out-selling X Factor winner Steve Brockstein's cover of Against All Odds by 2,000 copy on Tuesday. If the record doe make the top spot, it will be Elvis' 19th UK number one. The last time he topped the chart wa with the remix of the little-known song A Little Less Conversation, which wa number one in June 2002. If Jailhouse Rock doe reach number one on Sunday, it will be the 999th in the history of the UK pop charts. The song first topped the chart in 1958. Chart analyst say Elvis could score the 1000th number one a well. His record One Night will be released the following week, followed the week after by A Fool Such As I, a part of his record company SonyBMG's new Elvis campaign. It ha called it "the most ambitious single release campaign in the history of the UK record industry".

Title: Keegan hails comeback king Fowler
Article: Manchester City bos Kevin Keegan ha praised striker Robbie Fowler for his landmark return to form. The 29-year-old, out of favour at City earlier this season, took his Premiership goal tally past 150 with a brace in Monday's 3-2 win at Norwich. "He is still a quality player and know where the net is - we have just got to supply him with ammunition and, in the end, we did," Keegan said. "He ha worked hard to get back to where he is now." The former Liverpool striker, who moved to City in 2003 after a poor stint at Leeds, ha battled back into first-team contention after struggling with fitness at the start of the season. Fowler overtook Les Ferdinand on Tuesday evening to become the third highest scorer of all time in the Premiership, with 151 goals, and he only trail Alan Shearer (250) and Andy Cole (173). And Keegan belief there is still more to come from the former England forward. "He can get better if we can supply him better," added Keegan. "People want to write him off but if he ha kept the article of those people who have written him off he could throw them back at them and they would be left with a bit of egg on their face." Fowler's double strike helped City come back from two goal down to clinch a dramatic win at Carrow Road and Keegan sympathised with Norwich bos Nigel Worthington afterwards. "I feel a bit for Nigel Worthington," he said. "His team have got great character, they have a lot of drive and enthusiasm. "I know it is a killer blow for Norwich but I really think they have brought something to the Premiership. "The stadium and the atmosphere is great, it is just a tough league to stay in - a they are finding out and a we know."

Title: Europe asks Asia for euro help
Article: European leader say Asian state must let their currency rise against the US dollar to ease pressure on the euro. The European single currency ha shot up to successive all-time high against the dollar over the past few months. Tacit approval from the White House for the weaker greenback, which could help counteract huge deficits, ha helped trigger the move. But now Europe say the euro ha had enough, and Asia must now share some of the burden. China is seen a the main culprit, with export soaring up 35% in 2004 partly on the back of a currency pegged to the dollar. "Asia should engage in greater currency flexibility," said French finance minister Herve Gaymard, after a meeting with his German counterpart Hans Eichel. Markets responded by pushing the euro lower, in the expectation that the rhetoric - and the pressure - is unlikely to ease ahead of a meeting of the G7 industrialised country next week. Early on Tuesday morning, the dollar had edged higher to 1.3040 euros. The yen, meanwhile, had strengthened to 102.975 against the dollar by 0730 GMT.

Title: Ministers 'naive' over phone-taps
Article: The government is being naive by refusing to allow phone-tap evidence in court, a senior EU politician says. Javier Solana, EU foreign policy chief, say phone-tap evidence work in the court of other European countries. Human right groups, top police officer and many MPs say allowing the evidence would remove the need to detain terror suspect without charge. But Home Secretary Charles Clarke say the evidence would not make much difference to these cases. Mr Solana told ITV1's Jonathan Dimbleby programme: "[Phone-tap evidence in court] works, it is normal that it is done, it would be naive not to do it. "It would be naive not to use this technological thing that we have at our disposal." Mr Solana's comment come the day after Sir Ian Blair, the newly-appointed Metropolitan Police commissioner, said he wa in favour of phone-tap evidence. Under the Anti-Terrorism Crimes and Security Act 2001, foreign terror suspect can be detained in British jail without trial or charge. Several suspect have been detained under these power because evidence against them wa deemed too sensitive to be heard in court. Some of this evidence is believed to be telephone intercepts. Human Rights group Liberty ha argued that if intercept evidence could be heard, these detainee could be brought to trial. But critic of phone-tap trial say the evidence is often weak and can expose the method of the security services. The home secretary say intercept would not make much difference because case against terror suspect frequently rely on other kind of surveillance. But Mr Clarke ha been forced to change the regime of detention without trial after Law Lords ruled it illegal. He ha opted for a system of "control orders" whereby suspects, both British and foreign, can be held under house arrest or surveillance. These order will again involve a UK opt-out of part of the European Convention on Human Rights. While accepting that people "have to be prepared" for a possible terrorist attack, Mr Solana said he had "qualms" about the home secretary's new plans. "We have to fight terrorism with all our means, but not so far a to change our way of life," he said.

Title: Bomb threat at Bernabeu stadium
Article: Spectators were evacuated from Real Madrid's Bernabeu stadium on Sunday following a bomb scare during the game between the host and Real Sociedad. More than 70,000 people abandoned the ground with the score at 1-1 and only three minute left to play. The Basque newspaper Gara apparently received a telephone call saying a bomb wa due to explode at 2100 local time. But after searching the stadium with sniffer dogs, the police said that no explosive device had been found. "The police have said they have completed their search and have not found anything," said Real Madrid president Florentino Perez. "The best thing we can all do now is to put this nightmare behind us." Madrid midfielder Guti told private Spanish radio station Cadena Ser: "I have never seen this before and sport should be above it all." Real took the lead just before the break when Brazilian striker Ronaldo cracked home with his left foot. Sociedad levelled the match midway through the second half when Turkish striker Nihat Kahveci smashed home with an acrobatic finish. It is not yet clear if the remaining three minute of the game will be played at a later date or if the result will be allowed to stand. If the result remains at 1-1, Real will drop to third place in the standings, 11 point behind leader Barcelona, who snatched a late 2-1 win at Albacete on Saturday. Initial report suggested the Basque separatist group ETA may be responsible for the bomb threat after issuing similar warning before a series of small explosion in recent days. The Bernabeu wa targeted by ETA on 1 May, 2002, when Madrid were about to play FC Barcelona in a Champions League semi-final. A car bomb exploded in a street outside the stadium and 17 people were slightly injured.

Title: WorldCom trial starts in New York
Article: The trial of Bernie Ebbers, former chief executive of bankrupt US phone company WorldCom, ha started in New York with the selection of the jury. Mr Ebbers, 63, is accused of being the mastermind behind an $11bn (Â£6bn) accounting fraud that eventually saw the firm collapse in July 2002. His indictment includes charge of security fraud, conspiracy and filing false report with regulators. If found guilty, Mr Ebbers could face a substantial jail sentence. He ha firmly declared his innocence. Under Mr Ebbers' leadership, WorldCom emerged from Mississippi obscurity to become a $160bn telecom giant and the darling of late 1990s investors. Yet a competition intensified and the telecom boom petered out, WorldCom found itself under growing financial stress. When WorldCom finally collapsed, shareholder lost about $180bn and 20,000 worker lost their jobs. Mr Ebbers' trial, which is expected to last two months, is the latest in a series of attempt by US prosecutor to pursue senior executive for fraud. It will coincide with the retrial of former Tyco International chief Dennis Kozlowski and his top lieutenant, accused of looting the industrial conglomerate to the tune of $600m. Trail preparation are also preparing for former executive of shamed US energy firm Enron.

Title: World leaders gather to face uncertainty
Article: More than 2,000 business and political leader from around the globe are arriving in the Swiss mountain resort Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will discus issue ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the more than 20 government leader and head of state leader attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protest against the WEF are expected to be muted. Anti-globalisation campaigner have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to run in parallel with the WEF's ritzier event in Davos. The organiser of the Brazilian gathering, which brings together thousand of campaigner against globalisation, for fair trade, and many other causes, have promised to set an alternative agenda to that of the Swiss summit. However, many of the issue discussed in Porto Alegre are Davos talking point a well. "Global warming" feature particularly high. WEF participant are being asked to offset the carbon emission they cause by travelling to the event. Davos itself is in deep frost. The snow is piled high across the mountain village, and at night the wind chill take temperature down to minus 20C and less. Ultimately, the forum will be dominated by business issue - from outsourcing to corporate leadership - with boss of more than a fifth of the world's 500 largest company scheduled to attend. But much of the medium focus will be on the political leader coming to Davos, not least because the agenda of this year's forum seems to lack an overarching theme. "Taking responsibility for tough choices" is this year's official talking point, hinting at a welter of knotty problems. One thing seems sure, though: transatlantic disagreement over how to deal with Iran, Iraq and China are set to dominate discussions. Pointedly, only one senior official from President Bush's new administration is scheduled to attend. The US government may still make a conciliatory gesture, just a happened a year ago when Vice President Dick Cheney made a surprise appearance in Davos. Ukraine's new president, Viktor Yushchenko, is to speak, just day after his inauguration, an event that crowned the civil protest against the rigged first election that had tried to keep him from power. The European Union's top leaders, among them German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder and European Commission President Manuel Barosso, will be here too. Mr Blair will formally open the proceedings, although his speech will be pre-empted by French President Jacques Chirac, who announced his attendance at the last minute and secured a slot for a "special message" two hour before Mr Blair speaks. The organiser also hope that the new Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, will use the opportunity for talk with at least one of the three Israeli deputy prime minister coming to the event, a list that includes Shimon Peres. Davos fan still hark back to 1994, when talk between Yassir Arafat and Mr Peres came close to a peace deal. Mr Blair's appearance will be keenly watched too, a political observer in the UK claim it is a calculated snub against political rival Chancellor Gordon Brown, who wa supposed to lead the UK government delegation. Microsoft founder Bill Gates, the world's richest man and a regular at Davos, will focus on campaigning for good causes, though business interest will not be wholly absent either. Having already donated billion of dollar to the fight against Aids and Malaria, Mr Gates will call on world leader to support a global vaccination campaign to protect child in developing country from easily preventable diseases. On Tuesday, Mr Gates pledged $750m (Â£400m) of his own money to support the cause. Mr Gates' company, software giant Microsoft, also hope to use Davos to shore up it defence against open source software like Linux, which threaten Microsoft's near monopoly on computer desktops. Mr Gates is said to be trying to arrange a meeting with Brazil's President Lula da Silva. The Brazilian government ha plan to switch all government computer from Microsoft to Linux. At Davos, global problem solving and networking are never far apart.

Title: Euro firms miss out on optimism
Article: More than 90% of large company around the world are highly optimistic about their economic prospects, a survey of 1,300 boss suggests. Their biggest worry are not terror threats, but over-regulation, low-cost competition and the wild ups and down of oil prices. There is one exception: Firms in Western Europe - but not the UK - are lacking confidence after year of slow growth. When business adviser PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) conducted the same survey two year ago, nearly 30% of boss were gloomy about their prospects. Global business leader say that they are facing a two-pronged regulatory assault. After a string of corporate scandal in the United States - from Enron to WorldCom - the Sarbanes-Oxley act force company to be much more transparent, but doing all the paperwork cost a lot of time and money. Across Europe, meanwhile, all stock exchange-listed company are currently in the process of moving to new and complex accounting standard called IFRS. Hacking through the red tape can hardly be avoided, but many chief executive around the world appear to have decided on how to deal with low-cost competitors. Already, about 28% of the boss polled for the survey say that they have moved part of their business into low-wage countries, and another 11% plan to do so in the future. Possibly a a result, the worry about low-cost competition ha slightly fallen from last year, with just 54% of company calling it a "significant threat" or "one of the biggest threats". But PwC's global chief executive, Samuel DiPiazza, said a growing number of company were also concerned that move to outsource work to cheaper country could both hurt their reputation in their home market and harm the quality of service they provide to their customers. According to Frank Brown, global advisory leader at PwC , the trend of large company to have global operation ha one clear upside: "One risk in one region - for example the Middle East - won't kill your business anymore." Surprisingly, the survey suggests that the rapid decline of the US dollar is not seen a a huge threat anymore, unlike even a year ago, when it wa cited a the third-largest problem. Mr DiPiazza said the interview with chief executive suggested that company had "adjusted" to the new reality of a euro that buy $1.30 and more, while others had successfully hedged their position and locked in more favourable exchange rates. - For the survey, PricewaterhouseCoopers interviewed 1,324 chief executive throughout the world during the last three month of 2004.

Title: Share boost for feud-hit Reliance
Article: The board of Indian conglomerate Reliance ha agreed a share buy-back, to counter the effect of a power struggle in the controlling family. The buy-back is a victory for chairman Mukesh Ambani, whose idea it was. His brother Anil, the vice-chairman, said had not been consulted and that the buy-back wa "completely inappropriate and unnecessary". The board hope the move will reverse a 13% fall in Reliance's share since the feud became public last month. The company ha been fractious since founder Dhirubhai Ambani died in 2002, leaving no will. "Today's round ha gone to [Mukesh], there is no doubt about it," said Nanik Rupani, president of the Indian Merchants Chamber, a Bombay-based traders' body. The company plan to buy back 52 million share at 570 rupee (Â£6.80; $13) apiece, a premium of more than 10% to it current market price.

Title: Venezuela reviews foreign deals
Article: Venezuela is to review all foreign investment in it mining industry in an effort to strengthen it indigenous industrial output. President Hugo Chavez ha ordered all existing contract with foreign firm to be examined to see if they provide maximum benefit to the country. The review will cover production of gold, aluminium and iron ore although it excludes the country's oil sector. Chavez ha sought to extend the state's role in all sector of the economy. The left-wing president is conducting a controversial review of land ownership in the country while also seeking to create a state-run telecom firm to compete with foreign-owned businesses. He ha argued that major economic reform are vital to improve the life of Venezuela's poorest citizens. Announcing the review of raw material production, minister Victor Alvarez said the government would seek to transfer technology, training capability and content from project with foreign partners. "We are defending our national sovereignty over the use of our national resource which must serve the endogenous development of the nation," Mr Alvarez said. "For this reason we are reviewing all memorandum of understanding, all letter of intent, all agreement that have been signed, all contracts, to check which of these comply with these directives. "Everything, absolutely everything, ha to be reviewed." Venezuela ha previously assured foreign company with operation in the mineral rich country that it respect existing contracts. However, the government insisted that it needed to develop it own industrial infrastructure in order to create new job and lessen it reliance on foreign partners. "If we don't do this, we are just going to carry on being slaves, supplier of raw materials, all our life and we will never develop our own productive capacity," Mr Alvarez added. Companies from the United States, Canada, France and Switzerland all have substantial investment in Venezuela's mining sector.

Title: Show over for MTV's The Osbournes
Article: Rock star Ozzy Osbourne ha said his family will not make any more episode of reality TV show The Osbournes. "At the end of it I didn't like having camera around the house all the time," the Black Sabbath singer told reporter at the MTV Europe Awards in Rome. His wife Sharon, who also appears in the popular MTV show based on the Osbournes' family life, agreed. "Now everybody's doing reality shows. He's done it, he's been there, he's got to do something else," she said. Ozzy Osbourne said he had had enough of the work involved in making the series. "When you watch a 25-minute episode, I've been filming all day," he said. Sharon Osbourne is currently appearing a a judge and mentor in ITV1 talent show The X-Factor alongside Simon Cowell and Louis Walsh. Earlier this year she topped a poll of the most important people in rock, for her part in guiding the career of husband Ozzy and her family. She wa the driving force behind The Osbournes, which ran for three series, earning the family a reported $85m (Â£46m). The renewed popularity for Ozzy ha seen sale of his merchandise hit the $50m (Â£27.2m) mark, a record for a heavy metal artist. Sales of T-shirts, accessory and action figure have rocketed since The Osbournes hit screens. At it peak, The Osbournes had a regular audience of eight million, with America's TV Guide magazine describing the series a "a cross between The Simpsons and This Is Spinal Tap". Osbourne himself wa at a loss to explain it popularity: "I suppose Americans get a kick out of watching a crazy Brit family like u make complete fool of ourselves every week."

Title: Israeli economy picking up pace
Article: Israel's economy is forecast to grow by 4.2% in 2004 a it continues to emerge from a three-year recession. The main driver of the faster-than-expected expansion ha been exports, with tourism seeing a strong rebound, the statistical office said. The economy is benefiting from a quieter period in Palestinian-Israeli violence and a pick-up in global demand for technology products. The outlook is better than it ha been for a number of years, analyst said. Many company have focused on cost cutting and greater efficiency, while the government ha been trying to trim public spending and push through reforms. The growth figure come about despite a strike earlier this year by about 400,000 public sector worker which closed banks, hospitals, postal service and transport facilities. Title: Wenger dejected as Arsenal slump
Article: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger claimed their display in the 3-1 defeat against Bayern Munich wa "our worst peformance in the Champions League". Kolo Toure's late goal give the Gunners hope for the second leg, but Wenger said: "The only positive is that we are still in the tie. "The player are really down in the dressing-room. I feel we really turned in a bad performance. "At 3-0 we faced a real struggle, but 3-1 at least give u a chance." Goalscorer Toure wa also at fault for two goals, and Wenger said: "We need to help Toure rebuild his confidence a he is low at the moment." Wenger also tried to stay upbeat himself, adding: "But there is enough time for crying. I could cry - maybe it would be easier - but life go on. "In this job, you have good and bad nights. This wa a bad night - but I still have confidence in the quality of my players, a well a their spirit and desire." But Wenger's Bayern counterpart Felix Magath wa in no mood to celebrate either. He said: "I am far from happy despite the win. My player failed to try and score a fourth to kill the tie and then conceded the late goal. "Arsenal are fully capable of scoring several goal against u on their own turf." Arsenal keeper Jens Lehmann, whose personal rivalry with Bayern goalkeeper Oliver Kahn wa not helped by the result, said: "Do I blame myself for the third goal? As a goalkeeper, I always blame myself. "I just know the goal were very easy against us. In my time here, we have never conceded three easy goal like that - but sometimes it happens. "It would have been impossible to go through at 3-0 - but with the goal we have chances. Everything is now possible."

Title: Johnny and Denise lose Passport
Article: Johnny Vaughan and Denise Van Outen's Saturday night entertainment show Passport to Paradise will not return to screens, the BBC ha said. The ex-Big Breakfast presenter were recruited to host the BBC One family variety show last July. "There are currently no plan for another series," a spokeswoman said. She added the pair "brought a real warmth to Saturday night, but in the end we felt we had done enough with the format of the show". Passport to Paradise involved a combination of game and outside broadcast with a high level of audience participation. The first instalment attracted more than 4.1 million viewer - but that had dropped to fewer than 2.7 million by the time it ended. The BBC spokeswoman said Graham Norton's Strictly Dance Fever would be a priority for 2005. "That's very much on the card for next year, and we're concentrating at the moment on Strictly Come Dancing, which is doing phenomenally well," she said.

Title: Blair backs 'pre-election budget'
Article: Tony Blair ha backed Chancellor Gordon Brown's pre-Budget report amid opposition claim he wa too bullish about the state of the UK economy. In a speech in Edinburgh, the prime minister said Thursday's report reinforced stability and opportunity. And that would be central to Labour's next election campaign, planning for which wa already well advanced. Mr Brown earlier denied his economic forecast were too optimistic - but refused to rule out future tax rises. He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "No politician should make the mistake that John Major and his colleague made in 1992 of saying no matter what the circumstance are, they can make all sort of guarantee on every individual thing. "That is not what politician should do, it would not be responsible to do." Mr Brown insisted his spending plan were "affordable" and he could afford to be optimistic because Britain wa now a stable, low-inflation economy and house price were now stabilising. Mr Blair praised his chancellor for his role in creating economic stability, which he said wa the "cornerstone" of Labour's programme. In a speech at Edinburgh's Napier University, he said Labour would publish over the next few month "a rich agenda for future policy in any possible third term". "In every area of work there is a detailed plan for the future, much clearer than those in 1997 or 2001. All of it fit together around common theme of opportunity, security and stability for all," Mr Blair said. In his pre-Budget report, Mr Brown surprised some City expert by forecasting UK growth at between 3% and 3.5% for next year. Many believe the figure is more likely to be under 3% - and fear tax rise or spending cuts, saying tax receipt have been overestimated. Carl Emmerson, from the Institute for Fiscal Studies, told BBC News: "He think everything will come out in the wash and it will, in fact, be OK. We're not so sure." David Page, of Investec Securities, said: "His forecast that he will meet the golden rule with a margin of Â£8bn is way too optimistic. "It's going to take a significant turnaround in the economy to meet these targets." Conservative Shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin said: "I can't find a single economic forecaster from the IMF to the Institute of Fiscal Studies who belief anything other than the chancellor ha got a black hole in his finances. "In order to deal with that he will have to raise tax after the next general election." Mr Letwin accused the chancellor of using "fancy statistics" to hide public service failures. Vincent Cable, for the Liberal Democrats, called on Mr Brown to open up the government's book to the National Audit Office, to see if he had met his "golden rule". "It is very clear that there are some serious loose end in government public spending," Mr Cable told MPs.

Title: Home phones face unclear future
Article: The fixed line phone in your home could soon be an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia show that more and more people are using their mobile phone for every call they make or take. According to the study, more than 45 million people in the UK, Germany, US and South Korea now only use a mobile. It showed that people keep their fixed line phone because call charge are lower, but most of those questioned said the future wa definitely mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research showed that mobile and fixed phone were used for different purposes. Home phone were used for longer call but conversation on mobile tended to be shorter, between mobile and to friends. In the UK 69% of those questioned said they turned to their fixed phone because it wa still cheaper to use than a mobile. However, when pressed few could say with accuracy how tariff on fixed and mobile phone compared. In the US and Germany many of those interviewed said they used the fixed phone because it wa more reliable than a mobile handset and let them get access to the net at relatively high speeds. In all the country where interview were carried out, older people were more likely to use a fixed line phone more than a mobile. Women aged 50 or above almost never use a mobile phone, the research found. The move to mobile wa most pronounced in South Korea where 65% of those questioned said they already make most of their call from a mobile. 18% said they would not get a landline if they moved house. Many of those questioned said they had an emotional connection to their fixed phone that drew on it position in the home and the "cosiness" of making a call there. Nokia said these finding had implication for mobile operator who must work hard to ensure that mobile are seen a cheap, reliable and providing good call quality. The survey also showed that it is not just voice call that are going wireless. Some of those questioned said they were looking to use a mobile or wireless service to get net access within the next couple of years. Polling firm Mori interviewed more than 6,000 people in the UK, US, Germany and South Korea for the survey.

Title: Economy 'strong' in election year
Article: UK business are set to prosper during the next few month - but this could trigger more interest rate rises, according to a report. Optimism is at it highest since 1997 and business will reap the benefit of a continuing rise in public spending, say researcher at BDO Stoy Hayward. The Bank of England is expected to keep rate on hold this week - but they could go up later in the year. Rates are likely to rise after the anticipated general election in May. The BDO optimism index - a leading indicator of GDP growth two quarter ahead edged up in January to 102.5, from 102.2 in October. The rise is due, in part, to an increase in public spending and increased merger and acquisition activity. The only thing blighting business optimism this year will be uncertainty associated with the general election, BDO said. Its BDO's output index - which predicts GDP movement a quarter in advance - remained at 100.8 for January, implying GDP growth at 2.9% in the second quarter of 2005. However, the output index is being held back by recent interest rate rises, sterling's strength against the dollar and high oil prices, the group noted. Its inflation index, which ha risen continuously over the last 8 months, climbed to 110.0 in January from 108.0 in October last year. "The UK is looking strong going into the general election, but business need to prepare themselves for a jolt ahead a the Bank of England reacts to growth and inflationary pressures," said Peter Hemington, partner at BDO Stoy Hayward. "Growth will probably slow by the end of 2005 and it is likely that we will see higher interest rate or a sharp drop in demand for product and services."

Title: Ebbers denies WorldCom fraud
Article: Former WorldCom chief Bernie Ebbers ha denied claim that he knew accountant were doctoring the book at the firm. Speaking in court, Mr Ebbers rejected allegation he pressured ex-chief financial officer Scott Sullivan to falsify company financial statements. Mr Sullivan "made accounting decisions," he told the federal court, saying his finance chief had "a keen command of the numbers". Mr Ebbers ha denied charge of fraud and conspiracy. During his second day of questioning in the New York trial Mr Ebbers played down his working relationship with Mr Sullivan and denied he frequently met him to discus company business when questioned by the prosecution. "In a lot of weeks, we would speak ... three or four times," Mr Ebbers said, adding that conversation about finance were rarely one-on-one and were usually discussed by a "group of people" instead. Mr Ebbers relationship to Mr Sullivan is key to the case surrounding financial corruption that led to the collapse of the firm in 2002 following the discovery of an $11bn accounting fraud. The prosecution's star witness is Mr Sullivan, one of six WorldCom executive indicted in the case, He ha pleaded guilty to fraud and appeared a a prosecution witness a part of an agreement with prosecutors. During his time on the witness stand Mr Sullivan repeatedly told juror he met frequently with Mr Ebbers, told him about change made to WorldCom's account to hide cost and had warned him such practises were improper. However during the case on Tuesday Mr Ebbers denied the allegations. "I wasn't advised by Scott Sullivan of anything ever being wrong," he told the court. "He's never told me he made an entry that wasn't right. If he had, we wouldn't be here today." Mr Ebbers could face a jail sentence of up to 85 year if convicted of all the charge he is facing. Shareholders lost about $180bn in WorldCom's collapse, 20,000 worker lost their job and the company went bankrupt. The company emerged from bankruptcy last year and is now known a MCI.

Title: Confusion over high-definition TV
Article: Now that a critical mass of people have embraced digital TV, DVDs, and digital video recorders, the next revolution for TV is being prepared for our sets. In most corner of TV and technology industries, high-definition (HDTV) is being heralded a the biggest thing to happen to the television since colour. HD essentially make TV picture quality at least four time better than now. But there is real concern that people are not getting the right information about HD on the High Street. Thousands of flat panel screen - LCDs (liquid crystal displays), plasma screens, and DLP rear-projection TV set - have already been sold a "HD", but are in fact not able to display HD. "The UK is the largest display market in Europe," according to John Binks, director of GfK, which monitor global consumer markets. But, he added: "Of all the flat panel screen sold, just 1.3% in the UK are capable of getting high-definition." There are 74 different device that are being sold a HD but are not HD-ready, according to Alexander Oudendijk, senior vice president of marketing for satellite giant Astra. They may be fantastic quality TVs, but many do not have adaptor in them - called DVI or HDMI (High-Definition Multimedia Interface) connector - which let the set handle the higher resolution digital images. Part of this is down to lack of understanding and training on the High Street, say industry experts, who gathered at Bafta in London for the 2nd European HDTV Summit last week. "We have to be careful about consumer confusion. There is a massive education process to go through," said Mr Binks. The industry already recognised that it would be a challenge to get the right information about it across to those of u who will be watching it. Eventually, that will be everyone. The BBC is currently developing plan to produce all it TV output to meet HDTV standard by 2010. Preparations for the analogue switch-off are already underway in some areas, and programme are being filmed with HD cameras. BSkyB plan to ship it first generation set-top boxes, to receive HDTV broadcasts, in time for Christmas. Like it Sky+ boxes, they will also be personal video recorder (PVRs). The company will start broadcast of HDTV programmes, offering them a "premium channel packages", concentrating, to start with, on sports, big events, and films, in early 2006. But the set-top box which receives HDTV broadcast ha to plug into a display - TV set - that can show the image at the much higher resolution that HD demands, if HDTV is to be "real". By 2010, 20% of home in the UK will have some sort of TV set or display that can show HD in it full glory. But it is all getting rather confusing for people who have only just taken to "being digital". As a result, all the key players, those who make flat panel displays, a well a the satellite company and broadcasters, formed a HD forum in 2004 to make sure they were all talking to each other. Part of the forum ha been concerned with issue like industry standard and content protection. But it ha also been preoccupied with how to help the paying public know exactly what they are paying for. From next month, all device that have the right connector and resolution required will carry a "HD-Ready" sticker. This also mean they are equipped to cope with both analogue and HDTV signals, and so comply with the minimum specification set out by the industry. "The logo is absolutely the way forward," said David Mercer, analyst with Strategy Analytics. "But it is still not appearing on many retail products." The industry is upbeat that the sticker will help, but it is only a start. "We can only do so much with the position we are in today with manufacturers," said Mr Oudendijk. "There may well be a number of dissatisfied customer in the next few months." The European Broadcast Union (EBU) is testing different flavour of HD format to prepare for even better HDTV further down the line. It is similarly concerned that people get the right information on HDTV formats, a well a which device will support the formats. "We believe consumer buying expensive display need to ensure their investment is worthwhile," said Phil Laven, technical director for the EBU. The TV display manufacturer want u to watch HD on screen that are at least 42in (106cm), to get the "true impact" of HD, they say, although smaller display suffice. What may convince people to spend money on HD-ready device is the falling prices, which continue to tumble across Europe. The price are dropping an average of 20% every year, according to analysts. LCD price dropped by 43% in Europe a a whole last year, according to Mr Oudendijk.

Title: Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing'
Article: The China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to obey a government order to stop construction of one of it giant dams, the Chinese state press ha said. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the sister Xiluodu dam, said the Beijing News. The Xiluodu dam is one of 30 such large-scale construction project called to a halt because of a lack of proper environmental checks. The Beijing News said the company may instead choose to pay a fine. The firm ha also ignored order to stop construction at two of it other project - the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction project targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (Sepa) for having not carried out mandatory environmental impact assessment have complied with it shutdown order. The China Three Gorges Project Corp could now face a fine up to 200,000 yuan ($24,000; Â£12,700). Last week, it denied that it project violated regulations. "The Three Gorges Corporation ha all along abided by the law and have built our project in accordance with the law," it said. The Sepa order come a the Chinese government appears to be trying to cool the country's booming economy. Previously it ha encouraged construction of new electricity generating capacity to solve chronic energy shortages, which forced many factory into part-time working last year. In 2004, China increased it generating capacity by 12.6% to 440,700 megawatt (MW). The Xiluodu Dam is designed to produce 12,600 MW of electricity, and is being built on the Jinshajiang - or "river of golden sand" a the upper reach of the Yangtze are known. It is a sister project to the main Three Gorges Dam downstream where more than half a million people have had to be relocated, drawing criticism from environmental group and overseas human right activists.

Title: Venezuela identifies 'idle' farms
Article: Venezuelan authority have identified more than 500 farms, including 56 large estates, a idle a it continues with it controversial land reform policy. Under a 2001 land law, the government can tax or seize unused farm sites. A further 40,000 farm are yet to be inspected, the state's National Land Institute ha told Associated Press. Vice president Jose Vicente Rangel ha said farmer and rancher with their title in order and their land productive have "nothing to fear." Critics of the land reform policy claim president Hugo Chavez is trying to enforce a communist-style economic programme that ignores property right and will damage the country. Land owner claim the National Land Institute ha made mistake in classifying land a public or private. But the government - Venezuela's largest land owner - say they are proceeding cautiously to prevent conflicts. In a statement, Mr Rangel said the land reform is not against the constitution, which permit private property, while stressing the effort are to "vindicate social and economically" year of inequality in the country. One property in conflict with the government is the El Charcote cattle ranch, run by Agroflora, a subsidiary of the UK food group Vestey. Agriculture minister Arnoldo Marquez told Reuters news agency the site's document "do not guarantee that this is a private land". Administrators of the ranch, however, have complained that pro-Chavez squatter have taken over 80% of the property in the last four years, and the UK government ha asked Venezuelan authority to resolve the conflict. "You should ask the company when they are going to put their paper in order and hand over the land that is not theirs," said Mr Marquez.

Title: BBC poll indicates economic gloom
Article: Citizens in a majority of nation surveyed in a BBC World Service poll believe the world economy is worsening. Most respondent also said their national economy wa getting worse. But when asked about their own family's financial outlook, a majority in 14 country said they were positive about the future. Almost 23,000 people in 22 country were questioned for the poll, which wa mostly conducted before the Asian tsunami disaster. The poll found that a majority or plurality of people in 13 country believed the economy wa going downhill, compared with respondent in nine country who believed it wa improving. Those surveyed in three country were split. In percentage terms, an average of 44% of respondent in each country said the world economy wa getting worse, compared to 34% who said it wa improving. Similarly, 48% were pessimistic about their national economy, while 41% were optimistic. And 47% saw their family's economic condition improving, a against 36% who said they were getting worse. The poll of 22,953 people wa conducted by the international polling firm GlobeScan, together with the Program on International Policy Attitudes (Pipa) at the University of Maryland. "While the world economy ha picked up from difficult time just a few year ago, people seem to not have fully absorbed this development, though they are personally experiencing it effects," said Pipa director Steven Kull. "People around the world are saying: 'I'm OK, but the world isn't'." There may be a perception that war, terrorism and religious and political division are making the world a worse place, even though that ha not so far been reflected in global economic performance, say the BBC's Elizabeth Blunt. The country where people were most optimistic, both for the world and for their own families, were two fast-growing developing economies, China and India, followed by Indonesia. China ha seen two decade of blistering economic growth, which ha led to wealth creation on a huge scale, say the BBC's Louisa Lim in Beijing. But the result also may reflect the untrammelled confidence of people who are subject to endless government propaganda about their country's rosy economic future, our correspondent says. South Korea wa the most pessimistic, while respondent in Italy and Mexico were also quite gloomy. The BBC's David Willey in Rome say one reason for that result is the changeover from the lira to the euro in 2001, which is widely viewed a the biggest reason why their wage and salary are worth less than they used to be. The Philippines wa among the most upbeat country on prospect for respondents' families, but one of the most pessimistic about the world economy. Pipa conducted the poll from 15 November 2004 to 3 January 2005 across 22 country in face-to-face or telephone interviews. The interview took place between 15 November 2004 and 5 January 2005. The margin of error is between 2.5 and 4 points, depending on the country. In eight of the countries, the sample wa limited to major metropolitan areas.

Title: Mobile networks seek turbo boost
Article: Third-generation mobile (3G) network need to get faster if they are to deliver fast internet surfing on the move and exciting new services. That wa one of the message from the mobile industry at the 3GSM World Congress in Cannes last week. Fast 3G network are here but the focus ha shifted to their evolution into a higher bandwidth service, say the Global Mobile Suppliers Association. At 3GSM, Siemens showed off a system that transmits faster mobile data. The German company said data could be transmitted at one gigabit a second - up to 20 time faster than current 3G networks. The system is not available commercially yet, but Motorola, the US mobile handset and infrastructure maker, held a clinic for mobile operator on HSDPA (High Speed Downlink Packet Access), a high-speed, high bandwidth technology available now. Early HSDPA system typically offer around two megabit per second (Mbps) compared with less than 384 kilobit per second (Kbps) on standard 3G networks. "High-Speed Downlink Packet Access (HSDPA) - sometimes called Super 3G - will be vital for profitable service like mobile internet browsing and mobile video clips," according to a report published by UK-based research consultancy Analysys. A number of company are developing the technology. Nokia and Canada-based wireless communication product company Sierra Wireless recently agreed to work together on High Speed Downlink Packet Access. The two company aim to jointly market the HSDPA solution to global network operator customers. "While HSDPA theoretically enables data rate up to a maximum of 14Mbps, practical throughput will be lower than this in wide-area networks," said Dr Alastair Brydon, author of the Analysys report: Pushing Beyond the Limits of 3G with HSDPA and Other Enhancements. "The typical average user rate in a real implementation is likely to be in the region of one megabit per second which, even at this lower rate, will more than double the capacity... when compared to basic WCDMA [3G]," he added. Motorola ha conducted five trial of it technology and say speed of 2.9Mbps have been recorded at the edge of an outdoor 3G cell using a single HSDPA device. But some mobile operator are opting for a technology called Evolution, Data Optimised (EV-DO). US operator Sprint ordered a broadband data upgrade to it 3G network at the end of last year. We are "expanding our network and deploying EV-DO technology to meet customer demand for faster wireless speeds," said Oliver Valente, Sprint's vice president for technology development, when the contract wa announced. As part of $3bn in multi-year contract announced late last year, Sprint will spend around $1bn on EV-DO technology from Lucent Technologies, Nortel Networks and Motorola that provides average data speed of 0.3-0.5 megabit a second, and peak download rate of 2.4Mbps. MMO2, the UK-based operator with service in the UK, Ireland and Germany, ha opted for technology based on HSDPA. Using technology from Lucent, it will offer data speed of 3.6Mbps from next summer on it Isle of Man 3G network, and will eventually support speed of up to 14.4Mbps. US operator Cingular Wireless is also adopting HSDPA, using technology from Lucent alongside equipment from Siemens and Ericsson. Siemens' plan for a one gigabit network may be more than a user need today, but Christoph Caselitz, president of the mobile network division at the firm say that: "By the time the next generation of mobile communication debut in 2015, the need for transmission capacity for voice, data, image and multimedia is conservatively anticipated to rise by a factor of 10." Siemens - in collaboration with the Fraunhofer German-Sino Lab for Mobile Communications and the Institute for Applied Radio System Technology - ha souped up mobile communication by using three transmitting and four receiving antennae, instead of the usual one. This enables a data transmission, such a sending a big file or video, to be broken up into different flow of data that can be sent simultaneously over one radio frequency band. The speed offered by 3G mobile seemed fast at the time mobile operator were paying huge sum for 3G licences. But today, instead of connecting to the internet by slow, dial-up phone connection, many people are used to broadband network that offer speed of 0.5 megabit a second - much faster than 3G. This mean user are likely to find 3G disappointing unless the network are souped up. If they aren't, those lucrative "power users", such a computer geek and busy business people will avoid them for all but the most urgent tasks, reducing the potential revenue available to mobile operators. But one gigabit a second system will not be available immediately. Siemens say that though the system work in the laboratory, it still ha to assess the mobility of multiple-antennae device and conduct field trials. A commercial system could be a far away a 2012, though Siemens did not rule out an earlier date.

Title: Straw praises Kashmir moves
Article: The UK ha welcomed the decision by India and Pakistan to open a bus link across the ceasefire line dividing the disputed region of Kashmir. Foreign Secretary Jack Straw, touring South East Asian countries, praised the "spirit of cooperation" in achieving the breakthrough. Media report in both country describe the deal a a major step in the ongoing peace process. Mr Straw said he hoped the agreement would make a difference to Kashmiris. The bus service wa one of several announcement made after a meeting of foreign minister of both country in Islamabad on Wednesday. Kashmiri politician on both side of the Line of Control which divide the region welcomed the move. In a statement, Mr Straw said the bus service between Srinagar and Muzaffarabad "will be able to reunite family that have been divided for decades". "This will make a real difference to the life of Kashmiris on both side of the Line of Control," he said. "I warmly applaud the effort of both India and Pakistan to make this happen. "This spirit of cooperation will, I hope, lead to many more measure that will benefit all in the region." On Thursday Mr Straw wa in India visiting Sikhism's holiest shrine, the Golden Temple in Amritsar where he tried his hand at making Indian bread or roti. He is due to take part in talk with the Indian government on Friday. A second bus service linking the Pakistani city of Lahore with Amritsar in India wa also announced a well a a rail link between Rajasthan state and Pakistan's Sindh province. Both side agreed to begin talk on reducing the risk of nuclear accident and also said they planned to reopen their respective consulate in Karachi and Mumbai (Bombay). The mountainous region of Kashmir ha been a flashpoint between the two nuclear power for more than 50 years.

Title: Castaignede fires Laporte warning
Article: Former France fly-half Thomas Castaignede ha warned the pressure is mounting on coach Bernard Laporte following their defeat by Wales. France suffered a shock loss against the Welsh at the weekend after looking on course for an easy win. Castaignede told BBC Sport: "The pressure is big on Laporte after a huge loss to New Zealand, a slim win over Scotland and a miracle against England. "But the French have to get behind him and the team at Lansdowne Road." Following victory over South Africa and Australia in November, France were deemed by many to be the world's leading side. But they were then trounced 45-6 by New Zealand and only just beat Scotland after the Scots had a try disallowed in their Six Nations opener. It then took some woeful spot kicking from Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley to help them to victory against England at Twickenham. < Castaignede said: "You can't say any of those result have eased the pressure on Laporte. "Had England's kicker not been so bad, the position in the Six Nations would be very different now." Laporte ha been criticised for France's negative tactic in their win over Scotland and England. But his side played a more free-flowing style against Wales, making a mockery of the opposition's defence in the first half before suffering a shock turnaround in fortune after the interval. "All the chat in France ha been about how France will play against Ireland," said Castaignede ahead of the 12 March tie. "Everyone want to see the sort of play we saw against Wales. But everyone also want a win." Castaignede, a veteran of 43 international caps, admitted the French would go in a underdog against Ireland. "Going to Ireland is never easy but the way they're playing right now, it's harder than ever," said Castaignede. "They're very experienced and don't often lose at home. They've got some great forward and some electric runner on the break." Despite praising the Irish he claimed the Welsh had the upper hand in the Six Nations run-in. "Ireland have such a good pack but Wales are something else on the break," he added. "At the weekend they were simply awesome. As a Frenchman it wa disappointing to see, but you had to admire it. "Their commitment to every cause can make them win this championship." The 30-year-old also tipped Yann Delaigue to start ahead of Frederic Michalak at number 10 after an impressive display in Paris last weekend. "Delaigue played really well and admittedly Michalak played well too," said Castaignede. "I'm just glad I'm not the one who ha to make the decision."

Title: Cairn Energy in Indian gas find
Article: Shares in Cairn Energy rose 3.8% to 1,088 penny on Tuesday after the UK firm announced a fresh gas discovery in northern India. The firm, which last year made a number of other new find in the Rajasthan area, said the latest discovery could lead to large gas volumes. However, chief executive Bill Gammell cautioned that additional evalution wa first needed at the site. Cairn ha also been granted approval to extend it Rajasthan exploration area. This approval ha come from the Indian government. A spokesman said the company's decision to carry out further investigation at the new find showed that it believed there wa significant gas. But he added: "It's still too early to say what the extent of it is." Cairn's string of find in Rajasthan last year saw it elevated to the FTSE 100 index of the UK's leading listed companies. The company had bought the right to explore in the area from oil giant Shell. Mr Gammell is a former Scottish international rugby player.

Title: Camera phones are 'must-haves'
Article: Four time more mobile with camera in them will be sold in Europe by the end of 2004 than last year, say a report from analyst Gartner. Globally, the number sold will reach 159 million, an increase of 104%. The report predicts that nearly 70% of all mobile phone sold will have a built-in camera by 2008. Improving imaging technology in mobile is making them an increasingly "must-have" buy. In Europe, camera on mobile can take 1.3 megapixel images. But in Japan and Asia Pacific, where camera phone technology is much more advanced, mobile have already been released which can take 3.2 megapixel images. Japan still dominates mobile phone technology, and the uptake there is huge. By 2008, according to Gartner, 95% of all mobile sold there will have camera on them. Camera phone had some teething problem when they were first launched a people struggled with poor quality image and us for them, a well a the complexity and expense of sending them via MMS (Multimedia Messaging Services). This ha changed in the last 18 months. Handset maker have concentrated on trying to make phone easier to use. Realising that people like to use their camera phone in different ways, they have introduced more design features, like rotating screen and viewfinders, removable memory card and easier control to send picture messages. Mobile company have introduced more way for people to share photo with other people. These have included giving people easier way to publish them on websites, or mobile blog - moblogs. But the report suggests that until image quality increase more, people will not be interested in printing out picture at kiosks. Image sensor technology inside camera phone is improving. The Gartner report suggests that by mid-2005, it is likely that the image resolution of most camera phone will be more than two megapixels. Consumer digital camera image range from two to four megapixels in quality, and up to six megapixels on a high-end camera. But a lot of work is being done to make camera phone more like digital cameras. Some handset already feature limited zoom capability, and manufacturer are looking into technological improvement that will let people take more photo in poorly-lit conditions, like nightclubs. Other development include wide-angle modes, basic editing features, and better sensor and processor for recording film clips. Images from camera phone have even made it into the art world. An exhibition next month in aid of the charity Mencap, will feature snap taken from the camera phone of top artists. The exhibition, Fonetography, will feature image taken by photographer David Bailey, Rankin and Nan Goldin, and artist Sir Peter Blake, Tracey Emin and Jack Vettriano. But some us for them have worried many organisations. Intel, Samsung, the UK's Foreign Office and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories in the US, have decided to ban camera phone from their building for fear of sensitive information being snapped and leaked. Many schools, fitness centre and local council have also banned them over fear about privacy and misuse. Italy's information commissioner ha also voiced concern and ha issued guideline on where and how the phone can be used. But camera phone fear have not dampened the manufacturers' profits. According to recent figures, Sony Ericsson's profit tripled in the third-quarter because of new camera phones. Title: WMC profits up amid bid criticism
Article: Australian mining firm WMC Resources ha seen a fivefold rise in profit while continuing to be the target of a hostile takeover bid. WMC said it made net profit of 1.33bn Australian dollar ($1bn; Â£550m) in 2004, up from A$246bn the year before. It is currently arguing against an offer from Swiss Xstrata, which the firm raised to A$8.4bn last week after WMC said it wa an undervaluation. Now report say that the Australian government is against the deal. Trade Minister Mark Vaile ha said that the bid may be "against the national interest". Mr Vaile, who wa quoted in the Australian Financial Review, compared Xstrata's attempt to take over WMC to a similar bid by oil giant Shell for Australia's Woodside Petroleum in 2001. The bid wa thrown out by Treasurer Peter Costello on national interest grounds. WMC's interest in uranium deposit were a contributing factor, Mr Vaile said. WMC itself, however, ha no objection in principle to being bought out, having spun off it aluminium operation in 2002 to make itself a more tempting target - a long a the price is right. Its stellar performance in 2004 ha been built on sky-high price for metals. Copper and nickel in particular have been in high demand thanks to China's booming economy, which expanded more than 9% in each of the past two years. Nickel price rose 43% during the year, with copper up 36%.
