Title: BBC leads interactive Bafta wins
Article: The BBC and the National Theatre have led the field at this year's Interactive Bafta awards. The National Theatre's Stagework website picked up the prize for best learning a well a top factual site. The BBC collected three awards, including best online entertainment for the Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy Adventure Game. Spooks Interactive took the best interactive TV prize. The annual award recognise the best in digital media. BBC Sport Interactive fought off competition from CBBC Newsround and the Guardian to take home the best news and sport trophy for it coverage of England's exit from Euro 2004. It wa recognised for it "groundbreaking" use of animation. Bafta's Grant Dean, chair of Bafta's Interactive Entertainment committee, said all the entrant had been of "outstanding quality" and that judging had been "enormously difficult". "Without a doubt, 2005 ha been a landmark year for the Bafta Interactive Awards," he added. "Many of the top award this year have gone to the company we most commonly associate with traditional entertainment, showing how the gap between new media, film and television is closing." Awards were given out in 12 different categories, including interactive TV, film, music, design, a well a technical and social innovation, at a London ceremony. The top music award wa given to SSEYO miniMIXA, a mobile music sequencer designed to let people write, edit and share compositions. Warner Bros wa given two prize for it "inspiring" effort in film and DVD interactivity. The Chaplin Collection beat Oasis, Really Bend It Like Beckham, Shaun of the Dead and The Day Today in the DVD category, and Trauma won best film. Elsewhere, fashionista and clothes designer Alexander McQueen took the accolade for the best-designed website. The award have been running since 1997, but in 2002 the British Academy of Film and Television decided to split them into separate game and interactive ceremonies. On Tuesday Half-Life 2 dominated the game prizes. It collected six Baftas, including best game and best online game.

Article: Indian airline Jet Airways' initial public offering wa oversubscribed 16.2 times, banker said on Friday. Over 85% of the bid were at the higher end of the price range of 1,050-1,125 rupee ($24-$26). Jet Airways, a low-fare airline, wa founded by London-based ex-travel agent Naresh Goya, and control 45% of the Indian domestic airline market. It sold 20% of it equity or 17.2 million share in a bid to raise up to $443m (Â£230.8m). The price at which it share will begin trading will be agreed over the weekend, banker said. "The demand for the IPO wa impressive. We believe that over the next two years, the domestic aviation sector promise strong growth, even though fuel price could be high," said Hiten Mehta, manager of merchant banking firm, Fortune Financial Services. India began to open up it domestic airline market - previously dominated by state-run carrier Indian Airlines - in the 1990s. Jet began flying in 1993 and now ha competitor including Air Deccan and Air Sahara. Budget carrier Kingfisher Airlines and SpiceJet are planning to launch operation in May this year. Jet ha 42 aircraft and run 271 scheduled flight daily within India. It recently won government permission to fly to London, Singapore and Kuala Lumpur.

Title: Last Star Wars 'not for children'
Article: The sixth and final Star Wars movie may not be suitable for young children, film-maker George Lucas ha said. He told US TV show 60 Minutes that Revenge of the Sith would be the darkest and most violent of the series. "I don't think I would take a five or six-year-old to this," he told the CBS programme, to be aired on Sunday. Lucas predicted the film would get a US rating advising parent some scene may be unsuitable for under-13s. It open in the UK and US on 19 May. He said he expected the film would be classified PG-13 - roughly equivalent to a British 12A rating. The five previous Star Wars film have all carried less restrictive PG - parental guidance - rating in the US. In the UK, they have all been passed U - suitable for all - with the exception of Attack of The Clones, which got a PG rating in 2002. Revenge of the Sith - the third prequel to the original 1977 Star Wars film - chronicle the transformation of the heroic Anakin Skywalker into the evil Darth Vader a he travel to a Hell-like planet composed of erupting volcano and molten lava. "We're going to watch him make a pact with the devil," Lucas said. "The film is much more dark, more emotional. It's much more of a tragedy."

Title: Blair congratulates Bush on win
Article: Tony Blair ha said he look forward to continuing his strong relationship with George Bush and working with him during his second term a president. Mr Bush's re-election came at a crucial time for a world that wa "fractured, divided and uncertain", Mr Blair said. It had to be brought together, he added, saying action wa needed on poverty, the Middle East and the condition on which terrorist prey. Mr Blair said state had to work with the US to fight global terrorism. But there wa a need to recognise it would not be defeated by "military might alone but also by demonstrating the strength of our common values" he added. Solving the conflict in the Middle East wa the world's single most "pressing political challenge" of the present day, Mr Blair warned. The prime minister also urged Europe and the US to "build anew their alliance". "All of u in position of leadership, not just President Bush, have a responsibility to rise to this challenge. It is urgent that we do so." Mr Blair also paid tribute to Democrat John Kerry's campaign, saying he had helped make the presidential election "a true celebration of American democracy". The election of the US president wa significant for the world but particularly so for Britain because of it special relationship, he added. Earlier Tory leader Michael Howard sent Mr Bush his "warmest congratulations", saying: "We look to the president to be a unifying force for those all over the world who share our determination to defend freedom." Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy welcomed the fact there had been a quick conclusion to the election, unlike in 2000. Mr Bush's first task wa to "rebuild a sense of domestic purpose" within the US, he said. Mr Kennedy said: "Internationally, it is to be hoped that a second term will see a more sensitive approach to relation with long-standing allies, not least for the global effort to combat terrorism." Lib Dem foreign affair spokesman Menzies Campbell said a win by Mr Kerry would have given Mr Blair the chance of a fresh start, adding it wa almost a if there wa an "umbilical cord" between Mr Bush and the UK premier. "Europeans must hope that his administration will be much more multilateral in character, and that he will act swiftly to rebuild the Atlantic partnership which is so vital to security. "Iraq will remain an issue of potential division for some time to come." Even before the result became clear, Mr Blair wa being urged to push for action on climate change at his first meeting with whichever candidate won. Liberal Democrat environment spokesman Norman Baker underlined the issue of global warming during a Commons debate on Anglo-American relation on Wednesday. Environment Secretary Margaret Beckett ha said the US will act on global warming despite George Bush's refusal to sign up to the Kyoto protocol on carbon emissions. Public opinion would force change, she told BBC news. But Myron Ebell, an adviser on climate change to President Bush, ha said there would be no change in the US stance and rejected the threat of climate change. He claimed the US wa the only country with independent scientists.

Title: Warning over US pensions deficit
Article: Taxpayers may have to bail out the US agency that protects workers' pension funds, leading economist have warned. With the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC) some Â£23bn (Â£12m) in deficit, the Financial Economists Roundtable (FER) want Congress to act. Instead of taxpayer having to pick up the bill, the FER want Congressmen to change the PBGC's funding rules. The FER say firm should not have been allowed to reduce the insurance premium they pay into the PBGC fund. The FER blame this on a 2004 law, in a statement signed by several members, who include Nobel economics laureate William Sharpe. It said it wa "dismayed" at the situation and want Congress to overturn the legislation. Cash-strapped US companies, including those in the airline, car-making and steel industries, had argued in favour of the 2004 rule change, claiming that funding the insurance premium adequately would force them to have to cut jobs. "With a little firmer hand on the pension issue in the US, I think that Congress could avoid having to turn to the taxpayer and instead turn the obligation back onto the company that deserve to pay them," said Professor Dennis Logue, dean of Price College of Business at the University of Oklahoma. The PBGC wa founded in 1974 to protect workers' retirement rights. Its most recent action came last week when it took control of the pilots' pension scheme at United Airlines. With United battling bankruptcy, the carrier had wanted to use the money set aside for pension to finance running costs. The company ha an estimated $2.9bn hole in it pilots' pension scheme, which the PBGC will now guarantee.

Title: German business confidence slides
Article: German business confidence fell in February knocking hope of a speedy recovery in Europe's largest economy. Munich-based research institute Ifo said that it confidence index fell to 95.5 in February from 97.5 in January, it first decline in three months. The study found that the outlook in both the manufacturing and retail sector had worsened. Observers had been hoping that a more confident business sector would signal that economic activity wa picking up. "We're surprised that the Ifo index ha taken such a knock," said DZ bank economist Bernd Weidensteiner. "The main reason is probably that the domestic economy is still weak, particularly in the retail trade." Economy and Labour Minister Wolfgang Clement called the dip in February's Ifo confidence figure "a very mild decline". He said that despite the retreat, the index remained at a relatively high level and that he expected "a modest economic upswing" to continue. Germany's economy grew 1.6% last year after shrinking in 2003. However, the economy contracted by 0.2% during the last three month of 2004, mainly due to the reluctance of consumer to spend. Latest indication are that growth is still proving elusive and Ifo president Hans-Werner Sinn said any improvement in German domestic demand wa sluggish. Exports had kept thing going during the first half of 2004, but demand for export wa then hit a the value of the euro hit record level making German product less competitive overseas. On top of that, the unemployment rate ha been stuck at close to 10% and manufacturing firms, including DaimlerChrysler, Siemens and Volkswagen, have been negotiating with union over cost cutting measures. Analysts said that the Ifo figure and Germany's continuing problem may delay an interest rate rise by the European Central Bank. Eurozone interest rate are at 2%, but comment from senior official have recently focused on the threat of inflation, prompting fear that interest rate may rise.

Title: Court mulls file-sharing future
Article: Judges at the US Supreme Court have been hearing evidence for and against file-sharing networks. The court will decide whether producer of file-sharing software can ultimately be held responsible for copyright infringement. They questioned if opening the way for the entertainment industry to sue file-sharers could deter innovation. They also said that file-trading firm had some responsibility for inducing people to piracy. The lawsuit, brought by 28 of the world's largest entertainment firms, ha raged for several years. Legal expert agree that if the Supreme Court find in favour of the music and movie industry they would be able to sue file-trading firm into bankruptcy. But if the judge rule that Grokster and Morpheus - the file-sharers at the centre of the case - are merely provider of technology that can have legitimate a well a illegitimate uses, then the music and movie industry would be forced to abandon it pursuit of file-sharing providers. Instead, they would have to pursue individual who use peer-to-peer network to get their hand on free music and movies. The hi-tech and entertainment industry have been divided on the issue. Intel filed a document with the Supreme Court earlier this month in defence of Grokster and others, despite misgiving about some aspect of the file-sharing community. It summed up the attitude of many tech firm in it submission which state that it product "are essentially tools, that like any other tools, capable of being used by consumer and business for unlawful purposes". Asking firm to second-guess the us that it technology would be put to, and to build in way of preventing illegitimate use, would stifle innovation, it said. The Electronic Frontier Foundation, a civil right watchdog, is also defending StreamCast Networks, the company behind the Morpheus file-sharing software. The case raise a question of critical importance at the border between copyright and innovation, it said. It cites, a do many, the landmark ruling in 1984 which found that Sony should not be held responsible for the fact that it Betamax video recorder could be used for piracy. Defenders remain optimistic that the judge will rule in favour of the peer-to-peer networks, upholding the precedent set by the Sony Betamax case. A small band of supporter were outside the court a the lawyer entered, wearing "Save Betamax" t-shirts. "The Betamax principle stand a the Magna Carta for the technology industry and are responsible for the explosion in innovation that ha occurred in the US over the past 20 years," said Gary Shapiro, chief executive of the Consumer Electronics Association. Supreme Court Justice Stephen Breyer said that invention from printing to Apple's iPod could be used to illegally duplicate copyrighted material but had, on balance, been beneficial to society. He said that while file-trading software can be used to illegally trade movie and music, conceptually the technology had "some really excellent uses". Based on Tuesday's hearing it seems unlikely that the Betamax ruling will be overturned but file-sharing firm might still be held responsible for encouraging or inducing piracy. Grokster's lawyer argued that the company should be judged by it current behaviour rather than what it did when it first set up. But this argument wa dismissed a "ridiculous" by Justice David Souter. CEA bos Mr Shapiro think the case is the most important that the Supreme Court will hear this year. "It's about preserving America's proud history of technological innovation and protecting the ability of consumer to access and utilise technology," he said. The case ha already been heard by two lower court and both found in favour of the peer-to-peer networks. They ruled that despite being used to distribute million of illegal songs, file-sharing could also be used to cheaply distribute software, government document and promotional copy of music.

Title: Mitsubishi in Peugeot link talks
Article: Trouble-hit Mitsubishi Motors is in talk with French carmaker PSA Peugeot Citroen about a possible alliance. On Tuesday Mitsubishi, the only major Japanese car firm in the red, confirmed earlier report of negotiations. But a spokesman refused to comment on speculation that Mitsubishi could end up building car for PSA and perhaps it Japanese rival Nissan. Mitsubishi ha been hit by a recall scandal and the withdrawal of support from shareholder DaimlerChrysler. The US-German firm, once a majority shareholder, decided last April to stop providing financial backing. Mitsubishi's sale have slid 41% in the past year, catalysed by the revelation that the company had systematically been hiding record of fault and then secretly repairing vehicles. Mitsubishi is due to unveil a recovery plan later in January. Analysts said that alliance with other carmaker would be a necessary part of whatever it came up with, not least because it own slow sale have left it manufacturing capacity under-used.

Title: Robotic pods take on car design
Article: A new breed of wearable robotic vehicle that envelop driver are being developed by Japanese car giant Toyota. The company's vision for the single passenger in the 21st Century involves the driver cruising by in a four-wheeled leaf-like device or strolling along encased in an egg-shaped cocoon that walk upright on two feet. Both these prototype will be demonstrated, along with other concept vehicle and helper robots, at the Toyota stand at the Expo 2005 in Aichi, Japan, in March 2005. The model are being positioned a so-called personal mobility devices, which have few limits. The open leaf-like "i-unit" vehicle is the latest version of the concept which the company introduced last year. Built using environmentally friendly plant-based materials, the single passenger unit is equipped with intelligent transport system technology that allow for safe autopilot driving in specially equipped lanes. The model allows the user to make tight on-the-spot turns, move upright amongst other people at low speed and can be easily switched into a reclining position at higher speeds. Body colour can be customized to suit individual preference and a personal recognition system offer both information and music. Also on display at the show will be the egg-shaped "i-foot". This is a two-legged mountable robot like device that can be controlled with a joystick. Standing at a height of well over seven foot (2.1 metres), the unit can walk along at a speed of about 1.35km/h (0.83mph) and navigate staircase into the bargain. Mounting and dismounting is accomplished with the aid of the bird-like leg that bend over backwards. "They are clearly what we call concept vehicles, innovative idea which have yet to be transformed into potential product and which are a few year away from actual production," said Dr David Gillingwater from the Transport Studies Group at Loughborough University. "They clearly have eye-catching appeal, which is in part the name of the game here, and are linked to the iMac and iPod-type niche which Apple have been responsible for developing and leading in recent year - new, different, hi-tech, image conscious products. "As always with these concept vehicles, it is difficult to see 'who' they would appeal to and what their role would be in the 'personal transport' marketplace." The personal transport arena is taking on a new dimension though with futuristic device that augment human capabilities. Toyota's prototype represent the latest incarnation of wearable exoskeleton in a vehicular form that is specially focused on transport. Powered robotic exoskeleton have been the focus of much US military research over the year and Japan seems to have jumped onto the bandwagon with a wave of product being developed for specific applications. With an emerging range of device targeted towards the ageing world population, care giving and the military, wearable exoskeleton seem to represent a new line of future technology that meet an individual's particular mobility needs. While Toyota's prototype are geared towards mass transport, the company say that the vehicle will allow the elderly and the disabled to achieve independent mobility. Experts, though, are a bit sceptical of their acceptance in this area. "Those with arguably the greatest need for this sort of assistance, now and certainly in the future, are the elderly and infirm people," Dr Gillingwater told the BBC News website. "You have to ask whether these sort of vehicle will appeal to these groups." Design consideration also exist. Dr Erel Avineri, of the Centre for Transport and Society at the University of the West of England in Bristol said: "The design of the introduced mobility device is not completely adjusted to the specific need of the elderly and the disabled. "For example, one problem that many older passenger experience is limited ability to rotate the neck and upper body, making it difficult to look to the side and back when backing up. "It look like the visual design of the device interior doe not consider this need. This and other human-factors related issue in the design of such device are not the only issue that should be considered," said Dr Avineri. "In general, introducing a new technology requires the passenger to change behaviour pattern that have served the older passenger for decades. Elderly user might not necessarily accept such innovation. "This may be another barrier to the commercial success of such a vehicle." Such single-person vehicle may find a relatively small market niche and may be more suited towards specialised application rather than revolutionising the face of mass transport. "The concept of personal mobility behind these sort of innovation is great but they beg a huge number of questions," said Dr Gillingwater. "What's their range? How user-friendly will they really be? What infrastructure will be required to allow these vehicle to be used. "Overall I think these vehicle pose a number of important question than provide answer or solutions."

Title: Premier League planning Cole date
Article: The Premier League is attempting to find a mutually convenient date to investigate allegation Chelsea made an illegal approach for Ashley Cole. Both Chelsea and Arsenal will be asked to give evidence to a Premier League commission, but no deadline ha been put on when that meeting will convene. "It's hard to put a date on it," a Premier League spokesman confirmed to BBC Sport. "It's not a formal situation where they've got so much time to respond." Arsenal and England defender Cole reportedly met Blues bos Jose Mourinho and chief executive Peter Kenyon in a London hotel 11 day ago. Chelsea have yet to officially confirm or deny the meeting, which would be in breach of Premier League rule K3. Now the Gunners have asked for an inquiry to look into claim that their player ha been "tapped up". Both club have pledged to co-operate with the inquiry which will be conducted on a single day a opposed to being run a an ongoing evaluation. Cole is in negotiation with the Gunners over extending his current deal which end in 2007. And his Arsenal team-mate Robert Pires ha urged the England left-back to stay at Highbury. Pires told the Evening Standard: "He ha been at Arsenal for ever. He is a very attacking left-back and I think he is enjoying his football because at Arsenal he play in an offensive team. "I am not sure he will get the same pleasure at Chelsea, even though they are doing so well at the moment. "I have built a fantastic playing relationship with Ashley. "We play together so well - we could do it with our eye shut. "But you have to respect the decision of the player. Everybody ha that right."

Title: Abbas 'will not tolerate' attacks
Article: Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas ha said he will not tolerate attack such a last Friday's suicide bombing in the Israeli city of Tel Aviv. In an interview ahead of a meeting in London to discus Palestinian reforms, Mr Abbas said such attack were against Palestinian interests. The Palestinian Authority (PA) wa exerting "a 100% effort" to end the violence, Mr Abbas added. The attack, which killed five, wa the first of it kind since he took office. Mr Abbas confirmed Israel shared information with the PA in the hunt for the organiser of the attack. The Israeli government refuse to accept Syria's denial that it wa implicated in the nightclub bombing. Israeli official gave an intelligence briefing to foreign ambassador on Monday, explaining Syria's alleged involvement. British foreign minister Jack Straw said there had been a "continuing stream" of information suggesting Palestinian militant group were operating from within Syria. In an email interview in the British newspaper the Independent, Mr Abbas said: "We believe peace is possible now and we are ready to negotiate with Israel to reach a true and lasting peace based on justice and international legitimacy." He added: "We have an opportunity and it would be irresponsible if we, the Israelis, or the world allow it to slip away." Tuesday's meeting on Palestinian reform is being hosted by British Prime Minister Tony Blair. Also due to attend are US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, UN Secretary General Kofi Annan, World Bank official and foreign minister from 23 European and Arab countries. The conference wa a "vital step" in renewing the peace process, Mr Straw said. "It's a high-level attendance, which reflects the sense of momentum and opportunity created by recent events," he added. A spokesman for Mr Blair said the Prime Minister expected the conference to discus "a comprehensive, co-ordinated and, above all, practical work plan for both the Palestinian Authority and the international community". Israel will not attend, but is said to be closely watching the outcome.

Title: File-swappers ready new network
Article: Legal attack on website that help people swap pirated film have forced the development of a system that could be harder to shut down. One site behind the success of the BitTorrent file-swapping system is producing it own software that avoids the pitfall of the earlier program. A test version of the new Exeem program will be released in late January. But doubt remain about the new network ability to ensure file being swapped are "quality copies". In late December movie studio launched a legal campaign against website that helped people swap pirated movie using the BitTorrent network. The legal campaign worked because of the way that BitTorrent is organised. That file-sharing system relies on link called "trackers" that point user to others happy to share the file they are looking for. Shutting down site that listed tracker crippled the BitTorrent network. One of the site shut down by the legal campaign wa suprnova.org which helped boost the popularity of the BitTorrent system by checking that tracker led to the movie or TV programme they claimed to. Now the man behind suprnova.org, who go by the nickname Sloncek, is preparing to release software for a new file-swapping network dubbed Exeem. In an interview with Novastream web radio, Sloncek said Exeem would combine idea from the BitTorrent and Kazaa file-sharing systems. Like BitTorrent, Exeem will have tracker that help point people toward the file they want. Like Kazaa these tracker will be held by everyone. There will be no centrally maintained list. This, said Sloncek, should make the system less vulnerable to legal action aimed at stopping people swapping pirated movie and music. The Exeem software ha been under development for a few month and is currently being tested by a closed group of users. An early public version of the software should be available before February. Sloncek said that currently only a Windows version of the software wa in development. There were no plan for a Linux or Mac version. He said that cost of writing the software will be paid for by advert appearing in the finished version of the program. Despite Suprnova administrator Sloncek's involvement with Exeem, the basic technology appears to have been developed by a firm called Swarm Systems that is based on Caribbean island Saint Kitts and Nevis. Users of the Exeem system will be able to rate file being swapped to help stop the spread of fake files, Sloncek told Novastream. Dr Johan Pouwelse, a researcher at the Delft University of Technology who study peer-to-peer networks, said Exeem wa the next evolution in file-sharing systems. But, he said, it would struggle to be a popular a BitTorrent and Suprnova because early version were not taking enough care to make sure good copy of file were being shared. "Exeem cannot prevent pollution," he said. "The rating system in Exeem seems flawed because it is easy to insert both fake file and fake ratings," he said. Studies have shown that organisation working for record label and movie studio have worked to undermine Kazaa by putting in fakes. By contrast moderator on Suprnova made sure file being shared were high quality. "The moderator are the difference between having a system that work and one that's full of crap like Kazaa," he said. "There is a fundamental tension between distribution and integrity," he said. Mr Pouwelse said that future version of file-sharing system are likely to incorporate some kind of distributed reputation system that let moderator prove who they are to the network and rate which file are worth downloading. When big file were being shared moderation system were key, said Mr Pouwelse. He added that the legal attack on BitTorrent had driven people away from site such a Suprnova but many user had simply migrated to other tracker listing site many of which have seen huge increase in traffic. "It's hard to compete with free," he said. No-one from the Motion Picture Association of America wa immediately available for comment on the file-sharing development.

Title: MPs issued with Blackberry threat
Article: MPs will be thrown out of the Commons if they use Blackberries in the chamber Speaker Michael Martin ha ruled. The Â£200 handheld computer can be used a a phone, pager or to send e-mails. The device gained new prominence this week after Alastair Campbell used his to accidentally send an expletive-laden message to a Newsnight journalist. Mr Martin revealed some MPs had been using their Blackberries during debate and he also cautioned member against using hidden earpieces. The use of electronic device in the Commons chamber ha long been frowned on. The sound of a mobile phone or a pager can result in a strong rebuke from either the Speaker or his deputies. The Speaker chair debate in the Commons and is charged with ensuring order in the chamber and enforcing rule and convention of the House. He or she is always an MP chosen by colleague who, once nominated, give up all party political allegiances.

Title: Clijsters set for February return
Article: Tennis star Kim Clijsters will make her return from a career-threatening injury at the Antwerp WTA event in February. "Kim had considered returning to action in Paris on 7 February," a statement on her website said. "She's decided against this so that she doe not risk the final phase of her recovery. If all go well, Kim will make her return on February 15." The 21-year-old ha not played since last October after aggravating a wrist injury at the Belgian Open. Back then, a doctor treating the Belgian feared that her career may be over, with the player having already endured an operation earlier in the season to cure her wrist problem. "I hope she come back, but I'm pessimistic," said Bruno Willems. Clijsters wa also due to marry fellow tennis star Lleyton Hewitt in February but the pair split "for private reasons" back in October.

Title: Queen recruit singer for new tour
Article: The remaining member of rock band Queen are to go on tour next year with former Free and Bad Company singer Paul Rodgers taking Freddie Mercury's place. Guitarist Brian May ha said he expects to be on the road with Rodgers and drummer Roger Taylor from April. May said: "Suddenly the Queen Phoenix is rising again from the ash and will take precedence over... our lives." Queen have played with many different singer since Mercury's death in 1991 but have reportedly not toured. May performed with Rodgers at a concert to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Fender Stratocaster guitar in London in September. "We were both so amazed at the chemistry that wa going on in [Free hit] All Right Now, that suddenly it seems blindingly obvious that there wa 'something happening here,'" May wrote on his website. They teamed up again for a concert to mark their induction into the UK Music Hall of Fame, and were joined by Taylor. "The show went so incredibly well from our point of view, and we got so many rave reaction from out there, we decided almost then and there that we would look at a tour together," May wrote. Queen went to number one in 2000 with a version of We Will Rock You sung by boy band 5ive and they have also played with Robbie Williams, Will Young and Bob Geldof. Queen bassist John Deacon ha currently retired from the stage. Rodgers wa singer with early 1970s rocker Free, who had a global hit with All Right Now, before forming Bad Company, a successful "supergroup" with member of King Crimson and Mott the Hoople. He ha also been in The Firm with Led Zeppelin's Jimmy Page and The Law with The Small Faces and The Who drummer Kenny Jones.

Title: Standard Life concern at LSE bid
Article: Standard Life is the latest shareholder in Deutsche Boerse to express concern at the German stock market operator's plan to buy the London Stock Exchange. It said Deutsche Boerse had to show why it planned Â£1.35bn ($2.5bn) offer for the LSE wa good for shareholder value. Reports say Standard Life, which owns a 1% stake in Deutsche Boerse, may seek a shareholder vote on the issue. Fellow shareholder US-based hedge fund Atticus Capital and UK-based TCI Fund Management have also expressed doubts. Deutsche Boerse's supervisory board ha approved the possible takeover of the LSE despite the sign of opposition from investors. "The onus is on Deutsche Boerse's management to demonstrate why the purchase of the LSE creates more value for shareholder than other strategies, such a a buyback," said Richard Moffat, investment director of UK Equities at Standard Life Investments. Atticus Capital, holding 2% of Deutsche Boerse, want it to buy back it own share rather than buy the LSE. And TCI which hold about 5%, ha made a request for an extraordinary shareholder meeting to be held to vote on replacing the company's entire supervisory board. It ha also demanded that shareholder be consulted about the proposed acquisition, and whether the operator of the Frankfurt stock exchange should return $500m (Â£266m) to shareholder instead. In December, Deutsche Boerse, which also owns the derivative market Eurex and the clearing firm Clearstream, put an informal offer of 530 penny per LSE share on the table. However, the LSE said the cash offer "undervalued" both it own business and the benefit of such a tie-up. Since then an improved offer from Deutsche Boerse ha been anticipated a it management ha continued talk with LSE chief executive Clara Furse. Title: Women MPs reveal sexist taunts
Article: Women MPs endure "shocking" level of sexist abuse at the hand of their male counterparts, a new study shows. Male MPs pretended to juggle imaginary breast and jeered "melons" a woman made Commons speeches, researcher from Birkbeck College were told. Labour's Yvette Cooper said she found it hard to persuade Commons official she wa a minister and not a secretary. Some 83 MPs gave their answer in 100 hour of taped interview for the study "Whose Secretary are You, minister". The research team, under Professor Joni Lovenduski, had set out to look at the achievement and experience of woman at Westminster. But what emerged wa complaint from MPs of all party of sexist barracking in the Chamber, sexist insult and patronising assumption about their abilities. Barbara Follet, one of the so-called "Blair Babes" elected in 1997, told researchers: "I remember some Conservatives - whenever a Labour woman got up to speak they would take their breast - imaginary breast - in their hand and wiggle them and say 'melons' a we spoke." Former Liberal Democrat MP Jackie Ballard recalled a stream of remark from a leading MP on topic such a women's leg or their sexual persuasion. And ex-Tory education secretary Gillian Shepherd remembered how one of her male colleague called all woman "Betty". "When I said, 'Look you know my name isn't Betty', he said, 'ah but you're all the same, so I call you all Betty'." Harriet Harman told researcher of the sheer hostility prompted by her advancement to the Cabinet: "Well, you've only succeeded because you're a woman." Another current member of the Cabinet say she wa told: "Oh, you've had a very fast rise, who have you been sleeping with?" Even after the great influx of woman MPs at the 1997 general election, and greater number of woman in the Cabinet, female MPs often say they feel stuck on the edge of a male world. Liberal Democrat Sarah Teather, the most recent female MP to be elected, told researchers: "Lots of people say it's like an old boy club. "I've always said to me it feel more like a teenage public school - you know a public school full of teenagers." Prof Joni Lovenduski, who conducted the study with the help of Margaret Moran MP and a team of journalists, said she wa shocked at the findings. "We expected a bit of this but nothing like this extent. We expected to find a couple of shocking episodes." But she said there wa a difference between the experience of woman before the 1997 intake and afterwards. This wa mainly because there were more woman present in Parliament who were not prepared to "put up with" the sexist attitude they came across, Prof Lovenduski said. But she added: "Some women, including the woman who came in 1997, received extraordinary treatment and I am not convinced that if the number of woman changed back to what it wa before 1997 that thing would not change back. "What I think is shocking to the general public is that these thing go on in the House of Commons." The interview are to be placed in the British Library a a historical record.

Title: Online games play with politics
Article: After bubbling under for some time, online game broke through onto the political arena in 2004. The US presidential election provided a showcase for many, aimed at talking directly to a generation that ha grown up with joystick and gamepads. Experts say this reflects how video game are becoming a mainstream part of culture and society. The first official political campaign game wa technically launched during the last week of 2003: the Iowa Game, commissioned by the Democrat hopeful Howard Dean. More than 20 followed suit, including Frontrunner, eLections, President Forever and The Political Machine, which allowed player to run an entire presidential campaign, including having to cope with the media. Others helped raise the stake during the Bush/Kerry contest by highlighting a candidate's virtue or his vices. The phenomenon ha astonished the forefather of political games, a handful of multi-discipline game enthusiast keen to push frontiers. "When I started researching political game at the university, about five year ago, I thought it wa going to be something that would take decade to happen," said Gonzalo Frasca, computer game specialist at the Information Technology University of Copenhagen. "I must admit that I wa the first person to be surprised at seeing how fast they have evolved," added the Uruguayan-born researcher, who ha so far created game for two political campaigns. Many artist and designer are experimenting with this form of gaming with an agenda in project such a newsgaming.com. The aim is to comment on international news event via games. The ability of game to simulate reality make them a powerful modelling tool to interact with actual situation in an original way. "Video game generate strong reaction mainly because they are new, but also because our culture need to learn how to deal with simulation," Mr Frasca told the BBC News website. This wa the case with the one he created for a political party in Uruguay, Cambiemos, an online puzzle game that offered a view on how the country's problem could be solved by working together. "It's up to u to explore what we can learn from ourselves through play and video games." Ultimately, Dr Frasca see game a a small laboratory where we can play with our hopes, fear and beliefs. "Children learn a lot about the world through play. There is no reason why we adult should stop doing it a we grow up." But expert estimate it will still take at least about a decade until this new breed of video gaming communication become a common tool for political campaigns. This is hardly surprising, compared to other form of mass medium like the worldwide web. Only a few year ago, most politician did not have a webpage, while now it is almost a must-have. Dr Frasca said: "Political campaign will continue to experiment with video games. They represent a new tool of communication that can reach a younger audience in a language that can clearly speak to them." "It will not replace other form of political propaganda, but it will integrate itself on to the medium ecology of political campaigns."

Title: Winemaker rejects Foster's offer
Article: Australian winemaker Southcorp ha rejected a takeover offer worth 3.1bn Australian dollar ($2.3bn; Â£1.8bn) from brewing giant Foster's Group. Southcorp, whose brand include Penfolds, Rosemount and Lindemans, dismissed the offer a inadequate. The two company held four day of talk after Foster's bought an 18.8% stake in Southcorp on 13 January. A merger would create a global player with worldwide annual sale of 39m case and revenue of A$2.6bn. Southcorp said Foster's A$4.17-a-share takeover proposal offered a "excellent strategic fit" but undervalued the company. "Southcorp's board ha informed Foster's that it is not prepared to recommend the offer a it doe not adequately reflect the strategic value of the company," said Southcorp chairman Brian Finn. Southcorp said Foster's takeover offer wa "opportunistic". However, it said that the offer may represent an 'opening bid', opening up the possibility of Foster's returning with an improved offer. Foster's said a combination of the two company would create a global player with an "unrivalled" collection of premium wine brands. Despite being best known for brewing Foster's Lager, Foster's is already one of Australia's largest wine producers, owning the Beringer and Wolf Blass brand among others. "The combination of Foster's and Southcorp will transform the global wine industry and significantly enhance Australia's competitive position on the global stage," said Trevor O'Hoy, Foster's chief executive officer. Foster's spent A$584m on buying an 18.8% stake in Southcorp from the Oatley family, which founded the Rosemount Estates business and later merged it into Southcorp. Shares in both company were suspended while the two held talk about a deal. Southcorp's share rose 12% to A$4.76 on news of the offer but Foster's share fell 3.7% to A$5.44.

Title: Ajax refuse to rule out Jol move
Article: Ajax have refused to reveal whether Tottenham's bos Martin Jol is on the Dutch champions' shortlist to become the Amsterdam club's new coach. Jol, who ha coached in his native Holland, ha guided Spurs to the Premiership's top eight. An Ajax spokesman told BBC Sport: "The coach must fit our profile - a coach who understands the Dutch league and offensive and distinctive football. "We need to find a solution soon, so someone is in place for next season." Ronald Koeman quit a Ajax bos last week after their exit from the Uefa Cup. Jol ha been linked with the vacant post at Ajax, with report saying he ha fallen out with Spurs' sporting director Frank Arnesen. But in a statement on Spurs' website, Jol said: "I'm happy here, I'm not in discussion with anyone else, I don't want to go elsewhere." Ajax have enlisted the help of Dutch legend Johann Cruyff, currently a consultant at Barcelona, to help find a new head coach. Cruyff ha admitted he ha been impressed by the way former RFC Waalwijk coach Jol ha turned round Spurs' fortune since taking over from Jacques Santini. Tonny Bruins Slot and Ruud Krol are currently in charge of Ajax, who are third in the Dutch league.

Title: US bank boss hails 'genius' Smith
Article: US Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan ha given a speech at a Scottish church in honour of the pioneering economist, Adam Smith. He delivered the 14th Adam Smith Lecture in Kirkcaldy, Fife. The Adam Smith Lecture celebrates the author of 1776's Wealth of Nations, which became a bible of capitalism. Dr Greenspan wa invited by Chancellor Gordon Brown, whose minister father John used to preach at the St Bryce Kirk church. Mr Brown introduced Dr Greenspan to the 400 invited guest a the "the world's greatest economist". Dr Greenspan, 79, who ha been in the UK to attend the G7 meeting in London, said the world could never repay the debt of gratitude it owed to Smith, whose genius he compared to that of Mozart. He said the philosopher wa a "towering contributor to the modern world". "Kirkcaldy, the birthplace in 1723 of Adam Smith and, by extension, of modern economics, is also of course, where your chancellor wa reared. "I am led to ponder to what extent the chancellor's renowned economic and financial skill are the result of exposure to the subliminal intellect-enhancing emanation in this area." He continued: "Smith reached far beyond the insight of his predecessor to frame a global view of how market economics, just then emerging, worked. "In so doing he supported change in societal organisation that were to measurably enhance standard of living." Dr Greenspan said Smith's revolutionary philosophy on human self-interest, laissez-faire economics and competition had been a force for good in the world. "The incredible insight of a handful of intellectual of the Enlightenment - especially with Smith toiling in the environs of Kirkcaldy - created the modern vision of people free to choose and to act according to their individual self-interest," he said. Following his lecture, Dr Greenspan - who received an honorary knighthood from the Queen at Balmoral in 2002 - wa awarded an honorary fellowship of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. He later opened an exhibition dedicated to Smith in the atrium of Fife College of Further and Higher Education. Joyce Johnston, principal of the college, said: "It is very fitting that the world's premier economist delivered this lecture in tribute to the world's first economist." Dr Greenspan - who became chairman of the Federal Reserve for an unprecedented fifth term in June 2004 - will step down in January next year. He ha served under Presidents George W Bush, Bill Clinton, George Bush, and Ronald Reagan. He wa also chairman of the council of economic advisor to Gerald Ford.

Title: Thompson says Gerrard should stay
Article: Liverpool legend Phil Thompson ha pleaded with Steve Gerrard to reject any overture from Chelsea. The ex-Reds assistant bos also warned that any honour won at Chelsea would be cheapened by the bid to buy success. He told BBC Radio Five Live: "Liverpool would think about any bid made but it will all be down to Steve in the end. "But it wouldn't have that same sweet feeling at Chelsea, where it's all money-orientated and about simply buying the best." Thompson reacted sharply to some Liverpool supporters, who criticised Gerrard's performance in the Carling Cup final against Chelsea. A number of fan questioned Gerrard's commitment and sarcastically branded his own goal in Liverpool's 3-2 defeat a his first goal for Chelsea. Thompson added: "I heard those comment from so-called supporter and they were diabolical, absolutely outrageous. "Stevie carried the club last year and this year. He's always put Liverpool first." Thompson, who savoured seven title-winning season and two European Cup triumph during his Anfield playing career, is confident that the lure of Champions League football will keep Gerrard at Anfield. "I hope Champions League football will beckon for Liverpool - either a winner or a finishing fourth in the Premiership - and he will commit himself. "There ha been a lot of soul-searching the way thing have gone lately. "I hope he's hardening to the fact he will have big decision to make but I hope it is to the benefit of Steven Gerrard and I hope it is worthwhile for Liverpool."

Title: Mobiles get set for visual radio
Article: The growth in the mobile phone market in the past decade ha been nothing less than astonishing, but the ability to communicate on the go is not the only reason we are hooked. Games, camera and music player have all been added to our handset in the last few years, but 2005 could see another big innovation that won't just see a change in our mobile phone habit - it might alter the way we listen to the radio. Finnish handset giant Nokia ha been working on a technology called Visual Radio, which take an existing FM signal from a radio station and enables that station to add enhancement such a information and pictures. It is not the first time that such an idea ha been suggested - the early day of DAB Digital Radio had similar intention that never really saw the light of day. One problem is that the name Visual Radio lead people to think of television but Reidar Wasenius, a senior project manager at Nokia, wa adamant that Visual Radio should not be confused with the more traditional medium. He said: "I'm very happy to say it's not television, what we're talking about is an enhancement of radio a we know it today. "If you have a Visual Radio enabled handset, when you hear an artist you don't know, or there's a competition or vote that you'd like to participate in, you pull out your handset and with one click you turn on a visual channel parallel to the on-air broadcast you've just been listening to." That visual channel is run from a computer within the radio station, and sends out different kind of information to the handset depending on what you are listening to. As well a detail on the track or artist of a particular song, there is also the ability to interact immediately with the radio station itself, in a similar way to digital television's "red button" content. Possible interactive content includes competitions, vote and even the chance to rate the song that is playing. But the interactive aspect will make the service especially attractive to radio stations, who will be able to track the number of people taking part in such activity on a real-time basis. This in turn should lead to an additional source of revenue, a it is very likely that advertiser will be keen to exploit new opportunity to reach listeners. As the Visual Radio content is transmitted by existing GPRS technology you would need to have that service enabled by your network. And there will be a cost for the service a well, although it may depend on your usage. "If you enjoy the visual channel occasionally and interact it'll be two or three pound per month," said Mr Wasenius. "But typically what we see happening is the operator offering a package deal for an 'all you can eat' arrangement per month." The payment system could therefore be similar to the way that broadband internet work versus dial-up connections. One thing that is for sure - assuming that Nokia retains it market share in handsets, it is estimating that there will be 100 million Visual Radio-enabled mobile phone in circulation by the end of 2006. "Basically, Visual Radio is not really revolutionary, but rather an evolution where we are providing tool with which people can participate in radio much more easily than ever before." The first Visual Radio service in the UK will begin in a few month time with Virgin Radio, who are positive about the impact it could have on their listeners. Station manager Steve Taylor commented: "Listeners can interact with the radio station in a new way. "Not only doe this give listener more information on the music we play but mean they can instantly purchase thing they like; mp3 music downloads and the latest gig tickets." Initially Visual Radio functionality will be limited to two Nokia handset due out soon - the 3230 and 7710 - but if successful, it is very likely that other manufacturer will want to join them. Title: Ask Jeeves joins web log market
Article: Ask Jeeves ha bought the Bloglines website to improve the way it handle content from web journal or blogs. The Bloglines site ha become hugely popular a it give user one place in which to read, search and share all the blog they are interested in. Ask Jeeves said it wa not planning to change Bloglines but would use the 300 million article it ha archived to round out it index of the web. How much Ask Jeeves paid for Bloglines wa not revealed. Bloglines ha become popular because it let user build a list of the blog they want to follow without having to visit each journal site individually. To do this it make use of a technology known a Really Simple Syndication (RSS) that many blog have adopted to let other site know when new entry are made on their journals. The acquisition follows similar move by other search sites. Google acquired Pyra Labs, maker of the Blogger software, in 2003. In 2004 MSN introduced it own blog system and Yahoo ha tweaked it technology to do a better job of handling blog entries. Jim Lanzone, vice president of search property at Ask Jeeves in the US, said it did not acquire Bloglines just to get a foothold in the blog publishing world. He said Ask Jeeves wa much more interested in helping people find information they were looking for rather than helping them write it. "The universe of reader is vastly larger than the universe of writers," he said. Mr Lanzone said the acquisition would sit well with Ask's My Jeeves service which let people customise their own web experience and build up a personal collection of useful links. "Search engine are about discovering information for the first time and RSS is the ideal way to keep track of and monitor those sites," he said. It would also help drive information and entry from blog to the portal that Ask Jeeves operates. There would be no instant sweeping change to Bloglines, said Mr Lanzone. "Our intent is to take our time to figure out the right business model not to try to monetise it right away," he said. Though Mr Lanzone added that Ask Jeeves would be helping organise the database of 300m blog entry Bloglines hold with it own net indexing technology. "Being able to search the blogosphere a one corpus of information will be very useful in it own right," said Mr Lanzone. Rumours about the acquisition were broken by the Napsterization weblog which said it got the hint from Ask Jeeves insiders.

Title: Mobile multimedia slow to catch on
Article: There is no doubt that mobile phone sporting camera and colour screen are hugely popular. Consumers swapping old phone for slinkier, dinkier version are thought to be responsible for a 26% increase in the number of phone sold during the third quarter of 2004, according to analyst Gartner More than 167 million handset were sold globally between July and September 2004, a period that, according to Gartner analyst Carolina Milanesi is "seldom strong". But although consumer have mobile that can take and send snaps, sound and video clip few, so far, are taking the chance to do so. In fact, the number of people not taking and sending pictures, audio and video is growing. Figures gathered by Continental Research show that 36% of British camera phone user have never sent a multimedia message (MMS), up from 7% in 2003. This is despite the fact that, during the same period, the number of camera phone in the UK more than doubled to 7.5 million. Getting mobile phone user to send multimedia message is really important for operator keen to squeeze more cash out of their customer and offset the cost of subsidising the handset people are buying. The problem they face, said Shailendra Jain, head of MMS firm Adamind, is educating people in how to send the multimedia message using their funky handsets. "Also," he said, "they have to simplify the interface so it not rocket science in term of someone understanding it." Research bear out the suspicion that people are not sending multimedia message because they do not know how to. According to Continental Research, 29% of the people it questioned said they were technophobe that tended to shy away from innovation. Only 11% regarded themselves a technically savvy enough to send a picture or video message. The fact that multimedia service are not interoperable across network and phone only add to people's reluctance to start sending them, said Mr Jain. "They ask themselves: 'If I'm streaming video from one handset to another will it work?'" he said. "There's a lot of user apprehension about that." There are other deeper technical reason why multimedia message are not being pushed a strongly a they might. Andrew Bud, executive chairman of messaging firm Mblox, said mobile phone operator cap the number of message that can be circulating at any one time for fear of overwhelming the system. "The rate we can send MMS into the mobile network is fairly constant," he said. The reason for this is that there are finite capacity for data traffic on the second generation network that currently have the most users. No-one want to take the risk of swamping these relatively narrow channel so the number of MMS message is capped, said Mr Bud. This ha led to operator finding other technologies, particularly one known a Wap-push, to get multimedia to their customers. But when network do find a good way to get multimedia to their customers, the result can be dramatic. Israeli technology firm Celltick ha found a way to broadcast data across phone network in a way that doe not overwhelm existing bandwidth. One of the first firm to use the Celltick service is Hutch India, the largest mobile firm in the country. The broadcast system get multimedia to customer via a rolling menu far faster than would be possible with other systems. While not multimedia messaging, such a system get people used to seeing their phone a a device that can handle all different type of content. As a result 40% of the subscriber to the Hutch Alive, which us Celltick's broadcast technology, regularly click for more pictures, sound and image from the operator. "Operators really need to start utilising this tool to reach their customers," said Yaron Toren, spokesman for Celltick. Until then, multimedia will be a message that is not getting through.

Title: Wada will appeal against ruling
Article: The World Anti-Doping Agency (Wada) will appeal against the acquittal of Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou on doping charges, if the IAAF doe not. The pair were cleared of charge relating to missing dope test by the Greek Athletics Federation last week. Wada chairman Dick Pound said: "I am convinced the IAAF will appeal against the decision, and we will support them. "But if they accept the federation's ruling we will go before the Court of Arbitration for Sport," he added. Kenteris's lawyer, Gregory Ioannidis, reacted angrily to Pound's comments. "Comments like these only help to embarrass the sporting governing bodies, create a hostage situation for the IAAF and strengthen our case further," he told BBC Sport. Kenteris, 31, and Thanou, 30, had been charged with avoiding drug test in Tel Aviv, Chicago and Athens and failing to notify anti-doping official of their whereabouts before the Olympics. They withdrew from the Athens Games after missing a drug test at the Olympic village on 12 August. But an independent tribunal ruled that the duo had not been informed that they needed to attend a drug test in Athens. However, their former coach Christos Tzekos wa banned for four year by the tribunal. Kenteris and Thanou still have to face trial on charge brought separately by Greek prosecutor of missing the drug test and faking a motorcycle accident to avoid testing at the Athens Games.

Title: UK bank seals South Korean deal
Article: UK-based bank Standard Chartered said it would spend $3.3bn (Â£1.8bn) to buy one of South Korea's main retail banks. Standard Chartered said acquiring Korea First Bank (KFB) fulfilled a strategic objective of building a bigger presence in Asia's third largest economy. Its share fell nearly 3% in London a the bank raised fund for the deal by selling new stock worth Â£1bn ($1.8bn), equal to 10% of it share capital. Standard Chartered expects about 16% of future group revenue to come from KFB. The South Korean bank will also make up 22% of the group's total assets. The move, a year after Citigroup beat Standard Chartered to buy Koram bank, would be the South Korean financial sector's biggest foreign takeover. This time around, Standard Chartered is thought to have beaten HSBC to the deal. KFB is South Korea's seventh largest bank, with 3 million retail customers, 6% of the country's banking market and an extensive branch network. The country's banking market is three time the size of Hong Kong's with annual revenue of $44bn. Standard Chartered ha it headquarters in London but doe two third of it business in Asia, and much of the rest in Africa. "We're comfortable with the price paid...the key here ha been speed and decisiveness in making sure that we won," said Standard Chartered chief executive Mervyn Davies at a London press conference. Standard Chartered said KFB wa a "well-managed, conservatively run bank with a highly skilled workforce" and represented a "significant acquisition in a growth market". In London, Standard Chartered's sale of 118 million new share to institutional investor pushed it share price down, and contributing to the FTSE 100's 0.3% decline. Standard Chartered's share were 28 penny lower at 925p by midday. Some analyst also queried whether Standard Chartered had overpaid for KFB. The deal, which requires regulatory approval, is expected to be completed by April 2005 and to be earnings accretive in 2006, Standard Chartered said. Rival banking giant HSBC, which is based in London and Hong Kong, wa also in the running. Standard Chartered is believed to have gained the initiative by putting together a bid during the Christmas break. "They were able to move so quickly it caught HSBC by surprise," the Financial Times newspaper quoted an insider in the talk a saying. HSBC will now have to wait for the next South Korean bank in line to be sold off - thought likely to be Korea Exchange Bank, also currently in the hand of a US group. Standard Chartered said it wa buying 100% of KFB, an agreement that would bring an end to the bank's complex dual ownership. The South Korean government owns 51.4% of KFB, while the remaining shareholding, and operational control, are in the hand of US private equity group Newbridge Capital. Newbridge bought it stake during the government's nationalisation of several bank in the wake of the 1997 Asia-wide currency crisis which crippled South Korea's financial institutions. South Korea's economy is expected to grow by 4.5% this year. Although often thought of an export-driven economy, South Korea's service sector ha overtaken manufacturing in the last decade or so. Services now make up roughly 40% of the economy, and consumer spending and retail banking have become increasingly important. In the aftermath of the Asian financial crisis, the government encouraged the growth of consumer credit. Bad loan problem followed; LG Card, the country's biggest credit card provider, ha been struggling to avoid bankruptcy for months, for instance. But analyst believe South Korea's financial service industry is still in it infancy, offering plenty of scope for new products. Standard Chartered see "the opportunity to create value by the introduction of more sophisticated banking products". Since 1999, KFB ha been restructured from a wholesale bank into a retail bank focused on mortgage lending, which make up 45% of it loans.

Title: Celtic make late bid for Bellamy
Article: Newcastle striker Craig Bellamy is discussing a possible short-term loan move to Celtic, BBC Sport understands. The Welsh striker ha rejected a move to Birmingham after falling out with Magpies manager Graeme Souness. The Toon bos vowed Bellamy would not play again after a bitter row over his exclusion for the game against Arsenal. Celtic are in no position to match Birmingham's Â£6m offer but a stay until the end of the season could suit Bellamy while he considers his future. According to Bellamy's agent, the player dismissed a permanent move to Birmingham. And it is unlikely that Newcastle would allow the player to go on loan to another Premiership club. Bellamy wa fined two weeks' wage after a live TV interview in which he accused Souness of lying, following a very public dispute about what position Bellamy should play in the side. Souness said: "He can't play for me ever again. He ha been a disruptive influence from the minute I walked into this football club. "He can't go on television and accuse me of telling lies." Chairman Freddy Shepherd described Bellamy's behaviour a "totally unacceptable and totally unprofessional".

Title: Beattie return calms attack fears
Article: Everton striker James Beattie ha been declared fit for training on Tuesday, despite suffering an alleged assault last Saturday. Beattie, 27, is not believed to be a seriously hurt a some report have suggested after being "the victim of an unprovoked assault" in Birmingham. He wa on a night out with his girlfriend and two friend following Everton's 3-1 win over Aston Villa. "He wa shaken but not badly injured," said Everton spokesman Ian Ross. He added: "He did speak to the police but will not be pressing charges. "He ha spoken to manager David Moyes about what happened." Beattie wa suspended for the win at Aston Villa after his red card against Chelsea and he will be available again for the Merseyside derby at Liverpool on 20 March.

Title: Blair told to double overseas aid
Article: Tony Blair is being urged to use all his negotiating power to end poor countries' debt and double aid. Some 45 million child will die needlessly before 2015 and aid budget are half their 1960 levels, Oxfam say in a report, Paying the Price. The call come a the prime minister prepares to assume the presidency of the G8 of top industrialised nations. "As rich country get richer, they're giving less and less. This scandal must stop," Oxfam's Barbara Stocking said. "The world's poorest child are paying for rich countries' policy in aid and debt with their lives. "2005 offer the chance for an historic breakthrough, but unless world leader act now the year will end in shameful failure," the charity's director added. The report said: "For rich countries, providing aid to help to end global poverty is an obligation and a matter of justice, not an act of charity." It also point out that in 1970 the G8 of top industrialised nation agreed to spend 0.7% of their income on aid. But 34 year later none of the organisation member have reached this target and many have not yet set a timetable, the report says. It argues that the price of not investing in poor countries' sustainable development will be felt across the world. The report said: "Global poverty threatens our shared prosperity and security. "Environmental crisis and natural disasters, disease and drug trafficking know no national borders. Poverty heightens the likelihood of conflict and unrest. "New threat to the peace and security of rich nation arise from poverty and gross inequalities. "Criminal and terrorist network are more likely to operate where state institution are weak." Both the prime minister and Chancellor Gordon Brown have called for urgent action to fight world poverty. Mr Blair, who ha described Africa a a "scar" on the world's conscience, ha already said tackling world poverty would be one his G8 priority along with climate change and the Aids epidemic. Mr Brown ha also pledged to write off the debt owed to Britain by the world's poor nations. A spokeswoman for the Department for International Development said: "The government had made a clear commitment to reaching 0.7% of gross national income for overseas development aid by 2013. "If Britain's proposal for an International Finance Facility were adopted, the objective of 0.7% could be achieved earlier, by 2008-09. "These additional resource will be used to increase UK bilateral aid to Africa to at least Â£1.25bn a year by 2008 and spend at least Â£1.5bn on HIV/Aids related work over the next three years."

Title: Apple unveils low-cost 'Mac mini'
Article: Apple ha unveiled a new, low-cost Macintosh computer for the masses, billed a the Mac mini. Chief executive Steve Jobs showed off the new machine at his annual MacWorld speech, in San Francisco. The $499 Macintosh, sold for Â£339 in the UK, wa described by Jobs a the "most important Mac" made by Apple. Mr Jobs also unveiled the iPod shuffle, a new music player using cheaper flash memory rather than hard drives, which are used in more expensive iPods. The new computer shift the company into new territory - traditionally, the firm is known a a design and innovation-led firm rather than a a mass-market manufacturer. The Mac mini come without a monitor, keyboard and mouse, and a second version with a larger hard drive will also be sold for $599. The machine - which will be available from 22 January - wa described by Jobs a "BYODKM... bring your own display, keyboard, and mouse". In an attempt to win over Windows PC customers, Mr Jobs said it would appeal to people thinking of changing operating systems. "People who are thinking of switching will have no more excuses," he said. "It's the newest and most affordable Mac ever." The new computer ha been the subject of speculation for several week and while few people will be surprised by the announcement many analyst had already said it wa a sensible move. In January, Apple sued a website after it published what it said were specification for the new computer. Ian Harris, deputy editor of UK magazine Mac Format, said the machine would appeal to PC-owning consumer who had purchased an iPod. "They want a further taste of Mac because they like what they have seen with iPod." Harris added: "Everybody thought that Apple wa happy to remain a niche maker of luxury computers, and moving into a market dominated by low margin manufacturer like Dell is a bold move. "But it show that Apple is keen to capitalise on the mass market success it's had with the iPod. The Mac mini will appeal to PC user looking for an attractive, 'no fuss' computer." The new iPod shuffle come in two version - one offering 512mb of storage for $99 (Â£69 in the Uk) and a second with one gigabyte of storage for $149 (Â£99) - and went on sale Tuesday. The music player ha no display and will play song either consecutively or shuffled. The smaller iPod will hold about 120 songs, said Mr Jobs. Mr Jobs told the delegate at MacWorld that iPod already had a 65% market share of all digital music players.

Title: Virus poses as Christmas e-mail
Article: Security firm are warning about a Windows virus disguising itself a an electronic Christmas card. The Zafi.D virus translates the Christmas greeting on it subject line into the language of the person receiving infected e-mail. Anti-virus firm speculate that this multilingual ability is helping the malicious program spread widely online. Anti-virus firm Sophos said that 10% of the e-mail currently on the net wa infected with the Zafi virus. Title: Electronics firms eye plasma deal
Article: Consumer electronics giant Hitachi and Matshushita Electric are joining force to share and develop technology for flat screen televisions. The tie-up come a the world's top producer are having to contend with falling price and intense competition. The two Japanese company will collaborate in research & development, production, marketing and licensing. They said the agreement would enable the two company to expand the plasma display TV market globally. Plasma display panel are used for large, thin TVs which are replacing old-style televisions. The display market for high-definition television is split between model using plasma display panel and others - manufactured by the like of Sony and Samsung - using liquid-crystal display (LCDs). The deal will enable Hitachi and Matsushita, which make Panasonic brand products, to develop new technology and improve their competitiveness. Hitachi recently announced a deal to buy plasma display technology from rival Fujitsu in an effort to strengthen it presence in the market. Separately, Fujitsu announced on Monday that it is quitting the LCD panel market by transferring it operation in the area to Japanese manufacturer Sharp. Sharp will inherit staff, manufacturing facility and intellectual property from Fujitsu. The plasma panel market ha seen rapid consolidation in recent month a the price of consumer electronic good and component ha fallen. Samsung Electronics and Sony are among other company working together to reduce cost and speed up new product development.

Title: Russian film wins BBC world prize
Article: Russian drama The Return (Vozvrashchenie) ha been named winner of the BBC Four World Cinema Award. The film tell the story of two adolescent boy who are subjected to a harsh regime when their strict father return after a 10-year absence. Directed by Andrey Zvyagintsev, The Return previously won the 2003 Golden Lion award at the Venice Film Festival. The prize wa presented at an award ceremony held in London on Thursday and hosted by Jonathan Ross. The winner wa chosen by a panel which included X Files actress Gillian Anderson, critic Roger Clarke and Touching the Void director Kevin McDonald. Ross, who is the presenter of BBC One's Film 2005, wa also involved in the deliberations. A shortlist of six film from around the world had been drawn up from which the panel chose. Other nominee included the Motorcycle Diaries, Zatoichi and Hero. A viewer poll saw director Zhang Yimou's martial art epic Hero emerge a the favourite with 32% of vote cast. Tragedy struck the production of The Return when one of the young stars, 15-year-old Vladimir Girin, drowned in a lake where some of the film's scene were set. The winner of the World Cinema Award last year wa the French animated feature Belleville Rendezvous

Title: J&J agrees $25bn Guidant deal
Article: Pharmaceutical giant Johnson & Johnson ha agreed to buy medical technology firm Guidant for $25.4bn (Â£13bn). Guidant is a key producer of equipment that combat heart problem such a implant defibrillator and pacemakers. Analysts said that the deal is aimed at offsetting Johnson & Johnson's reliance on a slowing drug business. They also pointed out that more merger are likely because the drug and healthcare industry are fragmented and are under pressure to cut costs. A number of Johnson & Johnson's product are facing patent expirations, while the company is also battling fierce competition from generic products. Meanwhile, demand for defibrillators, which give the heart a small electric shock when an irregular heartbeat or rhythm is detected, is expected to increase, analyst said. The move by Johnson & Johnson ha been widely expected and the firm will pay $76 for each Guidant share, 6% more than Wednesday's closing price. Analysts say that US antitrust regulator could force the firm to shed some overlapping stent operations. Stents are tube that are used to keep an artery open after it ha been unblocked.

Title: Cairn shares slump on oil setback
Article: Shares in Cairn Energy, a UK oil firm, have closed down 18% after a disappointing drilling update and a warning over possible tax demands. The company said test had shown no significant find in one of it Indian oil fields, but wa upbeat about the potential of other areas. It also said the Indian government had told it to pay a production tax, for which Cairn argues it is not liable. Cairn's share have jumped by almost 400% this year. Investors had piled into Cairn after the company announced significant oil find in India this year. Chief executive Bill Gammell said on Friday he wa "disappointed" with exploration in the so-called N-C extension area in Rajasthan. Investors had held high hope of major oil find in this area. But Cairn said estimate had been revised in what wa a "significant downgrade of the initial expectation". Cairn also said that the government believed the company wa liable to pay tax under it production-sharing contract. The company said the rate would be about 900 rupee ($20.40; Â£10.50) per tonne, or seven barrels, of oil. A spokesman for the firm said that the tax would wipe 5% of the field's current value. "Cairn refutes the government's position," Mr Gammell said. He insisted that the contract made it clear that the tax should be shouldered by the licensee - India's state-run Oil & Natural Gas Corp (ONGC) - and not the contractor. "We have a pretty strong legal case here," he added, saying it would only become an issue once the firm started production. Investors took a dim view of the statement though. The share closed down 247p, or 18%, at 1115 pence. "I think people were slightly over-ambitious for how quickly Cairn would be able to develop and potentially offload these reserves," said analyst Jason Kenney at ING. The disappointment overshadowed increased production target for Cairn's existing oilfields. The company raised target for it Mangala and Aishwariya field in India from 60,000 barrel a day to between 80,000 and 100,000 barrel a day. Its Mangala field, thought to contain a billion barrels, is it biggest find to date. "These two field will provide the core of the future development in Rajasthan," Mr Gammell said. Cairn added that it would be appraising another field early next year. Mr Gammell set up the company in the 1980s and ha successfully switched it focus to South Asia from interest in the US and Europe. Cairn, which also operates in Nepal and Bangladesh, wa catapulted into the FTSE 100 index of leading UK share earlier this year after the sharp rise in it share price.
