Title: When technology gets personal
Article: In 2020, whipping out your mobile phone to make a call will be quaintly passé. By then phone will be printed directly on to wrists, or other part of the body, say Ian Pearson, BT's resident futurologist. It's all part of what's known a a "pervasive ambient world", where "chips are everywhere". Mr Pearson doe not have a crystal ball. His job is to formulate idea based on what science and technology are doing now, to guide industry into the future. Inanimate object will start to interact with us: we will be surrounded - on streets, in homes, in appliances, on our body and possibly in our head - by thing that "think". Forget local area network - these will be body area networks. Ideas about just how smart, small, or even invisible, technology will get are always floating around. Images of device clumsily bolted on to head or wrist have pervaded thinking about future technology. But now a new vision is surfacing, where smart fabric and textile will be exploited to enhance functionality, form, or aesthetics. Such material are already starting to change how gadget and electronics are used and designed. So MP3 player - the mass gadget of the moment - will disappear and instead become integrated into one's clothing, say Mr Pearson. "So the gadget that fill up your handbag, when we integrate those into fabric, we can actually get rid of all that stuff. You won't necessarily see the electronics." Wearable technology could exploit body heat to charge it up, while "video tattoos", or intelligent electronic contact lenses, might function a TV screen for those on the move. However, this future of highly personal devices, where technology is worn, or even fuse with the body itself, raise ethical questions. If technology is going to be increasingly part of clothing, jewellery, and skin, there need to be some serious thinking about what it mean for u a humans, say Baroness Susan Greenfield. At a recent conference for technology, engineering, academic and fashion industry experts, at the Royal Society in London, neuroscientist Baroness Greenfield cautioned we "can't just sleepwalk into the future". Yet this technology is already upon us. Researchers have developed computer and sensor worn in clothing. MP3 jackets, based on the idea that electrically conductive fabric can connect to keyboard sewn into sleeves, have already appeared in shops. These "smart fabrics" have come about through advance in nano- and micro-engineering - the ability to manipulate and exploit material at micro or molecular scale. At the nanoscale, material can be "tuned" to display unusual property that can be exploited to build faster, lighter, stronger and more efficient device and systems. The textile and clothing industry ha been one of the first to exploit nanotechnology in quite straightforward ways. Many development are appearing in real product in the field of medicine, defence, healthcare, sports, and communications. Professional swimming suit reduce drag by incorporating tiny structure similar to shark skin. Nanoscale titanium dioxide (TiO2) coating give fabric antibacterial and anti-odour properties. These have special property which can be activated in contact with the air or UV light. Such coating have already been used to stop sock smelling for instance, to turn airline seat into super stain-resistant surfaces, and applied to window so they clean themselves. Dressings for wound can now incorporate nanoparticles with biocidal property and smart patch are being developed to deliver drug through the skin. But Baroness Greenfield is concerned about how far this more personal contact with technology might affect our very being. If our clothing, skin, and "personal body networks" do the talking and the monitoring, everywhere we go, we have to think about what that mean for our concept of privacy. Mr Pearson pick up the theme, pointing out there are a lot of issue human have to iron out before we become "cyborgian". His main concern is "privacy". "We are looking at electronics which are really in deep contact with your body and a lot of that information you really don't want every passer-by to know. "So we have to make sure we build security in this. If you are wearing smart make-up, where electronics are controlling the appearance, you don't want people hacking in and writing message on your forehead." As technology infiltrates our biology, how will our brain function differently? "We cannot arrogantly assume that the human brain will not change with this," warns Baroness Greenfield. There have already been successful experiment to grow human nerve cell on circuit boards. This pave the way for brain implant to help paralysed people interface directly with computers. Clearly, the organic, carbon of our body and silicon is increasingly merging. The cyborg - a very familiar part-human, part-inorganic science fiction and academic idea - is on it way.

Title: Wenger shock at Newcastle dip
Article: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger ha admitted he is at a loss to explain why Newcastle are languishing in the bottom half of the table. The Gunners travel to St James' Park on Wednesday, with Newcastle 14th in the Premiership after a troubled season. And Wenger said: "At the beginning of the season you would expect them to be fighting for the top four. "I don't know how they got to be where they are. It look to me from the outside that they have many injuries." Arsenal go into the game on the back of a 2-0 victory over Fulham on Sunday. And Wenger added: "The best way to prepare for a game is to win the previous one. We will go to Newcastle in good shape. "Fatigue won't play too big a part in the next few week a we have player coming back so I can rotate a bit more. "We do not play a season with 11 player and I believe that all of our squad deserve a chance in the team." Striker Thierry Henry, along with Robert Pires, scored against Fulham. And Henry afterwards described the display a "beautiful to watch". He said: "What matter is winning and the three points, of course. That is the only thing that really matters. But it is more enjoyable when you play like we did against Fulham. "We are playing a a team and that is important because there were some game when we maybe were not there a a team and suffered for that. Those were game we lost."

Title: Boateng to step down at election
Article: Paul Boateng, Chief Secretary to the Treasury, is to step down a a Labour MP at the forthcoming general election. Mr Boateng, 53, is to become the UK's high commissioner to South Africa. He wa the UK's first black cabinet minister when appointed to his post in 2002, promoted from the Home Office, where he had been prison minister. Mr Boateng served on the Greater London Council before being elected to Parliament in 1987, declaring "today Brent South, tomorrow Soweto". He will succeed the previous High Commissioner, Ann Grant, shortly after the next election, which is widely expected to be held on 5 May. The appointment is dependent on Labour's re-election. Prime Minister Tony Blair said: "Paul ha been both a valued colleague and a trusted friend for many years. "He ha made an immense contribution to public life in Britain and I am delighted that he ha agreed to continue that service to the people of Britain by acting a their representative in South Africa." Chancellor Gordon Brown said: "Over the past eight year Paul's contribution to the Treasury and the government ha been exceptional - and it ha been my privilege to have worked closely with him closely at the Treasury. "I congratulate Paul on his new appointment. "He ha displayed huge dedication to the cause of African development for many year and it is fitting that, in this year of challenge and opportunity for the African continent, Paul ha been given such a pivotal role in our fight against poverty and injustice. "I look forward to continuing to work with Paul on this vital agenda." Mr Boateng said: "I am honoured to be asked to take on this role, especially a it come at such an integral time for our relationship with South Africa and the African continent. "There shall be many new challenge and opportunity ahead and I look forward to embracing them with great anticipation." Asked if he wa appointed a the result of a "fair and open" competition, he replied: "I have been appointed a a result of a process that's been used before by Labour and Conservative government to appoint people of all party who have relevant experience." Mr Boateng also laughed off suggestion that his re-election in Brent South seat had been in danger saying it wa "one of the safest Labour seat in the country". Shadow foreign secretary Michael Ancram said that, if in government, he would refuse to approve either Mr Boateng's appointment or that of ex-Cabinet minister Helen Liddell a high commissioner to Australia. "Mr Blair's appointment of Paul Boateng is the latest example of a worrying trend of failed Tony's crony being appointed to senior diplomatic posts," he said.

Title: Police probe BNP mosque leaflet
Article: Police are investigating a British National Party leaflet posted to home in south Wales opposing plan for a new mosque. Anti-racism campaigner in Swansea have handed copy to South Wales Police. Swansea's Muslim community is raising money to open a new mosque and community centre in the former St Andrews United Reform Church. The building on George Street ha been derelict since the 1980s. Taha Idris, director of the Swansea Bay Race Equality Council, said his organisation contacted police after receiving complaint from the public. "I'm quite shocked to see this sort of leaflet by the BNP in Swansea," he said. "The BNP ha tried in the past to get into Swansea and this is another example of them trying again. "I am in no doubt that the BNP are not needed and not wanted here." A South Wales Police spokeswoman confirmed that they were looking at the content of the leaflet. According to the BNP's website, they have been posted to home in the Castle ward. The BNP website carry a photograph of party leader Nick Griffin - who life near Welshpool, mid Wales - delivering the leaflet. The BNP ha denied it is trying to stir up hatred of any race or religion, but argues that they should be able to debate this without fear of arrest. Swansea Unite Against Fascism (UAF) is meeting this week to plan a campaign. Following the death earlier this year of Kalan Kawa Karim, an Iraqi Kurd living in Swansea, it organised an anti-racism march in the city that wa supported by more than 1,000 people. It is planning it own mail shot campaign and may launch a petition in support of the plan for the mosque. Andy Richards, of Swansea UAF, said the leaflet wa exactly what he had come to expect from the BNP. "The people of Swansea will not put up with this." Swansea's Muslim community bought the former church, just across the road from the existing mosque on St Helen's Road, in the late 1990s. Title: BP surges ahead on high oil price
Article: Oil giant BP ha announced a 26% rise in annual profit to $16.2bn (Â£8.7bn) on the back of record oil prices. Last week, rival Shell reported an annual profit of $17.5bn - a record profit for a UK-listed company. BP added that it wa increasing it fourth-quarter dividend by 26% to 8.5 cents, and that it would continue with share buybacks. BP chief executive Lord Browne said the result were strong "both operationally and financially." The company is earning about $1.8m an hour. Despite the record annual profit figure, BP's performance wa below the expectation of some City analysts. However, BP's share price rose 4p or nearly 1% in morning trading to 548p. Its profit rise for the year included profit of $3.65bn (Â£1.97bn) for the final three month of 2004 - up from $2.89bn a year ago but below it third quarter. Speaking on the BBC's Today programme on Tuesday, Lord Browne said the profit were not solely down to the high oil price alone. "The profit are up more than the price of oil is up," he said. Lord Browne pointed out that BP wa reaping the benefit of it investment in oil exploration. "We have spent many year buying (assets) when the price is low," he said. The company ha made new discovery in Egypt, the Gulf of Mexico and Angola. However, Lord Browne rejected call for a windfall tax on his company's huge profits, saying that in the North Sea it paid progressively more tax, the more profit it made. Lord Browne belief oil price will remain quite high. Currently above $40 a barrel, he said: "The price of oil will be well supported above $30 a barrel for the medium term." BP put production for the year at 3.997 billion barrel of oil, up 10% on 2003, but slightly lower than the four billion barrel it had initially aimed for.

Title: Collins appeals against drugs ban
Article: Sprinter Michelle Collins ha lodged an appeal against her eight-year doping ban with the North American Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). The 33-year-old received the ban last month a a result of her connection to the federal inquiry into the Balco doping scandal. She is the first athlete to be banned without a positive drug test or an admission of drug use. CAS ha said that a ruling is normally given within four month of an appeal. Collins wa suspended by the US Anti-Doping Agency based on pattern observed in her blood and urine test a well a evidence in the Balco investigation. As well a being hit with the ban, Collins wa stripped of her 2003 world and US indoor 200m titles. The San Francisco-based Balco laboratory is at the centre of the scandal which ha rocked the sport. The company ha been accused of distributing illegal performance-enhancing drug to elite athletes.

Title: Firms pump billions into pensions
Article: Employers have spent billion of pound propping up their final salary pension over the past year, research suggests. A survey of 280 scheme by Incomes Data Services' (IDS) said employer contribution had increased from Â£5.5bn to Â£8.2bn a year, a rise of 49.7%. Companies facing the biggest deficit had raised their pension contribution by 100% or more, IDS said. Many firm are struggling to keep this type of scheme open, because of rising cost and increased liabilities. A final salary scheme, also known a a defined benefit scheme, promise to pay a pension related to the salary the scheme member is earning when they retire. The rising cost of maintaining such scheme ha led many employer to replace final salary scheme with money purchase, or defined contribution, schemes. These are less risky for employers. Under money purchase schemes, employee pay into a pension fund which is used to buy an annuity - a policy which pay out an income until death - on retirement. IDS said there were some scheme in good health. But, in many cases, firm had been forced to top up fund to tackle "yawning deficits". The level of contribution paid by employer ha increased gradually since the late 1990s. In 1998/99, for example, contribution rose by 4.7% and in 2002/03 by 8.6%. In contrast, between 1996 and 1998, some employer cut their contribution levels. Helen Sudell, editor of the IDS Pensions Service, said the rise in contribution wa "staggering" and the highest ever recorded by IDS. "We have warned before that the widespread closure of final salary scheme to new entrant is just the beginning of a much bigger movement away from paternalistic provision," said Ms Sudell. "With figure like this there can be little doubt that many employer will have to reduce future benefit at some point for those staff still in these schemes."

Title: Kidman wins photographer battle
Article: Actress Nicole Kidman ha won a restraining order against two paparazzo photographer who she claim left her fearful of leaving her Sydney mansion. The Oscar-winning star took action against Jamie Fawcett and Ben McDonald after a bugging device wa found outside her home earlier this week. Lawyers for the pair denied allegation they had planted the device. The Australian actress is currently in Sydney to film her latest movie, Eucalyptus, with Russell Crowe. Kidman wa prompted to take action following a reported high-speed car chase with member of the paparazzo in Sydney last weekend. According to local newspaper the Daily Telegraph, the incident involved paparazzo driving through red light and on the wrong side of the road in pursuit of Kidman's vehicle. Lawyers for Mr Fawcett and Mr McDonald denied that the pair were involved in the chase. Kidman sought the "apprehended violence" order - normally used in Australia in case of domestic violence and similar incident - after being advised to do so by local police. "Nicole would like to make it clear that she acknowledges she is a public figure and that reporter and photographer have a job to do and she respect that," said Kidman's publicist Wendy Day. "However, these are specific action against two individual who, over a period of time, have caused her to feel threatened, intimidated and unable to leave her home without fearing for her safety." Magistrate Lee Gilmore, who issued the restraining order at Waverley Local Court in Sydney, said she understood the photographer were entitled to earn a living but there had to be limit to their behaviour. "Miss Kidman say she's willing to put up with some of it, but it's gone beyond that," she said. "I do believe the allegation in relation to the driving is a serious issue."

Title: Mido makes third apology
Article: Ahmed 'Mido' Hossam ha made another apology to the Egyptian people in an attempt to rejoin the national team. The 21-year-old told a news conference in Cairo on Sunday that he is sorry for the problem that have led to his exclusion from the Pharaohs since July last year. Mido said: "There isn't much I have to say today, all there is to say is that I came specially from England to Egypt to rejoin the national team and to apologise for all my mistakes." Mido wa axed by former coach Marco Tardelli after failing to answer a national call-up, claiming he had a groin injury. But he then played in a friendly for his club AS Roma within 24 hour of a World Cup qualifying match at home to Cameroon last September. Mido added: "It's not my right to give order and say when I want to play ... at the same time I will always make sure that I put the national's team's match a my top priority. "I feel that the national player are playing with a new spirit a I saw them play against Belgium (Egypt won 4-0 on Wednesday) and I simply want to add to their success. "I do confess that I wa rude to the Egyptian press at time but now I have gained more experience and know that I will never go anywhere without the press's support. "Many of the international star like David Beckham and (Zinedine) Zidane had the press opposing them. "So I'm now used to the fact that the press can be against me at time and I don't have to overreact when this happens. Meanwhile, Egypt FA spokesman Methat Shalaby welcomed the apology and said no one had exerted pressure on Mido to apologise. "Mido's apology today doe not negatively affect Mido in anyway, on the contrary it make him a bigger star and a role model for all football players," Shalaby said. Shalaby earlier said that after an apology Mido would be available for the national side if coach Hassan Shehata chose him. Mido joined Tottenham in an 18-month loan deal near the end of the January transfer window, scoring twice on his debut against Portsmouth.

Title: Labour battle plan 'hides Blair'
Article: The Tories have accused Tony Blair of being "terrified" of scrutiny after Labour unveiled detail of how it will fight the next general election. In a break with tradition, the party will ditch the leader's battle bus and daily press briefing in Westminster. Instead Mr Blair will travel to key city and marginal seat to deliver the party's message. Labour election chief Alan Milburn denied the party wa trying to "hide" the prime minister. He promised "the most positive and upbeat election campaign Labour ha ever run". But Tory co-chairman Liam Fox said Labour's plan showed Mr Blair wa "terrified of facing proper scrutiny". "At a time when the British people are looking for more accountability and openness, this government turn it back on them; abandoning plan to tour the country and scared to face journalist in a press conference - it doe rather beg the question, 'What have they got to hide?'" The general election is widely expected next May and all the party are stepping up their campaign preparations. Mr Milburn said the economy would take centre stage in Labour's campaign in what would be a "watershed" election and the "last stand of the Thatcherites". Mr Milburn said Labour's slogan would be "Britain is working - Don't let the Tories wreck it." The tone of the campaign, said Mr Milburn, would be more conversational than rhetorical; more spontaneous less scripted; less national more local and less based on issue and more concentrated on people. The approach is particularly designed to appeal to woman voters, he said. Mr Milburn brushed aside question over why the chancellor wa not present at the Cabinet meeting to discus election strategy particularly since such importance wa being given to the economy. "I'm not privy to everybody's diary," he said. Mr Brown ha headed Labour's preparation for previous poll but Mr Milburn is taking that role this time. In a break with the past, Labour will not hold a daily news conference in London. It will not be a "battle bus" style campaign either, he said. In previous elections, each party leader ha had their own battle bus transporting national newspaper, television and radio reporter to staged campaign event around the country. Mr Milburn said Labour's medium effort this time would focus more on local newspaper and broadcasters, with every local radio station given the chance to interview the prime minister. Mr Milburn said there would also be a greater effort to set up face-to-face meeting between minister and the electorate. Former Downing Street medium chief Alastair Campbell is also returning to advise Labour on medium strategy and campaigning. Mr Milburn said no decision had been taken yet over whether David Blunkett would have a prominent role in the election. Liberal Democrat chief executive Lord Rennard suggested Labour wa avoiding news conference in London because it wanted less scrutiny of it record and proposals. "Tony Blair seems to have disappeared from Labour leaflet and broadcasts," he said. "In contrast Charles Kennedy will feature prominently in the Liberal Democrat campaign right across the country."

Title: Lawyer attacks anti-terror laws
Article: A senior barrister who ha resigned in protest over the government's anti-terror law say the current system is giving Britain a bad name. Ian MacDonald QC quit when the government failed to recognise a House of Lords ruling that detaining terror suspect indefinitely is unlawful. He wa part of a 19-strong panel who have special security clearance to act for suspected terrorists. Five more barrister are now reported to be threatening to resign. Mr MacDonald told BBC News: "The reason why I am resigning is because I fundamentally disagree with locking people up without any trial for an indefinite period on reasonable suspicion. "The current legal system is certainly having a very adverse effect on the Muslim community in Britain and the whole Asian community. "I think it is giving Britain a bad name internationally". Under the Anti-Terrorism, Crime and Security Act introduced by the government in 2001 in response to the 11 September attacks, foreign national suspected of involvement in terrorism who cannot be deported can be held indefinitely without trial. But Mr MacDonald belief that detainee currently being held should be entitled to a trial by jury. "My own view is we need to have a full return to trial by jury, a proper criminal trial with proper accusations. "As far a I'm concerned, the government have to start all over again and rethink their whole strategy for dealing with this." he added. The Attorney General Lord Goldsmith will receive a letter of resignation from Mr MacDonald on Monday. According to the Independent, his resignation is expected to be followed by those of five other barrister - Nicholas Blake QC, Andrew Nicol QC, Manjit Singh Gill QC, Rick Scannell and Tom de la Mare. They are all believed to be carefully considering their position on the panel of Special Advocates who represent detainee before the Special Immigration Appeals Commission (SIAC) - a secure court without a jury, which try terror suspects. Mr MacDonald said he had "no idea" whether further resignation would follow. But Barry Hugill, a spokesman for the campaign group Liberty, told Radio 4's Today programme that more lawyer may go. "I can assure that there is a distinct possibilty that more lawyer may be resigning," he said. "They are now in a situation where everything they have been trained to believe in, the right to trial by jury, ha been abandoned and that is what give some of them sleepless nights." Helena Kennedy, a Labour peer and a human right lawyer, said the Special Advocates' main concern wa that once they had seen any special intelligence they were not allowed to speak to the detainees. "When this whole procedure wa being considered immediately after 11 September there wa a great deal of argument particularly in the House of Lords about whether there really wa a process that could be considered a judicial review," she said. "Without that you are having detention with no habeus corpus and really a blot, a Ian McDonald ha said, on our legal landscape, something really quite shocking with regard to the rule of the law."

Title: Wales get Williams fitness boost
Article: Wales are hopeful that openside flanker Martyn Williams could be fit for Saturday's RBS 6 Nations championship opener against England in Cardiff. Williams wa expected to miss the match with a disc problem in his neck, but ha been making a speedy recovery. "He will have test in the next 48 hour and we are pretty optimistic he is getting there," Wales' team physiotherapist Mark Davies said. "It ha been frustrating but he is on the mend, he ha made good progress." Last week Williams, along with fellow flanker Colin Charvis - who is unlikely to play for at least a month while he recovers from a foot injury - wa all but ruled out of the Millennium Stadium clash. With Williams initially thought to be struggling, the sign pointed towards Wales coach Mike Ruddock handing a first cap to former Wales Under-21 skipper Richie Pugh. Cardiff Blues flanker Williams, 29, offer considerable experience and if he is declared fit then Ruddock might be tempted to include him in the back row. Charvis will be reviewed by the Wales medical staff next Monday, but Davies admitted that there wa only an "outside chance" of him being fit to face France in Wales' third championship game on 26 February. Wales' other injury concern is Pugh's fellow Neath-Swansea Ospreys player Sonny Parker, a the centre ha a trapped nerve in his neck. "Sonny's injury is still an issue," Davies said. "It is still painful and irritable. We will run the rule of thumb over him in the next couple of days." Ruddock will name his starting line-up for the England game at 1830 GMT on Tuesday evening, a Wales target their first victory in Cardiff over the world champion since 1993.

Title: England children's tsar appointed
Article: The first children's commissioner for England ha been appointed. Title: Air Jamaica back in state control
Article: The Jamaican government is regaining control of Air Jamaica in an bid to help the ailing company out of it financial difficulties. The firm ha failed to make money since the state sold a majority stake to hotel tycoon Gordon Stewart in 1994. In common with many carriers, Air Jamaica, with debt of $560m (Â£291m), ha been hit by high fuel cost and the impact of the 11 September attacks. The company will be restructured with the aim of finding a new buyer. "The administration is committed to a viable national airline that will serve a a major catalyst for our economy," said Finance Minister Omar Davies. The 35-year-old airline transport about 55% of all passenger to the island and it pilot are reportedly among the best paid in the industry, with senior member of staff earning in excess of $234,000 a year.

Title: Moya emotional after Davis Cup win
Article: Carlos Moya described Spain's Davis Cup victory a the highlight of his career after he beat Andy Roddick to end the USA's challenge in Seville. Moya made up for missing Spain's 2000 victory through injury by beating Roddick 6-2 7-6 (7-1) 7-6 (7-5) to give the host an unassailable 3-1 lead. "I have woken up so many night dreaming of this day," said Moya. "All my energy ha been focused on today. "What I have lived today I do not think I will live again." Spain's only other Davis Cup title came two year ago in Valencia, when they beat Australia. And Moya, nicknamed Charly, admitted: "The Davis Cup is my dream and I wa a bit nervous at the outset. "Some people have said that I am obsessed but I think that it is better this way. It help me reach my goal if I am obsessed. "It's really incredible - to get the winning point is really something." Spanish captain Jordi Arrese said: "Charly played a great game. It wa his opportunity and he hasn't let u down. "He had lost three time to Roddick, and this wa his day to beat him. "He had been waiting year to be in this position." Spain's victory wa also remarkable for the performance of Rafael Nadal, who beat Roddick in the opening singles. Aged 18 year and 185 days, the Mallorcan became the youngest player to win the Davis Cup. "What a great way to finish the year," said Nadal afterwards. US coach Patrick McEnroe want Roddick and the rest of his team to play more tennis on clay and hone their skill on the surface. "I think it will help these guy even on slow hard court to learn how to mix thing up a little bit and to play a little bit smarter and tactically better." "Obviously it's unrealistic to say that we're going to just start playing constantly on clay, with the schedule. "But certainly I think we can put the work in at the appropriate time and play a couple more event and play against these guy who are the best on this stuff," said McEnroe. Roddick wa left frustrated after losing both his single on the slow clay of Seville's Olympic Stadium. "It's just tough because I felt like I wa in it the whole time against one of the top three clay-courters in the world," said the American. "I had my chance and just didn't convert them. The bottom line is they were just better than u this weekend. "They came out, took care of business and they beat us. It's a simple a that."

Title: Man auctions ad space on forehead
Article: A 20-year-old US man is selling advertising space on his forehead to the highest bidder on website eBay. Andrew Fisher, from Omaha, Nebraska, said he would have a non-permanent logo or brand name tattooed on his head for 30 days. "The way I see it I'm selling something I already own; after 30 day I get it back," he told the BBC Today programme. Mr Fisher ha received 39 bid so far, with the largest bid currently at more than $322 (Â£171). "The winner will be able to send me a tattoo or have me go to a tattoo parlour and get a temporary ink tattoo on my forehead and this will be something they choose, a company name or domain name, perhaps their logo," he told the Radio 4 programme. On the online auction, Mr Fisher describes himself a an "average American Joe, give or take". His sale pitch adds: "Take advantage of this radical advertising campaign and become a part of history." Mr Fisher said that while he would accept any brand name or logo, "I wouldn't go around with a swastika or anything racial". He added: "I wouldn't go around with 666, the mark of the beast. "Other than that I wouldn't promote anything socially unacceptable such a adult website or stores." He said he would use the money to pay college - he is planning to study graphic design. The entrepreneur said his mother wa initially surprised by his decision but following all the medium attention she felt he wa "thinking outside the box".

Title: Telegraph newspapers axe 90 jobs
Article: The Daily and Sunday Telegraph newspaper are axing 90 journalist job - 17% of their editorial staff. The Telegraph Group say the cut are needed to fund an Â£150m investment in new printing facilities. Journalists at the firm met on Friday afternoon to discus how to react to the surprise announcement. The cut come against a background of fierce competition for reader and sluggish advertising revenue amid competition from online advertising. The National Union of Journalists ha called on the management to recall the notice of redundancy by midday on Monday or face a strike ballot. Pearson's Financial Times said last week it wa offering voluntary redundancy to about 30 reporters. The National Union of Journalists said it stood strongly behind the journalist and did not rule out a strike. "Managers have torn up agreed procedure and kicked staff in the teeth by sacking people to pay for printing facilities," said Jeremy Dear, NUJ General Secretary. NUJ official Barry Fitzpatrick said the company had ignored the 90-day consultation period required for company planning more than 10 redundancies. "They have shown a complete disregard for the consultative right of our members," said Mr Fitzpatrick, who added that the company now planned to observe the consultation procedures. The two Telegraph title currently employ 521 journalists. Some broadsheet newspaper - especially those which have not moved to a tabloid format - have suffered circulation declines, which are hitting revenues. The Telegraph ha announced no plan to go tabloid although both The Independent and The Times have seen circulation rise since shrinking in size. The Guardian is hedging it bets, planning a larger tabloid format like those popular in continental Europe. The Telegraph Group wa bought by the Barclay twin - Frederick and David - last year, having previously been owned by Lord Conrad Black's Hollinger International. The brother are currently mulling the sale of another of their businesses, retailer Littlewoods. Telegraph executive Murdoch MacLennan said the two newspaper would add eight colour page in the coming months. "Journalists are the lifeblood of any newspaper, and maintaining the quality of The Daily Telegraph and The Sunday Telegraph for our reader is vital," he said. "However, action to improve our production capability and secure our title against the competition is also vital." Many newspaper are investing in new printing machinery that enables them to print more colour pages, or in some cases, have colour on every page. They are hoping that by boosting colour it will make their publication more attractive to advertiser and reader alike. In recent month News Corp's News International unit, which publishes The Sun and the News of the World, the Guardian Media Group, Trinity Mirror and the Daily Mail & General Trust have all announced substantial investment in new printing plants.

Title: George Michael to perform for BBC
Article: George Michael is to perform live at London's Abbey Road studio a part of a BBC Radio 2 special next month. The session, which will broadcast on 18 December, will also see him talk about how his biggest hit came about. Michael's appearance is part of the station's Sold on Song initiative, which explores the art of songwriting. The station also confirmed that Chris Tarrant will be hosting a one-off New Year's Eve programme. He left London's Capital FM this year after 17 years. The former breakfast show host - who attracted some of the highest rating in Britain, despite only broadcasting to London - will offer his own individual take on the year in the two-hour show. "This should be great fun," Tarrant said. "I've had a fantastic year and I know that lot of other people have a well. I'm definitely looking forward to being on Radio 2." Other Christmas special from Radio 2 include singer Jamelia hosting a Christmas Day concert from the London Community Gospel Choir, while actor Christopher Lee will read Fireside Tales from the like of Edgar Allan Poe, E Nesbit and Ambrose Bierce. Comedian Harry Hill will host a spoof nostalgia show on Christmas Day, while singer Jamie Cullum will perform a live concert for the station.

Title: Dutch bank to lay off 2,850 staff
Article: ABN Amro, the Netherlands' largest bank, is to cut 2,850 job a a result of falling profits. The cut - amounting to 3% of the bank's workforce - will result in a one-off charge of 790m euro ($1.1bn). About 1,100 job will go in investment banking while 1,200 and 550 will go in IT and human resource respectively. ABN Amro is the third large European bank to announce cutback in the past month following Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse Group. Its profitability ha been hit by a fall in mortgage lending in the United States - the bank's largest single market - following recent interest rate rises. ABN Amro's operation in the Netherlands and the United Kingdom will be hardest hit. Jobs will also be lost in the US - which accounted for 46% of profit in the first half of 2004 - and across it operation in the Americas and Asia-Pacific regions. The restructuring is designed to improve efficiency by reducing administrative cost and increasing focus on client service. The bank said it wa on course for a 10% rise in net income this year but operating profit are set to fall because of a fall in US revenues. ABN Amro currently ha more than 100,000 staff. "To get any profit growth in the coming years, they will have to lower costs, so shedding job make total sense," Ivo Geijsen, an analyst with Bank Oyens & Van Eeghen, told Bloomberg. Europe's leading bank seem set for a period of retrenchment. Deutsche Bank said earlier this month it would reduce it German workforce by 1,920 while a many a 300 job will be lost at Credit Suisse First Boston.

Title: O'Sullivan commits to Dublin race
Article: Sonia O'Sullivan will seek to regain her title at the Bupa Great Ireland Run on 9 April in Dublin. The 35-year-old wa beaten into fourth at last year's event, having won it a year earlier. "I understand she's had a solid winter's training down in Australia after recovering from a minor injury," said race director Matthew Turnbull. Mark Carroll, Irish record holder at 3km, 5km and 10km, will make his debut in the mass participation 10km race. Carroll ha stepped up his form in recent week and in late January scored an impressive 3,000m victory over leading American Alan Webb in Boston. Carroll will be facing stiff competition from Australian Craig Mottram, winner in Dublin for the last two years.

Title: Bollywood draws global stars
Article: British actress Antonia Bernath is making her debut in Kisna - the Warrior Poet, marking a growing trend for non-Indian star to appear in Bollywood films. Directed by Bollywood veteran Subhash Ghai, the film is set in the British Raj and Bernath play an army general's daughter who fall in love with a rural boy, Kisna. "I liked the fluid nature of film-making. We improvised quite a lot," say Bernath. "At time it felt very chaotic but Mr Ghai wa quite clear about what he wanted." Picked from more than 200 girl in an audition in London, Bernath cut short her education at Bristol's Old Vic Theatre School to take up the opportunity. It is not often that somebody get to play the lead role straight out of a drama school. She spent three week learning Hindi and taking dance lessons. "Initially, I wa a bit sceptical about how people would respond to me," Bernath says. "But I found the Hindi film industry very warm and encouraging. I even had a few offer before the work on Kisna wa completed." Films are one of India's biggest export and those like Lagaan and Monsoon Wedding have broken the traditional boundary of colour and culture. Spurred by this, Bollywood producer are trying to go global in all aspect of film-making, be it technical or artistic. From young heart-throbs like Nick Moran of Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels to model Sophie Dahl, many non-Indian star want to make the most of this opportunity. "Bollywood ha truly gone global," say Taran Adarsh, editor of Indian film journal Trade Guide. "Directors are now attempting to woo non-Asian audience to increase their share in the overseas film market." Kisna ha been shot simultaneously in Hindi and English, with the English print shortened by an hour to accommodate the Western audience. The film even ha a song composed in English by AR Rahman, the director of the popular West End musical, Bombay Dreams. "Identification is a popular cinematic device. Use of European or American actor can be viewed a a step in that direction," say Adarsh. The cast of Kisna also includes British actor Michael Maloney, Caroline Langrishe and Polly Adams. Another actress, Annabelle Wallace, play the lead role in a bilingual romantic comedy Dil Jo Bhi Kahey (Whatever the Heart Says), which also star Indian screen legend Amitabh Bachchan. Actor and Producer Aamir Khan's forthcoming venture The Rising is set against the backdrop of the Indian mutiny of 1857, with British actor Toby Stephens in a key role. But it isn't only the Western actor looking eastwards. Bollywood sweetheart Aishwarya Rai, recently seen in Bride and Prejudice alongside New Zealand actor Martin Henderson, is building her international career. And, many other Bollywood star have their eye set on Hollywood. "Hollywood or Bollywood, it's the box office that determines whether something is a passing phase or a trend," say Adarsh. Kisna - the Warrior Poet open in the UK on 21 January.

Title: Microsoft releases bumper patches
Article: Microsoft ha warned PC user to update their system with the latest security fix for flaw in Windows programs. In it monthly security bulletin, it flagged up eight "critical" security hole which could leave PCs open to attack if left unpatched. The number of hole considered "critical" is more than usual. They affect Windows programs, including Internet Explorer (IE), medium player and instant messaging. Four other important fix were also released. These were considered to be less critical, however. If not updated, either automatically or manually, PC user running the program could be vulnerable to virus or other malicious attack designed to exploit the holes. Article: Partners of those who love their hi-tech gear may want to get their present in early a expert predict a gadget shortage this Christmas. With Apple's iPod topping wish list again, there may not be enough iPod mini to go round, predicts Oliver Irish, editor of gadget magazine Stuff. "The iPod mini is likely to be this year's Tracey Island," said Mr Irish. Stuff ha compiled a list of the top 10 gadget for 2004 and the iPod is at number one. For anyone bewildered by the choice of gadget on the market, Stuff and What Hi-Fi? are hosting a best-of gadget show in London this weekend. Star of the show will be Sony's Qrio Robot, an all-singing, all-dancing, football-playing man-machine who can even hold intelligent conversations. But he is not for sale and Sony ha no commercial plan for the robot. "He will greet visitor and is flying in from Japan. He probably ha his own airplane seat, that is how highly Sony prize him," said Mr Irish. Also on display will be a virtual keyboard which project itself onto any flat surface. The event will play host to a large collection of digital music players, from company such a Creative, Sony and Philips a well a the ubiquitously fashionable iPod from Apple. "Demand is huge and Apple ha promised that it can supply enough but people might struggle to get their hand on iPod minis," said Mr Irish. For those who like their gadget to be multi-talented, the Gizmondo, a powerful gaming console with GPS and GPRS, that also double up a an MP3 player, movie player and camera, could be a must-have. "What is impressive is how much it can do and how well it can do them," said Mr Irish. This Christmas, gadget will not be an all-male preserve. "Women will be getting gadget from husband and boyfriend a well a buying them for themselves," said Mr Irish. "Gadgets nowadays are lifestyle product rather than just for geeks."

Title: Hitachi unveils 'fastest robot'
Article: Japanese electronics firm Hitachi ha unveiled it first humanoid robot, called Emiew, to challenge Honda's Asimo and Sony's Qrio robots. Hitachi said the 1.3m (4.2ft) Emiew wa the world's quickest-moving robot yet. Two wheel-based Emiews, Pal and Chum, introduced themselves to reporter at a press conference in Japan. The robot will be guest at the World Expo later this month. Sony and Honda have both built sophisticated robot to show off development in electronics. Explaining why Hitachi's Emiew used wheel instead of feet, Toshihiko Horiuchi, from Hitachi's Mechanical Engineering Research Laboratory, said: "We aimed to create a robot that could live and co-exist with people." "We want to make the robot useful for people ... If the robot moved slower than people, user would be frustrated." Emiew - Excellent Mobility and Interactive Existence a Workmate - can move at 3.7m/h. Its "wheel feet" resemble the bottom half of a Segway scooter. With sensor on the head, waist, and near the wheels, Pal and Chum demonstrated how they could react to commands. "I want to be able to walk about in place like Shinjuku and Shibuya [shopping districts] in the future without bumping into people and cars," Pal told reporters. Hitachi said Pal and Chum, which have a vocabulary of about 100 words, could be "trained" for practical office and factory use in a little a five to six years. Robotics researcher have long been challenged by developing robot that walk in the gait of a human. At the recent AAAS (American Association for the Advancement of Science) annual meeting in Washington DC, researcher showed off bipedal designs. The three designs, each built by a different research group, use the same principle to achieve a human-like gait. Sony and Honda have both used humanoid robots, which are not commercially available, a a way of showing off computing power and engineering expertise. Honda's Asimo wa "born" five year ago. Since then, Honda and Sony's Qrio have tried to trump each other with what the robot can do at various technology events. Asimo, ha visited the UK, Germany, the Czech Republic, France and Ireland a part of a world tour. Sony's Qrio ha been singing, jogging and dancing in formation around the world too and was, until last year, the fastest robot on two legs. But it record wa beaten by Asimo. It is capable of 3km/h, which it maker claim is almost four time a fast a Qrio. Last year, car maker Toyota also stepped into the ring and unveiled it trumpet-playing humanoid robot. By 2007, it is predicted that there will be almost 2.5 million "entertainment and leisure" robot in homes, compared to about 137,000 currently, according to the United Nations (UN). By the end of that year, 4.1 million robot will be doing job in homes, said the report by the UN Economic Commission for Europe and the International Federation of Robotics. Hitachi is one of the company with home cleaning robot machine on the market.

Title: New media battle for Bafta awards
Article: The BBC lead the nomination for the Bafta Interactive Awards, including one for the Radio Times website and one for Sport Interactive's Euro 2004 coverage. The awards, which were started in 1997, recognise the best websites, digital TV show and CD roms. Other nominee include The Guardian news website, the National Theatre, MTV, the Science Museum and the London Stock Exchange. The winner from 12 different category are crowned on 2 March 2005. There were nearly 400 entry this year - a third more than last year. The BBC ha 16 nomination while The Guardian ha three nominations. "This year's nominee are a testament to the creative and innovative work going on within the industry," said Grant Dean, chair of the interactive committee. Categories include interactive TV, film, digital TV, mobile phone and music. Shaun of the Dead, Oasis' Definitely Maybe, Really Bend It Like Beckham, The Chaplin Collection and The Day Today will battle it out in the DVD category. ITV's Great British Spelling Test take on the BBC's Olympics and Spooks Interactive for the interactive TV award. And the Guardian take three of a possible five nomination in the news and sport category for it website coverage of Euro 2004, the Tour de France and the US elections. The BBC's iCan site is up for the technical and social innovation award alongside the like of Nottingham University's Uncle Roy All Around You. In 2002, the British Academy of Film and Television decided to split the award into separate game and interactive ceremonies, to fully cover the range of innovation outside the gaming industry.

Title: Incredibles win animation awards
Article: The Incredibles movie ha beaten Shrek 2 to the main prize at Hollywood's animation awards, the Annies. The superhero film wa named best animated feature while Brad Bird won best director, writer and voice actor for his role a designer Edna Mode. The Incredibles won a total of 10 award - but Shrek 2, which had seven nominations, went home empty-handed. The two movie will compete with Shark Tale in the best animated film category of the Oscars at the end of February. The Incredibles' award came despite Shrek 2's greater box office success. Shrek 2 took $881m (Â£468m) around the world, compared with $576m (Â£306m) for The Incredibles. SpongeBob SquarePants wa named best animated TV show while TV comedy King of the Hill picked up two prize including one for actress Brittany Murphy's voice work. Tom Kenny, who provides the voice for SpongeBob SquarePants, hosted Sunday's ceremony at the Alex Theater, Los Angeles. The award are handed out by the International Animated Film Society. Finding Nemo won nine Annies last year.

Title: Kennedy criticises 'unfair' taxes
Article: Gordon Brown ha failed to tackle the "fundamental unfairness" in the tax system in his ninth Budget, Charles Kennedy ha said. How wa it right that the poorest 20% of society were still paying more a a proportion of their income than the richest 20%, the Lib Dem leader asked. The new Â£200 council tax rebate for pensioner did nothing to fix the "unfair tax", he added. The government could not go on "patching up" the system, he added. Speaking in the Commons after Mr Brown had delivered what is widely thought to be the last Budget before the general election, Mr Kennedy acknowledged that the UK wa one of the most successful economy in the world. But he criticised both the chancellor and the Tories for failing to address the "ticking bomb" of council tax revaluation. He said the recent experience of Wales indicated seven million household in England would pay significantly more after revaluation. The chancellor's announcement that he wa to offer a Â£200 council tax rebate paid by pensioner household wa merely a "sticking plaster" to a much bigger problem. The Lib Dem plan for a local income tax would benefit the typical household by more than Â£450 a year, with half of all pensioner paying no local tax and about three million being better off. On pensions, Mr Kennedy said it wa a "scandal" that the system discriminated against woman who had missed making National Insurance payment when they were having children. He said a residency criterion would end "at a stroke this fundamental iniquity". Mr Kennedy added his party's priority of free long-term care for the elderly, abolishing top-up fee and replacing the council tax would be funded by charging 50% income tax to those earning more than Â£100,000 per annum. He contrasted his approach with Mr Brown's pledge in 2001 not to increase income tax. The chancellor went on to put up National Insurance contribution after the election. "For most individuals, most families, most households, it add up to exactly the same thing," said Mr Kennedy. "And they wonder why people get cynical about their politician when they give one impression before an election and do exactly the opposite after that election."

Title: Desailly backs Blues revenge trip
Article: Marcel Desailly insists there is no chance of history repeating itself when Chelsea take on Barcelona on Wednesday. The French star wa part of the Chelsea side crushed 5-1 at the Nou Camp in the Champions League quarter-final second leg in 2000. "Things will be totally different this time," he told BBC Sport. "Now everyone know about Chelsea and is a little bit afraid of them. They are one of the major club in Europe and the pressure will be on Barcelona." Chelsea have not played Barcelona since that quarter-final tie five year ago. The Blues had looked destined to progress after winning the first leg at Stamford Bridge 3-1, courtesy of two goal from Tore Andre Flo and one by Gianfranco Zola. But they collapsed in the second leg, going down to strike from Rivaldo (2), Luis Figo, Dani and Patrick Kluivert. Former Chelsea captain Desailly, who is now playing for Al-Gharafa in Qatar, say there is no comparison between that side and the current Blues team, who are top of the Premiership. "Mentally they are much stronger, even though a lot of their player are young," the 36-year-old said. "We made some mistake at the Nou Camp in 2000 - a lot of them were individual mistakes. "It would not happen now. This team ha a new motivation and a different mentality." World Cup winner Desailly saw huge change during his time at Stamford Bridge. He wa signed for Â£4.6m from AC Milan in 1998 by Ruud Gullit and went on to play under Gianluca Vialli and Claudio Ranieri. But the biggest change occurred when billionaire Roman Abramovich bought the club in 2003. Desailly say the Russian's arrival helped to instil a winning mentality at the club a well a a demand for success. "The whole of Chelsea is different now - the chairman, the manager and all the players," he said. "Everything is new and there is a huge determination to win. "Since that game in 2000, Chelsea have gained more experience in Europe and were very close to reaching the Champions League final last season." Desailly is one of the most decorated player in the history of football. He won the 1998 World Cup and 2000 European Championship with France, the Champions League in 1993 with Marseilles and 1994 with AC Milan, two Serie A title and the FA Cup in 2000 with Chelsea. He is now winding down his career in Qatar, alongside the like of Frank Lebeouf, Josep Guardiola, Titi Camara, Gabriel Batistuta and Christophe Dugarry. So he is full of admiration for two of his colleague from the great Milan side of the mid-90s who are likely to line up against Manchester United on Wednesday - Paolo Maldini and Alessandro Costacurta. "I'm happy that they have managed to play so long at a high level," he said. "I made a vow to Costacurta that a long a he plays, I will continue to play. "And it's amazing that Paolo ha managed to play at such a high level for such a long time."

Title: Tarantino to direct CSI episode
Article: Film director Quentin Tarantino is to direct an episode of US television series CSI: Crime Scene Investigation. The Oscar-winning Pulp Fiction director ha also written an original story for the season finale episode. CSI's co-producer, Carol Mendelsohn, said the episode would have "more bug and blood" than usual. It is not Tarantino's first venture into TV. In 1995 he directed an episode of the medical drama ER and ha also appeared in Alias. Ms Mendelsohn said the production team had been trying for a while to get Tarantino to direct an episode of CSI, and added that he wa a fan of the forensic drama. She said he finally agreed a few week ago while CSI wa doing some location shooting in Las Vegas and the show's star persuaded him. "He know everything there is to know about CSI, and he is into the whole mythology of CSI," Mendelsohn said. "Quentin came in a couple of week ago. We had a story meeting with the writers. "He had a great idea, and it wa so much fun to have him in the room... we are positively giddy." Filming is due to start in early April and the Tarantino-directed episode will be broadcast in the US on 19 May.

Title: A November to remember
Article: Last Saturday, one newspaper proclaimed that England were still the number one side in the world. That statement wa made to look a little foolish by event later that afternoon at Twickenham. But it illustrated the wonderful unpredictability of Test rugby at the highest level, at the end of a richly entertaining autumn series. The final weekend threw the world pecking order into renewed confusion, with Australia's triumph in London followed by France's capitulation to New Zealand. "Clearly, there is no number one side in the world at the moment," declared Wallabies coach Eddie Jones on arrival back in Sydney. "There are four, five or probably six side all competing at the same level and on any given day the difference between one side and another is only about 1%." While that bodes well for rugby a a whole, it also sharpens the sense of excitement ahead of what could be the most open Six Nations Championship for a decade. While the Wallabies, All Blacks and Springboks hit the beach before turning their attention to Super 12 matter in the new year, Europe's finest have less than 10 week before they return to the international fray. And for the first time in more than a decade, it will not simply be a straightforward choice between England and France for the Six Nations title. That owes much to Ireland's continued progress and the belief that Wales are on the verge of delivering a major scalp to cement the promise of their autumn displays. , who secured a first Triple Crown in 19 year last season, could go one better and win their first Five/Six Nations title since 1985. They start with away game against Italy and Scotland, before England and France come to Lansdowne Road. Their momentous victory over the Springboks can only bolster Ireland's self-belief, while Ronan O'Gara's late drop goal to deliver victory over Argentina wa further proof that Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now close out tight games. Not that England or France, who have won nine of the last 10 Six Nations title between them, will lay down quietly. dismantling of the Springboks suggested that even after the loss of such influential figure a Martin Johnson and Lawrence Dallaglio, they still have the personnel to prosper. The narrow defeat to Australia wa a timely reminder that not everything is blooming in the red rose garden, but the fresh shoot of post-World Cup recovery have been sown by new head coach Andy Robinson. A fresh desire to regain former height is evident, and if England emerge triumphant from an opening Six Nations engagement in Cardiff, a fourth title in six year is within reach. are in familiar revival territory, but this time it appears there is substance behind the rediscovered style. While South Africa's over-confidence in Cardiff made for a closer scoreline than expected, Wales could legitimately claim to have had victory within their grasp against the All Blacks in one of the best Tests in recent memory. If Mike Ruddock can coax a reliable set-piece platform from his pack, there is no reason why victory should not ensue come February. The last fortnight ha left in a state of bewilderment after an autumn series that began with a superb victory over Australia. A stunning defeat to Argentina, their first loss since the World Cup, could have been attributed to trademark French inconsistency. But the manner of New Zealand's 45-6 demolition job in Paris ha coach Bernard Laporte bemoaning a lack of young talent coming through to replace the old guard. Title: Millions to miss out on the net
Article: By 2025, 40% of the UK's population will still be without internet access at home, say a study. Around 23 million Britons will miss out on a wide range of essential service such a education and medical information, predicts the report by telecom giant BT. It compare to 27 million, or 50%, of the UK, who are not currently online. The idea that the digital divide will evaporate with time is "wishful thinking", the report concludes. The study call on the government and telecom industry to come up with new way to lure those that have been bypassed by the digital revolution. Although the percentage of Britons without home access will have fallen slightly, those that remain digital refuseniks will miss out on more, the report suggests. As more and more everyday task move online and offline service become less comprehensive, the divide will become more obvious and more burdensome for those that have not got net access, it predicts. The gap between "have-nets" and "have-nots" ha been much talked about, but prediction about how such a divide will affect future generation ha been less discussed. BT set out to predict future pattern based on current information and taking account of the way technology is changing. Optimists who predict that convergence and the emergence of more user-friendly technology will bridge the digital divide could be way off mark, the report suggests. "Internet access on other device tends to be something taken up by those who already have it," said Adrian Hosford, director of corporate responsibility at BT. Costs of internet access have fallen dramatically and coverage in remote area have vastly improved over the last year but the real barrier remains psychological. "There is a hard rump of have-not who are not engaging with the net. They don't have the motivation or skill or perceive the benefits," said Mr Hosford. As now, the most disadvantaged group are likely to remain among low income families, the older generation and the disabled. Those on low income will account for a quarter of the digital have-nots, the disabled will make up 16% and the elderly nearly a third by 2025, the report forecasts. Organisations such a BT have a responsibility to help tackle the problem, said Mr Hosford. The telco ha seen positive result with it Everybody Online project which offer internet access to people in eight deprived community around Britain. In one area of Cornwall with high level of unemployment, online training helped people rewrite CVs and learn skill to get new jobs, explained Mr Hosford. Such grassroot activity addressing the specific need of individual community is essential is the problem of the digital divide is to be overcome, he said. "If we don't address this problem now, it will get a lot worse and people will find it more difficult to find jobs, education opportunity will be limited and they'll simply not be able to keep up with society," he said. The Alliance for Digital Inclusion, an independent body with member drawn from government, industry and the voluntary sector ha recently been set up to tackle some of the issue faced by the digital refuseniks.

Title: Web photo storage market hots up
Article: An increasing number of firm are offering web storage for people with digital photo collections. Digital camera were the hot gadget of Christmas 2004 and worldwide sale of the camera totalled $24bn last year. Many people's hard drive are bulging with photo and service which allow them to store and share their picture online are becoming popular. Search firm such a Google are also offering more complex tool for managing personal photo libraries. Photo giant such a Kodak offer website storage which manages photo collections, let user edit picture online and provides print-ordering services. Some services, such a Kodak's Ofoto and Snapfish, offer unlimited storage space but they do require user to buy some print online. Other sites, such a Pixagogo, charge a monthly fee. Marcus Hawkins, editor of Digital Camera magazine, said: "As file size of picture increase, storage becomes a problem. "People are using their hard drives, backing up on CD and DVD and now they are using online storage solutions. "They are a place to store pictures, to share their picture with family and friend and they can print out their photos." While many of the service are aimed at the amateur and casual digital photographer, other website are geared up for enthusiast who want to share tip and information. Photosig is an online community of photographer who can critique each other's work. On Tuesday, Google released free software for organising and finding digital photo stored on a computer's hard drive. The tool, called Picasa, automatically detects photo a they are added to a PC - whether sent via e-mail or transferred from a digital camera. The software includes tool for restoring colour and removing red eye, a well a sharpening images. Photos can then be uploaded to site such a Ofoto. Many people use the site to edit and improve their favourite photograph before ordering prints. Mr Hawkins added: "The growth area is that you can order your print online. Friends and family can also access picture you want them to see and they can print them out too. "Rather than just a place to dump your pictures, it's about sharing them." The vast majority of picture remain on a PC's hard drive, which is why search tools, such a those offered by Google, become increasingly important. But some historian and archivist are concerned that the need for perfect picture will mean that those poor quality print which offered a tantilising glimpse of the past may disappear forever. "It's one thing taking pictures, it's another finding them," said Mr Hawkins. "But this is the same problem that ha always existed - how many of u have photo in wallet tucked away somewhere?"

Title: Lib Dems demand new inquiry
Article: A judge should look into the David Blunkett controversy a key question remain unanswered, the Lib Dems say. Sir Alan Budd's inquiry linked the ex-home secretary to the speeding up of a visa claim by his ex-lover's nanny. But he could not say whether Mr Blunkett had treated the nanny a a special case or had used her a an example of immigration problems. Lib Dem spokesman Mark Oaten said the number of official who had forgotten what happened wa worrying. He told BBC News: "I'm extremely concerned that 20 individual appear to have forgotten what happened or more suspiciously are not prepared to say what happened. "That must be bad for government, it must be bad for public confidence in the system." Mr Oaten said people would be mystified why Sir Alan's inquiry failed to uncover why processing of the visa application wa speeded up. He said: "There is a strong case for a judge-led judicial review of this because, of course, next time it happens it may not be about a nanny and their visa. It may be about something even more important than that. "So we do need to understand what took place and who wa involved." The Tories criticised the Lib Dem stance, saying Mr Oaten had initially said he accepted Mr Blunkett's word unless further evidence emerged. But Lib Dem official say Mr Oaten wa speaking when an inquiry wa under way and wa avoiding rushing to judgement.

Title: Nintendo handheld given Euro date
Article: Nintendo's new handheld console, the DS, will launch in Europe on 11 March, the company ha announced. The portable game machine, which feature touch-screen control, will retail for Â£99 in the UK (149 euros). Nintendo said 15 game would be available in the UK at launch, with price ranging from Â£19 to Â£29. More than 2.8 million DS console have been sold since it first appeared in the US and Japan at the end of 2004. Rival Sony ha said it will launch it first handheld console, the PSP, in the US and Europe before the end of March. The PSP is expected to compete for a large part of the same handheld market, despite Sony's assertion that the machine are aimed at different consumers. The 15 game available on the European launch date will include Nintendo's Super Mario 64 DS, a well a title from third-party developer such a Ubisoft's Rayman DS. More than 120 game are in development for the new console, Nintendo ha said. The DS is backwards compatible with the Game Boy Advance, allowing the earlier machine's back catalogue of 700 game to be played. Additionally, a short-range wireless link for multiplayer gaming is built in to the DS, with a "download play" option which allows a group to play against each other, even if just one person owns a copy. Other feature include a short-range messaging application called Pictochat, and a built-in microphone which is used in Sega's launch title Project Rub. Nintendo ha also announced a medium adapter, which will allow the console to play music and video on the move. The launch price of Â£99 (149 euros) compare favourably with the US price of $149, according to John Houlihan, editor of the Computerandvideogames.com magazine. "It's a very, very competitive price point. There are some innovative features, and Nintendo ha created quite a buzz," he says. "However, the line-up of game could have been stronger. Everyone wanted to see the eight-player Mario Kart DS, for example." Mr Houlihan belief that there is likely to be an audience for both the Nintendo DS and Sony's new PSP, with the former aimed largely at a younger audience and the latter expected to be marketed a a multimedia device. "The PSP is a sexy bit of kit, but Sony's attitude to the PSP ha been very understated in Europe, so far," Mr Houlihan said. The worldwide handheld software market had an estimated worth of $2.6bn at the end of 2004, according to industry analyst Screen Digest. In the past, game console and handhelds have generally launched much later in Europe than in other part of the world. However Nintendo president Satoru Iwata said the company wa "pleased to have offered such a short period of time between the US and European launch". "Europe is an extremely important market for Nintendo," Mr Iwata added. Nintendo raised it sale target for the DS console last December after selling a million in the US and Japan in just a few weeks.

Title: Bush to outline 'toughest' budget
Article: President Bush is to send his toughest budget proposal to date to the US Congress, seeking large cut in domestic spending to lower the deficit. About 150 federal program could be cut or axed altogether a part of a $2.5 trillion (Â£1.3 trillion) package aimed at curbing the giant US budget deficit. Defence spending will rise, however, while the proposal exclude the cost of continuing military operation in Iraq. Vice-President Dick Cheney said the budget wa the "tightest" so far. At the heart of the administration's fifth budget, presented to Congress on Monday, is an austere package of domestic measures. These would see discretionary spending rise below the projected level of inflation. Such belt-tightening is designed to tackle the massive budget deficit increase of President Bush's first term. Mr Cheney admitted that the budget wa the toughest of the Bush Presidency but argued it wa "fair and responsible". "It is not something we have done with a meat axe, nor are we suddenly turning our back on the most needy people in our society," he said. The war in Iraq and Afghanistan, increased expenditure on national security after 9/11 and the 2001 recession wiped out the budget surplus inherited by President Bush in 2001 and turned it into a record deficit. The shortfall is projected to rise to $427bn in 2005. Education, environmental protection and transport initiative are set to be scaled back a a first step towards reducing the deficit to $230bn by 2009. Most controversially, the government is seeking to cut the Medicaid budget, which provides health care to the nation's poorest, by $45bn and to reduce farm subsidy by $587m. Spending on defence and homeland security is set to increase, although not by a much a originally planned. President Bush's proposal would see the Pentagon's budget rise by $19bn to $419.3bn while homeland security would get an extra $2bn. The budget doe not include the cost of running military operation in Iraq and Afghanistan, for which the administration in expected to seek an extra $80bn from Congress later this year. Also not featuring in the proposal is the cost of funding the administration's radical proposed overhaul of social security provision. Some expects believe this could require borrowing of up to $4.5bn trillion over a twenty year period. Despite the Republicans holding a majority in both house of Congress, the proposal will be fiercely contested over the next few months. John McCain, a Republican Senator, said he wa pleased the administration wa prepared to tackle the deficit. "With the deficit that we are now running, I am glad the president is coming over with a very austere budget," he said. However, Democratic Senator Kent Conrad said the proposal exposed the country to huge financial commitment beyond 2009. "The cost of everything he [President Bush] advocate explodes," he said.

Title: Connors' rallying cry for British tennis
Article: "Do you have it in your heart? How much gut do you have? How much do you hate to lose?" These are the question Jimmy Connors will be asking of Britain's brightest tennis hope in the months, and possibly years, to come. The American legend swept into London on Thursday to announce a "long-term" relationship with the Lawn Tennis Association after spending three day at the Elite Performance winter camp in La Manga. And the man who epitomised the phrase 'will to win' before Lleyton Hewitt wa even born is clear about the quality he hope to convey. "You know, everybody hit the ball well and there's a very fine line between number one and number 100," said Connors. "I wa that fine line for a long time. But if I can help, I want to be part of teaching kid how to win." Connors is not the first great name to offer his service to the LTA - his long-time rival John McEnroe ha repeatedly done the same. But Connors is at pain to point out that his interest go well beyond any publicity stunt, and he gave a glowing recommendation to the work of LTA performance director David Felgate and his team. "Britain ha a different attitude, the right attitude, in taking the game forward and finding the next Wimbledon champion," said Connors. "That's something you don't find every day. Everybody talk a good game but not everybody put that into effect. "The impression I came away with after just seeing David and the other coach for three day wa one like I've never seen before, especially over here. "This is not going to happen overnight, there are no miracle workers, but you're going in the right direction." The 52-year-old's enthusiasm for the work going on in this country is in marked contrast to his relationship with tennis official back in America. "I've had discussion with the USTA (United States Tennis Association) over a number of years," he said. "That's where it (my input) ended." Connors is a straight-talker and will be equally blunt and honest in his dealing with the LTA and the cream of Britain's young players. "If they're chosen, they've got to produce," he said. "If not, someone will come and take their place. There's only one number one spot and it's lonely up there, but it's got the best view." In the year that ha seen Andrew Murray emerge a Britain's great new hope, Connors rejected suggestion that the Scot might be put under too much pressure too soon. "Tim Henman ha a whole country on his shoulder," said Connors. "I don't know that pressure, but if you like that it can be a certain push to get on to the next level. "Someone's going to have to come and take over from him (Henman). If I wa Andrew Murray, I'd embrace that. That's what we play for." Despite the emphasis on hard work, training and preparation, Connors doe admit that the desire required of a champion ha to come from within. "The passion I had, I don't know if you can find that," he admitted. "I wa also nuts. I say that because there wa nothing better for me than to compete on the tennis court. "It wa the most important thing in the world for me, and to do that something's got to be not right with you. There wa nothing better for me ever than to play tennis in front of 25,000 people. "What I had when I played tennis is what I am. You have to have that, you can't be moulded."

Title: Fuming Robinson blasts officials
Article: England coach Andy Robinson insisted he wa "livid" after his side were denied two try in Sunday's 19-13 Six Nations loss to Ireland in Dublin. Mark Cueto's first-half effort wa ruled out for offside before the referee spurned TV replay when England crashed over in the dying minutes. "[I'm] absolutely spitting. I'm livid. There's two try we've been cost," Robinson told BBC Sport. "We've got to go back to technology. I don't know why we didn't." South African referee Jonathan Kaplan ruled that Cueto wa ahead of Charlie Hodgson when the fly-half hoisted his cross-field kick for the Sale wing to gather. Kaplan then declined the chance to consult the fourth official when Josh Lewsey took the ball over the Irish line under a pile of body for what could have been the game-winning try. "I think Mark Cueto scored a perfectly legal try and I think he should have gone to the video referee on Josh Lewsey," said Robinson. "It is how we use the technology. It is there, and it should be used. "I am still trying to work out the Cueto try. I have looked at both, and they both looked tries. "We are very disappointed, and this will hurt, there is no doubt about that. "We are upset now, but the referee is in charge and he ha called it his way and we have got to be able to cope with that. "We did everything we could have done to win the game. I am very proud of my player and, with a couple of decisions, this could have been a very famous victory. "I thought we dominated.
