Title: Blind student 'hears in colour'
Article: A blind student ha developed software that turn colour into musical note so that he can read weather maps. Victor Wong, a graduate student from Hong Kong studying at Cornell University in New York State, had to read coloured map of the upper atmosphere a part of his research. To study "space weather" Mr Wong needed to explore minute fluctuation in order to create mathematical models. A number of solution were tried, including having a colleague describe the map and attempting to print them in Braille. Mr Wong eventually hit upon the idea of translating individual colour into music, and enlisted the help of a computer graphic specialist and another student to do the programming work. "The image have three dimension and I had to find a way of reading them myself," Mr Wong told the BBC News website. "For the sake of my own study - and for the sake of blind scientist generally - I felt it would be good to develop software that could help u to read colour images." He tried a prototype version of the software to explore a photograph of a parrot. In order to have an exact reference to the screen, a pen and tablet device is used. The software then assigns one of 88 piano note to individually coloured pixel - ranging from blue at the lower end of this scale to red at the upper end. Mr Wong say the application is still very much in it infancy and is only useful for reading image that have been created digitally. "If I took a random picture and scanned it and then used my software to recognise it, it wouldn't work that well." Mr Wong ha been blind from the age of seven and he think that having a "colour memory" make the software more useful than it would be to a scientist who had never had any vision. "As the note increase in pitch I know the colour's getting redder and redder, and in my mind's eye a patch of red appears." The colour to music software ha not yet been made available commercially, and Mr Wong belief that several people would have to work together to make it viable. But he hope that one day it can be developed to give blind people access to photograph and other images.

Title: Job cuts 'false economy' - TUC
Article: Plans to shed 71,000 civil service job will prove to be a "false economy" that could hamper public sector reforms, according to a TUC report. Public and Commercial Services union member have already voted to strike over cut for one day on 5 November. The TUC said cut would deliver less than 6% of the Â£22bn minister hope to save through efficiency reforms. General secretary Brendan Barber warned the "costs could easily outweigh the benefits". "The government's big boost to public spending is now showing results," said Mr Barber. "Public service are improving but looking for simple saving through job cut at this stage could be a false economy. "They may shoot a Tory fox, but cutting thousand of civil service job will hit the morale and capability of the public servant expected to implement government reforms. The cost could easily outweigh the benefits." Next Friday's strike action by the PCS is the biggest in the civil service since 1993, hitting Jobcentres, benefit agencies, pension offices, custom and driving tests. The union say it is concerned about pensions, sick pay and forced relocation a well a the cut in jobs. Last month it wa announced that a total of 37 social security office and Jobcentres across the UK would close in the first wave of plan to shed civil service jobs. The number of civil servant in Britain rose to more than 520,000 in April. Other area the strike will affect include passports, museum and galleries, library and health and safety inspections.

Title: Schools to take part in mock poll
Article: Record number of school across the UK are to take part in a mock general election backed by the government. Some 600 school have already signed up for the Y Vote Mock Elections 2005 run by the Hansard Society and aimed at boosting interest in politics. Pupils in the school taking part will learn the skill of speech writers, canvasser and political candidates. Schools Minister Stephen Twigg said engaging young people's interest wa "essential" to the future of democracy. He added: said "Young people who are engaged and motivated by the political process are essential to the future health of our democracy. "The mock election initiative provides an opportunity for pupil to develop their own understanding of how the democratic process work and why it matters. "By experiencing the election process first hand - from running a campaign to the declaration of the final result - we hope that young people will develop the enthusiasm to take part in the future." The Hansard Society, the Electoral Commission and the Department for Education and Skills are running the programme. Pupils will stand a party candidates, speech writer and canvassers. Michael Raftery, project manager at the Hansard Society, said: "The Y Vote Mock Elections for school mirror the excitement and buzz of a real election, raising awareness of citizenship, and the benefit of active democracy." The mock vote will take place around 5 May, widely expected to be the date of the general election. Information packs, including ballot paper and manifesto guides, with election happening in early May were sent out to the 3,000 school invited to take part.

Title: ECB holds rates amid growth fears
Article: The European Central Bank ha left it key interest rate unchanged at 2% for the 19th month in succession. Borrowing cost have remained on hold amid concern about the strength of economic growth in the 12 nation sharing the euro, analyst said. Despite sign of pick-up, labour market and consumer demand remain sluggish, while firm are eyeing cost cutting measure such a redundancies. High oil prices, meanwhile, have put upward pressure on the inflation rate. Surveys of economist have shown that the majority expect borrowing cost to stay at 2% in coming months, with an increase of a quarter of a percentage point predicted some time in the second half of the year. If anything, there may be greater call for an interest rate cut, especially with the euro continuing to strengthen against the dollar. "The euro land economy is still struggling with this recovery," said economist Dirk Schumacher. The ECB "may sound rather hawkish but once the data allows them to cut again, they will." Data coming out of Germany on Thursday underlined the problem facing European policy makers. While Germany's economy expanded by 1.7% in 2004, growth wa driven by export sale and lost some of it momentum in the last three month of the year. The strength of the euro is threatening to dampen that foreign demand in 2005, and domestic consumption currently is not strong enough to take up the slack. Inflation in the eurozone, however, is estimated at about 2.3% in December, above ECB guideline of 2%. ECB President Jean-Claude Trichet ha remained upbeat about prospect for the region, and inflation is expected to drop below 2% later in 2005. The ECB ha forecast economic growth in the eurozone of 1.9% in 2005.

Title: Set your television to wow
Article: Television started off a a magical blurry image. Then came the sharpness, the colour and the widescreen format. Now the TV set is taking another leap forward into a crystal clear future, although those in Europe will have to be patient. After year of buzz about high-definition TV (HDTV) it is finally taking off in a handful of country around the world, mainly the US and Japan. If you believe the hype, then HDTV will so wow you, that you will never want to go back to your old telly. "HDTV is just the latest must-have technology in viewers' homes," say Jo Flaherty, a senior broadcaster with the CBS network in the US. All television image are made up of pixels, going across the screen, and scan line going down. British TV picture are made up of 625 line and about 700 pixels. By contrast, HDTV offer up to 1,080 active lines, with each line made up of 1,920 pixels. The result is a picture which can be up to six time a sharp a standard TV. But to get the full impact, programme need to be broadcast in this format and you need a HDTV set to receive them. Most new computer display are already capable of handling high-resolution pictures. Viewers in Japan, the US, Australia, Canada and South Korea are already embracing the new TV technology, with a selection of primetime programme being broadcast in the new format, which includes 5.1 digital surround sound. But TV viewer in Europe will have to wait to enjoy the eye-blasting high-definition images. Many high-end European TV programmes, such a the recent Athens Olympics, are already being produced in high-definition. But they still reach your screen in the old 625 lines. The prospect for getting sharper image soon do not seem very encouraging. According to consultant Strategy Analytics, only 12% of home in Europe will have TVs capable of showing programme in high-definition by 2008. But the HDTV hype spilling out of the US and Japan ha spurred European broadcaster and consumer electronic company to push for change. Big sport and entertainment event are set to help trigger the general public's attention. The 2006 World Cup in Germany will be broadcast in high-definition. In the UK, satellite broadcaster BSkyB is planning HDTV service in 2006. There is already a HDTV service in Europe called Euro1080. Other European broadcasters, especially in France and Germany, also aiming to launch similar services. In Britain, digital satellite and cable are largely seen a the natural home for HDTV, at least while a decision is taken regarding terrestrial broadcast options. The communication watchdog Ofcom could hand over some terrestrial frequency freed up when the UK switch off it analogue TV signal. For now, broadcaster like the BBC are working on their own HDTV plans, although with no launch date in sight. "The BBC will start broadcasting in HDTV when the time is right, and it would not be just a showcase, but a whole set of programming," say Andy Quested, from the BBC's high-definition support group. "We have made the commitment to produce all our output in high-definition by 2010, which would put u on the leading edge." One of the option under consideration is to offer high-definition picture on the web. The BBC ha already dipped it toe into this, including some HDTV content in recent trial of it interactive medium player - a video player for PCs. It is planning to offer special release of selected flagship programme online in the near future. According to Mr Quested, this could help put Europe back into the running in the race to switch to HDTV. This is backed by recent research which suggests that the number of Europeans with broadband ha exploded over the past 12 months, with the web eating into TV viewing habits.

Title: Christmas shoppers flock to tills
Article: Shops all over the UK reported strong sale on the last Saturday before Christmas with some claiming record-breaking number of festive shoppers. A spokesman for Manchester's Trafford Centre said it wa "the biggest Christmas to date" with sale up 5%. And the Regent Street Association said shop in central London were also expecting the "best Christmas ever". That picture come despite report of disappointing festive sale in the last couple of weeks. The Trafford Centre spokeswoman said about 8,500 thousand vehicle had arrived at the centre on Saturday before 1130 GMT. "We predict that the next week will continue the same trend," she added. It wa a similar story at Bluewater in Kent. Spokesman Alan Jones said he expected 150,000 shopper to have visited by the end of Saturday and a further 100,000 on Sunday. "Our sale so far have been 2% up on the same time last year," he said. "We're very busy, it's really strong and people will be shopping right up until Christmas. "Over the Christmas period we're expecting people to spend in excess of Â£200m at the centre." On Saturday afternoon, a spokeswoman for the St David's Shopping Centre in Cardiff said it looked like being it busiest day of the year with about 200,000 shopper expected to have visited by the close of play. At the St Enoch's Shopping Centre in Glasgow, more than 140,000 shopper - an all-time record - were expected to have passed through the door by it closing time of 1900 GMT. Senior business manager Jon Walton said: "It ha been phenomenal - absolutely mobbed. "Every week footfall ha been showing strong growth and at the weekend it ha been going mad." Regent Street Association director Annie Walker said on Saturday: "The store were heaving today and a lot of people are going to be doing last minute shopping a many people finished work on Friday and can go in the week." She said report of a slump in pre-Christmas sale were related to the growing popularity of internet sales. "I do think this ha had a lot to do with report of lower sale figures," she said. "Internet shopping ha gone up enormously and not all store have websites."

Title: Federer breezes into semi-finals
Article: Roger Federer reached the last four of the Qatar Open with an easy 6-1 6-2 win over seventh seed Feliciano Lopez. The Swiss world number one reeled off a series winner to outclass the Spaniard and set up a semi-final match against Russian Nikolay Davydenko. Federer, who lost in the quarter-final in his last Qatar appearance in 2003, wa happy with his form. "I think I played better than against Greg Rusedski and I am happy I am playing so well," said the top seed. Lopez showed glimpse of resolve early in the second set when he held his first service game and came close to breaking Federer. But the Swiss saved a break point and promptly broke serve in the following game to seize control. Davydenko, meanwhile, upset French third seed Sebastien Grosjean 2-6 6-3 6-2. Fabrice Santoro completed a miserable day for France when he wa forced to retire when 6-2 3-0 down to Albert Costa. Spaniard Costa will next face Croatian Ivan Ljubicic after the sixth seed beat Rafael Nadal 6-2 6-7 (3/7) 6-3.

Title: Digital guru floats sub-$100 PC
Article: Nicholas Negroponte, chairman and founder of MIT's Media Labs, say he is developing a laptop PC that will go on sale for less than $100 (Â£53). He told the BBC World Service programme Go Digital he hoped it would become an education tool in developing countries. He said one laptop per child could be " very important to the development of not just that child but now the whole family, village and neighbourhood". He said the child could use the laptop like a text book. He described the device a a stripped down laptop, which would run a Linux-based operating system, "We have to get the display down to below $20, to do this we need to rear project the image rather than using an ordinary flat panel. "The second trick is to get rid of the fat , if you can skinny it down you can gain speed and the ability to use smaller processor and slower memory." The device will probably be exported a a kit of part to be assembled locally to keep cost down. Mr Negroponte said this wa a not for profit venture, though he recognised that the manufacturer of the component would be making money. In 1995 Mr Negroponte published the bestselling Being Digital, now widely seen a predicting the digital age. The concept is based on experiment in the US state of Maine, where child were given laptop computer to take home and do their work on. While the idea wa popular amongst the children, it initially received some resistance from the teacher and there were problem with laptop getting broken. However, Mr Negroponte ha adapted the idea to his own work in Cambodia where he set up two school together with his wife and gave the child laptops. "We put in 25 laptop three year ago , only one ha been broken, the kid cherish these things, it's also a TV a telephone and a game machine, not just a textbook." Mr Negroponte want the laptop to become more common than mobile phone but conceded this wa ambitious. "Nokia make 200 million cell phone a year, so for u to claim we're going to make 200 million laptop is a big number, but we're not talking about doing it in three or five years, we're talking about months." He plan to be distributing them by the end of 2006 and is already in discussion with the Chinese education ministry who are expected to make a large order. "In China they spend $17 per child per year on textbooks. That's for five or six years, so if we can distribute and sell laptop in quantity of one million or more to ministry of education that's cheaper and the marketing overhead go away."

Title: Golden rule 'intact' says ex-aide
Article: Chancellor Gordon Brown will meet his golden economic rule "with a margin to spare", according to his former chief economic adviser. Formerly one of Mr Brown's closest Treasury aides, Ed Balls hinted at a Budget giveaway on 16 March. He said he hoped more would be done to build on current tax credit rules. Any rate rise ahead of an expected May election would not affect the Labour Party's chance of winning, he added. Last July, Mr Balls won the right to step down from his Treasury position and run for parliament, defending the Labour stronghold of Normanton in West Yorkshire. Mr Balls rejected the allegation that Mr Brown had been sidelined in the election campaign, saying he wa playing a "different" role to the one he played in the last two elections. He rejected speculation that Mr Brown wa considering becoming Foreign Secretary, saying his recent travel had been linked to effort to boost international development. Gordon Brown's decision to announce the date of the Budget while on a trip to China wa a "sensible thing to do", since he wa talking about skill and investment at the time, Mr Balls told the BBC. Commenting on speculation of an interest rate rise, he said it wa not within the remit of the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) to factor a potential election into it rate decisions. Expectations of a rate rise have gathered pace after figure showed that house price are still rising. Consumer borrowing rose at a near-record pace in January. "I don't believe it would be a big election issue in Britain or a problem for Labour," Mr Balls said. Prime Minister Tony Blair ha yet to name the date of the election, but most pundit are betting on 5 May a the likely day.

Title: A question of trust and technology
Article: A major government department is without e-mail for a week, and technology analyst Bill Thompson want to know what happened. A couple of week ago I wrote about how my girlfriend had suffered when her cable modem blew up and she wa offline for several days. It seems that thousand of civil servant at the UK's Department of Work and Pensions went through the same thing last week. It ha emerged that the internal network crashed in a particularly horrible way, depriving staff of e-mail and access to the application software they use to calculate people's benefit and pension entitlement or note change in personal circumstances. Senior consultant from EDS, the computer firm which manage the system, and Microsoft, which supplied the software, were running around trying to figure out what had to be done to fix it all, while staff resorted to phone, fax and probably carrier pigeon to get work done. Fortunately the back-office system which actually pay people their money were still working, so only new claim and update were affected done properly. This is bad enough for those affected, but it doe mean that the impact is not devastating for million of pensioners. I am sure regular reader will be expecting one of my usual diatribe against poor software, badly specified system and inadequate disaster recovery plans. Although the full story ha not yet been told, it seems that the problem started when a plan to upgrade some of the computer from Windows 2000 to Windows XP went wrong, and XP code wa inadvertently copied to thousand of machine across the network. This is certainly unfortunate, but I have a lot of sympathy for the network manager and technology staff involved. Today's computer network are large, complex and occasionally fragile. The interconnectedness that we all value also give u a degree of instability and unpredictability that we cannot design out of the systems. It is the network equivalent of Godel's Theorem - any system sufficiently complex to be useful is also able to collapse catastrophically. So I will reserve judgment on the technology aspect until we all know what actually happened and whether it wa a consequence of software failure or just bad luck. What is really disturbing, and cannot be excused, is the fact that it took four day for news of this system failure to leak out into the technical press. It is, without a doubt, a major story and wa the second or third lead item on BBC Radio 4's Today programme throughout Friday morning. So why did not the prime minister's official spokesman mention it at any lobby briefing before Friday? Why wa not the pension minister in Parliament to make an emergency statement on Tuesday, when it wa clear that there wa a serious problem? If there had been an outbreak of Legionnaire's disease in the air conditioning system we would have been told, but it seems that major technology problem do not merit the same treatment. While EDS and Microsoft will no doubt be looking for technical lesson to learn from their week of pain, we can learn some political lesson too. And the most important is that in this digital world, technology failure are matter of public interest, not something that can be ignored in the hope that nobody will notice, care or understand. That mean we need a full report on what went wrong and what wa done to fix it. It would be unacceptable for any of the party involved to hide behind commercial confidentiality or even parliamentary privilege. A major system ha evidently collapsed and we need to know what went wrong and what is being done differently. Anything less is a betrayal of public trust. Bill Thompson is a regular commentator on the BBC World Service programme Go Digital.

Title: US bank in $515m SEC settlement
Article: Five Bank of America subsidiary have agreed to pay a total of $515m (Â£277m) to settle an investigation into fraudulent trading share practices. The US Securities and Exchange Commission announced the settlements, the latest in an industry-wide clean-up of US mutual funds. The SEC also said it had brought fraud charge against two ex-senior executive of Columbia Distributor. Columbia Distributor wa part of FleetBoston, bought by BOA last year. Three other ex-Columbia executive agreed settlement with the SEC. The SEC ha set itself the task of stamping out the mutual funds' use of market-timing, a form of quick-fire, short-term share trading that harm the interest of small investors, with whom mutual fund are particularly popular. In the last two years, it ha imposed penalty totalling nearly $2bn on 15 funds. The SEC unveiled two separate settlements, one covering BOA's direct subsidiaries, and another for business that were part of FleetBoston at the time. In both cases, it said there had been secret deal to engage in market timing in mutual fund shares. The SEC agreed a deal totalling $375m with Banc of America Capital Management, BACAP Distributors and Banc of America Securities. It wa made up of $250m to pay back gain from market timing, and $125m in penalties. It is to be paid to the damaged fund and their shareholders. Separately, the SEC said it had reached a $140m deal - equally split between penalty and compensation - in it probe into Columbia Management Advisors (CAM) and Columbia Funds Distributor (CFD) and three ex-Columbia executives. These business became part of BOA when it snapped up rival bank FleetBoston in a $47bn merger last March. The SEC filed civil fraud charge in a Boston Federal court against James Tambone, who it say headed CFD's sale operations, and his alleged second in command Robert Hussey. The SEC is pressing for the highest tier of financial penalty against the pair for "multiple violations", repayment of any personal gains, and an injunction to prevent future breaches, a spokeswoman for the SEC's Boston office told the BBC. There wa no immediate comment from the men's' lawyers. The SEC's settlement with CAM and CFD included agreement with three other ex-managers, Peter Martin, Erik Gustafson and Joseph Palombo, who paid personal financial penalty of between $50-100,000.

Title: Manchester wins Labour conference
Article: The Labour Party will hold it 2006 autumn conference in Manchester and not Blackpool, it ha been confirmed. The much trailed decision wa ratified by Labour's ruling National Executive Committee in a break with the traditional choice of a seaside venue. It will be the first time since 1917 that the party ha chosen Manchester to host the annual event. Blackpool will get the much smaller February spring conference instead in what will be seen a a placatory move. For year the main political party have rotated between Blackpool, Bournemouth and Brighton. And the news the much larger annual conference is not to gather in Blackpool will be seen a a blow in the coastal resort. In 1998 the party said it would not return to Blackpool but did so in 2002. The following year Bournemouth hosted the event before the party signed a two year deal for Brighton to host the autumn conference. Colin Asplin, Blackpool Hotel Association said: "We have tried very hard to make sure they come back to Blackpool. "Obviously we have failed in that. I just hope Manchester can handle the crowds. "It amazes me that the Labour Party, which is a working class party, doesn't want to come to the main working class resort in the country." The exact cost to Blackpool in term of lost revenue for hotel accommodation is not yet known but it is thought that block booking will be taken at the major Manchester hotel after the official announcement.

Title: Stalemate in pension strike talks
Article: Talks aimed at averting national strike over pension reform have ended without agreement after 90 minutes. Five public sector union met Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott at the Labour spring conference in Gateshead. They want the government to withdraw regulation - due to be introduced in week - which would raise the pension age for council worker from 60 to 65. Up to 1.4 million worker could take part in strike earmarked for 23 March. Discussions will resume next week. A spokesman for Unison, Britain's biggest union, said after Saturday's meeting: "At least we are still talking." All side are anxious to avoid a major confrontation in the run up to the general election, said BBC labour affair correspondent Stephen Cape. In four days, Unison will start balloting 800,000 local government worker on strikes. Other public sector union have pledged to follow. The five union which met Mr Prescott want the government to withdraw these regulations. This would allow month of tough negotiation to follow, said our correspondent. But a spokesman for Mr Prescott warned that the change to the local government pension scheme would have to go ahead in April. Privately minister believe this will be the "less painful" option, our correspondent added. The Public and Commercial Services Union (PCS) will co-ordinate any industrial action with up to six other public sector unions. PCS leader Mark Serwotka warned last week that there could be further walkout unless there wa a government rethink. "For a government that lecture everyone on choice - choice on public service, choice on this and choice on that - isn't it ironic that they're saying to public sector worker there is no choice," he said. "If you want the pension you were promised when you started you must work for an extra five year - that is working until people drop. "In the 20th century, it's completely unacceptable." Unison's 800,000 workers, the Transport and General Workers' Union's 70,000 and Amicus' 20,000 are among those being balloted about a 23 March walkout. Mr Prescott held a private meeting with senior union figure last week. It is understood no deal wa offered in that meeting but there wa room for further negotiations.

Title: Boro suffer Morrison injury blow
Article: Middlesbrough midfielder James Morrison ha been ruled out for up to eight week after an operation on Tuesday. The 18-year-old, who ha played in 13 of the club's last 14 games, had surgery to repair a double hernia. A club spokesman confirmed: "It is a bilateral sportsman's hernia, which wa operated on yesterday." Morrison wa sent for scan after being substituted at half-time during Boro's 2-1 UEFA Cup win over Graz AK in which he scored the equaliser. His injury is the latest blow for the Teessiders, who have been without Gaizka Mendieta, George Boateng and Mark Viduka for extended periods. Meanwhile, the kick-off time for Boro's Uefa Cup match at Sporting Lisbon on 17 March ha been brought forward from 2115 GMT to 1945 GMT.

Title: Bush website blocked outside US
Article: Surfers outside the US have been unable to visit the official re-election site of President George W Bush. The blocking of browser sited outside the US began in the early hour of Monday morning. Since then people outside the US trying to browse the site get a message saying they are not authorised to view it. The blocking doe not appear to be due to an attack by vandal or malicious hackers, but a a result of a policy decision by the Bush camp. The international exclusion zone around georgewbush.com wa spotted by net monitoring firm Netcraft which keep an eye on traffic pattern across many different sites. Netcraft said that since the early hour of 25 October attempt to view the site through it monitoring station in London, Amsterdam and Sydney failed. By contrast Netcraft's four monitoring station in the US managed to view the site with no problems. The site can still be seen using anonymous proxy service that are based in the US. Some web user in Canada also report that they can browse the site. The pattern of traffic to the website suggests that the blocking wa not due to an attack by vandal or politically motivated hackers. Geographic blocking work because the numerical address that the net us to organise itself are handed out on a regional basis. On 21 October, the George W Bush website began using the service of a company called Akamai to ensure that the pages, video and other content on it site reach visitors. Mike Prettejohn, president of Netcraft, speculated that the blocking decision might have been taken to cut costs, and traffic, in the run-up to the election on 2 November. He said the site may see no reason to distribute content to people who will not be voting next week. Managing traffic could also be a good way to ensure that the site stay working in the closing day of the election campaign. However, simply blocking non-US visitor also mean that Americans overseas are barred too. Akamai declined to comment, saying it could not talk about customer websites.

Title: Child access law shake-up planned
Article: Parents who refuse to allow former partner contact with their child could be electronically tagged under plan being considered by ministers. Curfews and community service order were other option which could be used if court order to allow parental access were defied, Lord Falconer said. The constitutional affair secretary outlined some of the plan on Tuesday. He denied fathers' activist had forced the changes, telling the BBC "there is a recognition that something is wrong". Between 15,000 and 20,000 couple go to court to resolve access dispute each year, although in nine out of 10 separation there is no court intervention. Lord Falconer told BBC Radio 4's Today programme he hoped voluntary mediation could help solve dispute before they reached court. But he opposed compulsory mediation, saying that it would lead to many people taking part with the wrong attitude. Other plan include: - Parenting plan to give advice on access arrangements, based on real-life example that have worked in the past - Extending in-court conciliation - more informal hearing before contested court case - Better access to legal, emotional and practical advice by telephone and internet - Legal aid change to give incentive for early resolution of disputes. Judges can already jail parent who breach contact order but that wa a "nuclear option" which wa rarely used a it wa not seen a being in the child's interests, a spokesman said. The aim of the new legislation wa to provide a "medium range" of penalties, such a fines, community service orders, compulsory anger management or parenting class or curfews. Failure to comply with these measure could result in offender being electronically tagged. On the possibility of tagging uncooperative parents, Lord Falconer said: "Tagging may be going too far, but let's have a debate about that." Full detail of the new power will not be revealed until a bill is published "in the next two weeks," a spokesman said. The government's proposal have met with disapproval from fathers' right groups. John Ison, from the controversial group Fathers 4 Justice, said: "It is very disappointing. What we have got is a cynical case of recycling existing legislation." Jim Parton, from Families Need Fathers, said the new proposal "lacked compulsion". "We would like to see couple develop a plan and then have it a a source of a court order - then you know where you stand, you know what the minimum access is. "Otherwise, you see people make agreement which then fall apart." Mr Parton said he had been told by Children's Minister Margaret Hodge there wa not enough time to pas the bill through parliament before the general election, which is likely to take place in May. The Conservatives have called for an equal split between parent on access to be made law. Theresa May, shadow secretary for the family, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that the government's plan were "inadequate" and were "papering over the crack of the current system". She said a Conservative government would bring a "radical reform" of the family courts, a well a enforcing a "legal presumption of co-parenting and compulsory mediation". "We want to make court the last resort, rather than the first resort," she added. The government say child cannot simply be divided up "like property" when a marriage collapses. The Liberal Democrats have argued for flexibility in deciding access rules, rather than having "rigid targets".

Title: Tomlinson stays focused on Europe
Article: Long jumper Chris Tomlinson ha cut his schedule to ensure he is fully fit for the European Indoor Championships. The 23-year-old ha a minor injury and ha pulled out of international meet in Madrid and Lievin this week a well a warm-weather training in Lanzarote. "It's nothing serious," said his coach Peter Stanley. "He strained a muscle in his abdomen at the Birmingham meeting but is back in full training." Sprinter Mark Lewis-Francis will also not compete in Madrid on Thursday. Title: Carry On star Patsy Rowlands dies
Article: Actress Patsy Rowlands, known to million for her role in the Carry On films, ha died at the age of 71. Rowlands starred in nine of the popular Carry On films, alongside fellow regular Sid James, Kenneth Williams and Barbara Windsor. She also carved out a successful television career, appearing for many year in ITV's well-loved comedy Bless This House. Rowlands died in Hove on Saturday morning, her agent said. Born in January 1934, Rowlands won a scholarship to the Guildhall School of Speech and Drama scholarship when she wa just 15. After spending several year at the Players Theatre in London, she made her film debut in 1963 in Tom Jones, directed by Tony Richardson. She made her first Carry On film in 1969 where she appeared in Carry On Again Doctor. Rowlands played the hard-done-by wife or the put-upon employee a a regular Carry On star. She also appeared in Carry On at your Convenience, Carry On Matron and Carry On Loving, a well a others. In recent year she appeared in BBC mini-series The Cazalets and played Mrs Potts in the London stage version of Beauty and the Beast. Agent Simon Beresford said: "She wa just an absolutely favourite client She never complained about anything, particularly when she wa ill, she wa an old trouper. "She wa of the old school - she had skill from musical theatre and high drama, that is why she worked with the great and the good of directors. "She didn't mind always being recognised for the Carry On film because she thoroughly enjoyed making them. She wa a really lovely person and she will be much missed." Her last appearance on stage wa a Mrs Pearce in the award-winning production of My Fair Lady at the National Theatre. Previously married, she leaf one son, Alan. Her funeral will be a private, family occasion, with a memorial service at a later date.

Title: Japan bank shares up on link talk
Article: Shares of Sumitomo Mitsui Financial (SMFG), and Daiwa Securities jumped amid speculation that two of Japan's biggest financial company will merge. Financial newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun claimed that the firm will join up next year and already have held discussion with Japanese regulators. The firm denied that they are about to link up, but said they are examining way of working more closely together. SMFG share climbed by 2.7% to 717,000, and Daiwa added 5.3% to 740 yen. Combining SMFG, Japan's third-biggest lender, and Daiwa, the country's second-largest brokerage firm, would create a company with asset of more than $1,000bn (Â£537bn). SMFG President Yoshifumi Nishikawa said that the company needed to bolster their businesses. "Both company need to strengthen retail and other operations," he said, adding that "it's an issue we have in common". Daiwa said that "although it is true that the two group have been engaging in various discussion to enhance cooperation, there are no plan to enter into negotiation to consolidate the two businesses". Analysts said that consolidation in Japan's financial sector wa likely to continue and that it wa likely to have a positive impact on earnings. "Cross-selling opportunity between bank and broker are increasing thanks to deregulation, so we can expect the relationship to get even stronger," said Heronry Nozaki, an analyst at NikkoCitigroup. The merger "would be a good move," he added.

Title: China had role in Yukos split-up
Article: China lent Russia $6bn (Â£3.2bn) to help the Russian government renationalise the key Yuganskneftegas unit of oil group Yukos, it ha been revealed. The Kremlin said on Tuesday that the $6bn which Russian state bank VEB lent state-owned Rosneft to help buy Yugansk in turn came from Chinese banks. The revelation came a the Russian government said Rosneft had signed a long-term oil supply deal with China. The deal see Rosneft receive $6bn in credit from China's CNPC. According to Russian newspaper Vedomosti, these credit would be used to pay off the loan Rosneft received to finance the purchase of Yugansk. Reports said CNPC had been offered 20% of Yugansk in return for providing finance but the company opted for a long-term oil supply deal instead. Analysts said one factor that might have influenced the Chinese decision wa the possibility of litigation from Yukos, Yugansk's former owner, if CNPC had become a shareholder. Rosneft and VEB declined to comment. "The two company [Rosneft and CNPC] have agreed on the pre-payment for long-term deliveries," said Russian oil official Sergei Oganesyan. "There is nothing unusual that the pre-payment is for five to six years." The announcement help to explain how Rosneft, a medium-sized, indebted, and relatively unknown firm, wa able to finance it surprise purchase of Yugansk. Yugansk wa sold for $9.3bn in an auction last year to help Yukos pay off part of a $27bn bill in unpaid tax and fines. The embattled Russian oil giant had previously filed for bankruptcy protection in a US court in an attempt to prevent the forced sale of it main production arm. But Yugansk wa sold to a little known shell company which in turn wa bought by Rosneft. Yukos claim it downfall wa punishment for the political ambition of it founder Mikhail Khodorkovsky. Once the country's richest man, Mr Khodorkovsky is on trial for fraud and tax evasion. The deal between Rosneft and CNPC is seen a part of China's desire to secure long-term oil supply to feed it booming economy. China's thirst for product such a crude oil, copper and steel ha helped pushed global commodity price to record levels. "Clearly the Chinese are trying to get some leverage [in Russia]," said Dmitry Lukashov, an analyst at brokerage Aton. "They understand property right in Russia are not the most important rights, and they are more interested in guaranteeing supplies." "If the price of oil is fixed under the deal, which is unlikely, it could be very profitable for the Chinese," Mr Lukashov continued. "And Rosneft is in desperate need of cash, so it's a good deal for them too."

Title: Newcastle to join Morientes race
Article: Newcastle have joined the race to sign Real Madrid striker Fernando Morientes and scupper Liverpool's bid to snap up the player, according to reports. Liverpool were reported to have bid Â£3.5m for the 28-year-old Spanish international this week. But the Liverpool Echo newspaper ha said Anfield bos Rafa Benitez will avoid a bidding war and instead turn his attention to Nicolas Anelka. Real are believed to still want Â£7m before selling Morientes. Monaco are also in the race for the player they had on loan last season. Reports suggest Liverpool will lift their offer to Â£5m - the highest they are willing to go before bowing out of any deal. On Tuesday, Morientes had said: "I like Liverpool and I am pleased that a club of their stature want to buy me. I have told Madrid that I want it to happen. "Madrid know my situation and they know they must do something about me. They must sort out the situation by being sensible. "I am in a position where I want to play, and I will have to look elsewhere to do that. If Madrid do not want me then it's in the best interest of everyone that they are realistic. "I haven't spoken to Rafa Benitez but I have always appreciated his work and I would like to play for him. But Benitez could yet turn his attention to the younger Anelka should Morientes be reluctant to pledge his future to Liverpool. Anelka previously played at Anfield under Gerard Houllier before sealing his permanent switch to Manchester City.

Title: Tsunami cost hits Jakarta shares
Article: The stock market in Jakarta ha seen it biggest slide in a month, after the country doubled the likely cost of rebuilding from the Asian tsunami. The fall came a Indonesia said it expected debt repayment of up to 30 trillion rupiah ($3.2bn; Â£1.7bn) to be frozen to help pay for the recovery. By Monday's close, the Jakarta Stock Exchange wa down 2.1% at 1,011.15. Bar a slight dip at the New Year, The JSE had risen steadily by 4.7% since the tsunami hit on 26 December. Construction and property company in particular have gained ground, although bank were among the main faller on Monday. So far, more than 100,000 people are believed to have been killed in Indonesia, the country closest to the earthquake which triggered the great wave. On Friday, the government said it five-year estimate of rebuilding cost for Banda Aceh province - much of which wa flattened by the quake and the tsunami - wa 20 trillion rupiah ($2.2bn; Â£1.1bn), twice what it had previously estimated. That cost could be defrayed by temporary debt relief. On Monday, Indonesian economy minister Aburizal Bakrie told reporter that the Paris Club group of creditor country wa expected to freeze 20-30bn rupiah in payment due in 2005 and 2006. "We hope we can resume the repayment at least from 2007," Mr Bakrie said. French finance minister Herve Gaymard said on Sunday that the Paris Club had already agreed to a moratorium on repayment for tsunami-hit country ahead of it meeting on 12 January.

Title: Casual gaming to 'take off'
Article: Games aimed at "casual players" are set to be even bigger in 2005, according to industry experts. Easy-to-play title that do not require too much time and that are playable online or downloadable to mobile device will see real growth in the coming year. The trend show that gaming is not just about big-hitting, game console titles, which appeal more to "hardcore" gamers, said a panel of experts. They were speaking before the annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas which showcase the latest trend in gadget and technology for 2005. The panel also insisted that casual gamers were not just women, a common misconception which pervades current thinking about gamer demographics. Casual game like poker, pool, bridge, bingo and puzzle-based titles, which can be played online or downloaded onto mobile devices, were "gender neutral" and different genre attracted different players. Greg Mills, program director at AOL, said it figure suggested that sports-based game attracted 90% of 18 to 24-year-old males, while puzzle game were played by 80% of females. Games like bridge tended to attract the over-50 demographic of gamers. But hardcore gamers who are more attracted to blockbuster gamers which usually require hi-spec PCs, like Half-Life 2, or Halo 2 on Xbox, also liked to have a different type of gaming experience. "When hardcore gamers are not playing Halo, they are playing poker and pool, based on our research," said Geoff Graber, director of Yahoo Games, which attracts about 12 million gamers a month. With the growth of powerful PC technology and ownership, broadband take-up, portable player and mobile devices, a well a interactive TV, casual gaming is shaping up to be big business in 2005, according to the panel. The focus for the coming year should be about attracting third-party developer into the field to offer more innovative and multiplayer titles, they agreed. "We are at a time where we are on the verge of something much bigger," said Mr Graber. "Casual game will get into their stride in 2005, will be really big in 2006 and will be about community." With more people finding more to do with their gadget and high-speed connections, casual game would start to open up the world of gaming a a form of mass-market entertainment to more people. Key to these type of title is the chance they give people who may not see themselves a gamers to dip in and out of game when they liked. Portal site which offer casual games, like AOL, Yahoo, and RealArcade, a well a other games-on-demand services, allow people to build up buddy list so they can return and play against the same people. This aspect of "community" is crucial for gamers who just want to have quick access to free or cheap game without committing long period of time immersed in Â£30 to Â£40 console or PC titles, said the panel. About 120,000 people are expected to attend the CES trade show which stretch over more than 1.5 million square foot and which officially run from 6 to 9 January. The main theme is how new device are getting better at talking to each other, allowing people to enjoy digital content, like audio, video and images, when they want, and where they want.

Title: Swap offer for pirated Windows XP
Article: Computer giant Microsoft ha launched a pilot scheme to replace counterfeit version of Windows XP with legal ones. The first-time initiative is restricted to the UK and to user with pre-installed copy of the operating system in PCs bought before November. Until December Microsoft said software can be sent to it for analysis if there are doubt about it legitimacy. The company aim to detect illegal trader and turn user of fake version of Windows into legitimate ones. The Windows XP Counterfeit Project will mean that software that is found to be counterfeit will be replaced for free, subject to certain conditions, until the end of the year. It is the first time Microsoft ha launched a counterfeit product replacement scheme in the world, the company told the BBC News website. In June, the software giant said that the major security update to Windows XP, Service Pack 2, would not work with the most widely pirated version of it operating system. The upgrade closed security loophole in XP and added feature that made it easier to keep machine safe from virus and other type of malicious computer code. The US company invited anyone who had suspicion about their version of Windows XP to submit it for testing a soon a possible. The procedure consists of a series of computer checks, collating documents, and filling out a witness statement. "This is a great opportunity for user to confirm the authenticity of Windows XP software whilst helping gather vital information about illegal traders", said Alex Hilton, licence compliance manager at Microsoft. The scheme ha also been welcomed by the technology and commerce industry. "It is important that user ensure that they are legally licensed to avoid the risk of purchasing and using counterfeit products", said David Frost, director general of the British Chambers of Commerce. The plan would enable Microsoft to gather intelligence about illegal trader in a prompt way, which would allow it to take action against software pirates. Microsoft said it would evaluate the result of the UK programme before setting up similar scheme in other countries.

Title: Oscars race enters final furlong
Article: The race for the Oscars entered it final stage a the deadline for voter to choose their winner passed. The 5,808 Academy voter had until Tuesday afternoon to return their ballot - any late submission will not be included in the count. The next five day will be spent counting the voting form and preparing the winners' envelopes. Best actor nominee Leonardo DiCaprio is to present a statuette for the first time at the LA ceremony on Sunday. The 30-year-old actor, who is nominated for playing Howard Hughes in The Aviator, will join other hopeful such a co-star Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman and Kate Winslet a Oscar presenters. The only people who will know the Oscar winner before they are revealed at the ceremony will be the auditor who are in charge of looking after the ballot count. After collating the results, they are responsible for sealing the result in the famous golden envelope which will be revealed by a host of celebrity presenter at the ceremony. Former Academy Award winner Gwyneth Paltrow, Dustin Hoffman and Halle Berry will also present prizes. The event at the Kodak Theatre will be attended by 3,300 people, including some of the best-known name in film, and organiser say they expect it will be watched on television by one billion people around the world. One current concern is the torrential rain which ha lashed Los Angeles for the past week, flooding suburb and causing mudslides. It is hoped the forecast for Sunday, for cool weather but no rain, will prove accurate. "The last time it rained on Oscars night wa in the mid-to-late 1980s," said Oscars communication director John Pavlik. "We have had rain up until the day before the show many times, but for some reason the Oscar god always shine on Sunday and we hope they will do so again this year," he added.

Title: Brown outlines third term vision
Article: Gordon Brown ha outlined what he think should be the key theme of New Labour's next general election bid. He said ensuring every child in Britain had the best start in life could be a legacy to match the NHS's creation. The chancellor ha previously planned the party's election strategy but this time the role will be filled by Alan Milburn - a key ally of Tony Blair. The premier insisted Mr Brown will have a key role in Labour's campaign, and praised his handling of the economy. Writing in the Guardian newspaper, Mr Brown outlined his view of the direction New Labour should be taking. "As our manifesto and our programme for the coming decade should make clear, Labour's ambition is not simply tackling idleness but delivering full employment; not just attacking ignorance, disease and squalor but promoting lifelong education, good health and sustainable communities." BBC political editor Andrew Marr said that Mr Brown's article wa "a warning shot" to Mr Blair not to try and cut him out of the manifesto writing process. "It was, a always, coded and careful... but entirely deliberate," wa Mr Marr's assessment. The prime minister wa asked about Mr Brown's article and about his election role when he appeared on BBC Radio 4's Today programme. Mr Blair said a decision had yet to be taken over how the election would be run but the chancellor's role would be "central". Mr Blair argued that under New Labour the country had changed for the better and that wa "in part" because of Mr Brown's management of the economy. And he pledged childcare would be a "centrepiece" of Labour's manifesto. He also predicted the next general election will be a "tough, tough fight" for New Labour. But the prime minister insisted he did not know what date the poll would take place despite speculation about 5 May. Mr Blair said he wa taking "nothing for granted" ahead of the vote - warning that the Tory strategy wa to win power via the back door by hinting they were aiming to cut Labour's majority instead of hoping for an outright win.

Title: Media gadgets get moving
Article: Pocket-sized device that let people carry around video and image are set to have a big year in 2005, according to industry experts. Last year saw the emergence of portable medium players, such a the Windows-based Creative Zen portable medium player, the Samsung Yepp, the iRiver PMC-100, and the Archos AV400 series among others. But this year, they are set to get smarter and more connected, to allow people to find more video to watch on them. Archos launched it latest range of it Linux-based portable medium device at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas on Friday. Dubbed the Pocket Media Assistant PMA430, it crucially ha wi-fi capability built-in for the first time. "Consumers are showing a great thirst for device that store all their medium in one place for anywhere access," said Henri Crohas, chief of Archos. "And now those consumer can stay connected and productive at the same time." Archos said the focus for the device is to be the second gadget in people's pockets, after the mobile. Unlike Windows-based players, the Archos AV400 series device have always been able to record from any video source, such a TVs, a well a playback. The content put onto the device is copy protected so cannot then be swapped to another device. Recording is perhaps a crucial functionality for those who have not seen the point of portable video if there is not a lot of video to watch on it. And wi-fi connectivity open up the possibility of content delivery via a high-speed wireless link. Archos also announced that it would open up the software development kit to Linux developer so that more application could be created for the device. Microsoft also made some announcement in the portable medium arena at CES, primarily for US consumer though. It ha agreed a content deal with personal video recorder company TiVo, which Bill Gates also showcased in his keynote speech at CES. The TiVo To Go service mean that US consumer will be able to take any programme they record on their TiVos and transfer it for free to watch on any of the Windows-based portable medium player or smartphones. It also said it had launched a service with MTV to let people watch Comedy Central, VH1 and Country Music TV on it devices. And a service is launching with MSN to provide people with shortened version of news, entertainment and other video on a subscription basis for download via the PC onto the portable devices. But the ability to record directly from TV, VCR, and digital cable and satellite boxes, which Windows-based device do not offer, certainly give people more content to watch on the go too. The increased capability of these devices, and the content deal that are being done, may go some way to persuading people to use them. Recent research by Jupiter suggested that people would prefer a device that wa dedicated to music. Only 13% of Europeans wanted to watch video while on the move. More seemed interested in spending their cash on music-only devices. "This year, we are ready for an explosion of portable media," Microsoft's Mike Coleman told the BBC News website. "We are very bullish about it. The fact that I can put photo on here too and share them is super-cool to the consumer," he added. The fact that Europeans are far larger public transport user than Americans is one reason why portable medium will take off in the coming year too. There is a burgeoning market there for commuter to watch news and other programme on their way to work. Although Microsoft's content distribution deal are for the US market at the moment, talk were "always on-going" with European content supplier to offer similar services. Various right management issue have to be ironed out first however. But that doe not prevent people from finding way to create their own content to share online and swap on portable devices, particularly via those which are wi-fi enabled. The possibility is open for non-professional maker of video and audio to take advantage of the growing portable medium market to distribute their work. CES, which run from 6 to 9 January, showcase more than 50,000 new gadget that will be hitting the shelf in 2005.

Title: Hearts of Oak 3-2 Cotonsport
Article: Hearts of Oak set up an all Ghanaian Confederation Cup final with a 3-2 win over Cameroon's Cotonsport Garoua in Accra on Sunday. The win for Hearts mean they will play Asante Kotoko in the two-leg final, after the Kumasi team qualified from Group A on Saturday. In the other Group B game Cameroon's beat of South Africa 3-2 in Douala, neither side could have qualified for the final. Hearts of Oak started the game needing a win to qualify for the final while Cotonsport only needed to avoid defeat to go through. Louis Agyemang scored the first two goal for Hearts either side of half time before Ben Don Bortey scored the third. Hearts looked set for a comfortable win but Cotonsport staged a late fight back scoring twice late on. First of all Boukar Makaji scored in the 89th minute and then 3 minute into injury time at the end of the game Andre Nzame III wa on target. But it wa too little too late for the Cameroonians and Hearts held on to win the game and a place in the final. The first leg of the final will be played in Accra on the weekend of 27-28 November and the second leg two week later on the 11 December in Kumasi. In the other Group B game Cameroon's Sable Batie took the lead in the 35th minute through Kemadjou before Santos equalised on the hour mark thanks to Thokozani Xaba . Bernard Ngom put Sable ahead just five minute later and then Ernest Nfor settled the game on 68 minutes. Ruben Cloete scored the South African side consolation with just three minute left on the clock.

Title: Player burn-out worries Robinson
Article: England coach Andy Robinson say English rugby ha to act now to prevent injury destroying players' careers. He will be without a host of big name for the Six Nations a the intensity of professional rugby union hit players. "Injuries are part of the sport but we have to have a look at the amount of injury that occur in the English season," Robinson told BBC Sport. "I think player are probably going to have three or four year taken off their careers." Robinson will be missing an entire midfield for the Six Nations with the like of Jonny Wilkinson, Mike Tindall and Will Greenwood injured. Rugby union ha become far more physically demanding since the game went professional nearly 10 year ago. As a result three of the major stakeholder in English rugby have launched an "injury audit" to find out how player are coping. The audit is jointly funded by the Professional Rugby Players' Association, the Rugby Football Union and Premier Rugby. As far a Robinson is concerned it finding must not be ignored. "I think there's an injury audit coming out in March that's got some great information in there that I think everybody in the English game ha got to look at," he said. "If we don't the situation is going to get worse and not better, so I think rugby a a whole ha got to look at this."

Title: Prince crowned 'top music earner'
Article: Prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, beating artist such Madonna and Elton John in US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer banked $56.5m (Â£30.4m) from concerts, album and publishing sale with his Musicology tour and album. He kept Madonna in second place, a she earned $54.9m (Â£29.5m) while embarking on her global Re-Invention Tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place, their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9m (Â£13.4m) last year. "Prince returned to centre stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine reported. The singer's 2004 tour took $90.3m (Â£48.5m) in ticket sale and he sold 1.9 million copy of his latest album Musicology. Although she grossed more than Prince last year, Madonna remained in second place because of the "monumental" production cost of her tour. Heavy metal band Metallica's Madly in Anger with the World tour helped push their 2004 earnings up to $43.1m (Â£23.1m). They were ahead of Sir Elton John, who took fourth place and almost $42.7m (Â£23m) from performance including a debut on the Las Vegas Strip. Other seasoned performer in the list included Rod Stewart, whose sold-out show and third volume of The Great American Songbook cover album helped net him Â£35m (Â£19m). The highest-ranking rap act in the list wa 50 Cent, who at number 19 took $24m (Â£13m) to the bank.

Title: Saint-Andre anger at absent stars
Article: Sale Sharks director of rugby Philippe Saint-Andre ha re-opened rugby's club-versus-country debate. Sale host Bath in the Powergen Cup on Friday, but the Frenchman ha endured a "difficult week" with six player away on England's Six Nations training camp. "It's an important game but we've just the one full session. It's the same for everyone but we need to manage it. "If five player or more are picked for your country they should move the date of the game," he told BBC Sport. Unless the authority agree to make changes, Saint-Andre belief England's national team will suffer a club opt to sign foreigner and retired internationals. "That's not good for the politics of the English team or for English rugby," he argues. It is an issue he ha taken up before, most notably during the autumn international when Sale lost all three Zurich Premiership match they played. Now he fear it could derail the club's hope of cup silverware after eight players, including captain Jason Robinson and fly-half Charlie Hodgson, were away with their countries. "We're in the quarter-finals, it's always better to play at home than away and it's a great opportunity," he added. "But we have to be careful. Bath have just been knocked out of Europe and will make it a tough game. It also come at the end of a very, very difficult week. "Sebastien Bruno's been with France, Jason White with Scotland and there are six with England, that's eight player plus injury - 13 player out of a squad of 31. "We'll have just one session together and will have to do our best to make that a good one on Thursday afternoon." Gloucester have also been caught in a club-versus-country conflict after England sought a second medical opinion on James Simpson-Daniel's fitness. The winger is carrying a shoulder injury and the national team management believe he requires time on the sidelines. As a result he miss the Cherry and White's quarter-final at home to Bristol. "Under the Elite Player Squad agreement, England wanted a second opinion, which they can do," director of rugby Nigel Melville told the Gloucester Citizen. "They obviously want him for international rugby and we want him for club rugby in what is a very important game for us. There is a conflict of interests. "The surgeon who carried out his operation said he wa fine for u but England say he is still vulnerable to be damaged again and want him on a full rehab programme." Simpson-Daniel added: "I've said to Nigel I want to be back playing and that mean if everything go well this week, I can target the Worcester game (on 29 January) for a return."

Title: Yeading face Newcastle in FA Cup
Article: Premiership side Newcastle United face a trip to Ryman Premier League leader Yeading in the FA Cup third round. The game - arguably the highlight of the draw - is a potential money-spinner for non-League Yeading, who beat Slough in the second round. Conference side Exeter City, who knocked out Doncaster on Saturday, will travel to Old Trafford to meet holder Manchester United in January. Arsenal were drawn at home to Stoke and Chelsea will play host to Scunthorpe. The only other non-League side in the draw are Hinckley United, who held Brentford to a goalless draw on Sunday. They will meet League One leader Luton if they win their replay against Martin Allen's team at Griffin Park. A number of Premiership team face difficult away game against Championship side on the weekend of 8/9 January. Third-placed Everton visit Plymouth, Liverpool travel to Burnley, Crystal Palace go to Sunderland, Fulham face Carling Cup semi-finalists Watford, Bolton meet Ipswich, while Aston Villa were drawn against Sheffield United. Premiership struggler Norwich, Blackburn, West Brom are away at West Ham, Cardiff and Preston North End respectively. Southampton visit Northampton, having already beaten the League Two side in the Carling Cup earlier this season. Middlesbrough were drawn away against either Swindon or Notts County, while Spurs entertain Brighton at White Hart Lane. Title: Faith schools citizenship warning
Article: Schools must improve the quality of citizenship lesson - or social cohesion and democracy will suffer, say the education watchdog. Independent faith school were singled out by Ofsted chief, David Bell, for not doing enough to promote the "wider tenet of British society". Mr Bell said Muslim, Jewish and Evangelical Christian school must be "intolerant of intolerance". Diversity "certainly must not mean segregated or separate", he said. Mr Bell's speech called for a much greater effort in all type of school to teach citizenship - with an accompanying survey showing that young people knew little about politics and had no enthusiasm to find out more. Badly-taught citizenship lesson have previously been criticised by Mr Bell, and in a speech to the Hansard Society, he warned that it wa failing to pas on an understanding of democracy, public service and shared values. He highlighted his particular concern for citizenship in the growing number of independent faith school - which he said included about 100 Muslim, 100 Evangelical Christian and 50 Jewish schools. Mr Bell expressed concern about school which did not teach child enough about a "common heritage" and needed to do more to promote principle of mutual tolerance and social inclusion. Title: US in EU tariff chaos trade row
Article: The US ha asked the World Trade Organisation to investigate European Union custom tariffs, which it say are inconsistent and hamper trade. The EU's own institution have noted the uneven way EU custom rule are applied but failed to act, the US Trade Representative's Office said. Small and mid-sized US firm were worst-hit, it added. The EU expanded from 15 to 25 member state in May. The US said it filed the complaint after talk failed to find a solution. The move came in the same week that the US and EU stepped back from confrontation in a tense dispute over aircraft subsidy to European manufacturer Airbus and US firm Boeing. New EU trade commissioner Peter Mandelson said on Tuesday that the two side had agreed to reopen talk in the aircraft subsidy row, which led to tit-for-tat WTO filing in last autumn. Explaining why it ha asked the WTO to set up a dispute settlement panel on custom barriers, the US Trade Representative's Office said that it want to tackle the issue "early in the EU's process of dealing with the problem of enlargement". Ten countries, mostly in Eastern Europe, joined the EU in May. The US said it trade with the 25 EU member country wa worth $155.2bn (Â£82.8bn) in 2003. "Although the EU is a custom union, there is no single EU custom administration," a statement issued on behalf of Robert Zoellick, US Trade Representative, said. Lack of uniformity, coupled with lack of procedure for prompt EU-wide review can hinder US exports, especially for small to mid-sized businesses", An EU spokesman in Washington dismissed the US complaint. "We think the US case is very weak. They haven't come up with any evidence that US company are being harmed," said Anthony Gooch. It could take several month for the WTO's dispute settlement panel to report it findings.

Title: Beckham virus spotted on the net
Article: Virus writer are trading on interest in David Beckham to distribute their malicious wares. Messages are circulating widely that purport to have evidence of the England captain in a compromising position. But anyone visiting the website mentioned in the message will not see picture of Mr Beckham but will have their computer infected by a virus. The pernicious program open a backdoor on a computer so it can be controlled remotely by malicious hackers. The appearance of the Beckham Windows trojan is just another example in a long line of virus that trade on interest in celebrity in an attempt to fuel their spread. Tennis player Anna Kournikova, popstars Britney Spears and Avril Lavigne a well a Arnold Schwarzenegger have all been used in the past to try to con people into opening infected files. The huge amount of interest in Mr Beckham and his private life and the large number of message posted to discussion group on the net might mean that the malicious program catch a lot of people out. "The public's appetite for salacious gossip about the private life of the Beckhams might lead some into an unpleasant computer infection," said Graham Cluley from anti-virus firm Sophos. Simply opening the message will not infect a user's PC. But anyone visiting the website it mention who then downloads and open the fake image file stored on that site will be infected. The program that installs itself is called the Hackarmy trojan and it try to recruit PCs into so-called 'bot network that are often used to distribute spam mail message or to launch attack across the web. Computers running Microsoft Windows 95, 98, 2000, NT and XP are vulnerable to this trojan. Many anti-virus program have been able to detect this trojan since it first appeared early this year and have regularly been updated to catch new variants.

Title: Wales stars need a rest - Ruddock
Article: Wales coach Mike Ruddock ha defended his decision not to release any of the international star for this weekend's regional Celtic League fixtures. Ruddock say the player will benefit from the rest, and their absence will give youngster a chance to impress. "We've got the WRU charter in place now which outline exactly what happens," Ruddock told BBC Wales Sport. "Once we're in the Six Nations, the player will only be released in his and the WRU's best interests." The Ospreys and Scarlets say they are happy to support the Wales cause, but the Dragons have expressed disappointment at not being able to use their national squad player in Friday's game with Ulster. Ceri Sweeney, Gareth Cooper, Ian Gough and Kevin Morgan have been used sparingly by Ruddock in the opening two Six Nations win and captain Jason Forster belief they would benefit from a game with the Dragons. "I'm sure the guy would want to come back to get some game time," Forster told BBC Wales Sport. "It would also be a timely reminder to Mike [Ruddock] a to what they can do. "And the supporter want to see the star player - no disrespect to the other guy - performing on the pitch." Ruddock, though, is keen to protect his player from injury and fatigue. "At this stage, there's nothing more [the players] can do in game to impress me further. "We've got to look at it at another angle and see the opportunity that are provided for the younger player in the region. "For example, the Dragons might use James Ireland this weekend. I've been looking at the lad - he's a great prospect for the future." French and English club have requested to have all their international player available which mean Stephen Jones, Gareth Thomas and Mefin Davies will play this weekend. The majority of Ireland and Scotland player have also been released for provincial duty.

Title: Brits debate over 'urban' music
Article: Joss Stone, a 17-year-old soul singer from Devon, beat Dizzee Rascal, Jamelia, Lemar and The Streets to win best British urban act at the Brit Awards. Her victory ha reignited the debate about what urban music is. I'm not really comfortable with the word urban. It's a word that's been manufactured in this country and America to describe black music. The word urban seems to cover such a broad range of black music that it's wrong. How far are the Brits removed from inner-city music and what people are doing? It's so far removed that I don't expect them to get it bang on. The music industry isn't championing music from our particular genre very well anyway. People don't feel like that's anything to do with us. I don't feel like urban music's just been celebrated by [Joss Stone] winning or her being nominated, or by the Brits acknowledging that there's an urban music scene because it's all a kick in the teeth at the end of the day. It's not really relevant. If Joss Stone is the closest thing that they feel comfortable championing because of what she look like and how she sound and who she's signed to, then so be it. It's got nothing to do with what's really going on. Urban a a genre is very broad. If you look underneath urban, there are a number of core element that include hip-hop, R&B, garage and into that obviously come soul. Joss Stone is a soul artist. Her first album wa called The Soul Sessions. So urban is a very broad brushstroke that is the umbrella over the top of sub-genres, and there are offshoot of all of those. Joss Stone ha had amazing success [in the US] given that she's a UK artist. What ha really captured everybody's imagination is that here you have a 17-year-old from Devon with a voice to die for and a bunch of really, really good tune and she look good - I think that's what's done it. The award for best British urban act wa voted for by viewer of MTV Base. I don't think Joss wa not a worthy winner. She make soul music and that definitely come under the category of what we describe a urban. The fact that she's from Devon is the interesting thing because most of the music we cover is made in large city and she's literally rural. The great thing about urban music is that there's a big range. If there is some sort of root with black music or dance music in Britain, I think that's where you can call it urban - that's where this new sub-category, or uber-category, ha come from. Joss Stone is certainly not old enough to have had some of the experience of an older soul singer, but you couldn't argue that she wa being inauthentic with her emotion - it is coming from somewhere genuine. It ha to come across a real. That's the only cut-off point we have here and that's the only way by which we judge people. What urban mean to u a an organisation is the politically correct term to describe music which originated from a black background. Music should become inclusive and if we are fighting for a multi-cultural Britain, then we should be fighting for inclusion rather than exclusion. If Joss Stone can be accepted within the urban music community, I think act from other ethnicity doing classical music and rock should be accepted too. Race doesn't make a difference if everyone is included. Out of all the award dished out yesterday, I'm still trying to find out what people of other race received any sort of recognition or award. A type of music (especially street music) that originates from a city, and typically reflects or is characteristic of urban life. She might not be urban, but when did R&B become the hip hop tainted thing it is now? R&B stand for Rhythm And Blues, remember! That Joss Stone is rubbish is certain. If anyone deserves to win an award for urban music (I think probably should include Hip-Hop, Soul & Funk at least but not rock or pop) this year it the Streets, although Dizzee Rascal stake a good claim She definitely deserved to win a prize, Joss Stone's album are quite simply amazing, easily better than anything else that wa released last year. This whole debate about what is urban, what isnt urban is completely pointless and probably fueled by urban artist who weren't nominated or didn't win. I cant see why people can't just congratulate her for the talent that she is. She did deserve it, but I agree with the comment about urban music. Its a stupid phrase, and particularly British. In the state they tend to use hip hop and R&B, if I say hip hop here a lot of people have no idea what I'm talking about. Very strange. What's in a name? A rose by any other name etc... If people want to call it urban, why not? If we really analysed it, the term 'dance music' is misleading because it doesn't describe everything you can dance to. Whilst I agree that the term 'urban' is open to interpretation, it strike me a simply weird that Joss Stone ha won. 'Urban' to me is what I hear being played in party in the inner city - I live in Brixton and have never heard The Soul Sessions pumping out of of a bass heavy sound system in any party I've been to. Good luck to Joss Stone, let's celebrate her victory - let's also question why, with artist so successful and talented a Jamelia, Lemar, Kanye West, Dizzee Rascal, Alicia Keys and Outkast - we didn't see a single black artist on stage collecting an award. So, what you're saying is that any music that ha black heritage is not allowed to be sung by anyone who isn't black. This idea of pigeonholing whatever is popular at the time is no different than what wa happening in the 1940s and 50 in relation to what "Jazz" was. The medium then called anything that had a swinging beat, syncopated melody or soulful feeling "Jazz", much to the chagrin of the artists. It would mean that "blues" would be put in the same mould a "bebop", "cool" and "ragtime", all very different style at that time. Jazz wa and remains such a massively misunderstood term. If we just let the music speak for itself and not judge the success of an artist by the number of award won, then maybe we can enjoy the music for what it is, rather than what it represents. The real question is would Joss Stone would have been that successful doing the music she wa doing if she were black?
