It seems that a lot of the fuss is about race where the real issue should be music and nothing else. Urban is PC version for saying black music. I'm not doubting Ms Stone's talent, but why didn't Jamelia or Lemar get a Brit? This reminds me of what happened to Craig David and Soul II Soul in the past, getting nomination are easy to get, but picking up a Brit seems to be the hardest thing. Refreshing to see people making reasonable, intelligent comment on any topic these days. More power to you, people! You have said it: there is music you like and music you don't like - who care what label you put on it? That entire category wa a mess. How can you have people like Dizzee Rascal up against Joss Stone? Its like putting Eminem against Bob Geldof. She should have been nominated for Best British R & B act. Joss Stone deserved to win an award for her talents, but I don't think it wa very 'urban' of her to sing angel with Robbie Williams. Urban is a nonsense term - music of black origin? Well doesn't that include rock? Music made in the inner cities? Well almost all band end up making music in London/Manchester etc. And doesn't that make some weird implication that all black people live in cities? It doesn't make any sense. Why doe music have to be put into a genre? It's music, you like it or you don't. Simple a that. I play in a heavy metal band. We are urban music a far a I'm concerned. We live in city and spend our working life in an urban environment; It therefore directly shape what we write musically. "Urban" seems to be the new name for all style of black music. All this "urban" and other such categorisation is just the red-tape of the music business and is best ignored. Yeah, she deserved it. She is talented. Urban is a crap, meaningless, politically correct and probably actually racist marketing term though. There's only two kind of music: good and bad.

Title: Tarantino 'to make Friday sequel'
Article: Director Quentin Tarantino is in talk to write and direct a new instalment in the Friday the 13th horror franchise, according to the Hollywood Reporter. The film-maker will reportedly meet executive from New Line Cinema this week to discus the 12th film in the long-running 'stalk and slash' series. The original film, released in 1980, ha spawned ten sequel based around mask-wearing murderer Jason Voorhees. The most recent, Freddy Vs Jason, wa released in summer 2003. That film saw Jason battle Freddy Krueger, star of the Nightmare on Elm Street franchise. According to the industry newspaper, New Line had been trying to make another sequel involving Ash, the hero of the Evil Dead movies, but wa unable to agree term with director Sam Raimi. Tarantino is said to be intrigued by the prospect of building a new film around one of the horror genre's most recognised figures. First, however, he is scheduled to direct the season finale of US television series CSI: Crime Scene Investigation. Filming is due to start in early April. Tarantino's episode, for which he also wrote the original story, will be broadcast in the US on 19 May.

Title: Muslim police stops 'more likely'
Article: UK Muslims should accept that people of Islamic appearance are more likely to be stopped and searched by police, a Home Office minister ha said. Hazel Blears said innocent Muslims would be targeted because of the search for Islamic extremists. Qualifications for religious leader to enter the UK could also be made tougher, she told a Commons inquiry. Her comment have been described a "irresponsible" and "outrageous" by the Islamic Human Rights Commission (IHRC). "The threat is most likely to come from those people associated with an extreme form of Islam, or who are falsely hiding behind Islam," the Salford MP told the Commons home affair committee. "It mean that some of our counter-terrorism power will be disproportionately experienced by the Muslim community." It wa a reality that should be recognised, she said. "If a threat is from a particular place then our action is going to be targeted at that area," she added. On minister of religions, such a imams, she said faith group would be asked what other qualification and skills, such a civic knowledge and ability to engage the community, should be demanded. Last year, minister introduced a requirement that minister should speak English to a certain level. IHRC chairman Massoud Shadjareh accused Ms Blears of "playing an Islamophobia card" in the run-up to a general election. "She is demonising and alienating our community," he said. "It is a legitimisation for a backlash and for racist to have an onslaught on our community. "This sort of comment is just music to the ear of racists." Later, the prime minister's official spokesman urged people to put Ms Blears' comment into context. The minister had been saying she understood there wa a perception that stop and search wa aimed at one community, but that wa not what wa happening, the spokesman said. "What is happening is that those power are aimed at those who are suspected of carrying out or planning certain activity who happen to come from one community. "It is not aimed at a particular community, it is not police policy to aim these power at a particular community," he added. Statistics showed that of the 17 people found guilty of terrorist act in the UK since the 11 September attacks, only four of the 12 whose ethnic background were known were Muslim, he added Figures published last week showed that people from ethnic minority were increasingly likely to be targeted by police stop and search tactics. Figures showed that, for 2003/2004, Asians were 1.9 time more likely to be stopped and searched, compared with 1.7 time more likely in the previous year. Separate figure on police search in England and Wales carried out under the Terrorism Act 2000 showed that ethnic minority were more likely to be targeted. Muslim group have repeatedly claimed that their community are being victimised under terror laws. In 2003/2004, 12.5% search under the law were on Asian people, even though they make up 4.7% of the population. Last July, the police were accused of Islamophobia by Muslim group after stop and search figure showed the number of Asians targeted had risen by 300% since the introduction of anti-terror laws.

Article: Irishmen JP McManus and John Magnier, who own a 29% stake in Manchester United, will reportedly reject any formal Â£800m offer for the club. The Sunday Times and The Sunday Telegraph say they will oppose any formal Â£800m takeover bid from US tycoon Malcom Glazer. Mr Glazer got permission to look at the club's account last week. Irish billionaire Mr McManus and Mr Magnier are said to believe that an Â£800m bid undervalues club prospects. Mr Magnier and Mr McManus, who hold their stake through their Cubic Expression investment vehicle have the power to block a bid. Mr Glazer's financial backers, including JP Morgan, the US investment bank have said they won't back a bid unless it receives backing from the owner of at least 75% of the club's shares. However, there ha been much speculation that the Irish duo simply do not think the price offered - 300p a share - is high enough. Mr Glazer ha been stalking the premier league football club since 2003. Mr Magnier and Mr McManus issued a statement late on Friday saying that they remained "long-term investors" in Man Utd. The Sunday Telegraph say the board of Manchester United also considered a management buyout at just over 300p but did not go ahead with it.

Title: Asia quake increases poverty risk
Article: Nearly two million people across Asia could be thrown into poverty because of the Indian Ocean tsunami, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) ha said. In it first overview of the disaster, the ADB said the impact on economic growth would be slight because major city and factory escaped damage. But the blow to many low-income people could be "enormous". The Paris Club of rich creditor nation on Wednesday offered to freeze debt owed by tsunami-hit countries. The move wa aimed at helping South Asian government find budget to rebuild devastated coastal areas, though so far only Sri Lanka, Indonesia and the Seychelles have indicated that they will take it up. Other country believe their economy are strong enough to cope or wish to avoid being viewed a credit risks. "Poverty is potentially the most important impact of this natural disaster," said ADB chief economist Ifzal Ali. Donor nation have promised to give $717m (Â£379m) in disaster relief over the next six months, according to the United Nations. Mr Ali added his voice to those warning that aid pledge must be promptly delivered, saying the number of people at risk of poverty hinged on "concerns over sanitation and health conditions, and other basic needs" being "properly and quickly addressed". There are 1.9 billion people in Asia living on less than $2 a day. The ADB fear that 1 million Indonesians could join them, while in India just over half a million people - 645,000 - are at risk of falling into poverty. A quarter of a million Sri Lankans and 23,500 people in the Maldives are also facing poverty. In the Maldives, where 43% of the population already life on less than $2 a day, this could rise to half. Sri Lanka and the Maldives are the two country the ADB fear are most at risk of suffering lasting economic damage from the tsunami. Sri Lanka's government ha estimated reconstruction cost at nearly $3bn. A government task force held meeting to discus an emergency rebuilding plan with the ADB, World Bank and Japanese aid agency on Wednesday, and promised to publish the plan within 10 days. Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and India have enjoyed strong economic growth in recent years, which should cushion them against reconstruction costs. Although Indonesia's northern province of Aceh suffered the worst death toll, the region's oil and natural gas production facility "have survived intact", the report said. However, it remains too soon to ass the damage to poor people's livelihood in Aceh because it would depend on how much farm land had been flooded by seawater. "This is a profoundly tragic event for the region and for the million who are suffering. But the economy of the affected country except Sri Lanka and the Maldives should emerge with minimal damage," the ADB report said. Some business may even gain from the reconstruction efforts, thereby creating jobs. At a meeting in Thailand, ABD president Thadao Chino said he wa confident of the country's "own capability to restore normalcy to the affected area and meet the rehabilitation requirements". Thailand ha said it doe not wish to opt for a debt repayment freeze, while India ha also rejected international aid, saying it can cope on it own resources. Debt repayment holiday carry the risk of credit rating downgrades, making it more expensive to borrow money in future. Indonesia, however, is pressing for greater help with it debt than the current freeze would bring. It is one of the world's most indebted countries.

Title: Label withdraws McFadden's video
Article: The new video of former Westlife singer Brian McFadden ha been pulled after a Dublin school complained about being associated with his song Irish Son. St Fintian's High School say it is clearly identified in the video, while McFadden never went there. McFadden make claim that he wa beaten at his own school in the song's lyrics, saying it had "cell blocks". The performer's record label Sony BMG ha withdrawn the video and issued replacement to television stations. The label believed the school name wa fictitious until they received the complaint. They have said the reference to the school wa unintentional and coincidental. The head of Christian Brothers' school St Fintian's, Richard Fogarty, said the video implied that the 24-year-old pop star had attended his school and wa abused there. "The school ha always treated it pupil with respect," Mr Fogarty said in a statement. McFadden make specific reference to the Christian Brothers in his song, but did not attend St Fintian's. Corporal punishment wa outlawed in Irish school in 1982 when McFadden wa two year old. McFadden, whose debut solo album is released next week, ha said that every song is autobiographical and "a true story". Alcoholism and domestic violence are among the other topic dealt with in his songs, half of which have been written with Robbie Williams' former collaborator, Guy Chambers. McFadden, who quit chart-topping group Westlife in March, went to number one in September with his first solo single Real To Me. He enjoyed 12 chart-toppers with the boy band before parting company with them.

Title: DVD copy protection strengthened
Article: DVDs will be harder to copy thanks to new anti-piracy measure devised by copy protection firm Macrovision. The pirated DVD market is enormous because current copy protection wa hacked more than five year ago. Macrovision say it new RipGuard technology will thwart most, but not all, of the current DVD ripping (copying) program used to pirate DVDs. "RipGuard is designed to... reduce DVD ripping and the resulting supply of illegal peer to peer," said the firm. Macrovision said the new technology will work in "nearly all" current DVD player when applied to the discs, but it did not specify how many machine could have a problem with RipGuard. Some BBC News website user have expressed concern that the new technology will mean that DVDs will not work on PCs running the operating system Linux. The new technology will be welcomed by Hollywood film studio which are increasingly relying on revenue from DVD sales. The film industry ha stepped up effort to fight DVD piracy in the last 12 months, taking legal action against website which offer pirated copy of DVD movie for download. "Ultimately, we see RipGuard DVD... evolving beyond anti-piracy, and towards enablement of legitimate online transactions, interoperability in tomorrow's digital home, and the upcoming high-definition formats," said Steve Weinstein, executive vice president and general manager of Macrovision's Entertainment Technologies Group. Macrovision said RipGuard would also prevent against "rent, rip and return" - where people would rent a DVD, copy it and then return the original. RipGuard is expected to be rolled out on DVDs from the middle of 2005, the company said. The new system work specifically to block most ripping program - if used, those program will now most likely crash, the company said. Macrovision ha said that Rip Guard can be updated if hacker find a way around the new anti-copying measures.

Title: PC photo printers challenge pros
Article: Home printed picture can be cheaper and higher quality than those from High Street developers, test shows. A survey carried out by PC Pro magazine looked at which of 100 home photo printer offered a better deal than handing your snap to a photo lab. The test found that image from top PC printer kept their colour longer than professionally produced photographs. But using the wrong printer cartridge could mean snap fade in months, warned the magazine. The group test of 100 home photo printer for PCs discovered how much it cost to create image using the device compared to online developer a well a High Street name such a Jessops, Boots and Snappy Snaps. The comprehensive test also revealed how quickly different printer produced images, the quality of the finished image and how resistant finished picture were to smudging or water damage. It found that although some ink for printer now cost more than Â£2 per millilitre it can still be cheaper to produce print from photograph at home than it is to send them off to a High Street store. "If you really like your photos, then it's definitely worth printing at home instead of going to the high street, but only if you choose the right printer," said Nick Ross, top tester at PC Pro. Mr Ross said that a new generation of printer produced image with brighter colour and that were less likely to fade than many High Street developer or even some professional wedding photographers. Some High Street photo shop can be the cheapest when it came to developing print that were 6x4in, said Mr Ross, but the test revealed that image 7x5in and 8x10in in size were cheaper to produce at home. According to PC Pro, producing a print 8x10in on an Epson R800 printer using top quality paper cost Â£1.87. At Jessops the same image would cost Â£2.50 and at Snappy Snaps Â£9.99. A 10x7in snap at Boots would cost Â£4.99. "Considering how inconvenient it can be to go to the High Street and how silver-halide print can fade in the sun, we're adamant that it's now better, cheaper and more convenient to print at home," he said. Ann Simpson, marketing manager at Snappy Snaps belief the convenience of high street printing will continue to attract customers. "Some people will want to do their own thing on their computer but the feedback to u is that customer often have to print two or three picture at home in order to get a good one," she said. "Many people are not skilled at getting the colour, contrast and cropping right and they don't want the hassle," she added. The magazine test found that which ink consumer use determined how long their print lasted before they started fading. It recommended avoiding so-called third-party ink not produced by printer maker because they tended to produce print that fade the quickest.

Title: Microsoft gets the blogging bug
Article: Software giant Microsoft is taking the plunge into the world of blogging. It is launching a test service to allow people to publish blogs, or online journals, called MSN Spaces. Microsoft is trailing behind competitor like Google and AOL, which already offer service which make it easy for people to set up web journals. Blogs, short for web logs, have become a popular way for people to talk about their life and express opinion online. MSN Spaces is free to anyone with a Hotmail or MSN Messenger account. People will be able to choose a layout for the page, upload image and share photo album and music playlists. The service will be supported by banner ads. "This is a simple tool for people to express themselves," said MSN's Blake Irving. This is Microsoft's first foray into blogging, which ha taken off a a web phenomenon in the past year. Competitors like Google already offer free service through it Blogger site, while AOL provides it member with journals. Accurate figure for the number of blog in existence are hard to come by. According to blog analysis firm Technorati, the so-called blogosphere, ha doubled every five and a half month for the last 18 months. It now estimate that the number of blog in existence ha exceeded 4.8 million, although some speculate that less than a quarter are regularly maintained.

Title: Fry set for role in Hitchhiker's
Article: Actor Stephen Fry is joining the cast of the forthcoming film adaptation of The Hitchhiker's Guide To The Galaxy. Fry will provide the voice of The Guide, an electronic book which accompanies the story's hero Arthur Dent on his travel around the galaxy. Martin Freeman, John Malkovich, Bill Nighy and Alan Rickman are co-starring in the film, due for release in May. The late Douglas Adams' original 1977 script have also been turned into a series of successful books. "Being asked to do the voice of The Guide is like having your birthday on Christmas Day, discovering a winning lottery ticket in your stocking and having chocolate poured all over you," said Fry, a self-confessed fan of the book. The film's executive producer Robbie Stamp said that Adams, who died in 2001, would have been "delighted" with the choice of Fry for the role. "His humour and intelligence are perfect for the voice of The Guide," added Mr Stamp. Adams wrote the screenplay based on his book before his premature death, while a new radio series wa aired 26 year after the first broadcast and included many of the original cast members. Article: A fresh delay ha hit controversial new European Union rule which govern computer-based inventions. The draft law wa not adopted by EU minister a planned at a Brussels meeting on Monday during which it wa supposed to have been discussed. The fresh delay came after Polish official had raised concern about the law for the second time in two months. Critics say the law would favour large company over small one and could impact open-source software innovation. "There wa at one point the intention to put the item on today's agenda. But in the end we could not put it on," an EU spokesman told the Reuters agency. He added that no date had been chosen for more discussion of the law. In December, Poland requested more time to consider the issue because it wa concerned that the law could lead to the patenting of pure computer software. Its minister want to see the phrasing of the text of the Directive on the Patentability of Computer-Implemented Inventions changed so that it excludes software patenting. Poland is a large EU member, so it backing for the legislation is vital. The EU say the law would bring Europe more in line with how such law work in the US, but this ha caused some angry debate amongst critic and supporters. Title: Greek pair attend drugs hearing
Article: Greek sprinter Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou have appeared before an independent tribunal which will decide if their ban should stand. They were given provisional suspension by athletics' ruling body the IAAF in December for failing to take drug test before the Athens Olympics. The pair arrived with former coach Christos Tzekos to give evidence at the Hellenic Olympic Committee's offices. A decision is expected to be announced before the end of February. Whatever the ruling, all party will have the right to appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Yiannis Papadoyiannakis, who wa head of the Greek Olympic team at the Athens Games last year, also testified at the tribunal, along with other Greek sport official and athletes. "I believe the tribunal will reach a decision that will uphold the standing of the institution," said Papadoyiannakis. "Whatever the athlete have done, we must not forget that they have offered u great moments." Kenteris won 200m gold at the 2000 Sydney Olympics, while Thanou won silver in the 100m. They withdrew from the Athens Games last August after missing drug test on the eve of the opening ceremony. The pair spent four day in a hospital, claiming they had been injured in a motorcycle crash. The five-member tribunal, assembled by the Hellenic Association of Amateur Athletics, is also examining allegation that Kenteris and Thanou avoided test in Tel Aviv and Chicago before the Games. Tzekos wa also banned for two year by the IAAF. He face charge of assisting in the use of prohibited substance and tampering with the doping inspection process. All three, who have repeatedly denied the allegations, have also been charged by a Greek prosecutor and face trial for doping-related charges. A trial date ha not been set. In imposing two-year suspension on the duo on 22 December, the IAAF described their explanation for missing the test a "unacceptable". But Kenteris' lawyer Gregory Ioannidis told BBC Sport earlier this week he wa confident the sprinter would be cleared of the charge of failing to give information on their location and refusing to submit to testing. "We refute both charge a unsubstantiated and illogical," he said. "There have been certain breach in the correct application of the rule on behalf of the sporting authority and their officials, and these procedural breach have also violated my client's rights. "There is also evidence that prof the fact that my client ha been persecuted."

Title: Ireland 19-13 England
Article: Ireland consigned England to their third straight Six Nations defeat with a stirring victory at Lansdowne Road. A second-half try from captain Brian O'Driscoll and 14 point from Ronan O'Gara kept Ireland on track for their first Grand Slam since 1948. England scored first through Martin Corry but had "tries" from Mark Cueto and Josh Lewsey disallowed. Andy Robinson's men have now lost nine of their last 14 match since the 2003 World Cup final. The defeat also heralded England's worst run in the championship since 1987. Ireland last won the title, then the Five Nations, in 1985, but 20 year on they share top spot in the table on maximum point with Wales. And Eddie O'Sullivan's side banished the ghost of 2003 when England were rampant 42-6 victor in claiming the Grand Slam at Lansdowne Road. In front of a supercharged home crowd on a dry but blustery day in Dublin, Ireland tore into the white-shirted visitor from the kick-off and made their intention clear when O'Gara landed a fourth-minute drop-goal. England took their time to settle but their first real venture into Ireland's half produced a simple score for Corry. The number eight picked up the ball from the back of a ruck and found an absence of green jersey between himself and the Irish line, racing 25 yard to touch down. England fly-half Charlie Hodgson nailed the conversion from out on the left, but almost immediately O'Gara, winning his 50th cap, answered with two penalty in quick succession. England were awarded a penalty of their own on the halfway line after 20 minutes, and Hodgson, the villain at Twickenham, coolly bisected the posts. The first quarter wa marked by period of tactical kicking, but it wa Ireland who were showing more willingness to spread the ball wide to their eager and inventive backs. A series of probe led by the talismanic O'Driscoll, back from hamstring injury, resulted in a penalty but Ireland chose to kick for touch. From the line-out, the ball wa recycled back to O'Gara, who stroked his second drop-goal, this time off the right upright. As the interval approached, wing Josh Lewsey wa the catalyst for England's most promising attack. The Wasps star raced up his touchline and Hodgson's cross-kick put in Mark Cueto for an apparent score, but the Sale wing wa ruled to have started in front of the kicker. England began the second half well and had Ireland pinned in their own half. But another English indiscretion on a rare Irish break-out awarded O'Gara a kick at goal, which he missed. England's pressure continued, and a wave of attack saw centre Jamie Noon dragged down yard from the line before Hodgson landed a drop-goal. The lead wa shortlived, however. Ireland raced upfield, deft handling from the backs, including a clever dummy from Geordan Murphy on Hodgson, ending with O'Driscoll going over in the right corner and touching down close to the posts. O'Gara missed a penalty which would have put Ireland nine point clear, and the home crowd breathed a sigh of relief when Hodgson's cross-kick wa fumbled by lock Ben Kay near the line. Anticipation of a home win sent the noise level sky-high, but O'Gara missed another chance to seal the game with a wayward drop-goal attempt. Inside the last 10 minutes, England poured forward, spurred on by scrum-half Matt Dawson, who replaced Leicester's Harry Ellis. But despite one near miss with the pack over the line - not checked on the TV replay by referee Jonathan Kaplan - England were unable to pull off a face-saving win. Ireland next face France at Lansdowne Road in two weeks' time before the potential title decider against Wales in Cardiff. England are still to meet Italy at Twickenham, in what is now a wooden spoon decider, and Scotland. Title: Jones files Conte lawsuit
Article: Marion Jones ha filed a lawsuit for defamation against Balco bos Victor Conte following his allegation that he gave her performance-enhancing drugs. The Sydney Olympic gold medallist say Conte damaged her reputation and she is seeking $25m (Â£13m) in the suit. Conte, whose company is at the centre of a doping investigation, made the claim in a US television programme. He and three others were indicted in February by a federal grand jury for a variety of alleged offences. In an email to the Associated Press on Wednesday, Conte said: "I stand by everything I said". Jones won three gold medal and two bronze in Sydney in 2000. Her lawsuit, filed in the US District Court in San Francisco, said the sprinter had passed a lie detector test and that she "has never taken banned performance-enhancing drugs". Conte's statements, the suit added, were "false and malicious". After the ABC television program earlier this month, Jones' lawyer Richard Nicholls said: "Marion ha steadfastly maintained her position throughout: she ha never, ever used performance-enhancing drugs. "Victor Conte is a man facing a 42-count federal indictment, while Marion Jones is one of America's most decorated female athletes. Mr Conte's statement have been wildly contradictory. "Mr Conte chose to make unsubstantiated allegation on television, while Marion Jones demanded to take and then passed a lie detector examination. "Mr Conte is simply not credible. We challenge him to submit to the same lie detector procedure that Marion Jones passed." The sport's ruling body, the IAAF, is taking a cautious approach to Conte's allegation but contacted the US Anti-Doping Agency. Communications director Nick Davies said the IAAF would seek to contact Conte "for further information". But Davies stressed it would be up to the American authority to decide whether they will take action against Jones in light of Conte's television interview and the world governing body would monitor the situation closely. "If it is felt there is case to answer, it would be for it national governing body (USA Track and Field) to take the appropriate disciplinary action," he added. "The US Anti-Doping Agency ha proved itself to be very diligent in it anti-doping war. "And I am sure, like ourselves, they will be watching the television programme with great interest." Jones, who is under investigation for steroid use by the US Anti-Doping Agency, ha continually denied ever taking illegal substance since being investigated in the Balco scandal, although she praised a zinc supplement Conte marketed. Jones, who did not win any medal in Athens in August, ha never failed a drug test. Meanwhile, Conte, who ha been charged along with three other men of distributing illegal steroid and money laundering, is due to face trial in March.

"A lot of people want the club's interest to be with people who have grown up with the club and have got it interest at heart," said Ferdinand. Title: Profile: David Miliband
Article: David Miliband's rapid rise through the rank of government continues with his promotion to Cabinet Office minister. Elected in a safe Labour seat in 2001 his previous job wa school standard minister - a role he won in May 2002. Prior to the last election he wa a key figure in New Labour a the head of the Downing Street policy unit where he wa a key member of the manifesto writing team. Seen a one of the more intellectual figure in the government, he wa also working for Tony Blair in his policy unit when he wa leader of the opposition. A brief glance at Mr Miliband's family background reveals an impressive socialist pedigree in the form of his father Ralph, who died in 1994. He wa an eminent and influential leftwing academic. And while David Miliband is seen a a key Blair lieutenant his brother Ed is a special advisor to Chancellor Gordon Brown. Prior to working for Mr Blair, David Miliband spent time at the left-leaning Institute for Public Policy Research. He then became secretary of the Commission on Social Justice. The 39-year-old wa educated at Haverstock Comprehensive before going on to Oxford to study politics, philosophy and economics. He also took an MSc in political science from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Title: Toxic web links help virus spread
Article: Virus writer have begun using the power of the web to spread their malicious wares. A Windows virus called Bofra is turning infected machine into distributor of it malicious code. Those clicking on the poisoned link in e-mail message sent out by infected machine may fall victim to the virus. The trick is being used to prevent the progam being caught by anti-virus software that comb through code contained in e-mail attachments. The virus that us this trick is called Bofra and the first member of the family of worm appeared on 10 November. They exploit a Windows vulnerability that wa discovered only a few day earlier. Like many other recent viruses, Bofra plunder the address book in Microsoft Outlook for e-mail address and scour other file on an infected machine for fresh target addresses. The virus us it own mail sending software to despatch e-mail message to potential victim but, unlike many other recent viruses, doe not itself travel via mail. Instead the body of the mail message sent out contain fake weblinks that, when clicked on, connect back to the machine that distributed that e-mail. Essentially, Bofra turn infected machine into small web server that happily dole out copy of the virus. The message try to trick people into clicking on the link by promising pornographic video and image or by posing a payment confirmation for a Paypal transaction. Copies of the message seen by the BBC News website had bright yellow and green backgrounds. Those clicking on the link will inadvertently download the Bofra virus which will then start searching for new address to send itself to. Filtering firm Clearswift said this tactic of creating thousand of mini web server wa designed to help the virus spread quickly and avoid attempt to shut it down. In the past other malicious program have relied on a single web server that downloads viral code to target machines. Shutting down this central server usually stop the virus spreading. Clearswift said that fact that no viral code travel in the e-mail message sent out by machine infected by Bofra could hamper effect to limit it spread. Finnish anti-virus firm F-Secure said that, so far, it had not seen many copy of the Bofra virus and it variant in circulation. Tim Warner, spokesman for anti-virus firm Finjan, said: "You have people getting very creative now to deliver the virus and get it propagating." Mr Warner said organisation needed to prepare deep defence to keep out the modern form of malicious mobile code. "Most firm have secured their e-mail gateway," said Mr Warner, "but the irony is that most of them let malicious content through the web gateways." He said behavioural system that monitor what user do can help to spot when virus have penetrated organisation and have started hunting for other victims. The Bofra family of viruses, which were originally thought to be offshoot of the MyDoom bug, can infect machine running Windows 2000, 95, 98, Me, NT, XP and Server 2003. Users running Windows XP that have applied the SP2 update are not vulnerable to the loophole that Bofra exploits.

Article: A regiments' campaign group is to target nine marginal Labour seat at the General Election. Save the Scottish Regiments will also field a candidate against Armed Forces Minister Adam Ingram in East Kilbride. The group, which is unhappy at defence merger plans, is endorsing opposition candidate in nine seats. The marginals are Aberdeen South, Dumfriesshire, Dundee East and West, South West Edinburgh, Ochil, Stirling, East Renfrewshire and Western Isles. The campaigner unveiled a huge poster featuring Black Watch soldier fighting the war in Iraq before they announced their election plans. Former Scots Guardsman Allan Hendry will challenge Mr Ingram. The group said it is well organised, with 350 volunteers, and will be announcing at least one other candidate later. It added that it can only be stopped from inflicting serious damage on Labour if the government revers it plan to merge the six Scottish regiments. Scotland's only Conservative MP Peter Duncan said the Save the Scottish Regiments had done a "superb job" in fighting against defence cuts. He added: "Their action have reflected the pride that most people in this country have in our troops, and have shown a steely determination to make Labour pay for their betrayal. "I have been honoured to speak at their rally throughout Scotland." Scottish National Party leader Alex Salmond said it had received a "big boost" from the campaign's decision to endorse SNP candidate in four marginal seats. "Labour's arrogance ha been their undoing. In trying to get rid of Scotland's historic regiments, Labour MPs will end up being scrapped themselves," he said. However, Labour MP George Foulkes said the campaigner would not make any difference to the outcome of the election and would not win the argument. "A serving soldier know that what Labour is proposing is right," he said. As well a their election move, Save the Scottish Regiments will join other campaigner at a rally in London in the spring. Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon announced last year that Scotland's regiment would be combined into a single unit. The move wa part of overall Army reforms.

Title: China suspends 26 power projects
Article: China ha ordered a halt to construction work on 26 big power stations, including two at the Three Gorges Dam, on environmental grounds. The move is a surprising one because China is struggling to increase energy supply for it booming economy. Last year 24 province suffered black outs. The State Environmental Protection Agency said the 26 project had failed to do proper environmental assessments. Topping the list wa a controversial dam on the scenic upper Yangtze River. "Construction of these project ha started without approval of the assessment of their environmental impact... they are typical illegal project of construction first, approval next," said SEPA vice-director Pan Yue, in a statement on the agency's website. Some of the project may be allowed to start work again with the proper permits, but others would be cancelled, he said. Altogether, the agency ordered 30 project halted. Other project included a petrochemical plant and a port in Fujian. The bulk of the list wa made up of new power plants, with some extension to existing ones. The stoppage would appear to be another step in the central government's battle to control project licensed by local officials. However, previous crackdown have tended to focus on project for which the government argued there wa overcapacity, such a steel and cement. The government ha encouraged construction of new electricity generating capacity to solve chronic energy shortage which forced many factory onto part-time working last year. In 2004, China increased it generating capacity by 12.6%, or 440,700 megawatt (MW). The biggest single project to be halted wa the Xiluodi Dam project, designed to produce 12,600 MW of electricity. It is being built on the Jinshajiang - or 'river of golden sand' a the upper reach of the Yangtze are known. Second and third on the agency's list were two power station being built at the $22bn Three Gorges Dam project on the central Yangtze - an underground 4,200 MW power plant and a 100 MW plant. The Three Gorges Dam ha proved controversial in China - where more than half a million people have been relocated to make way for it - and abroad. It ha drawn criticism from environmental group and overseas human right activists. The damming of the Upper Yangtze ha also begun to attract criticism from environmentalist in China. In April 2004, central government official ordered a halt to work on the nearby Nu River, which is part of a United Nations world heritage site, the Three Parallel Rivers site which cover the Yangtze, Mekong and Nu (also known a the Salween), according to the UK-published China Review. That move reportedly followed a protest from the Thai government about the downstream impact of the dams, and a critical documentary made by Chinese journalists. China's energy shortage influenced global price for oil, coal and shipping last year.

Title: Blair joins school sailing trip
Article: The prime minister ha donned a life jacket and joined school child in a sailing dinghy a he sought to sell his party's education policies. Tony Blair sailed across the lake in Bromsgrove, Worcestershire, while on a visit with Education Secretary Ruth Kelly to back school outings. Mr Blair later stressed Labour's election pledge to focus on education, when he met parent in the area. The Conservatives and Lib Dems both say his pledge are "worthless". All the party are stepping up campaigning ahead of a General Election widely expected to be held on 5 May. Mr Blair, looking a little windswept, joined two girl from St Egwin's Middle School in Evesham and an instructor for a trip in the Wayfarer dinghy, closely followed by a boat full of photographers. Afterwards he said outdoor activity were beneficial for child but accepted that lot of teacher now worried about taking part for fear of being sued if something went wrong. "What we're doing is introducing some simple guideline so if teacher follow those they are not going to be at risk of legal action," Mr Blair said. "When you are doing these type of activity you've got to exercise some common sense there obviously. "You can't have a situation where parent or teacher end up being worried that they're going to be subject to all sort of legal action if they take child sailing or doing outdoor activity that is actually good for the kid and good for their health and their character." The pledge on education - "your child achieving more" - wa one of six election pledge unveiled by Mr Blair last week. If it win a third term in the general election expected this year, Labour is committed to giving parent more choice between schools; allowing all secondary school to take on specialist status; opening 200 city academy and creating 100,000 more sixth-form places. It aim to improve discipline in school by adopting a "zero tolerance" approach to disruption of class and introducing fixed penalty notice for truants. Labour also plan to give head teacher at group of local school control over funding for unit to handle disruptive pupils. Parents and teacher who met Mr Blair on Tuesday were invited to the informal discussion after writing to their MPs to raise concern about education. It is the latest in a series of event designed to show the prime minister is speaking directly to voter in the run-up to the election - and that he ha not lost touch. For the Conservatives, shadow education secretary Tim Collins said: "Mr Blair¿s government is all talk. He must be judged on what he ha done in two terms, not what he mendaciously claim he would do in a third. That judgment will be damning." The Liberal Democrats are promising to cut class size for the youngest child and ensure all child are taught by a qualified teacher in each subject.

Title: India's Reliance family feud heats up
Article: The ongoing public spat between the two heir of India's biggest conglomerate, Reliance Group, ha spilled over to the board meeting of a leading company within the group. Anil Ambani, vice-chairman of India Petrochemicals Limited (IPCL), stayed away from a gathering of senior manager on Thursday. The move follows a decision earlier this month by Anil - the younger brother of Reliance Group president Mukesh Ambani - to resign from his post. His resignation wa not accepted by his brother, who is also the bos of IPCL. The IPCL board met in Mumbai to discus the company's result for the October-to-December quarter. It is understood that the board also considered Anil's resignation and asked him to reconsider his decision. However, Anil's demand that Anand Jain - another IPCL board member accused by Anil of creating a rift in the Ambani family - be thrown out, wa not met. Anil ha accused Anand Jain, a confidant of his brother Mukesh, of playing a negative role in the Ambani family, and being responsible for the trouble between the brothers. On Wednesday, the board of Reliance Energy, another Reliance Group company, reaffirmed it faith in Anil, who is the company's chief. Reliance Group acquired the government's 26% stake in IPCL - India's second-largest petrochemical company - in 2002, a part of the privatisation drive. Meanwhile, the group's flagship company, Reliance Industries, ha it board meeting on Friday to consider it financial results. Mukesh is the company's chairman and Anil it deputy, and it is expected that both brother will come face to face in the meeting. The Ambani family control 48% of the group, which is worth $17bn (Â£9.1bn; 745bn Indian rupees). It wa founded by their father, Dhiru Bhai Ambani, who died two year ago.

Title: Lib Dems 'to target stamp duty'
Article: The Liberal Democrats are promising to raise the stamp duty threshold if they win the general election, in a bid to court first-time house buyers. Vince Cable, the party's Treasury spokesman, said raising the threshold to Â£150,000 would prevent over 400,000 home-buyers from paying the tax. He said first-time buyer were being "squeezed out" of the housing market. The Labour party said the Liberal Democrats needed to explain how they would pay for the plan. The plan form part of a wider Lib Dems policy to encourage first time buyer and those on lower income into the market. Under the proposals, the average saving for a new buyer would be more than Â£1,000, according to Mr Cable. "First time buyer are being squeezed out of the housing market not only by higher house price but also by being swept into the stamp duty net," he said. "By failing to uprate the stamp duty threshold Gordon Brown ha hit first time buyer and those on low income the hardest. "By pledging to increase the threshold to Â£150,000, the Liberal Democrats will make it possible for many first time buyer to buy a property without facing this tax." Paul Boateng MP, Labour's Chief Secretary to the Treasury, said: "The Lib Dems' sum don't add up. "They can have no credibility until they can say how they would fund their ever growing list of tax and spending commitments." Mr Cable will publish his "Alternative Budget" on Monday.

Title: Jones medals 'must go if guilty'
Article: World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) chief Dick Pound say Marion Jones should be stripped of all her medal if found guilty of taking banned substances. Victor Conte, of Balco Laboratories, claim the American sprinter regularly used drug to enhance her performance. "If she is found guilty she should be stripped of all her medal and banned for two years," said Pound. Asked if there wa a timescale a to what medal could be taken, Pound said: "That is not an issue at all." However, under International Olympic Committee (IOC) rules, athlete can only be stripped of their medal if caught within three year of the event. Jones, who won five medal at the 2000 Olympics, denies using drug and say she will take legal action over Conte's allegations. Balco Laboratories is the firm at the centre of a wide-reaching investigation into doping in the US. Pound continued: "If she ha indeed taken drug it is going to be a big disappointment for a lot of people."

Title: Lufthansa may sue over Bush visit
Article: German airline Lufthansa may sue federal agency for damage after the arrival of US president George W Bush disrupted flights. Lufthansa said that it may lose million of euro a a result of Air Force One landing at Frankfurt airport. Flights were affected for an hour on Wednesday morning, double the time that had been expected, leading to cancellation and delays. Lufthansa account for six out of every 10 plane using Frankfurt's airport. "We are doing research into the possibility we have," Michael Lamberty, a Lufthansa spokesman told the BBC. "We are checking if there is action to be taken and in which court it could be taken." Mr Lamberty explained that the company did not plan to pursue Germany's air traffic controllers' organisation or the airport authority but wanted instead to see if it wa possible to sue the German federal agency that gave the orders. The company said that it had to cancel 77 short and medium-distance flights, affecting about 5,000 passengers. Long-haul traveller were not disrupted. Central to the problem wa that instead of half an hour, the arrival of President Bush on the German leg of his European tour took the best part of an hour, Lufthansa said. During that time, restriction were put on plane taxiing, taking off and landing at Frankfurt's Rhein-Main airport. The extra time taken by President Bush and his entourage meant that there wa a knock-on effect that led to significant delays. Mr Lamberty said that 92 outgoing flight and 86 income flight were delayed by an average of an hour following President Bush's arrival, affecting almost 17,000 passengers. Despite the problems, Mr Lamberty said that it wa not certain that Lufthansa would take legal action.

Title: Elton plays Paris charity concert
Article: Sir Elton John ha performed at a special concert in Paris to raise money for the victim of the Asian tsunami. The British singer played to a 2,700-strong audience on Sunday at the French capital's Bastille opera house. The concert wa also part of an attempt to bring a broader range of event to the famous venue. Money raised will go to the Fondation pour l'Enfance (Foundation for Childhood) which aim to rebuild a children's shelter in Sri Lanka. Sir Elton played hit from his vast back catalogue to a sell-out crowd which included former French president Valery Giscard d'Estaing and his wife Anne-Aymone. The veteran pop star played piano accompaniment throughout the concert which lasted for three hour without an interval. He told the crowd: "Throughout the years, I've done a lot of drug and alcohol. It's true that I wa a nightmare, impossible. For the last 14 year I've been normal. Now my drug is called David" - a reference to David Furnish, his partner. The crowd, who greeted each song with a standing ovation, also included French singer Charles Aznavour and British ambassador Sir John Holmes. Sir Elton ha also teamed up with Phil Collins to record a version of Eric Clapton's 1991 hit Tears In Heaven to raise money for the relief fund. A release date ha yet to be set for the recording, which wa organised by Sharon Osbourne.

Title: Labour's core support takes stock
Article: Tony Blair ha told Labour supporter he's "back" and still hungry for the job of prime minister - but doe that sum up the mood at the party's spring conference in Gateshead? "The electorate are keener on the government than some Labour Party members," is the dry assessment of Graham Lane, leader of the Labour group on Newham Council. The problem, according to Mr Lane, is not continuing division over Iraq, foundation hospital or tuition fees, or even voter apathy, but Mr Blair himself. "I have a new slogan. Vote Blair, Get Brown. That's what I am telling people on the doorstep. Don't worry, he will be gone soon." His friend, Saxon Spence, leader of Devon county Labour group, lay the blame for any lack of campaigning zeal on one issue above all others. "You cannot underestimate the impact of the war in Iraq. We lost people from our local party who had some key roles." But the two friend were fired up by Gordon Brown's speech on Saturday, with it appeal to core Labour value on social justice, health and education. "There wa real passion. I think we have all felt a little jaded, but it reminded u why we joined the party in the first place," said Mrs Spence. "If he hadn't have walked off the stage, they would still be clapping," added Mr Lane. But for every Brownite at the spring conference there wa an equally ardent fan of Mr Blair. Stephen Douglas, 26, from Wales, said after the PM's speech on Sunday: "I think it wa a bit of a turning point, given the roasting he ha had on some issues. The guy still ha it." Tony Martin, of Burnley, said: "He is the first leader who ha won u two terms. This bloke ha delivered for us." Malcolm Shipley, of Shipley, said it wa "as if he is coming round to the right approach again". Katrina Bull, a prospective parliamentary candidate said Mr Blair had shown he could rouse the party's grassroots: "I think if every voter wa able to spend time in a room with Tony, the way we have today, we will have no problem with turnout." She had just emerged from a Q&A session, in which Mr Blair - tieless and supremely at ease - answered question posed via the party's website. A party of councillor from Nottingham agreed that there wa nothing wrong with Mr Blair's leadership - and they were adamant that the campaigning strength of the party in their city wa a strong a ever. Iraq, they insisted, would not be a factor for most voters. "The biggest problem we have got at the moment is that we keep getting all these poll saying we are going to run away with the election. "It might sound great, but it doe create this sense of complacency among our own voter and I think that is the greater problem than Iraq," said Nottingham City Councillor Brian Parbutt. And even Mr Blair's most vocal critic seemed to agree on one thing - he is a master of the sort of glossy, high-profile campaigning that ha become Labour's hallmark, epitomised by Friday's whistle-stop tour of marginal seats. A group of shop steward from the Swan Hunter shipyard, who said they were facing redundancy, could barely suppress their anger at Mr Blair's failure to, a they saw it, shake off his Tory leaning and stand up for manufacturing in the North East. They were also scathing about the alleged benefit of showpiece project such a conference venue Sage Centre, heralded by John Prescott and others this weekend a a symbol of Labour's success in urban regeneration. "It is no good having the Sage or Baltic if you haven't got the money for the entrance fee," said Terry Telford. But when asked about Mr Blair's bravura performance on Friday, the men agreed he wa "brilliant". And they would all be out on the doorstep pushing the Labour message come election time. Title: Talks aim to avert pension strike
Article: Talks aimed at averting a series of national strike over pension reform will take place this weekend. Five public sector union will hold private talk with Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott at Labour's spring conference in Gateshead. They want the government to withdraw regulation - due to be introduced in week - which would raise the pension age for council worker from 60 to 65. Up to 1.4m worker could take part in a strike already earmarked for 23 March. However, all side are anxious to avoid a major confrontation in the run up to the general election, said BBC labour affair correspondent Stephen Cape. In four days, Britain's biggest union Unison will start balloting 800,000 local government worker on strikes. Other public sector union have pledged to follow. It is just week before new regulation are introduced to raise the pension age of local government workers. The five union meeting Mr Prescott want the government to withdraw these regulations. This would allow month of tough negotiation to follow, said our correspondent. But a spokesman for Mr Prescott warned that the change to the local government pension scheme would have to go ahead in April. Privately minister believe this will be the "less painful" option, our correspondent added. The Public and Commercial Services Union (PCS) will co-ordinate any industrial action with up to six other public sector unions. PCS leader Mark Serwotka warned last week that there could be further walkout unless there wa a government rethink. "For a government that lecture everyone on choice - choice on public service, choice on this and choice on that - isn't it ironic that they're saying to public sector worker there is no choice," he said. "If you want the pension you were promised when you started you must work for an extra five year - that is working until people drop. "In the 20th century, it's completely unacceptable." Unison's 800,000 workers, the Transport and General Workers' Union's 70,000 and Amicus' 20,000 are among those being balloted about a 23 March walkout. Mr Prescott held a private meeting with senior union figure last week. It is understood no deal wa offered in that meeting but there wa room for further negotiations.

Title: EU rules 'won't stop UK spending'
Article: The shape of the UK's economy In graphic But he denied that he wa ruling out British membership of the euro despite saying there would be no assessment of the five economic test this year. Mr Brown said that it wa vital the UK continued to invest in infrastructure, science, and education in the future. Otherwise it would be overtaken by the like of China, he told MPs. The chancellor said that the EU's planned change in the growth and stability pact - designed to ensure that country in the euro zone do not borrow too much - would force Britain to run a budget surplus of 1% over the economic cycle. Under Mr Brown's rules, the UK current budget must be in balance over the economic cycle, but public investment is not counted a part of that deficit. He told the House of Commons Treasury Select Committee that the EU rule "make it difficult for a low debt country to run the investment programme that are necessary to improve it infrastructure". But he argued that the EU wa moving in the direction of the UK principles, and would eventually recognise the need to consider budget deficit over a longer period than one year, to include investment, and to take more account of the total size of government debt a well a the balance each year. Under Mr Brown's "sustainable investment" rule, government debt should be under 40% - in contrast to the 60% allowed under the growth and stability pact. Mr Brown vigorously denied Conservative claim that he had in effect fiddled the figure to ensure that he met his own fiscal rules. In March the Office of National Statistics (ONS) reclassified Â£3.4bn of spending on road repair a public investment - shortly before the chancellor announced in the Budget that he would meet his own fiscal budget rule by only Â£6bn. Conservative Michael Fallon asked Mr Brown whether the Treasury had leaned on ONS to make this change, and said that the ONS had received a written paper from the Treasury on this matter. But the chancellor said Mr Fallon wa "impugning the integrity" of the Office of National Statistics and said the decision had been made completely independently. Mr Brown also denied that he wa increasing tax to fund his spending gap. He told the Treasury Select Committee that a growing economy meant more people in work and more profit for company which would boost Treasury coffers. Earlier, ex-Conservative chancellor Ken Clarke welcomed a relaxation of the rule governing the euro zone. Speaking on Radio 4's Today programme, Mr Clarke said political give and take would replace more "rigid" rules. But fellow Tory David Heathcoat-Amory said the folly of the system wa in trying to run Europe's varied economy on one set of rules. "The essential point here is that the stability and growth pact ha turned out to be a fake," he said. "The warning is about the European constitution, which we are going to have a vote on in a year or two, and that centralises and entrenches these rule in a constitution. It give more power to Brussels to co-ordinate thing like employment and economic policy." But, speaking to the Treasury Select Committee, Gordon Brown said that the new stability pact rule were not part of a binding Treaty and could be changed again the future - potentially opening the way for future euro membership. "The condition for euro entry are unchanged by this new decision about the stability and growth pact," Mr. Brown said.

Title: O'Sullivan keeps his powder dry
Article: When you are gunning for glory and ultimate success keeping the gunpowder dry is essential. Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan appears to have done that quite successfully in the run-up to this season's Six Nations Championship. He decreed after the 2003 World Cup that player should have a decent conditioning period during the year. That became a reality at the end of last summer with a 10-week period at the start of the this season. It may have annoyed his Scottish, and in particularly Welsh, cousin who huffed and puffed at the disrespect apparently shown to the Celtic League. We will say nothing of Mike Ruddock ''poaching'' eight of the Dragons side that faced Leinster on Sunday. But, like O'Sullivan, he wa well within his rights, particularly when you are talking about the national side and pride that go along with it. The IRFU ha thrown their weight behind O'Sullivan, who must be glad that in the main, there is centrally-controlled contracts. Bar Keith Gleeson who is just returning from a broken leg, everyone of O'Sullivan's squad is fit, fresh and standing at the oche ready to launch this season's campaign. But I doubt whether O'Sullivan is going to gloat about the handling of his players. He is not that sort of person. However, he may look at the overworked and injury-hit England, Wales and France squad whose player have been overworked, and then pat himself on the back for his foresight. But there is still the question of turning up and transferring that freshness into positive result when the referee signal the start of the game. Already Ireland are being earmarked a hot favourite in many quarter to go the whole hog this season. A first Grand Slam since Karl Mullen's led the team to a clean sweep in 1948. With England and France visiting Lansdowne Road for the last time before the old darling is pulled down, everything look perfectly placed. But in the day of yore that frightened the life out of any Irishman. Under the burden of great expectations, Ireland have crumpled. Take the Triple Crown-winning side of 1985 under Mick Doyle. They were expected to up the ante further for a Grand Slam, only the second in Ireland's history. What happened in 1986? Whitewashed. You see, Ireland, in any sport, love to be downsized. Then they can go out and prove a point to the contrary. It is the nature of the beast. But O'Sullivan's side are very capable of proving a salient point this season. After their first Triple Crown for 19 years, they can live up to their success and take a further step up the ladder. O'Sullivan ha kept faith and displayed loyalty to his players, and they have repaid him in spade ... and there is more to come. He ha some old dog in his squad, but he will come to this season's championship with a different box of tricks, and a new verve to succeed. Ireland can indeed succeed, but just whisper it.

Article: Sonia O'Sullivan ha indicated that she would like to participate in next month's World Cross Country Championships in St Etienne. Athletics Ireland have hinted that the 35-year-old Cobh runner may be included in the official line-up for the event in France on 19-20 March. Provincial team were selected after last Saturday's Nationals in Santry and will be officially announced this week. O'Sullivan is at present preparing for the London marathon on 17 April. The participation of O'Sullivan, currentily training at her base in Australia, would boost the Ireland team who won the bronze three year agio. The first three at Santry last Saturday, Jolene Byrne, Maria McCambridge and Fionnualla Britton, are automatic selection and will most likely form part of the long-course team. O'Sullivan will also take part in the Bupa Great Ireland Run on 9 April in Dublin.

Title: Comic Morris returns with sitcom
Article: Comedian Chris Morris, who created controversial TV show Brass Eye, is to return to screen with a new sitcom about a spoof London medium worker. Morris will direct and co-write Nathan Barley - a character from cult website TV Go Home - for Channel 4. It is a send-up of the stereotypical "cool" metropolitan medium scene, with Nicholas Burns in the title role. A Brass Eye satire of the medium handling of paedophilia sparked 2,500 complaint in 2001. Nathan Barley will be "a character-driven comedy", according to Charlie Brooker, who created TV Go Home in 1999 and ha co-written the series. Barley is described a a "webmaster, guerrilla film-maker, screenwriter, DJ and in his own words, a 'self-facilitating medium node". The story will also feature Dan Ashcroft, a style magazine columnist, and his sister Claire, a film-maker who hate the "cool" scene. As well a Brass Eye, Morris wa behind another news show satire, The Day Today, and dark sketch comedy Jam. The new show is expected to begin in February.

Title: Blinx sequel purrs nicely
Article: The original Blinx wa intended to convert many platform game lover to Microsoft's then new Xbox console. Its sharp graphic and novel gameplay, with the main character able to pause, slow, rewind and fast-forward time, were meant to lure many fan to the new machine. But poor design meant the game became a very frustrating affair with player often stranded half-way through a level without the required tool to finish. Thankfully, the sequel ha fixed many of the original faults. This time around you do not play a Blinx but instead you are given the chance to create two unique cat character and two pig characters. The character generator is very detailed and a few minute of tweaking and adjusting will create a unique personality to unleash on the game. As the game progress you swap between the two rival factions, pig and feline, assuming the role of your created characters. The thrust of the game see the two faction competing to recover piece of a missing Time Crystal. As in the original, your feline persona can control time, but this time the pig get to control space. There are a number of puzzle which require control over time to solve while the pig can create thing such a warps, space bubble and void trap in order to progress. The control over space and time is achieved through a number of VCR-style icon and is quite intuitive. Annoyingly, the puzzle are a little too obviously flagged up and most gamers will find it more of a chore than a challenge to solve them. The game ha also tried to emulate franchise such a Jak and Daxter and Ratchet and Clank on PS2 and so there are a number of combat elements. These are a little predictable and tend to drag the general polish of the game down to a more dulled affair. But the game's excellent graphics, easily the best-looking platform game around, sound and dollop of humour make it an attractive game for younger platform fans. Blinx 2 is out on Xbox now.

Title: Nintendo DS aims to touch gamers
Article: The mobile gaming industry is set to explode in 2005 with a number of high-profile device offering a range of gaming and other feature such a movie and music playback. Market leader Nintendo, however, is releasing a handheld console that it say will revolutionise the way game are played. The first striking thing about the DS is how retro it looks. Far from looking like a mould-breaking handheld, it look more like Nintendo dug out a mould from a 1980s handheld prototype. The lightweight clam shell device open up to reveal two screens, and when switched on it instantly reveals it pedigree. Both screen are crisp and clear while the bottom of the two is touch sensitive. Nintendo ha given developer free rein to utilise the dual screen and ability to control the action by simply touching the screen. The Japanese gaming giant hope the DS will maintain the firm's pre-eminence in an increasingly-competitive mobile gaming market. Nintendo first launched it GameBoy console in 1989 and ha dominated the market ever since. But it lead can no longer be taken for granted. Sony will enter the market later this year with it PlayStation Portable, while start-up company Gizmondo and Tapwave Zodiac are also offering hybrid devices. "We believe the DS will appeal to all ages, both gender and gamers of any skill," said David Yarnton, Nintendo Europe's general manager said at the recent press launch for the handheld. With it two screens, wireless connectivity and backwards compatibility with the GameBoy Advance, the DS certainly ha a number of unique selling points. It went on sale in the US in mid-November priced $150 and Nintendo say sale have exceeded expectations, without giving detailed figures. Japan and Europe will have to wait until the first quarter of 2005 to get the device. With more than two million pre-orders for the device in Japan, Nintendo is confident it will keep it number one spot. But will the device prove to be a revolutionary a claimed? The game ship with a demo of Metroid Hunters - a 3D action title which can be played alone or with a group of friend using the machine's wireless capabilities. It certainly look impressive on the small machine and play smoothly even with a group of people. The game can be controlled by using the supplied stylus to aim. The top screen is used to navigate the action while the bottom screen offer a top-down map and the ability to switch weapons. It is certainly a unique control method and while it make aiming more controlled it can be a little disorientating. Super Mario 64 DS is a faithful re-creation of the Nintendo 64 classic with a host of new mini-games and new levels. The game look stunning on the portable machine and the sound too is impressive for such a small machine. One thing is for certain. Hardened gamers will have to learn to adapt to a new way of playing while it could prove to be an accessible way in to gaming for novices, Ultimately the success or failure of the device lie in the hand of developers. If they manage to create title which use the Nintendo DS's key feature then a whole new market of gamers could open up. The fear is that the touch screen and voice recognition are treated a little more than gimmicks.

Title: Be careful how you code
Article: A new European directive could put software writer at risk of legal action, warns former programmer and technology analyst Bill Thompson. If it get it way, the Dutch government will conclude it presidency of the European Union by pushing through a controversial measure that ha been rejected by the European Parliament, lack majority support from national government and will leave million of European citizen in legal limbo and facing the possibility of court case against them. If the new law wa about border controls, defence or even the new constitution, then our TV screen would be full of expert agonising over the impact on our daily lives. Sadly for those who will be directly affected, the controversy concern the patenting of computer programs, a topic that may excite the bloggers, campaigning group and technical press but doe not obsess Middle Britain. After all, how much fuss can you generate about the Directive on the Patentability of Computer-Implemented Inventions, and the way it amends Article 52 of the 1973 European Patent Convention? Yet if the new directive is nodded through at the next meeting of one of the EU's ministerial councils, a seems likely, it will allow program to be patented in Europe just a they are in the US. Many observer of the computing scene, including myself, think the result will be disastrous for small companies, innovative programmer and the free and open source software movement. It will let large company patent all sort of idea and give legal force to those who want to limit their competitors' use of really obvious ideas. In the US you cannot build a system that store customer credit card detail so that they can pay without having to re-enter them unless Amazon let you, because they hold the patent on "one-click" online purchase. It is a small invention, but Amazon made it to the patent office first and now owns it. We are relatively free from this sort of thing over here, but perhaps not for long. The new proposal go back to 2002, although argument about patentability of software and computer-implemented invention ha been going on since at least the mid-1980s. They have come to a head now after a year in which proposal were made, endorsed by the Council of Ministers, radically modified by the European Parliament and then re-presented in their original form. Some national government seem to be aware of the problems. Poland ha rejected the proposal and Germany's main political party have opposed it, but there is not enough opposition to guarantee their rejection. Early in December the British government held a consultation meeting with those who had commented on the proposals. Science Minister Lord Sainsbury went along to listen and outline the UK position, but according to those present, it wa embarrassing to see how little the minister and his official actually understood the issue concerned. The draft Directive is being put through the council a what is called an "A" item and can only be approved or rejected. No discussion or amendment is allowed. So why should we be worried? First, there is the abuse of the democratic process involved in disregarding the view of the parliament and abandoning all of their carefully argued amendments. This go to the heart of the European project, and even those who do not care about software or patent should be worried. If coder are treated like this today, who is to say that it will not be you tomorrow? More directly, once software patent are granted then any programmer will have to worry that the code they are writing is infringing someone else's patent. This is not about stealing software, a code is already protected by copyright. Patents are not copyright, but something much stronger. A patent give the owner the right to stop anyone else using their invention, even if the other person invented it separately. I have never, to my shame, managed to read Lord Byron's Childe Harold's Pilgrimage. If it wa pointed out that one of my article contained a substantial chunk of the poem then I could defend myself in court by claiming that I had simply made it up and it wa coincidence. The same doe not hold for a patent. If I sit down this afternoon and write a brilliant graphic compression routine and it happens to be the same a the LZW algorithm used in GIF files, then I am in trouble under patent law, at least in the US. Coincidence is no defence. The proposed directive is supported by many of the major software companies, but this is hardly surprising since most of them are US-based and they have already had to cope with a legal environment that allows patents. They have legal department and, more crucially, patent of their own which they can trade or cross-license with other patent holders. Even this system break down, of course, a Microsoft found out last year when they initially lost a case brought by Eolas which claimed that Internet Explorer (and other browsers) infringed an Eolas patent. That one wa eventually thrown out, but only after month of uncertainty and million of dollars. But small companies, and the free and open software movement do not have any patent to trade. Much of the really useful software we use every day, program like the Apache web server, the GNU/Linux operating system and the fearsomely popular Firefox browser, is developed outside company structure by people who do not have legal department to check for patent infringements. The damage to software will not happen overnight, of course. If the directive go through it ha to be written into national law and then there will be a steady stream of legal action against small company and open source products. Eventually someone will decide to attack Linux directly, probably with some secret funding from one or two large players. The new directive will limit innovation by forcing programmer to spend time checking for patent infringement or simply avoiding working in potentially competitive areas. And it will damage Europe's computer industry. We can only hope that the Council of Ministers ha the integrity and strength to reject this bad law. Bill Thompson is a regular commentator on the BBC World Service programme Go Digital.

Title: Rochus shocks Coria in Auckland
Article: Top seed Guillermo Coria went out of the Heineken Open in Auckland on Thursday with a surprise loss to Olivier Rochus of Belgium. Coria lost the semi-final 6-4 6-4 to Rochus, who go on to face Czech Jan Hernych, a 6-4 7-5 winner over Jose Acasuso of Argentina. Fifth seed Fernando Gonzalez eased past American Robby Ginepri 6-3 6-4. The Chilean will meet sixth seed Juan Ignacio Chela next after the Argentine beat Potito Starace 6-1 7-6 (7-5). Rochus made the semi-finals at the Australian hardcourt championship in Adelaide last week and is naturally delighted with his form. "It's been two unbelievable week for me," he said. "Today I knew I had nothing to lose. If I beat him great, if I lost, I would be losing to a top-10 player." Coria conceded that Rochus "played just too good," and added: "When you give your best out there you can't be too sad."

Title: Wales silent on Grand Slam talk
Article: Rhys Williams say Wales are still not thinking of winning the Grand Slam despite a third Six Nations win. "That's the last thing on our mind at the moment," said Williams, a second- half replacement in Saturday's 24-18 win over France in Paris. "We all realise how difficult a task it is to go up to Scotland and beat them. "We've come unstuck there a couple of time recently so our focus is on that game and we'll worry about Ireland hopefully after we've beaten Scotland." With captain Gareth Thomas ruled out of the rest of the campaign with a broken thumb, Williams is vying for his first start in the championship so far. Kevin Morgan is probably favourite to replace Thomas at full-back, leaving Williams and Hal Luscombe to battle for the right wing berth. A hamstring injury denied Luscombe the opportunity to make a third successive start, but the Dragons winger is expected to be fit for the trip to Murrayfield on 13 March. Hooker Robin McBryde is doubtful after picking up a knee injury in Paris, but centre Sonny Parker and flanker Colin Charvis are set to recover from injury to be in contention for selection. Said Wales assistant coach Scott Johnson: "They've worked through the weekend and the report are a bit more positive. "So we're getting a couple back and that add to the depth of the squad." Scotland secured their first win of the campaign on Saturday by grinding out an 18-10 win over Italy. Matt Williams' side ha shown little in attack, but Johnson insisted the Scots will be difficult opposition to break down. "Italy are really brave opposition and sometimes it's very hard to win," he said. "So an ugly win can be just a effective a a 30 or 40 point victory. "Scotland are a hard side and very underrated so we're not taking anything for granted. "We're not basking in the glory of winning our first three games. We've got to be diligent in our preparation. "That's my job and we've got to make sure we're focused."
