Title: Choose hope over fear - Kennedy
Article: Voters will have a clear choice between the politics of fear and the politics of hope in the next general election, said Charles Kennedy. In his New Year message the Liberal Democrat leader said Labour and the Conservatives were united in relying on fear and "populist scares". He said his party wa the one of hope and wa ready for a 2005 poll. On the Asian tsunami he said it had been "very heartening" to learn of the generosity being shown by Britons. Mr Kennedy said his thought were with all those caught up in the disaster, which had dominated the Christmas and New Year period. At home he said many people were turning to the Liberal Democrats a they became disheartened with the politics of the other two main parties. The general election would be a three-party struggle, a the Conservative party "fades away" a a national force and the Liberal Democrats challenge Labour in it heartlands, he said. "A clear division is emerging in British politics - the politics of fear versus the politics of hope. "Labour is counting on the politics of fear, ratcheting up talk of threats, crime and insecurity. While the Conservatives are re-working their populist scare about asylum and the European 'menace'," he said. He said the government wa using this climate of fear to try to strip away civil liberties. It wa already using detention without trial at Belmarsh Prison, ignoring a recent Law Lords judgement that this contravenes basic human rights, he said. He also criticised attempt to bring in trial without jury, plan to lower the burden of proof in some criminal trials, curbing of right to protest, increased stop and search power and ID card plans. He said while everyone had the right to be secure they also had the right to be protected against unfair discrimination. "But at the same time, an overmighty state is a dangerous one," he said. His party "instinctively" understood the "new liberal Britain" which is no longer a nation with one family structure, and one colour, he said. "We are less deferential; more inclined to think for ourselves; more open about sexuality and equality. "Our national institution are changing too. We are no longer a nation of one church; we are a nation of many faiths. In our attitude and the way we live our lives, this is in many way a liberal Britain."

Title: Connick Jr to lead Broadway show
Article: Singer and actor Harry Connick Jr is to star in a Broadway revival of 1950s hit musical The Pajama Game. He will play the supervisor of a US pyjama factory who ha a romance with a union activist during labour unrest. Jeffrey Richards, the show's co-producer, said Connick wa "an actor of enormous charisma and skill, a wonderful singer and a bona fide star". He ha recently starred in hit US comedy Will and Grace a the husband of Grace, played by Debra Messing. The musical will open in November, said Mr Richards, who added that no other casting had been announced yet. The original book by George Abbott and Richard Bissell will be revised by playwright Peter Ackerman, who co-wrote the screenplay for the movie Ice Age. It ha a score by Richard Adler and Jerry Ross, and Adler is writing two new song for the score, which includes number including Hey There, Small Talk and Steam Heat. Connick appeared with his band on Broadway in 1990, and he wrote the score for a musical based on Emile Zola's novel Therese Raquin, called Thou Shalt Not. It had a three-month run on Broadway in 2001.

Title: Standard Life cuts policy bonuses
Article: Standard Life, Europe's largest mutual life insurer, ha cut bonus for with-profit policyholders. Annual bonus rate on it with-profits life policy were cut from 2.5% to 2%, while bonus on pension policy were reduced from 3.25% to 2.5%. It is the sixth time in three year Standard Life ha made cut to bonus rates, despite an 8.7% rise in the value of the with-profits fund in 2004. The insurer blamed the cut on poor share return and low interest rates. With-profits policy are designed to smooth out the peak and trough of stock market volatility. Profits made in good year are kept in reserve to pay investor an annual bonus even when the stock market performs badly. Slumping share price throughout 2001 and 2002 forced most firm to trim bonus rate on their policies. Standard Life came in for criticism for sticking with stock market investment during 2001 and 2002. The insurer argued that share outperformed other investment over the long term and that policyholder would feel the benefit when the stock market recovered. Recently, Norwich Union and Axa Sun Life both cut their with-profit bonus rates. John Gill, managing director of the insurer's life and pension division, said that a strong stock market recovery in the past two year had only "partly compensated for loss during 2001 and 2002". In addition, low interest rate meant that "long-term investment return are well below historic levels", Mr Gill added. However, Mr Gill maintained that with-profits continued to perform well over the long term. "Our payouts continue to stand up well against other type of long-term investment over similar periods," he said. Standard Life ha an estimated 2.4 million with-profits policyholders. Last year, the company announced that it wa looking to float on the stock market in 2006.

Title: February poll claim 'speculation'
Article: Reports that Tony Blair is planning a snap general election for February 2005 have been described a "idle speculation" by Downing Street. A spokesman said he had "no idea" where the report in the Sunday Times and Sunday Telegraph had come from. The paper suggest minister believe the government could benefit from a "Baghdad bounce" following successful Iraq election in January. A British general election wa last held in February in 1974. In that election, Edward Heath lost and failed to build a coalition with the Liberals. Harold Wilson took over and increased his majority later in the year in a second election The latest speculation suggests the prime minister favour a February poll in order to exploit his current opinion poll lead over Conservative leader Michael Howard. But that strategy could prompt criticism he wa seeking to "cut and run" after less then four year of a parliamentary term. The paper report that Alan Milburn, Labour's head of election strategy, ha played a key role in the plan for a February election, which would include a New Year advertising blitz. New Labour's campaign, both newspaper said, would be centred around the slogan "Britain is Working". A Labour Party spokesman said the election date wa ultimately a matter for Mr Blair, but he wa unaware of anything to suggest it would be in February. Most commentator have been expecting an election on 5 May. The last election wa in June 2001.

Title: Band Aid 20 single storms to No 1
Article: The new version of the Band Aid song Do They Know It's Christmas? ha gone straight in at number one in the UK single chart. The charity record is also tipped to be this year's Christmas number one. It feature vocal from the like of Chris Martin, Dido, Robbie Williams and the Sugababes. The original version - which wa the Christmas number one in 1984 - sold 750,000 copy in it first week and 3.5 million in total. It wa released in the US, and reached number 13 in the single chart. However, Band Aid 20 is not going to be released in the US, despite being sold in many country around the world. US record shop are stocking an import version of Do They Know It's Christmas, which is said to be selling very well in Los Angeles and New York. British star who appear on the current recording, such a Dido and Coldplay's Chris Martin, are well known to music fan across the Atlantic, along with U2 frontman Bono. Record company Universal is responsible for the global distribution of the single, which will be available across Europe, Asia, South America and Canada. But music fan in the US are still able to access the song and download it on Band Aid 20's official website. In 1985, a group of high-profile American star known a USA For Africa came together to record their own fund-raising single, We Are The World. The song wa written by Lionel Richie and Michael Jackson, with Quincy Jones a producer. It topped the US chart for three week and went on win Grammy award for best record and song. Dionne Warwick, Diana Ross and Tina Turner were among the line-up of performers. Proceeds from the sale of the Band Aid 20 single will go towards aid relief in Africa, in country such a Ethiopia and Sudan. The money raised will also be used to help combat HIV and Aids across the continent. The Band Aid Trust which wa set up 20 year ago, when the original single wa released, handed out $144m (Â£75m) to famine relief project across Africa between January 1985 and November 2004.

Article: Wipro, India's third-biggest software firm, ha reported a 60% rise in profit, topping market expectations. Net income in the last quarter wa 4.3bn rupee ($98m; Â£52m), against 2.7bn a year earlier. Profit had been forecast to be 4.1bn rupees. Wipro offer service such a call centre to foreign client and ha worked for more than half of the company on the Fortune 500 list. Wipro said demand wa strong, allowing it to increase the price it charged. "On the face of it, the result don't look very exciting," said Apurva Shah, an analyst at ASK-Raymond James. "But the guidance is positive and pricing going up is good news." Third-quarter sale rose 34% to 20.9bn rupees. One problem identified by Wipro wa the high turnover of it staff. It said that 90% of employee at it business process outsourcing operation had had to be replaced. "We have to get that under control," said vice-chairman Vivek Paul. Wipro is majority owned by India's richest man Azim Premji.

Title: Cole refuses to blame van Persie
Article: Ashley Cole ha refused to blame Robin van Persie for leaving Arsenal with no fully-fit striker for the FA Cup fifth round replay at Sheffield United. Van Persie is suspended alongside Dennis Bergkamp and Jose Antonio Reyes after being sent off at Southampton when Arsenal had a numerical advantage. Thierry Henry is ruled out with an Achilles tendon injury but Cole said: "No-one is putting the blame on Robin. "It's just something that happens on the spur of the moment." Cole added: "I've done it before and I hope they didn't blame me for anything. "Of course he'll learn. I've been sent off a couple of time now and it's just one of those thing when you go a bit crazy for one or two seconds. Freddie Ljungberg is likely to be used in an emergency striking role and will be partnered by either Arturo Lupoli, Quincy Owusu-Abeyie or Jeremie Aliadiere. Gunners bos Arsene Wenger said: "Freddie is an option but we need a second striker. "I have to decide whether it will be Aliadiere, Quincy or Lupoli who will start with him up front. Those three will be involved." Arsenal are also without winger Robert Pires, who sustained an ankle injury at St Mary's. Wenger added: "It doesn't look like anything is fractured, but it is a good ankle sprain. "It doe not look like Pires will be ready for two to three weeks."

Title: Slimmer PlayStation triple sales
Article: Sony PlayStation 2's slimmer shape ha proved popular with UK gamers, with 50,000 sold in it first week on sale. Sales have tripled since launch, outstripping Microsoft's Xbox, said market analyst Chart-Track. The number were also boosted by the release of the PS2-only game Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas. The title broke the UK sale record for video game in it first weekend of release. Latest figure suggest it ha sold more than 677,000 copies. "It is obviously very, very encouraging for Sony because Microsoft briefly outsold them last week," John Houlihan, editor of Computerandvideogames.com told BBC News. "And with Halo 2 [for Xbox] out next week, it really is a head-to-head contest between them and Xbox." Although Xbox sale over the last week also climbed, PS2 sale were more than double that. The figure mean Sony is reaching the seven million barrier for UK sale of the console. Edinburgh-based developer, Rockstar, which is behind the GTA titles, ha seen San Andreas pull in an estimated Â£24m in gross revenue over the weekend. In comparison, blockbuster film like Harry Potter and The Prisoner Of Azkaban took Â£11.5m in it first three day at the UK box office. The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King took nearly Â£10m over it opening weekend, although game title are four to five time more expensive than cinema tickets. Gangster-themed GTA San Andreas is the sequel to Grand Theft Auto Vice City which previously held the record for the fastest-selling video game ever. The Xbox game Halo 2, released on 11 November in the UK, is also widely tipped to be one of the best-selling game of the year. The original title won universal acclaim in 2001, and sold more than four million copies. Mr Houlihan added that Sony had done well with the PS2, but it definitely helped that the release of San Andreas coincided with the slimline PS2 hitting the shelves. The run-up to Christmas is a huge battlefield for game console and titles. Microsoft's Xbox had been winning the race up until last week in sales. The sale figure also suggest that it may be a largely adult audience driving demand, since GTA San Andreas ha an 18 certificate. Sony and Microsoft have both reduced console price recently and are preparing the way for the launch of their next generation console in 2005. "Both have hit crucial price point at around Â£100 and that really doe open up new console to new audience, plus the release of two really important game in term of development are also driving those sales," said Mr Houlihan.

Title: Bellamy fined after row
Article: Newcastle have fined their Welsh striker Craig Bellamy two weeks' wage - about Â£80,000 - following his row with manager Graeme Souness. But Bellamy, 25, ha not been put on the transfer list, although he did not train with the first team on Tuesday. Magpies chairman Freddy Shepherd told the Newcastle Evening Chronicle: "It is not about money. It is about a player thinking he is bigger than this club. "No individual is, be it the chairman, the manager or a player." Souness dropped Bellamy for Sunday's game against Arsenal, claiming the Welshman had feigned injury after being asked to play out of position. "When I heard what the manager wa saying I wa in shock," Bellamy said. "I thought 'not only ha he gone behind my back, he's lying'," he said in response to Souness' remarks. And the Wales international refused to apologise. "I won't apologise because I have done nothing wrong," he told the Evening Chronicle. "There's no doubt about it, I am out of here." The difficult relationship between Souness and Bellamy boiled over at the weekend, and ha led to a war of word in the media. Bellamy's claim that Souness had lied about the background to the bust-up wa strongly denied by Shepherd, who accused the striker of "cheating" the club. "I wish to put the record straight regarding the Bellamy situation," said Shepherd. "Craig walked off the training ground saying his hamstring wa tight (on Friday), but what he failed to reveal wa that he had told other member of the squad before training that he intended to feign injury. "When Graeme discovered this he immediately ordered Bellamy to attend a meeting in my office. "At that meeting Bellamy admitted to Graeme and I that he had told the player that he wa going to "fake" an injury in training and walk off. "He also agreed at that meeting to apologise to his team-mates for his behaviour. He didn't do this which resulted in the action taken by the manager at the weekend, which I fully support. "In my book this is cheating on the club, the supporters, the manager and his own team-mates. "He is paid extremely well and I consider his behaviour to be totally unacceptable and totally unprofessional." Bellamy's latest outburst would appear to make his chance of a first-team recall remote. But even before Newcastle said the player would not be sold, Bellamy insisted he had no intention of handing in a transfer request. "I don't want the fan to think for one minute that I wouldn't play for this club," he said. "I'd play anywhere for this club, even in goal. "It's a very difficult situation for me at the moment but I'd never ask to leave this club. "This club mean so much to me. I couldn't do it because I know I couldn't come back here and play against Newcastle. It would hurt too much."

Title: Finding new homes for old phones
Article: Re-using old mobile phone is not just good for the environment, it ha social benefit too. Research ha found that in some developing nation old mobile phone can help close the digital divide. The Forum for the Future research found that the low cost of these recycled handset mean they can have a very useful second life in poorer nations. But the Forum found that more needed to be done to collect old phone rather than let them rot in landfill sites. The report reveals that approximately 15 million mobile phone go out of use every year in the UK. Of the 15 million that are swapped for newer model each year, only 25% get returned to mobile phone firm for recycling or re-use. The slowly growing mass of unrecycled, discarded phone ha now reached 90 million handsets, the equivalent of 9,000 tonne of waste, estimate James Goodman, report author and a senior adviser at the Forum for the Future. "It's quite common for people to have two or three phone just lying around," said Mr Goodman. Many of these older phone could end up in landfill site leaking the potentially toxic material they are made of into the wider world, said Mr Goodman. Far better, he said, to hand the phone back to an operator who can send it overseas where it can enjoy a second lease of life. "We've heard the environmental argument for handing a phone back," said Mr Goodman, "but there's a strong social argument too." Older mobile phone are proving particularly useful in poorer nation where people want to use a mobile and keep in touch with friend and family but do not have the income to buy the most up to date model. The Forum for the Future report took an in-depth look at Romania where reconditioned mobile phone were proving very popular. "It's an interesting country because it ha a really crap fixed line network," said Mr Goodman, "and there's a real desire for people to get mobile phones." But the relatively low wage in Romania, which is one of the poorest country in Europe, mean few people can afford a shiny new phone. "The affordability of the handset is a real barrier to getting one," he said. Reconditioned handset have boosted take-up of mobile a the report revealed that almost one-third of Romanian pre-pay mobile phone user were using reconditioned handsets. The re-used handset tend to be about one-third of the price of a new handset. Georgeta Minciu, a Romanian part-time cleaner, said: "Normally a mobile phone would not be possible on my wages. I am a single parent - keeping in touch with my daughter is important to me." "This is the only way I can afford to have a phone," she said. Mr Goodman said phone operator and consumer needed to do more to ensure that more of Britain's mobile mountain made it overseas. But, he added, those keen to use a mobile will not accept any old handset. "If it more than a few year old people are not going to want it," he said.

Title: Sundance to honour foreign films
Article: International film will be given the same prominence a US film at next year's Sundance Film Festival, with movie dominated by the theme of war. The independent film festival will feature two new international cinema competitions, during it 20-30 January season in Utah. Forty-two film will debut at Sundance, including The Liberace of Baghdad by British director Sean McAllister. The prestigious festival wa founded by actor Robert Redford in 1981. "We have always had an international component, but from next year they will enter a jury competition," festival director Geoffrey Gilmore said. "We wanted to give world cinema more emphasis and have now put it on par with the American dramatic and documentary competitions." Twelve film competing in the new world cinema documentary category focus on country and people under siege. The Liberace of Baghdad feature an Iraqi pianist hiding in a hotel a he wait for a visa, while Finnish film The Three Rooms of Melancholia look at the war in Chechnya. Shake Hands With The Devil: The Journey of Romeo Dallaire tell of a UN mission to Rwanda during the 1994 genocide, while French-Israeli production Wall look at Israel's controversial security wall separating it from the Palestinian territories. The 16 film competing in the new world cinema dramatic category include work from Germany, South Korea, Angola, China, Denmark and Australia. Several Hollywood star feature in the festival's American independent drama category, including Keanu Reeves and Benjamin Bratt. Vince Vaughn star in quirky movie Thumbsucker while 21 Grams actress Naomi Watts play a budding Hollywood actress in Ellie Parker. The top Grand Jury prize at this year's festival went to low budget sci-fi thriller Primer, written and directed by Shane Carruth. Morgan Spurlock earned the directing award for Super Size Me, which became an international box office hit.

Title: US trade gap hits record in 2004
Article: The gap between US export and import hit an all-time high of $671.7bn (Â£484bn) in 2004, latest figure show. The Commerce Department said the trade deficit for all of last year wa 24.4% above the previous record - 2003's imbalance of $496.5bn. The deficit with China, up 30.5% at $162bn, wa the largest ever recorded with a single country. However, on a monthly basis the US trade gap narrowed by 4.9% in December to Â£56.4bn. Meanwhile, the Bush administration argues that the US deficit reflects the fact the America is growing at faster rate than the rest of the world, spurring on more demand for imported goods. Title: Savvy searchers fail to spot ads
Article: Internet search engine user are an odd mix of naive and sophisticated, suggests a report into search habits. The report by the US Pew Research Center reveals that 87% of searcher usually find what they were looking for when using a search engine. It also show that few can spot the difference between paid-for result and organic ones. The report reveals that 84% of net user say they regularly use Google, Ask Jeeves, MSN and Yahoo when online. Almost 50% of those questioned said they would trust search engine much less, if they knew information about who paid for result wa being hidden. According to figure gathered by the Pew researcher the average user spends about 43 minute per month carrying out 34 separate search and look at 1.9 webpage for each hunt. A significant chunk of net users, 36%, carry out a search at least weekly and 29% of those asked only look every few weeks. For 44% of those questioned, the information they are looking for is critical to what they are doing and is information they simply have to find. Search engine user also tend to be very loyal and once they have found a site they feel they can trust tend to stick with it. According to Pew Research 44% of searcher use just a single search engine, 48% use two or three and a small number, 7%, consult more than three sites. Tony Macklin, spokesman for Ask Jeeves, said the result reflected it own research which showed that people use different search engine because the way the site gather information mean they can provide different result for the same query. Despite this liking for search site half of those questioned said they could get the same information via other routes. A small number, 17%, said they wouldn't really miss search engine if they did not exist. The remaining 33% said they could not live without search sites. More than two-thirds of those questioned, 68%, said they thought that the result they were presented with were a fair and unbiased selection of the information on a topic that can be found on the net. Alongside the growing sophistication of net user is a lack of awareness about paid-for result that many search engine provide alongside list of website found by indexing the web. Of those asked, 62% were unaware that someone ha paid for some of the result they see when they carry out a search. Only 18% of all searcher say they can tell which result are paid for and which are not. Said the Pew report: "This finding is ironic, since nearly half of all user say they would stop using search engine if they thought engine were not being clear about how they presented paid results." Commenting Mr Macklin said sponsored result must be clearly marked and though they might help with some query user testing showed that people need to be able to spot the difference.

Title: Karachi stocks hit historic high
Article: The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) ha recorded it largest single day gain, surging 3.5% to a new high. The index rose 225.79 point in four hour of furious trading, with many investor optimistic that political stability could bring an economic boom. The KSE index closed at 6709.93 - an overall gain of nearly 400 point in the first two trading day of the week. Energy and telecommunication stock performed particularly well, recording an 8%-10% rise since Monday morning. In 2002, the KSE wa the world's best performing stock market, with the index rising 112%. Pakistani investor are expecting the KSE to repeat, if not improve on, it 2002 performance. Jubilant investor danced on the street a the market closed for the day on Tuesday, confident that the boom will continue at least until the public holiday on 22 January. Others, however, who had stayed out fearing an imminent collapse because of price overheating, continued to warn that the "bubble may burst any time". "That's rubbish," KSE chairman Yaseen Lakhani told the BBC News website. "Whenever the market reflects Pakistan's true economic reality, it is described a a bubble." Mr Lakhani feel that the market ha risen on the basis of solid economic growth and it current level rest on sound foundations. Market analyst are inclined to agree with Mr Lakhani, arguing that there are a number of major factor behind the KSE's performance. Analysts argue that a steady improvement in Pakistan's credit rating by international credit rating agency ha finally begun to register in the market. Standard & Poor's upgraded Pakistan a few week ago. There are indication of yet another upgrade by the end of February. Then, say analysts, there is corporate profitability in the current fiscal year, which ha gone up by 27% from last year. "Coupled with the 7% GDP growth expected by June this year, I am least surprised at the market's performance," say Mr Lakhani. One leading Karachi broker said the real reason may be political. "If you file a $1.3 trillion case against Saudi money after 9/11, Arab money will not go to the US any more." A lot of Arab money, he says, ha already gone to Malaysia and Indonesia. Pakistanis are now hoping that energy and telecoms, two of the strongest sector in Pakistan, draw some of the Arab money to the KSE. Locally, too, say analysts, recent political development have worked to the market's advantage. An anti-Musharraf campaign threatened by the MMA, a countrywide alliance of religious parties, ha fizzled out. The release of Asif Zardari, former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's husband, ha eased political tension between the military-backed government and the opposition Pakistan People's Party. Most importantly, say analysts, the failure of talk between India and Pakistan on the Baglihar dam in Indian-administered Kashmir ha not automatically led to heightened tensions. This, they say, indicates that neither country is interested in raising the temperature at this stage, irrespective of the state of their disagreements. The market is abuzz with speculation that substantial investment may now start to flow in from the US, a country seen locally a deeply interested in defusing tension between the South Asian neighbours. "You can call it a peace dividend," smile one broker. "Let u see how long one can reap it benefits."

Title: Vera Drake's Bafta triumph hope
Article: At the Bafta film award on Saturday night, there is the prospect that a home-grown movie could walk off with a clutch of trophies. Vera Drake, Mike Leigh's tale about a 1950s backstreet abortionist, is nominated in 11 categories. These include best film, best director and best actress shortlist for Imelda Staunton who play the eponymous character. The film ha spent month being lauded with prizes, from the Venice Film Festival to five award from the London Critics' Circle on Wednesday night. The Baftas ha a tradition of honouring British cinema, and this year Vera Drake is the obvious candidate to be heaped with praise. Empire magazine's review editor Dan Jolin said the film had "a very good chance" of doing well on Saturday, predicting that it would collect five or six awards. "I don't think it's going to do a Lord of the Rings-style sweep, but Imelda Staunton is a shoo-in for best actress," he said. "A best director prize for Mike Leigh and best British film are also likely and it could steal some award from heavily-nominated competitor The Aviator and Finding Neverland." Mr Jolin tipped another contender - most likely The Aviator - to walk away with the Bafta for best film, and added that Finding Neverland had been lavished with nomination but not trophies. Strong Oscar contender Million Dollar Baby and Sideways did not figure in the Bafta nominations, giving Vera Drake greater potential to walk away with the big prizes. "There is a sense that this film is ours and we should slap our own guy on the back. Out of all the film in the running for the Baftas, Vera Drake is the true blue British one." "If Mike Leigh is going to win award for anything, it should be Vera Drake at this year's Baftas", said Mr Jolin, adding that the film wa probably his most technically accomplished and lavish work yet. Mr Jolin also tipped Phil Davis for a best supporting actor prize for his role in Vera Drake but felt that Heather Craney could be outdone by Kate Winslet or Natalie Portman in the supporting actress category. "If there is anywhere where this film is going to win, it will be at the Baftas," he said. The Guardian's film critic Peter Bradshaw felt that there "might well be" a sweep of award for Vera Drake on Saturday night. "I hope that Bafta voter will respond to the extremely high standard of acting from the whole cast of the film. If Bafta can't do so, what hope is there?" he said. Mr Bradshaw felt that Mike Leigh's "masterpiece" wa entitled to the best film award - leaving Dead Man's Shoes, Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, My Summer of Love and Shaun of the Dead to slug it out for the best British film trophy. "I will be cheering if Vera Drake win a whole host of awards," he added.

Title: Kennedy calls for Iraq exit plans
Article: Tony Blair should set out a proper exit strategy from Iraq in the wake of next Sunday's election in the country, Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy ha said. In a speech focusing on issue arising from the re-election of George W Bush, Mr Kennedy said Iraq had become a "crucible of militant terrorism". He want to see a phased withdrawal of UK troop "as soon a the situation allows", he said in London. Any exit strategy must "augment and support" the democratic process. "There are some who are of the opinion that the mere presence of British and American troop in Iraq feed the insurgency," he said. "There is some truth in that, especially after the initial mistake that were made - the heavy-handedness of operation like Fallujah, and the well-publicised instance of abuse at the hand of coalition forces." Mr Kennedy pointed out that the Netherlands, Portugal and the Czech Republic, which all have troop operating in the southern sector of Iraq, have announced their imminent withdrawal "regardless of the situation on the ground". He accused Mr Blair's government of "being less than straightforward" over it plans. "Next week the prime minister should make a statement regarding the election in Iraq," Mr Kennedy said during his City of London speech. "He should set out a proper exit strategy, including the phased withdrawal of British troops, a the security situation allows." Mr Kennedy also argued that British troop deployed in Iraq should be replaced with force from other country - "especially Islamic countries".

Title: Blair Labour's longest-serving PM
Article: Tony Blair ha become the Labour Party's longest-serving prime minister. The 51-year-old premier ha marked his 2,838th day in the post, overtaking the combined length of Harold Wilson's two term during the 1960s and 1970s. If Mr Blair win the next election and fulfils his promise to serve a full third term, he will surpass Margaret Thatcher's 11 year by the end of 2008. In 1997, Mr Blair became the youngest premier of the 20th century, when he came to power at the age of 43. The last prime minister to be installed at a younger age wa Lord Liverpool, who wa a year his junior in 1812. Mr Blair's other political first include becoming the first Labour leader to win two successive full term in power after the 2001 Labour landslide. And the birth of the Blairs' fourth child, Leo, on 20 May, 2000, wa the first child born to a serving prime minister in more than 150 years. The last "Downing Street dad" wa Lord John Russell in 1848. Labour won a huge majority of 167 over the Conservatives in 2001, but Mr Blair ha since been criticised by many in his own party. The war in Iraq and reform of the health service and education system have provoked dissent from backbenchers. Gordon Brown, chancellor of the exchequer under Mr Blair, became Britain's longest-serving chancellor of modern time in 2004. Former Labour leader Lord Kinnock said the chancellor would be best placed to take over from Mr Blair. When asked about the future leadership of the party, he told ITV Wales' Waterfront programme: "That contest is a long way away and it will occur only when the Prime Minister, Tony Blair, decides he's subscribed all he can and then want to go. "I think that the main contender will be Gordon Brown, who is a man of virtually unmatched capability and now great experience." Both Mr Brown and Mr Blair rose to prominence when Lord Kinnock led Labour between 1983 and 1992.

Title: Georgia plans hidden asset pardon
Article: Georgia is offering a one-off 'tax amnesty' to people who hid their earnings under the regime of former president Eduard Shevardnadze. The country's new president, Mikhail Saakashvili, ha said that anyone now willing to disclose their wealth will only have to pay 1% in income tax. The measure is designed to legitimise previously hidden economic activity and boost Georgia's flagging economy. Georgia's black market is estimated to be twice the size of it legal economy. Mr Saakashvili, elected president in January after Mr Shevardnadze wa toppled, ha urged the Georgian Parliament to approve the amnesty a soon a possible. It is one of a series of proposal designed to tackle corruption, which wa rampant during the Shevardnadze era, and boost Georgia's fragile public finances. The new government is encouraging company to pay tax by scrapping existing corruption investigation and destroying all tax record from before 1 January, three day before President Saakashvili wa elected. "There are people who have money but are afraid to show it," the president told a government session. "Documentation about where this money came from doesn't exist because under the former, entirely warped regime, earning capital honestly wa not possible." By declaring their asset and paying the one-off tax, people would be able to "legalise their property", Mr Saakashvili stressed. "No one will have the right to check this money's origin. This money must go back into the economy." The amnesty will not extend to people who made money through drug trafficking or international money laundering. Criminal investigation in such case -thought to involve about 5% of Georgian business -are to continue. Mr Saakashvili ha accused the Shevardnadze regime, which wa toppled by a popular uprising in November, of allowing bribery to flourish. Georgia's economy is in a desperate condition. Half the population are living below the poverty line with many surviving on income of less than $4, or three euros, a day. The unemployment rate is around 20% while the country ha a $1.7bn public debt.

Title: Bad weather hits Nestle sales
Article: A combination of bad weather, rising raw material cost and the sluggish European economy ha hit sale at Swiss food and drink giant Nestle. Revenue dipped 1.4% to 86.7bn Swiss franc ($74.6bn; Â£39.1bn) in 2004 a sale of ice cream and mineral water were dampened by the wet summer. However, Nestle's profit margin were helped by a strong performance in the Americas and China. Nestle is to raise it dividend by 11% after paying back some of it debt. Nestle said that the strength of the Swiss franc against the US dollar, the disposal of business and challenging trading condition in Europe all dented sales. A poor summer across the continent - in contrast to the prolonged heat wave in 2003 - "severely affected" demand for ice cream. Sales of bottled water also fell, although chocolate, coffee, frozen good and petcare product performed better. Elsewhere, Nestle said it had enjoyed an "exceptional" year in North America, outperforming the market in term of sale growth. Nestle added that it had performed strongly in Africa and Asia despite the impact of high oil price and political instability. Nestle's total earnings before interest remained broadly flat over the past year, despite the company managing to boost profit margins. As well a increasing it dividend, Nestle plan to buy back share worth 1bn Swiss franc ($861m; Â£451m). Looking forward, Nestle forecast organic earnings growth of about 5% in 2005, although it warned that trading would remain just a competitive. Uncertainty remains over the future of Perrier, the iconic French mineral water owned by Nestle. Perrier ha been locked in a long-standing dispute with union about productivity level at the business, which ha lead Nestle to consider selling the firm. "The option of selling is Perrier is still on the table," chief executive Peter Brabeck-Letmathe confirmed on Thursday.

Title: Yangtze Electric's profits double
Article: Yangtze Electric Power, the operator of China's Three Gorges Dam, ha said it profit more than doubled in 2004. The firm ha benefited from increased demand for electricity at a time when power shortage have hit city and province across the country. As a hydroelectric-power generator it ha not been hurt by higher coal costs. Net income jumped to 3bn yuan in 2004 ($365m; Â£190m), compared with 1.4bn yuan in 2003. Sales surged to 6.2bn yuan, from 3bn yuan a year earlier. The figure topped analyst expectations, even though the rate of growth ha slowed from 2003. Analysts forecast that it is likely to decline further this year to a rate of expansion of closer to 20%. Yangtze Electric ha been expanding it output to meet demand driven by China's booming economy. The government ha delayed the building of a number of power plant in an effort to rein in growth amid concern that the economy may overheat. That ha led to an energy crunch, with demand outstripping supply. Earlier this month, work wa halted on an underground power station, and a supply unit on the Three Gorges Dam, a well a a power station on it sister Xiluodu dam because of environmental worries. A total of 30 large-scale project have been halted across the country for similar reasons. The Three Gorges Dam project ha led to more than half a million people being relocated and drawn criticism from environmental group and overseas human right activists. Its sister project, the Xiluodu Dam, is being built on the Jinshajiang - or "river of golden sand" a the upper reach of the Yangtze are known.

Title: Souped-up wi-fi is on the horizon
Article: Super high-speed wireless data network could soon be in use in the UK. The government's wireless watchdog is seeking help on the best way to regulate the technology behind such network called Ultra Wideband (UWB). Ofcom want to ensure that the arrival of UWB-using device doe not cause problem for those that already use the same part of the radio spectrum. UWB make it possible to stream huge amount of data through the air over short distances. One of the more likely us of UWB is to make it possible to send DVD quality video image wirelessly to TV screen or to let people beam music to medium player around their home. The technology ha the potential to transmit hundred of megabit of data per second. UWB could also be used to create so-called Personal Area Networks that let a person's gadget quickly and easily swap data amongst themselves. The technology work over a range up to 10 metre and us billion of short radio pulse every second to carry data. At the recent Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas product with UWB chip built-in got their first public airing. Currently, use of UWB is only allowed in the UK under a strict licencing scheme. "We're seeking opinion from industry to find out whether or not we should allow UWB on a licence-exempt basis," said a spokesman for Ofcom. Companies have until 24 March to respond. In April the EC is due to start it own consultation on Europe-wide adoption of UWB. The cross-Europe body for radio regulators, known a the European Conference of Postal and Telecommunications Administrations (CEPT), is carrying out research for this harmonisation programme. Early sight of the CEPT work ha caused controversy a some think it over-emphasises UWB's potential to interfere with existing users. By contrast a preliminary Ofcom report found that it would be quite straight-forward to deploy UWB without causing problem for those that already use it. The Ofcom spokesman said it wa considering imposing a "mask" or set of technical restriction on UWB-using devices. "We would want these device to have very strict control on power level so they can not transmit a long way or over a wide area," he said. Despite the current restriction the technology is already being used. Cambridge-based Ubisense ha about 40 customer around the world using the short-range radio technology, said David Theriault, standard and regulatory liaison for Ubisense. He said that UWB wa driving novel way to interact with computers. "It's like having a 3D mouse all the time," he said. He said that European decision on what to do with UWB allied with IEEE decision on the exact specification for it would help drive adoption. Prior to it adoption a a way for gadget and computer to communicate, UWB wa used a a sensing technology. It is used to spot such thing a crack under the surface of runway or to help fireman detect people through walls.

Title: Baghdad Blogger on big screen
Article: A film based on the internet musing of the "Baghdad Blogger" ha been shown at the Rotterdam Film Festival. The film ha been directed by the man who call himself Salam Pax, the author of the weblog about Iraqi life during and after the war. The movie version come in the form of a series of short made by Pax on a hand-held camera. Baghdad Blogger is among a number of film about Iraq showcased at the Dutch festival, which run until Sunday. Following the fascination with the writing of Salam Pax - not his real name - he began a regular column in The Guardian newspaper and wa given a crash course in documentary film-making. For the film he travelled Iraq to document the changing landscape of the country and the problem it ha faced since the invasion, speaking to ordinary Iraqis about their experiences. The festival will also see the screening of Underexposure, one of Iraq's first feature to emerge since the toppling of Saddam Hussein. Director Oday Rasheed made the film on discarded 1980s Kodak film taken from the remains for the former Ministry of Culture building. It centre on the life of family and stranger going about their everyday business a Baghdad is under siege. Rasheed said the title wa refers to the isolation felt by Iraqis under Saddam's regime and the difficult time the country is now experiencing. "Saddam's regime wa hell, but now I think the hell ha doubled," Rasheed said. The festival wa also due to screen murdered Dutch film-maker Theo Van Gogh's film about the treatment of woman under Islam, but it wa withdrawn due to safety fears. Van Gogh wa shot and stabbed in November 2004, following death threat he received about his film Submission.

Title: UK heading wrong way - Howard
Article: Tony Blair ha had the chance to tackle the problem facing Britain and ha failed, Michael Howard ha said. "Britain is heading in the wrong direction", the Conservative leader said in his New Year message. Mr Blair's government wa a "bossy, interfering government that take decision that should be made by individuals," he added. But Labour's campaign spokesman Fraser Kemp responded: "Britain is working, don't let the Tories wreck it again". Mr Howard also paid tribute to the nation's character for it generous response to the Asian quake disaster. The catastrophe wa overshadowing the hope for the future at this usually positive time of the year, Mr Howard said. "We watched the scene of destruction with a sense of disbelief. The scale, the speed, the ferocity of what happened on Boxing Day is difficult to grasp. "Yet Britain's response ha shone a light on our nation's character. The last week ha shown that the warm, caring heart of Britain beat a strong a ever." He went on to reflect on the value that "most Britons hold dear". Looking ahead to the coming general election, he pledged to "turn these belief into reality" and set out the choice he say are facing Britain. "How much tax do people want to pay? Who will give taxpayer value for money, the clean hospital and good, disciplined school they want? "Who can be trusted to get a grip on the disorder on our street and the chaos in our immigration system?" Mr Blair ha failed to tackle these problems, he claimed, saying he ha the "wrong solution" to them. "The result is big government and higher tax eroding incentives, undermining enterprise and denying people choice. "Worst of all, it is a government that ha wasted people's money and failed to tackle the problem family face today." The Tories, he said, can cut crime and improve public service without asking people to pay more taxes. "We can have progress without losing what make Britain great - it tolerance, the respect for the rule of law, the ability of everyone to fulfil their potential. "We simply need to change direction. The election will give Britain the chance to change." This is the record Mr Blair will have to defend in the coming months, he said, urging voter to hold him to account. But Labour spokesman Mr Kemp said: "It would be more appropriate for this message to come out on 1 April, not 1 January." "Let u never forget that when Michael Howard wa in government Britain suffered mass unemployment, 15% interest rates, record home repossessions, and the introduction of the poll tax. "With Labour Britain is working. Rather than alluding to false promise Michael Howard should be starting 2005 with an apology to the British people for the misery that the government, of which he wa a member, inflicted upon the country.

Title: AstraZeneca hit by drug failure
Article: Shares in Anglo-Swedish drug have closed down 8% in UK trade after the failure of it Iressa drug in a major clinical trial. The lung cancer drug did not significantly prolong survival in patient with the disease. This setback for the group follows the rejection by the US in October of it anti-coagulant pill Exanta. Meanwhile, another of it major money spinner - cholesterol drug Crestor - is facing mounting safety concerns. "This would be two of the three blockbuster drug that were meant to power the company forward failing... and we've got risk on Crestor," said Nick Turner, analyst at broker Jefferies. AstraZeneca had hoped to pitch it Iressa drug against rival medicine Tarceva. But Iressa proved no better than a placebo in extending life in the trial involving 1,692 patients. Tarceva - made by OSI Pharmaceuticals, Genentech and Roche - ha already proved to be successful in helping prolong the life of lung cancer patients. AztraZeneca ha now appointed a new executive director to the board. John Patterson will be in charge of drug development. The company said Mr Patterson would make "substantial change to the clinical organisation and it processes". "I am determined to improve our development and regulatory performance, restore confidence in the company and value to shareholders," said chief executive Tom McKillop.

Article: Susan Chepkemei ha decided she is fit enough to run in next month's Great Edinburgh International Cross Country. The Kenyan wa initially unsure if she would have recovered from her gruelling tussle with Paula Radcliffe in the New York Marathon in time to compete. But she ha declared herself up to the task and join a field headed by World cross country champion Benita Johnson. Race director Matthew Turnbull said: "Susan will add even more strength in depth to the world-class line up." Chepkemei, who won the six kilometre event three year ago when it wa staged in Newcastle, endured an epic battle with Radcliffe in the Big Apple until the Briton outsprinted her in the final 400m. Tirunesh Dibaba of Ethiopia will defend the title she won last year in Tyneside - before the race wa moved north of the border. Recently-crowned European cross country champion Briton Hayley Yelling also competes in Edinburgh on 15 January, a doe in-form Scot Kathy Butler.

Title: Williams stays on despite dispute
Article: Matt Williams insists he ha no thought of quitting a national coach a a result of the power struggle currently gripping Scottish rugby. The chairman, chief executive and three non-executive director all departed in a row over the game's future direction. But Williams said: "I want to make it clear that I'm committed totally to Scottish rugby. "I've brought my family here and we've immersed ourselves in Scottish life. There's no way that I'm walking away." However, he attempted to steer clear of taking side in the dispute. "I'd like to stress that the national team is separate to the political situation," he said. "When you come to an undertaking like this and you are trying to make a difference then there are always people who will begrudge you, who are jealous and want to try to drag you down. "When you have that situation, you have to have the courage of your conviction to see it through. "There wa some very unhelpful and uninformed comment that the national team had received a massive increase in budget at the expense of other part of Scottish rugby and that is simply not the case. "Like all good coaches, you go and ask for an increase. But we were told in no uncertain term that the financial situation did not allow that. "The idea that we are lighting cigar with Â£20 note while the rest of Scottish rugby flounder is absolutely untrue. "We also attracted criticism because of the number of day player spent with the national team. "But let me give you the truth. Our Irish counterparts, whom we have to compete with in a few days' time, had 70 day together at the summer. "They are currently in camp now and they will have another 21 day in camp before the Six Nations. "That mean they will have 91 day away from their club from July until the Six Nations. We, on the other hand, will have 16. "There must be a win-win philosophy and attitude within Scottish rugby and that is what we are after - both group winning, not competing."

Title: Mobiles 'not media players yet'
Article: Mobiles are not yet ready to be all-singing, all-dancing multimedia device which will replace portable medium players, say two reports. Despite move to bring music download service to mobiles, people do not want to trade multimedia service with size and battery life, said Jupiter. A separate study by Gartner ha also said real-time TV broadcast to mobile is "unlikely" in Europe until 2007. Technical issue and standard must be resolved first, said the report. Batteries already have to cope with other service that operator offer, like video playback, video messaging, megapixel camera and game amongst others. Bringing music download service based on the success of computer-based download service will put more demand on battery life. Fifty percent of Europeans said the size of a mobile wa the most important factor when it came to choosing their phone, but more power demand tend to mean larger handsets. "Mobile phone music service must not be positioned to compete with the PC music experience a the handset are not yet ready," said Thomas Husson, mobile analyst at Jupiter research. "Mobile music service should be new and different, and enable operator to differentiate their brand and support third generation network launches." Other problem facing mobile music include limited storage on phones, compared to portable player which can hold up to 40GB of music. The mobile industry is keen to get into music downloading, after the success of Apple's iTunes, Napster and other net music download services. With phone getting smarter and more powerful, there are also demand to be able to watch TV on the move. In the US, service like TiVo To Go let people transfer pre-recorded TV content onto their phones. But, the Gartner report on mobile TV broadcasting in Europe suggests direct broadcasting will have to wait. Currently, TV-like services, where clip are downloaded, are offered by several European operators, like Italy's TIM and 3. Mobile TV will have to overcome several barrier before it is widely taken up though, said the report. Various standard and way of getting TV signal to mobile are being worked on globally. In Europe, trial in Berlin and Helsinki are making use of terrestrial TV mast to broadcast compressed signal to handset with extra receivers. A service from the Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation let people watch TV programme on their mobile 24 hour a day. The service us 3GP technology, one of the standard for mobile TV. But at the end of 2004, the European Telecommunications Institute (Etsi) formally adopted Digital Video Broadcasting Handheld (DVB-H) a the mobile TV broadcasting standard for Europe. Operators will be working on the standard a a way to bring real-time broadcast to mobiles, a well a trying to overcome several other barriers. The cost and infrastructure need to set up the service will need to be addressed. Handsets also need to be able to work with the DVB-H standard. TV service will have to live up to the expectation of the digital TV generation too, which expects good quality image at low prices, according to analysts. People are also likely to be put off watching TV on such small screens, said Gartner. Digital video recorders, like Europe's Sky+ box, and video-on-demand service mean people have much more control over what TV they watch. As a result, people may see broadcasting straight to mobile a taking away that control. More powerful smartphones like the XDA II, Nokia 6600, SonyEricsson P900 and the Orange E200, offering web access, text and multimedia messaging, e-mail, calendar and gaming are becoming increasingly common. A report by analyst InStat/MDR ha predicted that smartphone shipment will grow by 44% over the next five years. It say that smartphones will make up 117 million out of 833 million handset shipped globally by 2009.

Title: Insurance bosses plead guilty
Article: Another three US insurance executive have pleaded guilty to fraud charge stemming from an ongoing investigation into industry malpractice. Two executive from American International Group (AIG) and one from Marsh & McLennan were the latest. The investigation by New York attorney general Eliot Spitzer ha now obtained nine guilty pleas. The highest ranking executive pleading guilty on Tuesday wa former Marsh senior vice president Joshua Bewlay. He admitted one felony count of scheming to defraud and face up to four year in prison. A Marsh spokeswoman said Mr Bewlay wa no longer with the company. Mr Spitzer's investigation of the US insurance industry looked at whether company rigged bid and fixed prices. Last month Marsh agreed to pay $850m (Â£415m) to settle a lawsuit filed by Mr Spitzer, but under the settlement it "neither admits nor denies the allegations".

Title: S Korean consumers spending again
Article: South Korea look set to sustain it revival thanks to renewed private consumption, it central bank says. The country's economy ha suffered from an overhang of personal debt after it consumers' credit card spending spree. Card use fell sharply last year, but is now picking up again with a rise in spending of 14.8% year-on-year. "The economy is now heading upward rather than downward," said central bank governor Park Seung. "The worst seems to have passed." Mr Park's statement came a the bank decided to keep interest rate at an all-time low of 3.25%. It had cut rate in November to help revive the economy, but rising inflation - reaching 0.7% month-on-month in January - ha stopped it from cutting further. Economic growth in 2004 wa about 4.7%, with the central bank predicting 4% growth this year. Other indicator are also suggesting that the country is inching back towards economic health. Exports - traditionally the driver for expansion in Asian economy - grew slower in January than at any time in 17 months. But domestic demand seems to be taking up the slack. Consumer confidence ha bounced back from a four-year low in January, and retail sale were up 2.1% in December. Credit card debt is falling, with only one in 13 of the 48 million card now in default - down from one in eight at the end of 2003. One of it biggest card issuers, LG Card, wa rescued from collapse in December, having almost imploded under the weight of it customers' bad debts. The government last year tightened the rule for card lending to keep the card glut under control.

Title: Real will finish abandoned match
Article: Real Madrid and Real Socieded will play the final six minute of their match, which wa abandoned on Sunday because of a bomb scare. The Bernabeu wa evacuated with the score at 1-1 and two minute of normal time remaining in the game. The team will now play the final two minutes, plus four minute of injury time, on 5 January. Brazilian Ronaldo and England captain David Beckham had to wait in the street in their kit after the abandonment. Real Sociedad president Jose Luis Astiazaran said: "We thought the best thing wa to play the time remaining." Hundreds of fan streamed across the pitch on their way to the exit after the game wa called off. Tourists and fan took advantage of the opportunity for a photograph between the famous stadium's goalposts. The two club met the Spanish FA on Monday and Astiazaran added: "We thought about giving the game a concluded but after talking with the FA we decided there wa no precedent for that and the best thing wa to play the time that wa remaining." Real Madrid director of sport Emilio Butragueno praised the spectator inside the ground for their conduct. "I'd like to highlight the behaviour of the fans, who showed great maturity and it wa an example of good citizenship," he said. Butragueno confirned, before confirming that Tuesday's charity match - which ha been billed a "Ronaldo's friend against Zidane's friends" - will go ahead a planned. "I'd also like to take the chance to say that tomorrow's game will take place," Butragueno declared of the "Partido contra la Pobreza" (Game Against Poverty). He added: "Football is important for society and we want to show that. "We also think that football should be a fiesta, we had programmed and people deserve to enjoy the game."

Title: US blogger fired by her airline
Article: A US airline attendant suspended over "inappropriate images" on her blog - web diary - say she ha been fired. Ellen Simonetti, known a Queen of the Sky, wrote an anonymous semi-fictional account of her life in the sky. She wa suspended by Delta in September. In a statement, she said she wa initiating legal action against the airline for "wrongful termination". A Delta spokesperson confirmed on Wednesday that Ms Simonetti wa no longer an employee. Delta ha repeatedly declined to elaborate on what it call "internal employee matters". A spokesperson reiterated this position on Wednesday, confirming only that Ms Simonetti wa no longer with the company. The spokesperson also confirmed that there were "very clear rules" attached to the unauthorised use of Delta branding, including uniforms. Ms Simonetti announced on her blog she had been fired on 1 November. She said in an official statement: "As a result of my suspension and subsequent termination without cause by Delta Airlines I am moving forward with filing a discrimination complaint with the Federal Government EEOC [US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]." She added she had also hired a Texas-based law firm to initiate legal action for "wrongful termination, defamation of character and lost future wages." Ms Simonetti told the BBC News website she had received no warning or further explanation when she wa suspended on 25 September. Queen of the Sky ha received a lot of support and advice from the global blogging community since news of her suspension wa brought to light on the BBC News website and others. Her story ha highlighted concern amongst the growing blogging community about conflict of interest, employment law and free speech on personal websites. The blog, which she started in January a a way of getting over her mother's death, contains a mix of fictional and non-fictional accounts. Queen of the Sky developed over the month a a character in her own right, according to Ms Simonetti. In the postings, she made up fictional name for city and other company she mentioned to protect anonymity. But some posting contained image of herself in uniform. Of the 10 or so image only one showed Ms Simonetti's flight "wings". She removed them a soon a she wa informed of her suspension. "I never meant it a something to harm my company and don't understand how they think it did harm them," Ms Simonetti said. A legal expert in the US speculated that Delta might be concerned that the fictional content on the blog may be linked back to the airline after the image were posted. Delta ha been hit recently by pressure of rising fuel cost and fierce competition. It ha said it need to cut between 6,000 and 7,000 job and reduce cost by $5bn (Â£2.7bn) a year. Analysts had warned recently that the airline might have to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy prevention. Last week, it struck a $1bn cost-cutting deal with it pilot which could save it from bankruptcy. The deal would see pilot accept a 32% pay cut in return for the right to buy 30 million Delta shares, union said. And on Monday, it negotiated a deal to defer about $135m in debt which wa due next year, until 2007. The airline also said it had agreed the term of a $600m loan from American Express.

Title: Gerrard happy at Anfield
Article: Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard ha reiterated his desire to stay at Anfield and win trophy with the club. The 24-year-old England midfielder is determined to see out his contract, despite reported interest from Chelsea. He said: "I'm signed here for this season and another two so there is no situation. There's a lot of speculation but that's not down to me. "As club captain all I want to do is help u get back up the table and into the Champions League again." Gerrard looked set to move to Chelsea during the summer and speculation of a switch to Stamford Bridge ha again arisen, with the January transfer window approaching. He raised doubt about his Reds future when he said he wanted the club to prove they were title challenger in the very near future or he might leave. Liverpool bos Rafael Benitez ha insisted that Gerrard ha promised him he want to stay at Anfield. Benitez said: "I said to Steven that I wa sure he wanted to stay here and he said 'I do'. "I then said to him 'Look, if you want to win titles, you want medal and you want Liverpool to have these thing then I am going to need your help'. "I really think he want to stay so now what we must do is make the squad stronger for him." Meanwhile, Gerrard ha urged the Anfield board to sign Real Madrid striker Fernando Morientes in the January transfer window. Morientes, 28, ha already expressed a willingness to come to England. Gerrard added: "He's a great player. He score goal in the league, in cup competition and also in the Champions League. "I don't think he'd be able to play for u in Europe this season but if we are able to get hold of him, we'd be getting ourselves a great player. "He'd have Spanish coaches, a Spanish manager and we have got three or four Spanish player here now so they'll help him settle in. "Rafael Benitez know what he want and he know how to strengthen the squad he's got and if the right player become available at the right price I am sure we will strengthen. "It would certainly be nice to see a few new face in January to freshen thing up."

Title: Jamieson issues warning to bigots
Article: Scotland's justice minister ha warned bigoted soccer fan that she want to hit them "where it hurt most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson said exclusion order are one of a series of measure being considered in the Scottish Executive campaign against sectarianism. She praised Celtic and Rangers for their work in tackling the problem. However, the minister said stopping sectarian abuse associated with Old Firm match is a key objective. Ms Jamieson wa speaking ahead of the third round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow club at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long associated with section of the support from both club ha become a significant target for the executive. Last week Ms Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met supporters' representative from both club to discus the issue. They plan to hold an anti-sectarian summit next month with official from the clubs, church leaders, senior police officer and local authority chief among those to be invited. Speaking on BBC Radio Scotland's Sunday Live programme, Ms Jamieson described Friday's meeting a "very productive" and said putting the squeeze on the bigot would be a key aim. Ms Jamieson stressed that sectarianism ha not been confined to football but it can act a a "trigger" for tension and violence. Clubs have taken action in the past to ban troublesome fan and supporters' group expressed their desire to ensure that the game is no longer tainted by the problem. Ms Jamieson said the executive should have a role in tackling the soccer troublemakers. She said: "We can't get away from the fact that in some instance some of the religious hatred that some people try to associate with football boil over into violence. "That is the kind of thing we want to stop and that's the kind of thing supporters' group are very clear they don't want to be part of either, and they will work with u to try and deal with that." Ms Jamieson praised the police for their action and said: "The police do want to identify whether there are particular individual who are going over the top and inciting hatred or violence - they will crack down very effectively on them. "We have of course already indicated that we will consider the introduction of banning order to give additional power to where there are people who are going over the top, who have made inappropriate behaviour at football matches, to be able to stop them attending the games. "That's the kind of thing that will hit those kind of people where it hurt the most in not allowing them to attend the games," she said. Praising Celtic and Rangers for their efforts, she said: "I don't think there is any doubt that we have seen some positive move from the clubs. "Both Rangers and Celtic football club have been involved in working with the executive to produce, for example, an educational pack for young people."

Title: Rocker Doherty in on-stage fight
Article: Rock singer Pete Doherty ha been involved in a fight with his band's guitarist at their biggest gig to date. Babyshambles played for 5,000 fan at London's Brixton Academy on Tuesday. The former Libertines singer traded blow with guitarist Patrick Walden. They were separated and bundled off stage before returning to end the set. The show wa earlier held up due to audience overcrowding. On Monday Doherty faced blackmail and robbery charge in court, which he denies. He is out on Â£50,000 bail and the judge agreed to extend his 2200 GMT curfew deadline by two hour so he could play the Brixton gig. Babyshambles, which he formed after his acrimonious departure from the Libertines, played a warm-up show at The Garage, north London, on Monday. On Tuesday, Doherty and his three bandmates were introduced to the crowd by Mick Jones, the former Clash guitarist who produced the Libertines' second album. Babyshambles took the stage to a frenzied reception at 2200 GMT, launching into their last single, Killamangiro, which reached number eight in December. But the group had to stop during the next song to persuade fan not to push forward and allow security guard to pull people out of the crush. Doherty appealed to fan to calm down, saying: "There's a few people getting hurt down the front, you've got to move back." The music resumed minute later but after several more songs, the singer appeared to accidentally disconnect Walden's guitar, leading the pair to trade kick and punches. Bouncers stepped in and the band left the stage, but returned after five minute and finished their 50-minute performance with no further trouble. Doherty, 25, had to be home by midnight to observe the curfew, which is one of the condition of his bail. On Monday, the judge agreed to allow him to perform on condition that request for change to his bail term were "not too regular an occurrence". The singer wa arrested with fellow musician Alan Wass on 2 February after an alleged dispute with documentary-maker Max Carlish at a London hotel. They are next due in court on 18 April.

Title: Junk e-mails on relentless rise
Article: Spam traffic is up by 40%, putting the total amount of e-mail that is junk up to an astonishing 90%. The figures, from e-mail management firm Email Systems, will alarm firm attempting to cope with the amount of spam in their in-boxes. While virus traffic ha slowed down, denial of service attack are on the increase according to the firm. Virus mail account for just over 15% of all e-mail traffic analysis by the firm ha found. It is no longer just multi-nationals that are in danger of so-called denial of service attacks, in which website are bombarded by request for information and rendered inaccessible. Email Systems refers to a small UK-based engineering firm, which received a staggering 12 million e-mail in January. The type of spam currently being sent ha subtlety altered in the last few months, according to Email Systems analysis. Half of spam received since Christmas ha been health-related with gambling and porn also on the increase. Scam mails, offering way to make a quick buck, have declined by 40%. "January is clearly a month when consumer are less motivated to purchase financial product or put money into dubious financial opportunities," said Neil Hammerton, managing director of Email Systems. "Spammers seem to have adapted their output to reflect this, focussing instead on medically motivated and pornographic offers, presumably intentionally intended to coincide with what is traditionally considered to be the bleakest month in the calendar," he said.

Title: Civil servants in strike ballot
Article: The UK's biggest civil service union is to ballot it 290,000 member on strike in protest at government plan to extend their pension age to 65. The Public and Commercial Services Union will co-ordinate any action with up to six other public sector unions. Unions have already earmarked 23 March for a one-day strike which could involve up to 1.4 million UK workers. The government say union will be consulted before any change are made to the pension system. PCS leader Mark Serwotka warned there could be further walkout unless there wa a government rethink. "For a government that lecture everyone on choice - choice on public service, choice on this and choice on that - isn't it ironic that they're saying to public sector worker there is no choice," he said. "If you want the pension you were promised when you started you must work for an extra five year - that is working until people drop. "In the 20th century, it's completely unacceptable." BBC correspondent Stephen Cape said the combined union represented "a formidable force" which could embarrass the government in the run-up to the General Election. A stoppage involving civil servants, in particular, could seriously disrupt or close government departments, agency and museums, he said. Opposition to raising the retirement age is "one thing all the union are agreed on", our correspondent added. Unison's 800,000 workers, the Transport and General Workers' Union's 70,000 and Amicus' 20,000 are among those being balloted about a 23 March walkout. Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott held a private meeting with senior union figure on Thursday night. Our correspondent said that he understood no deal had been offered in that meeting but that there wa room for further negotiations. There wa "some possibility" of the strike action being avoided, he added.

Title: Hamm bows out for US
Article: Women's football legend Mia Hamm ha played her final game. Hamm, 32, who officially retired after this year's Athens Olympics, took to the field for the last time to help the US claim a 5-0 win over Mexico. Hamm end her career a the most prolific scorer - male or female - in international football, with 158 goal in 276 game for the US. She wa twice Fifa women's player of the year and won the World Cup in 1991 and 1999 and two Olympic golds. On her retirement, Hamm said: "There are mixed emotions. There are thing in your life that you have had to put on the back-burner and you can focus more time and energy on that now. "I have to see what is out there and not commit to everything at the beginning." The friendly also saw the end of Julie Foudy and Joy Fawcett's US careers. Hamm will now embark on a new life with husband, Chicago Cubs shortstop Nomar Garciaparra, who wa in the stand to watch her final game. He ha just agreed a new deal with the Cubs after joining them in July.

There are thing in your life that you have had to put on the back-burner and you can focus more time and energy on that now. "I have to see what is out there and not commit to everything at the beginning." The friendly also saw the end of Julie Foudy and Joy Fawcett's US careers. Hamm will now embark on a new life with husband, Chicago Cubs shortstop Nomar Garciaparra, who wa in the stands for the final game of her career. He ha just agreed a new deal with the Cubs after joining them in July.

Title: US data sparks inflation worries
Article: Wholesale price in the US rose at the fastest rate in more than six year in January, according to government data. New figure show the Labor Department producer price index (PPI) rose by 0.3% - in line with forecasts. But core producer prices, which exclude food and energy costs, surged by 0.8%, the biggest rise since December 1998, increasing inflationary concerns. In contrast, the University of Michigan barometer of US retail consumer confidence showed a slight dip. The university's index of consumer spending fell to 94.2 in early February from 95.5 in January, which could indicate a fall in retail spending by the US public. The mixed set of data on Friday led to volatile early Wall Street trade, a the Dow Jones, Standard and Poor's 500, and Nasdaq swung between positive and negative territory. The economic figure come on the back of increased fear that the Federal Reserve chairman may be about to raise interest rate in order to stifle any inflationary pressures. The Fed ha been raising interest rate at a gradual pace since June 2004, in an attempt to make sure inflation doe not get out of control. Mr Greenspan told Congress this week that the central bank wa on guard against the possibility that a rebounding economy could trigger stronger inflation pressures. "The PPI would argue for Greenspan to continue to raise rate at a measured pace," said Joe Quinlan, chief market stategist at Bank of America Capital Management. "But this Michigan survey tell you that the consumer might be downshifting a little bit in term of their confidence and their spending; this could be an indication of that." Consumer spending account for 66% of US economic activity and is viewed a a gauge of the health of the economy, which is why the Michigan data is closely observed. However on Friday, it wa overshadowed by the core PPI core figure, which surged 2.7% during the past 12 months, the biggest year-on-year gain in nine years. "The concern is that trader might interpret this big jump in the core PPI a an impetus for the Fed to be more aggressive than a measured move in moving rates," said Paul Cherney, chief market analyst at Standard & Poor's. But Ian Shepherdson, chief US economist at High Frequency Economics, said the PPI report wa "much less alarming" than at first glance. One-time increase in alcohol and tobacco prices, which "are no indication of broad PPI pressure", were responsible for the increase, he said. Prices for auto and truck also jumped in January, but Shepherdson said "it is a good bet these increase won't stick".

Article: Liverpool chief executive Rick Parry insists the club will never sell Steven Gerrard amid report Chelsea will renew their bid to lure him from Anfield. Gerrard reiterated his desire to win trophy with the Reds after his superb Champions League winner on Wednesday. And Parry ha moved to scotch claim that Chelsea could launch a Â£35m bid. "There is no chance of Stevie going in January," said Parry. "That just won't happen. Our intention is that we will never let him go." Gerrard scored a spectacular late goal to give Liverpool a 3-1 win over Olympiakos and book their place in the knockout stages. "Of course he is ambitious but so are we," Parry added.
