Title: Chelsea denied by James heroics
Article: A brave defensive display, led by keeper David James, helped Manchester City hold the leader Chelsea. After a quiet opening, James denied Damien Duff, Jiri Jarosik and Mateja Kezman, while Paul Bosvelt cleared William Gallas' header off the line. Robbie Fowler should have scored for the visitor but sent his header wide. Chelsea had most of the possession in the second half but James kept out Frank Lampard's free-kick and superbly tipped the same player's volley wide. City went into the game with the proud record of being the only domestic team to beat Chelsea this season. And there wa little to alarm them in the first 30 minute a Chelsea - deprived of Arjen Robben and Didier Drogba through injury - struggled to pose much of a threat. Indeed, it wa the visitor who looked likelier to enliven a drab opening played at a lethargic pace. Shaun Wright-Phillips - watched by England bos Sven-Goran Eriksson - showed his customary trickery to burst into the right of the area and deliver a dangerous ball, which wa blocked by John Terry. But Chelsea suddenly stepped up a gear and created a flurry of chances. First, Duff got round Ben Thatcher and blasted in a shot that James parried to Kezman, who turned the ball wide. Soon afterwards, Jarosik found space in the area to powerfully head Lampard's corner goalwards but James tipped the ball over. Chelsea were now looking more like Premiership leader and James kept out Kezman's fierce drive before Bosvelt and James combined to clear Gallas' header from Duff's corner. City broke swiftly up the field and the last chance of a frenetic spell should have resulted in Fowler celebrating his 150th Premiership goal. Wright-Phillips raced down the left and crossed to Fowler but City's lone man up front, left free by Terry's slip, contrived to head wide when it seemed a breakthrough wa certain. The second half started a quietly a the first, although James wa forced to divert a cross from the lively Duff away from Eidur Gudjohnsen's path. There wa a nasty moment for Petr Cech, looking for a ninth straight clean sheet in the league, when a series of ricochet saw Fowler chase a loose ball in the area and collide accidently with the Czech Republic stopper. Another quiet spell followed, which Duff interrupted with a surging run that wa halted illegally on the edge of the penalty area by Bosvelt. Lampard stepped up to blast a shot through the wall and James somehow blocked it with his legs. Another timely challenge, this time from Richard Dunne in time added on, prevented Gudjohnsen from getting in a shot. There wa still time for James to produce a sensational save to tip Lampard's volley round the post. Title: Domain system scam fear
Article: A system to make it easier to create website address using alphabet like Cyrillic could open a back door for scammers, a trade body ha warned. The Internationalised Domain Names system ha been a work in progress for year and ha recently been approved by the Internet Electronic Task Force. But the UK Internet Forum (UKIF) is concerned that the system will let scammer create fake site more easily. The problem lie in the computer code used to represent language. Registering name that look like that of legitimate company but lead user to fake site designed to steal password and credit card detail could become a whole lot easier for determined scammers, say Stephen Dyer, director of UKIF. Domain name are the "real language" address of websites, rather than their internet protocol address, which is a series of numbers. They are used so people can more easily navigate the web. So-called ASCII code are used to represent European language but for other language a hybrid of a system called Unicode is used. So, for example, website PayPal could now be coded using a mixture of the Latin alphabet and the Russian alphabet. The resulting domain a displayed to the user would look identical to the real site a a Russian 'a' look just like an English 'a'. But the computer code would be different, and the site it would lead user to could be a fake. This is more than just a theory. A fake Paypal.com ha already been registered with net domain giant Verisign by someone who ha followed the debate around the Internationalised Domain Name (IDN) system, said Mr Dyer. As the idea wa to prove a point rather than be malicious the fake domain ha now been handed back to Paypal but it set a worrying precedent, Mr Dyer said. "Although the IDN problem is well known in technical circles, the commercial world is totally unaware how easily their website can be faked," said Mr Dyer. "It is important to alert user that there is a new and invisible and almost undetectable way of diverting them to what look like a perfectly genuine site," he added. There are solutions. For instance, browser could spot domain that use mixed character and display them in different colour a a warning to users. Mr Dyer acknowledged that it would be a huge undertaking to update all the world's browsers. Another solution, to introduce IDN-disabled browser could be a case of "throwing out the baby with the bath water," he said. CENTR, the Council of European National Top Level Domain Registries, agrees. "A rush to introduce IDN-disabled browser into the marketplace is an overly-zealous step that will harm public confidence in IDNs - a technology that is desperately needed in the non-English speaking world," the organisation said in a statement.

Title: Box office blow for Alexander
Article: Director Oliver Stone's historical epic Alexander ha failed in it bid to conquer the box office, entering the US film chart at number six. The sword and sandal blockbuster, rumoured to have cost more than $150m (Â£79m) to make, earned just $13.5 (Â£7m) over three day at the US box office. Due to the Thanksgiving holiday, the film opened on Wednesday, bringing it total taking to $21.6m (Â£11.4m). Top of the box office for a second week wa action movie National Treasure. The family adventure, starring Nicolas Cage, took $33.1m (Â£17.m), ahead of animated comedy The Incredibles - now in it fourth week in the chart - which took $24.1m (Â£12.7m). Last week Oliver Stone's film met with scathing review from US critics. The film star Irish actor Colin Farrell a one of history's most celebrated leader - a relentless and arrogant warrior who conquered much of the known world by the age of 25. In particular, it portrayal of Alexander a a bisexual ha met with a hostile reception and the threat of legal action from Greek lawyers. "Though the battle have the blood-and-sinew bravado you expect from Oliver Stone, this three-hour buttnumbathon is hamstrung by a hectoring grandiosity," wrote one reviewer in Rolling Stone magazine. Others poured scorn on Farrell's bleached hair and Angelina Jolie's unwieldy accent, which Variety called "a combination of Mata Hari and Count Dracula" . But novelist Gore Vidal defended the film, saying it wa "barrier-breaking" for it frank depiction of bisexuality. In Sweden last Thursday, to pick up a lifetime achievement award at the Stockholm International Film Festival, Stone expressed the hope that Alexander might be better appreciated in Europe. "One of the reason I am being honoured here is Europeans tend to see me a little differently than they do in the US," said the director behind JFK, Platoon and Born on the Fourth of July. He added Alexander "was not an easy movie, but then I've never made easy movies".

Title: Wales want rugby league training
Article: Wales could follow England's lead by training with a rugby league club. England have already had a three-day session with Leeds Rhinos, and Wales are thought to be interested in a similar clinic with rival St Helens. Saints coach Ian Millward ha given his approval, but if it doe happen it is unlikely to be this season. Saints have a week's training in Portugal next week, while Wales will play England in the opening Six Nations match on 5 February. "We have had an approach from Wales," confirmed a Saints spokesman. "It's in the very early stage but it is something we are giving serious consideration to." St Helens, who are proud of their Welsh connections, are obvious partner for the Welsh Rugby Union, despite a spat in 2001 over the collapse of Kieron Cunningham's proposed Â£500,000 move to union side Swansea. A similar cross-code deal that took Iestyn Harris from Leeds to Cardiff in 2001 did go through, before the talented stand-off returned to the 13-man code with Bradford Bulls. Kel Coslett, who famously moved from Wales to league in the 1960s, is currently Saints' football manager, while Clive Griffiths - Wales' defensive coach - is a former St Helens player and is thought to be the man behind the latest initiative. Scott Gibbs, the former Wales and Lions centre, played for St Helens from 1994-96 and wa in the Challenge Cup-winning team at Wembley in 1996.

Article: Arsenal's Brazilian midfielder Edu ha hit out at the club for stalling over offering him a new contract. Edu's deal expires next summer and he ha been linked with Spanish trio Real Madrid, Barcelona and Valencia. He told BBC Sport: "I'm not sure if I want to stay or not because the club have let the situation go on this far. "If they had really wanted to sign they should have come up with an offer six month before indicating they wanted to sign me and that's made me think." Edu's brother and representative Amadeo Fensao ha previously said that Arsenal's current offer to the midfielder wa well short of what he wa seeking. And Edu, 26, added: "My brother is due to come to London on Thursday. "There is a meeting planned for 6 or 7 January to sort it out with Arsenal. "Now I have a choice to stay or go. I want to sort it out a soon a possible, that's in the best interest of both the club and myself. "I'm going to make my decision after the meeting later this week." Edu is now able to begin negotiation with other club because Fifa regulation allow player to start talk six month before their contract expire. The midfielder, who broke in to the Brazilian national side in 2004, admitted he had been flattered to have been linked with the three Spanish giants. Edu said: "I've just heard story from the news that the Madrid president Florentino Perez, the Valencia people, a well a Barcelona are interested. "That's nice, but I've never talked to them, so I can't say they want me sign 100%." Last month Wenger said he we wa hopeful Edu would sign a new deal and played down suggestion that the lure of a club like Real Madrid would be too strong for Edu. Edu added that he had been encouraged by Wenger's support for him. "I still have a good relationship with Arsene Wenger - he's always said he want me to sign."

Title: Turkey knocks six zeros off lira
Article: Turkey is to relaunch it currency on Saturday, knocking six zero off the lira in the hope of boosting trade and powering it growing economy. The change will see the end of such dizzyingly-high denomination a five million lira - enough for a short taxi ride - and the 20m note, worth $15. These valuation were the product of decade of inflation which, a recently a 2001, wa a high a 70%. Inflation ha since been tamed and economic prospect are improving. The currency - officially to be known a the new lira - will be launched at midnight on 1 January. From that point, the one-million lira note will become the new one-lira coin. The government hope the change will be seen a a promise of growing economic stability a Turkey embarks on the long process of trying to join the European Union. On an everyday level, it is hoped the change will stimulate more international trade and end confusion among foreign investor and Turks alike. "The transition to the new Turkish lira show clearly that our economy ha broken the vicious circle that it wa imprisoned in for long years," said Sureyya Serdengecti, head of the Turkish Central Bank. "The new lira is also the symbol of the stable economy that we dreamed of for long years." The Turkish economy teetered on the brink of collapse in 2001 when the lira plunged in value and two million people lost their jobs. Turkey had to turn to the International Monetary Fund for financial assistance, accepting a $18bn loan in return for pushing through a wide-ranging austerity programme. These tough measure have borne fruit. Inflation fell below 10% earlier this year for the first time in decade while export are up 30% this year. Meanwhile, the economy is expanding at a healthy rate, with 7.9% growth expected in 2004. The government hope that the new currency will cement the country's economic progress, two week after EU leader set a date for the start of Turkey's accession talks. The slimmed-down lira is likely to be widely welcomed by the business community. "The Turkish lira ha been like funny money," Tevfik Aksoy, chief Turkish economist for Deutsche Bank, told Associated Press. "Now at least in cosmetic term it will look like real currency." Title: Web helps collect aid donations
Article: The web is helping aid agency gather resource to help cope with the aftermath of the tsunami disaster. Many people are making donation via website or going online to see how they can get involved with aid efforts. High-profile web portal such a Google, Yahoo, Ebay and Amazon are gathering link that lead people to aid and relief organisations. So many were visiting some aid-related site that some webpage were struggling to cope with the traffic. An umbrella organisation called the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) ha been set up by a coalition of 12 charity and ha been taking many donation via it specially created website. It urged people to go online where possible to help because donation could be processed more quickly than cash donated in other ways, meaning aid could be delivered a quickly a possible. The site ha so far received almost Â£8 million, with more than 11,000 donation being made online every hour. Telco BT stepped in to take over the secure payment on the DEC site and provided extra logistical support for phone and online appeal after it wa initially crippled with online donations. It ha also provided space in London's BT tower for one of the call centre dealing with donations. Some of the web's biggest firm are also helping to channel help by modifying their homepage to include link to aid agency and organisation collecting resources. On it famously sparse homepage Google ha placed a link that lead user to a list of site where donation can be made. Among the 17 organisation listed are Oxfam, Medecins sans Frontieres (Doctors Without Borders) and Network for Good. Many of the site that Google list are also taking online donations. Online retailer Amazon ha put a large message on it start page that let people donate money directly to the American Red Cross that will be used with relief efforts. Auction site eBay is giving a list of site that people can either donate directly to, divert a portion of their profit from anything they sell on eBay to the listed organisation or simply buy item that direct cash to those in the list. Yahoo is proving link direct to charity for those that want to donate. The Auction Drop website is asking people to donate old digital cameras, computer and other gadget they no longer want that can be auction to raise cash for the aid effort. Sadly, the outpouring of goodwill ha also encouraged some conmen to try to cash in. Anti-fraud organisation are warning about e-mail that are starting to circulate which try to convince people to send money directly to them rather than make donation via aid agencies. Those wanting to give cash were urged to use legitimate website of charity and aid agencies.

Title: Microsoft gets the blogging bug
Article: Software giant Microsoft is taking the plunge into the world of blogging. It is launching a test service to allow people to publish blogs, or online journals, called MSN Spaces. Microsoft is trailing behind competitor like Google and AOL, which already offer service which make it easy for people to set up web journals. Blogs, short for web logs, have become a popular way for people to talk about their life and express opinion online. MSN Spaces is free to anyone with a Hotmail or MSN Messenger account. People will be able to choose a layout for the page, upload image and share photo album and music playlists. The service will be supported by banner ads. "This is a simple tool for people to express themselves," said MSN's Blake Irving. This is Microsoft's first foray into blogging, which ha taken off a a web phenomenon in the past year. Competitors like Google already offer free service through it Blogger site, while AOL provides it member with journals. Accurate figure for the number of blog in existence are hard to come by. According to blog analysis firm Technorati, the so-called blogosphere, ha doubled every five and a half month for the last 18 months. It now estimate that the number of blog in existence ha exceeded 4.8 million, although some speculate that less than a quarter are regularly maintained.

Title: Trade gap narrows as exports rise
Article: The UK's trade gap narrowed in November, helped by a 7.5% rise in export outside the European Union. According to the Office for National Statistics, the difference between what the UK exported and imported wa Â£3.1bn ($5.8bn), down from October's Â£3.6bn. Overall UK export - including both good and service - rose by more than 3.2% to Â£24.8bn, although total import rose again to a new record of Â£27.9bn. The deficit for good alone wa Â£4.6bn, down from October's Â£5bn. During November the UK exported Â£16.9bn worth of goods, but imported Â£21.5bn. The cumulative deficit for the first eleven month of 2004 now stand at Â£36.3bn, Â£4.5bn higher than the same period in 2003. November saw an improvement in export level to both the European Union and the rest of the world, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said. EU export rose 2%, fuelled by an increase in sale of chemicals. Non-EU export shot up 7.5%, with growth seen across a range of manufacturing sector including cars, consumer durables and chemicals. The export boost offset a 1% rise in imports. Non-EU import rose 3%, but the growth in good entering the UK from the EU slowed to 0.5%. The UK's deficit with the EU fell to Â£1.9bn from Â£2.1bn, while it non-EU shortfall dropped to Â£2.7bn from Â£2.9bn in October. The country's surplus on trade-in-services remained steady at Â£1.5bn for the fifth month in a row. Paul Dales, UK economist for Capital Economics, said the figure represented an improvement on recent months. However, he stressed that the long-term prognosis for export wa still uncertain. "The figure are a lot better than expected but the trend still remains poor," he said. "There have been some very encouraging sign that the UK export recovery is starting to take hold. But there is a danger that this could be held back by the ongoing weakness of domestic demand on the continent."

Title: US casino 'tricks' face ban in UK
Article: Controversial new UK casino will be banned from using American trick of the trade to ensure they are "socially responsible", it ha been suggested. Culture Secretary Tessa Jowell said proposed super-casinos will be different from their US counterparts. In America, pheromone have reportedly been released from machine to encourage aggressive gambling and clock are often removed from walls. Eight super-casinos are proposed from 2010 if the Gambling Bill becomes law. Ms Jowell said the legislation would ban psychological trickery. She told The Times: "British casino will be quite different to those overseas. "They will have to act in a socially responsible way and will be tightly regulated. "They will be run according to British rule and we'll simply not allow any trick which people are subjected to unawares and which increase the risk of problem gambling." One tactic used in the US is simulating daylight during night-time to lull player into remaining at the table and slot machines. Casinos also frequently offer free food, drink and hotel accommodation to keep punter betting. A spokesman for the British Casino Association, which represents the UK industry, said the government wa trying to allay fear over a "UK Las Vegas". He said the way the licence were being awarded meant UK firm were at a massive disadvantage and foreign company would be certain to win the contracts. "The UK industry is one of the world's most respected," he said. "We have the lowest level of problem gambling in the world. "We certainly don't use pheremones. "The UK gambling industry is being totally frozen in time, and the foreign company will take over."

Title: Global release for Japan hit film
Article: Oscar-winning animator Hayao Miyazaki's latest film, Howl's Moving Castle, is to be released in 50 country around the world, it distributor ha said. Howl's Moving Castle set a Japanese box office record last week, taking 1.5bn yen (Â£7.7m) in it first two days. Miyazaki won an Oscar earlier this year for Spirited Away, Japan's first Academy Award for nearly 50 years. Howl's Moving Castle is based on a children's fantasy novel by UK author Diana Wynne Jones. It tell the story of an 18-year-old woman who age dramatically after falling under a witch's spell. She head to a moving castle kept by Howl, a wizard, and search for a way to become normal again. A spokesman for distributor Toho said the film "has received strong interest from domestic audience and foreign medium and viewer alike". "We have a good feeling about this film. We saw very good viewer response," he added. The film's worldwide release will start in South Korea on 24 December, and France on 12 January.

Title: EU fraud clampdown urged
Article: EU member state are failing to report fraud and irregularity in EU fund on a consistent basis, the UK's public spending watchdog ha said. The National Audit Office said although the latest figure showed reported fraud wa falling, the EU still had no common definition of fraud. It also expressed concern that, for the 10th year, the European Court of Auditors had qualified the EU accounts. The NAO urged the government to push for improvement in reporting fraud. It said member state needed to be more accountable on how money wa spent. The report said: "Member state still do not report fraud and other irregularity to the European Anti-Fraud Office on a consistent basis. "As the court ha now qualified it opinion on the Community account for a decade, it is essential for all the authority involved to contribute to the strengthening of the audit of EU revenue and expenditure and improving accountability for the financial management and use of EU resources." It said there were 922 case of reported fraud or irregularity in EU fund in the UK in 2003, worth Â£38.5m (52m euros), up from 831 case worth Â£35.7m in 2002. At the same time, reported fraud throughout the EU dropped from 10,276 case worth Â£808m to 8,177 case worth Â£644m. Edward Leigh, chairman of the Commons public account committee, said Britain had to set an example when it assumed the EU presidency. "Any fraud in other member state is potentially fraud against the UK taxpayer, given that we are the second largest net contributor to the Community," he said. "Departments responsible for administering EU fund need to make sure that they're doing everything possible to weed out improper spending. "The government must take the opportunity afforded by the UK presidency of the EU to press the Commission and other member state to take an equally robust stance against fraud and irregularity, and raise overall standard of financial management." A spokesman for the European Anti-Fraud Office said the organisation agreed with the NAO's assessment of fraud reporting. "The quality of reporting doe differ from member state to member state, and there is room for improvement," spokesman Jorg Wojahn said. He added that there is generally good co-operation with member state and the anti-fraud office on specific case of fraud, with the statistic studied by NAO providing a "good overview for planning strategic way of detecting fraud".

Title: Pop band Busted to 'take a break'
Article: Chart-topping pop band Busted have confirmed that they plan to "take a break", following rumour that they were on the verge of splitting. A statement from the band's record company Universal said frontman Charlie Simpson planned to spend some time working with his other band, Fightstar. However they said that Busted would "reconvene in due course". The band have had eight top three hits, including four number ones, since they first hit the chart in 2002. Their single include What I Go To School For, Year 3000, Crashed The Wedding, You Said No, and Who's David? The band, which also includes member Matt Jay and James Bourne, made the top ten with their self-titled debut album, a well a the follow-up, A Present For Everyone, in 2003. They won best pop act and best breakthrough act at the 2004 Brit Awards and were nominated for best British group. Most recently they topped the chart with the theme from the live-action film version of Thunderbirds, which wa voted Record Of The Year on the ITV1 show. The band have capitalised on a craze for artist playing catchy pop music with rock overtones. The trio are seen a an alternative to more manufactured artist who are not considered credible musician because they do not write their own song or play their own instruments. However, recent rumour have suggested that Simpson ha been wanting to quit the band to focus on Fightstar. He now plan to take Fightstar on tour.

Title: Snow Patrol feted at Irish awards
Article: Snow Patrol were the big winner in Ireland's top music honours, the Meteor Awards, picking up accolade for best Irish band and album on Thursday. The Belfast-born, Glasgow-based band collected the prize at the ceremony at Dublin's Point Theatre. Westlife won the award for best Irish pop act, voted for by the public, beating former member Brian McFadden. Franz Ferdinand picked up best international band and album while Paddy Casey collected best Irish male. Singer-songwriter Casey beat Brian McFadden and Damien Rice. Juliette Turner wa named best Irish female. In the international categories, Morrissey beat Eminem, Usher and Robbie Williams to best male while PJ Harvey pipped Kylie Minogue, Joss Stone, Anastacia and Natasha Bedingfield to the female crown. The 8,000 fan at the ceremony were treated to performance from US rapper Snoop Dogg, Brian McFadden with Delta Goodrem and The Thrills featuring Rolling Stones star Ronnie Wood. Snow Patrol's success came after a year in which they made a chart breakthrough with their third album Final Straw. "I think a lot of band should go through a wee bit of a kicking before the make a success," singer Gary Lightbody and drummer Jonny Quinn said. "It ha been good for us, but also hard for u over the past six years." Snow Patrol will support U2 on their European tour later this year - but U2 were not nominated for best Irish band and album.

Article: Shares in online auction house eBay fell 9.8% in after-hours trade on Wednesday, after it quarterly profit failed to meet market expectations. Despite seeing net profit rise by 44% to $205.4m (Â£110m) during October to December, from $142m a year earlier, Wall Street had expected more. EBay stock fell to $92.9 in after-hours trade, from a $103.05 end on Nasdaq. EBay's net revenue for the quarter rose to $935.8m from $648.4m, boosted by growth at it PayPal payment service. Excluding special items, eBay's profit wa 33 cent a share, but analyst had expected 34 cents. "I think Wall Street ha gotten a bit ahead of eBay this quarter and for the 2005 year." said Janco Partners analyst Martin Pyykkonen. For 2004 a a whole, eBay earned $778.2m on sale of $3.27bn. EBay president and chief executive Meg Whitman called 2004 an "outstanding success" that generated "tremendous momentum" for 2005. "I'm more confident than ever that the decision and investment we're making today will ensure a bright future for the company and our community of user around the world," she said. EBay now forecast 2005 revenue of $4.2bn to $4.35bn and earnings excluding item of $1.48 to $1.52 per share. Analysts had previously estimated that eBay would achieve 2005 revenue of $4.37bn and earnings of $1.62 per share, excluding items.

Title: Tory candidate quits over remark
Article: A Conservative election challenger is quitting after being quoted a wanting a "period of creative destruction in the public services". Danny Kruger, who also work in the Tory research unit, had been due to take on Tony Blair in Sedgefield. He say his remark last week wa misrepresented but he will not contest the election for fear of damaging the Conservative cause. Tory leader Michael Howard accepted his decision "with regret". Mr Kruger wa quoted in the Guardian newspaper saying: "We plan to introduce a period of creative destruction in the public services." In a statement, the party said the comment had been taken out of context. "He fully support the party's policy on, and approach to, the public services," said the statement. "However, in order to avoid any further misrepresentation of his view and any damage to the Party, he ha decided not to stand in the Sedgefield constituency at the next election." Mr Kruger is continuing in his job at the Tory campaign headquarters. Labour election coordinator Alan Milburn claimed Mr Kruger had exposed the Tory agenda for Â£35bn of cut to public services. Mr Milburn said: "He is not some unknown hopeful fighting an unwinnable seat. He is a man who ha worked at the heart of Conservative policy development... "His claim that the Tories were planning 'a period of creative destruction in the public services' is not a rogue claim. "It is the authentic and shocking voice of the Conservative Party. It reveals the true picture of what they would do."

Title: Rank 'set to sell off film unit'
Article: Leisure group Rank could unveil plan to demerge it film service unit and sell it medium business, report claim. Rank, formerly famous for the Carry On series, will expose the shake-up at the announcement of it result on Friday, the Sunday Telegraph reported. Advisors Goldman Sachs are understood to have valued it demerged Deluxe Film unit at Â£300m, the report added. Speculation of a possible shake-up ha mounted since Rank announced a study into a possible demerger in September. Since Mike Smith's appointment a chief executive in 1999, the group ha focused on fewer business and embarked on a major cost-cutting programme which ha seen it dispose of a number of businesses, including the Odeon cinema chain and the Pinewood studios. The move left the group with three core divisions: gaming, Hard Rock and Deluxe Films, which provides technical service to Hollywood studios. Rank now aim to concentrate on it gaming, bar and hotel business, including extending it Hard Rock brand to it casino - trial of which have been a success. It also owns Deluxe Media, which make and distributes DVDs and videos. However, that business is seen a less successful. Last year it made profit of Â£21.5m on a turnover of Â£392.1m and expert suggest it success in moving to DVDs from VHS video could make it an attractive target for a private equity buyer. A spokesman for the firm refused to comment on the reports, but said any result from the demerger study were likely to be set out when it unveiled it result on Friday. Analysts predict the firm is likely to report a slight drop in annual pre-tax profit to Â£170m from Â£194m last year. Formed in the 1940s the firm wa a leading UK film producer and cinema owner for many years. It ha now diversified into a range of other leisure activity - mainly in the UK - including hotels, roadside service area and holiday centres. It now owns 34 Grosvenor casinos, the Mecca Bingo chain and more than 100 Hard Rock Cafes in 38 countries.

Title: O'Leary agrees new Villa contract
Article: Aston Villa bos David O'Leary signed a three-and-a-half year contract extension on Thursday, securing his future at the club until summer 2008. O'Leary's future wa in question, but Villa chairman Doug Ellis said he wa happy to secure the deal. "David's record since his arrival in 2003 is excellent and he share the board's amibitions in taking this club forward," he told Villa's website. "For this reason it wa important we got this right." O'Leary put pen to paper after deal were sorted for his right-hand men Roy Aitken and Steve McGregor. "It wa important to me Roy and Steve, an integral part of my team, should stay for the same time," O'Leary said on Thursday ahead of signing his new deal. "Someone ha to try and put Aston Villa back where they should belong and I'm up for the challenge."Earlier in December, there were rumour O'Leary would quit if he is not offered a new deal before the end of the season. But he denied that, saying he wa happy to take on the challenge of improving Villa's fortune in the long term. "I want to make sure by the end of the five year I would have been in charge that Villa are achieving top six finish in the Premiership on a regular basis," said O'Leary, who took over at Villa Park in May 2003. "But to achieve that, and take the next step forward, we do need to bring in quality players. "I would like a couple next month if at all possible to set u on the way." Meanwhile, O'Leary ha rapped skipper Olof Mellberg for his comment before Sunday's derby with Birmingham. Mellberg spoke of his dislike of Villa's rival ahead of the match, which Steve Bruce's side won 2-1. "I've had more than a quiet word with Olof. It's been said within the whole group, not a a one-to-one," he told Villa's website. "You shouldn't leave yourself open to be shot down. You shouldn't give people the chance to take cheap shot at you and he set himself up for that."

Title: Broadband steams ahead in the US
Article: More and more Americans are joining the internet's fast lane, according to official figures. The number of people and business connected to broadband jumped by 38% in a year, said the US Federal Communications Commission (FCC). In a report, it said there were more than 32 million broadband connection by the end of June 2004. But the US is still behind compared to other nations, ranked 13th in the world by a UN telecom body. During his 2004 re-election campaign, President George W Bush pledge to ensure that affordable high-speed net access would be available to all Americans by 2007. According to the report by the FCC, broadband is becoming increasingly popular, with people using it for research and shopping, a well a downloading music and watching video. The total number of people and business on broadband rose by to 32.5 million in the year ending June 2004, compared to 23.5 million in June 2003. Whereas in the UK, most people hook up to broadband via Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line (ADSL) technology which let ordinary copper phone line support high data speeds. But in the US, cable lead the way, accounting for 18.6 million lines. Broadband over the phone line make up 11.4 million connections, according to the FCC figures.

Title: Wilkinson to miss Ireland match
Article: England will have to take on Ireland in the Six Nations without captain and goal-kicker Jonny Wilkinson, according to his Newcastle bos Rob Andrew. Wilkinson - who had targeted the 27 February match for his international comeback - ha been missed by England, not least for his goal-kicking. "Jonny's not fit yet," Falcons chief Andrew told BBC Radio Five Live. "He won't be fit for Dublin, there's no doubt about that, but he might be fit for Scotland and Italy." The 25-year-old ha not played for England since the 2003 World Cup final after a succession of injuries. England, who have lost three Six Nations game in a row, wasted a 17-6 half-time lead in their 18-17 defeat to France. Goal-kickers Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley missed six penalty attempt and a drop-goal between them. "They've probably got two of the best English kicker in the Premiership in Hodgson and Barkley," added Andrew, a former England fly-half and goal-kicker. "They're both pretty good kickers. Charlie is a good kicker week-in, week-out. "But it's all about pressure and unfortunately England are just not handling the pressure at the moment." Andrew also blamed England's poor run of recent result on a lack of leadership in the side following several high-profile retirement and injuries. "They just didn't have that leadership that would have seen them through. Martin Johnson, Lawrence Dallaglio and Jonny are obviously huge loss and leadership is so important in those situations," he said. "I think it is really difficult for Jason Robinson to lead the side effectively from full-back." Meanwhile, former England full-back Dusty Hare put England's mistake down to a lack of mental toughness. "Jonny Wilkinson ha proved himself a cool customer with around an 80% kicking success rate," Hare told BBC Radio Five Live. "But natural-born toughness come into it a well a all the practice you do. "You have to be able to shut out all the outside element and concentrate on putting the ball between the posts." Hodgson, who ha an excellent kicking record with club side Sale Sharks, ha introduced crowd noise into his practice routine of late. "The top golfer don't hit the fairway every time, and it is the same with goal-kicking," Hare added. "You need that mental toughness a well to put the ball over, but great goal-kickers like Jonny Wilkinson come along very rarely."

Title: Microsoft releases patches
Article: Microsoft ha warned PC user to update their system with the latest security fix for flaw in Windows programs. In it monthly security bulletin, it flagged up eight "critical" security hole which could leave PCs open to attack if left unpatched. The number of hole considered "critical" is more than usual. They affect Windows programs, including Internet Explorer (IE), medium player and instant messaging. Four other important fix were also released. These were considered to be less critical, however. If not updated, either automatically or manually, PC user running the program could be vulnerable to virus or other malicious attack designed to exploit the holes. Many of the flaw could be used by virus writer to take over computer remotely, install programs, change, and delete or see data. One of the critical patch Microsoft ha made available is an important one that fix some IE flaws. Stephen Toulouse, a Microsoft security manager, said the flaw were known about, and although the firm had not seen any attack exploiting the flaw, he did not rule them out. Often, when a critical flaw is announced, spate of virus follow because home user and business leave the flaw unpatched. A further patch fix a hole in Media Player, Windows Messenger and MSN Messenger which an attacker could use to take control of unprotected machine through .png files. Microsoft announces any vulnerability in it software every month. The most important one are those which are classed a "critical". Its latest release came the week that the company announced it wa to buy security software maker Sybari Software a part of Microsoft's plan to make it own security programs.

Title: Ban on forced retirement under 65
Article: Employers will no longer be able to force worker to retire before 65, unless they can justify it. The government ha announced that firm will be barred from 2006 from imposing arbitrary retirement ages. Under new European age discrimination rules, a default retirement age of 65 will be introduced. Workers will be permitted to request staying on beyond this compulsory retirement age, although employer will have the right to refuse. Trade and Industry Secretary Patricia Hewitt said people would not be forced to work longer than they wanted, saying the default age wa not a statutory, compulsory retirement age. She said employer would be free to continue employing people for a long a they were competent. Under age discrimination proposal from the Department of Trade and Industry last year worker were to be allowed to work on till 70 if they wished. Business leader had opposed the plan a they said it would be too costly and cumbersome. The British Chambers of Commerce welcomed the latest proposal. "This move today is the best of both worlds," it said. "Employers have the ability to define the end point of the employer-employee relationship and employee have flexibility with a right to request to work past the age of 65." But Age Concern said imposing a retirement age of 65 wa "cowardly" and a "complete u-turn". "This make a mockery of the Government's so-called commitment to outlawing ageism, leaving the incoming age discrimination law to unravel," said Gordon Lishman, director general of Age Concern England . "It is now inevitable that older people will mount legal challenge to the decision using European law." The decision will have no impact on the age at which worker can collect their state pension, the government ha said.
